site_title: Cascadale condo in Changi relaunched for en bloc sale at unchanged S$270m price
summary: The owners of Cascadale condominium in Changi, Singapore, are relaunching an en bloc sale at the same reserve price of S$270 million. The 134-unit freehold property will benefit from owners receiving between S$1.4 million and S$4 million each if the sale is successful. The site has a gross plot ratio of 1.6 and an allowable building height of up to 12 storeys, with plans for redevelopment into a condominium project with up to 292 units. The property's proximity to the airport and business park makes it attractive for redevelopment into serviced residences.

site_title: HDB resale flat prices rise 0.1% in Q3: Flash estimates
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore rose 0.1% in Q3, according to flash estimates, with the resale price index at 130.9. The final figures will be released on October 25.

site_title: Australian PM Morrison told Trump he was ready to assist with probe
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison told US President Donald Trump he was willing to assist with a Justice Department probe amid reports Trump sought his help to discredit the Mueller investigation. Morrison confirmed his readiness to cooperate during a telephone call, as reported by The New York Times. The inquiry, led by Attorney General William Barr, aims to gather information to shed light on matters under investigation.

site_title: Singapore businesses adjust to 'new normal' of sustained cyberattacks: poll
summary: Singapore businesses are adjusting to a "new normal" of sustained and sophisticated cyberattacks, with 96% of organisations suffering a breach in the last 12 months. Ransomware attacks target end users, causing financial damage and reputational harm. Despite this, 84.5% of businesses feel more confident in their ability to repel attacks, with 95% strengthening their defences through threat hunting. 99% plan to increase their cybersecurity budget in the next 12 months, but 67% face hiring difficulties for specialist IT staff.

site_title: Twitter lets users sideline unwanted direct messages
summary: Twitter is rolling out a filter to hide unwanted direct messages from people users don't follow, aiming to reduce abuse and vitriol on the platform. The filter, available on iOS, Android, and web, will automatically route such messages to a secondary folder and tag them for users to decide whether to open. The move follows Twitter's introduction of a reply filter earlier this year and seeks to give users more control over online conversations.

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit Metroline sells London bus garage for £25m, buys property for £7m
summary: METROLINE, a UK subsidiary of ComfortDelGro, has agreed to sell a London bus garage for £25m and buy an industrial property for £7m. The bus garage, located in west London, has a net book value of £4.7m, with the sale exceeding this value by £16.5m. The industrial property, also in west London, will be funded by internal resources. Both transactions are expected to complete before October 2021 and are not expected to impact ComfortDelGro's financials for the current year.

site_title: Australia's central bank cuts rates to new record low
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, cut interest rates to a new record low of 0.75% for the third time this year, amid concerns over a flagging domestic economy. The decision aims to extend a record 28-year recession-free streak. The move comes after the economy recorded its weakest annual growth in a decade, expanding just 1.4% in the year to June. The central bank's efforts aim to address stagnant employment levels, low wage growth, and high household debt.

site_title: Australia stocks climb after central bank cuts interest rates
summary: Australia's central bank cuts interest rates for a third time this year, aiming to stimulate the sluggish economy. The Reserve Bank of Australia lowered rates, sending the S&P/ASX 200 index 0.8% higher. Real estate stocks and consumer-focused companies rose, while export-driven healthcare and airline sectors also gained. The rate cut boosts home prices and weakens the local currency.

site_title: Payment delays improve for retail but worsen for manufacturing, services, wholesale sectors
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw the largest increase in slow payments among the five sectors in Q3, with slow payments making up more than one-third of total payment transactions. The retail sector posted a Q-o-q drop in slow payments, while the services and wholesale trade sectors also experienced quarter-on-quarter declines. Prompt payments accounted for less than half of total payment transactions, highlighting weak payment performance overall.

site_title: Asia: Tokyo leads market gains in holiday trade
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Tokyo leading gains, driven by a drop in the yen and US investors shrugging off a survey showing falling Japanese business confidence. US restrictions on Chinese investment were denied, boosting buyer sentiment. Taipei and Singapore jumped 1.0%, while Wellington and Seoul also saw gains. Markets await the resumption of talks between Beijing and Washington this month, which are seen as a positive for the markets. Oil prices fell sharply on Monday, but Brent crude remained down while West Texas Intermediate rose 0.5%.

site_title: Other white knights waiting in the wings, says Hyflux's lawyer
summary: Hyflux, a debt-laden water-treatment firm, applied to the court for a sixth extension of time to secure a rescue deal. The company is close to sealing a deal with Utico, a Middle Eastern utility company, which would take an 88% stake in Hyflux with an investment of $300 million. However, Utico's position is uncertain due to sticking points in the deal, and Hyflux's lawyer assured the court that other investors are ready to invest in the company. A two-month extension was granted until December 2, and talks with Utico are expected to continue despite disagreements over the total scheme consideration.

images.alt_text: Middle Eastern utility company Utico has regularly declared that it is locked, loaded and ready to go to the rescue of Hyflux, but court testimony on Monday suggested that the outcome may not be so clear.

site_title: Singapore shares rally on Tuesday morning with STI up more than 1%
summary: Singapore shares surged more than 1% on Tuesday morning, tracking Wall Street gains, as investors looked ahead to US-China trade talks. The Straits Times Index rose 31.72 points to 3,151.71, driven by a positive overnight performance from US stocks, including a 2.4% gain from Apple. The rally comes ahead of US GDP data and amid ongoing US-China trade uncertainty, with investors optimistic about the resumption of talks between Beijing and Washington.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares rallied on Tuesday morning in line with the rest of Asia tracking Wall Street gains overnight, as investors looked ahead to the resumption of talks between Beijing and Washington.

site_title: Bank of Japan will decide monetary policy appropriately: Minister
summary: Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura stated that the Bank of Japan will decide on monetary policy appropriately, taking into consideration the economic situation. The government will closely monitor potential downside risks from overseas, including the impact of a sales tax hike to 10% from 8%. This follows the implementation of the sales tax hike on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura said on Tuesday that he believe the Bank of Japan will decide monetary policy appropriately.

site_title: China's Sept PMIs up on domestic demand, no rebound yet
summary: China's manufacturing sector saw a slight improvement in September, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 49.8, up from 49.5 in August. A private survey showed a PMI of 51.4, the fastest pace of growth in 19 months. However, challenges persist, including the ongoing trade war and persistent slowdown, with factory output and car sales continuing to decline. Analysts expect further stimulus measures and a slowdown in growth rates, with the impact of tariffs still to be fully felt.

site_title: Japan proceeds with twice-delayed sales tax hike as growth sputters
summary: Japan has implemented a twice-delayed 2% increase in sales tax to 10% from 8%, aiming to fix its finances but risking a recession due to dampened consumer sentiment. The move follows concerns from the last 2014 tax hike, which led to a severe economic downturn. The government has introduced measures to mitigate the impact, including exemptions for low-income households and discounts. However, economists warn that consumer sentiment may deteriorate, dampening economic activity. The government is prepared to deploy additional measures if needed.

images.alt_text: Japan rolled out a twice-delayed increase in the sales tax to 10 per cent from 8 per cent on Tuesday, a move that is seen as critical for fixing the country's tattered finances but that could tip the economy into recession by dampening consumer sentiment.

site_title: Japan curbing export of key chipmaking material, South Korea says
summary: Japan is delaying export approval of liquid hydrogen fluoride, a key material for South Korea's semiconductor manufacturing industry, despite 90 days of review. Japan has not approved a single export request since the 90-day window, citing a need for additional documents. This move is part of Japan's export restrictions, which have been approved in a "highly restrictive manner" for other materials. The trade dispute between Japan and South Korea shows no signs of abating, further straining bilateral relations.

site_title: DBS partners taxman to digitise S$4.6b stamp duty collection in Singapore
summary: DBS is partnering with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) to digitize the S$4.6 billion stamp duty collection process, aiming to encourage businesses to make digital payments. From November, taxpayers will be able to set a GIRO account online to make payments, allowing for instant receipt of a stamp certificate. This move is part of Iras' digitalisation drive and aims to reduce cheque volumes, with DBS holding a significant market share in PayNow Corporate registrations. The partnership is expected to encourage more businesses, especially SMEs, to adopt digital payments.

site_title: Indonesia faces urgent call to quell discontent
summary: Indonesia faces a growing crisis as President Joko Widodo faces criticism from students, middle- and lower-income classes, and civil society over his economic policies and legislative actions. The government's hike in national health insurance premiums and electricity prices, as well as its disempowerment of the Corruption Eradication Commission, have sparked widespread protests. The president's silence on the issue has fueled the unrest, with demonstrators demanding the rescission of a draft law to revise the Criminal Code that could outlaw sex before marriage. The situation is further complicated by growing civil unrest in Papua and Indonesia's increasingly cozy diplomatic relationship with China.

site_title: No Signboard names Lok Pei San as group CFO after Voon Sze Yin quits
summary: No Signboard has appointed Lok Pei San as group CFO, following Voon Sze Yin's resignation. Lok, 40, is a chartered accountant with the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants and previously held roles at Zuellig Pharma Holdings and dnata Singapore.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.42% to 3,133.02
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.42% to 3,133.02 on Tuesday, following positive US and European markets. The Straits Times Index gained 13.03 points, driven by gains from financials, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, as well as Y Ventures and Rex International. The rally came ahead of GDP data, with analysts citing better-than-expected Chinese manufacturing data and downplayed US restrictions on Chinese investment.

site_title: China celebrates 70 years as Hong Kong seethes
summary: China celebrated 70 years of Communist Party rule with a massive military parade in Beijing, with President Xi Jinping declaring "no force" can shake the nation. The event overshadowed protests in Hong Kong, where pro-democracy demonstrators clashed with police. Xi vowed to maintain stability and protect Hong Kong's freedoms, while also pushing for reunification with Taiwan. The parade showcased China's military modernization and highlighted the party's determination to protect its interests, amid ongoing challenges from the US trade war and African swine fever.

site_title: Trade conflicts cost German exporters 30b euros in lost growth: Die Welt
summary: German exporters are expected to lose 30 billion euros (S$45.2 billion) in growth this year due to the ongoing trade war between China and the US, according to a report by the German Chambers of Commerce. The uncertainty and added bureaucracy from global trade tensions, as well as Britain's expected departure from the EU, are also affecting the economy. The report cites a record 1.34 million certificates of origin issued this year, highlighting the time-consuming process for exporters. The impact of these factors is set to result in nearly all export growth being wiped out this year.

site_title: WeWork IPO is withdrawn as investors grow wary
summary: WeWork has withdrawn its initial public offering (IPO) plans, citing investor wariness. The company had aimed to raise up to $4 billion, but growth concerns and huge losses have led investors to pull back. WeWork's expansion is expected to slow, with analysts estimating the company could run out of cash by mid-2020. The IPO withdrawal comes as investors increasingly scrutinize ambitious young companies with high growth rates and significant losses.

site_title: Nippon Life eyes India asset management growth with ESG products
summary: Nippon Life Insurance Co, Japan's largest life insurer, has completed a deal to raise its stake in Reliance Nippon Life Asset Management Co to 75% in India. The move aims to broaden product offerings and outpace the local industry's rapid growth. The deal was made after Reliance Group sold its interest to help meet debt obligations. Nippon Life's move is seen as a strategic expansion into the Indian asset management market, driven by increasing demand for environmentally and socially responsible investments.

site_title: Zimbabwe bans mobile cash payouts in bid to tackle cash crunch
summary: Zimbabwe's central bank has banned mobile cash payouts in an effort to address a chronic cash shortage, amid a surge in prices and economic crisis. The ban, effective immediately, aims to curb exorbitant commission fees charged by mobile money operators, which have distorted pricing and exacerbated the cash crisis. The move follows warnings from the IMF and an independent economist that the country's economy is on the brink of hyperinflation. The ban will restrict people's ability to use mobile money for cash transactions, forcing them to rely on traditional banking services.

site_title: Who will succeed Mark Carney? Brexit brings uncertainty to BOE
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is searching for a new governor to succeed Mark Carney, who will leave on January 31. The role comes with significant challenges, including targeting inflation, regulating banks, and responding to the economic fallout from Brexit. The appointment process is entangled in the UK's ongoing Brexit negotiations, with the current prime minister, Boris Johnson, holding significant influence. The next governor will face pressure to support the economy, which has been weakened by Brexit uncertainty, and will need to be a skilled communicator to navigate the complex situation.

site_title: Repsol paying up to US$46.5m for 40% stake in United Global unit
summary: Repsol, a global energy company, has acquired a 40% stake in United Global's United Oil Company Pte Ltd for up to US$46.5 million. The initial cash consideration is US$36.5 million, with a further US$10 million payable based on revenue targets for FY2023. This marks Repsol's first foray into South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: United Global CEO Jacky Tan and Repsol commercial businesses and chemicals executive MD Maria Victoria Zingoni at the signing ceremony for the deal.

site_title: Trump asked Australian PM to help discredit Mueller: NYTimes
summary: President Donald Trump asked Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison to help US Attorney General Bill Barr gather information to discredit the Mueller investigation, according to The New York Times. The request was made during a telephone call, and the White House restricted access to the transcript. This move comes amid an inquiry into the origins of the Mueller probe, which Trump has repeatedly described as a "political witch hunt." The original FBI probe into Russian meddling was launched after Australian officials tipped off the bureau, and Trump's call to Morrison may be seen as an attempt to enlist foreign assistance in discrediting the investigation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as yen falls
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, driven by an easing in US-China trade tensions and the yen's decline. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.59% to 21,885.24, while the Topix gained 0.96%. US comments denying potential new restrictions on Chinese investment boosted investor sentiment. The yen fell to 108.24 yen against the US dollar, supporting Japanese exporters. Despite a Japanese business confidence survey showing a decline, investors are looking ahead to resuming talks between Beijing and Washington in early October.

site_title: Leveraging Asean's diversity
summary: Asean, comprising 10 vastly different member states, presents both challenges and opportunities for businesses looking to expand abroad. The region's varying development stages, unique sector strengths, and growing economies offer opportunities for companies to serve local populations and businesses. Singapore businesses should consider leveraging these opportunities by partnering with local players, embracing digital platforms, and adapting to country-specific differences. Despite recent economic downturn concerns, Asean's position has changed since the last financial crisis, and the region has bolstered its domestic economies to brace against future recessions. Companies can take steps to derisk their expansion plans by partnering with local experts and embracing new markets.

site_title: China Sunsine Chemical calls for trading halt
summary: China Sunsine Chemical requested a trading halt on Tuesday pending an announcement, with shares up 0.9% to S$1.09. The company proposed a share split of every ordinary share to two, aiming to improve liquidity and broaden its shareholder base. The proposal, which would issue an additional 491.7 million shares, must be approved by the Singapore Exchange and shareholders. China Sunsine also appointed Yan Tangfeng as an independent director, responsible for investment management and business operations.

site_title: Impeachment is a journey into the political unknown
summary: US Democrats, led by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, have launched impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump, despite uncertainty about the outcome. This move is comparable to a battle with no clear victory, as seen in previous attempts to impeach a sitting president. The process is fraught with risk, as evidenced by the acquittal of Presidents Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton, and the consequences faced by Republican Speaker Newt Gingrich. With public opinion divided, the journey ahead is uncertain, but constitutional crises can create momentum, potentially changing public opinion and leading to a resolution.

images.alt_text: Protesters at the US Capitol building during the People's Rally for Impeachment on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC on Sept 26. At this stage, it does seem that while more Americans are now supporting impeaching the president, the country remains divided over the issue.

site_title: China at 70: Much to celebrate but with geopolitical clouds to watch
summary: China is celebrating its 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China with a military parade in Beijing. The event marks a significant milestone for the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), which has outlasted the Soviet Union's existence by a year. The parade will feature new military hardware, including the Dongfeng-41 intercontinental ballistic missile, and serves as a reminder of the country's tumultuous past under Mao Zedong. Despite its challenges, China has transformed into the world's second-largest economy under Deng Xiaoping's leadership.

site_title: Women-led non-profit raises S$50,000 for Nepal's underprivileged
summary: A Singapore-based non-profit, Taking Heart, raised S$50,000 for Nepal's underprivileged at its annual gala dinner. The funds will support the construction of rice-bag homes and skills training for families. Every S$6,500 raised provides a family with a new rice-bag home. The initiative aims to improve the lives of impoverished families in Nepal through sustainable and community-driven projects.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Markets closed for public holiday on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong markets are closed on Tuesday for a public holiday. No specific stock market events or news are mentioned in this article.

site_title: 4 startups picked to pioneer BlueChilli's healthtech accelerator in Singapore
summary: Four startups, Safe Space, Advanx Health, Xenomites, and Reemedy, have been selected to participate in BlueChilli's healthtech accelerator program in Singapore. The program aims to tackle regional health issues such as mental health, chronic diseases, and preventive care. The startups will have access to BlueChilli's venture studio for product advancement, customer base expansion, investment securing, and team expansion. This move is part of a growing healthtech funding landscape in South-east Asia, with 2019 seeing a threefold increase in healthtech deals worth US$189 million.

site_title: Marubeni is said to sound out potential buyers for Gavilon
summary: Marubeni Corp, a Japanese general trading company, has reportedly sounded out two potential buyers for its US grains unit Gavilon Group LLC. The talks are preliminary and no decision has been made. Marubeni initially denied the report, stating it is not considering selling Gavilon and will continue to position it as a core business.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, CMT, ComfortDelGro, Prudential, Frasers Property
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading on Tuesday. Keppel Reit sold Bugis Junction Towers for S$547.5 million, while CapitaLand Mall Trust secured a S$200 million green loan. ComfortDelGro Corporation agreed to sell a UK bus garage and purchase an industrial property. Prudential's Eastspring Investments acquired 50.1% of Thanachart Fund Management Co for S$190.3 million. Frasers Property appointed Reini Otter as CEO, and Sunpower Group won a manufacturing tender from Sinopec. Other companies, including BreadTalk Group, No Signboard, and Star Pharmaceutical, also made announcements.

site_title: Forever 21 closing stores in bankruptcy filing shows limits to fast fashion
summary: Forever 21, a fast-fashion retailer, filed for bankruptcy, joining a growing list of brick-and-mortar companies struggling with sales hit by online competition and changing fashion trends. The company plans to close up to 178 US stores and focus on its profitable core operations. Forever 21's low prices and large stores may be contributing factors to its financial trouble, with younger, more environmentally conscious shoppers choosing brands that ethically source garments. The retailer has requested court approval to restructure and has received $275 million in financing from existing lenders.

site_title: South Korea consumer prices fall for first time as export woes persist
summary: South Korea's consumer prices fell 0.4% in September for the first time, reflecting the economic impact of the US-China trade war and a slowdown in Chinese demand. The country's economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace since the global financial crisis this year. This decline in consumer prices underscores the domestic demand hit, as exports continue to be affected by the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up ahead of anticipated central bank rate cut
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,7000, driven by consumer discretionary and real estate stocks, amid anticipation of a central bank rate cut. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to announce its decision on Tuesday. However, some investors doubt the rate cut's impact, with concerns about the global economy's health. Real estate stocks, including Wesfarmers and Boral, jumped 1.3% and 1.5% respectively, while gold stocks declined amid a stronger US dollar.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen drops
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by easing US-China trade tensions and the yen's drop. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.36% to 21,834.39, while the Topix index climbed 0.50% to 1,595.73. Investors shrugged off a Japanese survey showing falling business confidence. The positive market trend was seen as a sign of investors' optimism despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: 'Jail them!': Brexit divisions rise on fringes of UK Tory meet
summary: Tensions within the UK Conservative party over Brexit reached a boiling point at its conference in Manchester, with some lawmakers calling for criminal action against those who voted against Prime Minister Boris Johnson's strategy. Shouts of "jail them!" were heard, but leading eurosceptic Steve Baker urged restraint. The incident highlights the deep divisions within the party, with tensions running high despite an otherwise largely disciplined conference.

site_title: WeWork landlords in London, NY bracing for a market fallout
summary: WeWork's landlords in London and New York are bracing for a potential market fallout due to the company's declining valuation and uncertain future. WeWork has a significant presence in both cities, with 7.2 million square feet in Manhattan and 3.7 million square feet in London. However, doubts about WeWork's future have led to job cuts, pending deal cancellations, and a decrease in valuation. London landlords may be particularly affected, with some having clauses in their leases that would allow them to operate WeWork's space independently.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds were quoted. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's tariff on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology and OCBC reported concerns over revenue and operating losses. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case, and Singapore's stocks saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: UK PM Johnson asks EU to block Brexit delay: The Times
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is asking the European Union to block further delay of Brexit, set for October 31, according to The Times. If Johnson fails to seek a delay, senior British judges are planning an emergency legal challenge. This comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row, adding to pressure on opposition leader Keir Starmer. Johnson's Brexit request follows a string of economic indicators showing a deteriorating UK economy.

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile quarter on positive note; oil prices slide
summary: US stocks ended a volatile quarter on a positive note, with the S&P 500 rising 0.5% for the session and 1.2% for the quarter. Oil prices slid amid reports that Saudi Arabia restored oil production following attacks on its infrastructure. Analysts cited better-than-expected Chinese manufacturing data and downplayed potential US restrictions on Chinese investment. The US-China trade conflict continues to weigh on growth, but a recession remains unlikely within the next 12 months.

site_title: HK flight attendants urge Cathay to explain layoffs
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd has faced criticism from flight attendants in Hong Kong for layoffs, with 32 employees, including pilots, terminated without valid grounds. The Hong Kong Cabin Crew Federation claims the airline monitored employees' social media accounts and obtained "dubious" information from whistle-blowers. Cathay Pacific reiterated its compliance with regulations, stating it cannot comment on individual cases. The unions are calling for transparency in investigations and an end to firing employees based on private social media activities.

site_title: Boustead Projects JV to buy IBM's Tampines technology park property for S$77.4m
summary: Boustead Projects Limited's joint venture company, BP-TPM LLP, is purchasing IBM's Tampines technology park property for SGD 77.4 million. The three-storey building, completed in 2010, has a gross floor area of 430,999 square feet and is currently leased by IBM for a 30-year period. The deal aims to generate long-term leasing income, with Boustead contributing SGD 14.2 million from equity. The purchase is part of Boustead Development Partnership's co-investment strategy.

site_title: Hong Kong defies China anniversary with 'Day of Grief' rallies
summary: Hong Kong marked the 70th anniversary of China's founding with "Day of Grief" protests, defying a police ban. Thousands of protesters marched through Causeway Bay, chanting slogans and ignoring authorities' warnings. The protests, which began in June, are demanding greater democratic freedoms and police accountability. The demonstrations, which have seen clashes with police, aim to overshadow Beijing's anniversary celebrations and pressure the Hong Kong government to meet protesters' demands. The protests have been ongoing for nearly four months, with protesters calling for an inquiry into the police, amnesty for arrested protesters, and universal suffrage.

site_title: Card power
summary: High-net-worth individuals can access exclusive credit card benefits, including concierge services, air miles, and luxury perks like spa and club access. These luxe cards, such as the Amex Centurion, DBS Insignia, and OCBC VOYAGE, offer bespoke services and high-end benefits. With annual fees ranging from over $7,000 to $5 million, these cards cater to the wealthy elite, with 187,000 millionaires in Singapore expected to grow to 239,000 by 2030. Banks report high usage and spending among luxe cardmembers, with some cards experiencing over 45% growth in overall billings.

site_title: PwC Singapore to spend almost S$10m on staff digital upskilling over next 2 years
summary: PwC Singapore is investing nearly S$10 million over two years to upskill its 3,500 employees in digital skills, including data visualization, analytics, and automation. The program includes customized training plans, e-learning platforms, and technology collaboration tools. This initiative is part of PwC's global upskilling commitment of US$3 billion over four years, aimed at addressing the growing mismatch between skills and the digital world.

site_title: State Dept continues probe into e-mail use by Hillary Clinton's staff
summary: The US State Department is continuing an investigation into email use by Hillary Clinton's staff, specifically examining whether employees used secure channels and proper classification designations for routine emails that have been retroactively marked as classified. The inquiry involves interviewing current and former officials, with around 130 officials contacted in recent weeks. This renewed focus on the emails, which were sent to Clinton while she was secretary of state from 2009 to 2013, is unusual, as it scrutinizes employees over handling of information that was not classified at the time.

site_title: Beijing: A US delisting of China firms will shake global markets
summary: The US is considering delisting Chinese companies from US stock exchanges, sparking global market instability. China has warned of potential economic and financial turmoil, while US President Trump's administration cites growing security concerns. The move is part of a broader effort to limit US investment in Chinese companies, and comes ahead of celebrations in Beijing marking 70 years since the founding of the People's Republic of China. The US and China are set to resume high-level trade talks next week.

site_title: Top tech investor bets India corner shops can fight Amazon
summary: Top tech investor GGV Capital is backing startups that serve India's corner shops, known as kiranas, to compete with Amazon and Walmart. The firm, which has invested $6.2 billion in unicorns globally, is focusing on kiranas due to their dominance in India's retail landscape. GGV plans to invest $5-10 million in early-stage entrepreneurs and $50 million in later-stage startups, aiming to empower kiranas to become e-commerce and lending enablers in their communities.

site_title: Compelling reasons for a green portfolio
summary: A shift in investment mindset is underway, with socially responsible investments gaining solid economic arguments in favor. China's Ministry of Ecology and Environment issued over $2 billion in fines for environmental harm, and the economics of renewable power are becoming irresistible, driving disruptive change. Research found that investing in renewables for electric vehicles yields 6-7 times more useful energy than investing in oil, and the price of oil would need to drop to $10/bbl for it to remain competitive. This trend is expected to be reinforced by governments pricing the externalities of fossil fuels, making sustainability a key consideration for investors.

site_title: Unleashed from Trump, Bolton says North Korea still seeks nukes
summary: John Bolton, former US national security advisor, warned that North Korea has not abandoned its nuclear ambitions, contradicting President Donald Trump's views. Bolton stated that Kim Jong Un's regime aims to maintain a nuclear capability and develop it further. Bolton also criticized Trump's approach, saying it's time for a more engaged US presence globally, not disengagement or withdrawal. The comments highlight Bolton's hawkish stance on North Korea, which differs from Trump's more conciliatory approach.

site_title: South Korean fighter jet conducts patrol flight over island disputed by Japan
summary: A South Korean fighter jet conducted a patrol flight over the disputed Dokdo/Takeshima island, claimed by both South Korea and Japan. The flight was reported by a South Korean Air Force pilot during a ceremony marking the military's founding. The island's ownership remains unresolved, with both countries asserting their claims.

site_title: Reini Otter takes the helm of Frasers Property's new industrial, logistics unit
summary: Reini Otter has been appointed as the CEO of Frasers Property's new industrial and logistics unit, Frasers Property Industrial (FPI). FPI combines Frasers Property's industrial and logistics operations in Australia and Europe, working closely with its Singapore-listed Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust. Otter, 49, has held executive positions with Frasers Property and Australand Property Group, and will oversee the integrated platform. The new unit was constituted on October 1, 2019, as a separate strategic business unit of Frasers Property.

site_title: Barricades up, shutters down as Hong Kong marks Communist China's birthday
summary: Hong Kong went into lockdown on October 1, 2019, as authorities attempted to prevent anti-government protests from overshadowing China's 70th anniversary celebrations. Barricades were set up in the city center, and riot police were present, while protesters vowed to use the occasion to push for greater democracy. The government had rejected a permit for a planned march and had cancelled the annual fireworks display due to public safety concerns. Demonstrations were expected to take place despite the authorities' efforts to control the situation, with protesters calling for those arrested to be released and for national mourning to be observed instead of celebrations.

site_title: Soh, Quah said to be hit with at least S$400m trading loss
summary: A High Court trial in Singapore heard that John Soh Chee Wen and Quah Su-Ling incurred at least S$400 million in trading losses due to the 2013 penny stock crash. The crash wiped S$8 billion off market value in days. Prosecution witness Tai Chee Ming testified that the pair's proxy accounts showed significant losses after the crash. The trial is ongoing.

site_title: Taiwan bridge collapses, at least 14 injured
summary: A bridge in northeastern Taiwan collapsed on Tuesday, injuring at least 14 people. The 140m single-arch bridge in Nanfangao, on Taiwan's eastern coast, came crashing down onto fishing vessels and a petrol tanker, sending it plummeting into the water. The driver of the tanker was among those injured. The cause of the collapse is being investigated, with President Tsai Ing-wen launching a rescue operation to look for any more injured or missing people. The bridge was built in 1998 and collapsed without warning, despite fine weather at the time.

images.alt_text: A bridge collapsed in northeastern Taiwan on Tuesday injuring at least 14 people as it smashed down on to fishing vessels moored underneath and sent a petrol tanker plummeting into the water.

site_title: China's 70th birthday: A nurtured narrative
summary: China is celebrating its 70th anniversary, with a focus on economic progress and global contributions. However, behind the celebrations lies a not-so-glorious story of Communist Party rule, including the deaths of millions during Mao Zedong's campaigns and the country's relative stagnation in the decades following. The government has crafted a narrative that downplays these issues and emphasizes the country's growth under Deng Xiaoping and Xi Jinping. This narrative has been criticized for omitting historical facts and glossing over China's interference in other countries' affairs.

site_title: Security ramped up as Hong Kong braces for China anniversary clashes
summary: Hong Kong authorities have increased security measures ahead of China's 70th anniversary, with police deterring pro-democracy protests and shutting down subway stations. The city's leader, Carrie Lam, attended a flag-raising ceremony in Beijing, while officials watched from a convention center due to security concerns. Protests continue, with small groups gathering to sing anti-Beijing songs and activists calling for a "Day of Grief" to overshadow Beijing's festivities. The protests, which began over extradition plans, have become a broader movement against democratic freedoms and police accountability.

images.alt_text: Police fanned out across Hong Kong on Tuesday in a bid to deter pro-democracy protests as the city marked communist China's 70th birthday, with local officials watching a flag-raising ceremony behind closed doors because of security concerns.

site_title: Singapore private home prices up 0.9% in Q3: URA flash data
summary: Singapore private home prices rose 0.9% in Q3, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's flash data. This is the second consecutive quarter of price increases, despite the country's economic slowdown. Year-over-year, prices are up 1.7%. Analysts suggest this may prompt the government to implement more cooling measures, citing the upward trend as a potential response to the economic slowdown and downside risks ahead.

images.alt_text: Private home prices in Singapore have risen for the second consecutive quarter, based on the latest official flash estimate.

site_title: Dubai Aerospace cancels plans for big jet order; targets M&A deal
summary: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise (DAE) has cancelled plans to order 400 single-aisle aircraft from Airbus and Boeing due to a disagreement over pricing and terms. The deal, worth over $40 billion, was considered a major opportunity for the company. Instead, DAE will focus on expanding through organic growth and a potential takeover of a rival aircraft lessor. CEO Firoz Tarapore stated that the pricing gap between the order price and rental market was too large to justify the deal. DAE aims to double its fleet to 800 jets within the next six to eight years.

site_title: Retaining the shine
summary: Global central banks are expected to ease monetary policy amid rising uncertainty over trade, geopolitics, inflation, and the business cycle. This will lead to a moderate rise in government bond yields, with credit spreads remaining broadly unchanged. Asia's high yield segment is expected to deliver a 3% total return, while investment grade bonds are expected to return around 4%. Inflation-linked bonds may also be attractive due to expected low inflation. Despite concerns over the US economy, most central bankers expect growth to moderate and inflation to stay low, supporting a dovish stance.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust snags maiden S$200m green loan from OCBC
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) secured a S$200 million, five-year green loan from OCBC Bank to finance properties with BCA Green Mark certification. This marks CMT's first foray into green financing, with 14 of its 15 properties already certified BCA Green Mark Gold and above. The loan supports CMT's efforts to achieve BCA Green Mark certification for all operational properties by 2020, and allows for diversification of funding sources.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.15 points to 1,584.06. Volume was 40.52 million lots worth RM13.06 million, with 82 gainers surpassing 67 losers.

site_title: South-east Asia is a region burning bright
summary: South-east Asia, comprising 10 countries, remains a key business hub despite global economic uncertainty, with an average annual growth rate of 5.4%. The region's young population, burgeoning middle class, and rapid urbanization drive growth, with opportunities in sectors like automotive, financial services, and e-commerce. Countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore are poised to run digitalized economies by 2025, offering more opportunities in e-commerce and financial services. Experts believe that despite potential economic slowdown, recessions can lead to more opportunities for companies to adapt and grow.

site_title: Global opera legend Jessye Norman dies at 74
summary: Global opera legend Jessye Norman, an American soprano known for her majestic voice, died at 74 due to septic shock and multi-organ failure after complications from a 2015 spinal cord injury. Born in 1945 in Augusta, Georgia, Norman showcased her voice in performances worldwide, earning a Grammy and numerous honors, including a Kennedy Center Honor and a National Medal of Arts. Her legacy was celebrated by the Metropolitan Opera, with a tribute performance of "Porgy and Bess" dedicated to her memory.

images.alt_text: Celebrated opera singer Jessye Norman, an American soprano who showcased her majestic voice in performances around the world, died Monday, her family said. She was 74 years old.

site_title: Indian motorcycles taps into 100-year roots with Japan relaunch
summary: Polaris Inc, the maker of Indian motorcycles, is relaunching its brand in Japan, aiming to boost single-digit market share to 10% by 2025. The company has taken direct control over local marketing and plans to double its store count to 30. Japan is a key market for Indian motorcycles, with a 44% share of the 20,385 bikes sold last year, and Polaris is leveraging its retro-styling and long history to attract well-heeled buyers. The move comes as US motorcycle sales face headwinds, prompting American brands to look abroad for growth.

site_title: Spread your wings - with a luxe card
summary: A luxury credit card with a high annual fee can earn extra bonus miles, offering value for Business or First Class airfare. The article profiles family businesses, including Cortina Holdings and PBA Group, and discusses impact investments and the outlook for fixed income. Meanwhile, neighboring Desaru is poised for luxury development, with Anantara Desaru Coast Resort & Villas accepting bookings and One&Only Desaru set to open in 2020.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) acquired Mapletree Business City Phase 2, increasing its assets under management (AUM) by 21% to S$8.9 billion. Units have outperformed S-Reits by 23% and are expected to see a 4-6% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion. Frasers Centrepoint Trust is preferred for its retail sector, while Wilmar International is upgraded to a "buy" call with a target price of S$4.75 due to expected crude palm oil price increases.

site_title: Shifting consumer demands forcing the evolution of retail
summary: Retail is evolving due to shifting consumer demands, with companies adapting to changing habits by offering diverse offerings and unique experiences. Industry leaders emphasized the importance of close collaboration, customer-centricity, and seamless online-offline integration. Examples include e-commerce giant Lazada's logistics expansion, supermarket NTUC FairPrice's data-driven in-store experiences, and fintech firm FavePay's mobile payment innovations. Experts also discussed the potential for unmanned retail stores and a shift towards cashless payments in the next few years.

site_title: Starting succession planning early
summary: Derrick Yap, CEO of PBA Group, aims to build a 100-year-old company through succession planning, starting at age 40. He has already begun planning his succession, organizing the business into three lines and forming a board of directors. Yap believes that a corporatized system is essential for the company's long-term success, allowing for a smooth transition to future leaders. He has also introduced a culture called the "PBA creed," which emphasizes values such as agility and openness to opposing views. Additionally, Yap has established a not-for-profit initiative, RACE, to provide education and training in robotics and automation.

site_title: Nurturing the human in HR
summary: PrimeStaff Management Services, a 25-year-old HR consultancy firm, has been recognized as an industry leader in Singapore's competitive HR market. Founded by Ronald Lee in 1994, the company has overcome economic turbulence, including the Asian financial crisis and Sars epidemic, by adapting to new technologies and diversifying its clientele base. With a focus on employee development and satisfaction, PrimeStaff has a familial culture that fosters teamwork and high productivity. The company is now preparing for succession, with Ronald Lee's son Jonathan set to take over the business in the near future.

site_title: Keppel Reit sells Bugis Junction Towers for S$547.5m, S$388m above purchase price
summary: Keppel Reit has sold Bugis Junction Towers to Village Prop Pte Ltd for S$547.5 million, exceeding the property's purchase price by S$388 million. The sale price translates to a yield of 3% and will contribute capital gains of S$378.1 million. The divestment is part of Keppel Reit's portfolio optimisation strategy, which aims to maintain a 99% committed occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 5.2 years. The sale will also contribute to Singapore's big-ticket investment acquisitions this year, with investors seeking office assets ahead of the peak of the CBD supply glut in 2021-2022.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

SIIC Environment Holdings formed a joint venture with Baowu Environment to expand its waste-to-energy business in Shanghai. Sunpower Group won a manufacturing tender from Sinopec worth 49 million yuan. Thakral Corporation acquired 4.4 hectares of land in Queensland for a resort-style retirement housing project. Frasers Centrepoint Trust appointed Koh Choon Fah as a non-executive director and audit committee member. BreadTalk Group promoted three C-suite executives to new roles. These announcements come after Henry Chu stepped down as BreadTalk CEO, with George Quek taking on the interim role. The moves are expected to have a positive impact on financial results.

site_title: Ahead of 2020, Facebook falls short on plan to share data on disinformation
summary: Facebook failed to share data on disinformation ahead of the 2020 presidential election, citing struggles to balance user privacy with researchers' needs. The company initially promised to share data on posts, links, and user activity to help study and flag disinformation, but nearly 18 months later, much of the data remains unavailable. Researchers have expressed concerns that the public's insight into disinformation campaigns on Facebook may be limited, and some have threatened to end their involvement in the research efforts.

images.alt_text: "Our goal is to focus on both providing ideas for preventing interference in 2018 and beyond, and also for holding us accountable," Mr Zuckerberg told lawmakers questioning him about Russian interference on the site in the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: China's Xi says country will stay on path of peaceful development
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that China will continue on the path of peaceful development, while prioritizing the country's sovereignty and security. Xi emphasized the importance of maintaining lasting prosperity and stability in Hong Kong and Macau, as well as promoting peaceful relations with Taiwan. This reaffirms China's commitment to its domestic and foreign policies, despite economic growth slowing down, according to recent predictions.

site_title: Shares of AB InBev's Asia unit up in Hong Kong debut
summary: AB InBev's Asia-Pacific unit, Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, raised about $5 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, priced at the bottom of the marketed range. Shares rose 4% on market debut, trading at HK$28, up 3.79% from its IPO price of HK$27. The IPO proceeds will help AB InBev reduce debt of over $100 billion and aid in creating an Asian brewing champion to spur consolidation.

site_title: Luxurious getaway
summary: Luxury hotel brands Anantara and One&Only are set to open in Desaru, Malaysia, a previously non-luxury destination. The Desaru Coast resort, developed by Themed Attractions Resorts & Hotels, will offer 108 rooms, villas, and residences, as well as amenities like a beachfront infinity pool and 24-carat gold spa treatments. Anantara Desaru is scheduled to open in December, while One&Only Desaru is set to open in early 2020, marking the luxury hotel chain's first resort in Asia.

site_title: 3 Things to know before buying an italian luxury real estate
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Italy's luxury real estate market is booming due to recent tax reforms that attract wealthy individuals and foreign investors. The Italian government's new tax legislation offers a flat tax of 100,000 euros (S$151,666) per year on all income generated outside of Italy, making it an attractive destination for high-net-worth individuals. To acquire residential property, buyers should follow a three-step process: preparing a non-binding letter of intent, signing a preliminary agreement, and completing the purchase with a definitive contract before an Italian notary public. This system is relatively easy to understand, but buyers should familiarize themselves with the legal and financial requirements.

site_title: Critical to forge a sense of unity among Singaporeans: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of unity among Singaporeans, stating that a sense of togetherness is crucial for the nation's survival. He also stressed the need for partnership, both domestically and globally, to tackle challenges such as climate change, pandemics, and economic competition. Heng noted that if Singapore loses its sense of purpose and community, it will face difficulties, but if it has a strong sense of unity, it can overcome challenges and remain relevant in the world.

site_title: Highest Indian monsoon rains in 25 years to boost winter crops
summary: India experienced its highest monsoon rains in 25 years, with 10% above average rainfall in 2019. This has boosted winter crops such as wheat, rice, and chickpeas, potentially improving rural demand and economic growth. However, heavy rainfall also damaged summer crops like cotton and soybeans. The prolonged monsoon has helped replenish reservoirs and groundwater, alleviating water shortages in some areas.

site_title: Forever 21 to file for bankruptcy
summary: Forever 21, a US fast-fashion retailer, will file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, closing up to 178 US stores and 350 globally. The company will continue to operate its website and stores in the US, Mexico, and Latin America. Revenue dropped to $3.3 billion in 2019, down from $4.4 billion in 2016. The restructuring aims to simplify operations and bring in $2.5 billion in annual sales. The company employs approximately 32,800 people, down from 43,000 in 2016. The bankruptcy marks a blow to the company's iconic status as a symbol of fast fashion.

site_title: Banking fintech Revolut could launch here this month
summary: Revolut, a London-based fintech, may launch its digital banking app in Singapore this month. The company has already granted access to around 15,000 users who signed up to its waiting list, offering a multi-currency e-wallet, budgeting, and spending tracking features. The services being rolled out in Singapore will be different from those offered to European customers, excluding cash withdrawals and cryptocurrency exchange. Revolut, which has 8 million users, aims to compete with incumbent financial players in the region.

images.alt_text: A Revolut bank card in London. The range of current services to be rolled out by Revolut in Singapore will not be the full suite offered to its European customers.

site_title: Taiwan dollar is a surprise winner from the trade war
summary: The Taiwan dollar has seen its first quarterly rise since March 2018, strengthening 0.1% in the third quarter, making it the biggest winner among Asian currencies in the US-China trade war. Foreign investors returned and firms redirected investments to Taiwan to avoid US tariffs against China, boosting the local dollar and Taiwanese stocks. Economists predict the currency to end the year at 31.5, with a 10-year sovereign yield ranging from 0.65% to 0.75%. Taiwan's economy has benefited from companies relocating manufacturing operations and investments from China amid the trade dispute.

site_title: Indonesian agency: Rainy season to help end forest fires soon
summary: Indonesia's disaster mitigation agency expects forest fires in Sumatra and Kalimantan to end soon with the arrival of the rainy season. The fires, caused by slash-and-burn farming practices, have been raging for months due to an El Nino weather pattern. Despite deploying over 29,000 personnel and aircraft, more than 320,000 hectares of forest have been burned this year, the worst damage since 2015. Rain has fallen in several areas, and the agency plans to maintain cloud-seeding procedures to optimize rain potential. The number of hot spots has declined by 78% in the latest satellite imagery.

site_title: Dubai developers race to lure buyers as downturn bites
summary: Dubai, known for its luxury towers and man-made islands, is experiencing a five-year property downturn with no end in sight. Developers are slashing prices and offering easy financing to lure buyers, while authorities have introduced incentives and regulations to revive the sector. The oversupply of mega projects has led to a slide in prices, with the government establishing a top-level committee to rebalance the market. Ratings agency Standard and Poor's predicts the industry may not stabilize until 2021, with only the strongest firms likely to survive the correction, which is expected to last three to four years.

site_title: SilkAir's 737 Max fleet to be parked in Australia
summary: SilkAir has relocated its first of six Boeing 737 Max aircraft to Alice Springs, central Australia, for storage due to the global grounding following two deadly crashes. The aircraft was flown by Boeing pilots, and the Australian government's CASA has confirmed SilkAir will transfer its planes to Australia. This move comes as the 737 Max continues to face regulatory issues and public scrutiny.

site_title: Under-invest in compliance at your peril - even in 'safer' Asian states
summary: Malaysia, South Korea, and Thailand are often underestimated due to their perceived ease of operation, but these "safer" Asian jurisdictions pose significant compliance risks. Malaysia's complex operating environment includes fraud, corruption, and regulatory zealotry, while South Korea's powerful chaebols are implicated in financial corruption. In Thailand, bribery, state-business collusion, and immigration law issues have led to threats of violence and criminal defamation suits. Companies must conduct proper market risk assessments and deploy sufficient compliance resources to address these gaps, as regulators are becoming hungrier and more powerful.

site_title: 2 Duxton Hill shophouses put on the market
summary: Two double-storey conservation shophouses in Duxton Hill, Singapore, have been launched for sale with a guide price of S$11 million (S$2,800 psf). The shophouses, located at 39 and 40 Duxton Road, are fully leased and sit within the Tanjong Pagar conservation area, zoned for commercial use. The sale is seen as an opportunity for investors to acquire an asset in the highly sought-after Duxton Hill locale, with the area expected to benefit from new developments and growth.

site_title: HKEX seeks loan of up to £8b to fund LSE bid
summary: HKEX is in talks with banks for a loan of up to £8 billion to fund its proposed takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange Group Plc. The bid, known as "Project Lima," must be submitted by October 9 under UK takeover rules. HKEX is seeking to convince LSE shareholders of the deal's merits, which includes the potential for combining an Asian exchange with a European counterpart. The Hong Kong exchange has faced resistance from LSE, which rejected the £29.6 billion proposal last month, citing complications and regulatory issues.

site_title: Taiwan bridge collapse crushes fishing boats, some crew feared trapped
summary: A bridge in northeastern Taiwan collapsed into a harbour on Tuesday, crushing several fishing boats with some crew feared trapped. At least nine people fell into the water and seven were rescued, with six seriously injured. Divers were searching for those feared trapped in fishing boats, and authorities set up an emergency centre with military assistance. The bridge collapse occurred in clear weather and damaged three fishing boats and two vehicles, with the reason for the collapse unclear.

site_title: Europe: Weak euro, Wall Street rally buoy shares
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by a Wall Street rally and a decline in the euro, boosting gains for exporters. Despite concerns about US-China trade negotiations and looming tariffs, investors appeared less fearful, with the benchmark European index posting its best monthly gain since June and year-to-date gains of around 16%. Germany's DAX index also rose, despite revised growth forecasts and lower inflation. Analysts predict an opportunity for euro zone equities to bounce back, with JPMorgan raising its rating to "overweight".

site_title: Japan's Aug factory output falls more than expected
summary: Japan's industrial output declined 1.2% in August, exceeding expectations and signaling pressure on the economy amid the Sino-US trade war. Despite this, retail sales expanded at a faster-than-expected pace, suggesting strength in private spending ahead of a nationwide sales tax increase. Manufacturers expect output to rise 1.9% in September but fall 0.5% in October. The bleak picture for Japan's export-reliant economy underscores broadening stress across the manufacturing sector, with the world's third-largest economy growing for the third straight quarter.

site_title: Red meat unhealthy? Maybe not, researchers say
summary: A review of dozens of studies has concluded that the potential risk of red meat consumption on cancer and heart disease is low and evidence uncertain. Researchers from seven countries suggest that adults can continue current unprocessed red meat consumption and current processed meat consumption, despite previous medical advice to cut back. The review found a modest risk reduction of seven deaths per 1,000 people from reducing red meat consumption by three servings per week, but noted that the evidence is uncertain and the risk reductions are small.

site_title: Credit Suisse clears CEO Thiam of spying on star banker
summary: Credit Suisse has cleared CEO Tidjane Thiam of ordering the botched surveillance of former wealth management head Iqbal Khan. An internal investigation found COO Pierre-Olivier Bouee alone initiated the observation, and Khan was not informed. The incident has triggered a criminal investigation and damaged the bank's reputation. Despite this, Thiam still enjoys the full confidence of the board, and his shares rose 0.8% after the news. The investigation did not find evidence of personal differences between Thiam and Khan contributing to the incident, contradicting media reports.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse on Tuesday cleared Chief Executive Tidjane Thiam of ordering the botched surveillance of the bank's former wealth management head Iqbal Khan, but said its chief operating officer had resigned to take responsibility.

site_title: Other white knights waiting in the wings, says Hyflux's lawyer
summary: Hyflux's lawyer says other white knights are waiting in the wings, amid negotiations with Utico over a potential deal. Despite Utico claiming Hyflux had not signed a definitive restructuring agreement, the company's lawyer believes talks have not stalled. Hyflux is prioritizing discussions with Utico, but is also exploring other options, including a non-binding term sheet for a novation of a waste-to-energy project. The company's financial troubles, including delays in its TuasOne project, may improve with the substantial realisation of receivables under an arbitration awarded last year.

site_title: Synagie's group financial controller leaves 'due to personal commitments'
summary: SYNAGIE Corporation's group financial controller, Jenny Tay Lee Wee, has resigned effective Sept 30 due to personal commitments. She served for 14 months and ensured a smooth transition. Her replacement, John Cai Jingren, assumed the role with immediate effect. Cai, 36, has previous experience as financial controller at KTL Global and finance manager at Oxley Holdings. The company is satisfied with the reason for her departure, according to sponsor RHT Capital.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust appoints Edmund Tie & Co CEO as non-exec director
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust has appointed Koh Choon Fah, CEO of Edmund Tie & Co, as a non-executive and independent director, effective October 1. Ms. Koh, 61, brings over 30 years of experience in the real estate industry and academia. Her appointments also include membership on the audit and nominating and remuneration committees. Following the announcement, Frasers Centrepoint Trust's units closed at S$2.74, a 2.24% increase.

site_title: Oil falls, Brent posts biggest quarterly drop this year on demand fears
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at $60.78, down 1.8% from the previous day, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures falling 3.3% to $54.07. The decline is attributed to fading concerns of supply shortfalls and conflicts in the Middle East, as well as demand fears due to the escalating US-China trade war. For the quarter, Brent posted its biggest quarterly loss, falling 8.7%, and WTI dropped 7.5%.

site_title: Towards a zero-carbon city
summary: Cities are a key focus for addressing climate change, with 70% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions emanating from urban areas. To meet the 2015 Paris Agreement's two-degree temperature limit, cities must adopt sustainable solutions. Governments can reduce their environmental impact by decarbonizing power, promoting greener transport, and making buildings more environmentally friendly. Over 100 urban authorities worldwide have pledged to be carbon-neutral or net-zero-carbon by 2050, with many cities already implementing initiatives such as all-electric bus fleets and energy-efficient wastewater treatment plants. Cooperation between the public and private sector is crucial for a successful zero-carbon transition.

images.alt_text: Governments command sizeable budgets and have wide-ranging powers covering areas such as land use, transport, energy, housing, waste, recycling, water and local taxation.

site_title: Fighting for an open Internet
summary: The open Internet, a founding principle of the Web, is facing threats from Big Tech consolidation, which undermines freedom and equality. Despite accounting for less than 50% of time spent online, Big Tech holds over 75% of industry value. This oligopolistic market limits innovation and impacts consumers' personal information, raising concerns over data misuse and conflicts of interest. To address these issues, public authorities must overhaul the digital ecosystem, separating consumer services from data monetization to promote transparency and protect users' choices. Immediate action is necessary to protect entrepreneurial freedom and individual choices.

site_title: Australian innovation finds a hothouse in Singapore
summary: Australia and Singapore have strengthened their bilateral relationship through a strategic partnership, fostering innovation and entrepreneurship. The countries have collaborated on various initiatives, including the Singapore Landing Pad programme, which supports Australian startups in scaling globally. Since its launch, 41 startups have benefited from the programme, with the number of Australian representatives in the region growing. The partnership has also enabled greater collaboration between Australian companies and Singapore institutions, leading to meaningful innovation and research outcomes.

images.alt_text: Australia and Singapore have forged one of the closest and most comprehensive bilateral relationships in the region thanks to long-standing diplomatic and trade relations, and a similar strategic outlook. As the country's largest trade and investment partner in Asean, Singapore has also evolved into a strategic focus for Australia's presence in the region.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Apple boost
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Monday, driven by Apple's boost. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.12% to 26,852.33, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.18% and 0.31%, respectively. Investors shrugged off reports that Washington was considering delisting Chinese companies from US stock exchanges. The rally came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Star Pharmaceutical gets enough acceptances to delist from Mainboard
summary: Star Pharmaceutical has met the 10% minimum threshold to delist from the Mainboard, with 42.3 million shares accepted by the offeror, representing 92.24% of the public float. The offeror, led by executive chairman Xu Zhi Bin, plans to take the company private, citing increased control and management flexibility. The S$0.45 per share offer closes on October 7, and the company will no longer maintain a public float.

site_title: Intl Cement cancels US$104.4m deal to buy African cement producer
summary: International Cement Group (ICG) has canceled its proposed US$104.4 million deal to buy African cement producer Schwenk Namibia. The deal was first announced in March 2019 but was terminated on September 27, 2019, due to concerns over Schwenk's non-profitability and ICG's lack of sufficient cash. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) had rejected the bid in June, citing a material adverse financial impact on the enlarged group. ICG had intended to fund the purchase with external loans and shareholder loans, but these plans were deemed unfeasible.

site_title: PwC earns record revenues, opposes market caps in UK
summary: PwC, the global accounting firm, reported record revenues of US$42.4 billion in its latest fiscal year, with plans to invest US$3 billion in employee skills over the next two years. The company faces regulatory scrutiny in the UK, where it was criticized for not meeting quality targets and will hire 500 auditors to bolster its audit business. PwC's global chairman, Bob Moritz, opposed the UK's proposed "joint audits" and market caps, calling them "anti-competitive," and instead advocates for reforming the audit industry to better meet investor demands.

images.alt_text: PwC earned US$42.4 billion in global annual revenues with US$3 billion going into bolstering skills over the next two years, the "Big Four" accountant said on Tuesday as it faces closer regulatory scrutiny in Britain.

site_title: Family succession takes centrestage
summary: Asian families are grappling with family succession, legacy, and governance, with some seeking a model from the Princely Family of Liechtenstein, which has owned the LGT Group for 900 years. The LGT Group, with assets under management of $215 billion, is a prime example of a successful family-run business. Lim Ping Ping, LGT Asia head of wealth planning, notes that many entrepreneurial families are now trying to put their succession plans into action, highlighting the importance of effective family governance. This trend is expected to continue in the years to come.

site_title: TikTok owner ByteDance's H1 revenue better than expected
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, reported revenue of 50 billion yuan (S$9.7 billion) to 60 billion yuan in the first half, beating expectations. The company was previously loss-making but posted a profit in June and aims to make a profit in the second half. ByteDance revised its revenue target for 2019 to 120 billion yuan, up from an earlier goal of 100 billion yuan. The company's global apps have 1.5 billion monthly active users and 700 million daily active users, and it's expanding into new areas, including search and music streaming.

site_title: This tiny bank is a canary in India's coalmine
summary: India's Punjab & Maharashtra Co-operative Bank (PMC Bank) is embroiled in a US$1 billion scandal, with alleged wrongdoing involving a single borrower group, Housing Development and Infrastructure Ltd (HDIL), which received nearly 73% of the bank's loan book. The RBI has banned depositors from withdrawing more than 10,000 rupees for six months, citing major financial irregularities and failure of internal controls. Top-level complicity is suspected, and depositors are being blamed, a situation that could have chilling consequences for India's already-stressed financial system.

site_title: New cyber security Masterplan for Operational Technologies launched to protect critical sectors
summary: Singapore has launched a cyber security Masterplan for Operational Technologies (OT) to protect critical sectors such as water supply and transportation networks. The plan aims to bolster defenses against cyber attacks and facilitate information exchange between the public and private sectors. The OT Cybersecurity Masterplan will grow the talent pool and enhance cybersecurity efforts in sectors with interconnected devices and computers, including energy, water, transport, and media. The initiative was announced by Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean at the Singapore International Cyber Week.

site_title: Abominable tops US box office with US$20.8m; Judy hits high note
summary: "Abominable" tops the US box office with a debut of $20.85 million in North America and $29.7 million worldwide, becoming the best opening of the year for an original animated film. Meanwhile, "Judy" earned $3 million at the specialty box office, generating Oscar buzz for Renee Zellweger's performance. Holdovers like "Downton Abbey" and "Hustlers" also performed well, with "It: Chapter Two" and "Ad Astra" competing for fourth and fifth place.

site_title: Dollar holds near recent highs on trade jitters
summary: The US dollar held near recent highs due to trade jitters, with investors seeking safety in the greenback amid uncertainty over the US-China trade war and deepening US political uncertainty. The dollar rose 0.1% to 99.169 against a basket of currencies, while the New Zealand dollar fell to a four-year low after business confidence tumbled. Investors also await a potential interest rate cut in Australia and a lull in trade-war headlines.

site_title: CapitaLand aims to more than double AUM in India to S$7b by 2024
summary: CapitaLand plans to more than double its assets under management in India to S$7 billion by 2024, from S$3.3 billion currently. The company aims to achieve this by investing in its development pipeline and expanding its fund management business with capital partners over the next five years. This expansion is part of CapitaLand's strategy to grow its presence in India, following its S$11 billion acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge in June.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand's Group CEO, Lee Chee Koon (second from left), following a site visit in International Tech Park Bangalore.

site_title: Thai growth outlook below potential, but no crisis yet: BOT governor
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Veerathai Santiprabhob stated that the country's economic growth forecast of 2.8% for this year is below potential. The economy, however, is not in a crisis yet, and monetary policy will be reviewed if conditions worsen. The Bank of Thailand downgraded its growth outlook from 3.3% last week, citing last year's growth of 4.1%.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing outgoing CEO Piyush Goyal. MAS and PBOC are strengthening cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: honestbee gets four-month debt moratorium
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted honestbee, a distressed grocery startup, a four-month debt moratorium, two months less than what was initially sought. The company will focus on its core grocery business and retail supermarket habitat while repaying salaries owed to ex-employees. Honestbee plans to restructure about $209 million owed to creditors via a debt-to-equity swap, with its largest shareholder, co-founder Joel Sng, supporting the plans.

images.alt_text: Distressed grocery startup honestbee has announced a slew of appointments to strengthen its management.

site_title: Eastspring Investments inks agreement to buy 50.1% of Thai fund manager
summary: Eastspring Investments, a subsidiary of Prudential, has agreed to acquire 50.1% of Thai fund manager Thanachart Fund Management Co (TFUND) for S$190.3 million. Eastspring is also acquiring 25.1% of TFUND from Thanachart Bank Public Company and 25% from Government Savings Bank. The acquisition aims to strengthen Prudential's presence in the Thai market, with TFUND being Thailand's eighth-largest mutual fund manager, and combined assets under management of 653 billion baht. Regulatory approval is required for the deal's completion.

site_title: Asia equities get mixed start to the week
summary: Asia equities started the week on a mixed note, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.2% lower at 3,119.99. Despite a better-than-expected China manufacturing sector reading, US President Donald Trump's latest trade threat weighed on markets. Hong Kong and South Korea notched gains, while Australia, China, and Japan posted losses. China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.9% to a month's low, and US funds are expected to remain a concern due to potential delisting of Chinese companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise as investors shrug off latest trade worries
summary: South Korean shares rose on Monday, despite US news of considering delisting Chinese companies from US stock exchanges, as investors viewed the move as a tactic to hold a dominant position in trade talks. China's slightly higher-than-expected factory activity survey also boosted domestic markets. The Kospi index ended up 13.12 points, or 0.64%, at 2,063.05, with foreigners buying 1 billion won worth of shares. The benchmark index has gained 4.84% for the month and 1.08% so far this year.

site_title: Singapore Sept market cap down 0.3%; more volatility expected
summary: Singapore's stock market value declined 0.3% in September, marking the third consecutive month of losses, with total market capitalization at S$859.9 billion. Banks and Reits were among the top gainers, while stocks with high exposure to Hong Kong were among the biggest losers. Low trading volumes are expected into October as markets wait for geopolitical events, particularly the US-China trade talks and the Brexit deadline. Industry-wise, finance and properties performed better, while commerce and manufacturing saw declines.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Saudi Arabia on rising geopolitical risk
summary: Fitch downgraded Saudi Arabia's credit rating to A from A+ due to rising geopolitical and military tensions in the Gulf, as well as a deterioration of the kingdom's fiscal position. The downgrade comes after an unprecedented attack on Saudi oil plants, which temporarily halved the country's oil production. Fitch believes there is a risk of further attacks, which could result in economic damage. The downgrade is a blow to Saudi Arabia's largest economy, just as it is gearing up for a potential international sale of US dollar denominated Islamic bonds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 137.46 points, or 0.53%, to close at 26,092.27. The gains were driven by big chemical and telecoms firms ahead of a market holiday on China's 70th anniversary. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell, with losses of 0.92% and 1.06%, respectively.

site_title: Keeping Cortina ticking
summary: Cortina Holdings, a family-owned watch retailer, has maintained profitability since its listing in 2002, despite a challenging business environment. The company's net profits surged 69% to S$9.5 million in the April-June quarter, driven by cost-cutting measures. Chief Operating Officer Jeremy Lim attributes the success to keeping costs down, particularly by optimizing inventory management. Cortina has implemented a sound inventory management system, with a stock turnover of around 180 days, and plans to reduce it further to 150 days.
