The company is also expanding into new markets and exploring digitalization, including an online watch manual on YouTube.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo from US President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned H2 revenue may be below target, mirroring the H1 operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.2% despite positive China factory data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.2% on Monday, closing at 3,119.99, despite positive China factory data. The decline followed US President Donald Trump's latest trade threat, which negatively impacted regional markets, including the Shanghai Composite Index, which fell to a month low. Local stocks, such as Singtel and DBS Group Holdings, were mixed, while real estate investment trusts (Reits) like Mapletree Commercial Trust fell 2.1% after its addition to the STI.

site_title: Sunpower wins 49m yuan tender from repeat customer Sinopec
summary: Sunpower Group has won a 49 million yuan tender from repeat customer Sinopec to provide flare packages for the Gulei Refinery and Chemical Integration Project. The contract is expected to have a positive impact on Sunpower's financial results for 2019 and 2020. Sunpower's shares rose 3.3% after the announcement, with executive chairman Guo Hongxin stating that the contract signals strong confidence in Sunpower's ability to supply equipment and solutions for large-scale petrochemical projects, reaffirming the stable partnership with Sinopec.

site_title: honestbee gets 4-month creditor moratorium; sought 6-month reprieve
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted honestbee, a distressed grocery startup, a 4-month creditor moratorium, two months less than the 6-month reprieve sought. Honestbee must outline its proposed scheme of arrangement by January 2020 and will repay salaries owed to ex-employees in four to five tranches.

site_title: British PM Johnson denies groping allegations as party conference opens
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson denied allegations of groping a female journalist, Charlotte Edwardes, 20 years ago, during the Conservative Party's annual conference. Edwardes claimed Johnson inappropriately touched her thigh at a lunch in 1999. Johnson said he did not recall the incident and accused the public of wanting to hear about his plans for public services. The allegations overshadow the conference, which comes as Johnson prepares to lead the UK out of the European Union on October 31.

site_title: European stock markets fall at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Monday, following losses in Asia. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1% to 7,421.50 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices lost 0.2% each. The decline was attributed to ongoing US-EU trade talks and uncertainty surrounding tariffs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as US-China trade row weighs
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday due to profit-taking amid US-China trade row concerns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.56% to 21,755.84, while the Topix index lost 1.03% to 1,587.80. US President Trump's consideration of severe new restrictions on investment in China weighed on sentiment. Despite China's manufacturing sector showing signs of improvement, ongoing trade pressure with the US impacted domestic demand. Market participants await key events and data, including the Bank of Japan's Tankan survey and US jobs data.

site_title: Thakral acquires 4.4ha Queensland site for A$6m via retirement resort JV
summary: Thakral Corporation acquired a 4.4-hectare site in Queensland, Australia for A$6 million through a joint venture with GemLife to develop a resort-style retirement housing project. Construction will start in October, with 96 homes expected to be completed by early 2020, bringing GemLife's total residences to over 1,400. The move aligns with Thakral's strategy to grow real estate investments for sustainable returns, capitalizing on Australia's growing demand for senior living communities.

site_title: Fintech Revolut could launch digital banking services in Singapore in October
summary: Revolut, a London-based fintech, is set to launch digital banking services in Singapore as early as October, after quietly onboarding 15,000 users in the country. The app, which operates as a multi-currency e-wallet, allows users to spend and transfer money abroad at the interbank exchange rate. Revolut's services in Singapore will not be the full suite offered in Europe, but will include features such as budget tracking and cryptocurrency exchange. The company aims to challenge incumbent financial players in the region, with Singapore as its Asia-Pacific headquarters.

site_title: BreadTalk promotes 3 C-suite executives following group CEO's resignation
summary: BreadTalk Group announced the promotions of three C-suite executives following the resignation of group CEO Henry Chu. Jenson Ong Chin Hock, 62, has been promoted to deputy group CEO, while William Cheng, 47, will become group chief operating officer. Chan Ying Jian, 36, has been promoted to group chief investment officer. The promotions will take effect from October 1, with Ong and Cheng retaining their current roles. This move comes after Chu's resignation for "personal and health reasons," which will be effective on December 31.

site_title: Repsol buys 40% stake in United Global unit for up to US$46.5m
summary: Repsol has entered a share purchase agreement to acquire a 40% stake in United Global's subsidiary United Oil Company Pte Ltd for up to $46.5 million. The deal will make UOC Group a joint-control entity of Repsol, allowing it to leverage Repsol's international brand presence to enhance its production and distribution in Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The acquisition is Repsol's first venture into the South-east Asian market, and United Global will receive $36 million in net proceeds, which will be used to fund future business expansion and investments.

site_title: Hong Kong police warn National Day protests will be 'very, very dangerous'
summary: Hong Kong police warned that pro-democracy protests on Tuesday, marking the 70th anniversary of China's founding, will be "very, very dangerous". Superintendent John Tse stated that core rioters are increasing violence and resorting to terrorism, citing a heightened risk of attacks. The warning comes ahead of the National Day celebrations, which have been marred by ongoing protests and clashes between police and demonstrators.

site_title: Sacked Hong Kong Cathay staff decry 'Cultural Revolution' purge
summary: Cathay Pacific staff who were fired for supporting Hong Kong's pro-democracy protesters have accused the airline of a "Cultural Revolution" style purge. The airline, facing backlash from Chinese authorities, banned staff from working on mainland flights or traveling through Chinese airspace. This move led to chaos and efforts to regain Beijing's favor. The firings have sparked criticism, with former employees claiming they were targeted for their political views. The incident highlights the growing tensions between Hong Kong and China.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's bank lending rose 0.6% in August, driven by a 1.3% increase in business loans, offsetting a 0.7% decline in consumer loans. Meanwhile, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warned of rising cyber risks from IT supply chains threatening financial firms. Globally, Vietnam was surprised by the US's decision to announce a new tariff on its exports, while Malaysia's government planned to seize RM3 billion in assets from a local businessman. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicted the MSCI global equity index would reach 1,150 by mid-2026.

site_title: The new strategy for banks: Create value instead of competing
summary: Banks are shifting their strategy from competing with non-traditional financial services to creating new value for customers. With digital banking penetration high, banks must innovate to remain relevant. Using big data and enterprise data clouds can help banks identify new markets, create personalized offers, and differentiate themselves from competitors. A study by McKinsey found that 97% of developed Asia's population uses banking services, while 40-50% of developed Asia's population uses payment solutions from non-traditional companies. Banks like UOB are successfully adopting enterprise data clouds to gain insights and drive innovation.

site_title: Fintech firm Revolut to hire 3,500 staff in global push with Visa
summary: Revolut, a British digital banking app, is set to hire 3,500 staff as it expands into 24 new markets with a new deal with Visa Inc. The company, which now has over eight million customers, plans to launch in eight new countries including Brazil, Japan, and the US by the end of this year. Revolut's expansion could see the company double or triple its customers in the next year, with its average customer holding around €1,000 in their account.

site_title: Hong Kong Aug home prices drop for 3rd month, steeper declines forecast
summary: Hong Kong private home prices dropped 1.37% in August, the third consecutive month, with the largest percentage decline since December 2018. The fall is attributed to the ongoing US-China trade war and social unrest. Despite this, prices still gained 8.5% in the first eight months of the year. Analysts forecast a full-year price drop of 5% to a rise of 5%. The housing sector remains resilient due to tight supply, with new launches selling most or all apartments.

site_title: Australian shares close lower ahead of central bank policy meeting
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Monday, closing at 6,688.3, as mining stocks dropped and financials led the losses ahead of a central bank interest rate cut. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index ended September with a gain, despite a mixed economic data from China and US-China trade talks. Oil prices fell, hurting energy stocks, but Woodside Petroleum Ltd rose 1.1% due to a positive outlook from Credit Suisse.

site_title: Roche extends Spark offer again as regulatory review drags on
summary: Roche extended its $4.3 billion offer to buy US gene therapy specialist Spark Therapeutics until October 30, as US and British regulators continue to review the deal. The terms remain unchanged, with analysts citing competition concerns over hemophilia A treatments as a potential hurdle. Roche has declined to comment on the Federal Trade Commission's delay in signing off on the transaction. The regulatory review has caused the deal to drag on, with no clear timeline for completion.

site_title: NZ sports store apologises over porn played on big screens
summary: Auckland, New Zealand - Asics New Zealand apologized after explicit pornography was broadcast on large television screens above its central Auckland store for several hours, shocking Sunday morning shoppers. An unknown individual gained access to the screens, displaying objectionable content. The company expressed regret, stating it was working with security suppliers to prevent a repeat incident. Several customers, including a mother with a 7-year-old son, were reportedly shocked by the display.

site_title: Singapore electricity tariffs to fall 3.3% in Q4
summary: Singapore's electricity tariffs are set to decrease by 3.3% from October to December, with an average drop of 0.79 cents per kilowatt hour. This decline is due to lower natural gas costs for electricity generation. Households can expect lower electricity bills, with the average monthly bill for families in four-room HDB flats decreasing by $2.84. The tariff decrease is part of SP Group's quarterly review, guided by the Energy Market Authority's pricing guidelines.

site_title: Starbucks becomes latest target of Hong Kong protester rage
summary: Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong targeted multiple Starbucks branches with graffiti over the weekend, amid intense clashes between protesters and riot police. The vandalism comes after a family member of the local restaurant chain that owns the Starbucks franchise spoke out against the protests, and amid pressure from Beijing on international brands to publicly condemn the protests. The move is part of a broader boycott campaign against Hong Kong businesses seen as sympathetic to the government.

images.alt_text: Starbucks has emerged as the latest brand to fall foul of Hong Kong's pro-democracy protesters after a family member of the local restaurant chain that owns the local franchise spoke out against demonstrators.

site_title: AB InBev's Asia unit opens higher despite gloomy IPO market
summary: AB InBev's Asia-Pacific beer unit, Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, raised US$5 billion in its Hong Kong IPO debut, with shares rising 2.2% to HK$27.60, despite a dim global market. The IPO helped reduce the parent company's debt load and sets the stage for future acquisitions. This is a rare bright spot for the dim global market, providing hope for the global IPO scene, which has been unsettled by volatile markets and geopolitical uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The Asia-Pacific beer unit of Anheuser-Busch InBev NV gained as much as 2.2 per cent in its Hong Kong trading debut, in a rare bright spot for the dim global market in initial public offerings (IPO).

site_title: PODCAST: How to start investing with forex (Money Hacks, Ep 55)
summary: In a recent podcast episode, "Money Hacks" explores how to start investing in foreign exchange (FX) as an investment vehicle. Sumeet Bhambri, Standard Chartered's regional head of wealth management, provides actionable tips on FX investing, including what FX is, how to use it as an investment vehicle, and tools to help navigate the market. The episode is intended for Singaporean investors and emphasizes the importance of consulting with a financial adviser before making investment decisions.

site_title: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,115.11, down 0.34% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 0.34% to 3,115.11 at 1:01pm on Monday, amid a mixed performance by other Asian markets. The decline was driven by a weaker performance in the region, with Japan's Nikkei index down 0.7% and South Korea's Kospi index down 0.4%. The US administration's plans to limit exposure to Chinese assets also weighed on the market.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of China anniversary
summary: Asian markets are mixed ahead of China's 70th anniversary, with Beijing's better-than-expected manufacturing data easing concerns. However, investors remain cautious due to US President Donald Trump's threats to restrict investment in China and ongoing trade tensions. Markets are also wary of planned protests in Hong Kong disrupting the celebrations. Despite this, Asian markets are largely unaffected, with Shanghai and Tokyo experiencing slight declines, while Sydney and Seoul rise.

site_title: Happy holidays? Not in China if frozen pork is on the table
summary: China's supermarkets have released 30,000 tonnes of frozen pork from state reserves to combat price surges, which have nearly doubled in a year due to a deadly virus affecting millions of hogs. The move has helped dampen price increases and boosted sales, especially in Beijing. However, analysts say the impact on overall prices will be limited, and some consumers are substituting pork with other meats, citing its high cost. The move aims to ensure sufficient pork supply for the National Day festivities, but some question the quality of the stored pork.

site_title: Dryness in Argentina hits corn and wheat outlook; election haze supports safe-bet soy
summary: Argentina's dry weather is affecting its wheat and corn crops, with climate expert Eduardo Sierra cutting his 2019/20 wheat forecast to 17 million tonnes and corn to 40 million tonnes. Growers are shifting to safe-haven soybeans due to uncertainty ahead of the October presidential election, with soy projections edged down to 50 million tonnes. The dryness has hurt wheat yields and slowed corn sowing, while Argentina signed a soymeal export deal with China, linking the country's main cash crop with its biggest consumer.

images.alt_text: Dryness in Argentina is hitting the outlooks for wheat and corn crops, local climate experts said, while low-cost soy is being supported by growers looking to hedge their bets with political uncertainty rising ahead of October's presidential vote.

site_title: On US delisting threat, China says 'decoupling' would harm both sides
summary: China warned that "decoupling" from the US would harm both sides, amid reports the Trump administration is considering delisting Chinese companies from US stock exchanges. The move, part of broader efforts to limit US investment in Chinese companies, would create turmoil in financial markets and endanger global trade and economic growth. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang urged the US to work with China to deepen economic and financial cooperation, and to take a "constructive attitude" toward resolving differences. The US and China are set to resume high-level trade talks next week.

site_title: Singapore workplace fatalities dip in first half of 2019, but injuries rise
summary: Singapore's workplace fatalities decreased to a seven-year low in the first half of 2019, with 17 worker deaths recorded between January and June. The top causes of death were falls from heights, traffic accidents, and structure collapses. However, workplace injuries increased to 6,561, with falls, slips, and machinery-related injuries being the leading causes. The Ministry of Manpower also reported a decrease in occupational diseases and near-misses. Despite the decline in fatalities, the ministry warned that non-fatal injuries continue to rise, and it plans to conduct more inspections and release workplace safety records of companies in 2020.

site_title: Cyber risks from IT supply chains a rising threat for financial firms: MAS panel
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore are increasingly vulnerable to cyber threats from IT supply chains, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Cyber Security Advisory Panel. To mitigate these risks, financial firms should conduct source code reviews, system integrity checks, and network anomaly detection. Effective "multi-layered defence" strategies and clear expectations for cyber risk culture are also essential. Strengthening cyber monitoring and surveillance through global intelligence-sharing networks is recommended. Poor risk culture and inadequate cybersecurity measures contribute to cyber incidents, emphasizing the need for proactive measures to protect against these threats.

site_title: World chocolatier will use the whole cacao for a fruitier taste
summary: Swiss chocolatier Barry Callebaut AG is introducing a product line made from the whole cacao fruit, targeting a "fruitier" taste in its WholeFruit chocolate. The company, facing competition pressure, aims to create a more sustainable approach to making chocolate. About 70% of the cacao fruit is typically wasted, and the new line is expected to be marketed to chefs and environmentally conscious consumers. Mondelez International Inc. will be the first to test-market the line, with WholeFruit chocolate products available from May.

site_title: China's factory activity edges up in September
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed signs of improvement in September, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 49.8 from 49.5 in August, beating expectations. However, the index remained below the 50 level, indicating contraction. An independent gauge, the Caixin China Manufacturing PMI, also improved, with production and new orders expanding at quicker rates. Despite this, concerns over the US-China trade war and global demand persist, with experts warning that the improved data may not mark a turnaround.

site_title: Pair of Duxton Hill shophouses up for sale with S$11m guide price
summary: A pair of two-storey conservation shophouses in Duxton Hill, Singapore, have been launched for sale with a guide price of S$11 million. Located on 39 and 40 Duxton Road, the shophouses have a combined land area of 2,161 sq ft and an estimated built-up area of 3,929 sq ft. The property is fully leased with a nightclub on the ground floor and offices on the upper floor, and is zoned "commercial" under the URA's Draft Master Plan 2019, making it eligible for foreign buyers and exempt from buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: Hyflux debt moratorium extended by two more months to Dec 2
summary: The High Court extended Hyflux's debt moratorium by two months to December 2, following a hearing on Monday. Most creditors supported the extension, except for an unsecured working group of seven banks. Hyflux's lawyer stated that the company was close to sealing a deal with Utico, a Middle Eastern utility company, and was working on finalizing details. A case management conference will be held on October 31 to update on the rescue deal and plan the actual hearing on November 29.

site_title: DFS handling of layoffs could have been better, says minister
summary: Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo said DFS Group could have handled its recent layoffs better, particularly in employee communication and severance packages. A taskforce has been activated to support affected staff from T Galleria by DFS in Scotts Road, and the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices is engaging with DFS.

site_title: Xi bows to Mao ahead of China's 70th anniversary
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping paid respects to Chairman Mao Zedong's embalmed body ahead of China's 70th anniversary of Communist rule. Xi and top officials bowed three times to Mao's statue, a rare gesture not seen since 2013. The move comes as China prepares for a tightly-choreographed celebration, despite facing economic challenges, including a US-China trade spat and African swine fever, as well as pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.

site_title: WeWork landlords in London and New York are bracing for a market fallout
summary: WeWork's landlords in London and New York are preparing for a potential market fallout as the company's plans to go public collapsed and its valuation drops. WeWork is the largest private-sector tenant in both cities, but doubts about its future have emerged after several executives left and deals for office buildings leased to WeWork are on the line. London landlords are bracing for a potential vacancy, but traditional landlords, brokers, and rival providers of flexible space are expected to step in to fill the gap, and some are even launching their own short-term rental units.

site_title: Oil recovers from 2-week low; US-China trade war caps gains
summary: Oil prices rose 0.3% on Monday, rebounding from a two-week low, to US$56.05 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures and US$62.12 a barrel for Brent crude futures. The gains were tempered by concerns over the global economy and the ongoing US-China trade war. Saudi Arabia's crown prince warned of potential oil price spikes if Iran is not deterred, while the US considers delisting Chinese companies from US stock exchanges, further escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.12 points to 1,584.26. The market saw 31.08 million lots traded worth RM6.44 million, with 73 gainers beating 59 losers. The rally comes as investors brush off new Trump threats, focusing instead on US-EU trade talks and a strong US stock market.

site_title: Practices of online travel booking sites flagged, prompt price transparency guidelines
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has proposed guidelines on price transparency for consumer-facing businesses, including online travel booking sites. The guidelines aim to tackle common practices such as drip pricing, pre-ticked boxes, strikethrough pricing, and pressure selling techniques that can mislead consumers. The CCCS has identified four common pricing practices that can lead to consumers paying more than they bargained for, and recommends that businesses ensure mandatory fees are included in the headline price, avoid pre-ticked boxes, provide clear disclosures of add-ons, and avoid false or misleading claims that create pressure to make an immediate purchase.

images.alt_text: Some Singaporeans paid more than they bargained for when booking their holidays, misled by pricing and marketing practices commonly used by online travel booking providers.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.6% in August: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore bank lending increased 0.6% in August, driven by a rise in business loans to S$422.7 billion, while consumer loans contracted for the fourth consecutive month. Total lending rose 2.2% from a year ago, surpassing July's 2.0% year-on-year gain. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's preliminary data reflects the sector's resilience despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, extending losses from the previous week, ahead of mass pro-democracy protests on China's 70th anniversary. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.36% to 25,860.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.02%.

site_title: 'What are you scared of? My house is full of lawyers', penny stocks saga's Quah allegedly said
summary: Former remisier Tay Peck Gek testified that Quah Su-Ling allegedly responded to his concern about market manipulation by saying "What are you scared of? My house is full of lawyers." Quah and co-accused John Soh Chee Wen stand trial for allegedly manipulating penny stocks Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital, and LionGold Corp in 2012-2013. Prosecution witness Tai Chee Ming stated that Quah and Soh executed trades on accounts belonging to others, avoiding wash trades to conceal their activities. The trial continues with Tai Chee Ming on the stand.

site_title: Goldman's 1MDB case in Malaysia to be moved to higher court
summary: Malaysia is seeking to move the 1MDB-linked case against Goldman Sachs Group to the High Court, citing the seriousness of the case. Units of the US bank face criminal charges of misleading investors in arranging $6.5 billion of bond sales for the state fund 1MDB. Malaysia is seeking fines in excess of $2.7 billion and the return of $600 million. The case has progressed slowly due to difficulties in serving charges against Goldman's units overseas. Goldman aims to resolve the case and "get the Malaysian people the money that they deserve."

images.alt_text: David Cope, head of financial crime compliance for Asia Pacific at Goldman Sachs Group Inc., right, arrives at the Kuala Lumpur Courts Complex in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Monday, Sept. 30, 2019.

site_title: Australia: Shares tick up on miners, energy stocks
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% on Monday, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,725.3, with mining stocks like Rio Tinto and BHP Group up 1.3% and 0.6% respectively. Energy stocks also climbed 1.1% as oil prices recovered. Despite uncertainty in the US-China trade war, markets are pricing in an expected interest rate cut by Australia's central bank.

site_title: CapitaLand associate buying Fullshare's office space in Cecil St tower
summary: A CapitaLand associate is buying the office space at the Cecil Street tower, formerly known as GSH Plaza, from a Fullshare Holdings fund in a deal expected to exceed S$500 million. The space is valued at about S$2,320 per square foot, lower than the S$2,600 psf paid by a Hong Kong-listed China firm in 2017. The deal is structured to give the seller a share of upside in the asset in future, mitigating the loss to the Fullshare fund.

site_title: Australia trims mining, energy export revenue for 2019/20 on trade war
summary: Australia trimmed its mining and energy export revenue expectations for the 2019/20 financial year due to the impact of the US-China trade war on global economic growth. The country now forecasts mining sector revenue at A$282 billion, down A$3 billion from its June forecast. Resource and energy exports, accounting for 60% of Australia's total export earnings, are expected to continue to drive the economy, with iron ore and liquefied natural gas expected to be top earners. However, export earnings are expected to fall to A$258 billion in 2020/21 due to a rising exchange rate and slowing industrial production.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.3% to 3,114.97
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index losing 0.3% to 3,114.97. The banking sector fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank down 0.2%, 0.8%, and 0.1% respectively. Other index stocks, including Singtel and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, also declined. The decline was part of a broader Asian market pullback, with investors weighing trade tensions and China's weakening economy.

site_title: Volkswagen faces first mammoth diesel lawsuit on home turf
summary: Volkswagen is facing a massive diesel lawsuit in Germany, with over 450,000 owners of manipulated diesel cars seeking compensation. The first hearing in a potentially years-long trial began in Brunswick, Germany, on September 30, 2019, with plaintiffs claiming the company deliberately harmed buyers by installing software that allowed vehicles to pollute more on the road. The trial is Germany's largest in the diesel scandal, which has cost Volkswagen over 30 billion euros in fines and compensation.

site_title: Forever 21 files for bankruptcy, adding to retail apocalypse
summary: Forever 21 Inc, a US-based fashion retailer, filed for bankruptcy protection in the Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware, estimating liabilities of $1 billion to $10 billion. The company obtained $275 million in financing and $75 million in new capital to revitalize its brand and fuel growth. A bankruptcy filing could help Forever 21 close unprofitable stores and raise funds, potentially impacting major mall owners like Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners. Founded in 1984, Forever 21 operates over 800 stores globally, specializing in fast-fashion apparel.

site_title: Taiwan shrugs as communist China hails 70th anniversary
summary: Taiwan is shrugging off China's 70th anniversary celebrations, with many younger Taiwanese viewing themselves as a distinct country with autonomy, government, and territory. Despite China's desire to reunify the island, a majority of Taiwanese (55%) now identify solely as Taiwanese, up from 18% in 1992. Older generations still see themselves as part of a wider Chinese family, but the growing Taiwanese identity poses a headache for Beijing's plans. The Chinese government's increasingly assertive rhetoric has failed to win over the Taiwanese, who value their democracy and freedom of speech.

site_title: Consumer gloom in India may dim festive cheer despite tax cuts
summary: Indian consumers may dampen festive cheer despite a US$20 billion tax cut for companies, due to slow economic growth, high unemployment, and tepid private consumption. Car sales in August fell the most on record, and market researchers have lowered their growth estimates for fast-moving goods. However, analysts predict that rural incomes will improve in the second half of the year due to plentiful rainfall and cash handouts to farmers, potentially lifting sales of staples in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Poor demand from Indian consumers could dampen the mood during festivals next month, especially for automobile makers and retailers that count on the season for a sales boost, analysts predict.

site_title: China's September services sector growth slows slightly: official PMI
summary: China's services sector growth slowed slightly in September, with the official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 53.7 from 53.8 in August. The services sector, accounting for over half of China's economy, has been cooling amid a broader slowdown, making businesses and consumers more cautious on spending. The August composite PMI, covering both manufacturing and services, rose to 53.1 from 53.0. The slight slowdown in services sector growth provides a buffer as trade tensions with the US escalate.

site_title: Factory fire kills 19 in east China: official
summary: A factory fire in Ninghai county, eastern Zhejiang province, China, has killed 19 people, with eight rescued and three injured. The incident occurred at a facility owned by the Ruiqi Daily Necessities Company and is under investigation. This is the latest deadly industrial accident in China, following a packed bus collision that killed 36 people and a gas plant explosion that left 15 dead.

site_title: Battered and bruised, Hong Kong cleans up for sensitive Chinese anniversary
summary: Hong Kong cleans up after a chaotic weekend of protests, with police firing water cannons and tear gas at protesters who set fires and vandalized government buildings. The city is on edge ahead of the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic, with authorities seeking to avoid embarrassing scenes. Two democracy activists were arrested, and a series of strikes and demonstrations are planned. The unrest marks the fifth anniversary of the "Umbrella" protests and is fueled by anger over Beijing's interference in Hong Kong's affairs and planned legislation that would have allowed people to be sent to mainland China for trial.

site_title: China September factory activity shrinks for 5th month: official PMI
summary: China's factory activity contracted for the fifth consecutive month in September, according to an official survey, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.8. This marks a slight improvement from August's 49.5. The decline points to persistent downward pressure on China's economy amidst the ongoing trade war with the US. The 50-point mark separates expansion from contraction, indicating a contraction in factory activity. This development raises concerns about the country's economic growth and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: China vows to continue opening financial markets
summary: China reaffirmed its commitment to opening its financial markets to foreign investment, despite US consideration of restrictions on fund flows to China. The country aims to boost the competitiveness and dynamism of its domestic financial system through further financial reform and opening. China may explore alternative markets, such as European and Southeast Asian markets, if the US imposes measures that slow down its efforts. The US Treasury denied contemplating blocking Chinese companies from listing on US stock exchanges, but warned of potential blow-back against US companies if China restricts its access to global markets.

site_title: Trump wants to meet whistleblower in Ukraine scandal
summary: President Donald Trump stated he wants to meet the whistleblower at the center of the Ukraine scandal. The whistleblower filed a complaint in August alleging Trump tried to get a foreign power to interfere in a US election. Trump has been critical of the impeachment inquiry, Democratic lawmakers, and the media, calling the whistleblower's account "inaccurate and fraudulent" and accusing the de facto leader of the inquiry, Adam Schiff, of lying to Congress. Trump wants Schiff questioned at the highest level for "Fraud & Treason."

site_title: Intense Hong Kong clashes ahead of China's 70th anniversary
summary: Fierce clashes broke out between protesters and riot police in Hong Kong on Sunday as thousands marched to protest against the erosion of its special freedoms under Beijing's rule. The clashes occurred ahead of China's 70th anniversary celebrations, which Beijing is preparing to mark with a tightly-choreographed military parade. The ongoing unrest in Hong Kong threatens to upstage the celebrations and cast a shadow over China's global emergence as a superpower. The situation remains volatile, with public anger simmering over the loss of freedoms.

site_title: Indian web giants woo festive shoppers amid slowing economy
summary: Indian e-commerce giants Amazon and Flipkart are launching major sales campaigns ahead of the country's festive season, aiming to boost sales amid a slowing economy. Despite aggressive promotions, online consumer spending has slipped by 20% in the past six months compared to last year. Retailers, including local family-run stores, are also increasing their visibility to compete with online behemoths. Economists believe recent government measures to revive the economy and corporate tax cuts will improve sentiment in the coming years.

site_title: SIIC eyes waste-to-energy business in Shanghai
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has formed a joint venture with Baowu Environment in Shanghai, with 1.1 billion yuan in registered capital. The JV, Shanghai SIIC Baojin'gang Environmental Resources Technology Co Ltd, will focus on power generation, waste management, and slag processing. The deal aims to expand SIIC's waste-to-energy business and serve urban industrial zones in Shanghai. SIIC's directors believe the agreement is on "normal commercial terms" and "fair and reasonable," with no expected material impact on the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau says will grow deficit to fund vote pledges
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced his financial policy ahead of elections, stating he will run a larger deficit to pay for campaign pledges, including tax cuts and investments in the middle-class and students. The projected C$27.4 billion deficit for next year is expected to rise and fall over the following years. Trudeau's campaign has been impacted by controversy surrounding images of him in blackface makeup. The Liberal Party's recent gains among younger voters have been attributed to support from the Green Party.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, extending losses on Wall Street, amid anticipation of key events this week, including China's manufacturing data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.49% and the Topix index dropped 0.72%. The losses follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Five injured in fire at Saudi high-speed train station: state TV
summary: A fire broke out at a high-speed train station in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, injuring five people and causing huge smoke plumes. The station serves the Haramain High Speed Rail system, which connects Mecca and Medina. The fire occurred at 12:35pm local time, and the railway temporarily suspended all trips. The cause of the fire is unknown, and authorities are working to extinguish the blaze. The incident is the latest in Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy by expanding its infrastructure spending, including a $22.5 billion metro system under construction in Riyadh.

site_title: Japan factory output falls as global slowdown keeps biting
summary: Japan's factory production fell 1.2% in August, marking the second consecutive decline in three months, amid a global slowdown that has battered exports. The economy's vulnerability is heightened by a sales tax hike taking effect this week, which may crimp domestic demand. The Bank of Japan is considering more stimulus, following a slowdown in overseas demand, especially in China, and a decline in exports. Retail sales rebounded in August after a prolonged rainy season, but the economy is losing momentum, with recession risk models flashing warnings.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia fends off Malaysian landlord's claim for unpaid rental
summary: Parkson Retail Asia has successfully defended against a Malaysian landlord's claim for unpaid rental of about RM1.5 million (S$500,000) at its M Square Mall store. The Malaysian court ruled that the landlord's notice was an abuse of court process and ordered the landlord to reimburse Parkson RM10,000 for legal costs. Parkson had obtained an injunction restraining the landlord from seeking further action, and will now proceed with an arbitration or legal proceeding against the landlord within 30 days.

site_title: Powder that wig: Paris fashion goes all 18th century
summary: Paris Fashion Week has taken a turn for the 18th century, with designers such as Dries Van Noten, Christian Lacroix, and Thom Browne channeling the era's opulence and grandeur. The trend, which includes powdered wigs, corsets, and crinolines, is seen as a reaction against the dominance of streetwear and sportswear. Designers like Vivienne Westwood and Andreas Kronthaler have cited the period's gender fluidity and fantasy as inspiration, with some even incorporating 18th-century elements into their designs for modern men and women. The trend is expected to continue with a major exhibition on Marie Antoinette opening in Paris next month.

site_title: Palm oil from illegal Indonesia plantation sold to Golden Agri, Musim Mas: forest group
summary: A US-based environmental group, Rainforest Action Network (RAN), has found that palm oil from an Indonesian rainforest, home to endangered orangutans, has entered the supply chains of major consumer brands like Unilever and Nestle. The palm oil was sourced from two mills that supply Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) and Musim Mas Group, which deny wrongdoing despite previous warnings. The companies involved have vowed to investigate and monitor their suppliers to ensure sustainable sourcing practices. The investigation puts pressure on companies to prove their pledges to not fuel deforestation and climate change.

site_title: Britain knows the shape of its proposed Brexit deal: Gove
summary: Britain's government has a clear outline of its proposed Brexit deal, differing significantly from the one negotiated by Theresa May, according to Michael Gove. The government is considering a deal that could be finalized at a Brussels summit on Oct 17-18, with a no-deal Brexit looming if an agreement is not reached.

site_title: FAA system not broken but must be improved: safety panel chief
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) certification process for new airplanes is not broken but needs improvement, according to Christopher Hart, chair of an international air-safety panel. Hart stated that the agency's overall certification process is safe but incidents like the Lion Air and Ethiopian Airlines 737 MAX crashes have shown room for improvement. The panel's recommendations, expected to be released shortly, include harmonizing international regulations and improving communications among regulators.

site_title: International Cement cancels US$104.4m deal to buy African cement producer
summary: International Cement Group (ICG) has cancelled its US$104.4 million deal to purchase African cement producer Schwenk Namibia, citing the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) rejection of the acquisition bid due to Schwenk's non-profitability and ICG's insufficient funds. ICG extended the deal's long stop date to January 31, 2020, but ultimately decided to terminate it. The decision led to a 12.5% drop in ICG shares.

site_title: Nasdaq cracks down on IPOs of small Chinese companies
summary: Nasdaq is tightening restrictions on initial public offerings (IPOs) of small Chinese companies, aiming to increase liquidity and attract US investors. The exchange has raised trading volume requirements and introduced a rule requiring at least 50% of shareholders to invest a minimum of $2,500 each. This move aims to curb the dominance of Chinese investors in these IPOs and improve the market's attractiveness to US institutional investors. The changes follow escalating tensions between the US and China over trade and technology, with some lawmakers introducing a bill to force Chinese companies to submit to regulatory oversight or face delisting.

site_title: Fonterra's August milk output in New Zealand inches up
summary: Fonterra's August milk production in New Zealand increased 0.8% from the previous year, driven by slightly higher rainfall and better pasture cover. In contrast, milk production in Australia dropped 8.4% in July, while Fonterra's milk collection from Australia plummeted 25.5% in August due to high farm input costs and challenging seasonal conditions. The company's dairy exports to China grew 14% in July, driven by increased demand for products such as skim milk and yoghurt, amid its focus on turning its business around after posting a record annual loss.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, SATS, SIIC Environment, Second Chance Properties, International Cement
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Key developments in Singapore stocks include City Developments Limited (CDL) acquiring Millennium & Copthorne shares, SATS selling its stake in Taj Madras Flight Kitchen, and SIIC Environment Holdings forming a joint venture with Baowu Environment. Second Chance Properties plans a bonus issue, while International Cement Group (ICG) cancels its US$104.4 million purchase of Schwenk Namibia. Market trends show a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with stocks like Singtel and Sinarmas Land on watch.

site_title: Fed up with US trade tactics, Europe eyes its own escalation
summary: Europe is considering a more aggressive stance against the US in response to US President Donald Trump's "America First" foreign policy, which has strained transatlantic relations. Disputes over aircraft subsidies and car tariffs are expected to escalate into a trade war, prompting the European Union (EU) to weigh retaliatory measures. The EU is considering tariffs on US goods worth over $8 billion, despite a 2006 agreement resolving the issue. EU officials fear the bloc lacks sufficient ammunition to counter the US, and a trade war could harm the global economy.

site_title: Boeing did not include 'key safeguards' on 737 Max: report
summary: Boeing omitted "key safeguards" from the 737 Max's anti-stall system, similar to an earlier military version, according to a Wall Street Journal report. The MCAS system, implicated in two fatal crashes, relied on a single sensor and was harder for pilots to override. Boeing is working on fixes to make the system more comparable to the earlier version, but a return to service for the 737 Max fleet remains uncertain, more than six months after its grounding.

site_title: Swiss auction supercars seized from Equatorial Guinea president's son for millions
summary: Swiss authorities seized 25 supercars from Equatorial Guinea's president's son, Obiang, in 2016. The cars, including Ferraris and Lamborghinis, were auctioned off in Geneva for 21.6 million euros, exceeding expectations. The funds will be donated to charities helping the poorest in Equatorial Guinea, a country plagued by corruption and poverty. Obiang was previously convicted in France for embezzling state funds and faces ongoing corruption allegations.

site_title: Russia rolls out red carpet for Huawei over 5G
summary: Russia has welcomed Huawei, the world's second-largest smartphone company, by allowing it to develop 5G networks in the country. Huawei opened its first 5G test zone in Moscow this month, with plans to roll out the service to the rest of the city within a few years. Despite US sanctions and concerns over espionage, Moscow has chosen Huawei over other vendors, citing its expertise in 5G technology and commitment to developing 6G. Huawei aims to employ 1,000 more people in Russia over the next five years, with the company already employing 550 in Moscow and Saint Petersburg.

site_title: British businesses losing faith in economy as Brexit approaches
summary: British businesses are losing faith in the economy as Brexit approaches, according to the Lloyds Business Barometer. A measure of optimism fell to its lowest since 2016, with 43% of businesses expecting a negative impact from Brexit. Economists predict a no-deal Brexit will lead to a recession and higher inflation. Despite this, some firms' trading prospects improved and staffing levels increased. The least-confident firms were in Scotland, Northern Ireland, and London. The UK's potential departure from the EU is set for October 31, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson pledging to quit the bloc with or without a deal.

site_title: Fear gaining on US bulls
summary: US stocks fell on a volatile week amid political instability and trade war tensions. The whistleblower report on President Trump's request to Ukraine's President Zelensky has led to calls for an investigation, potentially sparking an impeachment process. Despite this, economists believe the economy remains firm, and the bull market is unlikely to be impacted. However, concerns about the trade war's effects on the economy are growing, with a weak consumer sentiment reading and a slowdown in consumer spending.

site_title: Aides claim Trump the true 'whistleblower' in Ukraine scandal
summary: Top aides to Donald Trump claim the president was the true "whistleblower" in the Ukraine scandal, disputing Democrats' accusations of abuse of power. Trump advisor Stephen Miller and personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani argue that Trump was duty-bound to investigate Joe Biden's son Hunter for corruption in Ukraine, and that Democrats are trying to undermine the president. The whistleblower's identity remains protected, and Democrats plan to call them to testify "very soon."

site_title: BreadTalk founder George Quek buys majority stake in Taiwan department store chain Pacific Sogo
summary: BreadTalk founder George Quek has acquired a majority stake in Taiwan's Pacific Sogo Department Stores through a deal worth over S$275 million. Quek and his business partner Weng Chun-chih will own more than 50% interest in the department store chain, which operates seven stores in Taiwan and five outlets in mainland China. The acquisition is Quek's venture into the department store business and could deepen BreadTalk Group's presence in Taiwan.

site_title: Singapore, EAEU poised to sign FTA, boost closer relationship
summary: Singapore and the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) are set to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) after seven rounds of formal negotiations. The agreement, dubbed EAEUSFTA, aims to boost closer ties between the two parties and create stronger trade and investment links. The EAEU comprises Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Russia, representing a market of 183 million people with a GDP of $1.9 trillion. The agreement is seen as a pathfinder for an FTA between the EAEU and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong calling it a "breakneck speed" in FTA negotiations.

images.alt_text: Mr Pashinyan welcoming PM Lee in an official ceremony at the Armenian Governmental Residence in Yerevan, Armenia, on Sunday.

site_title: Oil prices post weekly loss as supply fears wane
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, posting a weekly loss as Saudi Arabia's faster-than-expected recovery in oil output alleviated supply fears. Brent crude futures dropped 83 US cents, or 1.3%, to settle at $61.91 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 50 cents, or 0.9%, to settle at $55.91 a barrel. The decline was also influenced by concerns over global crude demand amid slowing Chinese economic growth and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: 2013 penny stock crash has made at least half a dozen people bankrupt
summary: At least half a dozen individuals, including a former Phillip Securities broker and a former remisier with OCBC Securities, have been declared bankrupt due to losses incurred in the 2013 penny stock crash, which saw S$350 million in losses. The crash, orchestrated by John Soh Chee Wen and Quah Su-Ling, artificially inflated prices of three companies and led to the bankruptcy of 17 clients with trading losses exceeding S$12 million.

site_title: Clashes between protesters, police intensify in HK
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong clashed with police on Sunday, with thousands marching through the city despite tear gas and rubber bullets. The unsanctioned march was part of a global "anti-totalitarian" movement, with similar protests held in Australia, Taiwan, and Europe. Hong Kongers are demanding greater freedoms and an end to Beijing's erosion of their special rights under the "one country, two systems" policy. The city's unrest has been ongoing for 17 weeks, sparked by an extradition bill and escalating into a call for free elections and less intervention from Beijing.

site_title: 'Unicorns' that wowed investors face hard road on Wall Street
summary: Unicorns, startups valued over $1 billion, are facing a challenging environment on Wall Street due to investors' cautiousness about their profit potential and uncertain economic outlook. Prominent unicorns such as Uber, Lyft, and We Company have experienced significant drops in valuation and stock prices. Analysts attribute this to the startups' delayed listing on Wall Street, with growth slowing down. Despite some high-profile stumbles, the IPO market has been generally positive, with some success stories like Zoom and Beyond Meat.

site_title: Innotek's restructuring sets path to success
summary: Innotek, a Singapore-listed precision metal components manufacturer, has reported a net profit of S$7.7 million in the first half of 2019, up 32.6% from the same period a year earlier. The company's restructuring efforts, led by executive director Lou Yiliang, have focused on automation, cost-cutting, and improving quality. Innotek is shifting its focus to the automotive sector, where it is working on new programs with suppliers like Continental and Bosch. The company's revenue fell 10.7% in the first half, but its profitability has improved.

site_title: US sends belated condolences to France after Chirac death
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo sent belated condolences to France after the death of former President Jacques Chirac, who passed away on September 26, 2007. Pompeo praised Chirac's dedication to public service and his role in promoting democracy and peace. However, the statement avoided mentioning Chirac's opposition to the US invasion of Iraq in 2003. The US government's silence on the matter was notable, particularly given the tension between France and the US at the time. A memorial service was held in Paris, attended by about 30 heads of state, including Russian leader Vladimir Putin.

images.alt_text: People lookl at the coffin of former French President Jacques Chirac lying in state during a memorial ceremony at the Saint-Louis-des-Invalides cathedral at the Invalides memorial complex in central Paris on Sept 29, 2019.

site_title: Hamilton triumphs in Russia to foil Ferrari renaissance
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Russian Grand Prix, his first victory in four races, to foil Ferrari's winning streak. He took the lead from Sebastian Vettel, who suffered a mechanical failure, and held off teammate Valtteri Bottas to secure a one-two finish for Mercedes. Hamilton's win lifted him 73 points clear in the drivers' title race, his ninth of the season and 82nd of his career. Ferrari's Charles Leclerc finished third, while Red Bull's Max Verstappen took fourth place.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market declined further this week, with rates taking a significant downturn despite an initial slight uptick. The Baltic Dry Index plummeted, indicating a significant shift in market momentum. The decline is attributed to various factors, including changes in global demand and supply. The article does not provide a specific conclusion or forecast for the market's future trajectory.

site_title: Regulatory concerns may delay launch of Facebook's Libra: exec
summary: Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency launch may be delayed due to regulatory concerns worldwide. The Libra Association, backed by Facebook, is in talks with regulators in Europe and elsewhere to address concerns. A delay of one or two quarters is being considered, with the goal of launching the digital currency in 2020. The association, comprising 28 members including Vodafone and Mastercard, plans to bring more members on board, including banks, to foster trust and stabilise the price volatility of cryptocurrencies.

site_title: UL moves international HQ to Singapore to ride demand from Asia
summary: UL, a global safety science company, is relocating its international headquarters to Singapore to capitalize on growing demand in Asia. The move is expected to make Asia the majority of the company's business and employment. The Singapore office, led by Sajeev Jesudas, will serve as the international base for UL's operations outside the US. The expansion includes a new EMC-Wireless laboratory and an upgraded Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence, supporting wireless products and secure payments. CEO Keith Williams expects significant growth in Singapore.

site_title: FAA requiring inspections on cracks in some 737 NG planes
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has required inspections and repairs on some Boeing 737 NG jetliners due to structural cracks discovered during modifications on a heavily used aircraft. Boeing notified the FAA of the issue. The inspections will be conducted to identify and address any cracks, and operators will be required to make necessary repairs. This move follows a similar discovery on a 737 MAX plane, which led to a global grounding of the aircraft. The FAA's action aims to ensure the safety of passengers and aircraft operators.

site_title: CDL to compulsorily acquire remaining M&C shares
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) will compulsorily acquire the remaining shares of its London-listed subsidiary Millennium & Copthorne (M&C) held by shareholders who have not accepted the final offer of 685 pence per share. As of Sept 27, valid acceptances amount to 112 million M&C shares, representing approximately 99.21% of the issued ordinary share capital not already owned by CDL. The delisting of M&C shares is expected to take effect on Oct 11, and the company will be re-registered as a private entity.

site_title: OCBC funds food packs for dialysis patients
summary: OCBC's Food from the Heart initiative has launched a curated monthly food pack for needy dialysis patients through its Community Food Pack programme. The programme, benefiting over 4,000 families, will provide healthy food options specifically tailored for dialysis patients for the first time. The initiative aims to support those in need, offering a reliable food ration.

site_title: Solar, wind and batteries threaten future of nuclear power
summary: The US nuclear industry faces significant challenges as cheap natural gas and renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, threaten its future. Despite the advantages of nuclear power, including 24-hour electricity generation without carbon emissions, renewables are gaining ground. Battery prices have plummeted, and new technologies are emerging to provide long-term energy storage. US states are pushing for 100% renewable grids by 2040, while the nuclear industry is developing cheaper alternatives, including modular reactors and molten-salt systems. However, the industry's installed capacity is forecast to fall to 6GW by 2050, and it remains to be seen whether nuclear will remain a prominent player in the power mix.

site_title: L'Oreal celebrates female empowerment with glamorous runway show
summary: L'Oreal hosted its annual runway show in Paris, celebrating female empowerment with an all-star cast of celebrities and models. The event, now in its third edition, featured models from diverse backgrounds, including Korea, Brazil, India, and Mexico. Actress Eva Longoria and model Doutzen Kroes highlighted the importance of self-worth and diversity in the beauty industry. The show aimed to promote female empowerment and diversity, with L'Oreal collaborating with fashion houses such as Balmain and Elie Saab. The event closed with actress Helen Mirren, who ran joyfully on stage in a floral dress.

site_title: New Zealand central bank sees need to improve resilience of financial system
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, has identified vulnerabilities in the country's financial system, including high debt levels concentrated in housing and agriculture. The bank stated that while conditions remain favorable, it needs to improve the resilience of the system. Proposals to raise bank capital requirements have been put forward to address these concerns. Despite these challenges, the bank's report concludes that the financial system is well-equipped to manage current risks.

images.alt_text: [SYDNEY] New Zealand's financial system is well equipped to manage current risks but there is a need to improve resilience, the country's central bank said in its 2018/19 annual report on Monday.

site_title: US businesswoman admitted affair with Boris Johnson: UK report
summary: A US businesswoman, Jennifer Arcuri, who received thousands of pounds from a government agency controlled by Boris Johnson, has admitted to having a sexual affair with him, according to a UK report. Arcuri, 34, had confided to friends that she and Johnson, then mayor of London, were having an affair, which began in 2012. Johnson and Arcuri have denied any wrongdoing, but a police watchdog has referred him to an investigation into possible misconduct in public office. The scandal intensifies the Brexit crisis, which Johnson is struggling to navigate in Parliament.

site_title: No rest for markets despite China holiday
summary: Markets may not experience a significant relief from the US-China trade conflict despite China's upcoming week-long holiday, as the World Trade Organization is expected to approve US tariffs on European goods, potentially triggering retaliatory measures. Key manufacturing data from Singapore, the US, and other major economies will also be released, with some analysts predicting a dip in Singapore's PMI. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to provide insights into interest rates, and protests in China may impact businesses in Singapore.

site_title: Johnson vows to stay put even if no Brexit deal
summary: Boris Johnson vows to remain as UK Prime Minister, even if no Brexit deal is secured by October 31, despite parliament's "surrender act" law that requires him to request a delay. Johnson says his Conservative government can deliver Brexit on time, with or without a deal. He declines to explain how he plans to circumvent the law, adding to uncertainty over the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: Sias clarifies Hyflux stance, supports debt moratorium extension
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, clarified its stance on Hyflux's restructuring agreement with Utico, stating it does not support the deal at this stage due to outstanding issues. Sias instead supports a two-month extension of the debt moratorium to allow for negotiations with Utico and other interested investors. The association also clarified that a poll of Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference holders, which showed 77% support for Utico's offer, was not representative of the views of all holders and was not binding.

site_title: USDSGD poised to climb
summary: The Singapore dollar (USDSGD) is expected to climb as it approaches the upper band of its equidistant channel. Immediate resistance levels are at 1.3815 and 1.3825, with the 200-day moving average also converging with this resistance. The USDSGD is currently supported by the 100-day moving average and the 100 and 200-day moving averages on the daily charts. Technical indicators suggest the USDSGD is overbought and may continue to rise, although possible policy changes and global economic news could impact the currency.

site_title: Sonder takes Airbnb aesthetic to hotels in NY, London and elsewhere
summary: Sonder, a short-term rental startup, is expanding into the hotel industry by signing leases with 17 unique hotels in major cities worldwide. The company offers a blend of home and hotel experiences, targeting a "sweet spot" between the two. With a valuation of over $1 billion, Sonder aims to surpass Marriott's revenue by 2025. Despite concerns about its business model, Sonder's CEO Francis Davidson claims the company can charge 20% less than hotels and provide a seamless guest experience through technology.

site_title: Bridging social gaps
summary: Business leaders can help reduce inequality in society by adopting inclusive practices, such as delivering value to underserved customers, recognizing unconscious bias, and promoting diverse hiring and profit-sharing. They can also collaborate with partners to tackle complex challenges and prioritize social responsibility. By doing so, businesses can build social capital, address inequalities, and contribute to a better life for all. This approach requires a shift in mindset, with business leaders taking a "hippocratic oath" to do no harm, do well, and do good.

site_title: Second Chance Properties to undertake bonus issue of free warrants to subscribe for new shares
summary: SECOND CHANCE PROPERTIES plans to issue free warrants to subscribers for new shares, raising up to S$1.13 billion in gross proceeds. The bonus warrants will be issued to entitled shareholders, with three warrants for every one existing ordinary share. Each warrant allows the holder to subscribe for a new share at S$0.25. The issuance is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval.

site_title: SoftBank plans to get former Sprint boss to help fix WeWork
summary: SoftBank is seeking Marcelo Claure, former Sprint boss, to help turn around WeWork after ousting CEO Adam Neumann. Claure, who oversees Sprint and other SoftBank investments, will help identify revenue and cost-saving opportunities at WeWork. Claure's role has not been finalized, but he will work with WeWork's new leadership to clean up the company. This move comes after WeWork's IPO plan was delayed due to corporate governance concerns and boardroom drama.

site_title: British housing market suffers from fears of no-deal Brexit come Oct 31
summary: The British housing market is experiencing a slowdown due to fears of a no-deal Brexit, with property prices in London dropping 4% in the first quarter. Analysts predict the market will weaken further if Britain exits the EU without a deal, with potential price falls of up to 7.5% next year. Investors are hesitant to overpay for property, and some buyers are finding the market more accessible due to historically-low interest rates and a weaker pound.

site_title: HK's sky-high property prices prove resilient in face of protests
summary: Hong Kong's property market remains resilient despite months of protests, with home prices rising 10% in the first seven months of the year. Limited housing supply and large capital flows from mainland Chinese buyers have driven the growth. Despite concerns over affordability, property prices have hardly budged, with buyers confident in the market's stability. Sales of new apartments continue, with many buyers optimistic about long-term price increases, driven by a fundamental supply shortage.

site_title: Tesla labour practices, Musk tweet broke the law, says judge
summary: A US judge ruled Tesla committed labor law violations, including threatening and retaliating against employees and breaking the National Labor Relations Act. The company must offer reinstatement and back-pay to a fired employee, revoke a warning issued to another, and hold a meeting at its assembly plant. A tweet by Elon Musk in 2018 suggesting employees who joined a union would give up company-paid stock options was found to be in violation of the law. The ruling can be appealed, but the judge stated it will likely be appealed regardless of the outcome.

site_title: US labour judge rules that Tesla broke labour law
summary: A US labour judge has ruled that Tesla Inc interfered with legitimate union organizing and must inform workers of their rights. The company committed several violations of the National Labor Relations Act in 2017 and 2018, including a tweet by CEO Elon Musk that threatened employees with loss of stock options if they voted in favor of the union. The judge ordered Tesla to hold a meeting at its California assembly plant to inform workers of their rights under the law.

site_title: Lucky winner headed for Chiang Mai
summary: A low-profile individual has won a prize, though the article does not specify the nature or amount of the prize, and is headed for Chiang Mai. The winner visited Thailand with three others, playing golf at various courses in Pattaya, and no further details are provided.

site_title: Sias clarifies it does not support Hyflux restructuring agreement 'at this stage'
summary: Sias, a Singapore investors association, clarifies that it does not support Hyflux's restructuring agreement with Utico at this stage. The association supports a two-month extension for Hyflux's debt moratorium to facilitate negotiations with Utico. A poll among Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference holders showed 77% support for Utico's offer, but Sias notes that the poll's results are not representative of all holders and are not binding. If negotiations fail, the extension would allow Hyflux to discuss with other interested investors.

site_title: Facebook, WhatsApp will have to share messages with UK police
summary: Facebook and WhatsApp will share encrypted messages with UK police under a new treaty between the US and UK, set to be signed next month. The accord will allow intelligence agencies to access social media firms' messaging platforms to support investigations into serious crimes like terrorism and pedophilia. Facebook opposes the plan, citing concerns over user privacy and security. The US and UK have agreed not to investigate each other's citizens, while the US won't use British firm information in cases carrying the death penalty.

site_title: Euro rebounds from more than 2-year low
summary: The euro rebounded from a two-year low against the US dollar after falling to a record low of US$1.0903 due to weak growth data from the euro area, particularly Germany. The single currency rebounded to US$1.0938 after testing technical support levels. Analysts attribute the decline to negative interest rates, quantitative easing, and concerns over economic weakness in Europe. Sterling also fell to a two-week low, but later recovered to US$1.2291, while the Chinese yuan weakened amid US portfolio flow discussions.

site_title: US public support Trump impeachment inquiry: Pelosi
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated that public opinion now supports an impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump following the release of new information about his conversations with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy. Pelosi's support for the inquiry evolved after a whistleblower complaint and Inspector General report surfaced, describing Trump's actions as "cavalier" and a potential threat to national security. Pelosi believes the American people are increasingly backing the inquiry, saying a president withholding military assistance to "shake down" another country is a clear abuse of power.

site_title: National player Lee steers car times to BT League Golf crown
summary: National player Donovan Lee won the BT League Golf crown with a strong performance at the final leg. His impressive car times led to speculation about his potential to turn pro. However, no official announcement was made about his professional future. Lee's performance showcased his skills and potential in the golf world, leaving room for further speculation about his next move.

site_title: Gold cuts losses after reports say US mulling delisting China stocks
summary: US President Donald Trump's consideration of delisting Chinese companies from US stock exchanges has led to a decline in gold prices, with spot gold falling 0.5% to $1,498.07 an ounce. The metal had touched its lowest since September 18 earlier in the session. Investors opted for gold's safety amid the US-China trade war and concerns over global economic growth. The US dollar also rose to a three-week peak, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Sunpower targets green investment projects for growth
summary: Sunpower Group Ltd, a Singapore-listed environmental protection solutions provider, is targeting green investment projects for growth. Founded in 1997 by co-founder and executive director Frank Ma, the company has a strong track record and technological expertise, giving it a competitive edge. Sunpower has diversified into pollution control and environmental protection services, with a focus on centralised plants that supply steam, heat, and electricity in industrial parks. The company aims to grow its capacity to 30 million tonnes of steam and 3.5 million megawatt hours of electricity by 2021, driven by its green investments business.

images.alt_text: "Our stable and growing M&S (manufacturing & services) business complements our GI (green investments) unit by efficiently controlling the cost of construction and eliminating project delays," says Mr Ma.

site_title: ST Engineering leads buybacks; Eric Lew takes 10% stake in Y Ventures
summary: ST Engineering led share buybacks among primary-listed stocks, purchasing 400,000 shares for S$1.56 million. Y Ventures Group executive chairman Eric Lew acquired a 10% stake in the company via a S$2 million placement. The Straits Times Index declined 1% over the five sessions, while Reits edged 0.3% higher, bringing the STI's 2019 total return to 5.5%. Other notable transactions included director and substantial shareholder transactions, with close to 140 changes reported across 45 primary-listed stocks.

site_title: SATS to sell 30% stake in Taj Madras Flight Kitchen for S$3.5m
summary: SATS will sell its 30% stake in Taj Madras Flight Kitchen to Taj SATS Air Catering for S$3.5 million. The joint-venture catering business in India aims to acquire 100% ownership of the inflight catering facility. The sale is part of a corporate restructuring exercise to simplify the shareholding structure and reduce costs. The deal will not impact SATS' net tangible assets per share and consolidated earnings per share for the current financial year. Completion is expected to occur in the near future.

site_title: Spectre of Halloween haunts Singapore bourse
summary: The Singapore bourse is bracing for a potentially volatile October, with analysts attributing the "October effect" to a mix of folklore and real-world tensions, including the US-China trade spat, Brexit, and Hong Kong protests. Last year's Halloween month saw the Straits Times Index plummet 7% due to similar global economic concerns. This year's heightened stress may lead to market fluctuations, but Singapore stocks have recently experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, suggesting some optimism.

images.alt_text: The year-long gyrations in the Singapore bourse, similar to those seen in its regional peers, will culminate in an event-packed October with the on-going US-China trade spat, Brexit deadline, Hong Kong protests and political uncertainty in Washington adding more stress.

site_title: China markets to test risk of most extreme US threat yet
summary: The US Treasury is reportedly discussing ways to limit American money going to Chinese entities, potentially restricting access to US finance. This move could impact China's markets, with the MSCI China Index falling 1.6% on Friday. The US has $1.2 trillion in market capitalization of Chinese companies on US exchanges, and limiting this access could force Chinese firms to relist in Hong Kong and China. The move adds uncertainty to the US-China trade negotiations and could have a profound impact on Chinese companies listed on US exchanges.

site_title: McLaren to switch back to Mercedes engines from 2021
summary: McLaren will switch back to Mercedes engines starting from the 2021 season, ending its partnership with Renault. The decision was made due to the Mercedes engine being stronger and cheaper than Renault's. McLaren's drivers, Carlos Sainz and Lando Norris, will continue to compete with the German company, which also supplies engines to Mercedes' factory team, Racing Point, and Williams. The change is expected to be officially announced ahead of the Russian Grand Prix.

site_title: Nestle, P&G say they will miss 2020 deforestation goals
summary: Nestle and Procter & Gamble, the world's two largest consumer goods companies, have admitted they will miss their 2020 deforestation goals. Nestle now predicts 90% of its key commodities will be deforestation-free by the end of 2020, short of its original goal. Procter & Gamble also fell short of its target to establish zero deforestation in its supply chain by 2020. The companies' pledges were made in 2010, and advocacy groups have long been skeptical of their commitment to reducing deforestation.

site_title: XMH Holdings to dispose 80% stake in Z-Power Automation unit
summary: XMH Holdings will sell its 80% stake in loss-making subsidiary Z-Power Automation (ZPA) for S$1 to individual Goo Koh Chai. ZPA's business accounts for approximately 16.4% of the group's total revenue, but it has reported losses of S$3.2 million, S$1.8 million, and S$3.8 million for FY2017, FY2018, and FY2019, respectively. The disposal is seen as a strategic move to restructure the company.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on weak data, trade worries
summary: US stocks fell on Friday due to weak economic data and trade worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes fell 0.5% and 1.1%, respectively. Reports suggested the Trump administration is considering new restrictions on US investment in China, which contributed to the decline. Additionally, weak consumer spending and manufacturing demand were reported, raising concerns about the economy's hit from the trade war with China.

site_title: Apple streaming service films could debut in theatres: report
summary: Apple is reportedly making cinema alliances to allow its streaming service, Apple TV+, to debut in theaters, aiming to boost the service's prestige and attract top talent. The move could also qualify TV+ films for major industry awards. Apple TV+ will launch on November 1 in over 100 countries at $4.99/month, featuring original shows, movies, and documentaries. The service will compete with Netflix and Amazon Prime, offering a lower price point than Disney+. Apple will offer the first year of the service for free to customers who purchase an eligible device.

images.alt_text: Apple is making cinema alliances that would allow theatre debuts for films created for its online streaming service set to launch in November, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.

site_title: Tried & tested
