summary: Hong Kong billionaire Tony Yeung, managing director of Peterson Group, says the rich need to help address the city's social issues. Yeung, who has a net worth of $4-5 billion, has pledged to support philanthropic efforts, including funding ventures such as Light Be and Hatch, which aim to address housing affordability and job training. Despite the city's financial struggles, Yeung remains optimistic and believes the city will recover, citing its resilience during the 2008 global financial crisis. Yeung's efforts are part of a broader push by the city's wealthy elite to address the root causes of the protests, which have been driven by demands for democracy and better living conditions.

site_title: China says has no intent to play 'Game of Thrones' but warns on sovereignty
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi warned the US to respect its sovereignty, including in Hong Kong, during a speech at the UN General Assembly, amid a trade dispute between the two countries. Wang rejected US accusations of China's "Game of Thrones" ambitions and said Beijing would not bow to threats. He urged cooperation for mutual benefit and expressed hope for positive results in high-level trade talks next month. Wang also rejected US criticism of China's treatment of its Muslim minority in Xinjiang, saying actions were taken to prevent extremism and terrorism.

site_title: Trek 2000's Henn Tan, 3 others charged with falsification, cheating, among others
summary: Trek 2000's chairman emeritus Henn Tan, 63, and three former officers face charges of falsification, cheating, and forgery, with Tan accused of committing 15 offences including falsifying entries in financial statements and deceiving external auditors. The charges date back to 2006 and could result in imprisonment and fines of up to S$250,000. Tan and the others were granted bail of S$300,000 to S$400,000, and their cases will be mentioned on November 6.

site_title: Australian billionaire to back A$20b project to supply solar power to Singapore: report
summary: Australian billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes has pledged to help fund an A$20 billion project to supply solar power from northern Australia to Singapore via a subsea cable. The project, led by Singapore-based firm Sun Cable, aims to build the world's largest solar farm in the Northern Territory and export 3 gigawatts of power to Singapore. Cannon-Brookes, a vocal advocate for renewable energy, plans to finance the project through his family fund Grok, with an announcement expected before the end of the year.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Trump impeachment inquiry; New Zealand steady
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 43.2 points to 6,705.80, due to the US House of Representatives opening an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump. The inquiry, which will examine whether Mr. Trump sought Ukraine's help to smear former Vice-President Joe Biden, led to a decline in the S&P 500 on Wall Street. Markets were also anxious about US-China trade tensions, with iron ore prices falling and miners leading losses.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Masai says ready to ease further if price momentum lost
summary: Bank of Japan board member Takako Masai expressed readiness to ease policy further if price momentum is lost in achieving its 2% inflation target. She highlighted concerns over significant downside risks from overseas economies, particularly the negative impact on prices. Masai emphasized the central bank's willingness to consider all possible effects in guiding policy decisions, as a former commercial bank executive. Her comments came as the BOJ continues to navigate economic challenges amid global uncertainty.

site_title: Alibaba unveils self-developed AI chip for cloud computing division
summary: Alibaba has developed a self-designed AI chip, called Hanguang 800, for its cloud computing division. The chip specializes in machine-learning tasks and is currently used for product search, translation, and recommendations on Alibaba's websites. Alibaba has no immediate plans to sell the chip as a standalone product, unlike overseas tech giants like Alphabet and Facebook. This move is part of Beijing's efforts to promote China's semiconductor industry and reduce reliance on foreign imports of core technologies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.46 points to 1,591.87 at 9am. The market saw 65.27 million lots traded worth RM34.03 million, with losers beating gainers 73 to 59. This is the first update from the article, as the rest of the provided content appears to be unrelated to the Malaysia share market.

site_title: Temasek's SGX-listed trusts averaged 42.2% return in 3 years; DBS is portfolio's top performer
summary: Temasek Holdings' Singapore-listed investments averaged a 42.2% three-year return, with the 10 trusts in its portfolio delivering the highest returns. DBS was the top performer among the 15 SGX-listed companies, with a three-year return of 88.5%. The 10 trusts, led by Mapletree Logistics Trust, averaged a 75.6% three-year return. Temasek's portfolio has grown by S$41 billion in its Singapore exposure over the last decade, with a 40% exposure to Asia ex-Singapore and 34% to the rest of the world.

site_title: JPMorgan invests US$25m in fintech startups
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is investing $25 million in the Financial Solutions Lab to support fintech startups that help low-income Americans achieve financial health. The investment aims to provide early-stage fintech companies with products that can positively impact communities like Harlem. JPMorgan's head of global philanthropy, Karen Keogh, believes that fintech, in-person coaching, and behavioral nudging are crucial for financial well-being and will contribute to building strong economies.

site_title: China plans triumphant 70th anniversary despite headwinds
summary: China marks its 70th anniversary of Communist rule next week with a massive military parade in Beijing, despite headwinds from trade tensions with the US, pro-democracy unrest in Hong Kong, and international criticism of human rights abuses. President Xi Jinping will showcase China's economic and military power, while the anniversary comes as the country faces a slowing economy and rising food prices. Xi has tightened his grip on power, eliminating presidential term limits and cracking down on civil society, and is expected to use the anniversary to send a message that the party can overcome challenges to emerge stronger.

site_title: Collapse of Thomas Cook is a reality check for China's Fosun
summary: China's Fosun Group, led by billionaire Guo Guangchang, has faced a reality check with the collapse of its European investment, Thomas Cook, due to a US$1.1 billion bailout package being rejected by creditors. The company's reluctance to commit more funds highlights concerns over Fosun's expansion strategy amid a slowing global economy and trade war. Fosun's debt, totaling US$28 billion, and its focus on hospitality, healthcare, and finance businesses may signal a pause in its overseas acquisitions, with the company's last major deal in the tourism space being the failed rescue of Thomas Cook.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall on Trump impeachment move, trade fears
summary: Asian stock markets fell on September 25, 2019, following US Democrats' formal impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump and renewed trade concerns. The US market closed before the announcement, but Asian markets reacted negatively to the news. Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai dropped 0.5-0.4% respectively. Oil prices fell 0.6% due to Trump's tough talk on China, while the British pound slipped against the dollar amidst Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following Wall Street's decline, amid the US-China trade tensions. The Hang Seng Index fell 249.59 points, or 0.95%, to 26,031.41. The slump was attributed to the Democrats' formal impeachment proceedings against Donald Trump and the president's hard line on China ahead of key trade talks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking falls on Wall Street due to a higher yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.61% or 133.88 points to 21,964.96, while the Topix index declined 0.54% or 8.76 points to 1,614.18.

site_title: New Zealand central bank stands pat on policy, flags scope for more stimulus
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) held its official cash rate (OCR) at 1.0% as expected, but indicated scope for more fiscal and monetary stimulus to support the economy. The decision follows a 50 basis-point cut in August to combat the economy's slowdown and Sino-US trade war impact. Despite no change in monetary policy, the RBNZ stated there's room for more stimulus to meet inflation and employment objectives, signaling a cautious approach to monetary policy.

site_title: DBS eyes 3.5m PayLah! e-wallet users by 2023
summary: DBS Bank aims to double its mobile wallet users to 3.5 million by 2023, from 1.6 million. The bank plans to roll out new initiatives to expand DBS PayLah! functionalities, including payment touchpoints and partnerships. DBS has signed over 10 partnerships with lifestyle merchants in Singapore, including KFC and Sistic. The bank's P2B transactions have grown exponentially, with 65% of PayNow registrants being DBS/POSB customers. DBS aims to offer a seamless user experience through integrated rewards and payment options by 2020.

site_title: 135m new Keppel DC Reit units start trading on Sept 25
summary: Keppel DC Reit has begun trading 135 million new units on the Singapore bourse, part of its S$478.2 million equity fundraising to acquire two data centers. The new units, issued at S$1.744 per unit, represent 9% of the Reit's enlarged share capital. The units are pari passu with existing units and will receive distributions from Sept 25 onwards. The Reit's total units now stand at approximately 1.5 billion, with units closing at S$1.94 on Tuesday.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm Ensign promotes Tammie Tham to CEO
summary: Cybersecurity firm Ensign InfoSecurity has promoted Tammie Tham to CEO, replacing interim CEO Yeoh Keat Chuan. Tham, a 19-year industry veteran, will lead the company in its next phase of growth. Ensign, a 60-40 joint venture between Temasek Holdings and StarHub, employs 500 cybersecurity professionals and plans to increase its headcount to 600 by next year. Tham's appointment comes after the company established a global headquarters in Singapore and a new security operations centre.

images.alt_text: Ensign's new chief Tammie Tham was most recently the company's executive vice-president for enterprise and services. She replaces interim CEO Yeoh Keat Chuan from Temasek International.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady but Brexit worries pressure London shares
summary: European stocks closed steady on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 down 0.5% due to concerns over Brexit uncertainty. The pound rallied after the Supreme Court ruled that UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's parliament suspension was unlawful, reducing the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit. Investors sought defensive sectors like healthcare and travel, with travel stocks rising 1.2% after Thomas Cook's collapse. Despite this, economists warn that the UK economy will remain below-par until Brexit is resolved.

site_title: Pacific Radiance seeks further extension of debt moratorium
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine services firm, has applied to Singapore's High Court to extend a debt moratorium set to expire on October 17, 2019. The company, along with its two units, has also proposed meeting with creditors to discuss schemes of arrangement. The applications will be heard on October 7. Pacific Radiance is seeking debt funding of at least US$180 million and has had its shares trading voluntarily suspended since February 2019.

site_title: US Democrats to launch formal impeachment inquiry of Trump
summary: US Democrats are launching a formal impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump amid allegations of abuse of power, particularly in regards to his reported attempt to pressure Ukraine into investigating Joe Biden and his son Hunter. The inquiry, announced by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, marks a significant escalation of calls for Trump's removal from office. Trump has denied any wrongdoing, but his actions have sparked widespread criticism and support for impeachment from Democrats, including former Vice President Biden.

site_title: Vietnam's US$5b plan to neutralise Trump's tariff threats
summary: Vietnam is investing $5 billion in a liquefied natural gas project to reduce its trade deficit with the US. The project, led by Energy Capital Vietnam, aims to import US fuel and buy American products, including natural gas from Texas, coal from Pennsylvania, and aircraft engines. Vietnam's Communist government, under Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc, is seeking to boost its relationship with the US and avoid China's fate, which was threatened by President Donald Trump's tariffs. The project is part of a broader effort to trim Vietnam's trade surplus with the US, which hit $40 billion in 2018.

site_title: China's Tesla rival NIO plunges 26% on escalating losses
summary: NIO, China's electric-vehicle rival to Tesla, plummeted 26% after announcing a record quarterly loss of 3.29 billion yuan, exacerbating concerns about a bubble in China's EV market. The company's second-quarter net losses increased 83% from last year, with thousands of job cuts and plans to spin off non-core businesses. NIO's US-listed shares have fallen over 80% from their peak, with analysts estimating the company has only a few weeks of liquidity left. The dire situation has lent credence to concerns that China's state-sponsored support of the industry inflated a bubble poised to pop.

site_title: SingPost unveils smart stamp, letterbox prototypes
summary: SingPost unveils prototypes for a smart stamp and letterbox system, aiming to reduce lost and misdelivered mail, and improve delivery efficiency. The system uses data matrix codes and facial recognition to track mail items, allowing residents to track mail and retrieve it from a storage unit. The innovations, claimed as world firsts, could address productivity challenges and significantly reduce SingPost's carbon footprint. Implementation plans are unclear, with discussions with authorities underway, and no concrete cost estimates have been revealed.

site_title: Impeaching a US President: How the process works
summary: The US House of Representatives launched an official impeachment investigation of President Donald Trump after he encouraged a foreign leader to conduct a probe that could damage a political rival, Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy. The investigation follows Trump's public admission that he asked Zelenskiy to investigate the son of presidential candidate Joe Biden. The process of impeachment involves the House bringing charges, which would then move to the Senate for a trial to determine the president's guilt, requiring a two-thirds majority vote to convict and remove the president.

site_title: Singapore shares track Wall Street to open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.6% to 3,136.57
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday, mirroring Wall Street losses, to 3,136.57. The decline came after US President Donald Trump made a hawkish statement on trade and Democrats launched formal impeachment proceedings. The benchmark S&P 500 dropped 0.8%, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 1.5%. Key stocks fell, including Rex International Holding and OCBC Bank, while DBS, United Overseas Bank, and Singapore Exchange were also subdued. Asian equities also faltered, with Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi down 0.6% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: WeWork founder Neumann steps aside
summary: WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann stepped down as CEO, citing scrutiny and distractions, as the company tries to reposition its initial public offering campaign. Neumann, 40, will remain chairman and has faced criticism over his business approach, self-dealing, and ability to make the company profitable. The company has struggled with its bottom line, losing almost $2 billion in 2018. Neumann's departure marks a shift in fortune for the charismatic entrepreneur, who has been embraced by investors despite his unconventional business practices.

site_title: How 'Heidi' conquered Japan, sparking an anime revolution
summary: Swiss character designer Yoichi Kotabe's 1970s anime series "Alps no Shojo Heidi" played a significant role in Japan's booming anime industry, boosting the careers of creators Isao Takahata and Hayao Miyazaki. The 52-part series, which became a worldwide hit, featured a redesigned Heidi character with distinctive features, including ruffled, short, dark locks. The series' success had a lasting impact on Japanese culture, inspiring a dedicated Heidi museum, hiking trail, and souvenir shops in the Swiss village of Maienfeld, where the series was set.

images.alt_text: Heidi and Super Mario may not seem to have much in common but anime and video game aficionados will detect the signature style of Japanese character designer Yoichi Kotabe in both.

site_title: New Zealand announces plans to regulate conduct of banks, insurers
summary: New Zealand plans to regulate the conduct of banks and insurers with new measures, including a ban on target-based sales incentives. The government will introduce a new conduct licensing system, requiring financial institutions to meet specified standards of customer treatment. The Financial Markets Authority will have the power to direct institutions to change behavior and impose strong financial penalties for breaching obligations. The measures follow a review by regulators, which found weaknesses in banks' risk management and a disappointing response from life insurers to a conduct and culture review.

site_title: Payout to government raises questions about RBI's independence
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), is transferring 1.76 trillion rupees (S$34 billion) to the government, raising questions about its independence. The move, aimed at reducing capital ratios, follows a clash between the RBI and the finance ministry. The bank's governor, Urjit Patel, and his deputy left the institution after disagreements with the government. The transfer has sparked concerns about the central bank's autonomy, with some experts suggesting the government could use the funds to recapitalize nationalized banks or pay off debt.

site_title: Nissan, Carlos Ghosn fined over claims they hid more than US$140m in pay
summary: Nissan Motor Co and former CEO Carlos Ghosn have settled US$15 million and US$1 million fines, respectively, with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over claims they hid more than US$140 million in pay. Ghosn, 65, was barred from serving as a director or officer for 10 years, while former director Greg Kelly, 63, received a 5-year ban. The SEC alleges Ghosn used broad authority to set his own compensation, excluding US$90 million from public statements. Nissan cooperated with the SEC and has implemented remedial acts to prevent recurrence.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Congress opens impeachment probe of Trump; pound gains
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as congressional Democrats launched a formal impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, citing an abuse of power in his dealings with Ukraine. The pound gained against the dollar and euro after a British court ruled Prime Minister Boris Johnson's suspension of parliament was unlawful, potentially hindering a no-deal Brexit. The market is uncertain about the implications of the impeachment probe and its potential impact on consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks fell on Tuesday as congressional Democrats moved towards launching formal impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump, while the British pound gained on a sweeping court ruling that dimmed the chances for a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine C&C, Keppel Corp, Keppel DC Reit, Kimly, Shinvest, Trendlines
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singapore stocks are making headlines due to new developments. Jardine Cycle & Carriage's outgoing group managing director is optimistic about Indonesia's automotive industry, despite a soft patch in new car sales. Keppel Corporation issued S$200 million 7-year notes at 3% interest, while Keppel DC Reit began trading 135 million new units. Kimly plans to buy a coffeeshop property for S$14 million, and Shinvest hit a 52-week high of S$2.10. The Trendlines Group received conditional commitments of up to US$22 million for its new venture fund, and Mirach Energy's shares were flagged for caution by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Ukraine affair adds to slew of investigations into Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing multiple investigations, including a formal impeachment inquiry, over allegations of abusing his power by asking Ukraine to provide dirt on his Democratic rival, Joe Biden. The inquiry was announced by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, amid a slew of lawsuits and probes by Democratic-led congressional committees and New York prosecutors. These investigations are part of a growing list of accusations against Trump, who is now facing serious charges related to his Ukrainian scandal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Delong Holdings, a steelmaker, will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange on September 26 after its CEO Ding Liguo's privatisation offer closed with 98.75% ownership. The offeror and concert parties accepted the independent financial adviser's recommendation to accept the offer. PS Group Holdings, another company, has also accepted a private takeover offer deemed fair and reasonable by its independent directors and an independent financial adviser.

site_title: Trade tensions darken growth outlook for developing Asia: ADB
summary: Escalating US-China trade tensions have darkened the growth outlook for developing Asia, with the region expected to grow 5.4% this year and 5.5% next year, down from previous forecasts. The Asian Development Bank attributes this to the persistence of the trade conflict and declining investment, with China's economy projected to grow 6.2% this year and 6.0% in 2020. South Asia is expected to remain the fastest-growing region, while South-east Asia's growth is forecast to slow to 4.5% this year and 4.7% next year.

images.alt_text: Escalating trade tensions between the United States and China have darkened the outlook for developing Asia, with the region expected to grow slower than previously predicted this year and next, the Asian Development Bank said on Wednesday.

site_title: Google wins EU court fight over 'right to be forgotten'
summary: Google has won a European Union court battle over plans to impose a global "right to be forgotten," with the EU Court of Justice ruling that search engines should only remove results on European versions of their websites. The court found there is "no obligation under EU law" for links to be removed from all versions of Google's search engine worldwide. The ruling allows Google to weigh privacy concerns against users' right to know in each individual case, rather than globally.

site_title: Venezuelans accused of smuggling US$5m in gold into US
summary: Two Venezuelans, Jean Carlos Sanchez Rojas and Victor Fossi Grieco, have been charged with smuggling US$5 million worth of gold bars into the US via a private airplane. The gold, weighing approximately 104kg, was discovered in the airplane's nose compartment during a customs inspection at Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport. Both men claimed they had obtained the gold from multiple sources in Venezuela and intended to sell it in the US, but failed to declare it in their customs forms. They were arrested on September 20.

site_title: Creating value and differentiation in the 'post digital era'
summary: In the "post-digital era," businesses must create value and differentiation for stakeholders, investing in internal digital capabilities and external trends to meet evolving expectations. The era is characterized by personalized experiences, and companies must deliver tailored value to customers, employees, and partners. Five critical internal capabilities and five external technology trends identified by Accenture Research and Technology Vision professionals are key to success, including knowledge of trends and investment in digital capabilities. This shift requires a transformation journey, supported by a change campaign outlining benefits to all stakeholders.

site_title: STI rises 0.4% amid cautious optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.39% to close at 3,155.46, following cautious optimism from US economic data and eased tensions on the US-China trade front. Chinese importers bought 600,000 tonnes of US soybeans, and the US confirmed Oct 7 as the date for the next round of Sino-US trade talks. Despite this, traders remain cautious, with analysts warning of market volatility due to trade headlines. Gains were seen in Jardine Cycle & Carriage, Singapore Exchange, and Shinvest Holding, while TEE International and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding also rose.

site_title: Malaysia's 5G plan advances, a potential boon for China's Huawei
summary: Malaysia is set to launch a nationwide 5G demonstration project next month, potentially making it one of the first Asian countries to adopt the technology. The country's government has chosen to work with Huawei, despite US concerns over the company's equipment being used for spying. Malaysia's Minister of Communications and Multimedia, Gobind Singh Deo, said the country aims to position itself as a leader in 5G adoption. Huawei has preliminary agreements with Malaysian companies and expects to lead to contracts, with the technology set to support new technologies such as autonomous driving.

site_title: Malaysia competition watchdog steps up probe into Singapore's Grab
summary: Malaysia's Competition Commission is investigating Singapore-based ride-hailing startup Grab Holdings Inc for monopolistic practices. The probe follows complaints that Grab acquired Uber's Southeast Asian operations, and comes as the country aims to increase competition in its economy. The investigation is part of a broader push by the government to expose state-linked companies to competition and introduce open tenders. The move is seen as a key pledge by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad to lower the cost of living for Malaysians and enhance the country's standing as a business destination.

site_title: German steel giant Thyssenkrupp's board recommends sacking CEO
summary: Thyssenkrupp's supervisory board recommends replacing CEO Guido Kerkhoff, citing concerns over his handling of the company's restructuring efforts, including the failed merger with Tata and major job cuts. Kerkhoff will be replaced by Martina Merz as chairwoman on the executive board for 12 months. The move comes as the company struggles to regain its blue-chip status after a 60% decline in shares since 2018. Thyssenkrupp had previously announced plans to scrap the merger bid and list its elevators business on the stock market.

images.alt_text: Struggling German industrial conglomerate Thyssenkrupp, which has in recent months suffered merger setbacks and lost its blue-chip status, late Tuesday signalled plans to replace its CEO Guido Kerkhoff.

site_title: Ponzi ploys morph in post-Madoff era
summary: Ponzi schemes have evolved since the Madoff case, with scammers targeting investors with untraditional products such as natural resource mining and cryptocurrencies. According to a New York Times analysis, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) brought 50% more Ponzi prosecutions in the decade after Madoff's arrest than in the previous decade. Victims lost $31 billion, more than three times the amount lost in non-Madoff schemes. Scammers are using new tactics, including modest returns and bonding with victims over shared interests, to ensnare unwary investors.

site_title: Emage Vision's automated systems can replace human inspectors
summary: Emage Vision, a Singapore-based company, has developed automated machine vision systems that can replace human inspectors, enhancing production efficiency and quality. Chairman Charles Cher notes that the company's machine-learning vision inspection system is a hybrid system incorporating the best of machine vision and machine learning, successfully implemented in the production floor since 2019. Emage Vision aims to disrupt the machine vision industry with its innovative solutions, increasing customer yield, reducing costs, and boosting productivity, while considering an initial public offering in the future.

site_title: Oil drops to lowest since Aramco attacks after Trump scolds China
summary: Oil prices plummeted 2.6% to their lowest since the September 14 attacks on Saudi Arabia's key oil facilities, following US President Donald Trump's scolding of China over trade practices. The US-China trade conflict reignited fears of reduced energy demand, contributing to the oil price drop. Brent crude futures settled at $63.10 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate futures ended at $57.29 a barrel. Analysts predict continued oil demand growth may be hampered by the prolonged trade war and oversupply in the market.

site_title: Pavilion Energy plans to hire 50 employees for Madrid office after Iberdrola deal
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Singapore-based liquefied natural gas importer, plans to open an office in Madrid after purchasing Iberdrola SA's LNG business. The new office will hire up to 50 employees for front and back-office operations, marking a step towards becoming a global energy player. CEO Frederic Barnaud stated that the Madrid office will be a "real company, not a rep office," allowing for centralized risk management and coordination.

site_title: US consumer confidence plunges in September
summary: US consumer confidence plummeted to 125.1 in September, the largest drop in nine months, due to escalating trade and tariff tensions. This marked a significant shortfall from economists' expectations of 133.5. The reading fell from 134.2 in August, with the expectations index declining to 95.8 from 106.4. The decline in consumer confidence reflects a worsening economic outlook for Americans.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler manager charged in US diesel emissions case
summary: Fiat Chrysler manager Emanuele Palma, 40, has been charged with misleading US environmental regulators over the company's use of "defeat devices" to evade emissions tests. The company agreed to pay over $500 million to settle charges, recalling 100,000 diesel vehicles sold in the US. Palma allegedly knowingly misled EPA regulators to cover up illegal emissions control software installed in certain Fiat Chrysler diesel vehicles. This is part of a larger emissions scandal that has engulfed multiple automakers, including Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution when dealing in Mirach Energy shares
summary: SGX RegCo has urged caution when dealing in Mirach Energy shares due to a small group of individuals responsible for nearly 70% of the buy volume over a 7-month period. The group's trades led to a 21% increase in the stock price between April 29 and May 15, despite the Straits Times Index falling 5.53% during the same period. Mirach Energy's market capitalisation increased by around S$18 million to S$44.5 million between Feb 8 and Sept 20. SGX RegCo is reviewing the trades and will take necessary actions.

site_title: Capabilities of firms, workforce buffer for headwinds
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of companies and workers' capabilities in helping Singapore weather economic headwinds. He highlighted Applied Materials, a US firm that has invested over $100 million in Singapore, as an example of a strong partner. The government has committed $19 billion to its Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2020 plan, which includes advanced manufacturing, and has recognized Applied Materials as a winner of the Distinguished Partner in Progress Award.

site_title: South Korean leader proposes peace zone buffering North
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-In proposed the creation of an "international peace zone" to replace the Demilitarized Zone between North and South Korea. The 4km-wide zone would offer a guarantee for North Korea's security and allow for the removal of estimated 380,000 mines. Moon hopes the zone will become a UNESCO world heritage site and boost demining efforts. Despite optimism, North Korea has not taken concrete steps to end its nuclear program, and US President Trump expressed a positive tone towards Kim Jong Un, but did not consider additional pressure on North Korea.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Moon Jae In on Tuesday proposed that the United Nations create an "international peace zone" to replace the peninsula's divide, saying the idea would both reassure the North and inspire the world.

site_title: Grab says its contribution to SEA economy totals US$5.8b
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing giant, has contributed $5.8 billion to the region's economy in the 12 months leading up to March 2019, primarily through its platform and Kudo unit. The company aims to achieve three social impact goals by 2025, including digital literacy for 3 million South-east Asians, digitizing traditional businesses, and training 20,000 students. Grab has partnered with Microsoft to upskill workers and increase digital literacy, and is expanding its "Break the Silence" initiative for deaf drivers to reach more countries.

site_title: Euro below US$1.10 as fears of recession increase
summary: The euro held below US$1.10 due to concerns about a potential recession in Europe, despite a positive German business morale survey. The single currency has been stable, but fears of an economic slowdown have prompted hedge funds to increase negative bets against the euro. The European economy is expected to slip into recession, driven by the US-China trade conflict and Brexit.

site_title: UK court annuls parliament suspension in blow to Johnson
summary: The UK Supreme Court has unanimously ruled that Prime Minister Boris Johnson's suspension of parliament was unlawful, allowing parliament to convene immediately. The decision is a significant blow to Johnson, who has seen his authority weakened by a series of losses in parliament. The ruling comes just weeks before the UK's Brexit deadline and raises questions about the UK's ability to leave the EU on October 31. Johnson has refused to resign, but the decision is seen as a major victory for the rule of law and democracy, with many calling for a second referendum on Brexit.

site_title: China's central bank says in no rush to ease aggressively
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang stated that the country has ample options to stimulate its economy, but is in no rush to implement aggressive monetary policies. Despite a slowdown in growth, the PBOC is considering measures such as quantitative easing, but will maintain a cautious approach. China cut its benchmark lending rate for the second month, but the move was smaller than other central banks. Authorities will focus on sustainable development and people's livelihood, while also stepping up reforms and improving monetary policy transmission mechanisms.

images.alt_text: Mr Yi says Chinese authorities would maintain "normal" monetary policy for as long as possible.

site_title: Training programme to prepare those with disabilities for F&B jobs
summary: Singapore's Samsui Supplies & Services and Sodexo have launched a six-month "train-and-place" programme to equip individuals with disabilities for F&B industry careers. The programme, supported by SG Enable, exposes trainees to culinary skills and operations, and offers on-the-job training. Upon completion, trainees may be matched to suitable positions in Sodexo's network or partner F&B operators. The initiative aims to build independence and job opportunities for individuals with disabilities, fostering a supportive ecosystem for their growth.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of State Edwin Tong (third from right) with programme trainees and guests try their hand at making pau.

site_title: Aviva's Asian units attract interest from global suitors: sources
summary: Global insurers Allianz, Nippon Life, and MS&AD are vying to buy Aviva's Singapore and Vietnam businesses in a deal worth up to $2.5 billion. Other suitors include Canada's Sun Life Financial and Manulife Financial Corp. The divestment would capitalize on Asia's growing economies and relatively low insured population, expected to account for 42% of global premiums by 2029. The sale would add to regional insurance sector M&A momentum, following FWD's expansion efforts. Aviva aims to finalize the deal by year-end.

site_title: Creating more 'Jewels' in Singapore
summary: Singapore's development industry faces significant challenges, including the need for all parties to pull their weight in implementing massive projects. Key issues include outdated procurement practices, a lack of qualified professionals, and the focus on short-term profit maximization over stakeholders' interests. To address these challenges, developers, consultants, and contractors must adopt a paradigm shift in mindset, prioritizing stakeholders' interests, including community, employees, and the environment. Implementing progressive procurement practices, investing in technology, and promoting innovation and productivity can help drive the industry forward, ultimately benefiting Singapore's long-term development and sustainability.

images.alt_text: The recently opened Jewel Changi Airport with all its features and facilities did not happen by chance. It is an excellent example of the close collaborative work by all project participants.

site_title: Tale of two cities for recent condo launches
summary: Four recent condo launches in Singapore saw lukewarm sales, with Uptown@Farrer and The Antares selling 12 and 17 units, respectively, at median prices of S$1,860 and S$1,794 per square foot. In contrast, Avenue South Residence achieved 276 unit sales at a median price of S$3,341 per square foot. Analysts attribute the tepid sales to high pricing, with median unit prices above those of comparable freehold projects. The developers likely opted to launch now despite slim profit margins to capitalize on the Greater Southern Waterfront's positive news.

site_title: Short-volatility ETF bet shows hunt is on for returns
summary: A 5-month-old credit ETF, TVOL, has become one of the largest short-volatility instruments in the world, attracting a net inflow of 62 million euros. The fund, which tracks global high-yield debt, offers a racy way to ride the credit bull amidst dovish central banks and economic growth. Traders are seeking alternative sources of returns, with yield-hungry investors drawn to the fund's 2% carry return and 25% drawdown risk. The fund's success highlights the hunt for returns in a market where equity price swings are vanishing.

site_title: Xiaomi unveils two 5G phones for China
summary: Xiaomi has unveiled two 5G phones in China, the Mi 9 Pro and Mix Alpha, ahead of the holiday shopping season. The Mi 9 Pro features a Qualcomm Snapdragon 855+ processor and supports download speeds of over 2 gigabits per second. The phones are part of Xiaomi's efforts to regain its position in the Chinese market, where Huawei and Oppo dominate. The company aims to attract the first cohort of 5G users in China and improve its global ranking. Xiaomi's move is seen as a response to Huawei's aggressive expansion and the company's own declining market share.

site_title: PM Lee, Trump renew key defence pact on US use of Singapore air, naval bases
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and US President Donald Trump have renewed a key defence pact allowing American forces to use Singapore's air and naval bases for 15 more years, until 2035. The agreement, signed on Monday, reflects the strong defence cooperation between the two countries and extends a landmark agreement that has underpinned America's security presence in the region for nearly 30 years. The pact also underscores the US' support for regional peace, stability, and prosperity.

site_title: HK leader Carrie Lam says police under extreme pressure
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam acknowledged the police force is under extreme pressure amid protests, which have been marked by allegations of excessive force and beatings. Lam called for dialogue to resolve the crisis, but protesters are frustrated with Beijing's tightening grip on the city. Amnesty International urged an investigation into police actions, and Lam stated that while she supports the police, she won't condone irregularities. The protests, sparked by a now-shelved extradition bill, have evolved into broader calls for greater democracy and an independent inquiry into police actions.

site_title: Six adjoining Tanjong Pagar shophouses put on market for S$57.8m
summary: Six adjoining Tanjong Pagar shophouses, valued at S$57.82 million, have been launched for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise. The three pairs of two-storey conservation shophouses, with a combined land area of 8,213 sq ft, can be sold individually or collectively. Located in the central business district, the property is set to benefit from the Singapore government's plans to rejuvenate the city centre, with initiatives such as the CBD Incentive Scheme. The shophouses are fully let to three tenants, offering a strong tenant covenant and attractive initial yield of above 3%.

site_title: Keppel eyes 30% stake in China project
summary: Keppel Land China is acquiring a 30% stake in Westmin Plaza, an office and retail complex in Guangzhou, China, for HK$141.4 million. The deal is part of Keppel Land China's strategy to grow its commercial portfolio in China, marking its maiden entry into Guangzhou. Topchain Group will retain 70% ownership. The transaction is expected to complete by the end of September 2019, with no material impact on Keppel Corp's net tangible assets per share or earnings per share.

site_title: Kimly to acquire coffeeshop property at Teck Whye for S$14m
summary: Kimly, a Catalist-listed company, plans to acquire a coffeeshop property in north-west Singapore for S$14 million. Its subsidiary, Jin Wei Food Holdings, acquired the property at 143 Teck Whye Lane for S$10,000 in cash. The property has a 93-year leasehold title and will be operated and managed by Kimly. The acquisition is in line with the company's strategy to expand its business and mitigate uncertainty surrounding private leases. The deal is expected to be completed on or around November 1.

site_title: Sembcorp to bring smart energy solutions to Vietnam in tripartite pact
summary: Sembcorp Industries has entered into a tripartite partnership with Vietnam state-owned property developer Becamex and Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park JV Co to bring smart energy solutions to Vietnam. The solutions will focus on renewable energy, waste-to-energy, wastewater treatment, and water recycling. The partnership will be implemented in VSIP's integrated townships and industrial parks, and the first completed project is a 51 kilowatt-peak rooftop solar farm in Binh Duong province. The agreement aims to provide value-add to partners and customers by managing carbon emissions and achieving cost savings.

site_title: Bahrain launches fast-track programme for Singapore fintech startups
summary: Bahrain has launched a fast-track programme for Singapore fintech startups, offering a free service to help them set up and expand in the Middle East and North Africa region. The programme includes residency, visa requirements, business registration, and access to grants and financial support. Bahrain aims to position itself as a fintech test bed, providing startups with access to regulators, key stakeholders, and a supportive ecosystem. The programme is backed by Bahrain's development bank and sovereign wealth fund, and will focus on funding gap-filling in the venture capital ecosystem.

site_title: Job cuts at banks close to 60,000 as Commerzbank plans to swing axe
summary: Commerzbank plans to cut 4,300 positions, deepening a restructuring that started three years ago. This brings the total disclosed job cuts in Europe to about 58,200, with 90% in Europe, due to negative interest rates and a slowing economy. Other banks, including Deutsche Bank and lenders from Spain, UK, and France, are also slashing thousands of positions. However, Commerzbank plans to add 2,000 positions in strategic areas as part of its overhaul. The job cuts reflect the weakness of Europe's financial industry, which faces a fragmented market, slowing economic growth, and negative interest rates.

site_title: Gen Z ponders future - and finds it at grave risk of climate threat
summary: Gen Z is grappling with the bleak future of climate change, which has led to feelings of existential dread and hopelessness. Climate activist Greta Thunberg's warnings have resonated with young people, who fear that the world's current trajectory will result in catastrophic consequences, including extreme weather and rising sea levels. This pessimistic outlook may be contributing to a lack of drive and commitment to planning for the future, as younger generations question the point of taking action when the future appears uncertain.

site_title: The dangerous hypocrisy of the humble-bragging leader
summary: High-profile leaders have been boasting about their humility, claiming they are "humbled" by various achievements. However, this trend is seen as hypocritical, as many of these leaders have demonstrated hubristic behavior in the past. Experts argue that true humility involves acknowledging strengths and weaknesses, accepting help from others, and staying grounded in self-confidence. The emphasis on humility may be a PR tactic, rather than a genuine quality, and could ultimately lead to a fall.

site_title: Uber has two months to win over London regulator for licence
summary: Uber has been granted a two-month licence to operate in London after Transport for London (TfL) acknowledged the company's improved culture and governance. The licence, initially granted in 2018, was initially a 15-month probationary license. Uber must now demonstrate its drivers have insurance and training, and prevent driver fraud, within the next two months. The company can apply for a new license before November, potentially securing a longer permit. This marks a significant step forward for Uber after years of regulatory challenges.

site_title: Qatari investors take search for Deutsche Bank chairman into their own hands
summary: Qatari investors, who own over 3% of Deutsche Bank, are directly approaching potential candidates to replace chairman Paul Achleitner, who faces a prolonged stock slump. The investors, including former Qatar Prime Minister Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabor Al Thani, are reviewing candidates and debating whether to force Achleitner to leave before his 2022 term expires. The move comes after the shares lost 70% of their value under Achleitner's leadership, and underscores the frustration of key Deutsche Bank backers.

site_title: Lower trough, deeper cuts
summary: US-China trade tensions are likely to slow Asia-ex-Japan's growth, with the region reaching a trough in 1Q20. The ongoing trade tensions have led to a double-dip in regional growth, with the lowest quarterly pace since the 2009 Global Financial Crisis. A goodwill agreement between the US and China could bring a pause in escalation, but a durable resolution is essential for a robust recovery. The region's economies with current account deficits and endogenous domestic demand bases are less exposed to trade tensions. Central banks in the region are expected to cut interest rates further, with fiscal policy seen as a more effective tool for driving a stronger recovery.

site_title: Using superapps means attracting super threats
summary: Superapps, popular in Asia for their convenience in accessing multiple goods and services, pose a significant threat to security due to their ability to accumulate consumer data. This data can be exploited by cybercriminals, who can gain access to critical payment details through the theft of e-mail addresses and personal information. To mitigate this risk, businesses and consumers must prioritize cybersecurity, implementing measures such as multi-factor authentication, biometrics, and data analytics. By doing so, superapps can build trust with users, foster a more secure ecosystem, and contribute to the development of smarter cities.

site_title: SPH launches China-focused English e-magazine ThinkChina
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) launches a China-focused English-language e-magazine, ThinkChina, to bridge the gap in understanding China's complexities. The magazine, in collaboration with Lianhe Zaobao, will feature curated content from China experts and Chinese writers with a significant following in the Greater China region. Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of ThinkChina in shaping the narrative on China's role in the new international order, with significant implications for Singapore and the world.

images.alt_text: At the launch in The Capitol Kempinski Hotel were (from left) Chen Hwai Liang, supervising editor, ThinkChina; Anthony Tan, deputy CEO, SPH; Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean; Lee Huay Leng, head, SPH Chinese Media Group; and Chow Yian Ping, editor, ThinkChina.

site_title: Cannes to ban polluting cruise ships from next year
summary: Cannes, France, plans to ban polluting cruise ships from next year due to air quality concerns. The ban targets ships exceeding a 0.1% sulfur cap in fuel, affecting passengers from such ships. The move aligns with the European Union's clean air policy, which already enforces the cap in other ports. The ban aims to reduce pollution in the city, despite criticism from the cruise ship industry, with some passengers potentially being denied entry.

site_title: Gender equality is good for business
summary: Procter & Gamble's CEO, Balaka Niyazee, emphasizes the importance of promoting gender equality in business, citing its benefits for companies and the economy. With over 46% of women managers worldwide, P&G's Women Entrepreneurs Development Program aims to train women in business development and leadership skills. Niyazee notes that closing the gender gap could add $28 trillion to the world's economy by 2025, and companies must be intentional in promoting equality to reap these benefits, as unconscious biases and stereotypes can hinder progress.

site_title: Jardine C&C betting on Asean consumer story
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JC&C), a Singapore-based conglomerate, is betting on the growing consumer story in ASEAN, particularly in Indonesia. Outgoing group managing director Alex Newbigging is optimistic about the automotive industry's growth potential in Indonesia, despite current soft sales. JC&C has diversified its investments, including a stake in Vietnamese dairy company Vinamilk and Thai cement manufacturer Siam City Cement, and is investing in companies with strong growth potential. Newbigging will step down to lead Jardine International Motors, aiming to drive a unified strategy across the Jardine group's automotive interests in ASEAN and Greater China.

images.alt_text: "The long-term fundamentals remain very exciting in Indonesia. And for the automotive industry, if you look at the penetration levels of automotives, there's a lot of growth to come," says Mr Newbigging.

site_title: Saudi Arabia waives fees on expats working in industrial sector
summary: Saudi Arabia has waived fees for expatriate workers in the industrial sector for five years, starting October 1, 2019. The move is part of a job creation drive aimed at diversifying the economy and creating jobs for young Saudis. The government had previously imposed fees to encourage hiring of Saudis, but companies have complained it increases operating costs. The decision is seen as a step to support the industrial sector, a key area in Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's economic diversification plan.

site_title: Offer for PS Group Holdings fair and reasonable: IFA
summary: PS Group Holdings' independent directors have deemed a cash offer to take the company private as fair and reasonable. The offer, made by two directors, is at a premium of 195-267.5% over various share prices, citing low trading liquidity and greater management flexibility. The offer is set to be unconditional if 90.59% of shares are accepted by Oct 22, with the plan to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange. The independent financial adviser has recommended shareholders accept the offer.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oxley Holdings' FY2019 results show revenue and net profit attributable to shareholders after deducting minority interests at S$686.1 million and S$144.2 million, respectively. FY2020 is expected to be a record year due to profits from the Chevron House sale, Dublin landing, and Cambodia. Oxley has S$2.18 billion of debts expiring by 2020, with most being property loans that can be refinanced. The counter is trading at a 58% discount to its revalued net asset value, making it an attractive price level.

site_title: Trendlines gets commitments for Agrifood fund from Temasek and other investors
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-based startup incubator, has received conditional commitments of up to US$22 million for its Agrifood fund from investors including Temasek and Librae Holdings. The fund will invest in agrifood tech companies, with its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore. Trendlines expects the growing awareness of the agrifood industry's impact on climate change to drive innovation and create opportunities for technological solutions.

site_title: Trump calls on nations to reject globalism, embrace nationalism
summary: US President Donald Trump urged nations to reject globalism and embrace nationalism, stating that wise leaders prioritize their own people and countries. At the UN General Assembly, he emphasized the importance of sovereign and independent nations protecting their citizens and respecting differences. Trump's comments came amid a surge in global economic and trade issues, including rising US tariffs and slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: "The free world must embrace its national foundations. It must not attempt to erase them or replace them," he told the United Nations General Assembly.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, Aptiv to set up US$4b self-driving car venture
summary: Hyundai Motor Group has partnered with Aptiv to establish a US$4 billion joint venture for developing self-driving vehicle technologies. The venture will invest US$1.6 billion, with Hyundai's affiliates contributing to the partnership. The move aims to catch up with rivals in the autonomous car market, where global carmakers are forming alliances to share financial and technical burdens.

images.alt_text: Aptiv CEO Kevin Clark (left) and Hyundai Motor Group executive vice chairman Euisun Chung at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York on Monday.

site_title: Shinvest shares hit year-high in early trade
summary: Shinvest Holding shares surged 11% in early trading, reaching a year-high of S$2.10, before paring gains in the afternoon session. The stock, a precision manufacturer, finished the day 8.89% higher at S$1.96. Directors have been increasing their stakes, with managing director Teo Teck Leong acquiring 164,300 shares in August. The stock's performance has been driven by the directors' buybacks, which have gradually increased their total interest in the company.

site_title: Europe's top court limits 'right to be forgotten' privacy rule
summary: Europe's top court limited the 'right to be forgotten' privacy rule, restricting its reach outside the European Union. The court ruled that the right to free expression and information must be weighed before deleting links related to certain personal data. The decisions more define the scope of the right to be forgotten, which can force Google and other search engines to delete links to personal information considered old or not in the public interest. The ruling aims to prevent international disputes and potential censorship of the internet.

site_title: Gucci tax scandal spreads as Italy investigates executive pay
summary: Italian authorities are investigating over a dozen Gucci executives for allegedly evading taxes through a Swiss logistics center. Gucci's parent company, Kering SA, settled a similar investigation in May for 1.25 billion euros. The new probe focuses on individual executives' pay during 2011-2017, potentially leading to tens of millions of euros in back taxes. The investigation is part of a broader scrutiny of fashion brands' international operations, with no criminal inquiries yet opened.

site_title: A new look at watchkeeping standards is needed
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping is pushing for a review of the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers (STCW) to address concerns over competency levels and adapt to technological developments. The current regime, last updated 25 years ago, is deemed inadequate to respond to the pace of changes in the shipping industry, including increased automation. A revised STCW regime would provide a more flexible structure for competency accumulation and certification, and improve transparency and oversight, aiming to deliver competent and quality seafarers.

site_title: Trump warns China over trade and Hong Kong
summary: US President Donald Trump warned China at the UN General Assembly, stating that the era of trade "abuses" by Beijing is over and calling on China to protect Hong Kong's "democratic ways of life." Trump declared that the US is "carefully monitoring" China's handling of the Hong Kong crisis and expects China to honor its treaty and protect Hong Kong's freedom and legal system.

site_title: Keppel Corp to issue S$200m in notes due 2026
summary: Keppel Corp has priced its S$200 million notes due 2026 with a fixed interest rate of 3% per annum. The notes will be issued under its US$5 billion multi-currency medium-term note programme and have a tenor of seven years. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate or working capital purposes. The notes are expected to be issued on or about October 1 and listed on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: HSBC's gamble pays off as US$37m Euribor fine scrapped
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has won its fight against a 33.6 million-euro EU antitrust fine for rigging the Euribor benchmark, with judges agreeing that regulators provided insufficient reasoning for the amount of the fine. The decision reverses a 2016 EU fine of 485.5 million euros for HSBC and two other banks, and may give hope to other banks challenging penalties in the massive case. The EU will carefully analyze the ruling and may appeal the verdict to the European Court of Justice.

site_title: Singapore co-living platform Cove raises over US$2m in seed round, eyes regional growth
summary: Singapore-based co-living platform Cove has secured over US$2 million in seed funding to expand in South-east Asia. The round was led by Asian and European investors, including Venturra, Yuj Ventures, and Picus Capital. Cove aims to grow its inventory of rooms by 10 times in 2020 and targets the affordable housing market for millennials in the region. The platform uses AI to match flatmates based on their living habits and values, offering hassle-free rentals with super-fast WiFi, weekly cleaning, and all-inclusive monthly rent.

site_title: Trendlines gets conditional investment commitments of up to US$22m
summary: Trendlines Group, a startup incubator listed on the Catalist, has received conditional investment commitments of up to US$22 million for its Singapore-based venture fund, Trendlines Agrifood. The commitments were made by Temasek, Librae Holdings, and an additional South-east Asian investor. The fund will invest in innovation-based agrifood tech companies in Singapore and abroad, setting up its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore.

site_title: Bishan Park Condominium up for collective sale with S$680m-S$688m guide price
summary: Bishan Park Condominium in District 20, Singapore, has been launched for collective sale with a guide price of S$680 million to S$688 million. The 99-year leasehold development comprises five blocks of 10 storeys each, totaling 320 units. Owners can expect sales proceeds of S$1.9 million to S$2.3 million per unit if the en bloc sale is successful. Over 80% of the condo's subsidiary proprietors have signed the collective sale agreement, and the tender will close on November 8.

images.alt_text: The condominium's owners stand to receive sales proceeds ranging from S$1.9 million to S$2.3 million for each unit, if the en bloc sale is successful.

site_title: Banks line up £1.4b financing for possible LGC sale
summary: Banks are lining up £1.4 billion in financing to support a potential sale of UK forensic sciences group LGC, with bids due on October 8. Private equity firms, including KKR, Advent, Bain, and Blackstone, are expected to submit bids, alongside trade buyers Thermo Fisher Scientific and Danaher. JP Morgan, HSBC, and KKR Capital Markets are providing a staple financing package, offering senior and junior leveraged loans at 7.5-7.75 times LGC's Ebitda. The sale could be a significant deal, with LGC being a strong performer in the leveraged loan market.

site_title: Canada Conservatives' Scheer pulls ahead of Trudeau in polls in wake of blackface scandal
summary: Canada's Conservative Party leader Andrew Scheer has overtaken Liberal Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in polls ahead of the national election, with Scheer holding a 5-percentage-point lead. The shift comes after Trudeau's past blackface images were published, making him the front-runner in the campaign. The election, scheduled for October 21, has become a referendum on Trudeau's trustworthiness and competence, with the Conservative Party now expected to win 36% of the vote.

site_title: Thomas Cook managers face UK investigation over collapse
summary: The British government has launched an investigation into the role of Thomas Cook Group Plc management in the collapse of the 178-year-old tour operator, which led to 9,000 job losses and stranded 150,000 people. Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom has asked the state Insolvency Service to examine the responsibility of the company's directors and potential bonus payments. The government has also expressed concerns about the continuation of operations at Thomas Cook's German and Scandinavian arms despite the collapse.

images.alt_text: Passengers of British travel group Thomas Cook queue at Son Sant Joan airport in Palma de Mallorca on September 24, 2019. Britain has repatriated ten percent of nationals who were stranded abroad after the collapse of travel firm Thomas Cook, as anger erupted over excessive management pay.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.60 point to 1,592.33. Losers outnumbered gainers 425 to 349, and trading volume reached 2.0 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion.

site_title: Franco's remains can be exhumed, Spain's Supreme Court says
summary: Spain's Supreme Court has given the government permission to exhume the remains of dictator Francisco Franco and relocate them from the Valley of the Fallen mausoleum to a state cemetery. The move aims to transform the complex into a memorial to victims of the 1936-1939 civil war. The government, led by Socialist Pedro Sanchez, plans to proceed quickly with the exhumation, despite opposition from right-wing parties who accused Sanchez of using the move for electoral purposes. The ruling is seen as a victory for Spanish democracy, but relatives of victims of Franco's regime have expressed concerns that more work needs to be done to exhume people from mass graves.

site_title: HKEX 'thinking big' with US$39b bid as LSE sticks to Refinitiv plan
summary: Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing (HKEX) has made a US$39 billion bid for the London Stock Exchange (LSE), despite the LSE rejecting its previous US$27 billion offer for data and analytics company Refinitiv. HKEX CEO Charles Li believes the bid is a "case of now or never" to become a more global company, while LSE CEO David Schwimmer insists on pursuing the Refinitiv deal, citing its benefits for the LSE's data market position. The LSE has until October 9 to decide whether to accept HKEX's hostile bid.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda says any easing will aim to push down short and medium-term rates
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that if the central bank eases monetary policy, it aims to lower short- and medium-term bond yields without significantly reducing super-long yields. This would be achieved by adjusting the composition of its bond buying operations to prevent super-long bond yields from falling too much. Kuroda emphasized the need to push down short- and medium-term interest rates if the BOJ were to ease its monetary policy further.

site_title: Starbucks wins, Fiat loses in EU tax fights
summary: The European General Court ruled in favor of Starbucks, dismissing an EU demand for up to 30 million euros in back taxes in the Netherlands. In contrast, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles lost its challenge against an EU order to pay a similar amount in Luxembourg. The court's decision endorsed the European Commission's approach to tackling tax avoidance, but also emphasized the need for proper proof. The judgments are part of the Commission's crackdown on EU countries' tax breaks for multinationals, following cases involving Apple and Amazon.

site_title: UOB picks 16 Malaysian firms for digital accelerator programme
summary: UOB has selected 16 Malaysian businesses to participate in its Jom Transform Programme, a three-month digital accelerator program aimed at helping businesses go digital. The program, which received over 900 applications, will provide subsidies and technology partners to help businesses improve workflow processes, drive sales, and customer loyalty. Participants will be mentored by industry partners and showcase their outcomes after completion, with the goal of harnessing technology to optimize inventory, distribution, and human resource management systems.

site_title: China denies 'flexing muscles' in military parade
summary: China has denied that a planned military parade on its 70th anniversary is an attempt to "flex its muscles." The 80-minute parade, featuring 580 pieces of military hardware, will showcase the country's military strength and provide "more positive energy" for world peace. China's defense spokesman, Colonel Wu Qian, stated that the country has no need to demonstrate its military might through parades, and that the display is merely a celebration of the country's military development over the past 70 years.

site_title: Messi wins Fifa Men's Player of the Year award
summary: Lionel Messi won the FIFA Men's Player of the Year award, beating rival Cristiano Ronaldo, who stayed away from the ceremony in Milan's La Scala Opera House. Messi's victory came as a surprise, as Virgil Van Dijk won the UEFA player's award earlier in the year after helping Liverpool to the Champions League. This marked Messi's fourth time winning the award.

images.alt_text: Best FIFA Men's Player of 2019, Argentina and Barcelona forward Lionel Messi (left) and Best FIFA Women's Player of 2019, US and Reign FC midfielder Megan Rapinoe at the end of The Best FIFA Football Awards ceremony.

site_title: UK court ruling leaves Queen in 'hideous' position
summary: The UK Supreme Court has ruled that Prime Minister Boris Johnson's request to suspend parliament for five weeks, which Queen Elizabeth II approved, broke the law. This move was seen as a politically-explosive tactic to delay Brexit. Constitutional experts say the monarch's role was compromised, and the ruling raises questions about the monarch's authority and the UK's constitutional monarchy. The queen's decision to approve the suspension has been described as a "hideous moment" for the palace, with many calling for Johnson to treat the monarch and parliament with respect.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II was left exposed Tuesday to suggestions that Boris Johnson used her as a political pawn by having her approve a suspension of parliament that the Supreme Court has unanimously ruled broke the law.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as easing trade concerns boost techs
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by technology shares, after Washington confirmed that trade talks with China will resume in two weeks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.31%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.36% and 0.43%, respectively, reaching fresh records. The easing of trade concerns boosted investor confidence, easing some uncertainty caused by the cancellation of a US farm visit by Chinese delegates last week.

site_title: 'Buying local' groceries isn't always better for the environment
summary: A new study by the Hoffmann Centre for Sustainable Resource Economy at Chatham House suggests that buying locally produced foods may not always be better for the environment. In fact, transporting food from South America or Kenya can generate fewer greenhouse gas emissions than buying locally produced foods, especially for items like apples and vegetables that require long storage periods. The report calls for more sustainable trade policies and better land use systems to reduce emissions throughout the food supply chain.

site_title: French retailers widening crypto acceptance
summary: French retailers are expanding their acceptance of cryptocurrencies, with over 25,000 sales points set to accept crypto payments by early next year. Retailers such as Decathlon, Sephora, and Maisons Du Monde will use the Easy2Play payment platform. The system will convert cryptocurrencies into euros, with bitcoin leading the way, and other cryptocurrencies to be added in the future. Global POS, a French payment technology company, is partnering with retailers to introduce the system, which aims to link commerce, innovation, and sustainability.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that Singapore's vulnerabilities lie in global uncertainties, but its buffer against economic headwinds lies in companies and workers' capabilities. This enables the country to ride the eventual upturn. Meanwhile, global economic concerns persist, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Vietnam expressed surprise over the US tariff announcement, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion. Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index.

site_title: European stock markets rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 gaining 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.2%, and Paris' CAC 40 winning 0.3%. The gains followed tentative increases in Asian markets, despite investors remaining cautious due to contrasting economic data and the ongoing China-US trade standoff.

site_title: German prosecutors indict top VW bosses over emissions scandal
summary: German prosecutors have indicted top Volkswagen bosses Herbert Diess, Martin Winterkorn, and Hans Dieter Poetsch on charges of stock market manipulation related to the carmaker's emissions cheating scandal. The three allegedly failed to inform investors about the financial impact of the scandal, which Volkswagen admitted to in 2015. The indictment is part of a broader legal push to hold managers accountable for delaying disclosure. The CEOs' actions led to a 37% drop in Volkswagen shares, with investors potentially selling or not buying shares earlier if informed. Court proceedings are ongoing.

site_title: Decision to suspend UK parliament was 'unlawful': Supreme Court
summary: Britain's Supreme Court ruled that Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to suspend parliament in the run-up to Brexit was "unlawful" and "void of no effect". The court's head, Brenda Hale, stated that the decision was made without proper justification. House of Commons speaker John Bercow called for parliament to convene without delay. The ruling is a significant setback for Johnson, who had hoped to delay Brexit talks. The UK parliament will now resume its sessions, potentially altering the Brexit timeline.

images.alt_text: A handout screengrab made available by the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom shows President of The Supreme Court, Justice Lady Brenda Hale (C) during the judgement on the prorogation of British parliament, in London, Britain, 24 September 2019.

site_title: The future of wine: very, very dry
summary: In Israel's Negev Desert, researchers are studying how grapes can thrive in harsh conditions to develop techniques for adapting to climate change. Twenty wineries have emerged over the past 15 years, and scientists are testing methods such as shading, trellises, and sensors to optimize grape growth. The desert model is gaining interest from European winemakers, who are seeking solutions to extreme weather conditions. Experts hope Israel's desert agriculture can provide valuable lessons on adapting crops to unpredictable weather, with the goal of producing more with less water.

site_title: Indonesian police fire tear gas at sex law protesters
summary: Indonesian police used tear gas and water cannons to disperse protesters outside parliament in Jakarta, as thousands demonstrated against plans to outlaw pre-marital sex and weaken the anti-corruption agency. The proposed changes, which could affect millions of Indonesians, were delayed by President Joko Widodo after a public backlash. Critics have accused the bill of being draconian and invading personal freedoms, with hundreds of thousands taking to social media to express their frustration. The debate has sparked concerns among tourists, with the Australian embassy issuing a travel advisory warning of potential risks.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution when dealing in Mirach Energy shares
summary: SGX RegCo warns investors to exercise caution when dealing in Mirach Energy shares due to a small group of individuals responsible for nearly 70% of the buy volume over a near-seven month period. Mirach's share price rose 21% between April and May despite the Straits Times Index falling 5.53%. The company's market capitalisation increased by S$18 million to S$44.5 million between February and September. SGX RegCo is reviewing the trades and will take necessary actions, including referring the case to statutory authorities if warranted.

site_title: Deutsche Bank top holder takes chairman search into own hand
summary: Deutsche Bank's top shareholders in Qatar are directly approaching potential candidates to replace chairman Paul Achleitner, who is facing investor frustration after the bank's 70% stock slump. The Qatari royal family, which owns over 3% of the bank, is reviewing potential executives and considering whether to force Achleitner to leave before his 2022 term expires. The search appears to be running parallel to efforts by Deutsche Bank to find a successor, with CEO Christian Sewing planning to serve out his full term.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks snap six-day losing run
summary: Hong Kong shares ended a six-day losing streak on Tuesday with gains, as investors monitored the China-US trade saga. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.22%, the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.28%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.33%. This marks a brief recovery for the market, which had been weighed down by trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Alibaba buys a third of Jack Ma's Ant Financial
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has acquired a 33% stake in Ant Financial, the online financial services giant controlled by billionaire Jack Ma, five years after proposing a deal to strengthen ties between the two internet giants. This deal reduces Ant Financial's obligation to pay 37.5% of its pre-tax profits to Alibaba. Ant Financial, valued at $150 billion, has grown into a major player in micro-lending, insurance, and credit-scoring, and is now expanding overseas. The deal bolsters Alibaba's relationship with Ant Financial and may bolster its valuation, but many investors have already incorporated Ant's value.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding has bought a third of Ant Financial, the online financial services giant controlled by billionaire Jack Ma, five years after proposing a deal to strengthen ties between the two internet giants.

site_title: Xiaomi unveils first 5G phone for China in challenge to Huawei
summary: Xiaomi unveiled its first 5G phone, the Mi 9 Pro, in China, challenging Huawei's dominance in the market. The phone features a Qualcomm Snapdragon 855+ processor, seven antennas, and download speeds of over 2 gigabits per second. Xiaomi aims to regain its No. 4 position in China's smartphone market and capitalize on the 5G upgrade cycle, with the Mi 9 Pro starting at 3,699 yuan. The company's 5G offerings are set to compete with Huawei and other local rivals, as Xiaomi seeks to boost profitability through internet businesses and 5G technology.

site_title: Australia shares tread water ahead of central bank governor's speech; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Tuesday, losing less than one point to 6748.90, ahead of Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe's speech. Investors await the impact on interest rate cuts, with financial futures pricing in an 80% chance of a rate cut on Oct 1. The financial sector gained 0.3% while gold stocks rose nearly 2%, but the energy sub-index fell 0.3% due to declining oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 0.1%.

site_title: Just 5 major companies offer a year's paid, equal parental leave
summary: Five major companies - Aviva, British Land, Diageo, Hewlett Packard, and Spotify - offer a year of paid parental leave, allowing both mothers and fathers to share the time off. This practice aims to combat discrimination against women who take time off for maternity leave or childcare. Only about half of 187 countries offer statutory paid paternity leave, and companies often favor mothers over fathers. Experts argue that providing both parents with paid leave can help increase take-up and promote gender equality in the workplace.

site_title: Allianz, Nippon Life vying for Aviva's Singapore and Vietnam units for up to US$2.5b: sources
summary: German insurer Allianz, Nippon Life, and MS&AD Insurance are competing to buy Aviva's Singapore and Vietnam units in a deal worth up to US$2.5 billion. Canada's Sun Life Financial is also a contender, with a combined deal value estimated between US$2 billion and US$2.5 billion. Talks are at an early stage, and terms could change.
