Dealers remained optimistic about fresh developments in the China-US trade row, while bargain-buyers moved in. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up 0.18%. The gains come despite ongoing US trade uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: YouTube is about to demote a wide swath of its creators
summary: YouTube is demoting thousands of creators, including popular YouTubers with millions of followers, by removing their verification badges. The platform claims the changes aim to make channel verification more consistent for users and creators, but many creators feel it's a sign of YouTube becoming more corporate and abandoning its roots. The new verification system prioritizes prominent channels with a clear need for proof of authenticity, requiring creators to meet specific criteria. The move has sparked widespread disappointment and concern among creators, who worry it will affect their view counts, brand deals, and networking opportunities.

images.alt_text: YouTube announced sweeping changes to its verification system on Thursday, notifying a slew of high-profile YouTubers that they'd soon lose their checkmarks.

site_title: Japan's Aso says monetary policy up to the Bank of Japan to decide
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that monetary policy decisions are up to the Bank of Japan, rejecting the possibility of the central bank implementing deeper negative interest rates. The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, but signaled the potential for stimulus expansion as early as its October policy meeting to counter overseas risks affecting Japan's export-reliant economy.

site_title: Lenders seeking changes to WeWork chief's US$500m credit line: sources
summary: Banks providing a $500 million credit line to WeWork CEO Adam Neumann are considering revising the terms due to concerns that shares pledged as collateral have decreased in value, casting doubt on the IPO's success. The credit line, secured by Neumann's shares, has drawn $380 million, and lenders are worried about the potential risk. Talks with investors have pushed down expectations for the IPO valuation, now estimated at $15 billion or lower. Neumann's lenders have the ability to make a margin call if the stock declines below specific prices, and the credit line matures next September.

site_title: Singapore M&A soars 70.6% to US$88.3b in 2019 to date despite fewer deals: Refinitiv
summary: Singapore's merger and acquisitions (M&A) activity surged 70.6% to a record US$88.3 billion in the first nine months of 2019, driven by larger deal sizes. The real estate sector accounted for 49.8% of the total, with financials and high-tech sectors following. Domestic M&A doubled to US$16.7 billion, while inbound M&A rose 70.2% to US$15.3 billion. Investment banking fees in Singapore decreased 2% to US$577.8 million, with DBS Group Holdings topping the fee league table.

images.alt_text: Merger and acquisitions (M&A) involving Singapore soared 70.6 per cent year on year to US$88.3 billion in the year to date, making it the strongest first nine-month period on record, according to Refinitiv data.

site_title: Argentina crisis would have been much worse without IMF: Lagarde
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated that Argentina's crisis would have been much worse without the IMF's massive rescue program, which provided a record $57 billion loan. The fund's intervention helped stabilize the situation, but inflation remained a concern. Critics have accused the IMF of not bringing about lasting reforms, and the country's economic woes continue. Lagarde acknowledged Argentina's difficult situation but emphasized the IMF's role in mitigating the crisis, stating that not intervening would have led to a worse outcome.

site_title: Singapore accounting and tax sector needs to digitise more: report
summary: A report by TMF Group suggests that Singapore's accounting and tax sector needs to digitize more, with the city-state being one of the few in Asia not making electronic tax invoicing compulsory. This is in contrast to many other markets, where electronic invoicing is used to combat tax evasion. The report highlights the need for greater digitization, citing the potential benefits of adopting new technologies such as artificial intelligence, blockchain, and cloud computing. Despite having robust accounting and tax policies, Singapore's sector is lagging behind in terms of digitization, with only 46% of tax invoices being submitted electronically.

site_title: South-east Asia risks faring worse in the next downturn than in the 2007-09 crisis: report
summary: South-east Asia is more vulnerable to an economic downturn than it was during the 2007-09 global financial crisis, according to a report by Bain & Co. The region's economies are exposed to a slowing China and structural economic shifts, with half of the economies in a current account deficit. The commodities sector is also struggling, and corporate and household debt has increased to levels comparable to those in more developed markets. The report warns of a broad-based downturn, with varying impacts on countries that rely heavily on palm oil, coal, and other exports.

images.alt_text: The share of exports even doubled for both Malaysia, where it grew from 7 per cent to 14 per cent, and in Vietnam, from 8 per cent to 16 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.33 points to 1,597.61 on Friday, opening higher. Volume was 56.22 million lots worth RM12.26 million. Gainers outpaced losers 68 to 38.

site_title: Credit Suisse to charge wealthy for Swiss franc holdings
summary: Credit Suisse plans to charge wealthy clients a 0.4% fee for Swiss franc deposits, following UBS Group AG's introduction of similar charges for clients holding more than 2 million francs. The move aims to mitigate the costs of negative interest rates, which have led to Swiss banks paying to park excess cash. Credit Suisse will inform private banking clients of the fee in the autumn, while the European Central Bank and Swiss National Bank offer exemptions and free loans to soften the impact on lenders.

site_title: China bans South Korea pig imports on swine fever fears
summary: China has banned pig imports from South Korea due to concerns over the African swine fever outbreak. The disease has destroyed hog herds globally, causing a 50% increase in pork prices in China. China has culled at least 1.1 million pigs and strengthened quarantine inspections of shipments from South Korea. This ban follows similar measures taken by South Korea after the disease was confirmed in Paju, near the inter-Korea border. The virus is not harmful to humans but is fatal to pigs, and a mass cull is the only known way to prevent its spread.

site_title: Ezion says no material impact from POSH JV's US$27.6m loan default
summary: Ezion Holdings confirmed that the default of a POSH JV on US$27.6 million in debt has no material impact on its business. The default was announced by POSH Terasea Pte Ltd, a 50-50 joint venture with Ezion, which has an effective 25% interest in the venture. Ezion's management team stated that the default has no material impact, and the company's financial position remains unchanged.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Cosco, PACC Offshore, TEE International
summary: Key developments include: Manulife US Reit raised US$142.7 million through a private placement and preferential offering, Cosco Shipping International's president to be replaced by Zhu Jiandong, PACC Offshore Services Holdings faces a potential US$42 million impairment charge, Kimly appointed a new independent director, and TEE International received a 60-day extension for its annual general meeting and Q1 results.

site_title: US fintech startup Stripe valued at US$35b in latest funding round
summary: Stripe, a US fintech startup, raised US$250 million in its latest funding round, valuing the company at US$35 billion, a 56% surge from its previous valuation. The funding round was led by Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, and General Catalyst. Stripe plans to use the funds to expand its product suite and overseas footprint, with a focus on emerging markets. The company processes billions of dollars annually for millions of businesses worldwide, including prominent clients like Airbnb and The RealReal.

site_title: Hyflux seeks to extend debt moratorium by 2 more months
summary: Hyflux, a water firm, has applied to extend its debt moratorium by two more months until November. The applications will be heard on September 30. The company previously rebutted claims of a rescue deal with Utico, stating a definitive agreement had not been reached due to unresolved issues.

site_title: Singapore is world's best for retirement finances, but among worst for retirees' quality of life: Natixis
summary: Singapore ranked 28th globally in the Natixis Global Retirement Index 2019, scoring high in retirement finances due to its sound financial system, savings, and investment preservation. However, it underperformed in retirees' quality of life and material wellbeing, placing it among the worst countries in this category.

site_title: 99.co shows support for inclusivity with diversity-friendly tag for property listings
summary: Singapore property search portal 99.co has launched a new "Diversity Friendly" tag on its platform to combat housing discrimination against the LGBTQ community. The tag, which replaced the previous "All Races Welcome" tag, states that all renters or buyers are welcome regardless of race, ethnicity, religion, age, gender identity, sexual orientation, or physical ability. Since its launch, 86 listings have adopted the new tag, with a joint event held with community-based app Prout to raise awareness about housing discrimination and provide support for LGBTQ individuals.

site_title: China cuts slightly its new one-year lending benchmark rate
summary: China's central bank cut its one-year benchmark lending rate for the second month in a row, lowering it to 4.20% from 4.25% in August, as the economy faces a slowdown due to the US-China trade war. The five-year benchmark rate remained unchanged at 4.85%. The move aims to guide borrowing costs lower and prevent a property bubble, with analysts saying it's more of a "protection story" to avoid weaker growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.27% or 59.84 points at 22,104.29. The relatively cheaper yen provided relief after key central bank meetings, with investors taking heart from the lack of major market disruptions. The broader Topix index was up 0.25% or 3.99 points at 1,619.65.

site_title: Billionaire investor Howard Marks picks not losing money over fear of missing out
summary: Billionaire investor Howard Marks emphasized the importance of avoiding losing money over the fear of missing out while investing. He stated that investors should focus on balancing risk and return according to their needs, rather than making impulsive decisions. Marks also defended capitalism, citing its ability to promote economic progress and meritocracy, while expressing concerns about income inequality and the need for government support of successful companies and cushioning of failures. He also praised activist investors, but warned of the potential risks of short-term gains.

site_title: Manulife US Reit raises US$142.7m from placement, preferential offering
summary: Manulife US Reit successfully raised US$142.7 million from a private placement and preferential offering, exceeding its target of US$142.1 million. The issue price of the private placement was US$0.876 per unit, while the preferential offering's issue price was US$0.86 per unit. The funds will be used to partly finance a US$198.8 million office building acquisition in Sacramento, California, with about US$135.4 million allocated for this purpose.

site_title: Hong Kong's top filmmaker pulls out of Taiwan's Oscars after Beijing orders
summary: Hong Kong film director Johnnie To resigned as jury president of Taiwan's Golden Horse Awards, citing previously signed film production contractual obligations. The move comes after Beijing ordered all Chinese artists not to participate in the November 23 show, following comments by Taiwanese director Fu Yue supporting Taiwan's independence. The decision by To, known for films like "Election" and "Running Out of Time," is seen as a warning shot to President Tsai Ing-wen, who is facing re-election in January, amidst a prolonged period of political unrest in Hong Kong.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as bleak jobless data strengthens rate cut hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,760.20, tracking a strong expectation of a Reserve Bank of Australia rate cut in October due to a one-year high of 5.3% jobless rate in August. This reinforced concerns about spare capacity in the labor market, fueling hopes for more stimulus. The S&P/ASX 200 index was on track for a fifth consecutive weekly gain.

site_title: India's central bank chief sees room for rate cut
summary: India's central bank Governor Shaktikanta Das said there's room for interest rate cuts to spur economic growth, despite stable and below-target inflation. Das stated that a surge in oil prices following a Saudi Arabian crude facility disruption will likely be contained and won't pose a major challenge to monetary policy or inflation. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to consider rate cuts, with the final decision to be made in October 2019.

site_title: UBS bets on China's Nasdaq-style exchange to offset a ban in Hong Kong: sources
summary: UBS Group AG, a foreign-controlled investment bank in China, is betting on the nation's new Nasdaq-style exchange, the Star Market, to offset a ban in Hong Kong on underwriting IPOs. The bank aims to boost fees from arranging share sales on the tech board to 20% of its stock underwriting income from the mainland by December, potentially reaching 50% by next year. This move is seen as a way to mitigate revenue decline in Hong Kong, where UBS has been banned from sponsoring IPOs until April.

site_title: Global growth 'fragile,' 'under threat': Ex-IMF's Lagarde
summary: Former IMF head Christine Lagarde warned that global growth is "fragile" and "under threat" due to manmade vulnerabilities, such as Brexit and trade frictions. She urged policymakers to work together to reduce uncertainty and resolve issues. The OECD cut its global growth forecast to 2.9% due to trade tensions and slowing China's economy. Lagarde, set to become the first woman to lead the European Central Bank, emphasized the need for central bankers to be predictable and focus on job creation and stability.

images.alt_text: The former head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde, warned Thursday that global growth is "fragile" and "under threat" and policymakers should work to reduce manmade vulnerabilities.

site_title: Metech International calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: Metech International, a Catalist-listed e-waste management company, has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The shares closed at 14.2 Singapore cents on Thursday, down 0.6 cent or 4.05%. The company aims to raise S$6.88 million through a private placement and warrants issue to strengthen its financial position and repay a bond issue due in January 2020.

site_title: Trump's no-win situation over Iran
summary: US President Donald Trump's approach to Iran has put him in a "no-win situation" amid a growing threat to global oil supplies. After initially blaming Iran for the attack on Saudi Arabia's Abqaiq oil processing center, Trump stopped short of directly blaming the country, instead opting for a cautious approach. The US strategy, which includes economic sanctions and military threats, has failed to deter Iran, and a wider Middle Eastern war could erupt, threatening oil supplies and the global economy. Trump's inability to mobilize international support and his preference for diplomacy over military force have left him vulnerable to criticism and potential economic consequences.

site_title: 'Flying shame' is now starting to ground Swedish business travel
summary: Sweden's largest companies are shifting away from business air travel, driven by "flying shame" and the desire to reduce carbon emissions. A Bloomberg survey found that 21 of 29 companies listed on Sweden's benchmark index plan to reduce air travel, with some setting targets to offset emissions through carbon-dioxide fees. Companies such as SAS AB, Telia Co, and Nordea Bank Abp are taking steps to reduce air travel, including promoting online meetings and offsetting emissions. The trend is seen as a significant development in the fight against climate change, with Sweden's main airport operator reporting a 12-month decline in passenger traffic.

site_title: "I think we can have a deal": EU's Juncker on Brexit
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that a Brexit deal is possible, citing the potential for alternatives to the contentious Irish border backstop. He said that if the backstop's objectives are met, it may not be necessary, and expressed openness to finding another solution. Sterling rose to a two-month high against the dollar following his comments, which were part of an interview with Sky News.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Food tech solutions to combat diabetes
summary: Singapore's Alchemy FoodTech aims to combat diabetes through food tech solutions. The company, a finalist for the Emerging Enterprise Award, has developed innovative food products and technology to manage the condition. Co-founders Alan Phua and Verleen Goh discussed their mission and strategies during a podcast. Alchemy FoodTech's goal is to provide healthier and more sustainable food options, improving the lives of individuals with diabetes.

site_title: Airbnb says it plans to go public in 2020
summary: Airbnb plans to go public in 2020, becoming one of the last prominent tech startups to list its shares. The company reported second-quarter revenue of over $1 billion and has more than 7 million listings in 100,000 cities worldwide. Valued at $31 billion by private investors, Airbnb's public offering will be one of the most highly valued since this spring, following companies like Uber, Lyft, Slack, and Pinterest. A specific timeline for the IPO was not provided.

images.alt_text: Airbnb said Thursday that it planned to go public in 2020, becoming one of the last of a generation of prominent technology startups to aim for the stock market, even as some of its brethren have struggled since listing their shares.

site_title: Singapore shares edge slightly higher on Friday; STI up 0.1% to 3,162.62
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% to 3,162.62 on Friday, driven by a lacklustre US session and reduced volumes. The Straits Times Index rebounded after a flat US market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.2% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.1%. Gainers outnumbered losers 51 to 35, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Mapletree Logistics Trust leading the gains. The market was also boosted by a call-off of SingPost's US e-commerce sale and dovish signals from central banks.

site_title: Russia, China cast vetoes to block UN resolution on Syria
summary: Russia and China vetoed a UN Security Council resolution calling for a ceasefire in Syria's war-torn Idlib province, blocking a humanitarian measure aimed at preventing a "catastrophic" humanitarian situation. The resolution, backed by 12 of 15 council members, was blocked by Russia's 13th veto, with China also opposing the measure. The failed resolution aimed to stop fighting and protect civilians, but Russia countered with an alternative resolution that allowed for military operations against terrorist groups, sparking criticism from Western nations.

site_title: Lagarde urges policymakers to resolve manmade economic threats
summary: Christine Lagarde, the newly appointed European Central Bank president, urges policymakers to address manmade economic threats such as trade frictions and Brexit. She believes these issues can be "man-fixed" and notes that central banks, like the ECB, have done much of the heavy lifting in preventing a financial crisis. Lagarde cautions against politicians meddling with central bank independence and emphasizes the importance of sticking to facts and data to ensure predictability. She pledges to focus on job creation and stability in her new role, but acknowledges that stability alone may not be enough for real people.

images.alt_text: Accustomed to being the first woman in influential leadership positions and speaking frankly to men in power, Christine Lagarde says manmade threats to the global economy can be "man-fixed."

site_title: Pompeo favours 'peaceful resolution' to crisis after Saudi attack
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo expressed support for a peaceful resolution to the crisis sparked by Saudi oil facility attacks, blaming Iran for the assault. Pompeo described the incident as an "act of war" that knocked out half of Saudi Arabia's oil production. The US and Iran are locked in a decades-old struggle for dominance, raising the risk of an unpredictable escalation in the region. Pompeo's comments come after Iran raised the prospect of "all-out war" in response to the attack.

site_title: Brent rises 1% as Saudi supply risks come into focus
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose 1.3% to $64.40 a barrel, driven by fears of supply shortfalls following Saturday's attacks on a Saudi Arabian oil processing facility. The attacks, blamed on Iran by Saudi Arabia and the US, have limited Saudi Arabia's spare capacity and threatened its oil industry. Global tensions and potential US-Saudi responses are also contributing to the price increase. Saudi Arabia aims to restore lost production by the end of the month and bring its capacity back to 12 million barrels per day by November.

site_title: New York Federal Reserve to pump another US$75b into money markets on Friday
summary: The New York Federal Reserve announced it will inject $75 billion into US money markets on Friday, for the fourth consecutive day, to maintain control over short-term interest rates. The move comes after demand for liquidity exceeded the offered amount in previous operations. This is part of the Fed's efforts to preserve liquidity in the system, which has been running low. The Fed's actions aim to prevent a rise in interest rates and maintain financial stability.

site_title: US confident it will determine who behind Saudi attacks
summary: The US is confident it will determine who behind the weekend attacks on Saudi oil facilities, with indications pointing to Iran's involvement. However, the US will let Saudi Arabia announce the responsible party. The Pentagon has a high level of confidence in accurately attributing the attack but will continue to work with Saudi Arabia to reach that point. The US aims to deter conflict in the Middle East and has not made any decisions to increase its military presence in the region. Iran's Foreign Minister warned of an "all-out war" if the US or Saudi military strikes Iran.

images.alt_text: The United States is confident that it will be able to determine who was behind the weekend attacks on Saudi oil facilities, the Pentagon said on Thursday.

site_title: US FedEx pilot arrested by Chinese authorities
summary: A FedEx pilot, Todd Hohn, a former US Air Force pilot, was arrested by Chinese authorities in Guangzhou on September 12, 2019, while waiting for a commercial flight. Authorities searched his luggage and found air gun pellets. Hohn was released on bail. The arrest occurred amid a row between FedEx and Beijing over US delivery irregularities involving Huawei. The incident is related to FedEx's delivery operations in China.

images.alt_text: Todd Hohn, a former US Air Force pilot, was arrested by Chinese authorities a week ago as he waited for a commercial flight in the company's Asia hub of Guangzhou, after making a round of deliveries.

site_title: Zuckerberg meets US senators, rejects call to break up Facebook
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with US senators, including Democrat Mark Warner, to discuss future internet regulation and address concerns over competition, digital privacy, and transparency in political advertising. Zuckerberg rejected calls to break up the social network, with Warner expressing concern but not calling for dismantlement. The visit comes after Facebook faces regulatory and legal questions surrounding issues like data protection and anti-competitive actions. Zuckerberg also refused to sell WhatsApp and Instagram, which are part of Facebook's services, and was told to submit to an independent audit on censorship.

site_title: Japan August consumer inflation cools to 2-yr low in blow to BOJ
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation slowed to a two-year low in August, rising 0.5% from a year earlier, due to lower oil costs and weak economic growth. This data adds pressure on the Bank of Japan to increase its stimulus program to achieve its 2% price target. The nationwide core consumer price index was the slowest pace of increase since July 2017, with the central bank's monetary policy remaining steady. The BOJ faces growing challenges in meeting its price goal amid feeble economic growth and lower oil costs.

site_title: Vaping-related illness sickens over 500 in US
summary: More than 500 people in the US have been sickened by vaping-related illness, with 530 cases reported and seven deaths confirmed. The majority of cases involve young people, with 16% under 18 years old. The cause of the illness remains unknown, with the FDA testing over 150 samples of suspect product. Several cities, including Los Angeles and New York, have banned flavored e-cigarettes, and a bipartisan group of lawmakers has launched efforts to reduce youth vaping. A national ban on flavored e-cigarettes has been proposed, with lawmakers calling it a crucial step in addressing the epidemic.

images.alt_text: More than 500 people have been sickened in an outbreak of vaping-related illness in the United States, health authorities said Thursday, as Los Angeles became the latest city to take steps to ban flavoured e-cigarettes.

site_title: Asian markets unmoved by central banks' latest actions
summary: Asian markets remained largely unaffected by the latest central bank actions, despite growing concerns of a global economic slowdown. The US-China trade war and tepid expansion have led market watchers to speculate about further monetary stimulus. Economies are feeling the effects, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, and policymakers facing pressure to act. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve and PBOC, are exploring measures to counter the slowdown, with some considering stimulus packages to counter US tariffs.

images.alt_text: A "more extensive sequence" of rate cuts could be appropriate, if the economy does turn down, says Mr Powell.

site_title: Pretty In Pink
summary: Off-White, founded by Virgil Abloh, has opened its second store in Singapore, marking a significant expansion of the brand's presence in the region. The new 141sqm store features a striking pink aesthetic, including a herringbone-patterned wall, velvet curtains, and marble floor. This move comes as the brand's flagship store at 268 Orchard Road will now focus solely on men's collection. Off-White, known for its blend of high fashion and streetwear, continues to gain momentum under Abloh's creative direction.

site_title: Europe: Banks propel FTSE higher after flurry of central bank meetings
summary: The FTSE 100 index rose 0.6% on Thursday, boosted by a rebound in bank stocks after the Federal Reserve adopted a guarded stance on future interest rate cuts. The financial sector contributed to the gains, with a sub-index of banks advancing 1.4%. The Bank of England also kept interest rates unchanged, further aiding the index's rise. Meanwhile, clothing retailer Next fell 6% and JD Sports dropped 3% due to disappointing trading updates and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: US fines Hyundai US$47m over dirty diesel engines
summary: US authorities fined Hyundai Heavy Industries $47 million for importing and selling nearly 2,300 diesel-powered construction vehicles with non-compliant engines between 2012 and 2015. The company's actions violated the Clean Air Act, putting public health at risk due to high emissions of particulate matter and nitrogen oxide. A previous $2 million fine was imposed by a US court, and the company's profits were prioritized over environmental regulations. The case began with a whistleblower tip in 2015 and highlights the US government's efforts to enforce environmental rules.

site_title: Apple Arcade may boost ranks of gamers
summary: Apple Arcade, a low-cost subscription service, is expected to boost the ranks of gamers with its US$4.99 monthly price and unlimited access to over 100 exclusive games. The service differs from rivals by offering ad-free and non-purchase based games, potentially attracting new players to the gaming market and eating into free-to-play titles. Analysts see it as a part of a growing trend of subscription models, which could reshape the multibillion-dollar gaming market.

site_title: US: Wall Street slides a day after Federal Reserve rate cut
summary: US stocks ended flat on Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates, as investors lost appetite in afternoon trade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2% to 27,094.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq hovered near record levels. The US-China trade war escalated with President Trump's informal adviser warning of potential escalations if no agreement is reached. The Fed's rate cut and ongoing trade tensions led to a lack of buying, despite the benchmark interest rate cut.

site_title: 'Very engaged' Trump talks biofuels policy with US oil-state senators
summary: President Donald Trump discussed biofuels policy with US oil-state senators, including Louisiana Senator Bill Cassidy, who described Trump as "very engaged" on the issue. The oil industry opposes Trump's plan to boost annual ethanol usage mandates, while the corn industry benefits from exemptions for oil refineries. Trump's plan aims to compensate the corn industry for exempting 31 refineries from blending requirements. The meeting marks a test of ideas to balance the interests of Big Oil and Big Corn.

site_title: AI startup ADVANCE.AI raises US$80m in Series C funding
summary: AI startup ADVANCE.AI has raised US$80 million in Series C funding led by Gaorong Capital and Pavilion Capital to expand in Asia. The funding will support the company's ADVANCE Guardian product, which uses AI for e-KYC, fraud detection, and credit scoring, serving over 300 enterprise customers in Singapore, Indonesia, Vietnam, the Philippines, and India. This round also includes existing investors GSR Ventures and Vision Plus Capital, and new investors Unicorn Venture and eGarden Ventures.

site_title: Fed cuts rates again as economic risks rise
summary: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point for the second time since late July, citing an uncertain economic outlook and a growing number of officials expect another rate cut this year. Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the US economy remains strong, but there are risks to this positive outlook, and the Fed would be prepared to move aggressively if the economy weakens. The decision was met with a muted reaction from markets, and President Trump criticized the Fed's actions, calling them "terrible."

site_title: Amazon pledges to be carbon neutral by 2040
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos pledged to make the company carbon neutral by 2040 and encouraged other firms to follow suit, aiming to meet the Paris climate accord's 2050 goal 10 years early. As part of its "Climate Pledge" initiative, Amazon will invest $100 million in reforestation efforts, purchase 100,000 electric delivery vans, and reduce its carbon footprint in packaging, delivery, and energy use. The company expects to reach 80% renewable energy use by 2024 and 100% by 2030, with plans to achieve net-zero carbon by 2040.

site_title: Singapore projects target HK buyers in inaugural property festival in HK
summary: Singapore is hosting its inaugural property festival in Hong Kong, featuring over 20 residential projects from local developers such as CapitaLand, GuocoLand, and CEL Development. The event comes as ongoing protests in Hong Kong may be prompting buyers to look to Singapore, with some developers seeing increased interest from Hong Kong buyers. However, market watchers note that the numbers are still small, and Singapore's market is seen as more resilient compared to others. The festival aims to capitalize on this interest and attract Hong Kong buyers to Singapore's property market.

site_title: Wisecrackers Of Oz
summary: The Melbourne International Comedy Festival Roadshow is back with a lineup of stand-up comedians, including Becky Lucas, Aaron Chen, Ben Knight, Fakkah Fuzz, and Brennan Recce. The show runs from Sep 25 to 28 at the KC Arts Centre and features a mix of Aussie and international comedians. Tickets are available from Sistic.

site_title: Drop in online shopping hits UK retail sales in August
summary: UK retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.2% in August, driven by a decline in non-store retailing, primarily online sales, which dropped 3.2%. Despite concerns over Brexit and sterling, consumer spending remains resilient, with sales up 2.7% compared to August 2018. The decline in online sales may be attributed to reduced promotions, rather than Brexit fears, with retailers attributing the drop to unusually warm weather.

site_title: South-east Asia economic growth likely to slow to 4.5% this year: report
summary: South-east Asia's economic growth is forecast to slow to 4.5% this year due to uncertain US-China trade talks, with Singapore expected to be the hardest hit. The region's growth is also influenced by slower Chinese domestic demand and a downturn in the global electronics cycle. Central banks in the region, including Indonesia and Malaysia, are expected to cut interest rates to boost domestic demand. Vietnam is expected to outperform the rest of the region, with a GDP growth of 6.7% this year.

site_title: Swiss franc rallies as SNB declines to match US rate cut
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) kept its policy rate unchanged at -0.75% despite expectations, causing the Swiss franc to rally against major peers, posting its biggest daily jump in a month. The franc jumped 0.5% against the US dollar and 1% against the Australian dollar. The SNB raised the threshold for negative interest rate charges, indicating a greater effort to offset its impact on bank profitability. The decision was seen as a surprise, with analysts expecting a rate cut.

site_title: Audi A6 Avant review: Wunder wagon
summary: Audi's A6 Avant, a station wagon in Singapore, stands out for its sporty design and ample cargo space, making it a unique choice in the country's SUV-dominated market. The car boasts a luxurious cabin, modern features, and responsive handling, despite not being particularly exciting to drive. With options including a 2.0-liter or 3.0 V6 engine, the A6 Avant is poised to appeal to those seeking a stylish and practical vehicle for ferrying lifestyle essentials. Its arrival in early 2020 will mark a departure from the norm, making it a desirable choice for those willing to defy convention.

site_title: AI: A force for radical change in financial services?
summary: Traditional financial services providers in Asia-Pacific face disruption from AI-enabled disrupters, particularly in China, where the Greater Bay area hosts a third of China's AI companies. Established players such as Alibaba and Tencent are making inroads into asset management, while newcomers like DHL and Grab/Go-Jek offer financial services to unbanked populations. Sovereign wealth funds have invested in AI, but pension funds in the region remain cautious, with a more nuanced approach to risk. The impact of AI on financial services could be transformative, especially in less developed countries where banking penetration is low.

site_title: Japan's land prices rise for second year on higher tourism numbers, ultra-low interest rates
summary: Japan's land prices rose 0.4% for the second consecutive year, driven by higher tourism numbers and ultra-low interest rates. Regional Japan saw a 0.3% increase, marking a 28-year high, while commercial land prices nationwide rose 1.7%. Strong demand for hotel construction and office buildings contributed to the growth. Residential land prices, however, slid 0.1%. The increases reflect the benefits of the Bank of Japan's monetary policy, which has been in place since 2013.

site_title: SingPost US units to file for Chapter 11 after sale bid falls through
summary: SingPost's US e-commerce businesses, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, will file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy after a failed sale bid. The companies had received 105 expressions of interest but only two non-binding offers were deemed unfeasible. SingPost will incur professional and administrative fees during the process, which will not be material. The move comes after the company's unaudited consolidated loss from the US subsidiaries was around S$6.9 million for the quarter ended June 30.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: POSH could face a maximum impairment charge of US$42 million due to its joint venture's default on US$27.6 million worth of debt. Cosco Shipping International has announced the replacement of its president with Zhu Jiandong. Investors holding Noble Group shares must register with the appointed trustee by Dec 20 to receive their shares in the unlisted entity, Noble Group Holdings (NGH).

site_title: Data can power businesses to a prized podium finish
summary: Singapore firms lead the region in using data analytics, contributing at least S$1 billion annually to the economy. The country is becoming South-east Asia's big data hub, with almost 50% of analytics providers based there. To maintain an edge, businesses must harness real-time and historical data for informed decision-making. Companies like Mercedes-AMG Petronas Motorsport use data analytics to gain a competitive edge, and realizing the full potential of big data analytics requires creating systems of insight that combine data, insight, and action.

site_title: OUE to sell Oakwood serviced residences for S$289m
summary: OUE is selling its Oakwood Premier serviced residences in Singapore for S$289 million to a joint venture formed by AMTD Group and Dorsett Hospitality International. The 268-room hotel and residences will be transferred to DHI Holding (S) for S$287.1 million, with a small portion sold to OUE Downtown Pte Ltd for S$1.9 million. The deal is conditional on approval from the Hotels Licensing Board and Singapore's President as head lessee, with potential for remodels to offer additional hotel rooms and higher revenues per square foot.

site_title: Thailand's first self-driving tuk-tuk on trial run
summary: Thailand's first self-driving tuk-tuk is set to begin a trial run in November, marking a significant step towards developing autonomous-vehicle technology in the region. The public-private partnership aims to modernize the country's iconic three-wheeled taxi, which has been in use for nearly a century. The self-driving tuk-tuk is part of Thailand's efforts to stay ahead in the field of autonomous vehicles, following in the footsteps of other Southeast Asian countries.

site_title: Wearable Wipes
summary: Jian Yang, the world's largest male collector of Barbie dolls, has published a limited-edition hardcover book titled "#flushablefashion" featuring exquisite doll dresses made from toilet paper. Yang, who started creating the dresses to alleviate boredom in hotel rooms, drew attention from Vogue Italia and now has over 2,000 likes on Instagram. The book, published by Marshall Cavendish, marks a milestone for Yang as he turns 40. Yang's unique creations have turned into an internet sensation and a book, showcasing his creative skills.

site_title: Investors show no love for mixed Fed signals
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.25% to close at 3,158.80, down 8.04 points, after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates by 25 basis points but provided limited insight on its next move. Trading activity remained muted, with 845.89 million shares changing hands. The Straits Times Index (STI) swung between positive and negative territory, with losers outpacing gainers 193 to 163. Key sectors affected included local banks, oil and gas companies, and palm oil firm Golden Agri-Resources, which posted a second-quarter net loss.

site_title: Shedding Light On China-US Trade War
summary: A new wave of documentaries examines the China-US trade war, shedding light on the micro and macro factors behind the biggest trade war in economic history. Two documentaries, "American Factory" and others, compare the working conditions, work-life balance, and cultural values of American and Chinese factory workers, highlighting significant differences in lifestyle, productivity, and attitudes towards work and life. The documentaries reveal a permanent culture clash, with neither side willing to concede, highlighting the limits of globalization.

site_title: Wine And Dine
summary: Marques de Casa Concha, a renowned Chilean wine label, partners with 12 local restaurants to showcase its best offerings in a wine and dine promotion. The promotion features a range of wines, including Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Merlot, paired with dishes from restaurants such as Dusk Restaurant and Bar, Whitegrass, and Ristorante Luka. The "Marques Perfect Match" promotion is available until the end of October or December, depending on the restaurant.

site_title: From Page To Stage
summary: Singapore theatre company Teater Ekamatra has adapted Anthony Burgess' novel "A Clockwork Orange" into a Malay play, directed by Noor Effendy Ibrahim. The production features a notable cast, including Rizman Putra and Elnie S Mashari, and runs at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from Sep 25 to 29. This adaptation follows the critical reevaluation of the novel and film, which are now regarded as classics, and promises a provocative and unsettling production.

site_title: Palm oil to blame for 39% of forest devastation in Borneo since 2000: study
summary: A study by the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR) found that the palm oil industry was responsible for 39% of forest loss in Borneo between 2000 and 2018. The industry accounted for 2.4 million hectares of forest loss, with Indonesia and Malaysia being the top producers. The study's data shows that the forest loss has slowed down since 2012, but the palm oil industry remains a significant threat to biodiversity in the region.

site_title: Craft Appreciation
summary: Archifest 2019 celebrates the bespoke culture with a focus on craft, rather than swanky buildings or urban planning. The festival, running from Sep 27 to Oct 9, offers behind-the-scenes looks at the creative process of city-building and laborious work that goes into forming urban environments. Visitors can participate in workshops, such as woodworking and Kintsugi, and experience private home tours and architecture tools exhibitions, with the goal of gaining a better understanding of architecture through the appreciation of craftsmanship.

site_title: Reduce waste, save money: France's poorest city goes green
summary: In Roubaix, France's poorest city, a zero-waste project has been implemented by 500 families, aiming to reduce waste and save money. Participants make their own household products, such as deodorant, dishwashing liquid, and cosmetics, resulting in monthly savings of €100-€150 (S$152-S$228). The project has led to a significant reduction in household waste, with some households halving their waste and others achieving a 80% reduction. The initiative has also made residents more environmentally aware, with some reporting a sense of nostalgia for simpler, pre-plastic living habits.

images.alt_text: Magdalene Deleporte explaining how she manufactures deodorant, in Roubaix, northern France. She also makes her own dishwashing liquid, shampoo, toothpaste, yoghurt and cosmetics.

site_title: London deals for WeWork buildings falter amid IPO market fallout
summary: London deals for WeWork buildings, worth £90 million, are faltering amid WeWork's struggling IPO. Saudi-based Sidra Capital has pulled out of the deal to buy 70 Wilson Street near London's financial district. This comes as WeWork's planned IPO receives increasingly rocky reception from investors. The move is part of a broader trend of WeWork's failed or delayed deals, following its bankruptcy and post-bankruptcy struggles to secure new tenants.

site_title: Negative interest rates are not a magic pill for growth
summary: The European Central Bank has cut its deposit rate to a record low of minus 0.5% as economic pressures mount, including the US-China trade war. Negative interest rates, once a distant possibility, are now a concern for other countries, including Thailand and India. However, research suggests that negative rates have failed to stimulate growth, with European banks reluctant to charge retail clients for cash deposits and lower profit growth among banks curbing lending. The expected economic boost from negative rates appears to be based on short-term assumptions, and the global economy faces significant uncertainty, making it challenging to overcome its no-growth conundrum.

site_title: Samko Timber to invest US$20.7m in Indonesia firm
summary: Samko Timber's unit PT Sempurna Graha Abadi (SGA) will acquire a 51% stake in PT Sumber Graha Maluku (SGM) for up to US$20.7 million. SGM, an asset-holding vehicle, will acquire industrial plantations, forest concession rights, and other assets in Indonesia, including 59,138 hectares of forest concession rights and plywood factories. This investment is part of Samko Timber's expansion plans in the Indonesian timber industry.

site_title: 21st century rat busting is a high tech job
summary: In Singapore, Cre8tec employs high-tech methods to catch rats, utilizing sensors to track rodent movement and entry/exit points, enhancing the effectiveness of traps.

site_title: Senior level departures at CBRE; firm expected to add to capital markets team
summary: CBRE has announced several senior-level departures, including managing director of capital markets Jeremy Lake and executive director Galven Tan, who are joining Savills. Former executive director Brenda Ong is heading to Cushman & Wakefield, while Rimon Ambarchi will take over as head of industrial & logistics services at CBRE. The firm is also expected to add to its capital markets team with Greg Hyland joining from JLL and Hugh Menck, who focuses on cross-border investment deals. Michael Tay's role has been expanded to head capital markets for Singapore.

site_title: When disruptors go back to square one
summary: Disruptors such as Uber, Grab, and Airbnb are shifting their business models to be more asset-heavy, after initially operating as asset-light companies. This strategic move makes sense, as it allows them to control their assets and adapt to changing market conditions. Japanese conglomerate Hitachi is also adopting a similar approach, repositioning itself as a "social innovation business". This trend may be driven by the need for companies to adapt to new market realities and capitalize on emerging opportunities.

site_title: Johnson could suspend Parliament again if he loses court case
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson could suspend Parliament again if the Supreme Court rules that his original suspension was unlawful. A court submission by an opposition lawyer suggests that even if the court finds against Johnson, he could still consider a further prorogation. The Supreme Court is hearing a challenge to Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament for five weeks before Brexit. The outcome is uncertain, but Johnson's lawyers have stated that he could still take action if the court finds against him.

site_title: Italian Heritage
summary: Gherardini, a 130-year-old Italian leather accessories maker, has made its Southeast Asian debut with a boutique in Takashimaya, Level 2. Founded in 1885, the brand is known for its patented 'Softy' material, offering buttery soft, lightweight, and silky leather products. The new Fall/Winter collection features versatile and practical accessories, including the Ulita structured monogram bag and tote bags suitable for both business and leisure use. This marks Gherardini's entry into the Southeast Asian market, catering to European nobles and travelers.

site_title: Ferrari's S$1.5m eco sports car is here
summary: Ferrari unveiled the SF90 Stradale, its latest and possibly greatest car, in Singapore. The hybrid sports car combines a V8 engine with three electric motors, producing 1,000 horsepower and accelerating to 100km/h in 2.5 seconds. It can travel over 20km without burning petrol, making it a silent electric car. With a price tag of at least S$1.5 million, deliveries are set to begin in the second half of 2021. Ferrari's strategy of introducing eco-friendly sports cars seems to be working, with its shares up 56% year-to-date.

images.alt_text: The SF90 Stradale is the first of a new breed of Ferrari. With plug-in hybrid technology it can travel more than 20km without burning petrol, cruising the streets as a silent electric car.

site_title: MatchMove takes stake in P2P lending platform MoolahSense
summary: MatchMove, a Singapore-based fintech, acquired a stake of up to 20% in P2P lending platform MoolahSense. The acquisition aims to boost MatchMove's SME lending capabilities in the region. MatchMove plans to raise its stake to a majority over the next 12 months, enhancing its lending capabilities and expanding its presence in the Singapore market.

site_title: China's growth could slip below 6%, analysts warn, as tariff war ravages trade
summary: China's economic growth is at risk of slipping below 6% due to the ongoing tariff war, with analysts warning of a further slowdown in the third quarter or over the next year. Despite government efforts to stimulate the economy, economists disagree on whether the trend can persist. The country's GDP growth has been at a near 30-year low of 6.2% in April-June. Policymakers face pressure to address the slowdown, which could have implications for the global economy.

site_title: SIA extends title sponsorship for Singapore F1 until 2021
summary: Singapore Airlines has extended its title sponsorship for the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix for two more years, until 2021. The sponsorship deal will keep the race officially known as the Formula 1 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix.

images.alt_text: With the title sponsorship, the race is officially known as the Formula 1 Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix.

site_title: Tapping vast business opportunities in S-E Asia
summary: Asean, a region of 650 million people with a combined GDP of $2.76 trillion, is brimming with business opportunities. Despite economic uncertainty, the region is expected to moderate to 4.5% growth in 2019, with a focus on digitalisation and sustainable economic growth. A dialogue on September 24 will discuss business and expansion opportunities in Asean, with a focus on Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand. The region's thriving digital economy is expected to reach 480 million users by 2020, with predicted online spending of up to $200 billion by 2025.

site_title: How to get a Michelin Star
summary: Michelin Guide's new international director, Gwendal Poullennec, aims to increase transparency in the guide's star-giving process, dispelling misconceptions and frustrations among chefs. Poullennec emphasizes the importance of methodology and criteria, including quality of product, mastery of technique, balance of flavor, and consistency. He also assures that inspectors are not rating chefs, but rather the end-user experience, and that the guide is editorially independent. Poullennec plans to create more opportunities for chefs to discuss their restaurants with Michelin, and encourages chefs to focus on producing an authentic experience, rather than trying to game the system.

site_title: Qatar Airways posts US$639m loss as boycott bites
summary: Qatar Airways reported a net loss of $639 million for the year to March 2019, citing losses in key markets due to an economic boycott by the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and Egypt since June 2017. The airline attributed the loss to higher fuel costs and foreign exchange fluctuations, despite adding 31 new destinations and growing its fleet by 25 aircraft. Revenues rose 14% to $13.2 billion, a significant increase from the previous year's loss of $69 million.

site_title: Facebook's Libra puts your privacy rights at risk - more than you realise
summary: Facebook's Libra digital currency has raised concerns about users' privacy rights, as the company collects and shares sensitive personal and financial data. Despite claims of a new privacy-focused approach, loopholes in Facebook's statements suggest the company may not prioritize users' rights. The integration of Libra with Facebook's social data could give the company unparalleled access to users' information, potentially leading to identity theft and financial exploitation. Regulators are questioning the project's safety, and users should be cautious of the risks involved.

site_title: The meaning of life
summary: Singaporeans seek happiness beyond material wealth, according to a TEDxSingapore event. Participants wrote down things that bring them happiness, such as "Unconditional Love", "Compassion", and "Dreams", and then carried out the activities. Experts emphasized that happiness is not a one-size-fits-all descriptor and that individuals must define what makes them happy and accept the full range of experiences. They also discussed the importance of designing one's life, compartmentalizing work and personal life, and finding purpose. The event highlighted the disparity between Singapore's high financial security and low well-being scores, with many citizens feeling unfulfilled and disconnected from their true selves.

site_title: Eight great cars that aren't German
summary: Eight non-German luxury cars offer more value for money, beating their German counterparts. The Alpine A110 is a lightweight French sports car, while the Kia Niro EV is a spacious and comfortable electric vehicle. The Mazda 3 boasts a modern interior and mild hybrid technology. The DS Automobiles DS 7 Crossback features a luxurious interior and advanced technology. The Skoda Octavia RS 245 offers great value with a powerful engine and ample equipment. The Infiniti QX50 features a smooth and tireless engine, while the Range Rover Sport has a sleek dual touchscreen interface and a mild hybrid drive system. The Volvo V60 is a roomy and fun-to-drive wagon.

site_title: CapitaLand group of stocks outpaces global peers
summary: The CapitaLand group's eight Singapore-listed stocks have outperformed global peers and regional benchmarks, generating an average 3.3% total return in the quarter to September 18, bringing their year-to-date return to 28.2%. This surpasses the average and median returns of the 100 largest capitalised property stocks worldwide and the 100 largest real estate stocks in the Asia-Pacific region. The group's market capitalisation exceeds S$53 billion, and its assets under management are S$129 billion, with over 1,000 properties across more than 30 countries.

site_title: Saudi Arabia importing diesel and jet fuel to manage disruptions
summary: Saudi Arabia is importing diesel and jet fuel to manage disruptions in its energy industry following unprecedented attacks. The country's state oil company, Aramco, has purchased these fuel cargoes, and fuel oil for power generation plants has also been bought. The disruptions have affected exports of naphtha, a key product for gasoline and plastics production. This move is seen as a response to the attacks on its energy industry, which may lead to increased fuel oil usage in power generation plants.

site_title: Independents' Day
summary: The Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve (GPHG) has announced its finalists for the 2019 awards, with a strong showing from smaller independent watch brands. The Men's Watch category features six independent brands, including Alchemist Mechanical Healing, De Bethune, and Voutilainen, with Voutilainen's 28ti being the favorite to win. Independent brands also dominate the Challenge section for affordable timepieces and the Artistic Crafts category. The winners will be announced on November 7, with 84 out of 150 competing watches making it to the final.

site_title: It's Show Time
summary: Patek Philippe is hosting the largest and longest Patek Philippe Watch Art Grand Exhibition in Singapore from September 28 to October 13 at Marina Bay Sands. The 16-day free public exhibition showcases the brand's past and present creations, offering in-depth insights into its universe, including themed rooms such as the Watchmakers' Room, Movements Room, and Rare Handcrafts Room. The event is open to everyone, including family days with children's activities, and visitors can reserve free tickets online.

site_title: China said to be planning new coal power projects
summary: China is planning new coal power projects totaling 226.2 gigawatts, the highest in the world, according to environmental groups. The projects, which account for nearly 40% of the world's total planned coal-fired power plants, have raised concerns about the country's commitment to tackling global warming. Despite Beijing's promise to remain on a "clean energy and low-carbon development path," Chinese financial institutions continue to support coal projects. The move has been criticized as a step back from China's earlier ambitions to reduce its reliance on coal.

site_title: Apple's brand in China takes a hit from backlash against Trump
summary: Apple's brand in China has suffered due to the backlash against US President Donald Trump. The company fell to No. 24 in a Chinese consumer survey, down from No. 11 last year and No. 5 in 2017. Huawei, Apple's Chinese rival, rose to second place, while Alipay topped the list. The decline in Apple's ranking is attributed to the trade war's impact on consumer attitudes.

site_title: Singapore's stability makes it attractive as data centre host
summary: Singapore has emerged as a top destination for data centre investments, despite being more expensive than neighboring Malaysia, due to its stable and secure environment. The country's unique attractions, including low-latency connectivity and a wealthy investor base, make it an attractive location for tech companies. Data centre real estate investment trusts (Reits) such as Keppel DC Reit and Mapletree Industrial Trust are seeing high returns, with dividends exceeding 51% in some cases. However, Singapore's tropical climate and limited land availability pose challenges for the industry, with investors seeking alternative locations such as North America and Asia's Inner Mongolia.

site_title: S-Reits on acquisition binge amid low interest rates
summary: Singaporean S-Reits are on an acquisition spree amid low interest rates, with three S-Reits announcing equity financing this week to fund billions of dollars in purchases. Keppel DC Reit raised S$478.2 million for a S$587 million data centre deal, Mapletree Industrial Trust secured S$400 million for a US$1.4 billion data centre portfolio, and Manulife US Reit plans to raise US$142.1 million for a US$198.8 million US office building acquisition. The trend is expected to continue as low interest rates create a favorable environment for real estate investments.

site_title: Baller F1 Weekend
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix is set to begin, featuring a new glass-encased air-conditioned facility, the Upper Deck, and an elevated triple-level viewing deck, The Cube, offering unique experiences for spectators. The event takes place from September 19-22 and features performances by Swedish House Mafia, Muse, Gwen Stefani, Red Hot Chili Peppers, and Fatboy Slim. The race organizers have introduced these new experiences to enhance the spectator experience.

site_title: US housing starts, building permits scale 12-year high
summary: US housing starts surged to a 12-year high in August, reaching 1.364 million units, driven by lower mortgage rates and increasing demand. Building permits also rose to a 12-year high, reaching 1.419 million units, as the economy continues to grow moderately despite a year-long trade war with China. The US Federal Reserve cut interest rates again, citing "moderate" economic growth, and housing starts jumped 12.3% from the previous month.

site_title: Time It Right
summary: Apple has collaborated with luxury house Hermès to release the Apple Watch Hermès Series 5, combining craftsmanship and technology. The watches feature supple leather straps with saddle-inspired buckles in two colour schemes: Dark Art and Della Cavalleria. Available for S$1749, they can be ordered on Apple or Hermès websites or at their respective stores.

images.alt_text: Check out the cool collaboration between Apple and Hermès - namely, the new Apple Watch Hermès Series 5.

site_title: World economy mired in weakest growth in decade
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has cut its global growth forecast to 2.9% in 2019, the weakest in a decade, due to intensifying trade conflicts and protectionist policies. The OECD warned that governments are not doing enough to prevent long-term damage and urged collective action to halt the build-up of trade-distorting tariffs and subsidies. The US economy is expected to expand by 2.4% this year, while China's growth is forecast to slow to 6.1% in 2019. The OECD called for stronger fiscal and structural policy support to enhance the effectiveness of monetary policy and prevent sluggish growth from becoming the new normal.

site_title: By-the-numbers Michelin fare at Terra
summary: Terra Tokyo Italian, a Michelin-starred restaurant in Singapore, has regained its Michelin star after losing it in 2018. Chef-owner Seita Nakahara continued to work on perfecting his dishes, and the restaurant's new menu features premium ingredients and a focus on omakase. Prices have increased, with set lunches starting at $58 and tasting menus at $208, $308, and $408. The food is traditional Japanese fine dining, with highlights including parmesan risotto, Hokkaido uni pasta, and wagyu beef. The restaurant's service is formal, but the rapport between guests and servers is evident for regulars. Overall, Terra Tokyo Italian has regained its Michelin star, with a rating of 7.

images.alt_text: Terra Tokyo Italian's playbook of tried and true recipes features dishes you'd expect of a Michelin fine-dining restaurant such as (above) Crab Pasta; Uni and Shiroebi Bruschetta; and Hata Fish and Hamaguri.

Terra Tokyo Italian's playbook of tried and true recipes features dishes you'd expect of a Michelin fine-dining restaurant such as Crab Pasta; (above) Uni and Shiroebi Bruschetta; and Hata Fish and Hamaguri.

Terra Tokyo Italian's playbook of tried and true recipes features dishes you'd expect of a Michelin fine-dining restaurant such as Crab Pasta; Uni and Shiroebi Bruschetta; and (above) Hata Fish and Hamaguri.

site_title: The Road To Three Michelin Stars
summary: Chef Sebastien Lepinoy of Les Amis restaurant in Singapore achieved the ultimate culinary goal by earning three Michelin stars, a feat he accomplished after a four-year gamble to elevate the restaurant's quality. Lepinoy's strategy involved increasing food costs to nearly 80% and hiring staff to focus on classic French haute cuisine. Despite initial struggles, he persevered, changing his approach to focus on seasonal French ingredients and offering an exceptional dining experience. Lepinoy credits his success to the Les Amis group's trust and his own dedication to preserving French culture through his cuisine.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro's shares are neutral with a target price of S$2.55, driven by organic growth in its public transport business and acquisitions, but weighed down by weakening metrics in its taxi business and expected operating cost increases. The company's taxi fleet has declined 9.4% and idle rate is about 4%, amid competition from ride-hailing players. A sustainable 4% dividend yield supports the stock's fairly priced valuation at 17.1 times forecast price-to-earnings.

site_title: Asia FTAs support multilateral trading system: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated at the Milken Institute Asia Summit that Asia's free trade agreements, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, should not be exclusive and instead support the multilateral trading system. He emphasized that this approach will continue to inject momentum into the Doha round of World Trade Organisation negotiations. This approach aims to avoid "Fortress Asia" and promote regional cooperation.

site_title: Home Improvement
summary: A steel table base frame, Label Y Jeans, has been designed by furniture designer George Soo, allowing it to fit various table top sizes and materials. This is Fliq's first foray into mass retail furniture. The innovative design enables users to save space and money, making it a versatile solution for home improvement. Label Y Jeans is expandable and suitable for different table top materials, such as glass or wood.

site_title: Tiffany plans more China stores as tourist spending falls
summary: Tiffany & Co. plans to open more stores in mainland China as Chinese consumers shift their luxury spending back home due to a weak yuan and the US-China trade war. The company's CEO, Alessandro Bogliolo, stated that currency fluctuations have driven Chinese consumers away from spending overseas, resulting in a big increase in sales in mainland China. To stay competitive, Tiffany will absorb tariffs on its US-made jewelry exported to China, rather than passing the increases on to customers.

site_title: Boris Johnson's lies are plunging Britain into a dark morass
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is accused of lying to Queen Elizabeth II, with three senior judges charging him with premeditated deception in persuading the Queen to suspend parliament to force through Britain's departure from the EU. The accusations come as Johnson's government faces criticism for its handling of Brexit, with former Conservative prime ministers John Major and David Cameron joining the opposition. The UK Supreme Court will make a definitive ruling, but the damage to trust in government has already been done, with many believing that Johnson is not telling the truth.

images.alt_text: Mr Johnson's public refusal to say he will uphold the law in all circumstances underpins his contempt.

site_title: Amazon vows to meet goals of Paris climate agreement by 2040
summary: Amazon vows to meet the goals of the Paris Climate agreement by 2040, 10 years ahead of schedule, and aims to be net carbon neutral by then. The company will invest $100 million to restore forests and wetlands and purchase 100,000 electric delivery vehicles from Rivian Automotive by 2030. Additionally, Amazon plans to use 100% renewable energy by 2030 and has already invested in electric vehicles and renewable energy.

site_title: F1 Cooking Thrills
summary: Formula 1's newest lifestyle destination, Twenty3, has opened in Singapore, offering Michelin-starred cuisine, a whisky and rum speakeasy, and the circuit's only nightclub, Apex Lounge. The venue features Italian, Japanese, and Portuguese dishes, as well as a cocktail bar and chimney cakes. Tickets can be purchased through the official website or by calling 6731 5900. This exclusive destination is accessible via an exclusive ferry service from Bayfront North Jetty.

site_title: UK Supreme Court to issue parliament ruling 'early next week'
summary: The UK Supreme Court is set to rule early next week on whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to suspend parliament before Brexit was lawful. The court's president, Brenda Hale, stated that a decision is expected soon. The ruling may not prevent Johnson from suspending parliament again, according to a court submission. This decision comes amidst ongoing Brexit negotiations and economic uncertainty.

site_title: GIC sees bright spots in technology
summary: GIC CEO Lim Chow Kiat stated that despite the uncertain investment climate, technology offers immense investment possibilities due to its rapid innovation pace. This is seen as a bright spot in the investment landscape, with GIC believing technology has significant investment potential.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim says breakthroughs in technologies like AI, 5G, blockchain, Internet of Things... will be disruptive but will also create new industries, satisfy unmet needs and solve the problems of tomorrow.

site_title: With brownface photo, is Trudeau who he portrays himself to be?
summary: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada faced a major blow to his image after a 2001 photo emerged showing him in brownface makeup and a turban at an "Arabian Nights" party. The revelation, coupled with previous incidents of blackface and bullying accusations, threatens his re-election. Trudeau apologized for the behavior, but experts predict it will be difficult for him to recover, with one pollster calling it "as bad news as you can get in a campaign." The photo has reinforced the narrative that Trudeau isn't the image he portrays himself to be.

site_title: Novelship in race to capture Asia's resale market for rare sneakers
summary: Singapore-based Novelship is racing to capture the Asian resale market for rare sneakers, with seed funding secured to launch its e-commerce platform featuring authentication built-in. The company aims to compete with major players like US-based StockX and China's Poizon, which are expanding their markets. Novelship's platform addresses the lack of trust in the market, with escrow payments and a 9% take on sales, to ensure authenticity. With projected sales of S$1.6 million by the end of 2019, Novelship is poised to expand into Hong Kong, Australia, and other regions, aiming to become the main player in the Asia-Pacific market.

site_title: A Private Paradise
summary: The InterContinental Maldives Maamunagau Resort offers a luxurious beachfront holiday experience on a secluded island in the Maldives. The resort features a 40-minute seaplane ride from Male and access to snorkeling and diving spots, including the UNESCO World Biosphere Reserve. Guests can stay in beachfront, overwater, or lagoon villas with private pools and enjoy complimentary activities such as catamaran sailing and kayaking. The resort offers multiple dining options, including seafood and Mediterranean cuisine, and features an adults-only enclave and spa treatments.

site_title: BMW CFO wants to cut 5,000-6,000 jobs by 2022
summary: BMW's CFO, Nicolas Peter, plans to cut 5,000-6,000 jobs by 2022, mostly at the company's Munich headquarters. This decision comes as part of a shakeup of top managers, following the departure of Harald Krueger as CEO and the resignation of human resources board member Milagros Caiña Carreiro-Andree. The restructuring is aimed at improving efficiency and competitiveness, with Ilka Horstmeier and Milan Nedeljkovic set to take over human resources and production roles, respectively.

site_title: Bank of England keeps interest rate at 0.75%
summary: The Bank of England maintained its main interest rate at 0.75% amid Brexit uncertainty and weak global growth. The decision was unanimous, with the committee citing intensified trade tensions between the US and China and shifting expectations about the UK's Brexit timeline as factors. Inflation remains weak in Britain, and the BoE noted that a no-deal Brexit would likely lead to a weaker pound and slower GDP growth.

site_title: Walking Among Shophouses
summary: Russian photographer Tatyana Kildisheva has published a photo book, "Singapore Shophouse Walks," showcasing colourful shophouses in Joo Chiat, Katong, and Geylang. Kildisheva's fascination with Peranakan heritage and shophouses began in 2013, and the book features her four-year collection of photographs. The book is the first in a series of three, highlighting the unique design and vibrant colours of these historic buildings.

site_title: US: Microsoft, energy stocks lift Wall Street at open
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by Microsoft Corp and energy stocks, despite the Federal Reserve's decision to cut rates as expected. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 38.97 points, or 0.14%, to 27,186.05, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The Federal Reserve played down hopes of further monetary easing, with investors instead focusing on the impact of tariffs and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic eyes over 80 new routes at expanded Heathrow
summary: Virgin Atlantic plans to add over 80 new routes to its network at Heathrow Airport following the construction of a third runway, scheduled for completion in 2026. The airline aims to challenge British Airways owner IAG's dominance, with the potential to serve up to 84 locations. The expansion would depend on changes to slot allocation rules, currently dominated by IAG. Virgin Atlantic's CEO, Shai Weiss, says the move would lower fares and give passengers more choice.

site_title: SGX grants TEE International 60-day extension to hold AGM
summary: TEE International received a 60-day extension from the Singapore Exchange to hold its Annual General Meeting (AGM) by November 29 and release its Q1 results by December 13, following the discovery of unauthorized transactions of S$6.55 million and the appointment of an external investigator. The company's shares closed at S$0.047, up 2.17%. TEE International also plans to request an extension from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority to hold its AGM.

site_title: Austrian parliament votes to oppose EU-Mercosur pact
summary: Austrian lawmakers voted to oppose the proposed EU-Mercosur free trade pact, with nearly all parties in the European Union subcommittee voting against the draft. The deal, agreed upon by the EU and the Mercosur bloc of four South American countries, had been under negotiation for 20 years. EU officials have stated that ratification would not begin until at least a year after the text is finalized, and it will then go to individual EU countries for approval. Resistance to the deal has also been shown in other EU countries, with France and the Irish parliament previously calling for it to be blocked.

site_title: Burger King scraps plastic toys in children's meals, launches amnesty
summary: Burger King scraps plastic toys in children's meals, launching an amnesty for customers to return any freebies. The action will save 320 tonnes of single-use plastic annually. This move follows larger rival McDonald's, which plans to introduce books as an option from early next year.

site_title: BOE keeps interest rates at 0.75%
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has maintained its main interest rate at 0.75% in a unanimous decision, balancing Brexit uncertainty and weak global growth. The trade war between the US and China has intensified, and the UK's inflation has weakened. Unlike other central banks, the BOE is not cutting rates, citing a potential no-deal Brexit scenario that could lead to a weaker pound and slower GDP growth. The decision led to a decline in the British pound and government bond yields, with the FTSE 100 index rising 0.7% to its best day in a week-and-a-half.

site_title: Huawei seeks to upstage Apple with Mate 30 smartphone launch
summary: Huawei launched its Mate 30 smartphone range in Munich, Germany, touting its cameras, screens, and dimensions as superior to Apple's iPhone 11 Pro Max. The Mate 30 Pro starts at 1,099 euros, while the Mate 30 Pro 5G costs 1,199 euros. Despite US trade restrictions, Huawei expects to ship the phones in Europe and plans to invest US$1 billion in its app ecosystem. The company's new devices run on open-source Android, bypassing Google's services, and will be available in various versions, including a Porsche design model.

site_title: S-Reits ramp up acquisition binge amid low-rate environment
summary: S-Reits in Singapore are ramping up their acquisitions amid a low-rate environment, with three S-Reits announcing equity financing to fund deals worth billions of dollars. Analysts attribute the trend to a "prolonged low interest rate environment" that benefits Reits in terms of investor appetite for yield instruments and cheap funding costs. Leverage limits for S-Reits are being considered, which could raise debt headroom and opportunities for accretive deals. Industrial S-Reits are expected to benefit from the trend, with top picks including MIT, Ascendas Reit, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust.

site_title: SIA extends title sponsorship for F1 Singapore Grand Prix till 2021
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has extended its title sponsorship for the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix for two more years, through 2021. This marks the fourth extension of the sponsorship, which was first signed in 2014 for four years. The latest extension was announced jointly by SIA and Formula 1 on Thursday.

site_title: US existing-home sales increase to highest in more than a year
summary: US existing-home sales rose 1.3% in August to a 5.49 million annual rate, the highest in over a year, driven by lower borrowing costs and sustained income gains. This is the first back-to-back sales gain since 2017, suggesting the housing market is rebounding. The median sales price rose 4.7% to $278,200, and the Federal Reserve's rate cut may support demand for houses. Weakening business investment and trade uncertainty could limit gains, but the data may assuage concerns about a recession. New home construction surged in August to a 12-year high.

images.alt_text: Sales of previously owned US homes rose in August to the highest in more than a year amid lower borrowing costs and sustained income gains, adding to signs the housing market is breaking out of a slump.

site_title: US fines Hyundai US$47m over dirty diesel engines
summary: Hyundai has agreed to pay a US$47 million fine for illegally importing and selling dirty diesel engines in the US between 2012 and 2015, violating environmental rules. The company imported nearly 2,300 diesel-powered vehicles without meeting US emissions standards for particulate matter and nitrogen oxide. A US court had previously imposed a US$2 million fine, and this new fine is part of a settlement. The company prioritized profits over public health and the law, according to the US Justice Department.

site_title: Singapore F1 organisers stock up on anti-smog masks
summary: Singapore Grand Prix organisers are stocking up on anti-smog masks to sell to spectators amid the worst air pollution in three years. The haze, caused by fires in Indonesia, may impact the event, which has brought in over S$1 billion in tourism receipts.
