The city-state has a national stockpile of 16 million disposable masks, and masks will be available for sale at merchandise booths if pollution reaches certain levels. The event will also provide health advisories and make masks available to vulnerable groups.

site_title: COSCO Shipping International appoints new president
summary: COSCO Shipping International appoints Zhu Jiandong as new president, replacing Gu Jing Song, who will remain as non-independent executive director and chairman. No reason for Gu's decision to step down was provided. Zhu previously held roles at COSCO SHIPPING Lines and The Orient Overseas Container Line. The appointment was announced in a bourse filing.

site_title: Investors of 'Old Noble' being allocated shares in new unlisted entity
summary: Noble Group, a former SGX-listed commodities trader, has formed an unlisted entity called Noble Group Holdings (NGH) to manage its energy products and industrial raw materials supply chain. Existing shareholders of Noble Group will receive one share in NGH for every ten shares held, with allocations to be made by December 20. Shareholders must register with the appointed trustee, Lucid Issuer Services, and set up an account with Fluyd to receive their shares, which will be issued in electronic form and held via the Fluyd account.

site_title: Interview - Alain Ducasse
summary: French chef and restaurateur Alain Ducasse has opened his first restaurant concept in Singapore, BBR by Alain Ducasse, a 235-seater Mediterranean restaurant-bar. The 63-year-old chef aimed to create an elegant, casual, and affordable dining experience, deviating from his traditional fine dining approach. Ducasse, known for his 20 Michelin stars, has built a global empire of 30 restaurants, outlasting competitors like Gordon Ramsay and Jamie Oliver. The restaurant marks Ducasse's first foray into the Singapore market, following a visit to the city-state just before his 63rd birthday.

images.alt_text: "I only focus on the good parts. It's a decision that you make when you wake up in the morning. Success is a balance of what's good and what's not. Even if you have 49 per cent of bad, you still have 51 per cent of good. Even if there's a lot of downside, what counts is that you also have some positive (to build on)." ~ Alain Ducasse.

site_title: UOB becomes first foreign bank to open branch in China's Zhongshan City
summary: UOB (China) has become the first foreign bank to open a branch in Zhongshan City, Guangdong Province, China, as part of its expansion plans in the Greater Bay Area (GBA). The new branch will provide domestic and cross-border financial services, including cash management and foreign exchange hedging. This move strengthens UOB's presence in South China and enhances connectivity between Greater China and Southeast Asia. The branch is part of UOB's seven GBA branches and reflects the bank's long-term commitment to China.

site_title: No loudhailers, umbrellas allowed at talks with Hong Kong leader
summary: The Hong Kong government has set rules for an open dialogue between leader Carrie Lam and the public next week, excluding loudhailers, umbrellas, and other materials that could disrupt the event. The talks, open to 150 people, aim to address the city's discontent and find solutions to the ongoing anti-government protests. Participants must be "orderly" and refrain from bringing items that could cause nuisance or danger. The event follows months of violent protests, with protesters using umbrellas to hide from water cannons and police responding with tear gas and rubber bullets.

site_title: MAS chief Ravi Menon to head BIS Asian Consultative Council
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon has been appointed chairman of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) Asian Consultative Council (ACC) for two years, starting from September 26, 2019. Menon succeeds Veerathai Santiprabhob, governor of the Bank of Thailand. The ACC facilitates communication between BIS and regional central banks in the Asia-Pacific region, providing guidance for research and banking activities. This appointment aims to promote international cooperation and stability in the region's monetary and financial systems.

site_title: South-east Asia GDP growth to slow to 4.5% this year: Oxford Economics
summary: South-east Asia's GDP growth is forecast to slow to 4.5% in 2019 and 2020 due to global headwinds and uncertainty around the US-China trade talks. The region's economies are expected to experience a further deterioration, with growth remaining below potential in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. Singapore is forecast to be the hardest hit, while Malaysia and Vietnam are expected to outperform. Central banks in the region are expected to reduce interest rates to boost domestic demand, and fiscal policy will become more supportive amid higher infrastructure investment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with fresh losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 1.07% to 26,468.95, amid uncertainty over further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year. In contrast, China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.46% and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 1.03%. The losses come despite the Fed's rate cut, which has had little impact on investor sentiment in Hong Kong.

site_title: If he loses court case, UK PM Johnson could suspend parliament again - document
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson could suspend parliament again if the Supreme Court rules that his original suspension was unlawful, according to a court submission. The submission, from opposition lawyer Jo Maugham, suggests that the court's reasoning could still allow for a further prorogation, regardless of the ruling. This comes as the Supreme Court is set to decide whether Johnson's five-week parliament suspension was unlawful in the lead-up to Brexit.

site_title: China rebukes Washington after HK activists make Congress plea
summary: China has rebuked the US for supporting Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, calling it "adding fuel to the fire" of the city's unrest. The US lawmakers heard testimony from Hong Kong activists, including Joshua Wong, who appealed for US pressure on China to defend civil rights. China has repeatedly accused "foreign forces" of being behind the protests and has summoned the German ambassador after Wong visited the country. China urges the US to stop interfering in Hong Kong's affairs and to stop supporting "violent radical forces."

site_title: POSH faces maximum US$42m impairment with JV's loan default
summary: POSH faces a potential maximum impairment charge of US$42 million due to the default of its joint venture, POSH Terasea Pte Ltd, on US$27.6 million worth of debt. The joint venture is secured by five anchor handling tugs and has a remaining US$14.4 million due to POSH. Despite this, POSH expects no impact on operating cash flows, with US$90.4 million in debt headroom. The company had explored options to rescue the joint venture, but the default may be a blow to its already gloomy Q2 results.

site_title: Shell loads first LSFO cargo from Singapore refinery ahead of IMO
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has loaded its first cargo of low-sulphur fuel oil (LSFO) from its Singapore refinery, ahead of the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2020 mandate to lower sulphur in marine fuels to 0.5%. This is the first time Shell has produced LSFO from its own upstream crude, and it will be blended and supplied to bunker customers to meet the mandate. The move follows a trend of other refineries in Asia starting to produce very low-sulphur fuel oil (VLSFO) grades to meet the growing demand for lower sulphur fuels.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets wobble at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets wobbled at the start of trade Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index sliding 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index almost flat. Investors were uncertain about the next move from the Bank of England after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates. The eurozone markets saw slight gains, with the Paris CAC 40 adding 0.2%. The uncertainty surrounding US interest rates and ongoing US-EU trade talks weighed on market sentiment.

site_title: Asean Centre for Energy signs MOUs for R&D in renewables
summary: The Asean Centre for Energy (ACE) has signed Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) for research and development in renewable energy with universities in Indonesia and Japan. This move aims to promote the development of renewable energy technology in the region. The agreements follow the 37th annual Asean Minister on Energy Meeting (AMEM) in Bangkok, where energy ministers discussed progress in implementing the Asean Plan of Action on Energy Cooperation (APAEC) 2016-2025. Renewable energy currently accounts for 14.3% of Asean's total primary energy supply, with a goal of reaching 23% by 2025.

site_title: Liquid Group enables cross-border QR payments in more Asian markets
summary: Liquid Group has expanded its cross-border QR payment acceptance partnerships to 10 Asian markets, including South Korea, China, and the Philippines. The partnership enables merchants to accept multiple QR payment apps from overseas issuers, simplifying cashier workflows and standardizing settlement and dispute management. Travellers can use their preferred domestic mobile payment e-wallets to make cross-border QR payments securely in real-time. Interoperability trials will commence in the fourth quarter of this year, with the goal of enabling 75% of merchant bases for cross-border QR acceptance within 24-36 months.

site_title: Kimly appoints Lau Chin Huat as new independent director
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffeeshop operator, has appointed Lau Chin Huat as a new independent director. Lau, a partner at his accounting firm, brings experience in directorships at 10 other private companies. This appointment comes as Kimly is under investigation for its axed purchase of Asian Story Corporation and chairman Lim Hee Liat and executive director Chia Cher Khiang are being probed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department. The appointment was made following a bourse filing by the company.

site_title: Asian FTAs 'not exclusive', support multilateral trading system: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of non-exclusive free trade agreements (FTAs) in the Asia-Pacific region, stating that efforts aim to shore up the multilateral trading system and promote globalisation. He highlighted the need for a new division of global labor to maintain peace and stability, while crediting the division of labor for past prosperity and progress. Heng also discussed Singapore's role as a regional financial center, the need for financial inclusion, and the importance of regional infrastructure, including the Infrastructure Asia initiative.

site_title: Carro invests US$30m in Malaysian car bidding platform
summary: Carro, a Singapore-headquartered automotive marketplace operator, has invested US$30 million in myTukar, a Malaysian car-bidding online platform. This strategic investment marks Carro's entry into Malaysia as part of its regional expansion plans. myTukar, launched in 2018, has facilitated over 1,000 car sales and will expand further in Malaysia with the fresh funds, aiming to triple its existing transaction volume to over S$500 million. The investment will also establish a car financing centre to offer auto loan services.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.21 points to 1,596.28, closing lower on Thursday. The index saw 2.3 billion lots traded at RM1.5 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 461 to 366.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares gain on US rate cut, as BOJ stands pat
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.38% or 83.74 points to 22,044.45 on Thursday, following a US Federal Reserve rate cut, while the Bank of Japan maintained its stance. The broader Topix index gained 0.56% or 9.04 points to 1,615.66. This rebound comes despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Federal Reserve's cautious cut supports US dollar, Australian dollar whipped by jobs data
summary: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates, as expected, but offered mixed signals about future easing, supporting the US dollar while weakening the Australian and New Zealand dollars. The Aussie dropped 0.6% to a two-week low against the greenback, amid weak employment figures and expectations of another rate cut. The dollar gained against major currencies except the Japanese yen, which rose to its sharpest daily gain in almost a month due to safe-haven buying.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end higher on further monetary policy easing hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.46% to 2,080.35, extending a 10th straight session of gains, amid hopes for further monetary policy easing by global central banks. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut decision sparked optimism, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaling a higher bar for future rate reductions. The KOSPI has risen 1.93% this year, its best performance since 2011.

images.alt_text: The KOSPI ended up 9.62 points, or 0.46 per cent, at 2,080.35, extending its gains into a tenth straight session.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat expressed support for multilateral trading systems, stating Asia's free trade agreements, such as the RCEP, are not exclusive. Meanwhile, Singapore Post's US e-commerce units failed to find suitable buyers, and will seek court protection. Temasek's Vertex raised a record $305m fund, and CapitaLand's stocks outpaced global peers with a 28% YTD return. OUE Limited sold its serviced apartments for $289m. International news includes Vietnam's surprise over Trump's tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: Even as the region works on free trade agreements such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), it must do so in a way that is not exclusive, said Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat at the Milken Institute Asia Summit on Thursday

site_title: Indonesia cuts key interest rate for 3rd month in row
summary: Indonesia's central bank cut its key interest rate for a third consecutive month, lowering the seven-day reverse repurchase rate to 5.25% amid a deepening global economic slowdown. The move aims to bolster growth, with inflation expected to remain low. The bank also relaxed rules for property and vehicle loans as part of macroprudential measures. Despite the easing, growth concerns persist, with economists predicting further rate cuts and a cautious approach from the bank.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.3% on Fed's mixed rate signals
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.25% to 3,158.80 on Thursday, after the US Federal Reserve delivered a widely-expected rate cut but provided limited insight on its next move. The index had risen 0.4% the previous day, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian unemployment at year high in Aug, rate cut expected
summary: Australian employment rose in August with 34,700 jobs created, but the jobless rate worsened to a one-year high of 5.3% as more people looked for work. Full-time employment fell by 15,500, and underemployment and underutilization edged up. The Australian dollar slipped to two-week lows under $0.68, with traders expecting a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia in October. The RBA aims to see the unemployment rate fall to 4.5% to generate wage pressures, a challenging goal given the rising jobless rate.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,164.44 , down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading at 3,164.44, down 0.1% on Thursday afternoon, following a split finish on Wall Street. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut weighed on the market, with Asian equities mostly rising despite concerns about a more hawkish outlook from the US central bank. Losers outnumbered gainers 161 to 129 on the Singapore bourse, with Golden Agri-Resources and United Overseas Bank trading mixed.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank tracks Fed cut, hopes for calm amid protests
summary: Hong Kong's central bank lowered interest rates by 25 basis points to 2.25% on Thursday, following the Federal Reserve's rate cut. The move aims to alleviate economic pressure amid ongoing anti-government protests and US-China trade tensions. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) hopes for calm to restore order and allow commercial activities to continue normally. The economy is expected to slip into recession in the third quarter, prompting the government to consider further relief measures.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as jobless rate fuels stimulus hopes; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, led by financial sector stocks, after jobless data showed the unemployment rate at 5.3%, its highest in a year. Analysts expect further rate cuts from the Reserve Bank of Australia due to subdued economic activity. New Zealand's benchmark index also gained 0.2% on energy and healthcare stocks. The jobless rate is expected to rise to 5.4% by the end of the year, adding pressure for further rate cuts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.65 points lower at 1,597.84, with 48.73 million lots traded at RM22.10 million. The market had a slight edge in gainer vs. loser, 95-70.

site_title: Apple Arcade could boost ranks of video game players
summary: Apple's low-cost subscription service, Apple Arcade, is expected to bring new consumers into the gaming market, potentially reshaping the multibillion-dollar industry. Launching on Thursday, the service's $4.99 monthly price is seen as a draw for players, according to NPD Group executive director Mat Piscatella. This trend of subscription-based gaming is on the rise, and Apple's entry could boost the ranks of video game players, benefiting the market overall.

site_title: Huawei in public test as it unveils sanction-hit phone
summary: Huawei unveiled its latest high-end smartphone, the Mate 30 and Mate 30 Pro, in Munich, Germany, on September 19, 2019. The phones may be without popular Google apps due to US sanctions, raising questions about their success. Huawei has maintained secrecy about its plans, but will reveal more at a press conference. The company's ability to install popular apps despite the constraints remains uncertain, sparking debate among observers about the phone's potential.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.25% in early trade on Thursday, following an Asia-wide advance, as the Federal Reserve cut interest rates again. The Hang Seng Index increased to 26,820.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.24% and 0.26% respectively. The moves were seen as a positive response to the Fed's interest rate cut, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up on cheaper yen after US rate cut
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.85% on Thursday, driven by a cheaper yen following the US Federal Reserve's rate cut. The Nikkei 225 index increased 186.71 points to 22,147.42, while the Topix index rose 0.78% to 1,619.21. The US rate cut boosted investor sentiment, with Tokyo stocks opening higher.

site_title: Samko Timber unit to buy Sumber Graha Maluku stake for up to US$20.7m
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Samko Timber's unit PT Sempurna Graha Abadi (SGA) will buy a 51% stake in PT Sumber Graha Maluku (SGM) for up to US$20.7 million. The deal, funded through internal resources and/or loans, will see SGM become an asset-holding vehicle acquiring industrial forest plantations, forest concession rights, and other assets. The purchase is seen as a strategic move to expand Samko Timber's operations into new Indonesia locations, with the potential for lucrative business opportunities.

site_title: First phase of Thomson-East Coast Line to open before Chinese New Year next year, with three stations in Woodlands
summary: Singapore's Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) will launch its first phase, including three Woodlands stations, before Chinese New Year next year. The Transport Minister, Khaw Boon Wan, announced the opening, which will include a few days of free travel for commuters to familiarize themselves with the new stations and connections to the North-South Line.

site_title: New Zealand economic growth hits five-year low
summary: New Zealand's economic growth slowed to a five-year low of 0.5% in the April-June quarter, the lowest recorded since late 2013. Annual growth reached 2.1%, sparking expectations of further interest rate cuts. Economists predict the central bank will cut rates by 25 basis points at its November meeting, citing weak business and household confidence, as well as heightened uncertainty offshore. Monetary policy is seen as ineffective without fiscal support, with some experts calling for the government to boost spending to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday after Fed rate cut; STI up 0.29% to 3,176.05
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.29% to 3,176.05 on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut. The Straits Times Index gained 9.21 points, driven by gains in TEE International, Keppel DC Reit, and local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The US market also saw a modest gain, with the Dow Jones closing 0.1% higher. European and Asian shares also rose, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index up 0.85% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 flat.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps policy steady, signals chance of easing in October
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping short-term interest rates at -0.1% and pledging to guide 10-year government bond yields around 0%. The decision was made with a 7-2 vote, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda to explain the decision in a news conference. The central bank signals a possible easing of policy in October, citing the need to re-examine economic and price developments. This move comes as the BOJ judges the momentum towards achieving its price target may be lost.

site_title: Asia's global clout growing despite trade wars: McKinsey
summary: Asia's economies are expected to continue growing and gaining global influence despite trade wars and recession risks. By 2040, the region's economies may account for 39% of global consumption and be home to more than half of the world's middle class. Asia's services trade is the fastest in the world, with a compounded annual growth rate of 6.4%, while goods trade growth slows amid tariff wars. The region is also shifting towards regional trade and investment, with 60% of goods trade being intra-regional. Asia's long-term prospects are robust, and its increasing scale could strengthen its role in the world.

site_title: US, Chinese trade deputies face off in Washington amid deep differences
summary: US and Chinese deputy trade negotiators are set to resume talks in Washington, aiming to bridge deep policy differences and find a solution to the trade war. The negotiations, led by Vice Finance Minister Liao Min and Deputy USTR Jeffrey Gerrish, will determine whether the two countries are working towards a solution or are headed for new tariffs. This marks the first face-to-face talks in nearly two months, with high-level talks scheduled for early October. The outcome will impact the global economy, with the US and China being the world's two largest economies.

site_title: Ardmore Medical founder's conduct in case of patient who died 'goes beyond mere human error'
summary: A Singaporean coroner has concluded that Ardmore Medical Group's founder, Dr Sean Ng Yung Chuan, went beyond mere human error in treating a patient who died following a total knee replacement surgery. Dr Ng failed to make detailed notes and hand over the patient to another specialist when he traveled, which may have led to a delay in diagnosing internal bleeding. The coroner suggested making it mandatory for doctors to arrange for another specialist to cover them when unavailable and to have guidelines for proper handovers.

site_title: Japan court acquits ex-TEPCO executives over Fukushima disaster
summary: A Japanese court has acquitted three former Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO) executives over their roles in the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, the only criminal trial stemming from the disaster. The executives faced up to five years in prison for professional negligence resulting in death and injury. The court's reasoning for the ruling will be explained shortly.

site_title: CapitaLand group of stocks outpaced global peers with 28% YTD return: SGX
summary: The CapitaLand group of Singapore-listed stocks outperformed global peers with a 28% year-to-date (YTD) return, surpassing the average and median returns of the 100 largest capitalized property stocks in the world and Asia-Pacific. The group's eight stocks, including real estate companies, Reits, and trusts, averaged a 3.3% total return in the quarter to September 18. This outperformance was driven by interest rate cuts and significant moves in US Treasuries.

images.alt_text: Comprising real estate company CapitaLand Limited, five Reits, one hospitality trust and one business trust, the new unified entity has a combined market capitalisation of S$53 billion.

site_title: SGX queries Medtecs over 'unusual volume movements'
summary: Medtecs International Corporation received queries from the Singapore Exchange over "unusual volume movements" in its share trading on Wednesday. The company responded, stating it was not aware of any information not previously announced and confirmed its compliance with listing rules. Trading volume on Wednesday was 16.7 million shares, up 21.9% from the previous day, with shares closing at 3.9 Singapore cents. Medtecs shares are now trading at 3.8 Singapore cents, down 2.6% from the previous close.

site_title: Sale of WeWork Waterloo to Singapore's Bright Ruby falters: sources
summary: WeWork's planned sale of its Waterloo facility in London to Singapore's Bright Ruby Resources has stalled due to the company's struggling IPO. The deal, valued at £850 million, was agreed last month but negotiations have stalled amid investor concerns about WeWork's governance and valuation. The IPO delay has also affected SoftBank Group Corp's plans to raise money for a successor to its Vision Fund, putting pressure on WeWork to secure new capital. WeWork continues to burn cash and has lease obligations of $47 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares track regional gains after Federal Reserve cut; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,729.80, tracking regional gains after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates, but offered mixed signals on future moves. The benchmark shed 0.2% on Wednesday. Energy stocks rebounded, while mining stocks fell due to lower gold and iron ore prices. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1%.

site_title: OUE to sell serviced apartments to Hong Kong's Dorsett, AMTD for S$289m
summary: OUE Limited has agreed to sell its luxury serviced residences and hotel business, Oakwood Premier OUE Singapore, to a joint venture firm formed by Hong Kong's AMTD Group and Dorsett Hospitality International for S$289 million. The sale includes a 99-year leasehold interest that expires in 2066. The buyers, Alkas Realty and DHI Holding, will take over the business, plant, and equipment.

images.alt_text: Oakwood Premier is the hotel and serviced residences component of the redeveloped OUE Downtown, a mixed-use complex in Singapore's central business district.

site_title: Manulife US Reit in US$142.1m equity fundraising to buy US$198.8m California office tower
summary: Manulife US Reit is raising approximately US$142.1 million through a private placement and preferential offering to fund its US$198.8 million acquisition of a 29-storey office building in Sacramento, California. The acquisition, valued at US$206.1 million, includes a US$2 million acquisition fee and US$5.3 million in professional and transaction expenses. The property has a 94.9% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 5.9 years. The Reit expects the acquisition to be 2.3% accretive to its pro forma DPU.

site_title: UK's Johnson and Trump discuss need for united diplomatic response to Saudi attack
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and US President Donald Trump discussed a unified diplomatic response to the recent attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities in a telephone call. They condemned the attack and reiterated the need to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. The two leaders also reaffirmed the value of the special US-UK relationship in addressing shared security concerns.

site_title: Personality tests are the astrology of the office
summary: Personality tests, such as the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, Color Code, and CliftonStrengths, are being increasingly used in workplaces to identify employees' strengths and weaknesses. These tests categorize individuals into specific personality types, which can be used to determine their suitability for certain roles or to inform team dynamics. However, experts argue that the tests lack scientific validity and can be misused to make unfair hiring decisions. Adam Grant, a professor of organizational psychology, states that the tests are like asking people what they like more, shoelaces or earrings, and that they create the illusion of expertise about psychology. The use of personality tests has become a $500 million industry, with companies like McKinsey & Co and Bridgewater using them to assess employees' potential.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses after Saudi pledge to restore lost output
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous day, after Saudi Arabia pledged to quickly restore full production following attacks on its facilities. The US crude stockpile rose unexpectedly, and US President Donald Trump announced a major increase in sanctions on Iran in response to the attack. Brent crude oil futures fell to $63.60 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures declined to $58.11 a barrel.

site_title: Cboe's BZX exchange withdraws Bitcoin ETF proposal to SEC
summary: Cboe Global Markets' BZX exchange has withdrawn its proposal to the US Securities and Exchange Commission to list and trade shares of a Bitcoin investment vehicle, the VanEck SolidX Bitcoin Trust. The proposal was withdrawn after careful consideration with the exchange's client, VanEck Associates. The decision does not necessarily mean the Bitcoin ETF is dead, with Gabor Gurbacs of VanEck stating that the firm continues to work closely with regulators to achieve its goal of listing a publicly traded Bitcoin ETF.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex closes record US$305m South-east Asian fund
summary: Vertex Venture Holdings, a unit of Singapore's Temasek Holdings, has closed its fourth South-east Asia and India fund at a record US$305 million, exceeding its original target of US$230 million. This is a record for an early-stage investment vehicle in the region, underscoring growing interest in the startup scene. Vertex is among South-east Asia's best-performing VC firms, with its previous funds returning 19.1%, 24.3%, and 36.4% respectively. The new fund will focus on Series A-stage startups in enterprise technology, fintech, and consumer internet.

site_title: Trump says there are many options short of war with Iran after attacks on Saudis
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that there are several options to address Iran's alleged involvement in the Saudi oil facility attack without going to war. Trump mentioned that the US Treasury would increase sanctions on Iran within 48 hours. Saudi Arabia showed drone and missile debris as evidence of Iranian aggression, but Iran denied involvement. The Houthis, Iran's allies in Yemen, claimed responsibility for the attack, using drones and cruise missiles. The US and Saudi Arabia are working to establish the facts before reacting, with a UN investigation underway.

site_title: Venezuela calls on US to reopen diplomatic ties
summary: Venezuela's socialist government has called on the US to restore diplomatic ties with Caracas, following talks with opposition parties. The US broke off relations after recognizing opposition leader Juan Guaido as interim president in January. Vice-President Delcy Rodriguez said it's time for the US to "negotiate and diplomatic communication" with the Maduro government, after failing to remove him from power. The agreement includes the return of socialist lawmakers to the National Assembly and the release of political prisoners, with 58 opposition figures set to be released.

site_title: US auto strike forces layoffs of 1,200 GM workers in Canada
summary: A US auto strike led to the temporary layoff of 1,200 Canadian General Motors workers in Oshawa, east of Toronto. The strike, involving nearly 50,000 US auto workers, resulted from negotiations between GM and the United Auto Workers Union over a replacement agreement. The layoff is due to a part shortage caused by the strike, affecting production at the Oshawa plant. Operations at two other GM facilities in Ontario remain unaffected.

site_title: Millions in England one pay cheque away from homelessness
summary: Almost three million people in England are one pay cheque away from losing their homes due to unaffordable rent, according to a report by Shelter. Just under half of working people in privately rented homes would struggle to pay rent for more than a month if they lost their job. The charity calls for more affordable social housing alternatives. Homelessness has increased in England, with 84,740 households in temporary accommodation in March 2019, and the government has committed £400 million to reduce homelessness.

site_title: This less-known Singapore property play pays 51%
summary: Singapore is a major data centre hub, with the world's largest repository for storing and processing data, despite having no crude petroleum. The country's unique attractions, such as low-latency connectivity and predictable rule of law, make it an attractive location for tech companies. Real estate investment trusts (REITs) are seeing significant investment, with Keppel DC Reit and Mapletree Industrial Trust offering high returns of 51% and 30% respectively. Despite drawbacks such as high electricity costs and limited land, Singapore's long-term advantage comes from its stability and security, making it an ideal location for storing valuable data.

site_title: Qatar Airways reports US$639m loss as boycott bites
summary: Qatar Airways reported a net loss of US$639 million for the year to March 2019, citing the economic boycott by the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and Egypt as a major contributor. The airline added 31 new destinations and grew its fleet by 25 aircraft, despite a 14% rise in overall revenues to US$13.2 billion. This marks a significant decrease from the previous year's loss of US$69 million, highlighting the impact of the boycott on the airline's operations.

site_title: Bangladesh rural poor bear financial burden of climate change: study
summary: Poor, rural Bangladeshis are spending an average of $2 billion annually to combat climate change impacts, diverting funds from basic needs, according to a study by the International Institute for Environment and Development. This far exceeds the government's $1.46 billion budget for climate change in rural areas for 2018-19 and international financing of $154 million annually. Families are using money to repair homes, replace animals and crops, and take out high-interest loans, pushing them further into poverty. The study highlights an "alarming imbalance" in public climate finance reaching the poorest.

site_title: Australia budget deficit narrows to A$690m in 2018/19: government
summary: Australia's budget deficit narrowed to A$690 million in the 2018/19 fiscal year, narrower than the forecasted A$4.2 billion deficit. This marks a decrease from the A$10.1 billion deficit in the 2017/18 year. The improvement in the deficit is attributed to increased government revenue and reduced expenditure.

images.alt_text: Australia posted a budget deficit of A$690 million (S$647.5 million) in the 2018/19 fiscal year ended June 30, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said on Thursday, narrower than the A$4.2 billion deficit forecast in the April budget papers.

site_title: Venture capital firms share long-term investment strategies
summary: Venture capital firms in South-east Asia are shifting their investment strategies, focusing on seed-stage investments and consumer trends. Panellists at the DealStreetAsia PE-VC Summit announced plans to expand regionally, with firms like STRIVE and DSG Consumer Partners prioritizing seed investments and SME sectors. Golden Gate Ventures is also teaming up with Hanwha Asset Management to raise a growth fund, while keeping a focus on South-east Asia. The firms aim to identify long-term trends in consumer behavior and build sustainable brands.

site_title: New York Federal Reserve to pump US$75b more into money markets on Thursday
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will inject up to $75 billion into US money markets on Thursday to preserve control over short-term interest rates. This is the third consecutive day of operations to address banks' struggles to meet reserve requirements, which have driven up short-term borrowing rates. The move aims to maintain liquidity in the system and support the Federal Reserve's control over interest rates.

site_title: Celine Dion returns to Canada to kick off world tour
summary: Celine Dion has returned to Quebec, Canada, to kick off her first world tour in a decade, "Courage," after a 12-year hiatus. The 51-year-old Grammy winner has released a new album of the same name, featuring singles "Flying On My Own" and "Courage." Dion's tour, which includes 60 dates in North America, marks her first without her late husband and manager Rene Angelil, who passed away in 2016. The tour will run through April 2020 and follows a series of promotional dates in Quebec City.

site_title: This robo tuk-tuk will zip about an upscale Bangkok neighbourhood
summary: Thailand is launching its first self-driving tuk-tuk in a gated Bangkok community in November, as part of a public-private partnership to develop autonomous-vehicle technology. The trial, which could last up to six months, aims to gather data on the vehicle's performance and safety. The tuk-tuk, designed by Airovr, is a modified version of the traditional three-wheeled taxi, with a minimalist design and a 3D mapping system. The goal is to scale up the technology to 15-seat minibuses, which could be ready for service by 2021 and make Thailand a hub for autonomous-vehicle production in South-east Asia.

site_title: Airbus revises up jet demand forecast, shaves traffic growth
summary: Airbus revised up its jet demand forecast, now expecting 47,680 aircraft by 2038, a slight decrease from previous forecasts. The demand for new jets has been revised upwards due to airlines replacing more aircraft than initially thought. Airbus now predicts 36% of new deliveries will replace existing jets, with traffic expected to roughly double over 15 years. The company trimmed its forecast for average traffic growth to 4.3% a year, citing slower growth amid international trade tensions.

site_title: Bank of Japan seen on hold as global woes, dwindling options complicate policy path
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its current stimulus policy, keeping short-term interest rates at -0.1% and the 10-year government bond yield around 0%. Policymakers are unlikely to act in September due to market sentiment improving, despite growing risks to Japan's fragile economic recovery. The BOJ's readiness to ease policy swiftly will be stressed by Governor Haruhiko Kuroda, but analysts believe the bank will keep its "gun powder dry" for now, with cutting interest rates deeper into negative territory being the key option for future action.

site_title: Annual investments in robots hit record US$16.5b; Singapore, South Korea lead in robot density
summary: Annual robot investments reached a record US$16.5 billion in 2019, with shipments expected to jump 39% from 2018 to 2022. China invested US$5.4 billion, while Singapore and South Korea lead in robot density. Over 420,000 robots were installed in 2019, with 584,000 expected by 2022. The top five countries, including Japan and Germany, hold 74% of the market, with the US-China trade conflict impacting global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Robot shipments are expected to jump 39 per cent from 2018 to 2022 from a record annual sales level of US$16.5 billion last year, according to the World Robotics report.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank cuts interest rate after Fed move
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority cut its base rate by 25 basis points to 2.25% on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's rate cut of the same margin. This move locks-step with the US monetary policy, as Hong Kong's currency is pegged to the US dollar at a tight range. The decision aims to provide insurance against ongoing risks, including weak global growth and resurgent trade tensions. The Hong Kong dollar remained little changed at 7.8297 per dollar.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) on Thursday lowered its base rate charged through the overnight discount window by 25 basis points to 2.25 per cent, hours after the US Federal Reserve delivered a rate cut of the same margin.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell downplays concerns about cash crunch on financial markets
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell downplayed concerns about a cash crunch in US financial markets, stating it has no implications for the economy or monetary policy. The New York Federal Reserve injected $128 billion into the short-term funding market due to a surge in Treasury debt issues and a deadline for quarterly tax payments. Powell noted the operation was effective and the Fed will continue to monitor market developments to provide sufficient reserves. The Fed cut interest rates on cash reserves and daily overnight lending to alleviate funding pressures.

site_title: Singapore telcos must seize 5G opening to boost enterprise business
summary: Singapore's telcos face stagnant consumer growth, but 5G networks expected to boost enterprise business. By 2025, half of mobile phone lines will be 5G-enabled, offering faster speeds and lower latency. This will enable industrial applications, such as IoT and autonomous vehicles, and create opportunities for organic growth. Cisco predicts 5G services could boost annual revenues by US$510 million. Telecom operators can provide dedicated services to individual companies through network slicing, providing secure revenue streams. However, spectrum choice is crucial to delivering optimal services, with the Infocomm Media Development Authority working with companies to select the best spectrum bands.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE, Singpost, Manulife US Reit, FLT, SIIC, Envictus, Transcorp
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks saw significant developments on Thursday. OUE Limited sold its luxury serviced residences and hotel business for S$289 million. Singpost's six-month sale process for its US e-commerce businesses closed with no acceptable offers, prompting the company to explore restructuring options. Manulife US Reit acquired a California office building for US$198.8 million. FLT will join the GPR 250 Index Series, while SIIC Environment signed agreements for concession rights in China. Envictus International Holdings will cease its loss-making Texas Chicken operations in Indonesia. Transcorp Holdings called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Asian gasoil profit margins surge to highest Sept levels in 6 years
summary: Asian gasoil profit margins have surged to their highest September levels in six years, reaching a near 10-month high of US$18.52 a barrel, driven by expectations of higher demand due to the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2020 regulations. The regulations will force shippers to reduce sulfur content in fuels, leading to a switch to low-sulfur gasoil. Industry analysts predict a 1.4-2 million barrel-per-day increase in gasoil demand, further boosting margins. However, some analysts believe the market is overly bullish and expect middle distillate cracks to weaken from January onwards.

site_title: Nissan seeks sale of trading unit in US$1 billion deal
summary: Nissan Motor Co is seeking to sell its US$1 billion subsidiary, Nissan Trading Co, which distributes vehicle parts and materials, as part of its restructuring efforts. The sale aims to free up cash for the struggling Japanese carmaker, which has been hurt by slumping US sales and ageing vehicle models. Nissan Trading generated 676.1 billion yen in revenue in the fiscal year ended March. The sale process is ongoing, with no agreements reached, and a buyer may be selected by October. This move comes after Nissan's operating profit hit a decade low and the company stepped up restructuring measures.

site_title: US: Stocks post a split finish as Federal Reserve delivers a rate cut
summary: The US Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, erasing a 200-point drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average to close with a split finish. The rate cut was seen as a sign of the economy's strength, but Fed Chairman Jerome Powell also hinted at further rate cuts if the economy weakens. Despite the uncertainty surrounding future stimulus, the US stock market continued its upward trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Exxon Mobil seeks to sell Bass Strait oil, gas assets
summary: Exxon Mobil is seeking to sell its 50% stake in the Gippsland Basin oil and gas development in Australia's Bass Strait, a joint venture with BHP Group. The assets, which supply oil and gas to south-eastern Australia, are in decline due to declining output. Exxon has not disclosed a targeted value for the sale and operations will continue as normal. BHP has expressed its commitment to maintaining the supply of gas to the east coast domestic market, but has not ruled out buying Exxon's assets.

site_title: European car sales plunge in August, deepening industry woes
summary: European car registrations plummeted 8.4% in August, the steepest decline this year, due to sluggish demand and the challenge of electric vehicle rollout. This deepens industry woes, with key markets such as Germany and China facing slowdowns. Euro-area economic growth is forecast to slow to 1.1% this year, and car sales are down 3.2% over the year to date. Industry experts attribute the decline to high growth in the same month last year and the need for more charging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

site_title: Asian firms' sentiment lifts but recession fears fester: poll
summary: Asian firms' confidence lifted slightly in the September quarter, with the Thomson Reuters/Insead Asian Business Sentiment Index rising to 58, a five-point increase from the previous quarter. However, most firms do not plan on hiring or expect business to pick up due to concerns of a global recession. Respondents rate a global recession as the top risk, surpassing trade war fears. Only 39% of respondents expect their sales volumes to rise, with over two-thirds planning to cut staff or maintain numbers steady.

images.alt_text: Respondents rated a global recession as the top risk, overhauling trade war fears which had topped the table for the previous six quarters.

site_title: Brazil cuts interest rate to record low
summary: Brazil's central bank cut interest rates to a record low of 5.5% for the second time in less than two months, citing risks of a global economic slowdown. The move aims to revive growth, which has struggled since a severe economic crisis two years ago. The decision comes after the US Federal Reserve also cut its benchmark rate, and Brazil's economy grew 0.4% in the second quarter. The bank stated that the pace of growth will be gradual, following a unanimous decision to cut borrowing costs.

site_title: Europe: Shares tread water awaiting Federal Reserve's decision
summary: European shares ended flat on Wednesday, awaiting the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Defensive sectors such as real estate and utilities rose, while luxury goods makers declined. Investors expect a rate cut from the US central bank, with a 72.7% chance of a quarter-point cut, and anticipate the end of the easing cycle. The European Central Bank's recent rate cut and bond purchases have supported the market, but caution prevails ahead of the Fed's statement.

site_title: Angry farmers to face off with NZ's Fonterra over financial woes
summary: New Zealand's Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, is set to face off with angry farmer shareholders over its financial woes. The company is forecast to post a second year of losses, with asset writedowns worth billions of dollars. Farmers, who supply Fonterra with milk, are demanding a clear turnaround strategy and are transferring production to smaller rivals. The company's CEO has pledged to focus on producing milk in New Zealand, but many farmers are skeptical, citing a decline in share value and rising debt. The issue has significant implications for rural communities, which are a major voter base in New Zealand.

site_title: Accrelist to buy Wheelock aesthetics clinic for S$17m
summary: Accrelist, a Singaporean corporate services provider, plans to acquire The Wellness Clinic at Wheelock Place for S$17 million. The clinic offers non-surgical aesthetics treatments and has made a S$1.4 million profit in 2019. The acquisition is part of Accrelist's expansion into medical aesthetics and will be funded through cash and shares. The deal is subject to Accrelist shareholders' approval and a definitive agreement with Verita Healthcare Group, the clinic's parent.

site_title: Window closing fast for WeWork parent to launch IPO this year: fund managers
summary: WeWork's parent company, The We Company, faces strong headwinds in launching an initial public offering (IPO) by the end of 2019. Despite plans to update quarterly earnings, the company postponed its IPO, citing a lacklustre reception from investors. Fund managers warn of weak market demand in the fourth quarter, putting the company at risk of missing its debt repayment deadline. We Company aims to raise at least $3 billion in the IPO, but its chances are uncertain due to its loss-making status and corporate governance concerns.

images.alt_text: We Company's chief executive Adam Neumann told staff on Tuesday that he had been "humbled" by the IPO effort so far and said he had lessons to learn about running a public company.

site_title: Oil stabilises as Saudi output restoration calms market fears
summary: Oil prices stabilized after Saudi Arabia's Aramco announced the restoration of 41% of capacity at a key crude-processing complex, alleviating market fears following a devastating attack on the Abqaiq facility. The global crude benchmark rose to around $65 a barrel, with Brent edging higher after tumbling on Tuesday. Despite reassurances from Saudi Arabia, crude remained almost 8% higher than pre-attack prices, with the US and Saudi Arabia's response to the attacks still uncertain.

site_title: Trump's childhood home on auction block again
summary: US President Donald Trump's childhood home in Queens, New York, is set to auction off on November 14 after a failed attempt to sell for $2.9 million earlier this year. The 2,000 sq ft Tudor-style house, where Trump lived until age 4, is being sold by a limited-liability company without a disclosed reserve price. The home, valued at $980,000 in the neighborhood, has previously sold for $2.14 million in 2017 and $1.4 million in 2016, with some speculating that it may be bought by Trump supporters or investors looking to capitalize on its historical significance.

site_title: The abiding pursuit of happiness
summary: A recent TEDxSingapore event explored the pursuit of happiness beyond material goods, with experts concluding that Singaporeans can lead happy lives by defining their desires, tempering expectations, and accepting life's full range of experiences. The event came as Raffles Singapore opened BBR by Alain Ducasse, a Michelin-starred restaurant, and Sebastien Lepinoy, executive chef of the newly three-starred restaurant Les Amis, discussed his journey to achieve haute cuisine perfection. The findings and interviews offer insights into the importance of personal fulfillment and the pursuit of happiness.

site_title: Singapore mutual funds charge 'higher fees than global average'
summary: Singapore mutual funds charge higher fees than the global average due to the majority of funds charging front loads and trail commission, according to a Morningstar study. The country received a "below average" grade in the study, ranking alongside Taiwan. Fees and expenses are generally high in Singapore, and investors rarely pay for advice without commissions or retrocessions. Despite this, some positive changes have been observed, including the government's plan to reduce expenses for the Central Provident Fund Investment Scheme.

site_title: US lawmakers seek to ramp up pressure on HK
summary: US lawmakers are moving forward with plans to pressure Hong Kong's government over its treatment of protesters, threatening to impose sanctions and revoke the territory's special trading status. Senator Marco Rubio stated it's "long overdue" for the US and the free world to respond. This comes after protests in Hong Kong against the government's proposed extradition bill. The move could have significant economic implications for Hong Kong, which relies heavily on its special trading status.

site_title: Libra applies for court protection; creditors seek S$9.3m, property
summary: Libra Group, a CATALIST-listed company, has applied to the High Court for a six-month debt moratorium as it faces claims from creditors for approximately S$9.3 million in repayments and possession of a property. The company has excluded two properties from its application, but has received letters of demand from creditors, including Maybank and UOB, over unpaid debts and mortgage defaults. Trading in Libra's shares has been suspended.

site_title: When Donald Trump discovered the real Middle East
summary: Iran launched a devastating attack on the Abqaiq processing centre in Saudi Arabia, knocking off 5% of global oil supplies and driving oil prices up 10%. The attack, attributed to an Iranian-backed group, was a brazen move that exposed the vulnerability of Saudi oil infrastructure and underlined the disastrous failure of Riyadh's four-year military campaign in Yemen. The attack's impact was amplified by US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, which ignored Iran's ability to absorb pressure and its tendency to go on the offensive when defending itself.

site_title: Insurtech offering life insurance, investment returns and layoff benefit rolled into one
summary: Singapore Life, an insurtech company, is launching a hybrid product that combines life insurance, investment returns, and layoff benefits. The Singlife account, which comes with a corresponding debit card, allows customers to accumulate funds and spend through it. The account offers a market-beating interest rate, a free life insurance policy, and a retrenchment benefit tied to debit card spending. The company aims to attract 100,000 sign-ups within six months, with CEO Walter de Oude targeting a significant market share in the traditionally conservative insurance industry.

site_title: Hooked on bingo nights in Glasgow
summary: Margaret Fisher, a 70-year-old Glasgow resident, has been attending bingo nights at the same club for nearly 25 years. She has not met anyone who hasn't been to a bingo hall, highlighting the city's strong bingo culture. Fisher's dedication to the hobby is a testament to the enduring popularity of bingo in Glasgow, where it remains a staple of social life.

site_title: Wall Street's new battleground is green-bond market worth over US$135b
summary: HSBC, Citigroup, and Bank of America are leading the surge in green-bond sales, worth over $135 billion, as banks compete to capitalize on the growing demand for climate change initiatives. Global green-bond sales have more than quadrupled in the past five years, driven by corporations and governments seeking to invest in renewable energy and reduce fossil fuel use. Sovereign borrowers now account for only 29% of new bond volumes, while corporations dominate overall issuance, with companies like Vodafone and E.ON SE issuing green bonds.

site_title: Money FM podcast: What's your 4-digit number - the credit report and credit score that matters
summary: The Money FM podcast "What's your 4-digit number" discusses the importance of credit reports and credit scores in planning expenses, particularly with credit card usage. Experts Rohith Murthy and Elizabeth Huang from SingSaver and Credit Bureau Singapore shared insights on the significance of a 4-digit credit score. They emphasized how a good credit score can lead to better loan terms, lower interest rates, and improved financial stability. The conversation highlights the need for individuals to understand their credit reports and scores to make informed financial decisions.

site_title: Parliament suspension not a matter for judges, UK Supreme Court told
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to suspend parliament for five weeks is deemed lawful by his lawyer, James Eadie, who argues it's a matter of politics and not for judges to rule on. The Supreme Court will decide whether Johnson's advice to the Queen was unlawful, with a ruling expected on Friday. Critics accuse Johnson of trying to silence parliament before the UK's exit from the EU on October 31. If the Supreme Court rules against Johnson, he could recall parliament earlier than planned, potentially leading to a major embarrassment for the Prime Minister.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering upgraded to "buy" by OB Kay Hian Research, with a target price of S$4.34, following the acquisition of Glowlink Communications Technology. The acquisition is expected to enhance satellite communications offerings and increase earnings growth. Mapletree Industrial Trust maintained "buy" with a target price of S$2.50, driven by high-tech growth momentum and increasing distribution per unit visibility.

site_title: COE prices end mixed
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended mixed in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp settling at S$31,759, down from S$31,783 two weeks ago. Cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp rose to S$37,000, while open COE increased to S$40,000. Commercial vehicle COE rose slightly to S$25,556, and the motorcycle premium fell to S$3,601. Private-hire firms drove demand, typically buying petrol-electric hybrid cars.

site_title: Building the high-tech farms of tomorrow
summary: Agritech platform CrowdFarmX uses blockchain to connect farmers in less endowed regions with the global market, equipping them with skills to deliver higher yields. Founded by David Tan and Daniel Wong five years ago, the cooperative farming platform aims to help farmers profit from best practices. By adopting a people-centric approach, CrowdFarmX seeks to revolutionize the farming industry through technology, promoting sustainable and efficient agricultural practices.

site_title: Manhattan House up for sale, S$300m reserve price
summary: Manhattan House, a 99-year leasehold commercial site in Singapore, is up for sale via a public tender with a reserve price of S$300 million. The 269-unit development sits on a 4,167.7 square meter land area and is zoned for commercial use. The site has attracted interest from local and overseas developers, with ERA Realty Network noting its prime location and competitive reserve price. The tender closes on November 20.

site_title: Investing in Israeli tech: investors must bring more than just funding
summary: Israeli tech companies have gained international recognition for their innovative solutions, with many being acquired by top tech companies such as Amazon and Samsung. Recent acquisitions include CloudEndure by Amazon and Corephotonics by Samsung. The medical sector is also a promising area, with companies like those in this space showing potential for growth. Investors looking to invest in Israeli tech must consider not only funding but also the ability to support and grow these companies, which often require more than just financial backing.

site_title: New app by UOB, SoReal helps SMEs buy commercial properties faster
summary: UOB and SoReal Prop have launched a new mobile app, RealCommercial, allowing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to search and get valuations for commercial properties in less than a minute. The app provides a bank-backed valuation for loan applications, shortening the process from up to seven days. With the app, SMEs can view loan quantum based on their average monthly cash flow or affordability, and browse listings from SoReal Prop. This is the first commercial property solution in Singapore, offering a digital valuation service to SMEs.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust raises S$400m through private placement
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) raised S$400 million through a private placement of 176.6 million new units at S$2.265 per unit, with pricing at the top end of its indicative range.

site_title: Two Lefts won't beat a Right
summary: The Democratic Party's divide between the Old Centre and the New Left poses a challenge for the party's unity and potential success in the 2020 US presidential election. Traditionally, the left-leaning party has been associated with the working class, but recent electoral results show that its voters are predominantly upper-middle-class professionals. The New Left, led by figures like Elizabeth Warren and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortes, focuses on social justice and environmental issues, while the Old Centre, represented by Joe Biden, emphasizes strengthening the welfare state and protecting economic interests. To overcome this divide, Warren would need to move towards the centre on social-cultural issues while maintaining her commitment to workers' rights and a viable welfare state.

site_title: Losing the Apple battle might help win the tech tax war
summary: Apple is set to face off against EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager over unpaid taxes in Ireland. A 2016 ruling imposed a 13 billion euro bill on Apple, which may be used to her advantage if the court rules in her favor. A decision could boost Ireland's coffers and validate Vestager's efforts to end sweetheart tax deals. The outcome, expected in months, may also impact Vestager's position in the tech tax war.

site_title: Amazon's Alexa masters Hindi - and Hinglish - in time for Diwali
summary: Amazon's Alexa has mastered Hindi and Hinglish, a blend of Hindi and English, in time for India's Diwali shopping season. The voice assistant can now respond in Hindi and Hinglish, switching between the languages automatically, and can also understand regional accents and dialects. This move aims to cater to India's growing e-commerce market and target first-time internet users in the countryside. Amazon's head scientist of Alexa AI, Rohit Prasad, said that Alexa has to work for everyone, regardless of language, and is committed to improving its language skills.

site_title: IBM helps young students develop Pathways in Technology
summary: IBM's Pathways in Technology (P-Tech) programme in Singapore provides academic, technical, and workplace skills to students through a six-year period, from ITE to diploma studies at polytechnic level. The programme, which began in 2018, offers mentorship, workplace learning, and training, and aims to equip students with in-demand skills in STEM fields. IBM partners with industry players to provide students with skills training, mentorship, and paid internships, and has seen over 100,000 students participate in the programme globally. The programme aligns with IBM's corporate social responsibility goals and aims to develop skilled talent in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore's asset management industry grows at slower 5.4% pace in 2018: MAS
summary: Singapore's asset management industry grew at a 5.4% pace in 2018, reaching S$3.44 trillion, driven by a 15% surge in alternative assets to S$646 billion. Strong inflows and valuation gains in private equity and venture capital fueled this growth.

site_title: Thai court rejects petition seeking to disqualify PM
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court rejected a petition by 110 lawmakers to disqualify Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-o-cha, citing his eligibility to hold office after the March general election. The court ruled that Prayuth was not a state official when he won the parliamentary vote, and therefore was not ineligible to stand under constitutional rules. The decision is the second in a week to go in favor of the prime minister, signaling continued support for the government, according to a Thai politics expert.

site_title: Where's the beef? Argentine ranchers stake hopes on more of it going to China
summary: Argentine beef exports surged to US$870 million in the first seven months of 2019, with 185,604 tonnes shipped to China, surpassing Brazil's share. China is seeking to diversify its protein supply amid African swine fever, and Argentine ranchers hope to build on their recent status as top exporter to China by getting more local meatpacking plants approved. Industry officials and Chinese teams have inspected Argentine meat plants, and an Argentine trade delegation is currently in China meeting potential buyers. This could be a significant windfall for Argentina, which is battling a deep recession and debt crisis.

site_title: New South Wales rejects Korea-led coal project on climate concerns
summary: New South Wales has rejected Korea Electric Power Corp's (Kepco) Bylong coal project due to climate change concerns. The state's Independent Planning Commission ruled that the project was not in the public interest, citing intergenerational equity. The decision marks the third coal project in Australia knocked back this year, following a landmark ruling in February. The project, which aimed to mine 6.5 million tonnes of coal per year, will not proceed due to its predicted environmental and heritage costs being borne by future generations.

site_title: Huawei eyes computer market as US squeezes telecom business
summary: Huawei plans to expand its presence in the global computer hardware market as the US squeezes its telecom business. Deputy chairman Ken Hu expects the company to invest $1.5 billion in the market, citing a projected value of over $2 trillion by 2023. Huawei's 5G network rollout is expected to start contributing to revenue from next year, with over 50 commercial contracts secured. The company is also investing in artificial intelligence, launching the world's fastest AI training cluster, dubbed Atlas 900, and pledging to invest $1.5 billion in its developer program.

site_title: Dollar edges higher before Fed decision
summary: The US dollar edged higher against the Japanese yen, reaching a seven-week high, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Market participants expect a rate cut, but some are buying the dollar in anticipation of a more dovish outcome. The dollar index is up 0.2% to 98.43, while the euro is 0.2% lower at $1.1049. The Fed's decision will be closely watched, with the Bank of Japan's meeting also on the horizon, where officials may consider easing policy and introducing deeper negative rates.

site_title: Anwar expects to take power around May 2020
summary: Malaysian ruling party leader Anwar Ibrahim expects to take power around May 2020, two years after Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad took power. Anwar, who cut a deal to become prime minister ahead of the 2018 election, said there's an understanding that the transition will happen at that time, but he doesn't want to be too specific about the exact month.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OKIB, a joint-venture vehicle linked to Rich Capital, received a notice of default from the main contractor of the Oxley Convention Centre development project in Batam, Indonesia. The contractor alleges that OKIB breached contract terms by not making payments, totaling 32.7 billion rupiah. Envictus International Holdings is also ceasing its loss-making Texas Chicken operations in Indonesia, selling its six stores for RM9.25 million. FRASERS Logistics and Industrial Trust (FLT) will be included in the GPR 250 Index Series starting Sept 23.

site_title: Telcos need new ideas to dial up revenue from rising data use
summary: Singapore's telcos face a decline in data prices, despite strong growth in data usage, due to intense price competition. Market leader Singtel's data revenue shrank by 3% in the first six months of 2019, while mobile service revenues declined 7.5% and 9.9% for Singtel and StarHub, respectively. To recover, telcos may need to shift focus from price competition to offering value-added services, such as social media data packages, and exploring new revenue streams through platforms like streaming services. Moody's analysts expect the price war to end in the next three years, but the winner may not reap the expected benefits.

site_title: Saudi says Iranian sponsorship of attack undeniable, displays arms
summary: Saudi Arabia has displayed evidence of Iranian sponsorship in the recent attack on its oil facilities, including Iranian drones and cruise missiles. The attack, which halved Saudi oil production, was launched from the north and is undeniable evidence of Iranian aggression, according to Defence Ministry spokesman Colonel Turki al-Malki. Iran has denied involvement, but the coalition blames the Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthi movement, which is "covering up" for Iran. The incident has raised tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Libra Group receives letters of demand, applies for court protection
summary: Libra Group has received four letters of demand from creditors totaling S$9.3 million, prompting the company to apply for six months of court protection from creditors. The application, filed on Wednesday, grants Libra an interim debt moratorium of up to a month before the High Court decides on the matter. The company has also revealed that it has a mortgaged property at Sungei Kadut that creditors are seeking repayment for.

site_title: Trump orders government to 'substantially increase' Iran sanctions
summary: President Donald Trump announced plans to substantially increase sanctions on Iran in response to a suspected Iranian attack on Saudi oil facilities. The US already enforces widespread sanctions, but Trump's new measures aim to further cripple Iran's economy. A US official confirmed Iran's involvement, but Trump has not yet put categorical blame. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is set to meet with Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to discuss a response. The move is seen as a response to pressure from Washington to go to war with Iran, which Trump has resisted expanding US military entanglements abroad.

site_title: DBS aims to double Thai wealth business by 2023
summary: DBS Bank has announced plans to double its wealth assets managed in Thailand to $8 billion by 2023, up from $4 billion. The bank is partnering with DBS Vickers Securities (Thailand) to provide an integrated onshore and offshore wealth management proposition, catering to Thailand's growing pool of high-net-worth individuals. DBS aims to double its wealth relationship managers in Thailand to meet increasing demand. The partnership is seen as a response to Thailand's relaxing regulatory stance on offshore investments.

site_title: Japan's exports fall most since January
summary: Japan's exports fell 8.2% in August from a year earlier, the largest drop since January, due to China's slowdown, the US-China trade conflict, and a soft global tech sector. Shipments to China dropped 12.1% and to South Korea 9.4%, with food exports, including beer, plummeting 41%. Japan's economy is vulnerable to weak exports, particularly with a looming sales tax hike and uncertainty over US tariffs on Japanese cars and auto parts.

site_title: Toyota invests US$791m in Texas as trade deal nears
summary: Toyota is investing US$791 million in Texas to build next-generation pickups at its San Antonio truck factory, boosting output in the US and easing trade tensions with the Trump administration. The investment, part of a multi-decade production-localisation drive, aims to convince the administration not to impose tariffs on imported vehicles. Toyota's US operations pledge by 2021 totals US$3 billion, following an earlier US$10 billion pledge. The spending will incorporate advanced technologies and create new jobs, with an affiliate of a supplier hiring 900 workers for a new vehicle-parts production facility.

site_title: HK stocks dive fails to attract Eastspring Investments
summary: Hong Kong stocks, particularly those in the property sector, remain unappealing to Eastspring Investments due to high valuations. Portfolio manager John Tsai has trimmed holdings of Henderson Land Development and Sun Hung Kai Properties, citing expensive valuations and lower dividend yields compared to other sectors. Tsai prefers cheaper defensives, increasing holdings in telecommunications-related stocks. The protests in Hong Kong have led to a decline in home prices, with used home prices falling about 1% since mid-June, and new luxury homes experiencing an eight-month low.

site_title: India to invite bids from global coal miners before end-2019: sources
summary: India plans to invite bids from global coal miners before the end of 2019, ending Coal India Ltd's near-monopoly on coal mining. The move aims to cut imports, which surged after the government failed to open the industry to competition. Global firms like Glencore, BHP, and Peabody Energy are expected to participate. The government plans to allow winning bidders to start developing coal blocks by early 2020, with no clear timeline for production. This move seeks to increase competition and reduce reliance on imported thermal coal.

site_title: Envictus to sell loss-making Texas Chicken operations in Indonesia
summary: Envictus International Holdings is selling its loss-making Texas Chicken operations in Indonesia for RM9.25 million (S$3 million) to Quick Serve Indonesia, a franchisee of Texas Chicken. The Indonesian subsidiary has accumulated losses of IDR15.3 billion since 2018, and Envictus will write off RM1.45 million in book value. The sale will allow Envictus to focus on its Texas Chicken operations in Malaysia, which are showing earnings, and use the proceeds for general working capital. The sale is expected to be completed by March 31 next year.

site_title: 5 adjoining Kampong Glam shophouses up for tender
summary: Five adjoining conservation shophouses in Kampong Glam, Singapore, are up for sale via public tender at a guide price of S$23.8 million. The freehold properties, totaling 4,892 sq ft, are fully tenanted and zoned "commercial" under the Master Plan 2014. The sale offers flexibility in space reconfiguration and is expected to attract both investors and corporate entities. The public tender closes on October 24, with existing tenancies subject to sale.

images.alt_text: The shophouses at 17, 19, 21, 23 and 25 Baghdad Street are located at the prime corner of Baghdad Street and Muscat Street and are zoned "commercial" under the Master Plan 2014.

site_title: DBS Vickers remisiers, UOB Kay Hian tie knot after marathon courtship
summary: DBS Vickers Securities has agreed to transfer its retail securities brokerage business to UOB Kay Hian, Singapore's largest brokerage, with approximately 100 remisiers and 800 dealers expected to join. The transfer is part of DBS's integration strategy and will make UOB Kay Hian the largest brokerage in Singapore. The deal will allow UOB Kay Hian to scale and expand its business, increasing its market share to 25%. The remisiers will bring a significant client base, with many trading global markets, and will be integrated into UOB Kay Hian's model.

site_title: Two hospitality assets flipped for 30-70% profit in just months
summary: Two Singapore hospitality assets, Darby Park Executive Suites and Wangz Hotel, were sold for significant profits. Darby Park Executive Suites, a serviced residence property, was sold for S$160 million, yielding a 72% gain for the seller. The Wangz Hotel, a freehold property, was sold for S$14 million more than its original purchase price, resulting in a 30% gain for the buyer. These transactions are attributed to the increased demand for hospitality assets following the 2018 cooling measures on residential property, with market analysts noting that these deals may not mark the start of a trend.

images.alt_text: Royal Group is understood to have sold Darby Park Executive Suites for S$160m, after having the site rezoned from residential to hotel use.
The new owner of Wangz Hotel was drawn to its unique barrel-shaped design.

site_title: Dealing with uncertainty: lessons from Black Monday to today
summary: The article "Dealing with uncertainty: lessons from Black Monday to today" reflects on the 1987 stock market crash, known as "Black Monday," and how it taught the author to focus on customer needs amidst economic uncertainty. Despite the crash, the world was experiencing rising prosperity, thawing Cold War relations, and emerging economic forces. The author's interactions with clients at the time instilled the importance of clear vision and customer focus. This lesson remains relevant today, as the author notes that opportunity never truly disappears for those with a clear direction.

site_title: Not for courts to decide parliament suspension: UK PM's lawyer
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's lawyer, James Eadie, argued before the Supreme Court that it was not for judges to intervene over the suspension of parliament. Eadie claimed parliament had been considering Brexit for years and MPs could have requested more time before Johnson suspended parliament. The lawyer's comments came as the UK is set to leave the EU on October 31. The Supreme Court's decision on whether to allow the suspension to stand is expected to be made soon.

site_title: Iran warns of crushing response, blames US for regional tension
summary: Iran has threatened a crushing response to any military strike after US officials blamed Tehran for attacks on Saudi oil sites, which Iran denies. In a letter to the US, Iran said it would not be limited in its response and warned of "aggressive actions" against Iran. The attacks, which involved cruise missiles and drones, were claimed by the Iran-aligned Houthi group in Yemen.
