Iran's President Hassan Rouhani said the conflict started with Saudi Arabia and the US, and Iran does not want conflict in the region.

site_title: Thai court rejects petition seeking to disqualify prime minister
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court rejected a petition by 110 lawmakers that claimed Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha is ineligible for office due to being a state official at the time of his election. The court ruled that Prayuth was entitled to seek the premiership after the March general election. The decision comes as critics continue to question the military's grip on power and the government's legitimacy, with concerns about legislative gridlock and a potential slowdown in the Thai economy.

site_title: PM Khan warns Pakistanis against jihad in Kashmir
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan warned citizens against going to fight jihad in Kashmir, stating it would harm the region's cause. He expressed concerns over India's intentions, saying authorities are waiting for an excuse to crack down in the disputed region. Khan promised to raise the issue at the United Nations General Assembly next week, amid tensions over Kashmir's autonomy, which India revoked on August 5.

site_title: FLT to be included in GPR 250 Index Series from Sept 23
summary: Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust (FLT) will be included in the GPR 250 Index Series starting September 23, marking the company's inclusion in the 250 most liquid globally listed property securities. FLT joins nine other Singapore Reits in the index series, with a free float market cap of at least US$50 million and deriving 75% of operational turnover from property activities. The move is expected to enhance FLT's visibility and profile among global investors.

site_title: British Airways pilots call off planned strike seeking talks
summary: British Airways pilots have called off a planned one-day strike, seeking talks to resolve a deadlock over wages. The strike, set for September 27, was called off to prevent "irreparable damage" to the brand. The British Airline Pilots' Association had previously scrapped almost all scheduled flights, affecting over 200,000 customers. The union will announce new strike dates if the airline refuses to negotiate seriously. British Airways has already begun offering full refunds or re-booking on alternate days or airlines for passengers affected by the previous two-day walkout.

site_title: 'One Planet' summit aims to inject dose of optimism in battle against global warming
summary: The "One Planet" summit, co-hosted by French President Emmanuel Macron and UN Secretary-General António Guterres, aims to boost optimism in the battle against global warming. The event comes as climate scientists warn of increasing extreme events linked to global warming. Meanwhile, Asia-Pacific countries are leading the charge in implementing domestic climate legislation and regulation, with over 800 global warming laws and policies in place. A global carbon trading market, potentially led by Asia-Pacific, could be a game-changer in the fight against climate change, with China's planned national emissions trading system expected to surpass the EU's size.

site_title: India's top electricity generator to build mega solar park
summary: India's top electricity generator, NTPC Ltd, plans to build a 5-gigawatt solar park in Gujarat, the country's largest solar project. The $4.8 billion project aims to reduce fossil fuel dependence to 70% by 2032 and will begin operations by 2024. The move is part of NTPC's goal to build 32 gigawatts of renewable capacity by 2032. The company is also considering a 500-megawatt hydropower project in Himachal Pradesh, as government regulations to cap emissions from coal-fired power plants prompt the shift towards green energy.

site_title: US: Wall Street ticks lower as FedEx warns on profit; Fed on tap
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, pressured by FedEx's warning on full-year profit, while investors awaited the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.13% to 27,075.39, the S&P 500 dropped 0.14% to 3,001.50, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.14% to 8,174.62. The move comes amidst tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's rate decision.

site_title: India bans e-cigarettes as global backlash at vaping gathers pace
summary: India has banned the sale of electronic cigarettes, citing an "epidemic" among young people and growing health concerns. The ban, effective immediately, cuts off a significant market for e-cigarette makers, including companies like Juul Labs and Philip Morris International. The Indian health ministry warned of the dangers of these products, which it says have "attractive appearances and multiple flavors" and have been linked to a rise in youth vaping. The move is part of a growing global backlash against vaping.

site_title: SIIC Environment secures concessions for China water tariff hikes
summary: SIIC Environment, a Mainboard-listed company, has secured concessions for China water tariff hikes. The company's units, SIIC Environment (Dalian) Co and Fudan Water Engineering and Technology Co, have signed agreements for concession rights at two wastewater treatment plants in Liaoning and Zhejiang provinces. The agreements cover tariff hikes effective from 2018 and 2019, with the tariff rates ranging from 0.876 yuan to 1.784 yuan per cubic metre. The company expects the projects to contribute positively to its performance going forward.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall for third day
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell for a third consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.13% to 26,754.12, amid concerns over the impact of ongoing protests on the city. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw slight gains. The decline comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's key policy decision later in the day, which is expected to have significant market implications.

site_title: Inconceivable! Twitter throws fit over possible 'Princess Bride' remake
summary: Twitter erupts in outrage after Sony Entertainment's CEO mentions a possible remake of the 1980s cult classic "The Princess Bride". The idea sparks a social media firestorm, with thousands of fans and celebrities, including Cary Elwes, expressing their disapproval. Elwes writes on Twitter, "There's a shortage of perfect movies in this world. It would be a pity to damage this one." The outpouring of discontent highlights the strong emotional attachment fans have to the beloved film.

images.alt_text: The Princess Bride, starring Andre Rene Roussimoff.

site_title: S Korea: Stocks scale near 8-week high as oil prices cool; eyes on Fed
summary: South Korean shares reached an eight-week high, closing at 2,070.73, driven by declining oil prices and a focus on the US Federal Reserve's upcoming rate decision. The KOSPI index gained for a ninth consecutive session, its highest close since July 25. The market has risen 1.45% this year and 2.2% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: US housing starts, building permits hit 12-year high
summary: US home building surged to a 12-year high in August, with single- and multi-family housing construction increasing, as lower mortgage rates boosted the struggling housing market. Housing starts jumped 12.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.364 million units, while building permits rose 7.7% to a rate of 1.419 million units, the highest level since May 2007. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates again to keep the economy growing moderately.

site_title: STI falls 0.5% as traders await Fed decision
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.51% on Wednesday, amid concerns over the upcoming Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) interest rate decision. Oil prices remained elevated despite Saudi Arabia's potential oil output restoration by the end of September. Asian markets traded lower, with Rex International and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding also declining. However, Singapore Technologies Engineering was the top gainer, and Mapletree Industrial Trust rose on news of a large placement. Analysts expect the FOMC decision to have a significant impact on markets, with some predicting a dovish stance.

site_title: Rich Capital JV receives default notice from Batam project contractor
summary: Rich Capital's joint venture, OXLEY Karya Indo Batam (OKIB), received a notice of default from contractor Rich-Link Konstruksi (RLK) over unpaid payments for the Oxley Convention Centre project in Batam, Indonesia. OKIB allegedly breached contract terms by not making payments, despite certified progress payments of IDR32.7 billion (S$3.2 million). The notice was received on September 9.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps 10-day winning streak
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index slipped 0.18% to 21,960.71, snapping a 10-day winning streak, amid profit-taking from recent gains. The broader Topix index also fell 0.49%. The market downturn was attributed to investors cashing in on recent gains.

site_title: Europe: Equities dip at open before Fed meeting
summary: European stock markets declined at the open on September 18, 2019, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The FTSE 100 fell 0.1%, the DAX 30 dropped 0.1%, and the CAC 40 fell 0.2%. Investors expect the Fed to deliver its second interest rate cut of the year, which could boost markets.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.5% on Wednesday ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.51% on Wednesday due to sluggish market trading ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee interest rate decision. Oil prices remained elevated despite Saudi Arabia's potential oil output restoration by the end of September, amid Middle East tensions. Asian markets, including Singapore, traded lower, while China and South Korea closed with gains.

site_title: US lawmakers seek to ramp up pressure on Hong Kong
summary: US lawmakers are moving forward with a bill to pressure Hong Kong's government over its treatment of protesters, threatening the territory's special trading status. The Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act would allow sanctions on Chinese officials and require annual assessments of Hong Kong's autonomy. The bill's sponsor, Senator Marco Rubio, says it's long overdue for the US to respond, while Representative Jim McGovern's PROTECT Hong Kong Act aims to prohibit US companies from exporting crowd control equipment to Hong Kong. China's foreign ministry has urged the US to stop interfering in its affairs.

images.alt_text: Joshua Wong, secretary-general of Hong Kong's Demosisto party and leader of the "Umbrella Movement" arrives to testify before the Congressional-Executive Commission on China about the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong, on September 17, 2019 on Capitol Hill.

site_title: Malaysia's Malindo Air confirms passenger data breach
summary: Malaysia's Malindo Air has confirmed a data breach involving 35 million passengers, including passport details, addresses, and phone numbers, which were leaked online. The breach was discovered by a cybersecurity firm, Kaspersky, which alerted its users to treat incoming emails and messages with caution. Malindo Air is notifying authorities and advising customers to change their passwords. The incident occurred when files were uploaded to a public Amazon Web Services bucket. The airline has declined to provide details on the investigation, stating it does not store customer payment details.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as oil stocks weigh; domestic data, Fed outcome eyed
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.2% on Wednesday, weighed down by energy stocks ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate decision and key domestic employment data. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,681.60. Investors are also cautious about the impact of the upcoming employment report on the central bank's monetary policy decision.

site_title: Hot stock: Mapletree Industrial Trust jumps 4.3% after S$400m placement
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) surged 4.3% in afternoon trade after pricing an oversubscribed S$400 million private placement of units at S$2.265 each. The trust raised S$393.6 million to partially fund its US$1.37 billion North American data centre portfolio purchase. MIT's manager said the placement was about 6.3 times covered, with strong participation from new and existing institutional investors.

site_title: Thailand culls 200 pigs amid heightened fears over African swine fever
summary: Thailand has culled over 200 pigs in the northern province of Chiang Rai amid heightened fears of African swine fever, a deadly disease that has affected neighboring countries. The culling is a preventative action after two pigs died mysteriously, and blood and tissue samples are being sent to a lab for testing. Thailand has banned imports of pig and pork products from Laos and Myanmar, which have confirmed cases of the disease, and has not reported an outbreak in its own pigs. The action is in line with protocols to curb outbreaks of animal diseases.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's asset management industry grew at 5.4% to S$3.4 trillion last year, with a 15% surge in alternative assets to S$646 billion. This growth was driven by strong inflows and valuation gains in private equity and venture capital. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement and seeks a lower rate. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: DBS aims to double Thai wealth business by 2023
summary: DBS Bank aims to double its wealth assets managed in Thailand to S$8 billion by 2023, partnering with DBS Vickers Securities (Thailand) to provide an integrated onshore and offshore wealth management proposition. The bank plans to double its number of wealth relationship managers in Thailand to cater to the growing pool of high-net-worth individuals seeking to diversify their portfolios. The partnership will deliver a seamless onshore and offshore experience to clients, providing a holistic wealth management solution.

site_title: Millions may risk jail as Indonesia to outlaw sex outside marriage
summary: Indonesia is set to pass a new penal code that criminalizes consensual sex outside marriage, with penalties that could lead to jail time. The move has been criticized by rights groups as an intrusion on basic freedoms. The code, which includes stricter penalties for insulting the president's dignity, is expected to be adopted in the next week after a final draft was agreed upon by parliament and the government. The new code is seen as part of a trend towards deeper religious piety and conservative Islamic activism in Indonesia, a predominantly Muslim country with a significant Christian, Hindu, and Buddhist minority.

images.alt_text: Indonesian lawmakers said the new penal code, which would replace a Dutch colonial-era set of laws, was a long overdue expression of Indonesian independence and religiosity.

site_title: 5 adjoining Kg Glam shophouses up for sale with S$23.8m guide price
summary: Five adjoining conservation shophouses in Kampong Glam are up for sale at a guide price of S$23.8 million. The freehold shophouses, located at 17-25 Baghdad Street, have a total land area of 4,892 sq ft and are zoned "commercial" under the Master Plan 2014. The properties are fully tenanted, with food and beverage outlets on the ground floor and offices on the upper floors. Foreigners and companies are eligible to purchase, and the sale is subject to existing tenancies, closing on October 24.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,172.46, down 0.33% on day
summary: Singapore stocks closed down 0.33% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,172.46. Losers outnumbered gainers 154 to 124, and about 504.9 million securities worth S$408.8 million changed hands. Key movers included Rex International, down 3.23%, and Mapletree Industrial Trust, up 4.29%. Banking stocks also fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC losing 1.07%, 1.33%, and 0.54%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore companies not doing enough to retain, tap talent of older staff: Prudential survey
summary: A Prudential survey of 200 Singapore-based executives found that companies are not investing enough in retaining and tapping the talent of older staff, despite the rapidly aging workforce. Nearly 48% of executives admitted to not investing enough resources, and only 16% believed their companies were committed to supporting older employees. The study also found that older workers are valued for their strong work ethic and commitment, but often face negative perceptions due to age-related biases. Experts recommend measures to foster interaction and dispel perceptions, and companies are encouraged to view older employees as assets rather than costs.

site_title: Israel heads into unknown as Netanyahu's election gamble fails
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu's attempt to hold elections for a second time this year backfired, resulting in a deadlocked outcome that left Israel convulsed by political turmoil. The inconclusive race between Netanyahu's Likud and centrist Benny Gantz's Blue and White has left neither party with a majority, forcing them to seek out potential governing partners. A national unity government may be formed, potentially requiring Netanyahu to step aside or be forced out, as President Reuven Rivlin consults with parties to determine the next government. Coalition talks could take up to six weeks.

site_title: Haze closes Malaysian schools, sparks fears for Singapore F1
summary: Malaysia closed over 1,000 schools due to toxic haze from Indonesian forest fires, which worsened air quality to "very unhealthy" levels along the west coast. The haze, caused by illegal fires on Sumatra and Borneo islands, has added to concerns about global warming and has raised fears that this weekend's Formula One race in Singapore may be affected. Indonesia's government has deployed thousands of security forces and water-bombing aircraft to tackle the blazes, but experts believe they may not be extinguished until the rainy season in October.

site_title: US Zendesk bags EDB grant for regional tech talent development
summary: Zendesk, a US-headquartered customer experience solutions provider, has secured a grant from Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) to develop regional tech talent. The grant will help Zendesk double its product development and engineering team over the next three years. The partnership aims to hire more software engineers and expand into new initiatives, including the launch of its customer relationship management platform. Zendesk has over 650 employees in the Asia-Pacific, with a 23% year-on-year growth, and plans to reach its ambition of becoming a "billion-dollar company by 2020".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.81 points to 1,599.49. Losers outnumbered gainers 480 to 339, and volume reached 2.0 billion lots worth RM1.6 billion.

site_title: COE prices end mixed in latest tender
summary: COE prices ended mixed in the latest tender, with premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp settling at $31,759, marginally lower than two weeks ago. In contrast, COE prices for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp increased to $37,000, and Open COE prices rose to $40,000. Private-hire firms drove demand, submitting bids in the closing minutes of the tender, typically for petrol-electric hybrid cars. Commercial vehicle COE prices increased slightly to $25,556, while motorcycle premiums fell to $3,601.

site_title: Malaysia's Budget 2020 might see SME support, infrastructure spend: analysts
summary: Malaysia's Budget 2020 is expected to prioritize small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and infrastructure projects to mitigate the impact of the US-China trade war. Analysts predict a 3.2% fiscal deficit in 2020, with possible measures including lower interest rates, grants, and financing guarantees for SMEs. The government has also signalled no new taxes, but corporate tax cuts are unlikely. Contingency funds of RM5 billion to RM8 billion may be allocated for high-impact projects, potentially widening the fiscal deficit to 3.5-3.7% of GDP.

site_title: New app by UOB, SoReal helps SMEs buy commercial properties faster
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and property portal SoReal Prop have launched a new mobile app, RealCommercial, to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) buy commercial properties faster. The app provides bank-backed valuations and loan quantum information, shortening the process from up to seven days to under a minute. This is the first commercial property solution in Singapore, with UOB and SoReal Prop aiming to provide SMEs with certainty and speed in the property-buying process.

site_title: Meaty issue: Mock pork edges onto Southeast Asian plates
summary: Vegan alternatives to traditional Southeast Asian dishes are gaining traction, with chefs and food producers introducing plant-based versions of popular dishes. In Thailand, chef Songpol has created a vegan version of pad kra phao, a spicy Thai dish, using a pork imitation made from peas, shiitake mushrooms, rice, and soy. The trend is part of the growing "alt-protein" sector, expected to be worth $140 billion in a decade, driven by environmental, ethical, and health concerns. While some diners remain skeptical, there is growing interest in plant-based options, with companies investing heavily in the sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks edged up at the open, following a two-day sell-off, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.18% to 26,838.43. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight gains, up 0.20% and 0.19% respectively. Market attention is now focused on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the day.

site_title: Coachella, BTS concert promoter AEG sets up regional HQ in Singapore
summary: AEG, the sports and entertainment giant, has established its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, marking a significant expansion in the region. Industry veteran Matthew Lazarus-Hall has been appointed as senior vice-president for Asia-Pacific at AEG Presents, overseeing touring, festivals, and sports across the Pan-Asian region. The move is driven by AEG's continued growth in Asia and Australia, solidifying its commitment to partners and business.

site_title: Australia: Shares softer, dragged by resource sector; New Zealand down
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.2% in cautious trade ahead of employment data and the US Federal Reserve's rate decision, with resource stocks dragging the market down. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,682.60. The energy sector declined 1.6% due to a fall in oil prices, while Qantas Airways rose 2% on higher oil prices. New Zealand's benchmark index slid 0.7% due to consumer stocks.

site_title: Budweiser maker revives Hong Kong IPO plan with reduced ambitions
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev, maker of Budweiser and Stella Artois, has revived plans to list its Asia unit in Hong Kong, aiming to raise nearly $5 billion. The company had previously sought to raise $10 billion but scaled back ambitions after failing to garner enough institutional support. The IPO, backed by Singapore's GIC, will provide a boost to the Hong Kong stock exchange, which has been impacted by protests and the China-US trade war. The deal, valued at $4.8 billion, will be the second-largest IPO of 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong's summer of protests leaves economy bruised and battered
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests, now in their fourth month, have severely impacted the city's economy. Tourist arrivals have plummeted 40% in the last month, with hotel occupancy rates down by half and retail and dining sectors severely affected. Businesses, including luxury brands and local shops, have been forced to lay off staff as sales decline. The city's economy contracted 0.4% in the second quarter, with a 5.7% yearly fall in exports. The decline in mainland Chinese tourists, who account for the largest group, has also contributed to the economic downturn, with 90% fewer tour groups visiting the city in the first 10 days of September.

site_title: Singapore shares edge higher on Wednesday ahead of Fed; STI up 0.14% to 3,187.46
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.14% to 3,187.46 on Wednesday, driven by late US market gains and anticipation of a Federal Reserve rate decision. The Straits Times Index gained 4.46 points, with 34 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 44, as investors await the Fed's decision.

site_title: Singapore mutual funds charge higher fees than global average: Morningstar
summary: Singapore's mutual funds charge higher fees compared to the global average, with most funds charging front loads and trail commissions. According to Morningstar's Global Investor Experience report, Singapore is graded "below average" for fees and expenses, with asset-weighted median fees being high. However, some positive changes have been observed, including the government's reduction of expenses for the CPF Investment Scheme. The US, Australia, and the Netherlands received "top" grades for their low costs, while Taiwan and Italy received "bottom" grades. Overall, fund fees have declined globally, with the Netherlands seeing the biggest drop in fees since the last study in 2017.

site_title: Asia least prepared against ageing, automation threats as Singapore leads in region: study
summary: A study by Mercer and Marsh & McLennan Insights found that Asian countries, particularly South Korea, China, and Japan, are among the least prepared to combat the threats of societal ageing and workplace automation. Singapore ranked 13th, despite having a high labour workforce participation rate for those aged 65 and over. The study highlights the need for governments, organizations, and businesses to adapt to the challenges of ageing and automation, with measures including career path assessments, targeted skills-gap training, and flexible work arrangements.

site_title: US AI firm Digital Reasoning wins investment from StanChart's venture arm
summary: US AI firm Digital Reasoning has secured US$40 million in funding from Standard Chartered Bank's venture arm, SC Ventures. The investment will help expand its financial services product offerings in Asia Pacific, the Middle East, and other international markets. Digital Reasoning aims to broaden its pre-trained model catalog and support growth in financial markets across these regions. The company, which recently opened its Asia-Pacific business office in Singapore, will partner with Standard Chartered to develop communications surveillance solutions for financial institutions.

site_title: Health fears prompt Swiss 5G revolt
summary: Switzerland is experiencing a nationwide revolt against the deployment of 5G technology due to health concerns over radiation from the antennas. Demonstrators are set to protest in Bern, and several cantons have delayed or canceled 5G-compatible antenna constructions. The move comes amid the US-China trade war, with concerns over Chinese company Huawei's 5G equipment and potential espionage risks. The Swiss government has not commented on the health concerns, but the protest highlights growing public skepticism about the safety of 5G technology.

site_title: Gushcloud names Def Jam co-founder as president, raises US$11m for global push
summary: Gushcloud International, a Singapore-based influencer agency, has raised $11 million in funding to drive global expansion. Co-founder Russell Simmons, known for his work with Def Jam, has been appointed as president, tasked with navigating the company's global growth and expanding its portfolio of American talents and clients. The funding round, led by GDP Ventures, aims to establish the agency's headquarters in Los Angeles and build an international roster for export to South-east and North Asia.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of key Federal Reserve meeting, oil drops again
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's key policy decision, with oil prices tumbling after Saudi oil facilities were attacked. Crude prices dropped further in Asia, despite Riyadh's earlier-than-expected restoration of two major installations. Investors focus on the Fed's expected interest rate cut and post-meeting statement for future plans, with low fears of military retaliation against Iran.

site_title: Singapore's asset management industry grew at slower 5.4% pace to S$3.4 trillion last year: MAS
summary: Singapore's assets under management grew at a slower 5.4% pace to S$3.4 trillion in 2018, despite a challenging global financial market year. The growth was mainly driven by a 15% surge in alternative assets, such as private equity and venture capital. Traditional AUM declined 7% in 2018, while the alternatives sector expanded by 15% to S$646 billion. The Monetary Authority of Singapore attributes Singapore's asset management industry to its role as a global-Asia gateway for asset managers and investors, with over three-quarters of AUM sourced from outside the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 5.24 points to 1,599.06, amid a weaker market. Volume reached 52.52 million lots worth RM14.90 million, with 102 gainers outnumbering 68 losers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel DC Reit, Accrelist
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has entered into a conditional forward purchase agreement to acquire a warehouse in Australia for A$18.4 million (S$17.4 million). Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) raised S$400 million through an oversubscribed private placement. Keppel DC Reit's units rose 7.78% after raising S$478.2 million to fund a proposed acquisition. Meanwhile, Accrelist is looking to buy The Wellness Clinic at Wheelock Place for an indicative consideration of S$17 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of Federal Reserve decision
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on September 18, 2019, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's decision, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.05% and the Topix index down 0.32%. Investors await the Fed's decision, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Angry farmers to face off with New Zealand's Fonterra over financial woes
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, is facing financial woes and angry farmer shareholders over its ill-fated foreign expansion. The company is forecast to post a second year of financial losses, with asset writedowns worth billions of dollars. Farmers have transferred production to smaller rivals, and some have lost millions in dividends. Fonterra's management has pledged to rein in its global ambitions and focus on producing milk in New Zealand, but many farmers remain skeptical, calling for a clear turnaround strategy and a return to its core business of collecting, processing, and selling milk.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust raises S$400m through oversubscribed private placement
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) raised S$400 million through an oversubscribed private placement of 176.6 million new units at S$2.265 per unit, a 1.5% discount to its adjusted VWAP. The funds will partially fund a US$1.37 billion joint purchase of a North American data centre portfolio, with S$393.6 million allocated for the deal and S$6.4 million for fees and expenses. The trust's trading halt was lifted on Wednesday morning, with new units expected to commence trading on September 26.

site_title: South Korea confirms second case of African swine fever
summary: South Korea has confirmed its second case of African swine fever at a pig farm near the border with North Korea. The outbreak occurred at a farm in Yeoncheon, northwest of Seoul, and comes less than four months after North Korea reported its first case in May. This marks the first time the virus has spread to South Korea.

site_title: Asian firms' sentiment bounces from low but recession fears grow: poll
summary: Asian companies' sentiment improved slightly to 58 in the September quarter, up five points from 10-year lows, according to a Thomson Reuters/Insead survey. Despite the slight improvement, most firms do not plan to hire or expect business to pick up due to recession fears. The survey also noted that the risk of a global recession is a major concern, with companies citing uncertainty and slowing growth as key factors. The Asian Business Sentiment Index reading above 50 indicates that optimistic respondents outnumbered pessimists.

images.alt_text: Confidence among companies in Asia lifted slightly in the September quarter from 10-year lows, but most firms do not plan on hiring or expect business to pick up as they see a risk of a global recession looming, a Thomson Reuters/Insead survey found.

site_title: Accrelist to buy Wheelock medical aesthetics clinic for S$17m
summary: Accrelist, a CATALIST-listed corporate accretion services provider, is set to acquire The Wellness Clinic at Wheelock Place for S$17 million. The acquisition, valued based on the clinic's 2019 normalised profit after tax, is part of Accrelist's expansion into medical aesthetics. The clinic offers anti-ageing technology and non-surgical treatments. The deal is subject to a definitive agreement and shareholder approval. Accrelist aims to target affluent clients with its medical aesthetics arm, which has recently expanded into Malaysia and Singapore.

site_title: Wilton Resources to raise S$3.3m via share placements
summary: Wilton Resources Corporation, a CATALIST-listed gold miner, plans to raise S$3.3 million through the placement of 125 million new shares at S$0.0261 apiece. The placement, valued at 4.88% of the company's enlarged share capital, will fund the final stages of a flotation and carbon-in-leach mineral processing facility in Indonesia. The company will use 90% of the proceeds for the facility and 10% for general working capital. Trading in Wilton Resources shares was halted, but will resume on Wednesday.

site_title: Washington Post ad tech platform aims at Google-Facebook duopoly
summary: The Washington Post has launched a new ad tech platform called Zeus Prime, aiming to help newspapers counter the loss of online revenue to Google and Facebook. Zeus Prime is a self-service ad-buying interface that allows buyers to create ad campaigns and target across a marketplace of trusted publishers. The platform aims to give advertisers an alternative to the duopoly of Google and Facebook, which control 60% of US online ad revenues. Zeus Prime is part of the Post's Arc Publishing platform and will be offered to other newspapers starting in 2020.

site_title: Anwar says he will succeed Mahathir as Malaysia prime minister around 2020
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is expected to step down around May 2020, allowing Anwar Ibrahim to take power, according to Anwar Ibrahim. The transition is part of a deal made before last year's election. Anwar, 72, dismissed reports that other party leaders, such as Azmin Ali or Mukhriz Mahathir, would be considered for the role instead of him. The exact timeline remains flexible, with Anwar stating he should assume the position "around that time" without specifying the exact month.

site_title: Saudi says to meet oil commitment to Asian refiners, some changes
summary: Saudi Aramco has informed at least six Asian refiners, including three in India, that it will meet its oil commitment for October despite attacks on Saudi oil facilities. Refineries will receive full allocated volumes of crude oil, with some grade changes, such as switching to Arab heavy instead of Arab mix oil. This indicates Saudi Arabia's ability to maintain supply to top consumers despite the attacks, with no immediate disruptions expected.

site_title: AI firm DataRobot raises US$206m Series E funding; EDBI joins as new investor
summary: US-based AI firm DataRobot has raised US$206 million in a Series E funding round led by Sapphire Ventures. New investors include Singapore's EDBI, Tiger Global Management, and World Innovation Lab. Existing investors significantly increased their ownership, while others like Intel Capital, NEA, and Sands Capital also participated. The funding round is part of DataRobot's efforts to expand its presence in the AI market, strengthening its position in the competitive AI landscape.

site_title: Big banks score win as US regulator proposes easing post-crisis derivatives rules
summary: A US banking regulator proposed easing post-crisis derivatives rules, expected to free $40 billion across major banks, in a move seen as a win for Wall Street lenders. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) plan would scrap the requirement for affiliates within the same bank group to post upfront margin when trading derivatives with one another. Industry groups hailed the move, citing common-sense reforms to level the playing field, while Democratic lawmakers warned it could encourage banks to shift risk to the US, where they are backed by federal deposit insurance.

site_title: US unveils plans to extend scrutiny of foreign investment
summary: The US government has unveiled plans to extend scrutiny of foreign investment, including a proposal to block foreign purchases of real estate near military bases. The proposal, which is part of a proposal to expand the powers of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS), aims to review foreign investment in critical technologies, infrastructure, and sensitive data. This move is seen as a response to increasing concerns about Chinese companies' involvement in US firms, with the US Treasury Department seeking to strengthen oversight of foreign investments.

site_title: Black carbon from air pollution found in placentas: study
summary: Researchers have found black carbon particles from air pollution in placentas, particularly in those of women exposed to high levels of airborne pollutants. The study, published in Nature Communications, suggests that these particles can accumulate in the placenta and potentially harm fetal development, contributing to low birth weight and increased risk of health conditions. The findings provide a plausible explanation for the detrimental health effects of air pollution on newborns.

site_title: Pence rebuffs Solomon Islands PM after nation cuts ties with Taiwan
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence has canceled plans to meet with Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare due to the Pacific island nation's decision to cut ties with Taiwan in favor of China. This move comes as the Solomon Islands joins the sixth country to switch allegiance to China since 2016. Pence had initially agreed to meet with Sogavare in July, but the meeting is now off the table. The decision highlights tensions between the US and China over Taiwan's diplomatic status.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Mike Pence has canceled plans to meet with the leader of the Solomon Islands to discuss development partnerships after the Pacific island cut ties with Taiwan in favour of China this week, a senior US official said on Tuesday.

site_title: IBM, Citi, Ubisoft back Singapore blockchain accelerator for late-stage startups
summary: IBM, Citi, and Ubisoft have partnered with TRIBE Accelerator, a blockchain accelerator in Singapore, to support late-stage startups. The partnership aims to help growth-stage startups bring their blockchain solutions to market and scale internationally. The second cohort of startups, including Binance-backed Torus and SGInnovate-backed AID:Tech, will have access to global markets and resources. Since its launch last year, the accelerator has helped companies raise over S$16.8 million and has garnered support from government and corporate partners, including AXA and Intel.

site_title: Japan's exports fall for 9th straight month as global demand falters
summary: Japan's exports declined 8.2% in August for the 9th consecutive month, driven by a slowdown in global demand. This marks the longest run of declines since 2015-2016. The decline was smaller than expected, but still poses pressure on the Bank of Japan to expand stimulus. The global economic uncertainty, particularly over US trade policy, has contributed to the slowdown. Japan's trade surplus with the US rose 3.8% to 472 billion yen, driven by a 9.2% decline in imports from the US.

site_title: Airlines put AI on the frontline of customer service
summary: Airlines are increasingly using artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance customer service, with many adopting live chat and chatbots to respond to customer queries. Asian airlines, such as AirAsia, are among the first to adopt AI-powered chatbots, which have contributed to significant reductions in customer calls and enquiries. According to Gartner, companies are reporting reductions of up to 70% in customer calls after implementing AI chat technology. AirAsia's AI chatbot, AVA, has increased customer satisfaction by 90% and reduced wait times, while also generating revenue from ancillary services.

images.alt_text: AirAsia unveiled its AI chatbot with website and mobile app facelift in January this year.

site_title: TSMP Law expands on several fronts
summary: TSMP Law, a Singapore law firm, has strengthened its capabilities by hiring a second senior counsel, Jeffrey Chan Wah Teck, and expanding its regulatory offering. Chan will focus on white-collar crime, regulatory investigations, and investment disputes. The firm also established a new compliance consulting firm, Integrium, to service financial institution clients. Additionally, TSMP has beefed up its financial services space with a new dedicated desk and consultants specializing in regulatory and compliance for financial institutions.

site_title: Venezuela parliament ratifies Guaido as interim president
summary: Venezuela's opposition-dominated National Assembly ratified Juan Guaido as interim president, granting him "unrestricted political support" until new elections can be held. The move comes after the government of President Nicolas Maduro said its lawmakers would return to the legislature, which they abandoned three years ago. The National Assembly's endorsement is seen as a significant development in the country's ongoing political crisis.

site_title: Federal Reserve signals rate cut as market odds fluctuate
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to deliver its second interest rate cut of the year, signaling a shift in economic outlook. Chairman Jerome Powell has indicated a readiness to act amid significant economic risks, particularly due to President Trump's trade wars. The Fed has moved to prevent market fluctuations from pushing short-term interest rates beyond control. Futures markets have fluctuated wildly, reflecting uncertainty, but economists believe a rate cut is likely, with some predicting three more cuts this year.

site_title: Broadway Industrial names COO for diversification projects
summary: Broadway Industrial Group appointed S Purushothuman K Swaminathan (Kesavan) as chief operating officer for diversification projects. He will formulate the group's diversification strategy and oversee new initiatives. Kesavan, 53, was previously chief operations officer at Beyonics International from 2018 to 2019. This appointment comes after the company named Tan Choon Hoong as CEO last month. Shares were flat at 5.1 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: French Connection posts smaller loss for H1
summary: French Connection, a British clothing retailer, reported a smaller first-half operating loss of £3.7 million, down from £5.5 million a year ago, driven by growth in its US wholesale business. The company expects the sale process to be completed by the end of the year, with discussions ongoing with several parties. Despite retail challenges, French Connection remains on track to meet full-year expectations.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says oil output to be restored by end of September
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil output will return to normal by the end of September, following attacks on two major oil facilities that cut production in half. The attacks, blamed on Iran by the US, damaged the world's largest oil processing facility and the Khurais oil field. Saudi Arabia has dipped into its strategic reserves to maintain supply to clients. The country aims to restore 11 million barrels per day capacity by the end of September and 12 million bpd by the end of November, with some repair work expected to take several weeks.

site_title: WeWork makes small round of staff cuts, hours after delaying IPO
summary: WeWork, a co-working company, made a small round of staff cuts in its New York City unit, WeWork Now, affecting fewer than 10 employees. The move comes after the company delayed its initial public offering due to criticisms about financial discipline and corporate governance. The firings signal that WeWork is willing to reduce spending, despite previous indications of a hiring spree. The company has taken steps to address investor concerns, including reducing CEO Adam Neumann's voting power and reversing a plan for his wife to sit on a committee to select his successor.

site_title: Rush-hour Hong Kong MTR train derails, eight injured
summary: A passenger train derailed during the morning rush hour in Hong Kong, injuring eight people. The train, which had 500 passengers, left the tracks near Hung Hom station in Kowloon after a broken door. Authorities are investigating the cause of the derailment, but there is no immediate suggestion of foul play. Subway services were suspended, and intercity services to mainland Chinese cities were cancelled. This incident occurs amidst Hong Kong's fourth month of political unrest, with protests turning increasingly violent.

site_title: 'We are losing the race' on climate catastrophe, warns UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned that the world is "losing the race" to avert climate disaster, but greenhouse gas reduction targets are still within reach. He made the statement ahead of a UN youth climate summit and meeting with world leaders to urge countries to raise their Paris agreement commitments, aiming to limit the Earth's temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Guterres emphasized the need for increased action to address the climate crisis, which is critical in achieving the Paris agreement's goals.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said on Tuesday the world was "losing the race" to avert climate disaster, but that greenhouse gas reduction targets were not out of reach yet.

site_title: Financial integration can lead to greater risks for stock investors
summary: Financial integration in Asia is amplifying the transmission of financial shocks, particularly from China, due to increased global capital flows and technological advancements. A study by Professor Chow found that Asian stock markets have become more susceptible to volatility spillovers from China, while those from Japan have become less so since the global financial crisis. The study suggests that deeper financial integration brings economic benefits but also exposes domestic markets to higher risks of financial instability, highlighting the need for mitigating measures to address volatility transmission.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to buy two Las Vegas casinos
summary: Blackstone is in advanced talks to buy and lease back the Bellagio and MGM Grand Las Vegas casinos from MGM Resorts International. The transaction is private and no agreement has been reached, with one or both deals potentially falling through. If successful, the deal would mark a significant move by Blackstone into the US casino market.

site_title: Preparing for the rise of the machines
summary: Accounting professionals must acquire new skills to thrive in a world where digital technology disrupts the finance function. Robotics and artificial intelligence (AI) are becoming increasingly prevalent, with experts predicting 133 million jobs will be created globally over the next decade, compared to 75 million that could be displaced. To adapt, workers will need to develop skills such as data analytics, cloud computing, and AI, as well as softer skills like empathy and creativity. The finance function is already feeling the impact, with digital tools shifting accounting activities to the frontlines of business, and roles such as transaction processing and compliance likely to be automated.

site_title: Oil plummets 6% after historic surge as Saudis signal output to be fully restored soon
summary: Oil prices plummeted 6.5% on Tuesday after Saudi Arabia signaled the restoration of full oil production capabilities following a weekend attack on key installations. Brent crude futures dropped to $64.46 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures fell to $59.34 per barrel. Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman said oil output will be restored by the end of September and increased to 11 million barrels a day by the end of the month.

images.alt_text: Oil sank from a 3½-month high on Tuesday amid signs Saudi Arabia is restoring production after a debilitating weekend attack on key installations.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher as markets await Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks rose late Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.1%, as markets await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Despite weekend attacks on Saudi oil facilities, equities recovered somewhat, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. Fed policymakers are expected to cut rates, with many predicting a 25-basis-point cut, but recent economic data may temper expectations.

site_title: Trump says China trade deal could come before US election, or not
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that a trade deal with China could be reached before the 2020 presidential election or shortly after, with Beijing reportedly preferring a different outcome. Trump claimed China thinks he will win re-election, but warned that any post-election deal would be "far worse" for Beijing. The US-China trade negotiations, set to resume in Washington, aim to resolve the 14-month trade war between the world's two largest economies, with a superficial fix expected.

site_title: 300 more Chinese arrested in Philippines crackdown
summary: Philippines authorities have arrested 324 Chinese nationals for alleged cyber crimes, including online gaming activities and investment scams, in a raid on hotels and establishments in Puerto Princesa City. This is the second major crackdown in a week, following the arrest of 277 Chinese nationals for a similar investment fraud scheme. Most of the detainees are undocumented, and they will undergo deportation proceedings. The Philippines has seen a rise in Chinese arrivals, suspected to be working illegally in the online gambling industry, since President Duterte came to power in 2016.

site_title: New York Federal Reserve steps into market to move interest rates
summary: The New York Federal Reserve Bank announced it is injecting billions of dollars into financial markets to keep short-term interest rates in line with the Federal Reserve's target range. This move comes ahead of a Fed decision expected to lower the target range, which influences borrowing costs across the financial system. The operations are the first in over a decade, indicating a significant shift in monetary policy. The Fed's decision is anticipated to impact the global economy, particularly in light of slowing GDP growth in China and a shrinking UK economy.

images.alt_text: For the first time in more than a decade, the New York Federal Reserve Bank announced Tuesday it was pumping billions of dollars into financial markets to keep short-term interest rates in line with the Federal Reserve's target range.

site_title: China stocks fall, yuan loses steam as central bank holds loan rate
summary: China's central bank held steady on loan rates, despite data showing the economy slowed in August, leading to a 1.7% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index, its largest drop in over two months. The onshore yuan fell 0.34% and 10-year government bond yields rose for a sixth day. Analysts say the move shows China is sticking to a prudent approach to stimulus, as investors anticipated a more aggressive easing of monetary policy. The losses broke a recent calm in China's markets, which had been boosted by a thaw in the trade war.

site_title: Hong Kong activists take cause to US Congress, urge pressure on Beijing
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy leaders testified before a US congressional commission, urging lawmakers to apply pressure on Beijing to protect Hong Kong's civil rights. The activists, including Cantopop star Denise Ho, warned that erosion of Hong Kong's special status would embolden China's leaders worldwide. They emphasized that their plea is not for "foreign interference" or Hong Kong independence, but rather for the US to defend Hong Kongers' rights. The appearance is likely to infuriate Beijing, highlighting the tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong.

site_title: Boeing raises 20-year forecast for China aircraft demand
summary: Boeing raised its 20-year forecast for China's aircraft demand to 8,090 planes, a 5.2% increase from last year's prediction of 7,690 planes. The forecast, valued at nearly $1.3 trillion, is driven by robust air travel demand and investment in infrastructure. Boeing projects 5,960 new single-aisle planes and 1,780 new widebody planes over the next 20 years, with China's fleet requiring $1.6 trillion worth of commercial services.

site_title: Endowus launches CPFIS portfolios with markedly lower fees
summary: Endowus, a fee-only financial advisory firm, has launched its portfolio service for the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) in partnership with UOB Kay Hian, which has received CPFIS Investment Administrator status. The effective cost of Endowus' portfolios for the CPFIS is estimated at 0.98% for a balanced portfolio, significantly lower than the market's estimated going charges of 3.52%. This is due to Endowus' low wrap fee of 0.4% and absence of sales charges, which is in line with CPFIS' intention to cap wrap fees at 0.4% and slash sales charges to zero.

site_title: Staying secure in the era of connected medical devices
summary: The Fourth Industrial Revolution is transforming the medical technology (medtech) space with connected devices, enabling timely intervention and precise diagnosis. However, these devices also pose significant cyber security risks, as seen in vulnerabilities in CT scanners and outdated software. Regulations are emerging to address these concerns, with California and the FDA setting guidelines for manufacturers to ensure reasonable security features. Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on the growing medtech market, with a strong focus on resilient infrastructure and cyber security expertise. Secure medical devices are crucial to prevent data breaches and potential patient safety risks, requiring manufacturers and healthcare organizations to prioritize cyber security in their designs and operations.

site_title: Europe: Oil, Federal Reserve nerves keep shares grounded
summary: European stocks closed marginally lower on Tuesday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index falling 0.1% as investors sought refuge in defensive sectors amid heightened geopolitical tensions. Energy shares dropped 0.8% after Saudi Arabia's oil output was expected to be fully restored in two or three weeks, contrary to initial indications of months. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut was also a concern, with banks losing steam ahead of the expected move.

site_title: Spain to hold fourth election in four years on Nov 10
summary: Spain will hold its fourth election in four years on November 10, after a months-long impasse in the parliament. The election comes after the Socialists emerged as the biggest party in April's election but failed to govern on their own. Party leaders have failed to negotiate a government, with no guarantee that a repeat vote will break the impasse. The election will be the fourth in four years, highlighting the country's deepening political divisions and inability to form a stable government.

site_title: UK makes second arrest in golden toilet theft
summary: British police made a second arrest in the investigation of the theft of a 18-carat gold toilet from Blenheim Palace, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The toilet, designed by Maurizio Cattelan and previously displayed at the US President's residence, was stolen just three days after its display began. The thieves, who have not been named, are believed to have valued the toilet at around $5 to $6 million. The arrest is the second in the ongoing investigation, with the first made on Saturday.

site_title: Experts expected to criticise US aviation authority over Boeing 737 MAX: source
summary: A panel of global civil aviation authorities, the Joint Authorities Technical Review, is expected to criticize the US Federal Aviation Administration's approval of Boeing's 737 MAX, citing a lack of transparency and improper review of design changes. The FAA was criticized for allowing Boeing employees to inspect and approve the MCAS anti-stall system, and for failing to share data with peers during certification in 2017. The panel's report, due soon, is expected to make proposals to improve approval procedures.

site_title: Co-working spaces among top six occupier sectors at 3.7m sq ft
summary: Co-working spaces in Singapore now occupy 3.7 million square feet, tripling from 2015 and becoming one of the top six occupier sectors. The sector is expected to grow 24% in 2019, driven by demand from multinational corporations and new startups. The leading co-working operator, WeWork, holds a 22% share of the market, followed by IWG and JustGroup. Average desk costs have fallen 12% to US$573 per month, and operators may expand into fringe areas or merge with landlords.

site_title: California vows to fight Trump administration's plan on emissions
summary: California officials vowed to fight the Trump administration's plan to revoke the state's authority to set its own tailpipe emissions standards, calling it a "political vendetta." The plan, set to take effect on Wednesday, would undermine California's power to impose stricter emissions rules than those set by the federal government. California Governor Gavin Newsom and Attorney General Xavier Becerra denounced the plan, warning of "devastating consequences" for children's health and air quality. They announced plans to mount a legal challenge, saying the president's administration had "no basis and no authority" to pull the waiver.

site_title: Securities watchdog looking into billionaire couple's purchase of Chip Eng Seng shares
summary: The Securities Industries Council (SIC) in Singapore is investigating the circumstances surrounding billionaire couple Celine and Gordon Tang's purchase of Chip Eng Seng shares in October 2018. The Tangs acquired 29.73% of the company's shares, paying a premium of 33% to the market price, and have since proposed a rights issue that corporate governance advocates have raised concerns about. The SIC is looking into the acquisition and the rights issue, amid concerns that the Tangs may be strengthening their control over the company without paying minority shareholders a fair price.

site_title: Virgin Australia, Qantas to compete for slots at Tokyo's Haneda airport
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd will apply for one of two new slots at Tokyo's Haneda airport, competing against Qantas Airways Ltd. The slots, available from March 2020, are allocated to Australian carriers as part of a route network review. This move comes as Virgin Australia conducts a turnaround plan amid financial struggles. The airline's application will be reviewed by Australia's International Air Services Commission.

site_title: Oracle unveils more autonomous software to boost cloud growth
summary: Oracle has unveiled an autonomous operating system that can run without human oversight and update itself without downtime, aiming to boost cloud growth. This expansion of Oracle's autonomous products follows the company's transition to cloud computing. The new software is part of a suite of tools designed to ease Oracle's cloud migration process. This move is seen as a strategic move to improve its cloud offerings and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: NODX down 8.9% in Aug, boosted by gold exports
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 8.9% year on year in August, beating economists' expectations of a 10.6% decline. The improvement was largely driven by a surge in gold exports to China. Economists are divided on whether Singapore will dodge a technical recession in the third quarter, with some predicting a manufacturing-led recession and others citing front-loaded exports and a strong Asian currency. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is likely to loosen monetary policy at its upcoming meeting.

site_title: Common ownership of companies can be beneficial
summary: A new study by Singapore Management University researchers found that common ownership of companies, where large shareholders hold stakes in rival firms, can be beneficial. This phenomenon, known as "common ownership," helps managers gather industry insights and makes better operational and investment decisions. By analyzing stock price movements, managers can gain information about industry trends and competitors, leading to more accurate profit forecasts and better decision-making. The study suggests that common ownership can induce more efficient corporate decisions, contradicting previous concerns about its impact on competition and anti-trust issues.

site_title: 'Future of semi-conductor industry bright' even when chips are down
summary: STMicroelectronics, a European chipmaker, has doubled its capacity for a key semiconductor product at its expanded wafer fab facility in Ang Mo Kio, Singapore. Despite a global electronics downturn, CEO Jean-Marc Chery remains confident in the industry's future, citing growing demand for industrial applications and new technologies. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat also expressed confidence, stating that the semiconductor industry's "future is bright" despite the slowdown.

site_title: Malaysia fast-tracks investments to win trade-war business
summary: Malaysia has established a National Committee on Investment to expedite investments amid the US-China trade dispute. The committee approved over $720 million in new investments in its first meeting, aiming to attract businesses relocating from China. Foreign direct investment to Malaysia nearly doubled to $50 billion in the first half of the year, with US investment expected to increase further. The committee, headed by the ministers of finance and international trade, has the authority to approve incentives immediately, with Intel Corp, Dell Technologies, and On Semiconductor Corp among the lead players in Malaysia's electrical & electronics industry.

site_title: 'Negative' interest rates - what gives?
summary: The European Central Bank and other central banks have adopted negative interest rates to stimulate the economy, with the US Federal Reserve considering implementing them. Negative rates charge interest on commercial banks' reserves to encourage lending, and have already led to a significant increase in negative-yielding bonds. However, the effectiveness of negative rates is debated, with concerns about their potential impact on consumer spending and bank profitability. The US economy's dependence on constant stimulus raises questions about its ability to achieve adequate growth on its own, and the Fed's decision on negative rates is expected to be made in the coming week.

site_title: Getting to grips with Singapore's tax profile
summary: Singapore's tax profile is among the strongest in the Asia-Pacific region, with tax revenues increasing by 4.4% in 2018/19. The country's tax-to-GDP ratio is lower than the OECD average, but is expected to rise as the economy grows. Corporate income tax contributed the highest share of tax revenues in 2017, followed by goods and services taxes. The government's proposed 9% GST rate increase is expected to boost GST revenues. Singapore's business-friendly tax policy and efficient tax administration make it an attractive location for investors.

site_title: Gold stays steady ahead of expected Fed rate cut
summary: Gold prices remained steady ahead of the US Federal Reserve's expected rate cut, trading at US$1,498.80 per ounce. The rate cut, expected to be a quarter-point cut, is widely anticipated and has been relatively priced in, with traders looking for forward guidance. Analysts predict that gold may see a short-term reversal if the Fed goes against market expectations, but conviction remains positive as long as prices stay above US$1,500.

site_title: Protecting your business from ever-growing reach of cryptojacking
summary: Cryptojacking, a form of malware that hijacks computing power for cryptocurrency mining, has become a growing threat to businesses worldwide. According to NTT Security's 2019 Global Threat Intelligence Report, cryptojacking detections surged by 459% between 2017 and 2018, with the technology and education sectors being the most targeted. To combat cryptojacking, businesses must invest in cybersecurity measures, including executive-level buy-in, building a culture of cyber awareness, and implementing mission-critical infrastructure such as patching and back-ups. By taking these steps, businesses can reduce their threat profile and insulate themselves from the risks associated with cryptojacking.

site_title: China welcomes Solomon's move to ditch ties with Taiwan
summary: The Solomon Islands has ditched ties with Taiwan in favor of China, with Beijing hailing the move as bringing unprecedented development opportunities. This marks the sixth country to switch allegiance since Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen took office in 2016. China's Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying implied Taiwan's actions were driven by dollar diplomacy, while Taiwan has condemned China's pressure tactics. The Solomon Islands' decision is seen as a major victory for China, expanding its influence in the South Pacific and undermining Taiwan's diplomatic efforts.

site_title: Gulf bonds nosedive from haven to hazard as strikes stun market
summary: Gulf dollar bonds plummeted in value after a surprise attack on Saudi Arabia's oil facilities, shifting from safe-haven assets to high-risk investments. The attack, attributed to Iranian-backed rebels, has raised concerns of escalating conflict and potential disruption to global oil supplies. As a result, Saudi Arabian bonds suffered the largest losses, while Qatari securities saw losses about triple that of others in the region. Experts warn that the strikes may require a meaningful risk premium, potentially forcing investors to reevaluate their choices in the Gulf.

site_title: MIT, Keppel DC Reit to issue shares to fund their respective data centre buys
summary: MAPLETREE Industrial Trust (MIT) and Keppel DC Reit are issuing shares to fund their data centre purchases. MIT is raising at least S$350 million to fund its US$965 million share of a North American data centre portfolio, while Keppel DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. The issuances will help the companies partially finance their joint purchase of the data centre portfolio worth US$1.37 billion.

site_title: Vietnam's social media crowd swells with new entrant to take on Google, Facebook
summary: A new social network, Lotus, has launched in Vietnam, aiming to compete with Google and Facebook. The platform has received $41.5 million in funding and hopes to raise more. The move follows the government's push for domestic alternatives to foreign social media platforms, which are seen as harder to control. Lotus' focus is on content creation, rather than competing directly with established players. This comes after a Facebook-style app, Gapo, debuted last month, and amid tightened internet rules and a new cybersecurity law requiring foreign companies to set up local offices.

site_title: Monsanto suffers more dents to its image
summary: Monsanto, an agribusiness giant, faces a tarnished public image in the US and India. A journalist, Carey Gillam, alleges the company censored and discredited her reporting on its herbicide business. A new lawsuit was filed in Wyoming against the company's cancer-causing Roundup weedkiller. An antitrust probe in India found the company abused its dominant position as a supplier of genetically-modified cotton seeds, and the Indian government has cut its royalty payments. These developments further erode the company's image amidst ongoing legal and regulatory challenges.

site_title: Getting ready for the Fourth Propulsion Revolution
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping's 2019 Conference, Setting Course for 2050: Powering Global Trade, highlighted the need for the shipping industry to transition away from fossil fuels to achieve zero carbon by 2050. Speakers emphasized the importance of collaboration between the industry, policymakers, consumers, and suppliers to mitigate the risks of transformation. While there is no single "silver bullet" solution, various alternative fuels such as LNG, ammonia, and hydrogen were discussed as potential options. The conference concluded that different fuels could work well in different situations, and that international regulation or taxation could drive the industry to take significant steps towards achieving zero carbon by 2050.

site_title: Adding a spark to forex trading
summary: Spark Systems aims to develop a locally bred foreign exchange marketplace in Singapore, a goal supported by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The firm, co-founded by Wong Joo Seng, seeks to reduce costs and latency in trading by offering a platform with artificial intelligence capabilities and charging lower fees compared to competitors. With revenue doubling year-over-year and plans from major banks to establish electronic trading engines in Singapore, Spark is on track to break even in two to three years and potentially disrupt the foreign exchange trading industry.

images.alt_text: Mr Wong says Spark's platforms have artificial intelligence capabilities built into them, which allow traders to buy and sell at opportune times based on the algorithm's suggestions.

site_title: Geopolitical risks push US dollar to recent highs
summary: The US dollar surged to recent highs due to ongoing geopolitical risks in the Middle East, particularly the attack on Saudi Arabian crude oil facilities, and market expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the US central bank. The dollar edged 0.1% higher against a basket of rivals, nearing a two-year high of 99.37. Investors are pricing in an 80% probability of another US rate cut by the end of the year, with some market watchers believing this may be the last rate cut until evidence of a US economic slowdown.

site_title: SoftBank leads with US$110m in financing for Brazilian online retailer
summary: SoftBank Group Corp has led a US$110 million financing round for Brazilian online home goods retailer MadeiraMadeira, with Light Street Capital and Flybridge Capital also participating. The funding comes from SoftBank's US$5 billion Latin America fund, which will be used to invest in technology, logistics, and customer services. MadeiraMadeira, which offers over a million home furnishing products, aims to expand operations beyond Brazil in Latin America, with plans to concentrate investments in the region's largest economy.

site_title: SPH ties up with Samsung to offer news tablet to Berita Harian subscribers
summary: SPH has partnered with Samsung to offer a complimentary Samsung Galaxy Tab A to new and existing subscribers of Malay newspaper Berita Harian who subscribe for 24 months. The package includes access to the BH news tablet app, which automatically downloads the latest e-paper and allows for easy sharing of articles. This initiative follows a similar promotion for SPH's Chinese newspapers, which gained 9,000 subscribers. The partnership aims to enhance the digital experience for BH readers and contribute to Singapore's Smart Nation society.

site_title: Real estate fund manager ARA exploring listing in 2-3 years: CEO
summary: ARA Asset Management, a major Asian real estate fund manager, is exploring a dual stock market listing, including one in Singapore, within the next 2-3 years. Group CEO and co-founder John Lim stated that Singapore is a "likely scenario" for the listing, alongside another venue. This move aims to increase transparency and liquidity for investors.

site_title: WeWork parent says IPO still on despite recent setbacks
summary: WeWork's parent company, The We Company, announced it plans to complete its initial public offering (IPO) by the end of the year, despite recent setbacks. The IPO was delayed earlier in the week due to concerns that not enough investors would participate. We Company faces pressure to secure funding for its operations, and its valuation was expected to be between $10 billion and $12 billion, a significant discount from its previous valuation of $47 billion. The company's CEO, Adam Neumann, will retain majority control despite corporate governance changes aimed at addressing investor concerns.

site_title: Thai PM defends police monitoring of Muslim university students
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha defended the police's request for information about Muslim university students, citing the need to build a national security database. The request, which asked for details about Muslim-organized student groups, was criticized as discriminatory and illegal. The police claim the move is linked to a series of bomb blasts in Bangkok, but Muslim students and rights groups say it infringes on their rights and freedoms. The university was asked to supply information about Muslim students, but the name of the university was redacted in the official letter.

site_title: Singapore adds another arrow in quiver in quest for top tech talent
summary: Singapore has launched Tech@SG, a government initiative to attract top tech talent, particularly in areas like artificial intelligence, data science, and Internet of Things. The program aims to facilitate fast-tracked visa and employment pass applications for companies with venture capital funding and a digital or technology offering. The two-year pilot program targets companies with at least US$10 million in VC funding and a recognized VC backer. This move aims to boost Singapore's tech ecosystem and enable the transfer of knowledge and skills between local and international experts.

site_title: Big tech companies shouldn't be broken up, says Bill Gates
summary: Bill Gates, Microsoft co-founder and former CEO, has expressed opposition to breaking up the largest US tech companies. Gates, who battled the US Justice Department in the late 1990s, suggests targeting the objectionable issues instead of splitting up the companies. This stance comes after some politicians have suggested breaking up tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Facebook to promote competition. Gates believes that antitrust measures should focus on addressing specific problems rather than dismantling entire companies, potentially hindering innovation and economic growth.

site_title: Tiong Seng CEO, project director in CPIB probe
summary: Singapore-based construction firm Tiong Seng Holdings CEO Pek Lian Guan and project director Pay Teow Heng are out on bail amid a corruption probe by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau. They were interviewed on September 11 and 12 over alleged staff loan transactions. Despite ongoing investigations, the board has allowed them to continue with their roles to ensure business continuity. The probe relates to alleged corrupt acts under Section 6(b)1 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, which carries a maximum fine of $100,000 or imprisonment of up to five years.

site_title: Taking Burberry's Victorian past to the future in spring show
summary: Italian designer Riccardo Tisci unveiled Burberry's Spring/Summer 2020 collection at London Fashion Week, drawing inspiration from the brand's Victorian roots. The "Evolution" line features delicate lace, edgy street style, and luxurious details, catering to different age groups. Tisci mixed traditional elements with modern twists, including cinched waists, voluminous sleeves, and chain detailing. The collection was certified carbon neutral, reflecting Burberry's efforts to improve its environmental credentials.

images.alt_text: Mixing delicate lace with edgy street style for looks aimed at catering to different age groups, with the unicorn as the family crest. For the evening, dresses were adorned in crystal mesh or ostrich feathers.

site_title: More women in business, better performance
summary: Women remain underrepresented in business and leading positions worldwide, with only 15% in France and 25% in STEM jobs in Singapore. Empowering more women in these fields can benefit societies and economies. France and Singapore have taken steps to improve gender diversity, including measures to promote women in top management positions and combat prejudices. The "production pact" in France and Industry Transformation Maps in Singapore aim to increase industry share in GDP, and the G-7 Gender Equality Advisory Council has identified 79 good practices for gender equality laws.

site_title: European banking lobby faces backlash over hiring regulator as CEO
summary: The Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME) has appointed Adam Farkas, a European Banking Authority (EBA) executive director, as its new CEO, sparking criticism over the "revolving door" hiring practice. Farkas will immediately cease participating in policy and supervisory work and will be subject to a two-year ban on lobbying and professional contacts with EBA staff. Critics argue the conditions imposed are weak, and a longer cooling-off period is needed to prevent insider knowledge from going directly to the banking lobby.

site_title: Indonesia revises law on anti-graft agency; activists voice objections
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved changes to the law governing the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), sparking concerns among activists that the revisions will weaken the agency's ability to fight corruption. The changes include curbing the KPK's wiretapping powers and requiring independent investigators to be civil servants. Analysts and rights groups fear the revisions are part of a plot to undermine the KPK, which has prosecuted hundreds of politicians and officials since its formation in 2002. President Joko Widodo has defended the changes, saying a supervisory board is necessary for "good governance."

site_title: Muhammad Ali, Chris Evert among 10 Andy Warhol sports portraits up for auction in November
summary: Andy Warhol's 10 sports portraits, featuring Muhammad Ali, Chris Evert, and other athletes, will be auctioned off in New York in November.
