summary: Integrated Shield scheme insurers in Singapore have shown significant improvement in their underwriting results in 2018, with Prudential being the sole insurer to turn a profit. Most others reduced their losses, partly due to premium increases and the introduction of lower-priced riders. Prudential's claims-based pricing system rewarded healthy policyholders with lower premiums, while other insurers rolled out riders with co-payment requirements. Insurers are cautious about future premium hikes, and experts emphasize the need for cost containment measures that balance quality and access to care.

site_title: 'IT' stays atop North American box office but 'Hustlers' draws raves
summary: Horror film "IT Chapter Two" stayed atop the North American box office with an estimated US$40.7 million, down from its opening weekend. Jennifer Lopez's "Hustlers" took second place with US$33.2 million, earning rave reviews. "Angel Has Fallen" and "Good Boys" followed in third and fourth place, respectively. Disney's "The Lion King" surpassed US$533 million, while Warner Bros.' "The Goldfinch" had a poor start with US$2.6 million.

site_title: No-deal Brexit would be 'disaster' warns EU business lobby
summary: Business Europe, a major EU business lobby, has warned that a no-deal Brexit would be "a disaster" for all parties involved. The organization, led by CEO Markus J. Beyrer, urged the UK and EU to engage in constructive dialogue to avoid a no-deal exit. The warning comes as UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to meet EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, with a two-day European summit scheduled for October 17 in Brussels. A no-deal Brexit would be extremely harmful for both sides, according to Beyrer.

site_title: Progress in next few days key to Brexit deal chances: UK PM Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson says the next few days are crucial to securing a Brexit deal with the European Union, with less than a week remaining before the UK's scheduled departure on October 31. Johnson aims to finalize an agreement that protects business and citizens on both sides of the English Channel and Irish border. Despite EU skepticism, Johnson believes a deal is possible and is prepared to leave without one if necessary. He travels to Luxembourg on Monday to meet outgoing European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Sunday the next few days would be key to his chances of securing a Brexit deal, and that an agreement with the European Union was still his aim and still possible.

site_title: Multi-award winning chef feeds masses at street food fest
summary: Multi-award-winning Italian-Argentinian chef Mauro Colagreco served food at the Lyon Street Food Festival in south-east France, joining 80 fellow cooks. Colagreco, the chef at Mirazur in Menton, is the only foreign chef to have been awarded three stars in the Michelin guide. This event showcased Colagreco's culinary skills, highlighting his achievements in the culinary world.

site_title: OIC foreign ministers reject Netanyahu annexation pledge
summary: The Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) has rejected Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's pledge to annex part of the West Bank, specifically the Jordan Valley, in an emergency meeting of foreign ministers in Jeddah. The 57-member pan-Islamic body condemned the move as "dangerous escalation" that undermines international efforts for a just and lasting peace, and pushes the region towards further violence and instability. The OIC's rejection comes as Netanyahu's government approved a new settlement in the occupied West Bank, further complicating the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

site_title: Q & M Dental embarks on Asian brand-building journey
summary: Q & M Dental Group, a Singapore-listed dental services provider, embarks on an Asian brand-building journey. The company, founded by Raymond Ang and Chin Siau, aims to expand organically in Singapore, Malaysia, and China, and make a regional push into South-east Asia within three years. Ang credits his father's experience at Singapore General Hospital for sparking his interest in healthcare. He and Chin Siau formed a partnership after meeting at dental school, and their vision of uniting dentists under one roof led to the formation of Q & M Dental Group. The company has grown to operate 74 dental outlets and four medical clinics in Singapore, 27 dental clinics in Malaysia, and three dental supplies and equipment distribution companies across Singapore, Malaysia, and China.

site_title: Health buffs in US go bubbly over low-calorie alcoholic drinks
summary: Health-conscious American millennials are embracing low-calorie alcoholic drinks, particularly hard seltzers, as a healthier alternative to beer and wine. The trend is driven by viral social media trends and a pursuit of healthier lifestyles. Hard seltzers have become a popular choice, offering lower calories and carbohydrates than traditional alcoholic beverages.

site_title: Streaming giants paying top dollar for TV classics
summary: Streaming giants are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to acquire classic TV series, including Friends, The Office, and The Big Bang Theory, as they compete for audience share. Netflix has lost rights to these shows, with Friends moving to HBO Max for $425 million and The Office to NBCUniversal's platform for $500 million. This trend indicates a shift in the television industry, with streaming services now launching their own TV ventures to rival Netflix's vast offerings. Classic sitcoms remain popular, and streaming platforms are willing to invest in them, but are hesitant to produce original comedies.

site_title: General Motors auto workers call strike in US
summary: The United Auto Workers (UAW) union called a nationwide strike against General Motors, affecting 46,000 workers, on September 15, 2019, after contract talks broke down. The strike was the first major stoppage at GM in over a decade, with disagreements over wages, health care benefits, and job security. GM had presented a "strong offer" in contract negotiations, but the UAW's leadership deemed it insufficient. The strike was a last resort, following a federal corruption probe and a UAW executive board member's arrest on charges of embezzlement.

site_title: F&B players get insights on how to innovate
summary: The Future Economy Council is hosting an event on October 1 at the Food Innovation & Resource Centre (FIRC) at Singapore Polytechnic, providing insights to SMEs in the food and beverage sector on how to innovate. The FIRC offers consultancy, training, lab testing, and equipment leasing services to help SMEs develop better products and processes, with a focus on extending shelf life, packaging, and consumer studies. The event will feature a tour of the facilities, a dialogue with Senior Minister Chee Hong Tat, and testimonials from F&B business owners who have worked with the FIRC.

site_title: Malaysian building materials to cost more by end-2019
summary: Malaysian building materials are expected to cost more by the end of 2019 due to industry growth and infrastructure projects such as the East Coast Rail Link. Cement prices are forecast to rise 10% to RM220 a tonne in the fourth quarter and RM250 in 2020, while steel prices are expected to remain weak due to low demand and higher supply. The construction sector is expected to grow 1.1% in 2019 and 3.5% in 2020, according to Fitch Macro Solutions.

site_title: Blame game revs up over India's car woes
summary: India's car industry is experiencing a slump, with sales falling for the 10th-straight month in August, despite a population of 1.3 billion people. The main causes are economic, with low consumer confidence and income growth, as well as increased production costs due to new emissions and safety standards. A 28% GST on new cars also contributes to the problem. Analysts say the industry's problems run deeper than just millennials' preference for ride-hailing apps, and that a more comprehensive solution is needed to boost sales and mitigate the potential economic fallout.

site_title: Hopes for trade war truce, looser monetary policy may be in vain
summary: Stocks reached record highs last week amid hopes for a US-China trade war truce and looser monetary policy, but strategists warn that these hopes may be in vain. The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, contrary to expectations, and the trade war is unlikely to be resolved in the near term. The trade war's impact on the industrial sector is causing recession fears, and analysts predict continued volatility in currency and commodity markets.

images.alt_text: Wall Street expects Fed chairman Jerome Powell to cut rates this week but the Fed board is likely to act with more restraint than its European counterparts.

site_title: Iran dismisses US claim it was behind Saudi oil attacks, says it's ready for war
summary: Iran has dismissed US claims it was behind the drone strikes on Saudi oil plants, saying it is ready for "full-fledged" war. The attacks, which knocked out 5% of global crude supply, have raised tensions in the Middle East. Iran's Revolutionary Guards commander warned that US bases and aircraft carriers in the region are within range of its missiles. The US has offered to tap emergency oil reserves if needed, while Saudi Arabia has drawn on its reserves to compensate for the loss. The conflict has been in a military stalemate for years, with the Houthis stepping up missile and drone attacks on Saudi cities.

site_title: Gold sees further room for upward move
summary: Gold prices show further potential for upward movement after resisting a move above the $1,400 price point since March 2014. The metal has been trending upwards, with a recent peak at $1,556.93 in January. Analysis suggests the bullish trend is not yet exhausted, with key indicators such as the Fibonacci retracement, stochastics oscillator, and MACD indicator supporting a move higher. A target price of $1,524.02 is expected, with a potential reach of $1,556.93 if the level is broken.

site_title: India's 100b rupee housing fund seen not enough to spur sector
summary: India's 100 billion rupee housing fund, aimed at reviving the stalled residential sector, is seen as insufficient to address the problem. The fund will provide last-mile funding for mothballed projects, but most are already non-performing assets or facing insolvency proceedings. Experts say the issue is more complex, with developers repaying twice as much debt as income, and property prices in major cities, such as Mumbai, are flagging. The fund is expected to offer brief respite for healthy projects but fails to address demand creation and the larger issues plaguing the sector.

site_title: Husband-and-wife duo help Singapore golfers to Causeway Cup draw
summary: A husband-and-wife duo, Ken and Natasha Lye, played a crucial role in Singapore's 14-14 draw against Malaysia in the Causeway Cup golf media match. The Lyes won their foursome and fourball matches, and also claimed their singles titles, lifting Singapore's score from 6-8 to 14-14. Despite trailing, the team's captain, Darryl Wee, praised their preparations, which began three months prior, and their determination to reverse the Malaysians' previous win at the Horizon Hills course in Johor.

site_title: CTBC eyes South-east Asia for overseas growth
summary: CTBC Bank, Taiwan's largest privately-owned lender, is shifting its expansion strategy to South-east Asia, aiming to capture a greater share of the region's growing intra-regional trade flows and finance domestic mid-market corporates. The bank targets to grow its net profit from overseas operations to 45% of its overall bottom line by 2023. CTBC sees opportunities in emerging Asean economies, particularly Indonesia, where domestic consumption is driving growth and demand for new banking services. The bank plans to leverage its regional network to participate in cross-border activities, with Singapore serving as its key regional hub.

site_title: Harlem property investor who could've been rich may lose it all
summary: Gisele Allard, a Harlem property investor, may lose her multimillion-dollar properties after they were sold at a foreclosure auction for $5.5 million. Allard purchased two properties in the 1980s, 239 Lenox Ave and 32 W 120th St, due to financial difficulties. The sale of her properties comes as mortgage rates climb, affecting demand in the real estate market. The loss of her properties could leave Allard homeless, highlighting the challenges faced by investors in the current market.

site_title: Money FM podcast: StarHub's plans to bounce back after profits declined in the last quarter
summary: StarHub's profits declined in the last quarter due to weaker operating profits and higher finance costs. CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos discussed the company's plans to bounce back, but no specific strategies were revealed. StarHub aims to regain its footing, but details on how they plan to achieve this were not provided.

site_title: Pace of director activity continues as market extends rebound
summary: The Straits Times Index gained 1.5% over the past five trading sessions, bringing its 2019 total return to 7.8%. The Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index also averaged a 1.3% gain. In other news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Gabon's sole train a lifeline for people, economy
summary: Gabon's sole train, the Transgabonais, has been in operation since 1973, connecting 23 stations from the Atlantic coast to the interior city of Franceville. The 648-kilometer railway is a lifeline for the country's 320,000 passengers annually, who pay affordable ticket prices for air-conditioned comfort. The train hauls manganese, a key export, and is seen as a symbol of national unity and modernization, despite its high construction cost of $1.65 billion and criticisms of its use as a political tool.

site_title: 'Huge' progress being made in Brexit talks, insists Johnson ahead of EC meetings
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that significant progress is being made in Brexit talks ahead of meetings with EU officials. Johnson compared the UK's departure from the EU to the comic book hero Hulk, emphasizing the country's ability to break free. He made these comments on the eve of meetings with European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker and EU negotiator Michel Barnier in Luxembourg, aiming to boost optimism about the Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Virgin Australia poised to buy back Velocity frequent flyer programme
summary: Virgin Australia is in exclusive talks to buy back its 35% stake in Velocity frequent flyer programme from private-equity group Affinity Equity Partners, valued at around A$2 billion. The deal aims to support the airline's turnaround plan under new CEO Paul Scurrah, who is competing against Qantas Airways. The purchase would finance the airline's balance sheet and is part of a plan to cut 750 jobs and delay Boeing 737 MAX jet purchases. The deal could value Virgin at A$700 million for the stake being purchased.

site_title: WeWork IPO spells rough landing for CEO Neumann
summary: WeWork's IPO has ended in a rough landing for CEO Adam Neumann, who initially capitalized on post-financial crisis demand for workspace to grow the company into a global brand valued at $47 billion. However, the company's high valuation has become a symbol of a venture capital bubble, leading to concerns about unsustainable valuations. The IPO's failure marks a significant setback for Neumann's plans to take WeWork public, highlighting the challenges of navigating the current market landscape. The company's valuation has plummeted, and its future remains uncertain.

site_title: TEE International controlling shareholder gets offers for his shares
summary: Tee International, a Singaporean engineering group, announced that its controlling shareholder Phua Chian Kin has received offers for his shares, which hold a 39.24% direct interest and 6.37% deemed interest. Phua's updated shareholdings data shows he has sold nearly 81.41 million shares, with 41.52 million shares sold by RHB Securities, 21.88 million by DB Nominees, and 18.81 million by SBS Nominees. The company's board is in negotiations with third-party purchasers, but there is no assurance the transaction will materialize or lead to an offer for the company's shares.

site_title: All eyes on Fed's Sept rate decision
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to make a decision on interest rates on Wednesday, with economists predicting a 25-basis-point cut. The move is seen as a response to the US-China trade thaw and is expected to be followed by additional easing before the end of 2019. A Bloomberg poll of 65 economists shows 41 expect a 25-basis-point cut, while 24 predict no change. This decision will have significant implications for the global economy and financial markets.

site_title: The key to a successful digital future
summary: Singapore's prospects in attracting top tech talent are bright, with initiatives like Tech@SG aiming to secure the leading global technology expertise. The country's thriving innovation ecosystem, progressive regulatory environment, and strong reputation as a global financial centre make it an attractive destination for tech workers. Experts agree that fostering diversity, investing in local talent, and creating a supportive culture are crucial to closing the tech talent gap. While attracting "Jedi Masters" is a goal, Singapore must also prioritize training and developing its own talent to remain competitive in the global tech race.

site_title: Higher premiums work, but they're no magic pill
summary: Insurance providers' gains from premium hikes are largely attributed to over-consumption of healthcare services and over-charging among healthcare providers. While data show insurers have reduced underwriting losses in 2018, most gains were due to premium hikes. Insurers are exploring claims-based pricing systems to encourage responsible healthcare use, such as Prudential's 20% discount on rider premiums for healthy customers. Some insurers have seen significant improvements in underwriting results, with AIA's AQHP panel and AXA's pre-authorisation system contributing to better claims management. However, over-servicing and abuse remain major concerns.

site_title: Cloudflare jumps in trading debut after raising US$525m
summary: Cloudflare Inc made its trading debut, rising 20% to a market value of $5.28 billion, after raising $525 million in its initial public offering. The company's shares closed at $18, exceeding its target price of $15. This debut follows a disappointing IPO by SmileDirectClub, and Cloudflare's strong performance affirms the appeal of the sector to investors. Cloudflare's security services blocked 44 billion cyber threats per day and has paying customers including 10% of Fortune 1,000 companies.

site_title: Goldman uses JPMorgan's tactics against it in ETF battle
summary: Goldman Sachs is launching a broad-based index product strategy, similar to its competitor JPMorgan Chase, to boost its share in the US$4 trillion ETF market. The approach involves mimicking popular ETFs and moving client cash into Goldman's own products, potentially saving clients millions of dollars in fees. The strategy, dubbed "bring your own assets," has been successful for JPMorgan, which has ridden a strategy to a US$29 billion business. Goldman hopes to challenge the dominance of State Street, BlackRock, and Vanguard Group by offering low-priced ETFs, and may benefit from recent acquisitions and a growing fixed-income ETF market.

site_title: 'Ferrari woman' grants option to buy her GCB for S$47m
summary: SHI Ka Yee, known as the "Ferrari woman" for her driving offenses, is selling her Astrid Hill Good Class Bungalow for S$47 million, a price lower than her initial asking price of S$52 million. The 26,983 sq ft freehold property has a price per square foot of S$1,742. Market watchers consider the District 10 property ripe for redevelopment. This sale comes after a series of incidents, including a 2015 altercation with a neighbor over a tree pruning issue, for which Shi was dubbed the "Ferrari woman."

site_title: Certis' manpower plug: more tech and services
summary: Singapore's security firm Certis Group is leveraging technology to address a longstanding manpower crunch in the industry. The company has rolled out a new business approach called Security+, which combines advanced security strategies with facilities management and customer service. This move aims to reduce costs and manpower needs for its customers. With the success of securing big players like Jewel Changi Airport and JTC Corporation, Certis plans to expand its services globally, focusing on security outcomes through technology.

site_title: Growing Singapore's pool of senior volunteers
summary: Singapore's RSVP Singapore has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth to grow senior volunteerism in the country. The partnership aims to engage seniors in various community programs, particularly those aged 50 and above, and promote social and mental well-being. The move follows data showing that seniors will make up a quarter of Singapore's population by 2030, highlighting the need for senior volunteerism. The partnership is part of the SG Cares national movement, which seeks to work with partners to engage seniors and support them in their aging journey.

site_title: HK returns to violence with tear gas and Molotov cocktails
summary: Hong Kong descended into chaos on Sunday with clashes between riot police and hardcore pro-democracy protesters. Tens of thousands defied authorities to march through the city, with the protesters hurling rocks and petrol bombs at the government complex. Police responded with tear gas and water cannons after Molotov cocktails were thrown. The clashes marked a return to violence after a brief lull, with protesters demanding greater democratic freedoms and police accountability. The movement, which has been ongoing for 99 days, is the biggest challenge to China's rule since Hong Kong's handover in 1997.

site_title: Taking product packaging from cradle to grave
summary: Singapore-based company Tria plans to collect its eco-friendly foodware products from users and process them into compost for sale to local vegetable farms. The company, which designs and sells biodegradable containers and cutlery, will work with local waste management company Chye Thiam Maintenance to collect and compost the products. Tria estimates it can produce 20,000 tonnes of compost from the combined waste of major chains like McDonald's and Subway, and plans to expand its services internationally, including in Europe and the US, where single-use plastics bans are set to come into force.

site_title: NY finds US$1b in hidden transfers by family behind OxyContin
summary: New York state's attorney general's office revealed it found $1 billion in hidden wire transfers by the Sackler family, who own Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin. The transfers were made through Swiss bank accounts and suggest an attempt to shield wealth amid opioid crisis litigation. The discovery comes as thousands of municipal governments and nearly two dozen states reached a tentative settlement with the Sackler family and Purdue Pharma earlier in the week, with some states already objecting to the deal due to concerns over company profits.

site_title: HDB looking at 3D-printing tech in Tengah, Bidadari estates
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore is exploring the use of 3D-printing technology to improve construction productivity. The technology has the potential to build landscape furniture and architectural features in a faster, cheaper, and less labor-intensive manner. The HDB Centre of Building Research in Woodlands is testing a 3D-printer capable of building components up to 9 meters long. The printer successfully printed a room in 13 hours, reducing construction time by two months. HDB plans to trial 3D-printing for smaller components in Tengah and Bidadari estates, with the goal of increasing design flexibility and reducing costs.

site_title: Hazy conditions persist in Singapore due to smoke haze from Sumatra
summary: Hazy conditions persist in Singapore due to smoke haze from Sumatra, with air quality remaining close to unhealthy levels. The south experienced a 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) reading of 99 on Friday night, while the west recorded a 95 PSI reading at 1pm on Saturday, at the high end of the moderate range. The haze has been steadily climbing in the west, with hazy conditions across many parts of the island.

site_title: Drones spark fires at two Saudi Aramco oil facilities
summary: Fires broke out at two Saudi Aramco oil facilities in Abqaiq and Khurais after being struck by drones early Saturday, according to the kingdom's interior ministry. The fires have been controlled, and an investigation has been launched. This is the second attack on Aramco facilities, following a fire at the Shaybah natural gas liquefaction facility in Yemen last month. The Huthi rebels, who have carried out cross-border missile and drone attacks on Saudi facilities, have not claimed responsibility for Saturday's attacks, which have raised tensions in the Gulf region.

site_title: Biden, fellow Democrats back on campaign trail after third presidential debate
summary: Former US Vice-President Joe Biden returned to the campaign trail after a Democratic debate in Houston, solidifying his front-runner status. Biden clashed with liberal rivals Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders on healthcare, while facing criticism from Julian Castro and Cory Booker on his age. Despite the attacks, Biden remained sharp and aggressive, leaving him in a strong position as his rivals evaluate their strategies. The next debate is set for October 15 in Ohio, and several major events are on the campaign schedule in coming weeks.

site_title: African leaders to pay tribute at Mugabe state funeral
summary: Former Zimbabwean leader Robert Mugabe will be given a state funeral on Saturday with a dozen African leaders paying tribute to a man seen as a colonial-era liberation hero. Despite his 37-year rule marked by brutal repression and economic crisis, Mugabe's body is returning to a country struggling with inflation and shortages. His final burial will be held after a new mausoleum is built, with his family objecting to the initial plan to bury him at National Heroes Acre.

images.alt_text: Former Zimbabwe leader Robert Mugabe will be given a state funeral on Saturday with a dozen African leaders expected to pay tribute to a man lauded as a colonial-era liberation hero.

site_title: Facebook fact-checker finds UK Conservatives ran ads with altered BBC headline
summary: Facebook's third-party fact-checker Full Fact accused the UK Conservative Party of misrepresenting a BBC News article in its ads, altering the headline from "School spending: Multi-billion pound cash boost announced" to "£14 billion pound cash boost for schools". The BBC article actually reported a £7.1 billion spending increase, not £14 billion. Full Fact raised concerns with Facebook, which confirmed it is looking into the ads, and the charity criticized the altered headline as misleading for readers.

site_title: JTC, Singapore Polytechnic to drive tech adoption, train students in manufacturing
summary: JTC Corporation and Singapore Polytechnic have partnered to drive tech adoption and train students in manufacturing. The polytechnic will develop technology solutions, conduct workforce training, and redesign operations with industry players. It will also introduce work-study programs for students, entry-level professionals, and employees. The partnership aims to create a pipeline of skilled talent for the advanced manufacturing sector in Jurong West, a 600ha innovation district.

site_title: Google and Facebook's latest efforts to 'save' journalism are already getting eye rolls
summary: Google and Facebook have introduced new policies to promote original journalism, with Google changing its search rater guidelines and algorithms to prioritize original reporting, and Facebook offering major news outlets up to $3 million per year to license headlines and previews. However, these efforts have raised concerns about unintended consequences for news media, as some fear that the changes could favor established outlets over smaller publications and lead to a loss of diversity in news sources. The changes aim to maintain original reporting's ranking on search pages for a longer time.

site_title: Apple says Disney's Bob Iger resigned from board of iPhone maker
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook announced that Disney's Bob Iger resigned from the company's board, citing increased competition between the entertainment and technology giants. Iger had served as a director since 2011 and was a friend of Steve Jobs. The move comes after Apple expanded into original TV shows and movies, making it a rival to Disney. Iger's departure leaves Apple with seven board members, and his resignation was seen as a sign of the strained relationship between the two companies.

site_title: Trade tensions ease as China drops some pork and soybean tariffs
summary: China has dropped some tariffs on US soybeans and pork in a move to ease trade tensions with the US. The decision comes after President Donald Trump delayed the next round of tariff increases on Chinese goods until after early October talks. China has also made its first major purchase of US soybeans in months. The US welcomed the move, saying it would help ease tensions ahead of talks. The easing of agricultural tariffs could also help China with its own food inflation issues due to swine fever.

site_title: Tee International controlling shareholder Phua Chian Kin receives offers for his shares
summary: Singapore-listed engineering group Tee International's controlling shareholder, Phua Chian Kin, has received offers for his shares, which hold a 39.24% direct interest and 6.37% deemed interest in the company. The company's board is aware of the negotiations but is uncertain if the transaction will lead to a potential offer for the company's shares. Phua has been involved in a scandal over unauthorized transactions totaling S$6.55 million by Tee International subsidiaries to related parties. The outcome of the sale negotiations is yet to be determined.

site_title: More than ever, Mike Pompeo at helm of Trump foreign policy
summary: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has become the dominant figure in President Donald Trump's foreign policy, following the surprise exit of national security adviser John Bolton. Pompeo's ascent was swift, and he has risen to power by carefully following Trump's lead. Despite his influence, analysts say Pompeo's power is limited as he tends to give up when Trump takes a different direction. Pompeo is now facing the possibility of running for a Senate seat in Kansas, which could secure his position in Washington.

site_title: Pilot's coffee spill forced trans-atlantic flight to turn around, an inquiry shows
summary: A Condor Airlines flight from Frankfurt, Germany to Cancún, Mexico was diverted to Ireland on February 6, 2019, after the pilot spilled coffee on the cockpit controls, disabling audio control panels and causing a small amount of smoke. The 337-person flight turned around south of Greenland and landed safely in Shannon, Ireland. An investigation found that the incident was caused by the pilot's accidental knock-over of a cup of coffee, which was not properly secured with a lid. The airline has since implemented new procedures for handling liquids in the cockpit.

site_title: HK pushes new tax on developers to try to lower housing costs
summary: Hong Kong's government has gazetted a proposed vacancy tax bill to reduce housing costs and quell anti-government protests. The bill would impose a 200% tax on unsold apartments if they remain vacant for 12 months, with the goal of increasing housing supply. Developers, however, are opposing the bill, citing potential financial risks and the need to wait for the economy to stabilize. The move is seen as an attempt by Chief Executive Carrie Lam to regain trust from protesters, who have been focused on housing issues.

site_title: For children with peanut allergies, FDA experts recommend a new treatment
summary: The FDA has recommended approval of Palforzia, a new oral immunotherapy treatment for life-threatening peanut allergies in children. The treatment aims to reduce the risk of anaphylaxis by gradually exposing children to small amounts of peanut protein over six months. While the treatment shows promise, with two-thirds of participants able to tolerate 600 milligrams of peanut protein without an allergic reaction, some experts raised concerns about the safety and long-term effectiveness of the treatment. The FDA will require strict guidelines for the treatment, including mandatory epinephrine use and warnings about potential side effects.

images.alt_text: A Food and Drug Administration panel on Friday recommended approval of the first-ever drug to treat life-threatening peanut allergies in children, a condition that confounds and frightens families across the country.

site_title: US college admissions scandal: Actress Felicity Huffman gets 14 days jail
summary: Actress Felicity Huffman was sentenced to 14 days in jail for paying $15,000 to boost her daughter's SAT college entrance exam score, becoming the first high-profile figure to be sentenced in the US college admissions scandal. Huffman pleaded guilty in May and will also serve a $30,000 fine and 250 hours of community service. Judge Indira Talwani emphasized the importance of sending a message to other parents that they cannot use wealth to cheat deserving students. Huffman apologized for her actions and accepted the sentence.

site_title: Yarwood Avenue GCB up for auction with guide price of S$23m
summary: A two-storey good class bungalow (GCB) at 18A Yarwood Avenue in Kilburn Estate, Singapore, is set to go up for auction with a guide price of S$23 million. The 999-year leasehold property features 8,956 sq ft of floor area, a basement, swimming pool, and landscaped garden. Located within walking distance to King Albert Park MRT station, the property is marketed as having an accessible price point for its calibre. Successful sales of similar properties in the area include S$22.15 million and S$19.4 million, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong property hunters grab bargains in wake of protests
summary: Hong Kong property buyers are capitalizing on the city's economic downturn, snapping up commercial properties at discounted prices amid anti-government protests. Despite Fitch Ratings downgrading Hong Kong and Cushman & Wakefield predicting a 55% slump in transaction volumes, local investors remain confident in the market. They point to the city's history of resilience, low tax rates, and free flow of money as factors supporting property values. Some buyers, such as Wang Tse, believe the turmoil is an opportunity to buy on the cheap, with prices potentially dropping further if the protests persist.

site_title: An Apple a day
summary: Apple has released the iPhone 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max, with subtle design changes including a matte finish, increased weight, and thickness due to a new glass material. The devices feature the same screen sizes and resolutions as the previous models but boast a brighter, HDR-certified Super Retina XDR display with a 2,000,000:1 contrast ratio. The new displays support up to 1,200 nits of brightness and the DCI-P3 color space.

site_title: Cats, dolphins and one smart raven: the CIA's secret animal spies
summary: The CIA's secret animal spy program, active from the 1960s to 1970s, aimed to utilize animals for espionage during the Cold War. The program tested various animals, including cats, dogs, dolphins, birds (pigeons, hawks, owls, crows, and ravens), for their potential as spies. The most promising candidates were a raven named Do Da, who was trained to carry a camera and fly over Soviet territory, and pigeons, which were used to take photos of Soviet shipyards. However, the program ultimately failed due to the animals' unreliability and the challenges of training them for complex missions.

site_title: Muted demand for private residential properties a concern for developers, says Redas president
summary: Redas president Chia Ngiang Hong expressed concern over muted demand for private residential properties in Singapore, despite price increases in the second quarter. He attributed this to existing cooling measures, abundant unsold stock, and a worrying economy. Hong urged developers to focus on long-term growth, rather than short-term volatility, as new home sales remain lacklustre.

site_title: Employers ring alarm as Poland promises to double minimum wage
summary: Poland's government plans to nearly double the minimum wage to 4,000 zloty (S$1,407) per month over four years, sparking alarm among employer groups. The move, aimed at boosting poll standings ahead of the general election, is expected to lead to sharp rises in costs and fuel inflation. Lewiatan business lobby group warns that the plan will erode growth prospects, trigger job losses, and make it harder for Poland to attract high-end jobs and investment, potentially harming its competitiveness in European supply chains.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: A negative week for the Capesize market, with many routes losing ground, was reported. Limited timecharter activity occurred, mostly on a voyage basis. This decline is attributed to the overall negative market trend.

site_title: US: Wall Street pauses near record levels awaiting Fed meeting
summary: US stocks closed nearly unchanged on Friday, pausing near record levels after a strong rally driven by hopes for a trade war letup. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 27,219.52, while the S&P 500 fell 0.1% to 3,007.39. Ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, investors took a breather, with China announcing exemptions for US soybeans and pork from retaliatory tariffs. Individual companies, including Apple and PG&E, saw significant price movements due to new announcements.

site_title: Implications of a market dominated by passive funds
summary: A market dominated by passive funds can create bubbles and skew investments and indexes, as seen in the shift away from active funds. This phenomenon is a result of the benefits of diversification being achieved through unit trusts and mutual funds, with many failing to outperform broad market indices consistently due to high fees. As a result, passive funds have become the go-to place for equities exposure, leading to a potential imbalance in the market.

site_title: WeWork considers dramatic valuation cut in IPO
summary: WeWork's parent company, The We Company, may seek a valuation of $10-12 billion in its upcoming IPO, a significant discount from its previous valuation of $47 billion. This move could be a major blow to SoftBank's $108 billion Vision Fund, which has invested heavily in WeWork. The company's business model has raised concerns among investors, and its corporate governance changes, while symbolic, have been deemed insufficient to address these concerns. WeWork plans to complete the IPO this month, despite facing challenges in its roadshow.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters plan mall sit-ins after hill-top human chains
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy activists plan sit-ins at shopping malls and rallies to demand China honors a 1984 Sino-British Joint Declaration, which guarantees freedoms not enjoyed on the mainland. Following a peaceful Mid-Autumn Festival protest, protesters plan to gather outside the British Consulate on Sunday. The demonstrations, sparked by a now-withdrawn extradition bill, have broadened into calls for greater democracy, with concerns over sky-high living costs and job prospects. Britain says it has a responsibility to ensure China abides by the Joint Declaration, while China denies meddling and accuses the US and others of fomenting unrest.

site_title: Oil dips as demand concerns counter US-China trade hopes
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday, with Brent crude futures falling 16 US cents to settle at $60.22 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures ending at $54.85 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns about slower global economic growth and weaker demand outlook, despite US-China trade hopes. China exempted some US agricultural products from additional tariffs, but oil prices remained under pressure. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and the International Energy Agency predicted oil markets could end up in surplus next year.

site_title: LSE rejects Hong Kong Exchange's surprise £29.6 billion takeover bid
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group (LSE) has rejected Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing's £29.6 billion takeover bid, citing "fundamental flaws" in the proposal. The LSE's board deemed the bid to have problems in strategy, deliverability, form of consideration, and value. The LSE remains committed to its proposed US$27 billion acquisition of Refinitiv, which is currently underway.

site_title: Singapore lender still using faxes seeks virtual bank licence
summary: Hong Leong Finance, a 70-year-old Singapore lender, is seeking a virtual bank license and plans to partner with a fintech firm to appeal to the country's new businesses, particularly millennials. The firm aims to apply technology to its lending decisions and expand its customer base. In talks with fintech companies, Hong Leong Finance hopes to re-invent itself as a tech-savvy lender. The move is seen as an opportunity to find new customers and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Shopee, LinkedIn, Avast boost content in SkillsFuture classes on digital skills
summary: Singapore's NTUC LearningHub, in partnership with Shopee, LinkedIn, and Avast, is launching new SkillsFuture classes to upskill workers in digital skills. The two-day SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace (SFDW) course will be available from October, covering cybersecurity, e-commerce, and employability. The classes aim to equip Singaporeans with basic digital skills and prepare them for technological changes, with the goal of creating opportunities for online entrepreneurs and connecting jobseekers with networks and resources.

site_title: Trudeau vows tax on foreign property speculators if re-elected Canadian PM
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has vowed to tax non-resident property speculators by 1% annually if re-elected. He aims to curb foreign speculation in the housing market, which he blames for unaffordable prices and a shortage of homes. Trudeau proposes the tax on top of existing measures in Ontario and British Columbia to cool down red-hot real estate markets in Toronto and Vancouver. The move is part of his campaign to address the tough housing market and make homeownership a realistic goal for young Canadians.

site_title: SG Bike gets LTA nod to take over Mobike licence
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has approved SG Bike's application to take over Mobike's licence in Singapore, allowing the local firm to operate a maximum fleet size of 25,000 bikes. The transfer is delayed by a few weeks as the firms work out operational details. Existing Mobike users can continue to use Mobike's app, and Mobike users can transfer their account balances to SG Bike's app. SG Bike will not be able to operate an extra 3,000 bikes on top of the 25,000 allowed by Mobike's licence.

site_title: Goldbell launches accelerator programme for mobility startups
summary: Goldbell Group, a Singapore-based vehicle leasing company, has launched the Move.SG mobility accelerator programme, a one-year initiative focused on solutions for Singapore and the Asia-Pacific. The programme provides access to a fleet of 8,500 vehicles, mentorship, pilot opportunities, and funding opportunities. Since its launch in August 2019, the programme has received over 50 applicants, including companies developing autonomous vehicles and AI platforms. The accelerator aims to pilot and nurture mobility solutions in smart cities across Asia, with a focus on Singapore as a "perfect sandbox" for innovation.

site_title: Chappell fires rare 59 in return to PGA Tour
summary: Kevin Chappell made a remarkable return to the US PGA Tour, firing an 11-under-par 59 in the second round of The Greenbrier. The 59, his first on the tour, included a record-equalling nine consecutive birdies. Chappell finished the day on 10 under after 36 holes, three off the early clubhouse lead. He had a chance to join Jim Furyk as the only players to card a 58, but his 11-foot birdie putt at the 9th hole curled left at the hole, missing the historic achievement.

images.alt_text: Kevin Chappell made a scintillating return to the US PGA Tour on Friday, joining one of golf's most exclusive clubs by firing an 11-under-par 59 in the second round of The Greenbrier.

site_title: TEE Intl appoints PwC to probe unauthorised transactions
summary: TEE Intl appoints PricewaterhouseCoopers Risk Services as an external investigator to probe unauthorised transactions totaling S$6.55 million, allegedly made under the instruction of group CEO Phua Chian Kin. PwC will review transactions with Oscar Investment, owned by Mr Phua, and identify weaknesses in governance and internal controls. The appointment comes after Deloitte flagged concerns over the transactions, and the company has called for a trading halt amid the probe. PwC will report its findings directly to the Singapore Exchange Regulation.

site_title: Good governance contributes to long-term business success
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is celebrating its 20th anniversary and holding the 10th Singapore Corporate Governance (CG) Week 2019, themed "Technology - The New Face Of Governance?" from September 23 to October 1, 2019. To date, 77 companies have joined the Statement of Support initiative for excellence in corporate governance, a pledge to uphold and advance good corporate governance standards. CEOs from participating companies, including CNMC Goldmine Holdings, RSM, Singapore Telecommunications, Sembcorp Industries, and Singapore Technologies Engineering, emphasized the importance of good corporate governance in enhancing shareholder value, building confidence in stakeholders, and fostering business continuity.

site_title: CDL takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels turns unconditional
summary: CDL's takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) has been declared unconditional, with 58.28% of remaining shares accepted as of September 12. The delisting of M&C shares from the London Stock Exchange is expected to be effective on October 11. M&C will be re-registered as a private company after the delisting. The offer, which values the hotel chain at £2.23 billion, remains open for acceptance until September 27.

site_title: Away from the pool, Schooling masters the greens
summary: Golfing sensation Joseph Schooling, a 24-year-old Olympic world champion swimmer, has made a strong impression in the BT Corporate Golf League. Schooling, playing his first round in almost a year, showcased his precision and skill, boasting two birdies and a joint-day's best gross score of three-over 75. He demonstrated his sportsmanship and camaraderie, high-fiving his teammates and encouraging fellow golfers, including the author. Schooling's impressive performance has earned him a spot as Team Hugo Boss' "hired gun."

site_title: Ascendas Australia Hotel Trust's purchase of Melbourne apartments axed
summary: Ascendas Australia Hotel Trust has terminated its A$120 million acquisition of serviced apartments in Melbourne due to issues with property specifications and condition. The trustee will return A$5 million deposit and provide compensation for expenses incurred. The deal is not expected to impact Ascendas Hospitality Trust's net property income or distribution per issued security. The termination is also not expected to affect the proposed combination of Ascott Residence Trust and Ascendas Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Big signals for greener financial markets
summary: The green bond market is expected to expand globally, driven by three key factors: sovereign issuance, participation of reputable agents, and certification. In Asia, sovereigns such as Hong Kong, South Korea, and Indonesia have issued green bonds, demonstrating strong demand from investors. Multi-lateral institutions like the Asian Development Bank and International Finance Corp are also stepping in to catalyze broader green investment. A common standard for green bonds is emerging, with the Climate Bond Standard and Asean Green Bond Principles gaining popularity. As the market evolves, Singapore is poised to become a major green finance hub, supporting the growth of the green bond market across Asia.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AEM Holdings has received S$280 million in sales orders for fiscal year 2019, revising its expected revenue range to S$285 million to S$305 million. The company maintains its capital expenditure range of S$4 million to S$7 million. This update comes after a strong 5-day rally for Singapore stocks, ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng fends off concerns over rights issue
summary: Chip Eng Seng's proposed rights issue, aimed at raising S$96.3 million, has garnered skepticism from shareholders. Despite 78% of votes favoring the deal, concerns remain over the structure, which allows the Tang family to raise their stake beyond 30% without triggering a mandatory general offer. The company's CEO, Raymond Chia, cited market forces and long-term plans as reasons for the discounted price of S$0.63 per share, which is a 12-13% discount from the current share price. The board defended the decision, citing the need for the company's expansion plans and the involvement of independent directors in the process.

site_title: Thousands in attendance as Malaysian parties Umno and PAS ink unity pact
summary: Malaysia's two largest Malay Muslim parties, Umno and Parti Islam SeMalaysia (PAS), signed a unity pact on Saturday, aiming to unite the majority community against the Pakatan Harapan (PH) government. The pact, which has shown success in by-elections, outlines the primacy of Islam and the Malays without denying minority rights. The move is seen as a response to PH's policies perceived as eroding Malay and Muslim rights. The alliance, which has sparked fears of racial polarization, aims to replace the current government and defend the community from perceived threats.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's two biggest Malay Muslim parties inked a political cooperation on Saturday that they hope will spur the majority community to unite against perceived threats from the Pakatan Harapan (PH) government.

site_title: Top SoftBank investments under pressure from Wall St to California
summary: SoftBank's investments in WeWork and gig economy companies are under pressure from California's new labour law, which could force gig economy firms to incur substantial new employment costs. SoftBank has invested over $10 billion in WeWork and holds large stakes in Uber, DoorDash, and Wag. The law could lead to increased costs for Uber, potentially topping $500 million annually, and may force WeWork to reconsider its IPO plans. SoftBank's Vision Fund, which has a $10.7 billion commitment to WeWork, may face challenges in justifying continued paper gains.

site_title: Banks sizzle as European stocks log fourth week of gains
summary: European stocks logged their fourth consecutive week of gains, driven by a surge in banks, miners, and automakers. Euro zone banks rallied 2.4% on Friday, with analysts citing the European Central Bank's easing of long-term loan terms and introduction of tiered deposit rates. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% on the day, with momentum stocks boosted by signs of progress in US-China trade talks and a potential interim trade deal.

images.alt_text: A surge in banks, miners and automakers galvanised European stocks on Friday, as continued rotation into the cyclical sectors amid signs of progress in US-China trade talks drove the Stoxx 600 to its fourth straight week of gains.

site_title: Can banks survive negative rates?
summary: Negative interest rates, implemented by central banks to stimulate economic growth, are threatening the stability of the financial system. Banks raise fees or turn to other revenue measures to boost earnings, undercutting the purpose of negative rates. As profits decline, banks face funding difficulties, higher borrowing costs, and reduced lending, dampening consumption and investment. Negative rates distort incentives, leading to inefficient use of capital and setting the stage for long-term economic underperformance. The trend may spread to other countries, with US banks already lowering earnings guidance due to low profit margins.

site_title: STI ends Friday in positive territory, adding 2.1% this week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week at 3,211.49, up 16.53 points or 0.5% from last Friday's close. The rally was driven by positive news from the US-China trade front, the European Central Bank's rate cut, and accommodative central bank moves to combat economic growth. Key performers included AEM Holdings, Boustead, and local banks, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank gaining 0.8% each.

site_title: China prods state firms to boost investment in HK
summary: China's state firms have been urged to boost investment in Hong Kong, including real estate and tourism, to create jobs and stabilize financial markets amid months of unrest. Nearly 100 state-owned enterprises, including Sinopec and China Merchants Group, pledged to invest more in key industries at a meeting in Shenzhen. The move aims to calm China's biggest political crisis in years and assert control over companies in the financial hub. Beijing seeks to address concerns over creeping Chinese influence and the erosion of the "one country, two system" model.

site_title: TPG Capital, Hong Leong in US$1.2b deal to buy hospitals in S-E Asia
summary: TPG Capital and Hong Leong agreed to buy 18 healthcare assets from Columbia Asia for US$1.2 billion, marking TPG's re-entry into the hospital business in South-east Asia. The deal includes 17 hospitals and one clinic in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam, with each buyer owning 50% of the acquired assets. The transaction is expected to close at the end of 2019, driven by rising incomes and ageing populations in Asia's largest markets. This marks Hong Leong's first foray into healthcare, while TPG boosts investments in companies driven by domestic consumption.

site_title: Rich Capital gets legal demand from partner over Batam project
summary: Rich Capital Holdings has received two legal letters from Karya Indo Batam (KIB) demanding full control of a joint venture property development in Batam and S$20 million in compensation. The letters allege conspiracy and breaches of Indonesian laws. Rich Capital denies the allegations, stating that it has obtained Indonesian legal advice and has refunded a S$2 million advance payment. The firm's shares have been voluntarily suspended since June 27.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex adds new US$290m fund to back growth-stage tech firms
summary: Temasek's Vertex Growth Fund has raised US$290 million for its inaugural fund, exceeding its initial target of US$250 million. The fund will invest US$10-15 million per startup, primarily in third and fourth funding rounds, to support growth-stage tech firms globally. With secured commitments from various limited partners, including a sovereign wealth fund and institutional investors, Vertex Growth aims to provide early access to next-generation technologies and support startups in scaling their businesses.

site_title: Bribery: Does it have a role in today's business?
summary: A company's compliance with bribery involves giving or receiving something of value in return for something else of value, with motive and quantum being key factors in distinguishing generosity from bribery. Transparency is crucial in reducing the negative impact of bribery. In some cases, small-scale bribery may be acceptable if done openly and transparently, especially for low-paid workers. However, large-scale bribery and bribery with the express purpose of personal gain are unacceptable and constitute theft and money laundering. Keeping thorough records of transactions can help prevent bribery accusations. Ultimately, a little give and take is necessary in business, but it should not cross the line into bribery.

site_title: Reits (September 14-15, 2019)
summary: Real estate trends in the US, Singapore, and globally are showing signs of a shift. US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of decline, impacting the housing market. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases anticipated. The global market also saw notable transactions, including Goldman's purchase of Seoul assets and WeWork securing new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore. These developments signal a potential shift in demand and investment in the real estate sector.

site_title: Robust global risk appetites dent safe haven appeal
summary: Global risk appetites have boosted markets, easing concerns over trade tensions between the US and China. The European Central Bank has announced indefinite stimulus to support the eurozone, reducing borrowing costs and setting a tone for policy-easing measures. As a result, safe haven assets like gold have received headwinds. Markets are now focused on the Federal Open Market Committee Meeting on September 18 for forward guidance on US monetary policy, which may lead to a 25 basis point reduction in borrowing costs. Gold prices are expected to remain supported due to subdued global growth and accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Default fears hurt first-time China issuers of US-dollar bonds
summary: Chinese companies issuing US-dollar bonds for the first time are facing increased scrutiny from buyers due to a record pace of defaults. This has led to a decline in debut issuers, with only 13 debuts so far this quarter, compared to 22 in April-June. Investors are demanding bigger pricing concessions and more convincing evidence of the companies' creditworthiness, citing spotty disclosures from state-owned companies and local government financing vehicles. As a result, yields on junk-rated Asian dollar bonds have climbed, and investors are shifting towards safer investment-grade sales.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies trying to sell US dollar bonds for the first time have been finding it so tough lately that the number of debut issuers is down by almost half this quarter compared with the last one, even though sales in the broader market are holding up amid China's economic slowdown and the trade war.

site_title: Car, online sales help Aug retail numbers beat forecast
summary: US retail sales rose 0.4% in August, beating forecasts, driven by strong car sales and online shopping. The median estimate was 0.2% growth, and sales in the "control group" increased 0.3%, suggesting underlying consumer demand remains strong. The solid retail performance is a boost to economic growth, which has been slowed by global weakness and trade uncertainty. Treasury yields rose, and the 10-year yield hit its highest level since early August, as the report suggests consumers will continue to drive economic growth.

site_title: Local retailer Iuiga to remove and stop using Muji trademark
summary: Local retailer Iuiga has settled a trademark dispute with Japanese consumer goods company Muji out of court. Iuiga will stop referencing the Muji trademark in its promotional materials and website after displaying Muji's mark on its website was deemed a breach of contract. The settlement was reached in the Singapore High Court. The exact terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but the dispute arose from Iuiga's unauthorized use of Muji's mark. Iuiga will also remove the Muji trademark from its website and mobile application.

site_title: Japanese firms see land prices overheating in big cities, not regions
summary: Japanese companies say land prices in big cities are overheating, with 65% feeling prices are rising too fast relative to consumer inflation. In contrast, 80% of firms believe land prices in the countryside are stable. This trend poses economic inequality issues, as the country's population declines, with urban areas thriving while rural areas struggle. The government's "Abenomics" aims to address this disparity, but land prices remain unevenly distributed, with regional cities experiencing similar price hikes to Tokyo and Osaka, yet surrounding areas lagging behind.

site_title: Mixing business with pleasure is the new way to travel
summary: Business travel in Asia is expected to reach $900 billion by 2025, with "b-leisure" trips combining work and leisure activities becoming increasingly popular, particularly among Asian corporate travelers. This trend poses challenges for employers, who must balance employee benefits with compliance and duty of care issues. To mitigate risks, businesses should redesign their business travel interface, incorporate leisure add-ons, and educate staff on compliance. Employers that adapt to "b-leisure" travel can boost employee engagement, while those that resist may be seen as out of touch.

site_title: HK exchange sees potential return of two pulled IPOs
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is seeing a potential return of two pulled initial public offerings (IPOs), ESR Cayman Ltd and Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, which had initially sought to raise $11 billion. The two deals, which were postponed earlier this year, are now refiled with the Hong Kong stock exchange, marking a turnaround for the exchange's fortunes. A successful return of these deals could boost investor confidence and attract other issuers, following a significant increase in IPO activity in Hong Kong in recent weeks.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust has expanded its high-tech buildings segment to 43.3% of portfolio valuation, shifting away from flatted factories. UOB Kay Hian upgrades MIT to a buy rating with a target price of S$2.58. Wilmar International's Q2 result was disappointing due to low crush margins, but the research firm maintains a buy rating with a target price of S$4.50, citing improving soybean crush utilisation and increasing crude palm oil prices.

site_title: Ying Li International flags potential discrepancies in financial statements
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate has been granted an extension to report its Q2 results due to potential discrepancies in its financial statements, with a new deadline of November 14. The Singapore Exchange discovered the discrepancies in the company's financial statements upon the appointment of a new finance team.

site_title: Franklin Templeton appoints Dora Seow as Singapore country head
summary: Franklin Templeton appoints Dora Seow as its country head for Singapore, effective October 1. She replaces Adam Quaife, who will relocate to Australia in December. Seow will oversee the firm's business in Singapore and three other countries, while continuing her oversight of Thailand, Philippines, and Brunei. She joins a team led by Mark Browning, managing director for Asia-Pacific, who expressed excitement over Seow's leadership experience.

site_title: Bad workouts: 5 things that can ruin a gym session
summary: A survey of Men's Health and Women's Health staffers reveals common obstacles that can ruin a gym session, including missing essential items like headphones or fitness trackers, not having necessary gear such as sports bras or compression shorts, feeling that a workout didn't count if it wasn't long enough or intense enough, and needing to document progress on social media. These non-essential items and mental expectations can distract from the actual workout, causing individuals to give up or not fully engage.

images.alt_text: While there's nothing wrong with showing off your #gains, you should realise that your hard work is worth more than the likes.

site_title: US mortgage rates rise on trade talks optimism
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 3.56% for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, 3.09% for 15-year fixed-rate mortgages, and 3.36% for 5-year adjustable-rate mortgages, according to Freddie Mac. The increase was driven by optimism over US-China trade discussions and a rebound in economic data, causing bond yields to rise. This marks a reversal of a five-week decline in mortgage rates.

site_title: Sales of new private homes holding up in August
summary: Sales of new private homes in Singapore remained strong in August, with over 1,122 units sold, excluding executive condominiums, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The top-selling project was Parc Clematis, with 316 units snapped up in the month. Analysts attribute the sustained demand to changing buyer demographics and the fact that developers launched projects on the last weekend of August, which coincided with the end of the Hungry Ghost month. Sales are expected to continue in September, with many projects launching before the year-end holidays.

images.alt_text: Parc Clematis (above) is the top selling private residential project with 316 units snapped up in August.
Luxus Hills' Signature Collection (above) was launched to strong results on the weekend that the lunar seventh month ended.

site_title: Audi RS5 Sportback: Vroom for four, or more
summary: The Audi RS 5 Sportback is a high-performance vehicle that offers a unique blend of speed, comfort, and style. With 450 horsepower and a 0-100km/h time of 3.9 seconds, it is one of the fastest cars in its class. The RS 5 Sportback's design is aggressive and distinctive, with flared wheel arches and a sporty interior. However, its refinement and handling are somewhat compromised by the absence of drama and excitement, making it feel more like a comfortable and capable car rather than a thrilling driving experience. With a starting price of S$387,000, the RS 5 Sportback is a luxury item that requires self-restraint and careful driving.

site_title: Vibrant Group posts Q1 net profit of S$33.1m
summary: Vibrant Group posted a Q1 net profit of S$33.1 million, up from S$742,000 a year ago, driven by gains from disposal of assets. Revenue fell 10.3% to S$37 million due to decreased business activity. Earnings per share rose to 4.78 cents from 0.11 cents a year ago. The company's shares gained 2.1% to close at 14.6 cents.

site_title: Guoco Tower, Singapore's tallest building, clinches global award for excellence
summary: Guoco Tower, Singapore's tallest building, has won the 2019 Urban Land Institute (ULI) Global Award for Excellence, the only Singapore winner among 11 projects recognized for demonstrating "quality and a forward-looking approach to development and design." The mixed-use development integrates offices, retail, hotels, homes, and an urban park, and its group managing director, Cheng Hsing Yao, said the award affirms Guoco Tower's vision as a "premier quality business and lifestyle hub."

site_title: Where are we on the CPF Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme?
summary: Singapore's Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS) has been under development since 2016. The proposed scheme aims to provide a low-fee, professionally guided investment option for CPF members with surplus savings. Currently, 3.9 million CPF members have a combined $137.6 billion in savings, with only $22.5 billion invested. The government has reduced the sales charge for the CPFIS programme from 3% to 1.5% and plans to remove loads by 2020. The LRIS would offer institutional-level retirement products, such as life cycle funds, with lower fees and potential for higher returns, similar to the US' 401(k) plan.

site_title: EU regulators to set high bar to authorise Facebook's Libra
summary: EU regulators will set a high bar for approving virtual currency projects, including Facebook's Libra, to address concerns about financial stability. This decision was made after a meeting of euro zone finance ministers who agreed that common rules were needed to regulate cryptocurrencies. The regulators aim to ensure that these projects do not pose a risk to the financial system.

site_title: Hupsteel founding family gets enough acceptances of offer to delist firm
summary: The founding family of Hupsteel Limited has received enough valid acceptances to delist the company, with 95.5% of shares owned or agreed to be acquired. The offer price is S$1.20 per share. Trading of shares will be suspended due to the public float falling below 10%. The offeror, Hercules Pte Ltd, will acquire the remaining shares from shareholders who did not accept the offer.

site_title: Ying Li flags potential discrepancies in financial statements
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate has been given an extension to report its Q2 results due to potential discrepancies in its financial statements, which could result in a 30% decrease in consolidated net tangible assets. The company is working with an international accounting firm to conduct an independent review and has appointed legal counsel to advise on possible implications. The new finance team has been reviewing voluminous documents detailing the group's projects, and the company is seeking to lift a trading halt in its shares.

site_title: Indonesia to raise cigarette prices by more than a third next year
summary: Indonesia plans to raise the minimum price of cigarettes by more than 35% from January 2020, aiming to reduce smoking rates. The move is part of the government's efforts to combat the country's high smoking rates, with nearly 70% of adults smoking. The increase will also boost revenue from tobacco excises, targeting 172 trillion rupiah (S$16.9 billion) in 2020. This is the latest attempt by the government to curb smoking, following previous tax hikes since 2014.

site_title: Straight shooter
summary: UBS Asia Pacific president Edmund Koh emphasizes his connection with clients, observing that his seven-year tenure has given him a unique understanding of Asian growth. He attributes his success to humility, learning from clients, and a focus on people's lifestyle advancements rather than just business. Koh notes that UBS has risen through the ranks, with its private bank holding about $411 billion in assets under management from the Asia-Pacific region. He attributes this to his ability to understand clients' needs, hiring top talent, and maintaining institutional discipline. Koh is bullish on Asia's growth, citing factors such as urbanization, wealth disparity, and cultural values. He believes that Singapore banks should prioritize finding the best person for the job, regardless of nationality, and groom their talents accordingly.

site_title: London Stock Exchange rejects Hong Kong's US$39b takeover offer
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has rejected a $39 billion takeover offer from the Hong Kong Exchange (HKEX), citing fundamental concerns about the proposal and potential complications with the Hong Kong government. The LSE stated that the offer's assertions about a swift and certain implementation are "not credible." The rejection comes after HKEX made the surprise offer, and analysts expect the Asian exchange to return with an improved proposal.

images.alt_text: London Stock Exchange (LSE) has rejected the US$39 billion takeover offer from the Hong Kong Exchange (HKEX), opting to stick with its planned purchase of data and analytics group Refinitiv.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.25 points to 1,601.25. Volume was 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion, with 455 gainers outnumbering 319 losers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CDL's takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels has become unconditional. AEM Holdings received S$280 million in sales orders and revised its revenue guidance for FY2019. Vertex Growth Fund raised US$290 million to back growth-stage tech firms. TEE International appointed PwC to investigate unauthorised transactions. Circles.Life expanded its services to Australia through a partnership with Optus. The Straits Times Index rose 2.1% for the week, ending at 3,211.49.

site_title: Ascendas Australia Hotel Trust's purchase of Melbourne serviced apartments axed
summary: Ascendas Australia Hotel Trust's A$120 million acquisition of Melbourne serviced apartments has been terminated due to issues with property specifications and condition. The trustee will return A$5 million deposit and pay an agreed compensation sum. The deal's termination is not expected to impact Ascendas Hospitality Trust's net property income or distribution. Steps are being taken to terminate the management agreement, and the trust's shares closed at S$1.07, down 0.93% on Friday.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers approve corporate tax cuts
summary: Philippine lawmakers approved a bill reducing the corporate tax rate from 30% to 20% by 2029, in a final vote of 170-8 with six abstentions. The move aims to attract investment and create jobs, as part of President Rodrigo Duterte's infrastructure programme and tax reform measures. The bill is expected to make the tax system fairer and simpler.

site_title: Manila jolted by 5.2-magnitude quake
summary: A 5.2-magnitude earthquake struck east of Manila, Philippines, on September 13, 2019, causing buildings to sway and sending people into the streets. The quake hit offshore near Polillo Island, 130km from Manila, but authorities reported no damage. Several smaller aftershocks occurred, and locals were terrified, with some even shouting for evacuation. The Philippines is located in the Pacific "Ring of Fire," a region prone to seismic activity.

site_title: Ex-interim CEO of Pine Capital unit withdraws appeals against group
summary: Tan Choon Wee, former interim CEO of Advance Capital Partners Asset Management (ACPAM), has withdrawn his appeal against the appointment of himself as director and the removal of Wang Meng as CEO and director at an August EGM. The withdrawals were the result of negotiations between parties. Tan had faced allegations of potential conflict of interest and lapses in internal controls, leading to Pine Capital's call for an EGM to remove him and others from the board.

site_title: Oil slips towards US$60 on demand worries, despite trade hopes
summary: Oil prices slipped to around $60 a barrel due to concerns over a global economic slowdown and decreasing oil demand. Despite a US-China trade dispute, Opec and its allies have pledged to limit supplies until March, potentially leading to further production cuts. Analysts warn that maintaining these cuts will be challenging next year, putting pressure on oil prices. Oil benchmark Brent crude fell 20 cents to $60.18 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate declined 27 cents to $54.82 a barrel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end week with sharp gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a 0.98% gain, or 265.06 points, to 27,352.69. Investors were lifted by easing US-China trade tensions and anticipation of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut next week.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1, citing uncertain H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Philip Hamman. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and People's Bank of China agreed to deepen green and transition finance cooperation. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: India drawing up red lines on Asia trade pact before key meeting
summary: India is drawing up a list of "must haves" for a pan-Asian free trade agreement, known as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), as negotiations approach a final round in Vietnam. The government aims to protect its stake in sectors such as agriculture and infrastructure to minimize trade imbalances. India has raised concerns about market access, particularly with China and other countries, and is seeking easier movement of its citizens for services exports. The pact, which could become the world's largest trading bloc, is under pressure to be finalized by the end of the year.

site_title: SG Bike to take over Mobike licence, making it Singapore's largest bike-sharing operator
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has approved SG Bike's application to take over Mobike's licence in Singapore, making it the city-state's largest bike-sharing operator. The transfer of the licence was initially scheduled to be completed by Friday but will be delayed as the firms tie up loose ends. LTA has given its in-principle approval for the transfer with a maximum fleet size of 25,000 bikes, and the actual takeover is expected to happen in the coming weeks.

site_title: Lian Beng subsidiary secures S$107.5m construction contract
summary: Lian Beng's 60%-owned subsidiary United Tec Construction secured a S$107.5 million contract to build two 23-storey residential towers with 378 units in Singapore. The project is expected to start in September 2019 and be completed by June 2022. This contract brings Lian Beng's order book to S$1.5 billion, providing a sustainable flow of activity through FY2023.

site_title: Japan's first electricity futures may spark market shake-up
summary: Japan's Tokyo Commodities Exchange will start trading the country's first electricity futures on September 17, marking a significant move to boost competition in the US$130 billion power sector. The futures were delayed, but their introduction aims to provide a hedging tool for new entrants and existing companies, addressing price volatility. The liberalization of the electricity market, which began in 2016, has seen around 600 companies register to join the market, but most struggle to source power due to fluctuating prices.

site_title: Singapore shares post gains on Friday, up 2.1% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.1% on the week, ending at 3,211.49, driven by the European Central Bank's rate cut to -0.5%, a dovish move seen as a boost to markets. The blue-chip index also gained 0.5% on the week. Local equities were lifted by accommodative central bank moves and hopeful lead-up to US-China trade talks. Key performers included semiconductor play AEM Holdings and local banks DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank.

site_title: Emirates applies to competition watchdog to stop flying Singapore-Brisbane route
