summary: Emirates has applied to the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore to withdraw from its Singapore-Brisbane route, citing substantial losses. The airline claims declining revenues and rising costs, but this move could lead to a 16% drop in total seats available on the route. Qantas will continue to operate 3,290 weekly seats, and the CCCS is inviting public feedback on Emirates' application, which will determine the outcome. The consultation covers potential impacts on ticket prices, seat availability, and air freight services between Singapore and Australia.

site_title: Hong Leong, TPG buy South-east Asian hospitals for US$1.2 billion
summary: TPG Capital and Malaysian conglomerate Hong Leong agreed to buy 17 hospitals and one clinic in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam for $1.2 billion. The deal marks TPG's re-entry into the hospital business in Southeast Asia and represents Hong Leong's first foray into healthcare. The buyers will each own 50% of the acquired assets, and the transaction is expected to close at the end of 2019. This deal is part of the growing trend of private equity firms investing in healthcare services in Asia, driven by rising incomes and aging populations.

site_title: Yarwood Avenue GCB up for auction with S$23m guide price
summary: A two-storey Good Class Bungalow (GCB) at 18A Yarwood Avenue in Kilburn Estate is set to be auctioned off with a guide price of S$23 million, equivalent to S$1,216 per square foot. The 999-year leasehold property features a floor area of 8,956 sq ft, a basement, swimming pool, and landscaped garden. Located near King Albert Park MRT station, the property is considered accessible and offers a resort-like living experience. The auction will be held on September 18 at Amara Singapore.

images.alt_text: The two-storey, Balinese-styled bungalow has a floor area of 8,956 sq ft, a car porch and sheltered terraces totalling 678 sq ft.
The two-storey, Balinese-styled bungalow has a floor area of 8,956 sq ft, a car porch and sheltered terraces totalling 678 sq ft.

site_title: US retail sales rise more than expected in August
summary: US retail sales rose 0.4% in August, exceeding expectations, driven by spending on motor vehicles, building materials, healthcare, and hobbies. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles, gasoline, and food services, increased 0.3%. The strong July rise is expected to support a moderate pace of economic growth in the third quarter, with consumer spending forecast to pull back to a 4% annualized rate. The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates again to keep the economy growing, with economists forecasting a 1.9% growth rate in the third quarter.

site_title: Vietnam central bank to cut rates by 0.25 percentage points
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam, announced a rate cut of 0.25 percentage points across several interest rates, effective September 16, to support economic growth and control inflation. This is the first rate cut since October 2017. The move aims to stimulate the economy and offset capital shortages in the banking sector. The rate cuts include the annual refinancing rate, rediscount rate, overnight electronic interbank rate, and rate of loans to banks.

site_title: China to exempt pork, soybeans from additional tariffs on US goods
summary: China has exempted pork and soybeans from additional US tariffs, a move seen as a sign of easing tensions ahead of upcoming trade talks. China had previously imposed 25% tariffs on US agricultural products, including soybeans and pork, but will now exclude them. The exemption comes as China struggles with a deadly African swine fever outbreak and seeks to increase US soybean purchases. The move is also seen as a conciliatory gesture from China, with Chinese officials expressing hope that the US will fulfill its promise to create favorable conditions for cooperation in agricultural areas.

site_title: GIC raises stake in German conglomerate Thyssenkrupp
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC Pte Ltd has increased its stake in German conglomerate Thyssenkrupp to 5.3% as of September 6, up from 3.5%. This comes as Thyssenkrupp shares have risen 40% since mid-August due to hopes for a sale of its prized elevator division. The move suggests GIC's confidence in the company's future prospects.

site_title: Thais allowed six cannabis plants per household under draft law
summary: Thailand's ruling coalition proposes a draft law allowing households to grow up to six cannabis plants for medicinal purposes. The law, proposed by the Bhumjaithai Party, would also enable the sale of plants to licensed institutions. The proposed Plant-based Drug Institute would oversee the extraction and export of cannabidiol (CBD) from the cannabis plant. The proposal is designed to develop Thailand's medical marijuana industry and was campaigned on by the Bhumjaithai Party. The law could be passed in 6 months if there is enough government support.

site_title: France calls for EU rules on virtual currencies
summary: France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire calls for EU rules on virtual currencies, citing the need for a common framework to regulate the 28 EU countries. He also opposes the development of Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency in the EU. Additionally, Le Maire suggests the creation of a European "public digital currency."

site_title: French company liable for worker who died after sex on business trip
summary: A French court has ruled that a worker's death from a heart attack after having sex on a business trip should be considered a work-related accident. The decision, made by the Paris Court of Appeal, comes after the worker, identified as Mr. Xavier, suffered a heart attack while having an affair with a woman he met on the trip. The ruling found that having sex was as normal as taking a shower or having a meal, and that the company's health insurance fund should compensate his family. This decision has sparked debate among employers, who are now questioning whether they need to forbid workers from having sex during business trips.

site_title: Singapore homeware retailer Iuiga to remove and stop using Muji trademark
summary: Singapore homeware retailer Iuiga will stop making references to Japanese consumer goods company Muji in its promotional and marketing materials after a trademark dispute was settled out of court. Iuiga will also remove the Muji trademark from its website and mobile application. Muji had filed a suit in the Singapore High Court after Iuiga displayed the Muji mark and used phrases claiming direct affiliation with the brand. The dispute was settled without a court decision, with Muji stating it will continue to enforce its intellectual property rights.

site_title: China's Uber-for-trucks breaks even, en route to IPO
summary: China's truck-sharing startup Full Truck Alliance has broken even and is considering an initial public offering (IPO) after a private funding round was cancelled. The company, backed by SoftBank Group and Tencent Holdings, has improved financial performance despite a sector-wide downturn. Full Truck Alliance is expanding into automotive technology and has invested in autonomous trucking startup Plus.AI, with plans to introduce its first commercial product. The company's valuation stands at $6.4 billion post-money, and an IPO could be on the horizon.

site_title: Russia wants to rent out 1 million hectares of land to Asia's food companies
summary: Russia is seeking Asian food companies to rent 1 million hectares of its land in the Far East for farming, aiming to boost economic development and open up new export markets. The government has already attracted companies like China's Legend Holdings and China Mengniu Dairy, and is now considering joint investments with other nations. This move is expected to aid China's import needs and provide a new source of food supplies amid a trade war with the US.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing says he regrets protest comments were misrepresented
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing expressed regret over comments being misrepresented regarding the city's protests. He urged authorities to offer young people an olive branch, calling them "masters of our future". Li's remarks were misinterpreted by China's Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission, which accused him of "harbouring criminality". Li reiterated that any actions violating the rule of law cannot be tolerated, but did not clarify what he meant by his comments.

site_title: Credit Suisse turns bullish on UK equities as no-deal Brexit chances fade
summary: Credit Suisse has turned bullish on UK equities, expecting the FTSE 100 to reach 7,600 points by mid-2020, a 3.5% gain from current levels. The bank attributes this optimism to fading no-deal Brexit chances and UK stocks being undervalued compared to international peers. Analysts recommend buying UK international earners that are cheap in dollar terms, citing companies like Johnson Matthey, Elementis, and British American Tobacco as attractive options.

site_title: Aston Martin said to weigh new bonds as cash pressures mount
summary: Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings may issue new unsecured bonds to offset cash flow pressure. The company generated 900,000 pounds of cash in the first half of the year, but its sales have been affected by Brexit uncertainty and industry-wide issues. A new debt issuance is expected to bolster liquidity until the launch of a new SUV model in April 2020. The bonds will be rated CCC and offer existing bondholders a buffer against potential debt. The move comes as Aston Martin's equity has slumped 70% since its IPO.

images.alt_text: Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings may soon return to Europe's bond market to offset pressure on the luxury carmaker's free cash flow, according to four people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Skin-crawling discovery: 'body farm' scientists find corpses move
summary: Australian scientist Alyson Wilson found human bodies move significantly after death, contradicting the notion of "resting in peace." Over 17 months, she observed and photographed the movements of a cadaver, discovering that arms can fling out to the side. Her research could improve the estimation of time of death and help detectives and pathologists by providing a better understanding of post-mortem movement and decomposition rates. This could aid in identifying missing persons and solving crimes by accurately mapping crime scenes and victim positions.

site_title: Pulled Hong Kong IPOs rise from the ashes
summary: Two Hong Kong IPOs, ESR Cayman and Anheuser-Busch InBev's Asian unit, have refiled listing documents with the Hong Kong stock exchange after initial postponements. The potential return of the deals, valued at around $11 billion, marks a turnaround for the Hong Kong stock exchange, which is struggling to compete with Shanghai and New York in terms of IPO proceeds. Successful completions of the IPOs could boost investor confidence and attract other companies to list in Hong Kong, as market confidence has been hit by ongoing protests and the US-China trade war.

site_title: With glue and fake blood, climate protesters target London Fashion Week
summary: Climate activists from the Extinction Rebellion group targeted London Fashion Week, gluing themselves to a door and pouring fake blood on the red carpet ahead of the event. The protesters, wearing white dresses with blood-like stains, called for the fashion industry to address its impact on the environment. The British Fashion Council rejected the demand to cancel the event, instead seeing it as an opportunity to engage designers in the conversation about sustainability and climate change. The protest marked the start of a five-day event featuring luxury brands.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on optimism over US-China talks
summary: Tokyo shares rose, with the Nikkei index adding 1.05% to 21,988.29, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The talks have led to a 3.72% weekly gain for the Nikkei and a 4.73% gain for the broader Topix index. US President Donald Trump hinted at considering an "interim" deal with China, boosting market hopes for progress in trade negotiations. The European Central Bank's stimulus programme also lifted the market, with Toyota and SoftBank Group among the top gainers.

site_title: Europe says thank you for vaping as US tells consumers to stop
summary: European health officials endorse vaping as a way to wean people off smoking, citing its 95% lower harm compared to cigarettes. In contrast, US authorities advise consumers to stop vaping amid a mysterious lung illness crisis linked to THC-laced vaping liquids. The US has seen a rise in vaping among teenagers, with 1 in 4 high school students now regular users, while European teens vape less frequently. European countries have implemented stricter regulations on vaping products, including lower nicotine limits and restrictions on marketing to children.

site_title: Hong Kong unrest rocks insurers' sales as China buyers balk
summary: Hong Kong's summer of unrest has led to a decline in insurance sales to mainland Chinese buyers, with a group of 80 agents reporting a 30% drop in August sales compared to the previous year. The decline is expected to continue in September, with two other agents reporting steep falls in business. Chinese customers have traditionally flocked to Hong Kong for insurance products offering investment components and foreign currency payouts, but the unrest is deterring them.

site_title: US probes Nissan's top model on sudden unintended braking
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating Nissan's top-selling Rogue model after hundreds of drivers reported its automatic emergency braking system suddenly triggering the brakes for no apparent reason. Over 840 complaints have been filed, resulting in 14 crashes and 5 injuries. Nissan has implemented a software update to address the issue and notified affected customers. The NHTSA will examine the cause of the unintended braking and assess Nissan's steps to address the issue.

site_title: Goldbell launches accelerator programme for mobility startups
summary: Goldbell Group has launched Move.SG, a one-year mobility accelerator programme for startups in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific. The programme provides access to a fleet of over 8,500 vehicles, mentorship, pilot opportunities, and funding. It is the only mobility accelerator among Enterprise Singapore's Startup SG Accelerator initiative partners. The programme focuses on solutions for mobility, transport, and logistics in Singapore and the region, aiming to support the growth of mobility startups.

site_title: Court grants further extension to China Sky judicial management
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted an extension to the judicial manager of China Sky Chemical Fibre Company until March 13, 2020. The judicial manager, Yit Chee Wah, had initially applied for the extension on September 3. China Sky's shares are currently suspended, and the company had previously sold its investment holding company, Deluxe Dragon International Limited, to its chairman, He Zhidong, for S$190,000. This decision was deemed in the best interests of China Sky's creditors, as Deluxe Dragon is debt-ridden and has no operational assets.

site_title: TEE International appoints PwC external investigator into unauthorised transactions
summary: TEE International appoints PricewaterhouseCoopers Risk Services as an external investigator to probe unauthorised transactions totaling S$6.55 million, allegedly made under the instruction of group CEO Phua Chian Kin. The investigation will review financial records, transactions with related parties, and identify weaknesses in governance and internal controls. PricewaterhouseCoopers will liaise with the Singapore Exchange Regulation Pte Ltd and issue an overall findings report. The appointment follows concerns raised by external auditor Deloitte & Touche LLP regarding the transactions.

site_title: Japan Aug exports seen in sharpest fall in 3 years, core inflation to dip: poll
summary: Japan's exports likely contracted 10.9% in August, the largest decline in three years, due to the US-China trade war and slower global growth. Core consumer inflation is forecast to dip to the lowest level in two years, largely thanks to weaker energy prices. Imports are also expected to fall 11.2% in August, widening the trade deficit. The Bank of Japan may ease monetary policy further, citing stubbornly low inflation and heightened economic risks.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex adds new US$290m fund to back growth-stage tech firms
summary: Temasek's Vertex Venture Holdings has launched a new US$290 million growth-stage tech fund, surpassing its initial target of US$250 million. The fund is anchored by Vertex Venture Holdings and secured commitments from pan-Asian limited partners, including a sovereign wealth fund and institutional investors. This new fund is the sixth and newest member of Vertex Venture Holdings' global network of venture capital funds, supporting growth-stage technology firms.

site_title: WeWork considering curbing Neumann's voting power to save IPO: source
summary: WeWork's parent company is considering curtailing the voting power of founder Adam Neumann to address concerns over corporate governance standards ahead of its initial public offering (IPO). The company may revise Neumann's supervoting rights, which currently give him 20 times the voting power of ordinary shareholders. Additionally, Neumann's wife, Rebekah, may be removed from a role in succession planning, where she would pick a successor if Adam Neumann dies or is disabled. The changes are part of efforts to address business model sustainability and investor concerns.

site_title: Circles.Life extends reach to Australia through tie-up with Singtel's Optus
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based mobile virtual network operator, has partnered with Singtel's Optus to expand its services to Australia. The company has rolled out its services to the Australian Capital Territory and several states, with plans to launch in Western Australia and South Australia later. Circles.Life aims to offer a premium customer experience, flexible plans, and real-person customer service. The company plans to continue its strategy of offering no long-term contracts and bill shock protection, with prices starting from A$28 for 20 GB of data.

site_title: Shopee, LinkedIn, Avast roll out SkillsFuture classes on digital skills
summary: Singapore's Shopee, LinkedIn, and Avast have partnered with NTUC LearningHub and SkillsFuture Singapore to offer SkillsFuture classes on digital skills, available from October. The courses cover cybersecurity, e-commerce, and employability, aiming to upskill workers for the digital age. The two-day SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace (SFDW) course has been delivered to over 13 participants, who received hands-on training on Avast's mobile security app and LinkedIn's professional networks. The initiative aims to equip Singaporeans with basic digital skills and prepare them for technological changes.

site_title: Vietnam fights China moves to hinder offshore energy exploration
summary: Vietnam's foreign ministry has called on China to immediately leave its claimed waters in the South China Sea, where a Chinese-owned survey vessel has been intermittently zigzagging to study the seabed. Vietnam is pushing back against China's efforts to isolate it diplomatically over the territorial dispute. The move comes after China scored diplomatic wins with other South China Sea claimants, including a joint exploration deal with the Philippines. Vietnam's oil and gas project with Exxon Mobil will continue unimpeded, with the country asserting that any hampering of its exploration is a violation of international laws.

site_title: Google to promote original news reporting with algorithm change
summary: Google announced changes to its algorithm to promote original news reporting, highlighting critically important and labor-intensive stories. The changes, made by 10,000 reviewers, prioritize articles that demonstrate "original, in-depth, and investigative reporting." This shift aims to counter criticism that Google's algorithms have led to a decline in online traffic for media outlets. However, the impact on smaller online sites and local newspapers remains uncertain, and experts question the complexity of defining original reporting in the digital age.

images.alt_text: Original reporting will be highlighted in Google's search results, the company said as it announced changes to its algorithm.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,206.99, up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,206.99, driven by risk-on sentiment following the European Central Bank's economic stimulus and interest rate cut. Markets in Asia-Pacific also gained, with Australia, Hong Kong, and Japan trading higher. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank saw gains, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Boustead also experienced active trading.

site_title: Peru court cuts jail time for opposition leader Keiko Fujimori
summary: Peru's Supreme Court reduced Keiko Fujimori's pre-trial detention from 36 months to 18 months, allowing her to leave jail in April 2020. The opposition leader was held in a corruption case linked to Odebrecht. Fujimori's lawyer plans to appeal the decision to the Constitutional Court.

images.alt_text: Peru's Supreme Court on Thursday halved the pre-trial detention of Keiko Fujimori, paving the way for the opposition leader to leave jail in April of next year.

site_title: China, South Korea, Taiwan: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in China, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan are closed on Friday for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. US stocks edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices made gains. eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Sia Aik Kor named new chief of Singapore's competition watchdog
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) will have a new chief executive starting October 1. Sia Aik Kor, 44, a deputy chief counsel at the Attorney-General's Chambers, will replace Toh Han Li, who led CCCS since 2013. Sia has experience in vetting transactional documents and upgrading public sector procurement processes. She will oversee the CCCS in a new role.

site_title: Paris commuters hit by transport strike over pension overhaul
summary: Transport workers in Paris went on strike over plans to reduce their retirement privileges, disrupting 10 subway lines and two major train lines. The strike, expected to be the largest since 2007, aims to send a warning to President Emmanuel Macron's government as it launches a pension reform plan. Prime Minister Edouard Philippe has promised to carefully consider union demands, but the government remains determined to carry out the pension reform plan, which has been met with widespread criticism. The strike has already caused travel chaos, with commuters forced to find alternative routes to work.

images.alt_text: Parisian commuters faced travel chaos on Friday as transport workers went on strike over plans to reduce their retirement privileges in a challenge to President Emmanuel Macron's pension reform plans.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam to prioritise housing, livelihoods to appease protesters
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has promised to prioritize housing and people's livelihoods to appease protesters, who are demanding greater democracy and an end to what they see as Beijing's erosion of civil liberties. Lam said her government will increase housing supply and announce more policies, following a series of protests sparked by a now-withdrawn extradition bill and concerns over high living costs and job prospects. Demonstrations are set to continue, with activists planning sit-ins, human chains, and other actions to press their demands, amid a backdrop of economic recession and police crackdowns.

site_title: White House moving forward to strip California of vehicle standards authority
summary: The Trump administration is moving forward with a plan to revoke California's authority to set its own vehicle greenhouse gas standards, citing preemption of state rules. The EPA proposed rolling back Obama-era standards in 2018, and the White House has met with senior officials to finalize the plan. The administration plans to divide the rule into two parts, preempting states first, before issuing new yearly standards. The move is part of the Trump administration's plan to roll back federal fuel economy standards, which would freeze emissions requirements at 2020 levels through 2026.

site_title: Climate campaigners plan Heathrow drone shutdown
summary: Climate activists from Heathrow Pause, backed by Greta Thunberg, planned to fly toy drones around London's Heathrow Airport to protest construction of a third runway and cut emissions to zero by 2025. The plan was delayed after police arrested five group members on suspicion of conspiracy to commit a public nuisance. The activists aim to disrupt airport operations, but acknowledge the risks posed by drones to airport safety. The protest, which could last up to five days, has been met with criticism from the airport and police.

site_title: Trudeau vows tax on foreign speculators if reelected Canadian PM
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has vowed to tax foreign speculators who buy Canadian properties but don't live in them, if reelected. The one-percent annual tax on non-resident properties would be introduced to curb housing speculation, blamed partly for soaring prices in cities like Toronto and Vancouver. Trudeau aims to make homeownership more affordable, particularly for young Canadians, and expand first-time buyer incentives. The move is seen as a response to record-low interest rates and a housing supply shortage contributing to the increases.

site_title: Vietravel Airlines plans 2020 launch in fast-growing market
summary: Vietravel Airlines, Vietnam's leading tour operator, plans to launch its first flight in 2020, joining the country's fast-growing aviation market. The airline, which will start with three to four leased planes, expects to order an Airbus or Boeing narrowbody jet within five years. Vietravel Airlines aims to operate international flights to Japan, South Korea, Asean, Australia, and China, with plans to expand its fleet to 20-30 aircraft within five years. The airline has raised 700 billion dong (S$41.4 million) via a bond sale and plans to list on the local stock market exchange.

site_title: As unrest deepens, Hong Kongers eye exits from Vancouver to Melbourne
summary: Protests in Hong Kong have led to a surge in migration applications, with residents considering exits to destinations like Malaysia, Taiwan, Australia, and Canada. Since the extradition bill was scrapped, requests for police-record printouts jumped 54% in August, a five-year high. The Hong Kong government estimates 7,600 people left the city in 2019, with authorities in Malaysia, Australia, and Taiwan reporting spikes in migration enquiries. Property agents report strong interest in Vancouver, Melbourne, and other cities, with some investors already purchasing properties.

site_title: Event cancellations mount in protest-wracked Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's protests have led to a wave of event cancellations, including the postponement of the WTA Hong Kong Open women's tennis tournament, a musical production of Matilda, and a global wellness summit. The cancellations follow months of violent protests over a controversial bill allowing extraditions to mainland China. The city's tourism sector is also struggling, with on-year tourist arrivals falling by 40% in August and hotel occupancy rates down by half. The economic hardship has led to widespread calls for democracy and complaints against the erosion of freedoms under Beijing's rule.

site_title: Toyota using made-for-Tesla Panasonic batteries for China hybrids: Nikkei
summary: Toyota has started using Panasonic-designed batteries for its plug-in hybrids sold in China, including the Corolla and Levin models. Toyota ordered around 50,000 of the cylindrical batteries, which were originally designed for Tesla. This marks Toyota's first use of non-Tesla batteries for its plug-in hybrids. The move is part of Toyota's efforts to reduce costs and increase efficiency in its battery production.

site_title: Australia: Shares lifted by financials as trade war worries ease; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,667.10, driven by gains in the financial sector and hopes for a US-China trade resolution. The European Central Bank announced stimulus measures, boosting market sentiment. The Australian financial index rose 0.6%, with Commonwealth Bank climbing 1%. New Zealand's benchmark slipped 0.2%, pressured by energy and utilities, while manufacturing activity remained in contraction.

site_title: Asia: Markets boosted by fresh trade hopes and ECB easing
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday after the European Central Bank announced a fresh round of economic stimulus and interest rate cut, boosting hopes for growth. The ECB restarted its bond-buying program to support struggling banks and reduce borrowing costs. A report also suggested the US was considering a short-term trade agreement with China, providing further hope for a resolution. The news sent equities in Europe and New York higher, with the euro bouncing back from a decline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Friday slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.25% to 27,154.51. The gains were driven by a fresh round of stimulus measures from the European Central Bank, which boosted investor hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut next week. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Rich Capital's JV partner demands full control of Batam project, S$20m compensation
summary: Rich Capital Holdings' joint venture partner, Karya Indo Batam, has sent two legal letters demanding full control of the Oxley Batam Convention City Project in Batam and S$20 million compensation. The letters claim conspiracy and breaches of Indonesian laws due to the appointment of Rich-Link Construction as the main contractor. Rich Capital's Oxley Batam Pte Ltd partnered with KIB to form a 50:50 joint venture company, OKIB, in 2019. The dispute raises concerns over the management and ownership of the project.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.2% to 3,200.15
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,200.15, driven by gains in Wall Street stocks and European Central Bank's interest rate cut. Asian equities also saw modest gains, with Japan's Topix index advancing 0.5% and Australia stocks rising 0.3%. Banking stocks, including DBS and OCBC, were also in the green, while gainers outnumbered losers 61 to 33 on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange's China ties may backfire in LSE quest
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd's (HKEX) £29.6 billion bid for the London Stock Exchange Group Plc is facing potential backlash due to its China ties, which could be a commercial handicap. The bid is conditional on HKEX scrapping a US$27 billion deal for data provider Refinitiv. Critics argue that HKEX's connections to Beijing, including the Hong Kong government's ownership and Beijing's influence on the city's affairs, could lead to unwelcome pressure on the London Stock Exchange, particularly in the wake of Hong Kong's social unrest.

images.alt_text: When Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd bought the London Metal Exchange in 2012, the access it offered to the Chinese market was a big plus.

site_title: Biden fights off rivals in US Democratic 2020 debate
summary: In the third Democratic presidential debate, Joe Biden clashed with top rivals Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren on health care reform, pushing his plan to maintain and build on the Affordable Care Act. Biden accused his fellow septuagenarians of lacking a plan to fund their proposals, while Sanders and Warren defended their positions. Despite a noticeable dip in recent polls, Biden maintains a strong lead with 26.8% support, ahead of Sanders at 17.3% and Warren at 16.8%. The debate highlighted the party's unity in ousting Donald Trump but also exposed differences in policy and strategy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on ECB stimulus, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.59% on Friday, driven by the European Central Bank's stimulus package and a cheaper yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 128.72 points to 21,888.33. Investors were also encouraged by the strong rally in Singapore stocks, which marked a 5-day winning streak ahead of GDP data. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index's gains were attributed to the ECB's stimulus, while the cheaper yen provided additional support.

site_title: China prods state firms to boost investment in crisis-hit Hong Kong: sources
summary: China has urged its state-run companies to boost investment in crisis-hit Hong Kong, aiming to calm months of unrest in the city. At a meeting in Shenzhen, nearly 100 state-owned enterprises pledged to invest more in key industries, including real estate and tourism, to create jobs and stabilize financial markets. The move is seen as an attempt to exert more control over companies in Hong Kong and address concerns of creeping Chinese influence. The plan follows months of huge protests triggered by a proposed extradition bill.

images.alt_text: China has called on its biggest state firms to take a more active role in Hong Kong, including stepping up investment and asserting more control of companies in the financial hub, executives familiar with the matter said, as Beijing attempts to calm months of unrest in the city.

site_title: Google employees free to express views under settlement with US
summary: Google has reached a settlement with the US National Labour Relations Board, reminding employees of their right to express views on "workplace issues." The agreement comes after a fired engineer alleged he was targeted for his conservative views, but Google maintains the deal doesn't mention political activity. The company will post digital and physical notices on its internal network for 60 days, following a complaint by Kevin Cernekee and another worker. Google has denied any bias and emphasized its policy to avoid partisan debates.

site_title: Hong Kong festival mooncakes get a protest makeover
summary: In Hong Kong, baker Naomi Suen has created mooncakes with pro-democracy slogans, adding a contemporary twist to the traditional mid-autumn festival treats. The cakes feature messages such as "Hong Kong People" and "Be Water," referencing local protests and kung fu philosophy. Suen hopes the cakes will promote unity and understanding among generations. As the festival begins, protesters plan rallies and events, using the mooncakes as a symbol of their resistance against Beijing's eroding freedoms.

images.alt_text: At the back of her tiny shop, Hong Kong baker Naomi Suen pulls out a fresh tray of mooncakes - each one sporting popular slogans from recent pro-democracy protests.

site_title: CDL takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels turns unconditional
summary: CDL's takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) has been declared unconditional, allowing the delisting of M&C shares from the London Stock Exchange on Oct 11. The offer, with a final cash price of 685 pence per share, was accepted by 58.28% of remaining M&C shares, exceeding the 50% threshold. CDL will re-register M&C as a private company after delisting, and shareholders not accepting the offer may become minority shareholders in an unlisted private subsidiary of CDL.

site_title: HK chief executive 'has to serve two masters': Carrie Lam full transcript
summary: Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam said she "has to serve two masters" during a speech to businesspeople in late August. The transcript, obtained by Reuters, reveals Lam's comments on serving both China and Hong Kong, raising concerns about her loyalty. The remarks, made before the protests in Hong Kong began, suggest Lam's administration is under pressure to balance the interests of China and Hong Kong. The full transcript was published by Reuters, providing insight into Lam's views on her role and the challenges she faces.

site_title: US-China trade war risks driving Federal Reserve policy, not Trump's carping: economists poll
summary: US economists expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates for the second meeting in a row, with a median probability of a US recession in the next two years at 45% and a 30% chance in the next 12 months. The expected rate cut is unlikely to satisfy President Trump, who has called for deeper cuts to boost slowing economic growth. Economists attribute the Fed's decision to trade risks and not Trump's criticism, with nearly 80% saying the Fed's actions are not influenced by the President's tweets.

site_title: US House panel wants Boeing CEO to allow employee interviews on 737 Max crashes
summary: The US House Transportation Committee has requested Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg to allow employee interviews as part of a congressional probe into the 737 Max crashes that killed 346 people. The committee, led by Chairman Peter DeFazio, plans to hear from relevant Boeing employees to gather more information about the plane's development. The FAA has repeatedly stated that it will not certify the plane to fly again until it is safe to do so. Boeing has not immediately commented on the request.

site_title: Google agrees 945m euro tax settlement with France
summary: Google has agreed to a 945 million euro tax settlement with France, paying a 500-million-euro fine for tax evasion and 465 million euros to settle claims with French tax authorities. The settlement marks the end of a long-standing tax dispute and follows similar agreements in Italy and Britain. Google wants to see a coordinated international taxation framework, while French officials welcome the settlement as a victory for fiscal fairness and public finances. The agreement comes as France and its allies seek to address the taxation of digital giants, a topic also being discussed at the G-7 summit.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust completes S$274.8m acquisition of shopping mall in China
summary: Dasin Retail Trust completed the acquisition of Doumen Metro Mall in China for approximately S$274.8 million. The trust acquired all equity interests of Jiaxin Commercial Holdings, which also includes a 12-year lease agreement for 4,064 square meters of retail space. The lease agreement is expected to generate S$13 million in rental and associated fees, accounting for 1.7% of the trust's audited net tangible assets. The acquisition was made through a purchase price, repayment of indebtedness, and fees, with an acquisition fee of around S$2 million paid to the trustee-manager.

site_title: Japanese economy remains in moderate recovery: Aso
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the country's economy remains in a moderate recovery, with firm fundamentals supporting domestic demand. He declined to comment on the European Central Bank's monetary stimulus package and left the decision on the Bank of Japan's policy-setting meeting to the BOJ. Aso's comments came as the global economic landscape is shifting, with concerns over China's slowing GDP growth and the impact of US tariffs on Asian industries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.31 points to 1,600.69 at 9am on Friday, with 60.02 million lots traded worth RM16.73 million. Gainers beat losers 80 to 39. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, while Asia traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally. In other markets, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US tariff uncertainty, and an eSIM platform raised US$220 million in new funding.

site_title: Europe: ECB stimulus draws tepid response from stocks; banks end flat
summary: European stocks rose 0.8% after the European Central Bank cut its deposit rate to a record low of -0.5% and announced bond purchases of 20 billion euros a month. However, gains were short-lived, and stocks ended flat due to concerns over the ECB's easing of loan terms and tiered deposit rates. Banks, including Italian banks, rose 0.24-1.2%, while automakers jumped on news of a potential US-China trade deal.

site_title: A look at US Reits in Singapore
summary: US property trusts have listed on the Singapore Exchange, offering investors access to the US real estate market. Three trusts have listed this year, despite being a relatively new asset class in Singapore. Analysts consider them high-yielding, but their performance and prospects remain uncertain. The move is seen as expanding the range of investment options for Singapore investors, but the market's response to these new assets is still evolving.

site_title: US to reveal Saudi official allegedly tied to 9/11 attackers
summary: The US Justice Department has announced it will unmask the name of a Saudi official allegedly tied to the 9/11 attackers, in response to years of pressure from victims' families. The individual, the third of three main Saudi officials referred to in an FBI report, is believed to have assisted some of the attackers after they arrived in the US. The unmasking comes amid claims of damages that could reach billions of dollars, and follows a 2012 redacted FBI report that repeated allegations of Saudi intelligence involvement.

site_title: Singapore lender still using faxes seeks digital bank licence
summary: Hong Leong Finance, a 70-year-old Singapore lender, is exploring a digital bank licence to tap into the country's virtual banking plans and modernize its services. The firm, which still uses faxes in its application process, wants to partner with fintech companies to apply technology to its lending decisions and attract younger clients. With a market capitalization of S$1.2 billion, Hong Leong aims to adapt to the tech-savvy needs of the nation's new businesses and millennials.

site_title: AEM Holdings gets S$280m in sales orders; raises revenue guidance for FY2019
summary: AEM Holdings received sales orders worth S$280 million for delivery in FY2019, revising its revenue guidance to S$285-305 million. The company posted a 65.4% jump in net profit to S$15.7 million in the second quarter, with revenue surging 34.8% to S$97.9 million. An interim cash dividend of two cents per share was declared, up from 1.5 cents a year ago. The revised guidance and strong financial performance suggest a positive outlook for the company.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Digital cross-border payments with InstaReM
summary: Singapore-based InstaReM, the only digital cross-border payments company with presence across Asia-Pacific, North America, and Europe, has created a unique payments mesh for fast and low-cost cross-border payments to over 55 countries. The company's CEO, Prajit Nanu, discussed the digital payments landscape with Money FM podcast. Meanwhile, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has begun accepting applications for Singapore's first digital bank initiative, highlighting the growing importance of digital payments in the region.

site_title: US says tanker spotted in Syria shows Iran deceitful
summary: The US claims Iran has shown itself untrustworthy after a tanker, the Adrian Darya 1, was found to have delivered oil to Syria despite promises it would not. The ship was held by Gibraltar authorities for six weeks before being released. Iran's Iranian ambassador was summoned to protest, with the US criticizing the regime's broken promises and its support for President Bashar al-Assad's brutal regime. The US has long been critical of Iran, having slapped punishing sanctions on the country and walking away from a nuclear accord.

site_title: Cool Retreat in Karuizawa
summary: Karuizawa, a mountain resort in Japan, offers a cooler escape from Tokyo's sweltering summer heat. Located 90 minutes away, the area boasts lower temperatures and a more relaxed atmosphere. Rich Japanese and short-stay refugees alike find refuge in Karuizawa, with ample lodging and souvenir shops available. The town's Shishi-Iwa House, designed by architect Shigeru Ban, serves as a serene retreat for guests to connect with nature and each other, providing a tranquil oasis in the midst of Japan's scorching summer.

images.alt_text: Shishi-Iwa House looks like part farmhouse and part chapel from the outside.
The curved side of the house flanks the garden.
The minimalist bedrooms look out into greenery.
Left: The minimalist bedrooms look out into greenery. Right: The dramatic high-ceiling entrance.
Sezon Museum of Modern Art is a relaxing short walk from the house.
Sezon's garden is home to sleek sculptures

site_title: US: Stocks gain on ECB stimulus, trade war moderation
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by the European Central Bank's new stimulus measures and signs of moderation in the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 climbed 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.3%. The ECB cut interest rates deeper into negative territory and announced new debt purchases and support for struggling banks. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said trade negotiators are seeking "meaningful progress" with China in October talks, amid a delay in tariff increases.

site_title: US wants to make 'meaningful progress' in China trade talks
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed cautious optimism about making "meaningful progress" in upcoming trade talks with China, following conciliatory gestures by both sides. The talks, set to begin at the deputy level, aim to advance towards a deal to resolve the ongoing trade conflict. Mnuchin warned that President Donald Trump will only accept a good deal and is willing to raise tariffs if necessary, while China has agreed to delay one round of tariff increases on $250 billion worth of goods until October 15.

site_title: France's Piketty bashes billionaires in new 1,200-page book
summary: French economist Thomas Piketty released a 1,200-page book, "Capital and Ideology", warning about the dangers of global capitalism's concentration of wealth among the super-rich. Piketty suggests policies such as raising death taxes up to 90% and giving large handouts of public money to individuals at age 25 to address inequality. Critics argue that his proposals would reduce incentives to work and lead to massive tax evasion, while Piketty claims that unequal systems ultimately transform themselves through democratic deliberation.

images.alt_text: Reform or face ruin: the surprise literary sensation of 2013, French economist Thomas Piketty, returned with another doorstep-size book on Thursday that warns darkly about the excesses of global capitalism.

site_title: North American trade deal must be 'greatly improved': top Democrat
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi says a new North American trade pact, the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), must be "greatly improved" to address concerns over labor protections for Mexican workers. Despite progress in negotiations, Pelosi says there is no text to vote on and that changes to enforcement provisions should be made within the treaty itself. The pact's future hangs in doubt ahead of a presidential election year, with Democrats seeking to ratify the treaty to protect US industry and farmers.

images.alt_text: "It has to be greatly improved in terms of enforcement," Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from California, told reporters. "We think we're making progress."

site_title: US finds North Korean readiness for talks 'encouraging'
summary: The US has expressed encouragement towards North Korea's willingness to resume negotiations, with State Department spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus calling it an "encouraging sign". However, the US criticized North Korea's recent missile launches, which they deemed counterproductive. Despite this, the US remains committed to talks with North Korea, with no scheduled meetings yet. North Korea has stated its intention to hold "comprehensive discussions" with the US by the end of the month, following a recent summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Hanoi.

site_title: Mexico's Pemex offers to prepay chunk of US$14.7b in bonds
summary: Mexico's state-owned oil company Pemex has launched a tender offer to prepay around a third of its US$14.7 billion in bonds maturing between 2020-2023, using a US$5 billion capital injection from the government. The offer aims to shore up the company, which is heavily indebted with US$104 billion in debt. The move is part of President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador's efforts to revive Pemex, which has struggled with declining oil output and mismanagement. The offer expires next Wednesday, with Pemex also offering additional bonds with maturities of seven, 10, and 30 years.

site_title: Boeing's 737 Max may make 'phased' return, says CEO
summary: Boeing's 737 Max is expected to return to service on a "phased" timetable if regulators worldwide approve the grounded jet at their own pace. The company's CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, stated that Boeing is making "solid progress" in addressing concerns from global regulators, including the European Union Aviation Safety Agency. The Max's redesigned flight-control system has undergone over 600 flights testing, and Boeing has completed a second-wave evaluation of the entire software and flight control systems. A phased return to service is seen as a possibility, with the US Federal Aviation Administration leading the way.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% on US-China trade doubts, Opec+ talks
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Thursday due to US-China trade doubts and a meeting of Opec+ that yielded no decision on deepening crude supply cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $60.38 a barrel, and WTI crude futures at $55.09 a barrel. The European Central Bank cut its deposit rate to a record low and announced bond purchases to prop up euro zone growth. A senior White House official denied a report on a potential US-China trade deal, and Saudi Arabia's new energy minister said deeper cuts would not be decided before a December Opec meeting.

site_title: Bridging the supply chain gap
summary: Tech startup TraMes aims to simplify supply chain operations and provide visibility for its clients, tackling the fragmented logistics industry. The company consolidates data from various sources into a single platform, enabling easier tracking and communication among parties in the supply chain. TraMes has secured a proof-of-concept with a Fortune 500 company and is tracking 50% of its global shipments, with plans to integrate with enterprise resource planning systems. Despite securing $500,000 in funding, TraMes faces challenges in attracting local talent, with many Singaporeans preferring established MNCs.

site_title: Eurozone bond markets calm ahead of possible ECB storm
summary: Eurozone bond markets remained calm ahead of a possible European Central Bank (ECB) announcement of fresh stimulus measures. Despite expectations of a rate cut and potential quantitative easing (QE), bond yields remained steady, with German 10-year bond yields at -0.57%. The ECB is expected to consider a 10- or 20-basis-point rate cut, but the focus is on whether they will restart QE, which could impact borrowing costs and long-dated bonds.

site_title: Core consumer prices rise 0.3% in Aug
summary: US underlying consumer prices rose 0.3% in August, the largest annual gain in a year, driven by increases in healthcare costs, airline tickets, and used cars. This solid increase in core CPI is unlikely to deter the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates next week to support a slowing economy.

site_title: Sounds Like Nostalgia
summary: Dick Lee's 1989 album "The Mad Chinaman" achieved platinum status in multiple countries, becoming a sensation in Singapore and beyond. To celebrate its 30th anniversary, Lee is staging a one-night-only concert at the Esplanade Concert Hall on September 15, featuring a 60-piece orchestra and 100 singers. This concert marks the first time Lee has performed the entire album since the early 1990s, bringing back nostalgic memories for fans.

site_title: Buy China stocks, says trillion-dollar fund manager
summary: T Rowe Price's Thomas Poullaouec recommends investing in Chinese stocks due to their undervalued prices and expected earnings growth from stimulus efforts. Chinese shares have risen 9% in the past month, while US shares have risen just 2%. Poullaouec believes China's stimulus measures are currently under-recognized by investors, and the market is pricing too many Fed cuts. He favors an underweight stance on US shares and a neutral stance on Japan, with emerging markets being the only overweight position. This is in contrast to the poor performance of developed market stocks this year.

site_title: Claire Chiang, Business Owner and Activist
summary: Claire Chiang, co-founder of Banyan Tree Holdings, has dedicated her life to conservation and environmental efforts. Born in 1952, Chiang grew up in a resource-scarce Singapore, where she learned to reuse and recycle from a young age. This ethos has guided her work in establishing the luxury group with 49 hotels and resorts, championing social and environmental causes. The Wildlife Reserves Singapore Conservation Fund, co-founded by Chiang, celebrates its 10th year of supporting endangered native wildlife species in Singapore. Chiang believes that conservation is an integral part of business, and her work aims to raise the "Nature Quotient" of Singaporeans, promoting environmental responsibility and sustainability.

site_title: honestbee chairman Brian Koo looms large in startup's revamp bid
summary: Honestbee, a Singapore-based grocery delivery startup, is seeking court protection to restructure its $209 million in debt. Chairman Brian Koo, a key backer, holds significant influence with $185 million in unsecured debt owed to his family's business and himself. However, minority creditors may have a say in the outcome, as the company's restructuring plan requires support from at least 75% of creditors in each class. The outcome may depend on how creditors are divided into classes, with some experts suggesting that unsecured creditors may band together to block the proposal and potentially force a liquidation scenario, which could be worse for minority creditors.

site_title: Sembcorp to provide solar power for UBS's Singapore offices for a decade
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a 10-year deal with UBS to supply renewable power to the bank's Singapore operations. The deal involves selling surplus energy from 15,000 rooftop solar panels, totaling 6.3 megawatt-peak capacity, to UBS. The partnership aims to reduce carbon emissions by 20 million kilogrammes over 10 years, with UBS planning to run its entire Singapore operations on renewable energy by 2020. The contract is not expected to significantly impact Sembcorp's earnings.

site_title: Gender diversity target on SGX-listed boards proving a challenge
summary: Singapore's top 100 primary-listed companies by market capitalisation have 15.7% female board members, according to the Council for Board Diversity. Despite a 0.5 percentage point increase in the first half of 2019, the council's target of 20% or 171 directorships by end-2020 is now in doubt. The slow progress raises concerns about achieving the goal, casting a shadow on the country's efforts to increase gender diversity on SGX-listed boards.

site_title: Moonlight Tales
summary: The Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre is hosting the Mid-Autumn Yeah!, a multi-sensory festival celebrating cultural heritage. The event features an interplanetary journey to explore moon lore, a virtual-reality moon viewing experience, and workshops. Visitors can participate in activities like "The Mooncake Heist" and take part in a mass-escape activity to break into the moon vault. The festival runs on September 13 and 14 at the Cultural Centre, with free admission but some activities chargeable.

site_title: Euro waits for ECB as trade thaw spurs yuan rebound
summary: The euro hovered near US$1.10 as traders awaited the European Central Bank's expected stimulus package, with investors expecting a rate cut and potential restart of quantitative easing. The euro has shed 3.4% since June, but rose 0.2% on Thursday. China's yuan and Australia's dollar rallied on signs of a US-China trade war thaw, while the US dollar fell slightly against a basket of currencies. The ECB's decision is scheduled for Thursday, with traders expecting a package that would be a disappointment for the market, potentially pushing euro long rates higher.

site_title: SGX FX futures hit record volume in August on macro uncertainties
summary: SGX FX futures recorded a record monthly volume of over 2.6 million contracts traded in August, with an aggregate trading volume of US$143 billion, driven by macroeconomic volatility. This represents a 22% month-on-month increase and a 53% year-on-year increase in the notional value traded. The surge in trading was largely attributed to the yuan breaching seven to the US$ for the first time in a decade, and volatility in the Indian rupee.

site_title: Anime Alert
summary: Studio Ghibli's Makoto Shinkai returns to the big screen with his new film, Weathering With You, which has already surpassed $100 million at the domestic box office. The film tells the story of a teenager who befriends an orphan girl with weather manipulation abilities in a Tokyo hit by persistent rain. Picked as Japan's entry for Best Foreign Film at the Oscars next year, Weathering With You is the director's first new material since Hayao Miyazaki's retirement in 2014.

site_title: Trump without Bolton: More missteps ahead?
summary: US President Donald Trump's national security advisor, John Bolton, was fired this week, raising questions about Trump's ability to fulfill his campaign promises, particularly regarding his foreign policy. Trump had planned to meet with Taliban representatives at Camp David to end the war in Afghanistan, but the meeting was cancelled after a Taliban-claimed attack in Kabul. With Bolton gone, Trump may feel more freedom to pursue his goals, including withdrawing US troops from Afghanistan and reducing the US military footprint in the Middle East.

site_title: Girl Power
summary: The Alex Blake Charlie Sessions, a new day-long event, has been announced by the creators of Laneway Festival. The event, taking place on Dec 7 at Pasir Panjang Power Station, features a strong female-fronted lineup with acts such as Cate Le Bon, Charly Bliss, Goat Girl, and Soak. The event spans multiple genres, including pop rock, R&B, indie folk, and electronica. Tickets are available from S$100 via APACTix, with updates available on alexblakecharlie.sg.

site_title: London selfie shop lets Instagram generation strike a pose
summary: A pop-up selfie studio, The Selfie Factory, has opened in London's Westfield shopping centre, featuring 20 themed booths and backdrops for social media photos. The £10-per-circuit space, created by 26-year-old Will Bower, aims to provide abundant Instagrammable content for the "Instagram generation." Visitors, mostly teenagers and 20-somethings, pose in quirky settings, while others, including 60-somethings, also participate. The concept is inspired by popular Instagram hotspots in Asia and North America, with Bower seeking to capitalize on the social media craze.

site_title: EU-Singapore FTA opens doors to third markets: Iswaran
summary: Singapore firms can leverage the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) to enter regional markets beyond Europe, including ASEAN, by partnering with European peers. Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran stated that Singapore companies can form partnerships with European enterprises to create solutions for regional markets, such as renewable energy. The EUSFTA also provides harmonization of standards in areas like healthcare, benefiting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Iswaran expressed optimism about a potential larger EU-ASEAN FTA, with the EUSFTA serving as a stepping stone, and emphasized the importance of the multilateral rules-based trading system represented by the World Trade Organization (WTO).

site_title: Protests have hurt HK's reputation, AmCham poll finds
summary: Businesses in Hong Kong overwhelmingly say the ongoing protests have tarnished the city's business reputation, with 67% agreeing it has harmed their reputation and 80% affecting their decision to invest. Despite this, only 1% plan to move out of Hong Kong, with 91% choosing Singapore as their primary destination. Experts note that Hong Kong's strategic location as a gateway to China makes it difficult for companies to abandon the city, even with protests ongoing.

site_title: Man Of The Moment
summary: Ermenegildo Zegna is redefining masculinity with its new Fall/Winter 2019 campaign, eliminating traditional stereotypes and embracing vulnerability and self-expression. The brand's CEO, Gildo Zegna, believes that the static notion of masculinity no longer works and that men are becoming more emotionally available. Zegna is not only progressive with its designs but also ideas, tapping two-time Oscar winner Mahershala Ali and Asian celebrity Nicholas Tse to front the campaign. The brand aims to foster a conversation around modern masculinity and broaden the dialogue with younger generations.

images.alt_text: Backstage at Ermenegildo Zegna Fall/Winter 2019 show.
Backstage at Ermenegildo Zegna Fall/Winter 2019 show.
Backstage at Ermenegildo Zegna Fall/Winter 2019 show.

site_title: AB InBev targets US$5b in Asian unit's HK IPO
summary: AB InBev, the parent company of Budweiser Brewing Co, is reviving its plan to raise approximately US$5 billion through a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) by the end of September. The company had initially scrapped the plan in July, but is now gauging investor demand and preparing to launch the deal. The IPO involves AB InBev's minority stake in Budweiser Brewing Company APAC Ltd, excluding its Australian operations, which it sold to Asahi Group Holdings for US$11.3 billion.

site_title: Time for protesters, HK government to bring concerns to the table
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong demand structural reform and good governance, but their tactics, such as vandalizing MTR stations, may be counterproductive. The government has met some of the protesters' demands, including withdrawing the extradition bill, but further talks are needed. An independent inquiry into police excesses and universal suffrage are key issues to be discussed. The protesters' actions have led to a breakdown in social order, and Beijing may intervene to preserve the city's autonomy. To achieve lasting change, protesters must balance their demands with a willingness to engage in constructive dialogue and compromise.

site_title: Fall/Winter 2019 Fashion Report
summary: This season's fashion report emphasizes elegance and refinement, with bright and bold colours dominating the trends. Jewel tones and day-glo hues are popular choices, adding a pop of colour to winter outfits. Meanwhile, winter capes are also making a statement, offering a stylish layering option for the cold season.

site_title: Duck and more at Kai Duck
summary: Kai Duck, a new Chinese restaurant in Singapore, offers a casual dining experience with a modern twist on traditional Cantonese cuisine. The restaurant's signature Peking duck is a highlight, served with a sweet-salty miso paste and crispy dehydrated beancurd wafers. Other dishes, such as the hot and sour soup with shredded duck meat and the poached fish in hot chilli oil, show promise, despite some inconsistencies in quality. While the restaurant's price point and portioning can be confusing, the staff is friendly and the atmosphere is welcoming. Overall, Kai Duck is a promising addition to Singapore's dining scene.

site_title: Asia-Pac markets see mixed trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 9.56 points or 0.3% to 3,194.96 on Thursday, amid mixed trading in Asia-Pacific markets. China delayed tariffs on US imports until mid-October, while Japan's benchmark index added 0.75% or 161.85 points to close at 21,759.61. Despite optimism over US-China trade tensions, markets remain cautious due to the unpredictable nature of the relationship, with financial markets positioned for central bank love but built on fragile foundations.

site_title: Redefining the future of work amid digital disruption, change
summary: The future of work is being redefined amid digital disruption, with new technologies like machine learning, big data analytics, and IoT changing companies' business models. While some jobs may be automated, new ones are being created, such as "developers," "creatives," and "relationship experts." Humans will focus on solving customer problems, defining and pre-structuring them, and evaluating machine-driven solutions. Technology will become more integrated into the workplace, enhancing productivity and synergy between employees. Ultimately, work may become more fulfilling and enjoyable, expanding opportunities for people without access to technology, including those without digital literacy, older individuals, and those in rural areas.

site_title: Perfect Pair
summary: Lawry's The Prime Rib Singapore is hosting a one-night-only dinner event pairing its dishes with single malt Scotch Auchentoshan. The menu features a customized cocktail, Flowers by the Bay, and pairs each course with a different Auchentoshan whisky, including 18 Years Old, 21 Years Old, and 12 Years Old. The dinner is priced at S$128 per person and will take place on September 18 at 7pm. Bookings can be made through lawrys.com.sg/events. This unique culinary experience combines fine dining with whisky tasting.

site_title: What to wear to womansplain
summary: Fashion shows have been criticized for lacking empowerment, instead featuring weak and subtle designs. However, some collections, like Proenza Schouler's, have made a statement with bold and powerful clothing, including oversized jackets, high-waisted pants, and exaggerated curves. These designs aim to reclaim women's power and confidence, rejecting the male gaze and instead embracing a sense of strength and individuality.

site_title: Bread Basket
summary: Antoinette, a bakery known for French-style pastries, has introduced a new line of breads and buns at its Penhas Road outlet and Millennia Walk shop. The range includes traditional European breads and Japanese-style buns, with locally-inspired creations such as a Gula Melaka croissant and Singapore Laksa Baguette Toast. Prices range from $1.50 to $4.50. The bakery aims to make a baking statement with its soft and chewy breads.

site_title: CPF to take action against honestbee for unpaid July contributions
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board is taking enforcement action against honestbee for failing to pay July contributions to its employees. 38 former employees have filed claims with the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) over unpaid salaries, with most owed between one and two months' salary. Honestbee has confirmed a "salary delay" due to insufficient working capital, but has stated it intends to meet its obligations to staff. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) is monitoring the situation and advising employees to file claims with TADM if they are still owed salaries.

site_title: Preventing Cold War II in a world of competing interests
summary: The world is witnessing a growing rivalry between the US and China, posing a risk to global stability and multilateralism. The escalating superpower rivalry has led to increased tensions, economic costs, and a widening power imbalance. A new Cold War-like scenario is unfolding, with the US and China divided by ideology and mutually antagonistic relations. However, economic interdependence and globalization have created a "two systems, one world" dynamic, where both countries rely on each other. To prevent a repeat of the Cold War, a more integrated Europe and an outward-looking America could strengthen ties and support multilateralism, potentially countering Chinese power.

site_title: Alain Ducasse makes Mediterranean debut in Singapore
summary: Celebrated French chef-restaurateur Alain Ducasse has opened his Mediterranean-inspired restaurant, BBR by Alain Ducasse, at Raffles Singapore. The 235-seat restaurant, formerly known as Bar & Billiard Room, offers a social dining experience with dishes such as Spanish potato omelettes and grilled octopus. Ducasse aimed to preserve the historic space while creating a modern, casual yet elegant atmosphere. The restaurant's menu reflects Ducasse's philosophy of natural sweetness and Mediterranean cuisine, without incorporating local elements. BBR by Alain Ducasse marks Ducasse's presence in Singapore, alongside other notable restaurants in his portfolio.

site_title: Strike-hit BA flying into turbulence
summary: British Airways (BA) faced significant disruptions due to a two-day strike by pilots, resulting in the cancellation of around 1,600 flights and travel chaos for 200,000 passengers. The strike, sparked by a pay dispute, grounded BA's UK fleet and damaged the airline's global reputation. However, experts say that timely and effective management of the situation can help BA recover from the incident. The airline offered full refunds and alternative flight options, and is working to restore normal flight schedules.

site_title: Sun Hung Kai Properties' profit up 6.6%
summary: Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd, Hong Kong's largest developer, reported a 6.6% increase in annual earnings before the city's political crisis intensified. Underlying profit reached HK$32.4 billion, missing the mean estimate of HK$33.3 billion. The company expects uncertain results in future years due to the challenging situation in Hong Kong. Despite this, Hong Kong property sales and land bank increased, and the company has one of the lowest levels of leverage. Shares fell 0.8% but are still up 4.8% for the year.

site_title: Singtel gets its employees digitally ready
summary: Singtel is investing S$45 million over three years to train its 12,600 employees in Singapore to stay relevant in the digital economy. The program, named ACT, aims to accelerate learning, empower employees to create their own skill pathways, and transform their roles. The telco has partnered with the Union of Telecoms Employees of Singapore and the NTUC to implement the program, which includes a Company Training Committee to support future-ready workers. The initiative aims to help employees deepen their digital capabilities and meet the demands of the new economy.

site_title: Yahoo Japan to take over online fashion retailer Zozo
summary: Yahoo Japan Corp will acquire Japan's top online fashion retailer Zozo Inc for 400 billion yen (S$5.09 billion), breathing fresh life into the website. Zozo's billionaire founder Yusaku Maezawa will step down as CEO and sell most of his stake after the company's shares dropped by 60% in the past year. The deal offers Yahoo Japan a chance to lead Japan's online fashion space, where Amazon and Rakuten have struggled. Zozo's market value was 680 billion yen at the time of the deal.

images.alt_text: Yusaku Maezawa created the trendy, user-friendly website over a decade ago, at a time of scepticism about whether Japanese consumers would buy clothes online.

site_title: Trump administration plans to ban flavoured e-cigarettes
summary: The US government plans to ban the sale of most flavored e-cigarettes, excluding tobacco flavors, amid concerns over vaping-related illnesses and teenage vaping. The ban, announced by President Donald Trump, is part of a plan by the FDA to remove flavored e-cigarettes and nicotine pods from the market. The move comes after Michigan became the first state to prohibit the sale of flavored e-cigarettes and amid mounting pressure from lawmakers, public health officials, and parents. The ban is seen as a step towards reducing the vaping epidemic among teenagers, with the FDA citing flavors as a key factor in initiating youth to tobacco use.

site_title: China head, turnaround exec among candidates for Nissan CEO: sources
summary: Nissan's CEO is set to resign on September 16, and discussions are underway for a new leader. Two top candidates, Makoto Uchida and Jun Seki, are favored by different groups, with Uchida seen as Renault-friendly and Seki preferred by Nissan insiders. Temporary CEO Yasuhiro Yamauchi is also considered a possibility for the role. The new CEO will have significant implications for Nissan's future, including its alliance with Renault and its corporate governance.

site_title: Return Of Bon Iver
summary: American singer-songwriter Justin Vernon's indie folk band Bon Iver has released its fourth album, i,i, which marks another shift in the band's evolution. The album incorporates elements of electronic music, hip-hop, and samples, but with a more delicate and assured approach. The results are dense and layered cacophonies, with Vernon's voice taking center stage on tracks like "Hey, Ma" and "Faith." The album is available on Apple Music and Spotify, showcasing the band's continued experimentation and growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The High Court has approved the partial return of S$33 million to the contributories of Griffin Real Estate Investment Holdings (GREIH), an associate company of Sakae Holdings. Sakae will receive S$8.1 million in net proceeds. Meanwhile, Anchor Resources has cancelled its plans to issue S$10 million in unsecured redeemable equity-linked notes. Yorkshine Holdings reported a US$4.9 million profit for Q1, driven by increased revenue from its tin-plate manufacturing business, but remains highly leveraged with US$19.4 million in borrowings.

site_title: UBS to review businesses as recession test looms for industry
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, is reviewing certain sectors or geographies due to a looming recession, but will not cut costs yet. The bank's Asia-Pacific president, Edmund Koh, said the focus is on slowing hiring and right-sizing sluggish sectors. Despite a near-9% fall in operating income, UBS has seen a 10% increase in net new assets and remains ahead in the Asia-Pacific market, managing $411 billion in assets. Koh emphasized the importance of maintaining a balance between topline growth and invested assets, and will not increase leverage to bring in more clients, as this would be too expensive in private banking.

site_title: Riady scion takes action to revive Lippo flagship
summary: Indonesia's Lippo Group, a property developer, has turned a corner under the leadership of John Riady, the 34-year-old grandson of founder Mochtar Riady. A US$788 million rights issue in July, sale of assets, and debt recast have helped ease a cash squeeze and put the company on a path to recovery. Shares have surged 37% since John Riady took over, and the company aims to be one of the largest real-estate companies in Southeast Asia within two decades, capitalizing on Indonesia's growing demand for homes.

site_title: Apple prices TV Plus at US$5, but will people pay for it?
summary: Apple has priced its streaming service, Apple TV Plus, at $5 per month, with CEO Tim Cook touting the value as "crazy." The move aims to compete with other streaming services. However, it remains to be seen whether consumers will pay for the service, given the relatively low price point.

site_title: Political risks of Hong Kong exchange's US$39b LSE approach take toll on shares
summary: Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) shares fell 3.3% on Thursday due to concerns over the US$39 billion approach to take over the London Stock Exchange (LSE), citing political and regulatory risks. The deal aims to create a pan-Asian and European exchange powerhouse. Investors linked the proposed takeover to the Hong Kong government, sparking financial and political concerns.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks maintain a positive outlook due to strong capital buffers and good dividend visibility, despite potential NPL risks as the global financial cycle turns. Maybank Kim Eng recommends United Overseas Bank (Buy, S$25.77 target price), DBS Group Holdings (Hold, S$24.95 target price), and OCBC Bank (Hold, S$10.85 target price). Sembcorp Industries is also recommended (Buy, S$3.20 target price) due to its undervalued energy business and long-term growth prospects.

site_title: Belmont Road GCB takes 3rd stab at mortgagee sale
summary: A 3rd mortgagee sale auction for a 80 Belmont Road Good Class Bungalow (GCB) is set for Sept 18, with a new guide price of S$39 million (S$1,444 psf) after previous attempts failed. The 2-storey GCB has 27,000 sq ft of freehold land area and features a lift, playground, and swimming pool. The sale is part of a mortgagee sale after the owner defaulted on the mortgage, with Deutsche Bank as the mortgagee.

site_title: BAT stubs out 2,300 jobs as vaping casts cloud
summary: British American Tobacco (BAT) plans to cut 2,300 jobs globally by January as its new CEO seeks to drive revenue in e-cigarettes amid a crackdown on flavored vaping products. The company aims to deliver £5 billion in new category revenues by 2024, with over 20% of the job cuts being senior roles. The decision comes after US President Donald Trump's administration announced plans to ban flavored e-cigarettes. BAT shares rose 2.0% following the announcement.

site_title: Citigroup sees Middle East, Africa revenue growth this year even as oil weighs
summary: Citigroup expects Middle East and Africa revenue to grow this year, driven by its markets, cash management, and investment banking businesses, despite lower oil prices and political uncertainty. Revenue growth is expected to be a high single-digit rate, driven by a 10% compound annual growth rate in recent years. The bank's emerging markets cluster, led by CEO Atiq Rehman, is expected to account for 10% of global profit. Revenue growth may slow to a mid-single digit rate in 2020.

site_title: Tenders awarded for Tan Quee Lan St, Bernam St and one-north Gateway sites
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has awarded tenders for three Government Land Sales (GLS) sites in Singapore: Tan Quee Lan Street, Bernam Street, and one-north Gateway. The tenders closed on September 5, 2019, with the highest bidders securing the sites for 99-year lease terms. The awarded sites are valued at S$800.2 million for Tan Quee Lan Street, S$440.9 million for Bernam Street, and S$155.7 million for one-north Gateway, with the highest bids received by GuocoLand subsidiary, HY Realty, and TID Residential respectively.

site_title: Bag In Style
summary: Luxury French heritage brand Fauré Le Page has made its Southeast Asian debut with a new flagship store in Singapore's Takashimaya Shopping Centre.
