Edmund Tie attributes the trend to higher land prices and increased average unit size, with buyers preferring larger units.

site_title: Office provider The Executive Centre pauses sale amid HK protests
summary: Office provider The Executive Centre has paused its sale process amid concerns its large Hong Kong exposure will impact its valuation due to ongoing protests. The decision comes as violent protests in Hong Kong continue for a third month, affecting the city's economy. The company operates over 130 offices globally, with 30% of its earnings coming from Hong Kong. Its sale pause follows WeWork's recent valuation drop, and the company is seeking a valuation of over $750 million.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close down as London lags, banks shine
summary: European stocks closed down 0.3% on Monday as the FTSE 100 tumbled due to a stronger pound and selling in defensive sectors. Despite a surprise rise in German exports, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended a three-day run of gains. However, the banking index rose 2.2% to hit a one-month high, driven by Santander's share gain. Investors are awaiting the European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday, which is expected to introduce new monetary stimulus.

site_title: Goldman leaders court Saudis over Aramco IPO after 1MDB fallout
summary: Goldman Sachs is courting Saudi Arabian officials, led by CEO David Solomon, Richard Gnodde, and Dina Powell, to secure a stake in Aramco's initial public offering (IPO) following a missed opportunity in Abu Dhabi due to the 1MDB scandal. The move aims to capitalize on Saudi Arabia's large market and attract foreign investment. Goldman Sachs has spent months wooing top officials in Riyadh, seeking to capitalize on the kingdom's growing influence in the global economy.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc is tapping its upper echelons to navigate a notoriously complicated region where it has stumbled of late: the Middle East.

site_title: Patients die as Manila's jams delay ambulances
summary: Manila's severe traffic congestion is causing delays in ambulances, resulting in patient deaths. The city's outdated infrastructure and lack of enforcement of emergency lanes are major contributors. Experts warn that swift medical response is crucial for recovery, but delays can be fatal. The situation has sparked outrage on social media, with officials attributing the problem to irresponsible road users and bureaucratic hurdles.

site_title: Oil gets boost as new Saudi minister commits to output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Monday after Saudi Arabia's new energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, reaffirmed the country's commitment to limiting crude output to support prices. This move boosted Brent crude futures to $62.59 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures to $57.85 a barrel. Prince Abdulaziz stated that the Opec+ alliance, which includes Russia, will continue to cut oil production by 1.2 million barrels per day to achieve oil market balance.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose about 2 per cent on Monday after the new Saudi energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, confirmed expectations that he would stick with his country's policy of limiting crude output to support prices.

site_title: London-Singapore flights cancelled due to BA pilots' 48-hour strike
summary: British Airways pilots went on a 48-hour strike, cancelling most flights and affecting thousands of travelers. This is the first ever strike by BA pilots over a pay dispute. The British Airline Pilots Association (Balpa) initiated the industrial action, which started on Monday, September 9, 2019.

site_title: EU-Singapore FTA particularly helpful to SMEs: Iswaran
summary: EU and Singapore signed a free trade agreement (EUSFTA), expected to benefit small and medium enterprises (SMEs). Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran stated that the agreement will help SMEs navigate new markets and gain access to them. The agreement also promotes liberalization of trade and investment in services, offering improved market access and facilitated mobility for professionals. The European Services Forum aims to promote the agreement to corporate communities, particularly SMEs, to raise awareness of its benefits.

images.alt_text: Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran (centre) speaking at the official launch of the EU-Singapore Business Roundtable in Brussels, Sept 9, with BusinessEurope director general Markus Beyrer (left) and Singapore's Ambassador to Belgium Jaya Ratnam (right).

site_title: Why the insurance industry needs to level up for the digital age
summary: The insurance industry must adapt to a "digital first" experience, leveraging analytics, automation, and AI to meet the demands of the next generation of customers. Failure to do so risks becoming an "irrelevant relic of another age." Companies must prioritize digital transformation to remain competitive, but the article does not provide specific details on how to achieve this transformation.

site_title: Chinese auto giant invests in flying-taxi startup
summary: Chinese auto giant Geely has invested 50 million euros in flying-taxi startup Volocopter, giving it a 10% stake in the company. The investment will help Volocopter bring its VoloCity aircraft to commercial launch within the next three years. This move has sparked concerns about Chinese investments in EU firms, particularly in strategic sectors, and has unsettled German politicians and businesses. Despite this, Volocopter's founders remain the largest shareholders, alongside other major investors such as Mercedes-Benz and Intel.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust's (MCT) share price surged following its inclusion in the Straits Times Index, attracting heightened investor interest and liquidity. Analysts expect the acquisition of Mapletree Business City II (MBC II) to take place in FY2021, potentially elevating MCT to the fourth-largest S-Reit and positioning it closer to office REIT peers. However, risks include a slowdown in retail sales and a slower-than-expected office rent pick-up.

site_title: Standard Chartered on track to hit 2021 returns target
summary: Standard Chartered is on track to meet its 2021 return targets in the Asia-South Asia (ASA) region, driven by growth in corporate and institutional banking in Indonesia. The bank's operating profit in Indonesia rose 28% in the first half of 2021, largely due to growth in corporate and institutional banking. To boost returns, StanChart is focusing on capital-light businesses such as wealth management and deposits, and is exploring partnerships with e-commerce companies to expand its retail-banking segment. The bank aims to achieve a return on tangible equity (RoTE) of at least 10% by 2021.

site_title: Razer committing S$10m to boost Singapore gaming, e-sports
summary: Razer is committing S$10 million to boost the Singapore gaming and e-sports scene over the next 12 months. This is the largest financial commitment made by the gaming peripherals brand, supporting e-sports teams and investing in gaming companies. The funding will also go towards Team Singapore for the SEA Games, where e-sports will debut as a medalled sport for the first time.

site_title: Charting growth through choppy waters
summary: Transworld Group Singapore, a shipping and logistics company, continues to thrive despite turbulent global shipping times. Founded by Mahesh Sivaswamy in 1999, the company has grown to annual revenues of US$300 million, projecting US$350 million for 2019. Sivaswamy attributes the group's success to its regional focus, ability to seize opportunities, and strong team. The company operates seven business verticals, including ship owning, ship management, and logistics, all of which continue to thrive.

site_title: Euro remains subdued before key ECB meeting
summary: The euro remained subdued on Monday before the European Central Bank's (ECB) meeting, dropping to a five-day low against the dollar. Investors expect the ECB to introduce monetary stimulus, including a potential 20-bp rate cut, and possibly unconventional measures such as buying eurozone equities. Money markets are pricing in a 72% chance of a rate cut, with hedge funds adding short euro positions. The euro was steady against the dollar at $1.10335, while the dollar index was flat at 98.33.

site_title: StashAway launches Singapore-focused income portfolio
summary: StashAway, a robo-adviser service, has launched a Singapore-focused income portfolio, offering retail investors with at least S$10,000 the ability to invest in six Singapore-listed ETFs. The portfolio, which has a 11.05% year-to-date average total return, is customised to suit each investor's risk preferences and goals, with asset allocation managed by algorithms. The service charges an annual management fee of 0.2-0.8%. This launch follows StashAway's recent US$12 million funding round and comes as DBS also expands its robo-investment platform digiPortfolio to retail investors.

site_title: Strategies that add value to your businesses
summary: Several industries, including cyclical and technology-disrupted sectors, can benefit from specific strategies to add value. Companies like Transworld created a niche and ecosystem, while others co-create with customers to drive innovation. Heavy industry and capital-intensive sectors can adopt asset-light strategies, reducing debt and weathering downturns. Embracing digitalization, such as RFID capabilities, can also add value in industries like timber. By implementing these strategies, businesses in challenging sectors can increase resilience and competitiveness.

site_title: Boris Johnson likely to win fewer seats than Theresa May: ex-govt adviser
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is likely to win fewer seats than his predecessor Theresa May in an election, according to private polling for his office. A former government adviser stated that Mrs. May won 318 seats in 2017, while Mr. Johnson lost his majority after Conservative Party defections and the expulsion of lawmakers who rebelled over Brexit.

site_title: Energy companies catching up on gender diversity, but gaps remain
summary: A new report by S&P Global shows that the energy sector is making progress in increasing gender diversity, but gaps remain. Women now occupy less than one-fifth of senior leadership spots, with female board members and C-level positions at 15% and 13% respectively. The report notes that progress has accelerated in the past decade, but achieving 50-50 gender parity is unlikely until 2058 if current trends continue.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Entwine: Maybank women Eco-Weavers meet Southeast Asian artists
summary: The Maybank women Eco-Weavers met Southeast Asian artists on the Money FM podcast Entwine. The event aimed to promote sustainability and eco-friendly practices. The podcast featured discussions on mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste futures, and financial literacy for women. The Maybank women Eco-Weavers showcased their work, highlighting the importance of community engagement and environmental awareness. The event aimed to inspire positive change and promote a culture of sustainability in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Taxi operator Trans-cab revives IPO plan
summary: Singapore's second-largest taxi operator, Trans-cab, is reviving its plans for an initial public offering (IPO), seeking a valuation of up to S$200 million. The company aims to list on the Catalist board in the first quarter of next year, as the government prepares to license ride-hailing operators like Grab and Gojek. This move aims to bring safety-related rules in line with taxi operators, protecting commuters and drivers. Trans-cab seeks to stem the decline in the taxi business by expanding into car financing and leasing.

site_title: SPH records revaluation gain of £22.8m on UK accommodation portfolio
summary: SPH recorded a £22.8m (S$38.4m) revaluation gain on its UK student accommodation portfolio, a 6.7% increase. The portfolio, valued at £361.2m by Cushman & Wakefield, comprises 5,059 beds across 10 UK cities. SPH expects the UK student accommodation sector to remain strong, with up to £3.5 billion in investments this year. The company has expanded its operational expertise and marketing capabilities to capitalize on demand from Chinese students for UK higher education.

site_title: HK tourism plunges 40% in August, the most since SARS crisis
summary: Hong Kong's tourism industry has plummeted 40% in August, the largest decline since the 2003 SARS epidemic, due to ongoing protests that have impacted the city's international image as a safe destination. The tourism, retail, and hotel industries have been particularly hard hit, with occupancy rates of hotels in some districts falling over half and room rates decreasing 40-70%. The protests have also raised the prospect of a technical recession, with Hong Kong's economy contracting 0.4% in the second quarter.

site_title: Japan downgrades Q2 GDP as trade war hits business investment
summary: Japan's economy grew at a slower pace in the second quarter, with an annualized 1.3% expansion, down from the initial estimated 1.8% due to the US-China trade war's impact on business investment. Capital spending rose just 0.2%, lower than expected, and private consumption advanced 0.6%. The Bank of Japan is under pressure to deepen stimulus, with some analysts warning of a possible drop in domestic consumption after the sales tax hike next month, and a possible negative growth rate in the October-December quarter.

site_title: Stimulus, rate-cut hopes barely move STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) added 1.85 points or 0.06% to close at 3,146.33, as regional markets rose following China's stimulus measures and hopes for a US Federal Reserve rate cut. The US economy may be weakening, supporting rate cut expectations. Trading volume was lower than the daily average, with decliners outpacing advancers 192 to 166. The local banks were mixed, while real estate player UOL Group's shares rose after launching sales for a new project.

site_title: RCEP will be a gamechanger, says Balakrishnan, urging India to join
summary: Singaporean Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan urged India to join the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a free trade pact that could secure prosperity for its members. The deal, involving 10 Asean nations, China, Japan, South Korea, India, Australia, and New Zealand, aims to promote trade and economic integration. However, India has expressed reservations, citing concerns over unequal access to Chinese markets and a large trade deficit with China. The deal's geo-strategic objective is to counter protectionist and unilateral policies, but India's economic benefits must be prioritized.

site_title: Naspers' Amsterdam foray eases pain for South African fund managers
summary: Naspers, a dominant tech giant in South Africa, is listing its unit Prosus NV in Amsterdam, reducing its weighting in the Johannesburg stock market. Prosus will house Naspers' 31% stake in Tencent Holdings Ltd and other tech investments, valued at around $100 billion. This move will ease concerns for fund managers, as it will drop Naspers' weighting in the main local index from 21% to around 15% and in the Swix index from 25% to around 18%. The change will take effect on September 20.

site_title: WeWork plans to cut valuation to below US$20b
summary: WeWork plans to cut its valuation to below $20 billion, its second reduction in three days, amid concerns from investors about its prospects and business model. The company faces skepticism about its ability to make money quickly and withstand a global economic slowdown. Its planned initial public offering is also under pressure, with some investors pushing for a 2020 debut. JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs are meeting with investors to ease fears, but a roadshow to market the shares is in doubt. WeWork lost $1.9 billion last year with revenues of $1.8 billion.

site_title: Singapore, Russia sign 6 agreements to deepen cooperation in various sectors
summary: Singapore and Russia signed six agreements to deepen cooperation in various sectors, including digital development, innovation, and education. The agreements were inked at the 10th Session of the High-Level Russia-Singapore Inter-Governmental Commission (IGC) in Vladivostok, Russia. The agreements focus on technical education, research on clothing materials for healthy ageing, and collaboration in other areas. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Russian Deputy Prime Minister Maxim Akimov witnessed the signing of the agreements, reaffirming the growing ties between the two countries.

site_title: Innovation on the top of Beca's agenda
summary: Beca, a Singapore-based engineering consultancy, is prioritizing innovation with various initiatives, including a virtual reality (VR) technology for reviewing building designs before construction. The company aims to attract and elevate talent, stay competitive in the digital transformation role, and offer new services such as smart building consulting. Beca's managing director, Lee Ang Seng, emphasizes the need for innovation to address these challenges.

site_title: Singapore firms can tap EU expertise in urban sustainability
summary: Singapore firms can tap into European expertise in urban sustainability, particularly in areas like waste management and environmental technology, thanks to the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA). Keppel Seghers Belgium, a Singapore unit, has successfully collaborated with European firms, showcasing the potential for future partnerships. The agreement's alignment of standards and free movement of goods and services are expected to facilitate more Singapore companies entering the European market, with urban sustainability being a key area of focus.

site_title: Team Citi cut Car Times' lead to just two points
summary: Team Citi narrowed the gap to just two points with 111 points, retaining second spot in the The Business Times Corporate Golf League with one leg remaining. Led by Joey Chang's 38 points and Charles Tan's 37 points, the team trails overnight leaders Team Car Times, who scored 110 points. The final leg is set for September 20.

site_title: China data centres set to consume more power than Australia: report
summary: China's data centres are projected to consume more electricity than Australia by 2023, emitting 163 million tonnes of carbon emissions, nearly triple the 2018 figure of 99 million tonnes. Despite China's lead in renewable energy capacity, data centres rely heavily on coal, and the industry's massive carbon footprint highlights the need for more action to combat climate change. Boosting renewable energy intake from 23% to 30% could save the equivalent of 10 million round-trip transatlantic flights in carbon emissions.

site_title: SGReit goes shopping for Isetan's share of Wisma Atria
summary: SGReit, a Singapore-listed Reit, has issued a letter of intent to acquire Isetan Singapore's share of Wisma Atria, a prime leasehold property in Orchard Road, for more than fair value. This move comes after months of negotiations. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move by the manager of SGReit, part of the YTL Group controlled by Malaysian tycoon Francis Yeoh. The details of the deal are yet to be disclosed, but it is expected to be a significant move in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Nirvik Singh named new COO of Grey Group
summary: Nirvik Singh, chairman and CEO of Grey Group's Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa, has been appointed as the company's new Chief Operating Officer. He will lead the development of Grey's borderless integrated marketing model and identify acquisition targets. Singh, a 30-year veteran of the company, will continue to be based in Singapore. He praised the company's borderless strategy, which has seen success in leveraging resources and promoting collaboration across offices. This appointment aims to enhance Grey's best-in-class offering and build its future-facing digital practices.

images.alt_text: Mr Singh will continue to be based in Singapore

site_title: Nadal wins 4th US Open, and weeps uncontrollably
summary: Rafael Nadal won his 4th US Open title, defeating his opponent in a grueling match. After the win, Nadal became emotional, weeping uncontrollably as a video tribute played on the large screen. Fans in Arthur Ashe Stadium erupted in cheers, and the 7-time champion dropped his head into his hands. This victory marked a significant milestone in Nadal's illustrious tennis career.

site_title: The globalisation backlash
summary: The US-China trade war is expected to have severe consequences on the global economy and geopolitics, potentially leading to a disintegration of the existing global trading system. The conflict mirrors historical parallels of the 1930s, where the Great Depression hastened the collapse of pre-World War II globalisation. The US and China's push for protectionism and economic sovereignty may lead to a redefinition of the international economic system, with overt political considerations taking precedence over economics. The outcome is uncertain, but the potential risks to global stability are significant.

site_title: Trade war as impetus to broaden horizons
summary: Singapore businesses can capitalize on the growing Asean market due to the country's strategic location within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region. The rising trade tensions between the US and China may present an opportunity for SMEs to gain a competitive advantage. This is mainly due to three reasons: Singapore's proximity to key Asean markets, the country's strong economic ties with Asean nations, and the region's growing economic potential.

site_title: Scottish estate buyers want to plant trees as well as stalk deer
summary: Wealthy individuals and companies are investing in Scottish estates to balance their carbon portfolios and gain green credentials, with many opting for sustainable farming and forestry projects. Sales of Scottish estates have seen a rise in recent years, with 21 estates sold for £86 million last year, and a new breed of buyer is emerging, focusing on environmental sustainability. Estates are diversifying by investing in renewable energy production, such as hydroelectric power, and receiving subsidies for promoting green projects, with the Scottish government offering grants for establishing new woodlands.

site_title: Brexit means big changes for the European Union too
summary: The European Union is experiencing significant changes in response to Brexit, with key debates about the union's future taking center stage. The EU's re-balancing, external role, and positioning in a changing world will be crucial in determining its future and place in the world. The EU is reforming its defense policies, considering a European army, and re-evaluating its relationships with non-EU European countries. The choices of the US and Russia, particularly under President Trump and Vladimir Putin, will significantly influence the context of Brexit and the EU's broader place in the world.

site_title: Chinese food producers have world's richest valuations
summary: Chinese food and beverage stocks have reached the world's richest valuations, with six of the top 10 food and beverage stocks having the highest price-earnings ratios globally. The surge is driven by African swine fever and the trade war, with pork prices skyrocketing and demand for domestic consumer stocks increasing. However, strategist Shen Zhengyang warns that these valuations are unsustainable and may lead to a bubble. Despite this, Chinese food and beverage stocks have surged 68% this year, outperforming the Shanghai Composite Index and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index.

site_title: Private equity firm mulls options for Singapore's Canadian school
summary: A private equity firm, Southern Capital Group Pte, is exploring options for Canadian International School in Singapore, including a potential sale valued at at least US$500 million. The school, which educates 3,000 students from age two to 18, has been founded in 1990 and competes for applicants from expatriate and local families. This move comes as Singapore's economy cools, with Southern Capital joining private equity firm KKR & Co in looking for options for their Singapore-based assets. A sale would be a significant development for the school.

site_title: Britain at risk of losing leading edge in maritime services
summary: Britain's position as a top hub for maritime services is being eroded due to competition, loss of shipping finance business, and removal of tycoon-friendly tax breaks, a report states. The UK has dominated marine insurance, ship broking, and shipping finance for centuries, but its leading edge is at risk as Brexit approaches. This development deepens uncertainty for the UK's financial sector, which relies heavily on maritime services. The UK's maritime industry faces significant challenges, including increased competition from other global shipping centers.

site_title: Killiney Group leads S$1.7m seed funding in Hoow Foods
summary: Singaporean foodtech startup Hoow Foods has secured S$1.7 million in seed funding led by Killiney Group, with additional backing from Innovate360 and TRIVE Ventures. Founded by four engineers and scientists from the National University of Singapore, Hoow Foods reformulates common food products into healthier versions while retaining taste and texture. The funding will support expanding research and development capabilities and staff strength. The company aims to produce game-changing food products within unprecedented development speeds.

site_title: Nissan board announces CEO Saikawa stepping down
summary: Nissan's CEO Hiroto Saikawa is stepping down amid accusations of financial irregularities. The board of directors asked him to leave, following a report of him improperly adding 47 million yen to his compensation by altering bonus terms. Saikawa apologized for the payment, denying any wrongdoing. He will step down on September 16, with current COO Yasuhiro Yamauchi taking over as acting CEO.

site_title: An opportunity to fundamentally rethink public housing system
summary: Singapore's public housing system is under scrutiny, with the prospect of new HDB flats in the Greater Southern Waterfront region reigniting debate over fairness and merit. The current system, where HDB subsidises flat costs and allocation is based on luck rather than need, is seen as regressive and benefiting those with deeper pockets. Proposed solutions, such as increasing minimum occupation periods or imposing resale levies, are deemed flawed. Instead, a new system benchmarking flat prices based on buyer income level could provide more accessible and affordable housing. This change could also limit investment benefits and align with HDB's public housing mandate.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US charges Chinese professor in latest shot at Huawei
summary: US prosecutors have charged Chinese professor Bo Mao with wire fraud for allegedly taking technology from a California company to benefit Huawei, a move seen as another shot at the embattled telecommunications equipment maker. Mao, an associate professor at Xiamen University, entered into an agreement with a California tech company to obtain its circuit board, claiming it was for academic research. The case is related to Huawei and follows a previous civil case between Huawei and a US startup, CNEX Labs Inc. Mao pleaded not guilty to the charge and a hearing is scheduled for this week.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A consortium led by Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd has agreed to buy a stake in Vietnam's VCM Services and Trading Development Joint Stock Company for US$500 million. Vingroup will remain the controlling shareholder. Additionally, NTUC Enterprise has appointed Seah Kian Peng as group CEO, replacing Kee Teck Koon. In the tech sector, Magic Micro emerged as a substantial shareholder of Raffles Infrastructure Holdings with a 20.3% stake acquired at S$0.50 a share.

site_title: US House panel to consider formalising Trump impeachment probe
summary: The US House Judiciary Committee will consider a resolution to formalize its impeachment investigation into President Donald Trump this week. The five-page measure would allow for more aggressive questioning of witnesses and enable the White House to respond in writing to evidence. The panel has already rebranded its probe as an impeachment investigation, but has avoided a full House vote, which could be risky for Democratic freshmen. A more formal investigation could strengthen lawsuits seeking court orders to compel testimony from former White House Counsel Don McGahn.

site_title: The future of money is being built in Asia
summary: Asia is at the forefront of the future of money, with over $1.8 billion in cryptocurrency traded daily on Asian exchanges, accounting for nearly 60% of global adjusted daily-traded volume. The region is home to 15 of the 20 biggest cryptocurrency exchanges by traded volume, and Singapore is a hub for initial coin offerings (ICOs). Asia's critical infrastructure for cryptocurrencies, including mining facilities and specialized chips, is also based in the region. The region is leading the way in adopting blockchain-based fund-raising methods, with many countries recognizing cryptocurrencies in national regulations and establishing standards for the industry.

site_title: Mt Elizabeth serviced apartment block for sale
summary: A 22-storey serviced apartment block at No 2 Mount Elizabeth Link in Singapore is for sale with an indicative price of S$230 million. The 72-unit tower has a land area of 35,385 sq ft and a gross floor area of 104,375 sq ft, exceeding the plot ratio of 2.8 under the Master Plan 2014. Located in District 9, it is near the Orchard Road shopping belt and major schools, with options to redevelop or retain its existing serviced apartment use, capitalizing on demand from medical tourism and tourist/business travelers.

site_title: The ECB's deflation obsession
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing further stimulus measures to combat deflation, despite prices being stable across the developed world. However, low inflation rates in the eurozone are not a cause for concern, as nominal GDP growth remains high and debt burdens are decreasing. The ECB's definition of "price stability" as a year-on-year inflation rate of 2% is overly optimistic, as downward wage stickiness is unlikely to become a concern in the near future. The ECB's expansionary monetary policy stance may be unnecessary, and its hyper-vigilance about falling prices is misplaced.

site_title: 120 talents picked for ChildAid concert
summary: Over 120 talented children aged 6-19 have been selected to perform at the 15th ChildAid concert in Singapore on November 20-21, 2019. The concert, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, aims to raise funds for arts training programs and school support for underprivileged children. Since its inception in 2005, ChildAid has raised over S$18 million and assisted over 175,000 children, with notable supporters including UOB and Citi. The concert will feature a performance bootcamp and training sessions with Dick Lee Asia, with President Halimah Yacob as the guest of honor.

images.alt_text: Rehearsals and training begin for the 15th ChildAid concert, a charity concert organised by The Business Times and The Straits Times. From left to right: Rey Phua, 11; Gisele Chiam, 10; Steven Simopoulos, 12; and Sri Qaseh Nuraisyah binte Abdullah,12.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing tells Hong Kong leaders to 'have mercy'
summary: Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing, urged the government to "have mercy" in dealing with the city's unrest, calling it the worst crisis since World War II. Li, 91, made the remarks during an event at a Buddhist temple, expressing concern over the ongoing protests. Despite the government's recent decision to withdraw a bill allowing extraditions to the mainland, demonstrators still have several demands, including the right to elect a leader. Beijing has ruled out this demand, and Li's comments were seen as a call for reconciliation between the government and protesters.

site_title: Elliott takes US$3.2b stake in AT&T, seeks asset sales
summary: Elliott Management Corp has taken a $3.2 billion stake in AT&T, aiming to boost its share price by over 50% through asset sales and cost-cutting. The hedge fund proposes a four-part plan, including exiting non-strategic businesses, improving operational efficiency, and recommending new board members. The move comes after AT&T's shares underperformed the S&P 500 over the past decade, with Elliott citing a series of strategic setbacks, including failed acquisitions. AT&T shares surged 7.8% in early trading, reaching their highest level since 2018.

site_title: Lloyds Bank CEO says european banks are laggards on cost control
summary: Lloyds Bank CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio criticized European banks for their poor cost control, stating none have been leading in efficiency. Horta-Osorio advised European banks to create a cost advantage to improve their attractiveness to investors. This comes after Lloyds suspended its share buyback due to £21.8 billion costs related to mis-sold payment protection insurance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start week flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Monday marginally lower, with the Hang Seng Index declining 9.36 points to 26,681.40, as profit-taking and worries about long-running protests offset easing Chinese measures and expectations for a US interest rate cut.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended Monday marginally lower, with Chinese easing measures and expectations for another US interest rate cut offset by profit-taking and worries about long-running protests in the city.

site_title: UK parliament Speaker John Bercow announces intention to quit
summary: UK parliament Speaker John Bercow announces his intention to quit, effective October 31, as he seeks to prevent Britain's no-deal Brexit. Bercow has bent parliamentary rules to allow lawmakers to try to prevent a no-deal Brexit. If the government's attempt to call an election fails, he will step down on October 31.

site_title: Aussie mining towns lead in housing market recovery
summary: Australian mining towns are leading the recovery in the property market, with nine out of 10 suburbs experiencing strong growth in median prices. Notable gains were recorded in suburbs near major lead and steel smelters, such as Risdon Park South and Whyalla Norrie, with median house prices increasing by 71% and 42%, respectively. Record-low interest rates and easing bank-lending rules are driving demand. This trend contrasts with Australia's capital cities, where preliminary auction clearance rates were higher but lower volumes were involved.

site_title: Ascott Business Trust established, following proposed combination of Ascott Residence Trust and Ascendas Hospitality Trust
summary: Ascott Business Trust (Ascott BT) was established following the proposed combination of Ascott Residence Trust and Ascendas Hospitality Trust. The trust scheme of arrangement was approved by the Singapore Exchange, with 2.18 billion new Ascott Reit-BT stapled units to be issued to existing Ascott Reit unitholders. The deal, valued at S$1.0868 per stapled unit, includes S$0.0543 in cash and 0.7942 Ascott Reit-BT stapled units.

site_title: Is BreadTalk's S$80m offer for Food Junction worth the dough?
summary: BreadTalk has offered to buy Food Junction for S$80 million, sparking concerns over the deal's value. Food Junction's weak net profit in 2019 was due to high costs and unprofitable stalls, but its valuation is comparable to that of competitors Kimly and Koufu. Analysts have questioned the price tag, citing a lower valuation in 2013 and higher interest costs from drawing down debt. However, BreadTalk's management believes the deal will secure its position as the third-largest player in the market and provide benefits beyond the numbers, including Mr. Quek's nostalgia and the opportunity to revitalize Food Junction.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on hopes of monetary stimulus
summary: US stocks opened higher for the fourth straight session on Monday, driven by mixed global economic data and lifted expectations of monetary stimulus from the US Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.26%, the S&P 500 gained 0.33%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.34%. The rally comes amid uncertainty over the Fed's next move and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: US economy untouched by trade war: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated the US economy remains unscathed despite over a year of trade conflicts with China and Europe. Mnuchin brushed off concerns about slower employment growth, falling business investment, and a weakening manufacturing sector, calling the US the "bright spot" in the global economy. High-level trade negotiations are set to take place in Washington next month, with Mnuchin holding out hope for progress.

site_title: Nissan CEO told to go, COO appointed as interim chief
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa will step down next week amid accusations of financial irregularities, including improperly adding 47 million yen to his compensation. Current COO Yasuhiro Yamauchi will take over as acting CEO on September 16. The move follows Saikawa's admission of violating internal procedures and comes as the company faces a crisis after the arrest and ouster of former CEO Carlos Ghosn. The company's nomination committee is discussing potential successors, with over 10 candidates on the shortlist, including COO Yamauchi and Jun Seki, tasked with Nissan's performance recovery.

site_title: Singapore's GIC-led consortium to invest US$500m in Vingroup unit
summary: A consortium led by Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd has agreed to invest US$500 million in Vingroup JSC's VCM Services and Trading Development Joint Stock Company. Vingroup will remain the controlling shareholder. This deal comes as Vingroup expands its business, including launching smartphones, cars, and exploring artificial intelligence and aviation sectors. The investment is part of GIC's efforts to diversify its portfolio and capitalize on emerging markets.

site_title: Saudi Arabia flags plan to enrich uranium as US seeks nuclear pact
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to enrich uranium for its nuclear power program, a move that could complicate talks with the US on an atomic pact. The country aims to diversify its energy mix, but enrichment also raises military concerns. The US wants Saudi Arabia to sign a 123 agreement, which would govern the peaceful use of nuclear technology, but Saudi Arabia is hesitant to limit its uranium enrichment capabilities. The plan is expected to be tendered in 2020, with US, Russian, and other firms involved.

site_title: 'Recalcitrant' Hour Glass co-founder Jannie Chan starts 2-week jail term for contempt
summary: Businesswoman Jannie Chan, co-founder of luxury watch retailer The Hour Glass, began serving a two-week jail term for contempt of court on September 9, 2019. Chan, 74, lost her appeal against the sentence, imposed in 2017, after she repeatedly flouted a court order restraining her from defaming and harassing her ex-husband Henry Tay. Despite claiming depression and distress, the Court of Appeal dismissed her arguments, stating that she knew she was in contempt by sending out e-mails to Cabinet ministers and others.

site_title: South Korean electronics firm emerges as substantial shareholder of Raffles Infrastructure
summary: South Korean electronics firm Magic Micro has acquired a 20.3% stake in Raffles Infrastructure Holdings through an off-market deal at S$0.50 a share, totaling about S$6.9 million. Magic Micro, led by CEO Choi Jae Hoon, designs and manufactures electronic components. The acquisition marks a significant move by the South Korean company into the infrastructure sector.

site_title: Singapore shares barely move on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) barely moved on Monday, adding 1.85 points or 0.06% to close at 3,146.33. Regional peers, including Australia, China, and Japan, rose, while Hong Kong remained unchanged. This quiet start follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Johnson would do worse than predecessor in an election now
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson would win fewer seats than his predecessor Theresa May if an election were held now, according to private polling. Johnson is expected to secure around 295-300 seats, down from May's 318, with losses in Scotland, London, and southwest England. The UK parliament will be prorogued on Monday, with Johnson seeking to block MPs from blocking his Brexit strategy. The move has sparked criticism and opposition MPs have passed legislation forcing Johnson to seek a Brexit delay if he hasn't reached a deal with the EU by October.

site_title: US home purchase sentiment edges up in August - Fannie Mae
summary: US consumer sentiment about buying a home increased in August, reaching its highest level since the survey began, according to Fannie Mae. The index rose 0.1 percentage point to 93.8, driven by lower mortgage rates despite reduced optimism about home price appreciation and the timing to buy and sell. Mortgage rates have fallen to their lowest levels since 2016, offsetting global economic uncertainties. The survey also showed a decline in job worries, with 77% of consumers saying they are not worried about losing their job, and a narrowing gap between those expecting mortgage rates to rise or fall.

site_title: SPH records £22.8 million revaluation gain on UK student accommodation portfolio
summary: SPH recorded a £22.8 million (approximately S$38.4 million) revaluation gain on its UK student accommodation portfolio, valued at £338.4 million. The gain comes after a year of expansion into the sector, with 5,059 beds across 10 cities. A real estate consultancy valued the portfolio at £361.2 million, indicating strong investor interest in the UK student accommodation sector, with up to £3.5 billion of investments expected this year.

site_title: Raffles City Chongqing launched with 95 per cent committed occupancy
summary: Raffles City Chongqing, a 235,000 sq m shopping mall, opened in China with over 900,000 visitors during its launch weekend, exceeding initial expectations. The 95% occupied mall features 400 international and local brands, including 40% new-to-market brands. The 1.12 million sq m integrated development, spanning multiple skyscrapers, includes a serviced residence, hotel, office space, and luxury apartments. CapitaLand's president notes that the project marks a milestone in China's urbanization push, aiming to spearhead the renewal of the Chaotianmen riverfront district with world-class amenities.

site_title: Novartis CEO promises to speed data integrity disclosures
summary: Novartis CEO Vas Narasimhan has pledged to quickly disclose credible questions about data integrity in future applications, with a commitment to notify regulators within five business days. This comes after the company delayed informing the FDA about discrepancies in its gene therapy Zolgensma, which was approved in May. The FDA has raised questions about the timing of Novartis's disclosure, and the company could face possible civil or criminal penalties. Narasimhan said the company is changing its practices to avoid similar situations in the future.

site_title: Saudi reforms start to yield results, more work needed: IMF
summary: Saudi Arabia's economic reforms, including VAT and higher energy prices, have started to yield results, according to the International Monetary Fund. The reforms were implemented to diversify the economy after a crash in oil prices led to budget shortfalls for five years. The IMF stated that the outlook for the economy is positive, but more work is needed to plug a chronic budget deficit. These results come after Saudi Arabia imposed a range of measures to stabilize its economy and ensure long-term growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.56% to 21,318.42 on profit-taking amid eased Brexit and US-China trade war concerns. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index ended higher, with electronics and banks also benefiting. However, Nissan fell 0.22% amid reports of its CEO's resignation. The dollar traded at 106.89 yen in Asian markets, while other major stocks, including Sony and Canon, ended higher.

site_title: German export rise gives flagging economy glimmer of hope
summary: Germany's exports rose 0.7% in July, exceeding economists' expectations, and the trade surplus increased to 20.2 billion euros. This data suggests the economy may withstand the impact of tariff disputes and Brexit uncertainty. The stronger-than-expected figures cut against a recent run of weak data, alleviating concerns of a recession. The European Central Bank is expected to deploy fresh stimulus at its policy meeting.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore real estate market: The share of new condo units priced under S$1m fell to 24% in Q2, attributed to high land prices. Razer is set to invest S$10m in Singapore's gaming and e-sports sector. A serviced apartment block in Mt Elizabeth Link is up for sale with an indicative price of S$230m. Meanwhile, a foodtech startup Hoow Foods secured S$1.7m in seed funding. On the business front, FairPrice CEO Seah Kian Peng will head NTUC Enterprise. Singapore shares barely moved, with the STI adding 1.85 points to finish at 3,146.33.

site_title: Australia: Shares end marginally higher; NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed marginally higher, 0.01% higher at 6,648.00, driven by financial sector firms amidst global economic slowdown concerns. Investors await central bank stimulus. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.1% to 11,202.93, as manufacturing sales volumes fell 2.7% and dairy/meat exports declined 8.2%. Expectations of lower US and European interest rates boosted the Australian dollar.

site_title: Home Credit to test Hong Kong IPO market as protests convulse city
summary: Home Credit, a Prague-based consumer lender with a significant Chinese business, is set to launch its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong as early as this month, seeking to raise over $1 billion. The IPO comes as Hong Kong's markets have been weakened by pro-democracy protests and political turmoil, with the Hang Seng Index down 3% from its 12% gain earlier in the year. The IPO will be a key gauge of sentiment, with the last four months of the year typically seeing the busiest IPO activity in Hong Kong.

site_title: DP World's Topaz, P&O merger to complete by year end
summary: DP World's merger of P&O Maritime and Topaz Energy and Marine is expected to be completed by the end of 2019, according to Topaz's CEO René Kofod-Olsen. The acquisition, announced in July, will be a short process. DP World, a leading port operator, is acquiring Topaz, an oil services and marine logistics company.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise on China's liquidity boost
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.52% on Monday, marking the fourth consecutive gain, as investors anticipated China's policy easing measure to boost exports to Seoul's largest trade partner. Foreigners bought US$193.75 million worth of shares on the main board, contributing to the market's growth. The KOSPI has fallen 1.05% this year, but its recent gains may indicate a recovery.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hover near recent peaks on global stimulus hopes
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hovered near recent peaks on Monday due to global stimulus hopes, with the Aussie climbing 1.7% last week for its best weekly performance in nearly a year. The New Zealand dollar also jumped 1.9% last week, posting its best showing since late June. The surge in riskier assets was fueled by news that the US and China will resume trade talks in October and China's decision to add stimulus to its economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,149.10, up 0.15% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.15% to 3,149.10 on Monday, driven by gains in DISA Limited and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings. The gains were influenced by positive reactions to China's fresh stimulus measures and below-par US jobs data. Other Asian markets, such as Tokyo, Shanghai, and Seoul, also saw gains, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng index slipped.

site_title: Apple, Foxconn say they overly relied on temporary workers in China
summary: Apple and manufacturing partner Foxconn acknowledged employing too many temporary workers in China, exceeding 10% of the total workforce, as reported by China Labour Watch. The companies claimed they investigated and found the issue and are working to resolve it. They also stated that interns at a supplier facility had worked overtime voluntarily and were properly compensated. Foxconn confirmed the use of dispatch workers and overtime, but said it was voluntary and addressed. The issue comes amid trade tension between the US and China, which has threatened to disrupt the tech industry's supply chains.

site_title: Lloyds warns mis-selling could cost it an extra £1.8b
summary: Lloyds Banking Group is setting aside an additional £1.8 billion to settle mis-selling claims related to payment protection insurance (PPI) in Britain, following a surge in consumer enquiries ahead of the August 29 deadline. This increase will be reflected in its third-quarter results and is expected to dent its profitability. The bank has already paid out over £20 billion in PPI payouts, with analysts estimating the final bill could top £50 billion.

site_title: Heavy winds fan Australian bushfires, disrupt Sydney flights
summary: Strong winds fueled Australian bushfires, ravaging thousands of hectares of land and prompting fire service warnings. Five properties were destroyed and five damaged in New South Wales, while over 200 homes were saved. The heavy winds, driven by a low pressure system, also disrupted flights at Sydney Airport, with one runway shut for three hours. This early start to the bushfire season, exacerbated by two years of drought, has raised concerns about the country's fire conditions over the next few months.

site_title: Mt Elizabeth Link serviced apartment block up for sale with S$230m indicative price
summary: A 22-storey serviced apartment block in Singapore's District 9 has been put up for sale with an indicative price of S$230 million. The 72-unit building has a plot ratio of 2.95, exceeding the URA's Master Plan 2014. Located near Orchard Road and major schools, it offers a prime location for redevelopment or continued use as a luxury serviced apartment. The tender closes on October 23, with buyers able to redevelop the site or retain its existing use to capitalize on demand from medical tourism and tourists.

site_title: Hong Kong school students form human chain after weekend of protests
summary: Hundreds of Hong Kong school students formed human chains across the city in support of anti-government protesters, chanting slogans and displaying posters with the protesters' five demands. The students, many wearing masks, joined the human chain after a weekend of clashes between protesters and police. The three-month-old protests have evolved into a broader backlash against the government, with demands for democracy, freedom, and human rights. The students called on authorities to respond to the promises of freedom and human rights, amidst a tense mood in the city.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up on strong German data, stimulus hopes
summary: European stock markets opened higher, driven by a surprise rise in German exports and expectations of a European Central Bank stimulus. Germany's DAX index rose 0.2% and the pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.1%. The ECB is expected to cut its interest rate for the first time since 2016, which has boosted market sentiment. Oil stocks were the biggest gainers, tracking higher crude prices.

site_title: UK warns it lacks policy tools to avert 'painful' recession
summary: The UK faces a high likelihood of a recession due to a lack of policy tools to combat it, according to the Resolution Foundation. Interest-rate cuts and bond-buying could only provide a quarter of the support needed in an average recession, given the low starting point of the Bank of England's benchmark. The think tank warns that the UK is not recession-ready and that the next recession could be "unnecessarily painful." A no-deal Brexit is forecasted to trigger a recession lasting four quarters, with output contracting by 1.5% next year.

site_title: Japanese investors pile into US bonds in July, biggest buying in 3 years
summary: Japanese investors purchased a record 2.57 trillion yen (S$34.2 billion) of US bonds in July, the largest net buying in three years, amid a decline in European bond yields due to negative yields. This is part of their efforts to seek decent returns abroad as low domestic interest rates. The US dollar bonds offer the highest yield among developed countries, making them attractive to global investors, including Japanese investors.

site_title: Killiney Group leads S$1.7m seed funding in foodtech startup Hoow Foods
summary: Singapore-based foodtech startup Hoow Foods has secured S$1.7 million in seed funding led by Killiney Group, a local food and beverage heritage brand. Other backers include Innovate360, Singapore's first government-backed food incubator, and Trive Ventures. Hoow Foods, founded by four National University of Singapore engineers and scientists, aims to utilize the funding to drive growth and innovation in the foodtech industry.

site_title: Scottish estate buyers want to plant trees as well as stalk deer
summary: Wealthy individuals are investing in Scottish estates with a focus on planting trees and promoting sustainable practices to gain green credentials and cash. The Pait and West Monar Estate, valued at £2 million, aims to balance its carbon portfolio and secure subsidies for renewable energy and farming. This shift reflects the growing emphasis on climate change and the potential for landowners to generate income through sustainable practices.

site_title: Alibaba's new chief talks strategy and his fondness for NBA 'killer'
summary: Daniel Zhang, the new chairman of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, outlines his strategy for the company's next 20 years, focusing on developing more businesses and services to address customer pain points. Zhang, a 47-year-old former accountant, aims to build Alibaba as the digital infrastructure for its business partners. He also emphasizes the importance of innovation, starting new businesses, and killing existing ones to stay competitive. Zhang's fondness for the NBA, particularly Reggie Miller, is also revealed, with the player being referred to as a "killer."

site_title: Asian equity valuations fall to lowest in 3 months in August: Refinitiv data
summary: Asian equity valuations fell to their lowest in three months in August, according to Refinitiv data, due to a sharp selloff triggered by the escalation of the US-China trade war. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index declined 3.4% in August, reducing its forward 12-month price-to-earnings ratio to 12.78 times. This is the lowest level in three months, following a lacklustre earnings performance for Asian firms in the second quarter. Goldman Sachs revised its 12-month target for the MSCI Asia-Pacific ex-Japan to 515, citing downward revisions to earnings estimates.

site_title: Naspers Amsterdam foray eases pain for South African fund managers
summary: Naspers, a dominant South African tech giant, is listing its unit Prosus NV in Amsterdam, which will reduce its weighting in the Johannesburg stock market. The move is expected to ease concentration risk for fund managers, who currently cannot fully replicate Naspers' performance due to regulatory restrictions. Naspers' benchmark index weighting is expected to fall to around 18% from 25%, with Prosus valued at around $100 billion when it starts trading in Europe. The listing may also lead to reduced activity on the JSE, as foreigners may prefer to access Tencent Holdings Ltd through the Amsterdam bourse.

site_title: Asia: Markets start on upbeat note after China easing move
summary: Asian markets started Monday on a positive note after China's People's Bank of China announced fresh stimulus measures, slashing reserve requirements to its lowest level in 12 years, freeing up over $100 billion for the stuttering economy. The move boosted investor confidence and led to gains in markets such as Tokyo, Shanghai, Seoul, and Hong Kong. The US jobs data also reinforced expectations of a Fed interest rate cut this month, further fueling the rally.

site_title: Singapore flights cancelled due to 48-hour British Airways pilots strike
summary: British Airways pilots began a 48-hour strike on September 9, 2019, over a pay dispute, grounding most of the airline's flights. The strike has disrupted thousands of travelers' plans, with Singapore flights BA12 and BA16 canceled. The British Airline Pilots Association (Balpa) wants the airline to share more profits with its pilots. The strike is the first ever by BA pilots and has led to criticism of the airline's handling of communications with passengers. The UK Civil Aviation Authority is investigating and has reminded BA of its obligations to passengers.

images.alt_text: British Airways (BA) pilots began a 48-hour strike on Monday, grounding most of the airline's flights and disrupting thousands of travellers' plans in unprecedented industrial action over a pay dispute.

site_title: FairPrice CEO Seah Kian Peng to also head NTUC Enterprise
summary: NTUC FairPrice CEO Seah Kian Peng will lead the NTUC group of cooperatives, replacing Kee Teck Koon as group CEO of NTUC Enterprise, effective October 1. Seah currently holds the position of NTUC FairPrice CEO, marking a dual appointment. This move is aimed at strengthening the NTUC group's overall leadership and strategic direction.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open Monday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, extending last week's gains, after China unveiled fresh economic stimulus. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.20%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 0.81% and 0.84%, respectively. Weak US jobs data fueled speculation of further Federal Reserve interest rate cuts, contributing to the market's optimism.

site_title: China to issue subsidies for large pig farms: state planner
summary: China's state planner announced subsidies of up to 5 million yuan for large-scale pig farms in Beijing to support pig farming after a devastating disease ravaged its hog herd. The subsidies, to be issued by the end of 2020, aim to cover disease prevention, waste treatment, and environmental controls. This move comes as China's hog herd has shrunk by almost a third since a year ago, leading to rising pork prices and concerns for low-income consumers. The subsidies will also support the establishment of facilities to collect, treat, and reuse manure from pig and poultry farms.

site_title: Geely backs air taxi firm Volocopter in 50m euro funding round
summary: German air taxi startup Volocopter has raised 50 million euros in a funding round led by Geely Holding, a Chinese conglomerate. The investment will help Volocopter bring its electrically powered air taxis into service within three years. The company is developing air taxis that can take off and land vertically, aiming to reduce traffic congestion in mega-cities. Additionally, Volocopter and Geely are founding a joint venture to bring urban air mobility to the Chinese market.

site_title: Razer to give S$10m boost to Singapore gaming, e-sports over next 12 months
summary: Razer is committing S$10 million in funding to the Singapore gaming and e-sports scene over the next 12 months, the company's CEO Tan Min-Liang announced. The funding will support e-sports teams, gaming and e-sports companies in Singapore, and Team Singapore for the SEA Games. This is Razer's largest financial commitment to the local gaming industry, which has also recently partnered with Visa and signalled interest in applying for a digital banking licence. The funding aims to boost the growth of gaming and e-sports in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Razer, the official e-sports partner for the 30th SEA Games 2019, most recently organised a South-east Asia e-sports bootcamp in Singapore, gathering and training national e-sports teams from Singapore, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia.

site_title: British Airways faces first global pilots' strike
summary: British Airways faced its first global pilots' strike, with 4,300 pilots on strike due to a nine-month pay dispute. The airline proposed a 11.5% pay increase, but the pilots' union, BALPA, rejected it, citing lower salaries and significant debt for junior pilots. The strike could disrupt travel plans of nearly 300,000 people, with BA preparing to cancel 850 flights on Monday. The airline's parent company, IAG, reported a 10% jump in pre-tax profits, while BALPA claims the airline's cost-cutting measures have made it harder for pilots to do their jobs.

site_title: Hong Kong tourist arrivals plunge 40% in August, most since SARS crisis
summary: Hong Kong's tourism industry has suffered a significant decline, with tourist arrivals plummeting 40% in August from a year earlier, the largest year-on-year decrease since the 2003 SARS epidemic. The ongoing protests have impacted the city's international image, causing occupancy rates of hotels to fall over 50% and room rates to decrease 40-70%. The protests have also affected the economy, with retail sales dropping 11.4% in July and the overall economy contracting 0.4% in the second quarter.

site_title: China A-H share gap widens as trade war outcome divides traders
summary: China's A-share market is outperforming its H-share peers, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising over 20% this year, compared to a 3% gain by the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index in Hong Kong. Domestic investors are betting on state support ahead of China's 70th anniversary, while foreign traders are growing pessimistic due to a slowing global economy and a sliding yuan. The divergence is expected to continue as long as the trade war drags on, with analysts predicting a narrowing gap between the two markets as valuations in Hong Kong drop to historical lows.

site_title: China, Singapore iron ore futures slip on easing supply concerns
summary: China's iron ore imports rose 4.2% in August to a 19-month high, totaling 94.85 million tonnes, after supply concerns eased. Iron ore futures on the Dalian and Singapore exchanges fell, with the most-traded iron ore on Dalian dropping 3.6% to 621 yuan a tonne and the Singapore front-month October contract falling 1.1% to US$85.04 a tonne. This rebound in supply is expected to suppress bullishness from China's rate cut, but analysts remain cautious due to the uncertain trade outlook and China's industrial economy.

site_title: The rise of the ASEAN superapps
summary: ASEAN superapps, which integrate multiple services under one umbrella, are gaining popularity, with GoJek and Grab likely to become dominant players in the region. WeChat's success in China demonstrates the potential for high profits and market valuation. As the region's economy grows, superapps could generate higher revenues and profits, offering customers convenience and value. However, the rise of superapps also raises concerns about competition and market saturation.

images.alt_text: GoJek is already close to a Superapp in Indonesia and given its and Grab's regional ambitions, it is quite likely that both of them will aim to become Superapps in the ASEAN region. So, what are the prospects of becoming a dominant Superapp in ASEAN countries?

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.06% to 3,146.46
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.06% at the opening bell on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,146.46, driven by cautious optimism over government stimulus following weak economic data. Markets in the region, including Asia-Pacific shares, also edged up. Bank stocks held steady, while TEE International retreated 13% after appointing an external investigator into unauthorized transactions.

site_title: Australia gives banking licence to mobile startup firm Xinja
summary: Australia granted a new banking licence to online-only banking firm Xinja Bank, allowing it to compete against the country's "Four Big" lenders. The licence, granted by the financial regulator, enables Xinja to compete for deposits and use the funds to lend. Xinja plans to grow its product line and add lending products in 2020, offering a real alternative to incumbent banks. This move aims to address the lack of banking competition, detrimental to customers, and follows a trend of increasing banking licences granted to competitors in the country.

site_title: China will not tolerate attempts to separate Hong Kong from China: state media
summary: China reaffirmed its stance that Hong Kong is inseparable from China, warning that any attempts to separate the territory will be crushed. State media accused foreign forces of backing the protests, which began over a contentious extradition bill, and urged demonstrators to stop challenging the central government. Despite Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam's recent concessions to end the protests, China remains firm in its stance, emphasizing the rule of law and warning of severe consequences for secessionism.

site_title: Bank of England's Brazier says central bank has prepared lenders for any Brexit shock: The Times
summary: The Bank of England's executive director for financial stability, Alex Brazier, stated that the central bank has prepared lenders for any shock from Britain's departure from the European Union. Brazier expressed confidence that the financial system will not collapse after Brexit, citing the central bank's preparedness. The BoE's current governor, Mark Carney, is set to stand down at the end of January 2020, and his successor will be formally chosen by the finance minister.

site_title: Twitter-owned mobile monetisation platform MoPub hires Asia-Pacific MD
summary: Twitter-owned MoPub hires Dushyant Sapre as managing director for the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, focusing on Japan, South Korea, and China. Sapre, formerly managing director at Criteo, will develop and implement a regional growth strategy, establishing partnerships with publishers, app developers, and media companies. The APAC region is expected to experience explosive growth due to its mobile-first economies, with MoPub anticipating it will become the number one region for app downloads, advertising spend, and consumer spend over the next three years.

site_title: Share of new condo units priced under S$1m falls to 24% of developer sales in Q2: report
summary: Singapore's new condo unit prices trended higher in Q2, with 24% of units priced under S$1 million, down from 37% in Q1. The proportion of units priced above S$3 million rose to 5%, from 3%. Sales volume increased 7.4% year-over-year to 3,966 units, with 2,246 units sold in Q2. Foreigner buyers accounted for 6% of sales, while Singapore citizens opted for less expensive properties. The market is expected to remain "cautiously optimistic" in the second half of 2019, with prices largely expected to remain stable.

site_title: UK's Johnson prepares plan to legally stop Brexit extension: The Telegraph
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has prepared plans to legally stop any Brexit extension, according to a report by The Telegraph. Johnson's advisers met to counter attempts to enforce a three-month Brexit extension if no new deal is agreed. The plan involves sending a letter with the Brexit extension request stating that the government does not want any delay after October 31.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday for public holiday
summary: Malaysian financial markets closed on Monday for a public holiday, resuming trading on September 10. This comes after a series of articles discussing global market trends, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, the extension of a stocks rally despite US trade threats, and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Air China has no plans to take over Cathay Pacific: media report
summary: Air China has no plans to take over Cathay Pacific Airways, according to Air China non-executive director Stanley Hui. Despite being Cathay's second-largest shareholder, Air China sees any Beijing-led ownership changes as sending a wrong signal to foreign investors. Cathay chairman John Slosar is set to step down in November, amid mounting regulatory scrutiny and CEO Rupert Hogg's departure. Analysts had suggested it was logical for Air China to take over Cathay, but Hui disagrees, citing the importance of maintaining Cathay's independence.

site_title: Chinese food producers have world's richest valuations
summary: Chinese food and beverage stocks have seen a significant surge in valuations, with six of the top 10 stocks globally boasting price-earnings ratios of over 600 times. This is largely due to African swine fever and the trade war, driving demand for domestic consumer stocks. However, experts warn that these valuations may be unsustainable, citing China's slowing economy and defying the benchmark index. Chinese companies Luoniushan, Muyuan, and Hunan New Wellful have seen the highest valuations, with Luoniushan's valuation reaching 1,900 times its earnings.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher on hopes of stimulus boost; New Zealand drops
summary: Australian shares rose 0.12% to 6,655.50, driven by gains in financials and expectations of a potential stimulus boost from central banks, including the Reserve Bank of Australia. The US Fed's promise of future rate cuts and the European Central Bank's expected interest rate cut on Thursday also boosted market confidence. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 0.3% amid a cautious stance from investors.

site_title: 'No illegal immigrants allowed to stay' in India: govt
summary: India's home affairs minister stated that his government will not allow any illegal immigrants to stay, amid controversy over a citizenship register in Assam that excluded nearly two million people. The register, published on August 30, sparked outcry from local BJP leaders, who felt it was a cover for expelling Muslims. The government's stance aims to address concerns about the register's impact on the voting power of excluded groups.

site_title: Digitalising the insurance industry
summary: CXA Group, an insurtech startup, aims to modernize the insurance industry by digitizing claims and providing a self-service platform for employers to offer health, wealth, and wellness benefits to their employees. Founded by CEO Rosaline Chow Koo, the company has raised US$58 million in funding and projects to double its revenue this year. Chow Koo predicts the startup will turn profitable by late 2020 and become a unicorn, valued at US$1 billion or more, with plans to expand to Asia, Europe, and Canada.

site_title: Oil producers committed to balancing market, says UAE energy minister
summary: UAE Energy Minister Suhail al-Mazrouei stated that Opec and non-Opec oil producers are committed to achieving oil market balance, despite current prices. He emphasized the need to monitor oil inventories rather than production cuts, citing politics and global trade tensions as the main factors affecting the market. The joint ministerial monitoring committee will meet on Thursday in Abu Dhabi to discuss potential oil production cuts, with the UAE supporting any consensus decision.

site_title: China's Internet data power usage to surge through 2023: study
summary: China's internet data sector is expected to surge in power usage by two-thirds by 2023, according to a study by Greenpeace and North China Electric Power University. The sector's power consumption is projected to reach 267 terawatt-hours, with CO2 emissions from coal-fired power plants increasing. To mitigate this, the study suggests increasing renewable energy sources to 30% of the sector's power intake, potentially reducing CO2 emissions by 16 million tonnes. The sector's growth is expected to be driven by the creation of decentralized "smart grid" systems, but it poses a challenge to China's efforts to curb smog and carbon emissions.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index slips at open
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened lower on Monday, slipping 0.04% or 8.80 points to 21,190.77, amid weaker-than-expected US jobs data. The broader Topix index rose 0.11% or 1.66 points to 1,538.76. Despite this, Asian markets continue to rally, with Singapore stocks posting a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data, and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Jack Ma exits as China tech 2.0 unease sets in
summary: Chinese tech mogul Jack Ma will step down as Alibaba chairman on Tuesday, marking a new era for the company. Ma, 55, will remain on the board until 2020, handing over to successor Daniel Zhang. Despite Beijing's tightening grip on fellow tech executives, Ma has maintained a relatively high profile and Alibaba's annual revenue is forecast to grow 36% to $72 billion. Ma's departure comes as the company diversifies into cloud computing, offline retail, and other areas, and he has taken steps to improve governance and transparency.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma's exit ushers in a nervous new era for Chinese tech. The charismatic co-founder of the US$460 billion-plus Alibaba will step down from his chairman role when he turns 55 on Tuesday. His exit comes as Beijing tightens its grip on fellow bosses like Tencent's Pony Ma, who must also grapple with a slowing economy.

site_title: Bugatti's Chiron supercar is the main course at French dinner
summary: Bugatti's Chiron supercar sold almost all of its limited-edition road models at a French dinner, with CEO Stephan Winkelmann announcing plans to produce 30 cars. The Chiron Super Sport 300+ costs 3.5 million euros and has a top speed of 304 mph. Winkelmann expressed skepticism about producing an electric version of the Chiron, citing the need for internal combustion engines. He also discussed the possibility of uniting VW's luxury brands under one umbrella, but declined to comment on a potential public stock offering for Bugatti.

site_title: WeWork considers dropping valuation below US$20b: Dow Jones
summary: WeWork is considering a valuation for its initial public offering (IPO) below $20 billion, citing concerns from investors about the company's business prospects. The office-sharing company had previously been valued at $47 billion, but is now considering a range of $20 billion to $30 billion. WeWork's IPO plans have been delayed, with some investors pushing to postpone the listing. The company's access to a $6 billion credit facility is contingent on successfully raising $3 billion in a stock listing.

site_title: Clashes after peaceful crowd takes Hong Kong message to US consulate
summary: Pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong held a massive march to the US consulate, calling for international pressure on Beijing to address their demands for greater democracy, police accountability, and an amnesty for arrested protesters. The peaceful rally turned violent when hardcore protesters clashed with riot police, leading to arrests and injuries. The protests, which have gripped the territory for 14 weeks, have raised concerns about China's increasing authoritarianism and the city's unique freedoms under a 50-year deal with Britain.

images.alt_text: Pro-democracy activists jammed Hong Kong streets in a march to the United States consulate on Sunday in a bid to ramp up international pressure on Beijing, but hardcore protesters later clashed with riot police across the city's core.

site_title: Mugabe's family pushes back against government burial plan
summary: Robert Mugabe's family is pushing back against the Zimbabwe government's plan to bury him at the National Heroes Acre monument, instead insisting on a burial in his home village of Kutama. The family has agreed to a state funeral led by the government, but refuses to accept the burial site, sparking a dispute between the two parties. The government had initially planned to hold a state funeral and burial at National Heroes Acre, but Mugabe's family is seeking to rebuke his successor, President Emmerson Mnangagwa, and the ruling ZANU-PF party.

site_title: Even as a rival says he is 'declining,' Biden keeps poll lead
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden remains in the lead among Democratic presidential aspirants, holding 29% of the vote, according to a Washington Post/ABC News poll. Despite recent criticism from rival Ohio Congressman Tim Ryan, who said Biden is "declining," Biden's lead has remained relatively steady. Biden's age, 76, and concerns about his mental clarity have been raised by his rivals, but many voters, including some younger candidates, have avoided direct criticism. A new Republican challenger, former South Carolina Governor Mark Sanford, has announced his candidacy against President Donald Trump.

site_title: Saudi Aramco likely to give IPO roles to Citi, Goldman, HSBC and Samba: source
summary: Saudi Aramco is likely to appoint Citi, Goldman Sachs, HSBC, and Samba Financial Bank as advisers for its planned initial public offering (IPO), in addition to Morgan Stanley and JP Morgan Chase & Co. The IPO, which could be the world's biggest, aims to sell up to 5% of shares by 2020-2021 to attract foreign investment and diversify away from oil. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's economic transformation drive. The appointment is expected to be made in the coming days.

site_title: Stocks to watch: TEE International, Thomson Medical, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, Tiong Seng
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments on Monday that may affect trading of their shares. TEE International appointed an external investigator to look into unauthorized transactions totaling S$6.55 million. Thomson Medical Group's executive director and CEO Roy Quek is stepping down to pursue other interests. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit agreed to acquire an office complex in Dallas for US$101.5 million. Tiong Seng Holdings secured a S$287 million contract to build an industrial building. China Jinjiang Environment's outlook was revised from negative to positive by S&P Global Ratings. Pharmesis International called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Japan Q2 GDP revised down to 1.3% annualised growth
