summary: Japan's economy grew at a slower pace than initially estimated in the second quarter, with annualized GDP growth revised down to 1.3% from 1.8%. The US-China trade war and global economic slowdown have prompted business spending to slow, increasing pressure on the Bank of Japan to deepen stimulus. The central bank is considering lowering interest rates further into negative territory to prevent the yen from spiking. Despite this, growth is expected to hold up in the current quarter due to consumer front-loading purchases ahead of a sales tax hike, but the outlook remains clouded.

site_title: Manhattan's tallest condo joins swamped luxury market
summary: The Central Park Tower, Manhattan's tallest condo, has joined the luxury market with 179 ultra-luxury apartments valued at over $4 billion. Despite being the most expensive condo project in the US, sales have been slow, with a 91% decline in median price of pending purchases compared to the previous year. The building's prices are 15% lower per square foot compared to a competitor, and Gary Barnett, president of Extell Development, notes that there is more competition in the market, leading to a slowdown in sales.

site_title: Mexico frees up some spending in budget, but discipline trumps stimulus
summary: Mexico's government has released a 2020 budget proposal with a slightly loosened primary surplus target of 0.7% of gross domestic product, a decrease from earlier targets. The budget aims to boost spending on social welfare programs, security, and state-run oil company Pemex, while maintaining fiscal discipline. President Lopez Obrador's administration is balancing welfare promises with the stagnant economy, avoiding new taxes or fuel price hikes.

site_title: Scrapping Afghan summit, Trump makes US even less predictable
summary: US President Donald Trump abruptly canceled secret talks with the Taliban, citing the group's killing of a US soldier in a Kabul bombing. The talks, scheduled for Camp David, aimed to discuss a US troop withdrawal. Critics say Trump's unpredictability weakens US credibility and undermines efforts to advance peace deals in Afghanistan and with North Korea and Iran. Trump's approach has been described as "the summit of the vanities" and "unpredictable and erratic," creating incentives for other countries to discount US words and actions.

site_title: Strong typhoon winds lash Tokyo area, causing transport chaos
summary: A strong typhoon, Typhoon Faxai, made landfall just east of Tokyo, bringing record-breaking winds, stinging rain, and causing transport chaos. Over 130 flights were cancelled, and scores of train lines were closed, affecting millions in the Tokyo area. The storm brought wind gusts of 207 km/h, with some rivers close to overflowing, and caused minor landslides and power outages. One serious injury was reported, and authorities warned of the danger of heatstroke due to unseasonably hot temperatures. The storm has since headed out to sea, but heavy rains are expected to continue.

site_title: World's worst bad-loan mess set to worsen
summary: India's banking system is set to worsen its bad-loan mess due to a prolonged shadow-banking crisis and hurdles in bankruptcy rules. The nation's bad debt ratio is the highest among major economies at 9.6%, with over 2.4% of total loans under stress. India's efforts to revive economic growth are being undermined by the failure to slash stressed assets, with only six of 12 delinquent borrowers resolved so far. Italian banks have made significant progress in cleaning up their balance sheets, halving their toxic debt from a peak of 341 billion euros in 2015.

site_title: Powerful typhoon Faxai in direct hit on Tokyo
summary: A powerful typhoon, Faxai, made landfall in Tokyo's Chiba region, packing winds of up to 216 km/h, causing widespread blackouts, transport disruptions, and damage. Over 390,000 people were evacuated, with nearly 290,000 households losing power and at least 10 houses damaged. The typhoon is expected to pass through the region overnight, affecting the Monday morning commute and Rugby World Cup preparations. No immediate reports of serious injuries or significant damage were reported, but eight surfers were rescued after being swept out to sea.

site_title: San Francisco makes US$2.5b bid for PG&E's electric system
summary: San Francisco has offered a US$2.5 billion bid to buy PG&E Corp's power lines and electrical system infrastructure serving the city. PG&E, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January, is expected to file a reorganization plan addressing its estimated US$30 billion in liabilities from California wildfires. The city aims to provide safe, clean, affordable, and reliable energy to its citizens, while PG&E continues to serve the area.

site_title: Smooth succession: Jack Ma eases out of a thriving Alibaba
summary: Jack Ma steps down as chairman of Alibaba on his 55th birthday, marking the end of an era for the online retail behemoth. Despite his departure, Alibaba is expected to continue thriving due to its culture of innovation. Ma, who built Alibaba from a start-up into a global giant, leaves behind a legacy of disrupting traditional industries and fostering entrepreneurship in China. His successor will build on the foundation he established, ensuring Alibaba's continued success in the e-commerce and technology sectors.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore HR startup StaffAny raises S$1 million in seed funding
summary: Singapore HR startup StaffAny has raised S$1 million in seed funding. Co-founded by four friends in 2018, StaffAny is a workforce management application connecting HR and operations to better manage hourly workers. The funding, received from unknown investors, will be used to enhance the platform and expand its reach. StaffAny aims to change the workforce landscape by providing a more efficient and effective way to manage hourly workers, with Co-Founders Eugene Ng and Janson Seah planning to use the funding to drive growth and innovation.

site_title: Ferrari to lift lid on new F8 Spider to maintain fast track growth
summary: Ferrari is set to unveil its new F8 Spider on Monday, aiming to sustain its core earnings and share price growth through an aggressive model rollout. The F8 Spider boasts a 720-hp, 3.9L engine and a retractable hard top, positioning itself as sportier than the 488 Spider it replaces. The company seeks to maintain its fast-track growth, less extreme than the 488 Pista Spider but more sporty than its predecessor.

images.alt_text: Ferrari will reveal its latest sports car on Monday as the Italian premium automaker pursues an aggressive roll-out of new models to sustain its turbo-charged core earnings and share price growth.

site_title: Will ECB, Fed and Trump's tweets sap market optimism?
summary: Stocks rose last week due to optimism over central-bank action and a US-China trade stalemate. However, gains may be tempered by the European Central Bank meeting, Fed officials' speeches, or US President Trump's tweets. The US and China's resumption of trade negotiations in October has raised hopes, but observers are skeptical about bridging the gap on divisive issues like cyber espionage charges and tariffs. Market optimism may be short-lived as concerns over the global economy, including China's slowing GDP growth, continue to weigh on investors.

site_title: Galleon's Rajaratnam gets early release from prison
summary: Rajaratnam, the mastermind of a large hedge-fund insider-trading ring, was released from prison after serving 11 years, nearly two years early. He was granted early release under the First Step Act, which allows federal inmates over 60 or with terminal illnesses to serve the end of their sentences at home. Rajaratnam, 62, is now living with his family in Manhattan and is mostly confined to his apartment.

site_title: China's August exports shrink unexpectedly
summary: China's exports unexpectedly fell 1% in August, the largest decline since June, as US shipments slowed sharply amid escalating trade tensions. The decline was driven by a 16% year-on-year drop in exports to the US, with imports also shrinking 5.6% on-year. Beijing is expected to announce more support measures to avert a sharper economic slowdown, with the central bank cutting banks' reserve requirements for a seventh time since 2018. The decline highlights the need for stimulus as the Sino-US trade war escalates, with more US tariff measures set to take effect in October and December.

site_title: Grounding the 737 Max eases turbulence for airlines
summary: The grounding of Boeing's 737 Max has eased turbulence for airlines, as the aircraft constitutes about a third of the global passenger airline fleet and accounts for 80% of global departures. The grounding has resulted in a 387-aircraft reduction in service, which could have pushed load factors down by about a percentage point if deliveries had continued as planned. However, the reduction in seat supply due to the grounding has led to record seasonal highs in industry-wide load factors, with the industry riding out a fall in ticket prices.

site_title: Iran says it could release UK-flagged tanker within days
summary: Iran hinted it could release the UK-flagged oil tanker Stena Impero within days, amid rising tensions with the US and Britain. The tanker was seized in July and has been held in sensitive Gulf waters. Foreign ministry spokesman Abbas Mousavi said the "necessary steps" to set the ship free are underway, without providing further details. This move comes after Iran released a tanker seized by Britain in August after receiving written assurances. The Stena Impero is loaded with 2.1 million barrels of oil, which has been sold, but its destination remains unclear.

site_title: UK rail industry is reaching key political junction
summary: The UK rail industry is at a critical juncture, with full state-control possible amid high fares, delays, and costly investments. A passenger-focused review, led by Keith Williams, is set to deliver its findings by the end of the year, which could lead to renationalization. The industry is also facing significant challenges with the High Speed 2 (HS2) project, which has seen soaring build costs and massive delays. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's party is likely to capitalize on the issues, with full nationalization being a potential vote winner.

site_title: More than 90% of 300 Avenue South Residence units launched on first day sold
summary: More than 90% of the 300 units launched at Avenue South Residence in Singapore were sold on the first day of sales. The majority of buyers were Singaporeans, with one-bedroom units starting from S$858,000 and two-bedroom units from S$1.15 million. The project, developed by UOL Group, features nearly 10,000 sq ft of commercial facilities and is expected to be launched overseas due to strong foreign interest. Units in the Peak Collection, which offer unblocked city views, are selling for over S$2,250 per square foot.

site_title: China's August copper imports, aluminium exports fall
summary: China's copper imports fell 3.8% in August to 404,000 tonnes, down from 420,000 tonnes in July and 3.8% year-over-year. The decline is concerning as it raises demand for copper despite high prices. Meanwhile, China's aluminium exports dropped 4.3% in August to 466,000 tonnes, the lowest since February, due to production outages and a weaker yuan. This slowdown in key sectors raises concerns over China's economic growth and demand for metals.

site_title: Boards need to put people first
summary: Boards of directors are increasingly expected to prioritize human capital management, recognizing its crucial role in attracting and retaining key talent. This includes setting tone at the top, addressing corporate culture, and overseeing succession planning, talent management, and organizational development. Boards should focus on four key constituents: senior executives, the entire company, society, and the board itself. Effective human capital management can drive productivity enhancements, sustainable growth, and profitability, making it a critical aspect of a company's overall strategy.

site_title: EC World Reit bullish on e-commerce
summary: EC World Reit remains bullish on e-commerce in China, citing ample growth potential despite the country's economic slowdown. Only 20% of retail transactions in China were online last year, providing room for expansion. The Reit has a portfolio focused on e-commerce warehouses, with 50% of its assets now allocated to this sector. The company's CEO expects growth to continue, driven by key sales events like JD Day and Singles' Day. EC World Reit plans to expand its portfolio in China and South-east Asia, particularly in Vietnam and Indonesia.

site_title: A win-win option for all
summary: Businesses prioritize resolving commercial disputes quickly, efficiently, and with minimal damage to their reputation. The Singapore Convention on Mediation aims to provide a framework for cross-border enforcement of mediated settlement agreements, making mediation a more attractive option. By offering certainty of enforcement, mediation can lead to more commercially driven outcomes, reducing the need for costly and time-consuming court battles. The convention's ratification by 46 countries, including major economies like the US, India, and China, is expected to elevate Singapore's stature as a dispute resolution hub, encouraging businesses to opt for mediation over litigation.

site_title: Silicon Valley big names want to create a settlement on the moon
summary: A non-profit organization called the Open Lunar Foundation, based in San Francisco, aims to create a collaborative lunar settlement. The group, comprising tech executives and engineers with ties to NASA, seeks to establish a peaceful and cooperative presence on the moon. With a goal of developing a permanent, economically self-sustaining presence, Open Lunar plans to raise funds and share data and hardware designs with international partners. The organization, led by director Chelsea Robinson, hopes to set precedents for a harmonious moon settlement and accelerate exploration and settlement through open-source technology.

site_title: The world's oil glut is much worse than it looks
summary: A meeting of Opec+ ministers will take place in Abu Dhabi, providing guidance on its output-cutting strategy. Despite the group's efforts, oil prices remain low due to a massive oil glut. Opec+ aims to reduce excess stockpiles, but the original target of returning to a five-year average level was never sufficient. The group is considering a new target based on a 2010-2014 average, and may need to consider deeper cuts to manage the market's excess inventory.

site_title: Saudi prince must pay Trump Organization US$1.8m in rent
summary: US court rules that Saudi Prince Faisal bin Abdul Majeed al-Saud must pay Trump Organization $1.8 million in back rent for a luxury Manhattan apartment he leased in 2013 but stopped paying in 2017. The prince had agreed to extend the lease and pay rent of over $115,000 per month, but stopped paying after June 2019. The court denied the Trump Organization's request to throw out the prince's claims, allowing the case to proceed to determine if the landlord is owed more than $1.9 million in rent.

site_title: Students in West outsource homework to writers abroad
summary: Students in Kenya and other developing countries are outsourcing homework to writers abroad through websites such as Ace-MyHomework and EssayShark, generating significant income for writers. The industry, known as "contract cheating," has grown in recent years as websites have become more sophisticated, with over 50,000 members in a Facebook group for academic writers in Kenya. Experts warn that this practice undermines academic integrity and could lead to diploma mills, but it remains largely unregulated and unpunished, with some websites even claiming to provide "research and reference purposes only."

site_title: 'IT Chapter Two' scares up US$91m to top North America box office
summary: "IT Chapter Two" topped the North American box office with a US$91 million opening weekend, falling short of the original "It" film's US$123 million debut in 2017. The film, starring Jessica Chastain and James McAvoy, marks the second-horror film to reach the top spot, following the original "It." The two films now rank as the top two horror openings ever.

site_title: MIT Media Lab director quits after outcry over Epstein ties
summary: MIT Media Lab director Joichi Ito resigned after an outcry over his financial ties with Jeffrey Epstein, who made significant donations to the lab. Ito admitted taking $525,000 from Epstein for the lab and $1.2 million for his personal investment funds. The lab's efforts to conceal its relationship with Epstein were exposed in a New Yorker article, eroding Ito's support among lab members. Ito's resignation came after an internal review was initiated following his online apology, and he also stepped down from his position on The New York Times Co. board.

images.alt_text: Mr Ito, who took over the Media Lab in 2011, had strong support in the lab, where he had helped raise over US$50m in donations over the years. But the Epstein revelations eroded his support.

site_title: Stripped-back auto show mirrors gloom in German car industry
summary: The International Auto Show in Frankfurt is facing a gloomy atmosphere, with major foreign carmakers, including Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi, Toyota, and General Motors, canceling their appearances. German manufacturers are struggling to meet EU carbon emissions limits, with Volkswagen and Audi failing to impress with their electric models. Climate demonstrators will take to the streets, calling for a "transport revolution," amid a backdrop of a diesel emissions scandal and a changing German politics landscape. Chancellor Merkel's government is set to unveil a new climate strategy ahead of a UN summit.

site_title: Speculators boost US dollar net longs for 1st time in 5 weeks
summary: US dollar speculators boosted net long bets for the first time in 5 weeks, with a value of $14.24 billion in the week ending Sept 3. This increase was driven by escalating trade tensions between the US and China, which boosted the dollar as a safe haven. However, tensions have eased with upcoming trade talks, which may diminish bullish positioning on the dollar. The dollar also benefited from comments from Federal Reserve officials suggesting reluctance to cut interest rates, with some analysts warning that the market may be misjudging the Fed's dovishness.

site_title: Saudi king names his son, an industry insider, as oil minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's King named Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, his son and a longtime energy ministry official, as the new energy minister, replacing Khalid al-Falih. Prince Abdulaziz is seen as a capable and experienced technocrat, with no expected changes to oil policy. The move comes amid a trade war weighing on global demand and Opec's efforts to limit output and support prices. The kingdom is set to meet with Opec+ on Sept 12 to review its strategy to balance global oil markets.

site_title: Tokyo's famed Okura Hotel gets makeover ahead of 2020 Olympic Games
summary: The Okura Hotel in Tokyo, a historic landmark that hosted US presidents, British royalty, and James Bond, is set to reopen on September 12 after a $100 million renovation. The hotel, which was demolished in 2015, has been rebuilt into two towers with 508 luxury rooms, conference spaces, and a spa. Nods to the past include the lobby's style and furniture, while the new design incorporates modern Japanese minimalism. The hotel's reopening coincides with the 2020 Olympic Games, which will be held in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: The extensive renovation preserves some past elements such as the famous lanterns in the hotel lobby (above) while adding modern touches dominated by wood in other areas.
The extensive renovation preserves some past elements such as the famous lanterns in the hotel lobby while adding modern touches dominated by wood in other areas (above).

site_title: Credit Suisse hopes to keep on backing Asian entrepreneurs
summary: Credit Suisse, the second-largest wealth manager in the Asia-Pacific, has reported a 5% annualized growth in net new assets to 2.8 billion Swiss francs (S$3.92 billion) in the second quarter of 2019. The bank's approach to focusing on Asian entrepreneurs has allowed it to boost its standing as an "entrepreneurs' bank" and increase its total assets under management by 6% to 219 billion Swiss francs. Credit Suisse's private banking revenues were at its second-highest on record, driven by higher transaction-based revenues and net interest income.

site_title: UK democracy, economy still vibrant and robust: British High Commissioner
summary: The UK's economy and democracy remain strong and vibrant, with a record-high employment level of 32.7 million and low unemployment since 1975. The country is attracting record foreign investment in tech, with £5.5 billion secured in the first seven months of 2019. The UK is home to seven of Europe's 10 unicorn venture capital fund investors and one-third of Europe's AI startups. The British High Commissioner to Singapore highlights the UK's welcoming environment for international business, with a pro-business framework, a strong education system, and a globally respected innovation ecosystem.

images.alt_text: The UK economy is the fifth largest in the world and Britain's employment level is currently at a record high with 32.7 million people in work.

site_title: Johnson keeping to Brexit plan, won't seek delay: ministers
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is sticking to his Brexit plan, refusing to seek a delay to Britain's departure from the EU by October 31, despite the resignation of work and pensions minister Amber Rudd. Two of his ministers stated that Johnson is determined to "keep to the plan" and will not delay Brexit.

site_title: iPhone to share the spotlight with services at Apple's big event
summary: Apple is set to unveil its new iPhone models at a media presentation, with speculation suggesting the company will also introduce services and online content. Analysts expect the event to include three upgraded iPhones, including "Pro" models, and a successor to the iPhone XR. Apple's focus on services and content comes as the company seeks to shift its focus away from iPhone sales, which have declined. The launch of Apple TV+ and a new game subscription service, Apple Arcade, may also be announced.

site_title: Technical, fundamental analyses point to £ slide
summary: The GBP/USD has experienced volatility amid the Brexit news cycle as the UK approaches its Oct 31 deadline. A bill passed by the House of Commons, which would force the government to request a three-month Brexit delay, has reduced the likelihood of a "hard Brexit." As a result, the GBP has rebounded from its 28-month low. The bill is expected to pass the House of Lords, potentially thwarting UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's plans for a "hard Brexit."

site_title: Central banks could upstage trade as key sentiment driver
summary: Central banks may surpass trade tensions as key drivers of market sentiment, with the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank set to meet, potentially leading to interest rate cuts. The US economy showed signs of weakness with a lower-than-expected job creation rate, while China's August trade figures missed expectations. Despite eased tensions between the US and China, a single tweet from President Trump can still destabilize markets.

site_title: Australian mining towns posting strongest house price growth
summary: Australian mining towns are experiencing the strongest median property price growth, with nine out of 10 suburbs recording increases. This is driven by record-low interest rates, easing bank-lending rules, and strong rental growth. REA Group Chief Economist Nerida Conisbee attributes the surge to greater investor demand. The mining towns are among those experiencing a pricing surge, with suburbs in cities like Melbourne and Perth benefiting from the economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters aim to 'stress test' airport
summary: Hong Kong protesters plan to "stress test" the city's airport on Saturday, aiming to disrupt transport links and put pressure on authorities to meet their demands, including an amnesty for arrested protesters and universal suffrage. The move comes after the city's leader, Carrie Lam, announced the scrapping of a contentious extradition law, which protesters deem too little, too late. The airport, a key target of protests, has already seen disruptions in recent weeks, with hundreds of flights canceled and security measures increased.

site_title: 34 director acquisitions filed as STI recovers 2% in line with region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 2.0% from Aug 30 to Sept 5, with a total return of 6.2% for 2019. There were 170 changes in director interests or substantial shareholdings filed for 50 primary-listed stocks. Director acquisitions and disposals included UOB-Kay Hian Holdings chairman Wee Ee Chao's 29.33% stake, Sing Investments & Finance managing director Lee Sze Leong's 30.256% stake, and Singapore Medical Group non-executive chairman Tony Tan Choon Keat's 7.51% stake.

site_title: Brazil deforestation rises in August, adding to Amazon fire worries
summary: Brazil's Amazon rainforest experienced a 92% increase in deforestation in the first eight months of 2019, with 6,404.8 square kilometers (2,472.91 square miles) of forest cleared. This rise, followed by more than tripled deforestation in August, has raised concerns about fires already ravaging the region. The Brazilian government has been criticized for its handling of the issue, with President Jair Bolsonaro accused of emboldening deforesters and those setting fires. Environmental groups have called for action, including the establishment of a Justice Ministry task force to resolve conflicts over public land.

site_title: Veteran banker touts India bonds on prospect of deeper rate cuts
summary: Indian bond veteran Neeraj Gambhir expects a surge in bond prices due to potential deeper rate cuts by the central bank. Despite a $24 billion windfall, the government's economic stimulus package is limited, and lower interest rates will drive yields lower. Gambhir believes this creates an opportunity for investors to buy Indian bonds, despite concerns about the economy.

site_title: EU-Singapore FTA signals commitment to economic integration: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran emphasized the importance of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) as a symbol of commitment to economic integration amidst anti-globalization rhetoric. The agreement, nearing final stages of ratification, presents opportunities for European businesses in the rapidly growing Asean region with a rising middle class. Iswaran's visit to Italy's Ambrosetti Forum marked a step towards meeting EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom and engaging with European businesses, highlighting the significance of the EUSFTA in promoting economic cooperation between the two regions.

site_title: Six flights between Singapore, South Korea retimed due to Typhoon Lingling: SIA
summary: Six flights between Singapore and South Korea, operated by Singapore Airlines (SIA) and SilkAir, were rescheduled due to Typhoon Lingling. Four SIA flights and two SilkAir flights were affected, with some flights departing earlier or later than originally scheduled. The typhoon caused strong winds and rain in South Korea, grounding planes and leaving thousands without electricity. SIA advised customers to update their contact details for flight status updates.

site_title: Significant investment, substantial roadblocks stand in way of Indonesia's capital relocation
summary: Indonesia's plan to relocate its capital faces significant investment hurdles and environmental concerns. The estimated $46 billion construction project is expected to take 3-4 years, with funding via fiscal spending, foreign direct investment, and public-private partnerships. Analysts anticipate opportunities in surrounding cities, but also warn of potential deforestation and environmental issues. Despite these challenges, the relocation is seen as a positive step for infrastructure development and promoting growth in the provinces of Kalimantan.

site_title: DAFs still quite new concept: charities index
summary: Singapore's charitable giving landscape is evolving, with donor-advised funds (DAFs) becoming a relatively new concept. According to the Community Foundation of Singapore, just 1.1% of total giving in 2017 went to DAFs, but the foundation aims to increase this percentage. DAFs allow individuals to pledge money to causes they support, and some donors are using them to collaborate with charities and make a greater impact. Experts note that transparency and due diligence are key to rebuilding public trust in Singaporean charities, and initiatives like the Community Foundation of Singapore are helping to facilitate this.

site_title: Nissan CEO Saikawa tells some executives he plans to resign - Nikkei
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa plans to resign, according to a report by Nikkei, citing increasing doubts over his ability to steer the automaker to recovery. The decision comes amid a series of crises, including the admission of being overpaid and a plunge in Nissan's profit. A nominations committee has drawn up a shortlist of potential successors, including Jun Seki, Yasuhiro Yamauchi, and Makoto Uchida. The board is scheduled to meet on Monday to discuss the succession process, which is expected to take about six months.

site_title: Expected restructuring bids could test Singapore's insolvency regime
summary: Singapore's insolvency regime, revamped in 2017 to favor debtors, is set to face its biggest test amid a downturn and rising corporate distress. Weaker economic conditions have led to a surge in companies seeking judicial management and restructuring, with statistics showing 90 applications in 2017 and 32 in the first six months of 2019. Experts predict a "perfect storm" of defaults and corporate distress, testing the effectiveness of the enhanced debt-restructuring regime.

site_title: Zimbabwe begins national mourning for hero-turned-despot Robert Mugabe
summary: Zimbabwe has begun a period of national mourning after the death of former President Robert Mugabe, who ruled the country for 37 years. Mugabe, 95, died in Singapore on Friday. President Emmerson Mnangagwa declared him a "national hero" and said Zimbabwe will mourn him until his burial. Opinions about Mugabe are sharply divided, with some hailing him as a liberator and a "revolutionary icon," while others remember him as a tyrant who ruined the economy. International leaders, including South Africa's Cyril Ramaphosa and China, have praised Mugabe's legacy, while Britain described his death as a "mixed emotion."

site_title: Hong Kong police in position at airport ahead of planned protest
summary: Hong Kong police are in position at the airport ahead of a planned protest, following a week of clashes between protesters and police. Demonstrators, many masked and dressed in black, attacked MTR metro stations on the Kowloon peninsula on Friday night, leading to violent arrests and international attention. The protests, which began in June, are calling for more democracy and an independent inquiry into perceived police brutality. Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam announced concessions this week, including formally scrapping a extradition bill, but many protesters say they are too little, too late.

site_title: TEE International investigating unauthorised transactions worth over S$6m linked to CEO
summary: TEE International, a Singaporean engineering group, is investigating unauthorized transactions worth over S$6.55 million made by its subsidiaries to related parties. The transactions, which took place from July 2018 to May 2019, were allegedly made under the instruction of CEO Phua Chian Kin. The group has repaid the monies and appointed an external investigator to look into the matter. CEO Phua has been removed from his role and duties, and an interim CEO has taken over. The investigation aims to determine the nature and purpose of the remittances and assess potential breaches of internal controls.

site_title: Walmart's plan to keep guns out of stores won't keep them all out
summary: Walmart has introduced a policy discouraging patrons from openly carrying guns in stores, relying on signage rather than employee confrontation. The policy allows individuals with guns to shop, as long as they're not making others uncomfortable. Employees are supposed to alert a manager if an individual with a gun is disturbing others, who may then alert law enforcement or ask the person to leave. The move, modeled after other retailers, has sparked debate over businesses' role in preventing mass shootings, with some gun-control advocates expressing concerns that patrons can still openly carry firearms.

site_title: Motor racing-Leclerc sparks Ferrari celebrations with Italian GP win
summary: Charles Leclerc won the Italian Formula One Grand Prix, Ferrari's first home victory since 2010, holding off a Mercedes challenge. Leclerc led from pole position, while Valtteri Bottas finished second for Mercedes and Lewis Hamilton third. Leclerc's win marked his 14th for Ferrari and was fueled by the team's home crowd. Hamilton's lead over Bottas was cut to 62 points, and teammate Sebastian Vettel had a disastrous race, serving a 10-second penalty and being lapped by Leclerc.

site_title: Hong Kong police fire tear gas as clashes erupt after thousands appeal to Trump
summary: Thousands of Hong Kong protesters gathered near the US Consulate, calling for democracy and freedom from Chinese rule. Police responded with tear gas, as protesters set barricades, smashed windows, and started street fires. The protests, which have lasted for three months, were peaceful but violent in nature. US President Donald Trump was urged to "liberate" Hong Kong, with some protesters demanding the US take action to protect human rights. The Hong Kong leader announced concessions, but protesters say it was too little, too late.

site_title: India space agency loses communication with Moon-landing craft
summary: India's space agency lost communication with its Moon-landing craft, Vikram, just before it was due to land near the South Pole of the Moon. The ISRO chairman said the lander's descent was proceeding as planned until communication was lost. Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised the scientists, saying their hard work was a significant achievement. The ISRO acknowledged the complex manoeuvre, calling it "15 minutes of terror," and expressed hope that communication with the lander would resume, allowing the journey to continue.

site_title: Canadian teen Andreescu holds her nerve to beat Williams in US Open final
summary: Bianca Andreescu, a 19-year-old Canadian tennis player, won her first Grand Slam singles title at the US Open, defeating Serena Williams 6-3, 7-5. Andreescu, the first Canadian to achieve this feat, overcame a deficit from 5-1 to 5-5 and sealed the win with a precise forehand shot. Williams, who had a dismal match, fell short of her 24th Grand Slam title and acknowledged her frustration. Andreescu's victory marked a historic moment for Canadian tennis and propelled her to the top five rankings, up from a lowly No. 178 just a year ago.

images.alt_text: Andreescu, the Ontario-born daughter of Romanian immigrants, is the first Grand Slam singles champion from Canada.

site_title: US college admissions scam: Will parents like Felicity Huffman get jail?
summary: Wealthy parents, including actress Felicity Huffman, face reduced jail time after pleading guilty to paying to cheat their children into prestigious colleges. Prosecutors recommend 1-15 months of imprisonment, but Huffman's lawyers argue she should receive no jail time but instead a year of probation, community service, and a $20,000 fine. The first group of parents to be sentenced will have a hearing to air the dispute, with some potentially facing short terms of imprisonment or probation. The outcome could have ramifications for the rest of the case, where dozens more parents and coaches are still fighting charges.

site_title: Gold falls 1% on Powell's remarks, improved risk appetite
summary: Gold prices fell 1% on Friday, September 6, 2019, amid upbeat remarks from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and improved risk appetite, despite a weaker-than-expected US nonfarm payrolls report. Powell stated the US economy is strong, offsetting concerns about a recession. Gold is on track for a second straight weekly loss. Analysts attribute the decline to Powell's optimistic tone and improved risk appetite, but expect gold to remain supportive due to stimulus from the Fed and China's central bank.

site_title: Thousands try to flee hurricane-devastated Bahamas islands
summary: Thousands of people fled the Bahamas island of Great Abaco by boat or on a cruise ship to escape the catastrophic aftermath of Hurricane Dorian, the most powerful hurricane on record to hit the Bahamas. The storm has left hundreds missing, with a death toll of 30 expected to rise, and widespread destruction, including leveled neighborhoods and knocked-out infrastructure. Relief efforts are focused on providing food, water, and medical supplies to survivors, with the US Coast Guard and international aid groups involved.

site_title: Property boom turns unlikely Chinese cities into real-estate gold
summary: A four-year property boom in China's second-tier cities has made them into real estate gold, but at a cost. Prices in cities like Xiamen and Hangzhou have rivaled those in London and Seattle, pricing out middle-class buyers. The average household debt-to-income ratio in China has soared to a record 92%, with many families struggling to afford homes. Experts warn of a property bubble and increased household debt, threatening Beijing's goal of making these cities affordable to rural migrants.

site_title: HK police fire tear gas as clashes erupt after thousands appeal for US support
summary: Hong Kong police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in the Causeway Bay shopping district after demonstrators rallied at the US Consulate, calling for help in bringing democracy to the city. The clashes mark the third month of unrest in the city, with protesters dispersing to nearby districts before reassembling. The protests, which began in June, have been largely peaceful but have escalated into clashes with police. The US Consulate has not commented on the protesters' appeal for support.

images.alt_text: Protesters marching to the US Consulate during a rally in Hong Kong on Sunday. They waved the Stars and Stripes and placards demanding democracy.

site_title: 'They're all idiots': Amid Brexit chaos, Britons lose faith in politicians
summary: British voters, who supported leaving the European Union in the 2016 referendum, have lost faith in their politicians amidst the Brexit crisis. Many express frustration with Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who has failed to deliver on his promise to "do or die" on Brexit. The public is calling for a second referendum, and some are questioning the legitimacy of the current government. The opposition parties have also announced they will not support Johnson's bid for an early election. As a result, a bill to block a no-deal Brexit has been approved by the House of Lords, further eroding Johnson's control over Brexit.

site_title: Vaping related lung disease claims third life in US
summary: A third person has died in the US due to a severe pulmonary disease linked to vaping, bringing the total to three fatalities and over 450 possible cases. The outbreak is focusing on black market cannabis e-cigarette products containing vitamin E oil, with high levels found in all 34 cases in New York. No single substance has been identified in all samples tested nationwide. Many patients initially misdiagnosed with bronchitis or viral illnesses before severe symptoms escalated, leading to hospitalization and ventilators.

site_title: Blast wounds 7 people at public market in southern Philippines
summary: An explosion at a public market in southern Philippines wounded at least 7 people, the 4th blast in the area in 13 months. A suspected improvised explosive device was found beside a motorcycle, with a militant group operating in the area as a suspect. The incident occurred in a city plagued by banditry and armed rebellions, with Islamist militants operating in the region and links to al Qaeda and Islamic State.

images.alt_text: An explosion at a public market in the southern Philippines wounded at least seven people early on Saturday, the fourth blast in that area in 13 months, the military said.

site_title: Airlines up the ante on the ground, in premium lounges
summary: Airlines are increasing investments in airport lounges to retain premium passengers. Singapore Airlines has spent $50 million upgrading its lounges at Changi Airport Terminal 3, increasing capacity to 1,000 passengers. Other airlines, such as Qantas, are also expanding their lounges, with Qantas' new First Class Lounge at Changi Airport's Terminal 1 offering a 30% increase in capacity. The upgrades include made-to-order meals, champagne, and shower facilities. Analysts say that lounges are a key differentiator for airlines, and that investments in this area are essential for retaining premium customers.

site_title: A flowery take on the margarita
summary: The Sampan, a Singaporean restaurant-bar, offers a unique take on the classic margarita by infusing tequila with dried hibiscus for 6-8 hours, lending a tart sourness that's countered by vanilla. The drink is part of the bar's modern Asian menu and decor, which combines contemporary elements with traditional details. The bar's head bartender, Herman Jasmani, tweaks the drink's potency based on the customer's order, and the bar also offers other signature cocktails with Asian elements, such as the Mango & Chilli Smash.

site_title: Alibaba dials up luxury push with US$2b buy of Netease e-commerce arm
summary: ALIBABA Group has agreed to buy e-commerce business Kaola from Chinese gaming company NetEase for US$2 billion, expanding its luxury goods offerings. This move aims to drive new revenue as the e-commerce market matures in China. Alibaba will also invest US$700 million in NetEase's music streaming arm, taking on market leader Tencent Music. The deal marks a significant push by Alibaba into luxury e-commerce and strategic investments in the music streaming market.

site_title: US-China trade conflict could take years to resolve: Kudlow
summary: US-China trade talks aim for "near term" results in September and October, but White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow warns the trade conflict could take years to resolve due to its global importance. Kudlow notes that 18 months of negotiations is a short period for issues at stake, suggesting talks could continue much longer. The US seeks tangible results, while China's economic growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. A deal's success remains uncertain, and the conflict's resolution timeline remains unclear.

site_title: US: Wall Street swings to split finish; notches weekly gains
summary: US stocks ended nearly unchanged on Friday but posted gains for the week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.3% and the S&P 500 gaining less than a tenth of a percent. The jobs report showed a weaker-than-expected 130,000 net new jobs in August, but the Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell signaled a potential rate cut this month. Investors also reacted to economic stimulus in China and weak industrial output in Germany, while Facebook shares fell 1.8% amid an antitrust investigation.

site_title: Boeing suspends testing of long-haul 777X aircraft
summary: Boeing has suspended testing of its long-haul 777X aircraft due to an issue encountered during the "final load" tests, a crucial step in the certification process overseen by the FAA. The tests, aimed at subjecting the plane to extreme loads and stresses, were halted following the discovery of the problem. This setback comes as Boeing battles to recover from the crisis surrounding the 737 MAX. The cause of the issue is not specified, and the suspension of testing is expected to delay the aircraft's certification and entry into service.

site_title: Oil jumps after Fed says it will act to sustain US growth
summary: US oil prices rose above $61 a barrel on Friday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated the central bank will act to sustain US economic growth, citing a "bid in the market ahead of the weekend". Oil prices had fallen earlier due to concerns over US job growth and trade tensions, but Powell's comments suggest further interest-rate reductions, boosting crude prices. Global oil demand forecasts have been reduced, with UBS analyst Giovanni Staunovo predicting a 900,000 barrels per day growth in 2019 and 2020.

site_title: When the AI professor leaves, students suffer, study says
summary: A study by researchers at the University of Rochester found that the exodus of AI professors from academia to industry has negatively impacted students. Over the last 15 years, 153 AI professors left their posts for industry, with 68 retaining part-time roles. The migration has increased dramatically, with 41 professors making the move in 2018 alone. The trend is expected to continue, indicating a potential shortage of AI talent in academia. This could lead to a loss of expertise and innovation in AI research and education.

site_title: Axiata, Telenor to end talks on merging Asian telco business
summary: Axiata Group and Telenor have ended talks on merging their Asian telecom operations, citing "complexities" as the reason. The deal, which aimed to create a company with 300 million customers across nine countries, was halted after Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad questioned employment impacts. Axiata will explore opportunities to consolidate its business, while Telenor will focus on growth and efficiency in Asia, leaving the door open for future talks.

site_title: Tennis: Medvedev grinds out win over Dimitrov to reach US Open final
summary: Daniil Medvedev defeated Grigor Dimitrov 7-6(5), 6-4, 6-3 in the US Open semi-finals, advancing to his first Grand Slam final. The win marks Medvedev's 12th consecutive match and his fourth straight final appearance. The Russian fifth seed has overcome a complicated relationship with the Flushing Meadows crowds to reach the championship, where he will compete for his first Grand Slam title.

site_title: Fewer suspicious transactions but more intelligence gleaned from data: CAD report
summary: Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) reported 32,660 suspicious transaction reports (STRs) filed in 2018, a decrease from 35,471 in 2017. Despite fewer reports, qualitative financial data analysis led to more intelligence for enforcement agencies, with a 111% increase in financial intelligence reports circulated. CAD successfully prosecuted 133 individuals for money-laundering offences, a 51% increase from 2017, and seized S$18.5 million of illicit proceeds from a syndicate that defrauded SkillsFuture Singapore.

site_title: Pet spa? Private lift? At US luxury condos, amenities race heats up
summary: US luxury condominium developers are offering increasingly extravagant perks to attract buyers, amid a slowdown in the market. Amenities like private lifts, pet spas, and smart technology have become common, while developers are also incorporating art and exclusive services like cryotherapy. However, experts say that while luxury features are attractive, classic design and a sense of history are what truly hold value. The top five core amenities – doorman, elevator, laundry, roof deck, and gym – add significant value, while private elevators and other privacy perks are also in high demand.

site_title: Setting the pace in Europe's top football leagues
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

In the early days of the European football season, top clubs are making an early impact in the English Premier League, Italy's Serie A, the Bundesliga, and La Liga. Liverpool leads the EPL with 12 points, followed by Manchester City, while Inter-Milan, Juventus, and Torino are atop Serie A with perfect records. RB Leipzig sits first in the Bundesliga, and Atletico Madrid leads La Liga with a perfect winning record. Key players, such as Liverpool's Mohamed Salah and RB Leipzig's Timo Werner, are making significant contributions to their teams' success, setting the stage for an exciting season.

site_title: New scheme to link up Singapore fintech firms with legal expertise on compliance issues
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) have launched a pilot programme to connect fintech firms with legal expertise on compliance issues, aiming to enhance Singapore's appeal as a fintech hub. The programme, called the Payments Regulatory Evaluation Programme (PREP), provides a standard questionnaire for fintechs to fill out, followed by a customised assessment report on applicable regulations. This streamlined path will enable fintechs to access legal advice more easily and quickly, addressing the complex regulatory landscape in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on China stimulus despite weak US, German data
summary: European markets rose for a third day, driven by China's stimulus package boosting bank lending and outweighing weak US job growth and German industrial output data. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1.7% for the week, its third weekly gain. Shares in trade-sensitive companies surged after China's central bank cut reserve requirements, increasing liquidity and supporting the economy. This positive trend in Europe follows recent positive turns in politics in Britain, Italy, and Hong Kong, as well as US-China trade talks resuming.

site_title: Robots displacing jobs means 120 million workers need retraining
summary: An IBM survey reveals that over 120 million workers globally will need retraining within the next three years due to the impact of artificial intelligence on jobs. The training required is now longer, taking 36 days to close a skills gap compared to just three days in 2014. This poses a significant concern for employers, who cite a talent shortage as one of their top threats to their organizations.

site_title: Hong Kong protests resume after Carrie Lam offers olive branch
summary: Hong Kong protests resumed after Carrie Lam withdrew the extradition bill, sparking tear gas, pepper spray, and fire clashes with protesters. The unrest, which began in June, has expanded beyond the extradition bill to include calls for fundamental political reforms and an independent inquiry into police behavior. Protests are planned for this weekend, including attempts to disrupt the airport and urge the US Congress to pass a proposal to penalize officials who suppress freedoms in Hong Kong.

site_title: STI posts slight losses on Friday but adds 1.2% on the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore closed at 3,144.48, down 2.58 points or 0.1% on Friday, despite a risk-on day due to the removal of Hong Kong's extradition bill and hopes for trade resolution. However, the index added 37.96 points or 1.2% for the week, its first weekly gain since June. Asian markets, including Australia, China, and Hong Kong, finished higher, with the Hang Seng gaining 0.7% and Hong Kong's benchmark rising 3.8% for the week.

site_title: Japan's July household spending up for 8th straight month, but at slower pace
summary: Japan's household spending rose 0.8% in July, the eighth consecutive month, but at a slower pace than forecast. This marks the longest run of expansion since 2000, but concerns remain due to a global slowdown and US-China trade war. Household spending slowed due to cooler weather, and real wages adjusted for inflation slipped for the seventh month. The Bank of Japan is expected to ease further stimulus after a global slowdown threatens Japan's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending rose for an eighth month in July, albeit at a slower-than-expected pace, offering a warning about consumption in an economy already struggling with weak external demand amid the bitter US-China trade war.

site_title: Reits (September 7-8, 2019)
summary: Key real estate news includes rising US mortgage rates, a Q3 condo launch wave in Singapore, record Manhattan rents, and a rebound in UK homebuyer demand. Additionally, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail asset in Seoul and WeWork secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy location in Singapore. These developments indicate ongoing market fluctuations and shifting demand in various regions.

site_title: US Aug job growth slows more than expected but wages post strong gains
summary: US job growth slowed more than expected in August, with 130,000 new jobs added, down from the 158,000 forecasted by economists. Despite slower job growth, wages posted strong gains, with a 0.4% increase in average hourly earnings, the largest since February. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 3.7%. The slowdown in job growth is attributed to trade tensions, with the White House's year-long trade war with China and rising uncertainty. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates again to keep the economy expanding moderately.

site_title: The UK's fixed-term parliament and the Brexit gridlock
summary: The UK is experiencing a deadlock between the executive and legislative branches of government due to the 2011 Fixed-Term Parliaments Act, which has introduced an intractable impasse over Brexit. The law, intended to secure the stability of a coalition government, has created a situation where the prime minister can't call an election unilaterally and the opposition can block the government's plans. The current impasse is between Conservative Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, with Johnson seeking to call new elections to secure a Brexit deal, while Corbyn wants a fresh election to win power.

site_title: Gold retreats over renewed global risk appetites
summary: Gold prices retreated as global risk appetites improved, with US-China trade talks resuming and softer geopolitical tensions easing risk-off sentiments. Better-than-expected China PMIs and strong US labor markets spurred risk assets, while profit-booking activities by money managers imposed headwinds on gold. The next FOMC meeting on September 18 is expected to see an interest rate cut, supporting safe haven assets amid economic uncertainties. Gold prices must break above $1,535 to continue the bullish trend, while failure to hold above $1,516 may promote bearish bias.

site_title: Setting the right boundaries
summary: A former colleague, A, was forced to resign after a friend, B, betrayed her trust by sharing confidential conversations and text messages with superiors. The betrayal occurred outside of work, as A and B were former schoolmates and would meet after office hours. The incident led to a compliance investigation, resulting in A's resignation. The article emphasizes the importance of maintaining professional boundaries with colleagues to protect one's job and reputation.

site_title: Named the World's Best Bar, Dante plans a sequel
summary: Dante, the World's Best Bar, is set to open a new location in New York's West Village, dubbed Dante West Village, in October. The bar will take inspiration from Spain's Basque Country and feature a new chef, Angel Fernandez, and a focus on the martini and spritz. The menu will also include a Mediterranean martini, made with gin, thyme, and mastiha. The new location will have more space than the original, seating 75, and will feature pavement seating. The owners are preparing for potential community resistance, acknowledging that customer feedback often dictates a bar's identity.

site_title: HKEX websites attacked on Thursday: CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd's websites suffered cyberattacks on Thursday, according to CEO Charles Li. The attacks were unrelated to the derivatives market trading halt caused by a software bug. Trading resumed on Friday without issues. While rare in Hong Kong, trading halts due to software issues have occurred globally, including at the London Stock Exchange. HKEX will review procedures to prevent similar glitches in the future.

site_title: The TBx investment infection
summary: US President Trump, UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson, and Chinese President Xi Jinping pose a significant threat to investment health due to their erratic economic policies and international trade destruction. The "TBx" infection has led to a decline in Singapore's GDP and has sparked concerns about a US recession. Trump's freezing of Venezuelan assets and suggestion to freeze Chinese assets could lead to a weakening yuan and increased US debt. Meanwhile, Boris's proroguing of parliament and Xi's resilient Shanghai Index suggest a potential for a nuclear or thermo-nuclear outcome, with gold being the only clear winner.

site_title: Singapore SMEs in HK look to things returning to normal
summary: Singaporean SMEs in Hong Kong remain optimistic about doing business there despite ongoing protests. Companies such as Lunch Actually and Love, Bonito have seen a slight recovery in August, with more dates and customers. However, some SMEs, including the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, are taking a wait-and-see approach, citing concerns about a potential change in Hong Kong's environment and culture. The withdrawal of the extradition bill may not be enough to appease protesters, and some businesses may consider spreading themselves out of Hong Kong.

site_title: A peek into the future of medicine
summary: MWH Holdings, a medical entity in Singapore, is shifting its focus from curative medicine to preventive care, believing that preventing disease is the future of medicine. The company is investing in technology, such as Siemens' MRI and CT machines, to provide 3D imaging and non-invasive procedures. This approach aims to reduce hospitalization costs and improve patient outcomes. With a focus on preventive medicine, MWH is also training its staff to maximize technology and deliver high-quality care. The company's chief medical officer, Michael Lim, believes that this approach will pay off in the long run and become the standard in the industry.

site_title: Deutsche chops dozens of 'safe' jobs in fixed-income trading
summary: Deutsche Bank is cutting dozens of traders and sales-people in its global fixed-income unit, a move that was largely unexpected given the unit's relative safety during the bank's initial overhaul two months ago. The cuts are in high yield, distressed, and investment-grade debt teams in New York and abroad. The move is part of CEO Christian Seweff's efforts to cut losses, but the bank still has not completed its overhaul plans. This is the second round of job cuts for Deutsche Bank in recent months.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Corporate digest: CSC Holdings secured foundation contracts worth over S$70 million, including work on Exxon Mobil's expansion and the North-South Corridor Tunnels. Tiong Seng Holdings secured a S$287 million contract to build an industrial building at Ang Mo Kio industrial park. China Jinjiang Environment's S&P ratings were revised to positive from negative, with its issuer rating and senior notes rating affirmed.

site_title: This phone isn't just about the folding stuff
summary: Samsung's Galaxy Fold, a $1,980 luxury phone, is not expected to drive sales but rather spark competition. The device's folding screen design was marred by a severe defect discovered in pre-release units, raising concerns about Samsung's technological innovation. This setback comes three years after the company's Galaxy Note 7 model was recalled due to exploding batteries. The Galaxy Fold's launch may ultimately be measured by the number of competitors who decide to develop their own folding-screen devices, rather than sales figures.

images.alt_text: The spotlight will once again be on the redesigned Galaxy Fold's screen to see whether the design can hold up to daily wear and tear.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rates hit lowest level since October 2016
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates have fallen to their lowest level since October 2016, averaging 3.49% in the week ended Sept 5. This decline is attributed to weakening economic data and declining bond yields. Analysts expect this decrease to offset rising home prices and low inventories, which have impacted home sales. The monthly payment on a $300,000, 30-year loan would be $1,345, down from $1,527 a year ago.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit announced a name change to Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, with plans to enter a new outsourcing management agreement with Pacific Oak Capital Advisors. The reorganisation aims to distinguish the Reit from its peer, Prime US Reit. Despite rising US-China trade tensions, the office portfolio is expected to remain resilient and outperform the market. Analysts also highlighted CSE Global's potential for growth driven by increased capex in oil majors and infrastructure projects in Australia, with a projected earnings compound annual growth rate of 15%.

site_title: US Democrats to probe into Pence's stay at Trump hotel in Ireland
summary: US House Democrats have launched an investigation into Vice President Mike Pence's stay at a Trump-owned hotel in Ireland, citing potential conflicts of interest and violations of the US Constitution. Pence stayed at the Trump International Golf Club in Doonberg, despite meetings in Dublin, 300km away. The investigation seeks documents on the visit, which media reports described as a "problematic investment" for Trump's company. The probe aims to determine if US taxpayer funds were used to personally enrich President Trump and his companies.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit buys Dallas property for US$101.5m
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit has agreed to acquire an office complex in Irving, Dallas for US$101.5 million. One Twenty Five, a 95.5% occupied office complex, is leased to 20 tenants. The acquisition is part of the company's strategy to expand its US portfolio. The deal marks Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's latest move in the US real estate market, following its previous investments in the country.

site_title: Great wearables for good sports
summary: A list of recommended wearables for different fitness personalities is presented. The Fitbit Inspire HR is ideal for workout newbies, tracking basic activity, heart rate, and calories burned. For regular runners, the Garmin Forerunner 245 Music is suggested, offering features like music storage and VO2 max estimation. The recommended prices range from S$158 to S$529.

site_title: Understanding business cycles and their impact on asset classes
summary: A business cycle is a prolonged period of economic growth, followed by a recession, and then recovery. The cycle consists of four stages: peak, recession, recovery, and expansion. During the peak phase, growth slows down, and corporate earnings and profits decline. In the recession phase, businesses slow down, leading to higher unemployment rates and decreased consumer spending. The recovery phase marks the beginning of a new expansion, with stabilizing GDP, falling unemployment, and moderate inflation. To navigate these phases, investors should diversify across multiple asset classes and maintain a long-term perspective, avoiding short-term market noise and emotional decisions.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after China stimulus plan, jobs data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday after China's stimulus plan to boost its economy and weak jobs data led to expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones rose 62.10 points, the S&P 500 gained 4.33 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 8.75 points. The positive market reaction was attributed to the potential economic stimulus and the anticipation of an interest rate cut by the Fed later this month.

site_title: Tiong Seng unit clinches S$287m deal from JTC to build industrial building
summary: Construction firm Tiong Seng Holdings has secured a S$287 million contract from JTC Corporation to build a seven-storey industrial building at Ang Mo Kio industrial park. Site possession is expected in September, with no expected impact on the company's net tangible assets and earnings for the current financial year. The contract was announced on September 6, 2019, and shares of the mainboard-listed firm closed unchanged at S$0.215.

site_title: Fed warns of decline in global growth due to trade conflicts
summary: The Federal Reserve warns of a decline in global growth due to trade conflicts, citing a 0.8% decline in global GDP by the first half of 2019. The research note attributes this decline to the escalation of trade tensions in 2018 and 2019, which may weigh on the world economy into 2020. US President Donald Trump's trade policies and the Fed's decision to lower interest rates are also highlighted as contributing factors. The Fed aims to quantify the costs of the global trading regime and push back against Trump's claims that the Fed, not trade policies, is responsible for financial market volatility.

site_title: Christine Lagarde and the case for more QE
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to announce a significant stimulus package, including rate cuts, to combat dwindling inflation. ECB President Mario Draghi will step down in November, and Christine Lagarde, the International Monetary Fund chief, will take over. Many economists believe Lagarde will continue Draghi's loose monetary policy, including restarting quantitative easing. The ECB is facing a major external shock due to the US-China trade conflict, and inflation has fallen below the central bank's target of 2%. A new round of stimulus is seen as necessary to stop the deceleration of prices, with potential measures including cutting the deposit rate further into negative territory and revising inflation and growth forecasts downward.

images.alt_text: Ms Lagarde has promised to combat dwindling inflation and said a "highly accommodative policy is warranted for a prolonged period".

site_title: Thomson Medical Group CEO Roy Quek quits but remains on board as non-executive director
summary: Thomson Medical Group's (TMG) CEO Roy Quek is stepping down as executive director and chief executive, effective September 16, to pursue other professional interests. He will remain on board as a non-executive director. TMG is expanding its operations beyond Singapore and Malaysia, with plans to establish new platforms and specialist services. The company has appointed Wong Chiang Yin, a public health specialist, as special advisor. Quek's departure follows a four-year tenure, during which he oversaw the expansion of TMG's services and established new platforms.

site_title: EU stresses IAEA role in verifying Iran nuclear deal
summary: The European Commission expressed "great concern" over Iran's withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal, citing the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) role in monitoring and verifying Iran's compliance. Iran has announced its third cut to its commitments since July, sparking fears the deal is crumbling. The EU relies on the IAEA's reports to assess Iran's compliance and urged Iran to reverse its actions. Meanwhile, a special purpose vehicle to shield Iran's oil sales from US sanctions has started processing payments, but Iran argues Europe is not doing enough to support its interests.

site_title: Kudlow says trade talks between China, US will likely 'heat up'
summary: White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow stated that trade talks between the US and China are likely to "heat up" in October, following a failed July meeting. The talks, which will include high-level discussions, do not have any conditions. China's commerce ministry had previously confirmed that the talks would take place in early October in Washington. Kudlow expressed uncertainty about the outcome of the talks, saying he cannot predict an outcome. The meetings come after US President Donald Trump imposed fresh tariffs on virtually all Chinese imports in July.

site_title: Facebook joins Google in states' antitrust crosshairs
summary: Facebook Inc joins Google in being scrutinized by state attorneys general for possible antitrust violations, amid concerns over advertising prices, consumer choice, and personal information handling. New York Attorney General Letitia James is leading a bipartisan investigation, while federal agencies also probe Google's online advertising market and Facebook's acquisitions. Facebook's vice president says the company will work with policymakers to address competition concerns, but warns that stopping innovation could lead to users leaving the platform. The scrutiny marks the latest challenge to Silicon Valley giants' market dominance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore payment firms will gain access to specialized legal expertise for compliance under a new plan. The program streamlines the process for fintech firms to meet payment services regulations. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement and is seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Livin' la vida larger
summary: LG CineBeam HU85L and HU70L projectors have been announced, featuring 4K resolution, long lifespan, and minimal visual artefacts. The HU85L uses a laser + LED hybrid light source, while the HU70L uses an LED light source, both with 20,000-30,000 hour lifespans. Nikon has also announced the D6 professional DSLR camera and a new 120-300mm telephoto lens, set to release before the 2020 Olympic Games. Razer has released the Blade Stealth 13 gaming ultrabook with up to an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650 GPU and Intel's 10th Gen Ice Lake processors.

site_title: Digitalising built-environment sector 'can attract the young to it'
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) chief executive Hugh Lim stated that digitalising the built-environment sector can make careers in the industry more attractive to young people. The government's efforts to encourage digitalisation have shifted from providing software and hardware support to supporting programmes that connect different parts of the value chain. This move aims to change the nature of work in the sector and make it more appealing to the younger generation.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to raise stake in Waterway Point in S$90m deal
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is set to acquire an additional 6.67% stake in Waterway Point, a suburban mall in Singapore, in a S$89.6 million deal. This will increase FCT's stake in the property to 40%. The acquisition is part of FCT's strategy to expand its market share in Singapore's suburban retail sector. FCT plans to fund the deal with a combination of debt and internal sources. The deal is expected to position Waterway Point for long-term growth and good returns for FCT and its unitholders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.72 points to 1,604.47. The market saw a 410-336 gain-to-lose ratio, with a total volume of 1.66 billion lots worth RM1.43 billion.

site_title: Del Monte swings to loss in Q1 on lower revenue
summary: Del Monte Pacific, a dual-listed Philippines firm, reported a net loss of US$38.3 million in its first quarter due to lower revenue, mainly from the sale of its Sager Creek business in 2017. Excluding one-off items, the company would have posted a recurring net income of US$4.1 million. Del Monte aims to improve cash flow and strengthen its balance sheet, with plans to reduce leverage and interest. The company expects to be profitable for FY2020 on a recurring basis, despite facing headwinds in the US market.

site_title: Hong Kong police fire tear gas as protests resume despite withdrawal of bill
summary: Hong Kong police fired tear gas, rubber bullets, and pepper spray to disperse protesters outside a subway station in Kowloon, marking the latest clash in 14 weeks of anti-government demonstrations. The protests, sparked by a bill allowing extraditions to mainland China, have morphed into calls for more democracy. Despite the withdrawal of the bill, protesters say concessions are too little, too late. The demonstrations have paralyzed parts of the city and drawn international attention, posing a challenge to Chinese President Xi Jinping. Clashes are expected to continue into the weekend.

site_title: US payrolls rise 130,000, boosted by 25,000 for census count
summary: US companies' hiring slowed in August, adding 130,000 jobs, below the median estimate of 150,000. Private payrolls rose 96,000, while total nonfarm payrolls climbed 130,000, boosted by temporary government workers. The jobless rate remained at 3.7%, while average hourly earnings increased 3.2% from a year earlier. The data suggests cracks in the labor market, potentially threatening consumer spending and the record-long expansion, and may prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates this month.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with healthy gains, driven by news that China and the US would resume trade talks next month. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.66% and the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.46%. This follows a 3% weekly increase for the Hang Seng Index and a 3.9% rise for the Shanghai Composite Index. The positive momentum was attributed to investor optimism over the resumption of US-China trade talks.

site_title: Swedish foreign minister Wallstrom resigns
summary: Sweden's Foreign Minister Margot Wallstrom has announced her resignation to focus on family, effective immediately. A veteran diplomat with a long career in Swedish and international politics, Wallstrom served as foreign minister since 2014, implementing a "feminist foreign policy." Her tenure was marked by controversy, including strained relations with Israel and Saudi Arabia, with which Sweden's diplomatic ties were frozen in 2015. Wallstrom cited her desire to spend more time with her family and grandchildren as the reason for her departure.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit buys Dallas office complex for US$101.5m
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit has agreed to acquire One Twenty Five, a Dallas office complex, for US$101.5 million. The complex offers 445,317 sq ft of space and has a 95.5% occupancy rate. The acquisition is expected to increase the Reit's net leasable area by 10.5% and assets under management by 9.3%. The deal is subject to unitholders' approval and is expected to result in a 1% growth in pro-forma distribution per unit.

site_title: British opposition parties discuss PM Johnson's Brexit election gamble
summary: British opposition parties will discuss how to respond to Boris Johnson's bid to call a snap election after he stated he would rather die in a ditch than delay the UK's Oct 31 departure from the European Union. The Labour Party and other opposition parties aim to prevent Johnson from leading the country out of the EU without a deal. Former Prime Minister John Major called for Johnson to fire his advisor Dominic Cummings, who dismissed the suggestion. The UK is set to hold another vote on holding an early election on Monday.

site_title: Thailand unveils 'relocation package' to draw firms hit by trade war
summary: Thailand has unveiled a relocation package to attract foreign companies affected by the Sino-US trade war, offering tax incentives, special investment zones, and changes in laws to facilitate foreign investment. The package includes a 50% corporate income tax reduction for firms with real investment of at least 1 billion baht and higher tax deductions for advanced technology training and automation. The goal is to boost Southeast Asia's second-largest economy, which grew at its weakest annual pace in nearly five years in the second quarter.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end higher on trade truce hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose on Friday due to hopes of a trade truce, with the KOSPI index ending up 0.22% at 2,009.13. This is the benchmark index's highest gain since early April. Despite early gains, concerns about the outcome of trade talks trimmed gains. Foreigners were net buyers of $39.62 million worth of shares on the main board. The KOSPI has fallen 1.56% so far this year, but added 2.1% for the week.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters gather in renewed protest as night falls
summary: Hong Kong protesters gathered outside a subway station on Friday, expecting crowds to swell into the night as they aim to disrupt transport links to the airport. The move comes after Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam withdrew a controversial extradition bill. The airport announced that only passengers with tickets would be allowed to use the Airport Express train service on Saturday, and bus services could also be disrupted. The protest is the latest in a series of demonstrations sparked by Lam's decision, with demonstrators seeking to maintain pressure on the government.

site_title: Germany plans to ban single-use plastic shopping bags next year
summary: Germany plans to ban single-use plastic shopping bags from next year, joining a growing movement to fight global pollution. The ban, set to take effect in the first half of 2020, will bar supermarkets and retailers from offering lightweight plastic carrier bags, including those marketed as biodegradable. Breaches will result in fines of up to 100,000 euros. The move aims to reduce plastic pollution in waterways and oceans, and follows a 2016 voluntary commitment by the retail industry to phase out free plastic bags.

site_title: Singapore shares post slight losses on Friday, up 1.2% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,144.48 on Friday, down 2.58 points or 0.1% from the previous week's close, despite a risk-on sentiment in the region. The blue-chip index gained 1.2% from last Friday's close. Key markets in the Asia-Pacific region, including Australia, China, and Hong Kong, finished higher. Despite a lower trading volume, the STI still outperformed other markets, with 208 advancers beating 158 decliners.

site_title: China mulls target for 60% of auto sales to be electric by 2035
summary: China is considering a target of 60% of all automobiles sold in the country to run on electric motors by 2035, according to people familiar with the matter. This ambitious plan, spearheaded by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, would represent a 12-fold jump from the current 5% of new energy vehicles (NEVs) sold. The proposal, still under discussion, aims to lead the world in the push away from combustion engines and add pressure on global carmakers to electrify their fleets.
