site_title: Thomson Medical Group CEO Roy Quek quits, remains on board as non-executive director
summary: Thomson Medical Group's CEO Roy Quek is stepping down as executive director and chief executive, effective September 16, to pursue other professional interests. He will remain on board as a non-executive director. Quek led the group's expansion of specialist services and established new platforms, including Thomson Wellth. The company has appointed Dr Wong Chiang Yin, a public health specialist, as special advisor. The board expressed appreciation for Quek's service and looks forward to his continued contribution as a board member.

site_title: China to cut reserve requirements for banks to boost economy
summary: China's central bank announced a 50 basis point cut in reserve requirements for banks on September 16, freeing up about $126 billion to boost lending and support the slowing economy. The move aims to bolster the real economy and counter the impact of US tariffs. The People's Bank of China (PBoC) described the decision as "the latest effort to bolster the economy." The cut is expected to increase lending and stimulate economic growth, which is expected to slow down.

site_title: Engineering firm CSC bags contracts worth over S$70m
summary: Engineering firm CSC Holdings secured contracts worth over S$70 million in August, including work on Exxon Mobil's expansion, Singapore Institute of Technology's new campus, and the North-South Corridor Tunnels. The contracts are expected to positively contribute to CSC's full-year results for the financial year ending March 31, 2020.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata to end talks to merge Asian business with Norway's Telenor
summary: Axiata Group Bhd and Telenor ASA have ended talks to merge their Asian telecommunication operations, scrapping a plan to create a company with 300 million customers across nine countries. The decision comes after complexities were cited as the reason for the halt. Telenor will continue to operate in Asia, while Axiata will explore opportunities to consolidate its business. The merger was canceled months after Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad questioned its impact on employment.

site_title: Zimbabwe's former president Robert Mugabe dies in Singapore
summary: Former Zimbabwean leader Robert Mugabe, 95, has died in Singapore, where he received medical treatment. Zimbabwe's President Emmerson Mnangagwa announced Mugabe's death on Twitter, describing him as a "founding father" and former President. Mugabe was forced to resign in 2017 after an army coup and ruled the country for nearly four decades since independence in 1980. His death comes after years of private media reports suggesting he had prostate cancer, which officials repeatedly denied.

site_title: HKEX websites were attacked on Thursday, says CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd (HKEX) suffered cyberattacks on Thursday, with its websites experiencing intermittent technical difficulties. The attacks, described as distributed denial-of-service, were unrelated to a derivatives market trading halt caused by a software bug. Trading resumed without issues on Friday. HKEX's CEO, Charles Li, acknowledged the issue and vowed to review procedures to prevent future glitches. The incident highlights the risks of cyberattacks on financial markets, with traders facing losses due to the halt.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,156.61, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday with a 0.3% gain, reaching 3,156.61 at 1:02pm, amid a global rally. Gainers outnumbered losers 174-125, driven by hopes for US-China trade talks and positive US economic data. Key stocks rose, including DBS Group Holdings (0.8%), OCBC Bank (0.7%), and Rex International Holding (1.2%). The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on trade talk hopes, NZ closes at record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,647.3, driven by hopes for reduced US-China trade tensions following a deal to hold high-level talks. The S&P/ASX 200 index recorded its third straight weekly gain. New Zealand's benchmark index closed at a record high, up 1% to 11,218.99, after a 1% weekly gain. Strong US economic data also supported risk sentiment, with energy stocks jumping 1.3%. The market's gains followed a failed trade meeting at the end of July that led to fresh US tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: Singapore insurance body offers standard form to simplify pre-authorisation of hospital bills
summary: The Life Insurance Association, Singapore (LIA Singapore) has introduced a standard form for pre-authorisation of hospital bills, simplifying the process and reducing administrative burden for doctors. The new form will be used by all Integrated Shield Plan (IP) insurers starting October 1, 2019, and must be completed by the policyholder's attending doctor. The standardised form aims to reduce administrative burden and provide clarity to healthcare providers and insurers, giving patients peace of mind and ensuring medical necessity and cost assessments are made.

site_title: Taleban supporters cheer US withdrawal plans
summary: Taleban supporters in Afghanistan are cheering a potential US withdrawal deal, which could see the US military draw down its forces after 18 years of conflict. The deal is expected to require "intra-Afghan" talks between the Taleban and the Afghan government, with the Taleban seeking a peace based on "Islamic values." Supporters express hope for a dignified peace but warn that the war could continue if handled poorly, and some worry about the group's ability to make a separate agreement with the Afghan government.

site_title: App attempts a rare trick in China: online privacy
summary: A Chinese tech entrepreneur, Yang Geng, has launched an app called LeakZero, which offers online anonymity and encrypted messaging services, making it the only one of its kind in China. The app, which has gained over 34,000 aliases, allows users to surf the web, protect passwords, and send encrypted messages without revealing their identities. Yang's goal is to provide a secure alternative to heavily monitored services like WeChat and Baidu, while the Chinese government strengthens data protection laws and foreign encrypted messaging apps face restrictions.

site_title: Nissan not currently considering asking CEO Saikawa to resign: sources
summary: Nissan's CEO Hiroto Saikawa is not expected to resign despite admitting to being overpaid in violation of internal procedures. An internal investigation found he and other executives received improper compensation, raising doubts about his pledge to improve governance. Saikawa apologized and vowed to return any improperly paid funds, but a board meeting on Monday is expected to discuss potential disciplinary action. Nissan's board is not currently considering asking Saikawa to resign, with one source stating "it's not going to happen."

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor is not currently considering asking embattled CEO Hiroto Saikawa to resign, two people with knowledge of the matter told Reuters on Friday, a day after he admitted to being overpaid in violation of internal procedures.

site_title: 'Spare our passengers': Hong Kong airport's plea to protesters
summary: Hong Kong's Airport Authority issued a newspaper ad pleading with protesters to spare passengers from further disruption ahead of another weekend of anti-China demonstrations. The ad, published in the South China Morning Post, urged demonstrators not to target the transport hub, which handles tens of thousands of travelers daily. Last weekend's protests resulted in violent confrontations, delayed or canceled flights, and damage to train stations and the high-speed rail link. The ad is part of efforts by Hong Kong authorities to combat the unrest, which continues despite the withdrawal of the extradition bill that sparked the protests.

site_title: More than a decade before driverless buses take over, says Volvo
summary: Volvo predicts bus drivers will be needed for at least 10-15 years before autonomous vehicles take over public transportation. The company's executive, Akash Passey, says autonomous technologies can boost efficiency and improve safety, reducing driver fatigue and increasing focus on the road. Volvo's full-sized driverless buses are set to begin trials at a Singapore university campus, with plans to extend to public roads. Singapore aims to operate autonomous buses in off-peak periods by 2022.

site_title: Singapore saw fewer suspicious financial transactions reported in 2018 but more intel gathered
summary: Singapore saw a decrease in suspicious financial transactions reported in 2018, with 32,660 reports filed, down from 35,471 in 2017. Despite the lower number of reports, data from the reports led to a 111% increase in financial intelligence reports circulated to domestic enforcement agencies. The Suspicious Transaction Reporting Office (STRO) also received 273 requests for assistance from foreign financial intelligence units and sent out 280 requests to its foreign counterparts. The CAD seized S$18.5 million of illicit proceeds from a criminal syndicate and prosecuted 133 individuals for money laundering offenses.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares track global rally as Sino-US tensions ease
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,641 on Friday, driven by a global rally as Sino-US tensions eased. The US and China agreed to hold high-level talks in October, boosting appetite for riskier assets. Strong US economic data also supported the rally. This marked a third consecutive weekly gain for the S&P/ASX 200 index.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 2.48 points to 1,602.23. The market saw a gain of 116 to 28 gainers to losers. No other information is provided.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied 0.97% in early trading on Friday, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street, where US private-sector jobs data showed a healthy increase. The Hang Seng Index rose to 26,773.13, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.13% and 0.45% respectively.

site_title: Cocoa trees being ravaged by a disease with no known cure
summary: A deadly disease, swollen-shoot, is ravaging cocoa trees in West Africa, affecting about three-quarters of the world's cocoa production. The disease, identified nearly a century ago, has no known cure and can take years to appear. Ghana, the world's second-largest cocoa producer, has cut its crop forecast by 11% due to the outbreak, with 16% of its cocoa crops infected. Scientists warn that if left unchecked, the disease could shift cocoa production to South America and the Caribbean, impacting the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands of small-scale farmers.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Hong Kong after months of protests
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Hong Kong's long-term foreign currency issuer default rating to "AA" from "AA+" due to months of unrest and protests in the region. The rating outlook is negative, citing concerns over the erosion of freedoms and autonomy under Chinese rule. The downgrade reflects Fitch's assessment of Hong Kong's creditworthiness, which has been impacted by the violent protests. The move is seen as a further blow to the city's reputation as a global financial hub.

site_title: Fed puts hard number on how much trade uncertainty dragged down growth
summary: The Federal Reserve research note reveals that trade-policy uncertainty is holding back global economic growth, accounting for a 0.8% decline in global GDP by the first half of 2019. The uncertainty, exacerbated by escalated trade tensions in May and June 2019, is expected to push down GDP further in the second half of 2019 and into 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on US-China talks, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, driven by a cheaper yen, planned US-China trade talks, and solid US economic data. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.54% to 21,199.57, while the Topix index rose 0.17% to 1,537.10. The US-China trade talks and a strong US economy also supported shares, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for weekend protests as Carrie Lam fails to appease activists
summary: Hong Kong is bracing for weekend protests as embattled leader Carrie Lam's withdrawal of a controversial extradition bill fails to appease some activists. Protesters plan to block traffic to the city's international airport on Saturday, a week after disruptions caused by demonstrators. The Airport Authority urged protesters not to disrupt the journey of tens of thousands of travelers. The move comes after thousands of demonstrators disrupted transport links, resulting in some of the worst violence since the unrest escalated three months ago.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Port Holdings Trust to exit STI amid trade tensions
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust, backed by Li Ka-shing, will be removed from Singapore's Straits Times Index due to a 84% drop in market value amid rising global trade tensions. The trust's operating income has fallen since 2016, and Hong Kong's container port has lost volumes to its neighbors. The removal marks the end of an era for the trust, which was one of the biggest IPOs in 2011. The Straits Times Index will be updated in December, with Mapletree Commercial Trust to be added.

site_title: Alibaba to buy luxury e-commerce business from Netease for US$2b
summary: Alibaba Group Holding acquired e-commerce business Kaola from NetEase Inc for US$2 billion, targeting China's luxury goods market. The platform specializes in cross-border shopping, offering high-end products directly from suppliers to consumers. Alibaba plans to operate Kaola independently while leveraging its ecosystem. The deal aims to boost growth in China's slowing e-commerce industry. Chinese consumers account for over a third of the global luxury goods market, and Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang stated that Kaola will further elevate import services for Chinese consumers.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise again as investors make most of feel-good vibe
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, driven by upbeat data and trade optimism. The US and China are set to resume high-level trade talks next month, and China is expected to unveil economy-boosting measures. The pound remains strong against the dollar, fueled by optimism about Britain avoiding a no-deal EU exit. However, analysts caution that the positive economic data may make it challenging for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates, with Fed boss Jerome Powell expected to deliver a tepid commentary.

site_title: Tech investor Naspers prepares to list global empire
summary: Naspers, a South African-based tech investor, is preparing to list its global empire, Prosus NV, valued at $100 billion. The separation will allow Naspers to attract more international investors and reduce its significant influence on the Johannesburg stock exchange. Prosus will include Naspers' stakes in companies such as OLX, Letgo, Swiggy, Delivery Hero, and iFood, which will continue to be backed by Naspers. The listing aims to narrow the discount on Naspers' Tencent Holdings stake and demonstrate the company's ability to invest in its portfolio companies.

site_title: In China, P2P insiders say regulatory shortcomings have choked industry
summary: China's peer-to-peer lending industry is struggling due to regulatory shortcomings, with many firms shutting down or struggling to meet requirements. The industry, once seen as crucial for the country's economy, has been plagued by pyramid scheme scandals and runaway bosses. Regulators have passed oversight to local governments, but these agencies lack the expertise and resources to confidently set standards. This has led to a lack of consistency in regulations, making it difficult for firms to plan. The industry's collapse threatens China's ability to balance financial risk and innovation.

site_title: Japanese scientists find new dinosaur species
summary: Japanese scientists have identified a new species of dinosaur, a hadrosaurid herbivore, from a nearly complete skeleton measuring 8 meters long. The skeleton, dated 72 million years old, was found in northern Japan after a partial tail was discovered in 2013. After analyzing hundreds of bones, the team from Hokkaido University concluded that the skeleton belonged to a new species. This discovery is the largest dinosaur skeleton found in Japan and provides new insights into the late Cretaceous period's flora and fauna.

site_title: Mexico moves to launch world's largest oil hedge programme: sources
summary: Mexico has begun its annual $1 billion oil hedging program by requesting quotes from banks for financial oil options contracts for 2020, a move seen as the world's top sovereign derivatives trade. The program aims to guarantee Mexico's revenues from oil exports by state oil company Pemex. Negotiations are secretive and limited to few participants, with market sources indicating increased buying in specific contracts expiring in June and the second half of 2020, amid volatile oil prices.

site_title: Robots displacing jobs means 120m workers need retraining: poll
summary: An IBM survey found that over 120 million workers globally will need retraining in the next three years due to the impact of artificial intelligence on jobs. This is a top concern for employers, who cite a talent shortage as a major threat. The training required is also longer, with workers needing 36 days to close a skills gap compared to three days in 2014. The shift towards soft skills is emphasized, as traditional job displacement due to AI is expected to be less significant.

site_title: Moon appointee's 'privileged' daughter angers young South Koreans
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In's nominee for justice minister, Cho Kuk, faces a parliamentary confirmation hearing amid a scandal surrounding his daughter's academic perks. The 28-year-old daughter allegedly received scholarships and was named as a first author of a medical paper despite her poor academic performance. The scandal has sparked protests and criticism from young South Koreans who feel the system is unfair and biased towards the elite. If confirmed, Prof Cho would oversee the prosecutors' office, but he has vowed not to receive reports on any investigation into his family.

images.alt_text: The scandal has struck a chord in South Korea where young people, who compete furiously through school and university, are increasingly finding themselves scrambling for a dwindling number of positions in a slack job market, in a system they see as plagued by systemic unfairness and bias in favour of the elite.

site_title: Singapore payment firms to tap specialised legal expertise on compliance under new plan
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) have launched a payments regulatory evaluation programme to connect fintech firms with lawyers specialising in payment services regulations. The programme aims to provide a streamlined process for firms to meet compliance needs. Seven local and international law firms in Singapore will participate in a two-month pilot run, with feedback to be taken into consideration for adjustments. The programme will help Singaporean payment firms tap into specialised legal expertise to ensure comprehensive regulatory assessments.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) have rolled out a payments regulatory evaluation programme to help connect the payments industry with legal service providers.

site_title: Deutsche Bank cutting dozens of jobs in fixed-income trading
summary: Deutsche Bank is cutting dozens of traders and salespeople in its global fixed-income unit, following a restructuring plan that includes 18,000 job reductions across all businesses. The cuts are largely tied to underperformance of certain divisions, such as the credit business in Latin America, which is being eliminated entirely. The bank had previously committed to maintaining most of the fixed-income unit, but is adjusting its plans to improve profitability. Senior executives, including managing directors and credit trading executives, are leaving as part of the restructuring efforts.

site_title: Australia's Westpac hit by class action lawsuit
summary: Westpac Banking Corp faces a class action lawsuit filed by law firm Slater and Gordon on behalf of thousands of superannuation members allegedly "shortchanged" by the bank's superannuation funds. The lawsuit targets Westpac subsidiaries BT Funds Management Ltd and Westpac Life Insurance Services Ltd. This comes after Slater and Gordon filed similar lawsuits against Commonwealth Bank of Australia and AMP last year. Westpac has announced it will defend itself against the class action.

site_title: WeWork dents the case for private markets
summary: WeWork's potential IPO valuation has plummeted to as low as $20 billion, significantly lower than its previous private valuation of $47 billion. The company's poor governance and unrealistic valuations are attributed to the influence of sovereign wealth funds and venture capitalists, such as SoftBank's Vision Fund, which has invested over $10 billion in WeWork. This trend suggests that private markets are not providing sufficient discipline for startups, potentially increasing the risk of failure.

site_title: Big Oil undermines UN climate goals with US$50b of new projects: report
summary: Major oil companies have approved $50 billion of projects since last year that won't be economically viable if governments implement the Paris Agreement on climate change. A report by Carbon Tracker found these projects, including those by Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and ExxonMobil, contradict the 2015 Paris Agreement's goal to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Oil majors are "betting heavily against a 1.5 degree Celsius world," according to report co-author Andrew Grant. This undermines efforts to meet the Paris Agreement's climate goals.

site_title: HKEX chief says derivatives trading glitch caused by software bug
summary: HKEX chief Charles Li stated a derivatives trading glitch was caused by a software bug, not human error. The bourse operator suspended trading in its derivatives market due to prolonged connectivity issues. The glitch occurred on a day after the market opened, with trading resumed in the afternoon and after-hours sessions. Li's statement addressed concerns about the cause of the issue, providing clarity on the matter.

site_title: India's auto industry urges government action to fight slowdown
summary: India's auto industry is urging the government to take urgent action to revive the sector, which is experiencing its worst slowdown in history, with sales set to drop for the 10th straight month in August. Executives from top automakers, including Tata Motors and Mahindra and Mahindra, called for a cut in the goods and services tax (GST) on vehicles to boost demand. The industry has already laid off 350,000 workers and faces dire consequences if the government doesn't act, with some warning of steeper production cuts and job losses if the slowdown continues.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars set for strong weekly gains, bonds see a sell-off
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are expected to see strong weekly gains as investors flock to risk assets amid positive US data and optimism on Sino-US trade talks. Australian and New Zealand sovereign bonds saw heavy selling, leading to multi-week highs in yields. The Australian dollar reached a one-month high of US$0.6809, up 1.1% for the week, while the New Zealand dollar gained nearly 1% to US$0.6376. Market analysts attribute the surge to improved risk sentiment and anticipation of a potential trade deal between the US and China.

site_title: Petrobras unit head removed amid bribery allegations
summary: Brazil's Petrobras unit head, Ivan de Sá, has been removed amid bribery allegations. A middleman implicated him in a plea bargain testimony, stating that Sá helped coordinate a scheme in which Petrobras employees accepted bribes from commodity trading firm Vitol in return for cut-price oil contracts. Sá denied the allegations, calling them "mere insinuation" without basis. The move follows a broader crackdown on graft allegations at Petrobras, with scores of executives and politicians charged with bribery schemes since President Jair Bolsonaro took office.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.6% to 3,164.72
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% to 3,164.72 on Friday, driven by optimism over US-China trade negotiations resuming in October and positive US data on private-sector hiring and services sector activity. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 1.4% and 1.3%, respectively. Key gainers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, and the banking trio DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen, US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a cheaper yen and US rallies following news of resuming high-level trade talks between the US and China. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.65% to 21,223.75, while the Topix index increased 0.48% to 1,541.89.

site_title: DR Congo cabinet chief fingered in US$15m graft scandal
summary: The cabinet chief of DR Congo President Felix Tshisekedi, accused of involvement in a US$15 million graft scandal, has been called upon by an opposition movement to stage a protest march on Friday despite an official ban. The alleged corruption stems from a government payment of US$100 million to oil companies for earnings shortfalls. The Lutte pour le Changement opposition movement is set to defy the ban and march in defiance of the allegations, which have raised concerns about corruption in the government.

site_title: H&M suspends Brazil leather purchases over Amazon fires
summary: H&M has suspended leather purchases from Brazil due to concerns over the Amazon fires. The Swedish clothing retailer will impose a temporary ban on orders until it has confidence that the leather is not causing environmental harm. This move comes after US-based VF Corporation also halted leather purchases from Brazil. The decision is part of H&M's efforts to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2030, and it joins a growing list of fashion industry firms prioritizing climate-friendly materials and practices.

site_title: Fintech startup Stripe offers lending service to customers
summary: Stripe, a fintech startup, launched Stripe Capital, a lending service for businesses. The service, starting in the US, provides loans of $10,000 to $20,000 to smaller businesses using Stripe. Stripe will use customer data to determine loan eligibility and terms. The company's co-founder, John Collison, stated that the service will focus on businesses with strong cash flow and growth potential. This move aims to expand Stripe's financial offerings and provide access to capital for businesses already using the platform.

site_title: North Korea wants reduced UN aid presence
summary: The United Nations is negotiating with North Korea to reduce its aid presence in the country, which Pyongyang claims has been politicized. North Korea requested the reduction in a letter, asking for it to occur before the end of the year. The move comes as working-level denuclearization talks with the US remain stalled. The UN is seeking to address North Korea's concerns, but the details of the negotiations have not been disclosed.

site_title: Friend of a friend: Facebook brings dating service to US
summary: Facebook has launched its online dating service, Facebook Dating, in the US, allowing over two billion users to connect for long-term relationships. The free service, available in 19 other countries, uses friends of friends and Instagram posts to facilitate romantic connections. Key features include a "Secret Crush" option, allowing users to secretly express interest in others, and the ability to report and block suspicious activity. The service prioritizes safety, security, and privacy, and will be free, unlike some rival dating apps.

site_title: Doctor In The House
summary: A new medical documentary series, Diagnosis, stars real-life doctor Lisa Sanders, who investigates mysterious illnesses with the help of internet crowdsourcing. The show features cases of patients with rare and unexplained symptoms, such as muscle pain and paralysis, and follows Dr. Sanders' process of gathering information and seeking diagnoses from medical experts and online communities. While not every episode has a happy ending, the show showcases the power of collaboration and the kindness of strangers in finding solutions to medical enigmas. Diagnosis is streaming on Netflix.

site_title: Trump administration considering increase in US biofuels mandates: document
summary: The Trump administration is considering a 1 billion-gallon increase in US biofuels mandates for 2020, comprising 500 million gallons for conventional biofuels and 500 million gallons for advanced biofuels like biodiesel. This move aims to address "excess waivers" given to small refineries and would add to the EPA's proposed 20.04 billion-gallon biofuel target for 2020. The plan would help quell farmer anger over recent exemptions for oil refiners.

site_title: Del Monte swings to US$38.3m loss in Q1 on lower revenue
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$38.3 million for its FY2020 first quarter, down from a US$3 million profit a year ago. Revenue fell 14% to US$375.9 million due to divestiture of its Sager Creek business and lower sales in the US and exports of processed pineapple products. Excluding one-off items, the company expects a recurring net income of US$4.1 million. The group plans to improve cash flow, strengthen its balance sheet, and reduce leverage, aiming to be profitable in FY2020.

site_title: Japan's July household spending up for 8th straight month, but at slower pace
summary: Japan's household spending rose 0.8% in July for an eighth consecutive month, but at a slower pace than expected. The growth fell short of a 1.1% forecast and was slower than the 2.7% rise in June. The slower pace highlights concerns about consumption in an economy weakened by the US-China trade war and a global slowdown, increasing pressure on the Bank of Japan to expand stimulus. This warning sign comes as risks from the global slowdown and trade standoff threaten economic growth.

site_title: Japan real wages drop for 7th straight month in July
summary: Japan's real wages dropped 0.9% in July, marking a seventh consecutive month of decline, amid concerns over sustained consumer spending. This follows a 0.5% annual decline in June and a 0.3% monthly decline in cash earnings. The drop is attributed to the country's economic struggles with slower global growth, including an eight-month export slump. The labour ministry's wage data has been questioned due to faulty polling methods, making it challenging to assess actual wage growth.

images.alt_text: Real wages in Japan adjusted for inflation fell for a seventh month in July, adding to worries whether consumer spending can be sustained while the economy wrestles with slower global growth.

site_title: WeWork mulls slashing IPO valuation as skepticism rises over business model: sources
summary: WeWork owner The We Company is considering slashing its initial public offering (IPO) valuation to around $20 billion, down from its previous valuation of $47 billion, amid growing investor skepticism over its business model and lack of profitability. The company has struggled with significant losses, burning through cash to expand, and has faced criticism over its governance and ties to co-founder Adam Neumann. A lower valuation could also impact the IPO expectations of other Silicon Valley unicorns.

site_title: No place like home: China firms stung by trade war build up domestic brands
summary: Chinese companies, such as Matsutek, are shifting focus from exporting to the US market to building domestic brands due to the trade war. This shift is prompted by declining sales and the introduction of tariffs on Chinese goods. Companies like Matsutek and Anhui Deli are promoting their own brands on e-commerce platforms, such as Alibaba's Tmall and Pinduoduo's e-commerce platforms. The move is expected to lead to fiercer competition for big foreign companies in the Chinese market, with some firms exploring alternative strategies, including transferring production to other countries.

site_title: Peugeot, Dongfeng agree to restructuring plan for Chinese venture
summary: Peugeot and Dongfeng Group have agreed to a restructuring plan for their joint venture, Dongfeng Peugeot Citroen Automobiles, in China. The plan aims to slash costs, reduce the break-even point to 150,000 vehicles by 2021, and boost annual sales to 400,000 units by 2025. The joint venture will consolidate manufacturing resources, dispose of idle assets, and launch 14 new models in China over the next three years, including electrified versions. This move follows a decline in the Chinese market, which contracted last year for the first time since the 1990s.

site_title: Asia's beaches go quiet as Chinese tourists stay home
summary: Chinese tourists are staying home, causing a decline in travel to South-east Asia's vacation belt, including Thailand and Indonesia. The economic malaise in China, combined with a weakening yuan, is affecting the region's tourism industry. The decline in Chinese arrivals is being felt across the region, with empty rooms in hotels and quiet beaches in Bali. This trend is a painful lesson for nations that had become overly dependent on China's economy.

site_title: Airports up the ante on the ground
summary: Airports are upgrading their lounges to compete with airlines for premium passengers. Top airlines are investing in luxurious amenities, including complimentary hot meals, champagne, and other perks. This strategy aims to lure frequent flyers and increase loyalty. As a result, airports are elevating their offerings to match those of airlines, creating a more appealing experience for high-end travelers.

site_title: Rapper Nicki Minaj announces retirement
summary: Nicki Minaj has announced her retirement from music to focus on her family, citing her engagement to music executive Kenneth Petty and an upcoming wedding. The 36-year-old rapper, known for hits like "Super Bass," made the surprise announcement on Twitter, saying she will "keep reppin" her fans until her death. Minaj's decision comes after a busy summer that included releasing a single and appearing in Megan Thee Stallion's song "Hot Girl Summer." The news has sparked speculation about a potential album drop, but Minaj has confirmed she is retiring from music.

site_title: Trudeau says China uses detentions as political tool
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau accused China of using "arbitrary detentions" as a tool for political gain, sparking concerns among Western allies. The move comes after China detained two Canadians, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, in retaliation for the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou. Trudeau stated that nations, including the US, UK, and Germany, have expressed similar concerns about China's tactics, which observers describe as "hostage diplomacy." Ottawa and Beijing have recently nominated new ambassadors, potentially paving the way for dialogue.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, MCT, HPH Trust, SATS, Del Monte, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit
summary: DBS Bank will issue A$700 million senior unsecured floating-rate notes on Sept 13 with a quarterly coupon of 63 basis points. Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) will join the Straits Times Index on Sept 23, replacing Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust). SATS acquired 49% of its food-distribution joint venture for S$17 million, and Del Monte Pacific swung to a net loss of US$38.3 million for its first quarter. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit changed its name and outsourced management to Pacific Oak Capital Advisors.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as new trade talks announced
summary: US stocks rose as new trade talks between the US and China were announced, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbing 1.4% to 26,728.15. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained, with the Nasdaq jumping 1.8% to 8,116.83. The announcement comes after data showed increased private-sector hiring and better-than-expected services sector activity. The news lifted hopes of possible progress in the ongoing trade war, which has hung over markets for over a year.

site_title: Ukraine releases MH17 'suspect' ahead of expected prisoner swap
summary: Ukraine released Vladimir Tsemakh, a suspected air defence specialist for pro-Russian separatists, ahead of an expected prisoner swap with Russia. Tsemakh's release came amid speculation he might be part of a high-profile prisoner exchange, prompting concern from the Netherlands that he may avoid questioning. The release of Tsemakh, a key suspect in the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17, has been met with criticism from European lawmakers and the Dutch MH17 victims foundation, who fear he may disappear or be killed in Russia.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally 1% on trade hopes, FTSE lags
summary: European stocks rallied 1% on Thursday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and positive corporate updates, including a surge in tariff-sensitive shares and a rally in banking shares. The gains were led by automakers, parts suppliers, and industrial goods, with banking shares rising 1.1% for a second day. However, Britain's FTSE 100 fell 0.6% due to several large-cap names trading ex-dividend. Investors also took heart from the formation of a new government in Italy and the UK parliament's progress in averting a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Trade uncertainty to cut 1% from US GDP: Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy is expected to lose about 1% in GDP through early 2020 due to trade uncertainty created by President Trump's global trade offensive. This uncertainty, fueled by tariffs and business concerns, has slowed world industrial production and global trade. Research from the Federal Reserve found similar decreases in GDP across advanced and emerging economies, with potential knock-on effects pushing down GDP further in the second half of 2019 and 2020. The uncertainty's impact is expected to be felt globally, with the Fed attributing it to escalations in trade tensions since May 2019.

site_title: Team behind world's first black hole image wins 'Oscar of science'
summary: The Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration, consisting of 347 scientists, won the Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics for the world's first image of a black hole. The image, captured on April 10, 2019, shows a supermassive black hole at the center of the Messier 87 galaxy, 55 million light years away. The team, led by Shep Doeleman at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, spent over a decade simulating a computational telescope to combine signals from eight radio telescopes worldwide. The $3 million prize, often referred to as the "Oscars of science," recognizes their groundbreaking achievement.

site_title: Grab to splurge US$150m on AI to build super app
summary: Grab Holdings plans to invest $150 million in artificial intelligence to enhance its super app, targeting users across Southeast Asia's diverse consumer and ethnic cultures. The company aims to improve fraud prevention and natural language processing tech, and expand its services to include lending and insurance. With a focus on localization, Grab believes AI will help it tailor its services to local markets, growing transactions on its food delivery platform three-fold in the first six months.

site_title: Muted response to two Government Land Sale sites, but third site pulls in nine bids
summary: Singapore's Government Land Sale (GLS) tenders yielded mixed results, with two sites in Tan Quee Lan Street and Bernam Street receiving fewer bids, while a third site in one-north Gateway attracted nine bids. Observers attribute the muted response to cautious developers seeking less competitive sites or lower quantum bids. The one-north Gateway site, requiring the least outlay, is seen as a more attractive option.

site_title: US democrats put climate crisis at heart of 2020 race
summary: US Democrats are focusing on the climate crisis as a key issue in the 2020 presidential election, with 10 hopefuls unveiling plans to transition away from fossil fuels and achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The emphasis comes amid concerns over the "existential threat" of climate change, following recent natural disasters like Hurricane Dorian.

site_title: France's cash-strapped Aigle Azur to cancel all flights
summary: France's second-largest airline, Aigle Azur, plans to cancel all flights starting Friday night due to financial difficulties. The airline had warned of potential flight cancellations and suspended ticket sales from September 10. Aigle Azur is seeking a takeover bid to save the company, which has been struggling with heavy losses and operational difficulties. The airline's largest shareholder, HNA Group, is exploring a white-knight offer to acquire the airline and its 1,150 employees. Passengers are advised to check their existing insurance for reimbursement.

images.alt_text: France's second-largest airline Aigle Azur, which went into receivership this week, plans to cancel all flights starting Friday night as it seeks a takeover bid to save the company, according to an internal document seen by AFP on Thursday.

site_title: 'Deepfake challenge' aims to find tools to fight manipulation
summary: A "deepfake challenge" has been launched to develop tools to detect manipulated videos and media by artificial intelligence. The $10 million initiative, backed by Facebook and Microsoft, aims to curb misinformation and curb the spread of manipulated content. The challenge, supported by top universities and industry partners, will produce technology that can detect AI-generated manipulated videos, which have significant implications for online information legitimacy. The goal is to improve detection tools and promote beneficial uses of artificial intelligence.

site_title: Take that, rat! New York turns to alcohol in rodent fight
summary: New York City has introduced a machine called Ekomille to combat its rat population, deploying a trap door that drops rats into a pool of alcohol-based liquid. The device, imported from Italy, was tested in a month-long trial and successfully killed 107 rats. The city's long-running efforts to cull the rat population have been met with varying success, but officials say the Ekomille is a humane and environmentally friendly solution to the "rat crisis" gripping the city. The device will be rolled out in some of Brooklyn's most rat-infested districts.

images.alt_text: The machine - called Ekomille - is battery operated and resembles a cabinet around 60cm high.

site_title: New York State Of Mind
summary: A Brooklyn couple, Gunjan and Showbhiq Kalra, recreated their NYC townhouse in a 6,800 sq ft home in Singapore. Designed by architect Matthew Lai of MU Architects, the two-storey bungalow with an attic features a facade clad in limestone, brick, and timber, and large open spaces with a gallery-like feel. The home includes a New York-style kitchen, a lap pool, and a walk-in wardrobe with a standalone tub. The couple incorporated distinctive elements from their Brooklyn home, including brick tiles, a porthole-shaped whisky cabinet, and a chandelier, to create a unique and nostalgic space.

site_title: Crazy Rich Asians writer says she's leaving sequel because of pay disparity
summary: Adele Lim, a screenwriter for the 2018 film Crazy Rich Asians, has left the sequel due to a pay disparity with co-screenwriter Peter Chiarelli, according to a Hollywood Reporter story. Lim, who was offered $110,000, claimed she was brought onto the project as "soy sauce" and not given equal credit or heavy storytelling work. The pay gap is the latest in a series of departures by female actors and writers of color from projects aimed at bridging the well-documented wage gap in Hollywood.

site_title: US sees 'modest' growth, while businesses show 'near-term' optimism: Fed
summary: The US economy grew at a "modest pace" in recent weeks, according to the Federal Reserve, despite escalating US-China trade tensions. Businesses remain optimistic about the near-term outlook, with vehicle sales and tourism rising, but farms are struggling due to bad weather, low prices, and trade uncertainties. Consumer spending is mixed, and employers face challenges in finding workers and offering higher pay. The Fed may cut interest rates again in two weeks to insulate the US economy from global weakness and mounting fears of economic damage from President Trump's trade wars.

site_title: Free traders may be losing the political fight
summary: The US economic nationalist President Donald Trump's anti-free-trade stance may be losing momentum, as public opinion polls show that most Americans support free trade policies. Contrary to conventional wisdom, a Gallup poll found that 51% of Americans believe trade with other countries has a positive effect on jobs, while 60-70% see trade as benefiting product innovation, US economic growth, and American businesses. Despite this, Trump and Democratic presidential candidates like Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren are adopting increasingly protectionist stances, potentially backfiring politically.

site_title: Oil little changed as US crude stockdraw countered by demand fears
summary: Oil prices remained little changed on Thursday as US crude inventories drew down 4.8 million barrels, the lowest since October 2018. Global benchmark Brent crude rose 25 cents to $60.95 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose 4 cents to $56.30. Despite a sharp drawdown, fears of slowing global demand growth amid the US-China trade feud kept prices in check. The prolonged trade dispute has been a dampener on oil prices, but production cuts by Opec and Russia have helped Brent rise 12% this year.

site_title: Millennial Sensation
summary: Irish author Sally Rooney, 28, has been hailed as the voice of her generation with her novels "Conversation With Friends" and "Normal People". Her writing style, though initially simple, reveals sharp and lucid observations about modern life, including the complexities of relationships and human insecurities. Rooney's relatable characters, who lead ordinary urban lives, make readers recognize their own desires, needs, and emotions. Despite her young age, Rooney's writing shows remarkable insight and gift, making her a promising literary talent, with her next work eagerly anticipated.

site_title: Solid homecoming by Jereme Leung at Yí
summary: Singapore-born chef Jereme Leung's debut restaurant Yí by Jereme Leung offers a winning combination of fantasy, art, and cooking at the Raffles Hotel. The elegant dining room features fine bone china and delicate floral patterns, while the menu showcases Leung's creations inspired by different regions in China with modern twists. Standout dishes include the Durian, Avocado, and Crab Tartare, the Eight-hour golden broth with scallops and prawns, and the Taiwanese beef noodles. While service is a bit restrained, the restaurant's harmonious blend of aesthetics, creativity, and execution earns it a 7.5-star rating.

site_title: Kao family makes S$0.28 delisting offer for San Teh
summary: The Kao family has made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.28 per share for San Teh Ltd, valuing the firm at S$95.8 million. This represents a premium of about 81.82% over the last traded price. The offer is aimed at delisting San Teh Ltd, a company that deals in property development, investment, and other industries.

site_title: Old Is Gold
summary: Retro shopping malls in Singapore are facing redevelopment or disappearance, sparking concern over the loss of the country's past. Independent creative Shaiful Risan is leading a tour to showcase the charms of these older malls, including People's Park Complex and Peninsula Shopping Centre, which have unique characters and histories. The tour, priced from $25, aims to provide an authentic, un-sterile experience, highlighting the nostalgia and charm of these strata-titled malls.

site_title: Putting people first
summary: Boards of directors are urged to prioritize human capital management to drive long-term growth and profitability. This includes focusing on senior executives, the entire company, society, and the board itself. Boards should ensure a holistic approach to organisational development, corporate culture, and succession planning. Key constituents include attracting and retaining top talent, defining desired skills and competencies, and investing in up-skilling and re-skilling employees. The board's oversight of human capital strategies is crucial to ensuring sustainable growth and profitability.

site_title: Porsche in talks to buy electric-car batteries from China
summary: Porsche is in talks with Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd (CATL) to procure electric-car batteries from China, expanding its supplier network to secure key components for future vehicles. Porsche's sister brand Audi is also in advanced talks to buy batteries from China's BYD. The German carmaker aims to get an exemption from a 10% purchase tax in China for its electric vehicles, with the goal of obtaining it within 2020. This move follows Volkswagen AG's existing partnership with CATL, which is building a plant in Germany to strengthen its presence in Europe.

site_title: Hong Kong's Carrie Lam resists protesters' demands for more action
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has resisted protesters' demands for more action after formally withdrawing the extradition bill, calling it a "first step" towards addressing the city's unrest. Despite the withdrawal, protesters and lawmakers say it's "too little, too late" and still want their remaining major demands met, including an independent inquiry into police tactics and the nomination of their own leaders. The protests, which have expanded beyond the bill, are expected to continue, with another "stress test" planned for transportation networks around the city's airport.

site_title: An ungovernable Britain is an alarm bell for foreign investors
summary: The UK's governance crisis has raised concerns among foreign investors, with the country's economy slipping into recession due to Brexit uncertainty and a global trade slowdown. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is determined to achieve Brexit by October 31, but his tactics, including ignoring parliamentary conventions and sacking opposition MPs, have sparked criticism. The opposition has tabled a bill that would allow Johnson until October 19 to negotiate a deal, but he rejected it. The UK is now at risk of a no-deal Brexit, which could lead to a general election and potentially impact the global economy.

site_title: China and US to hold trade talks in October as mistrust remains
summary: China and the US have agreed to hold face-to-face trade talks in Washington in early October, amid ongoing tariff tensions and concerns about the impact on the global economy. The talks aim to address issues such as China's refusal to make significant reforms, as sought by the US. The US is set to increase tariffs on Chinese goods on October 1 and December 15, with the IMF estimating a 0.8% reduction in global GDP growth in 2020 due to the current and upcoming tariffs.

site_title: New Singapore govt e-service to help banks combat fraud
summary: Singapore has launched a new e-service, Trade Finance Compliance (TFC), to help banks combat fraud and money laundering in trade financing. Created by a joint partnership between Singapore Customs, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and financial institutions, the service allows financial institutions to reference data from permits issued by Singapore Customs to augment their checks for trade finance compliance. Currently, six major banks have signed up for the service, which aims to increase efficiency and accuracy in trade finance compliance checks, enabling financial institutions to better assess fraud risks.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit changes name to Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit changed its name to Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, effective September 5. The Reit's manager also announced a reorganisation of its asset management team and a new outsourcing management agreement with Pacific Oak Capital Advisors LLC. The Reit's portfolio comprises 12 US office buildings and has a combined asset value of US$1.09 billion, with a technology focus in Seattle, Austin, and Denver. The counter closed at US$0.74 on the day of the announcement, down 1.5 US cents or 1.99 per cent.

site_title: Different grapes from different regions, all screaming Italy
summary: Italian red wines, made from various non-native and native grapes, share a common signature of great acidity, sweet fruit, and refreshing bitterness, despite regional differences. Three wines from Italy's Alto Adige, Tuscany, and Piedmont showcase this characteristic, including Elena Walch's 2018 Schiava, Foradori's 2016 Teroldego, and G.B. Burlotto's 2017 Freisa. These wines, made from lesser-known grapes, demonstrate the diversity and complexity of Italian wines, which transcend regional boundaries and commercial pressures.

site_title: Volvo's revival: How Ford's folly turned into Geely's gold
summary: Volvo Cars, once put up for sale by Ford in 2009, has flourished under Chinese ownership by Geely, achieving its best full year on record in 2018 with 642,253 car sales. The company has seen steady growth, selling 340,286 cars in the first six months of 2019, with an operating profit of S$780 million. Geely's hands-off approach has allowed Volvo to run independently, enabling the brand to develop new models, such as the S60 and V60, and invest in electric drive technology and artificial intelligence computing. Volvo is on track to outperform 2018, with a record-breaking year expected.

site_title: Elon Musk, take note: Porsche's electric Taycan is coming to Singapore
summary: Porsche's electric Taycan is set to arrive in Singapore by the second quarter of 2020, offering a genuine Porsche driving experience despite being an electric vehicle. The car, which boasts up to 761 horsepower, can travel up to 412km on a full charge and charge to 80% in 20 minutes. Porsche has collected 30,000 deposits worldwide and plans to price the Taycan between the Cayenne and Panamera lines, with the exact pricing for Singapore yet to be confirmed. The Taycan is part of Porsche's strategy to electrify half of its cars by 2025.

site_title: India needs to revive economy to be on track for a US$5t GDP
summary: India's economy, aiming to reach a $5 trillion GDP by 2024, has seen a dramatic decline in growth, plummeting to 5% in the April-to-June quarter. Manufacturing activity has also slumped, with car sales crashing 29% in August. The government has rolled back budgetary provisions and announced bank mergers to tackle non-performing assets. To revive the economy, India needs to grow at 9% a year for the next five years, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi must prioritize reforms and signal intent to boost investor confidence and revive the "animal spirit" of risk-taking.

site_title: Fewer HDB resale flats sold in August, prices up slightly: SRX
summary: Fewer HDB resale flats were sold in August, with 1,921 units changing hands, a 9.4% decline from July and 7.6% lower than the same month last year. Resale prices showed a slight increase of 0.1% compared to July, but were 0.6% lower than August last year. The highest transacted price was S$1.2 million for a five-room Pinnacle@Duxton flat. Demand remains resilient, with 1,511 flats approaching their five-year minimum occupation period, but a buyers' market is expected due to increased competition.

site_title: Conservative Party: Bourgeois style is back
summary: Fashion designers Hedi Slimane, Demna Gvasalia, and Riccardo Tisci have shifted their focus from subversive, youth-inspired styles to a more traditional, bourgeois aesthetic for their Fall/Winter collections. This season's designs feature classic, high-end pieces such as buttonless coats, minimalist pantsuits, and ladylike dresses, reflecting a desire for stability and practicality in fashion. The trend is seen as a reaction to the unpredictable nature of streetwear, with designers embracing a more polished, refined look.

site_title: Prison On Fire
summary: A Netflix documentary "Happy Jail" showcases life in the Cebu Provincial Detention and Rehabilitation Center (CPDRC) through the unorthodox management of ex-convict Marco Toral. Toral, appointed as Special Consultant, brings an interesting approach to the overcrowded prison, earning love from inmates but criticism from the outside. The documentary follows the events when an inmate escapes, highlighting the complexities of prison life. The film offers a glimpse into the realities of prison life, far from the fictional portrayal in TV shows like "Orange is the New Black."

site_title: Far East Hospitality to open its first hotel in Japan ahead of Tokyo 2020
summary: Far East Hospitality will open its first hotel in Japan, Village Hotel Ariake Tokyo, in the second quarter of 2020, ahead of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The 306-key hotel is a joint venture between FEH and Far East Organization, located near the Ariake waterfront area. This marks the first Village brand hotel outside of Singapore. FEH aims to capitalize on Japan's growing mid-tier market and raise brand exposure in the country.

site_title: Certis wins contract to manage security for over 60 JTC properties
summary: The JTC Corporation has appointed security firm Certis to manage advanced integrated security solutions for over 60 properties in Singapore, spanning a 150 square-kilometre area. The properties include community spaces, industrial buildings, and vacant land. This contract marks a significant expansion of Certis' services and highlights the importance of integrated security solutions in managing large-scale properties.

images.alt_text: Digital technology being applied at the Certis Integrated Operations Centre, where staff monitor many different areas without having to deploy employees on-site.

site_title: Celebrities raise S$13.2k for charity
summary: Celebrities Li Nanxing and Christopher Lee raised S$13,200 for charity at a cooking event in Singapore. The funds were split equally between The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, supporting children and low-income families. The event aimed to make arts accessible for disadvantaged youths and provide financial assistance to students in need.

site_title: Best Of Both Worlds
summary: The Casio G-Shock GA-2100 has been released with a unique design featuring an octagonal bezel resembling Audemars Piguet's Royal Oak. The watch boasts an analogue aesthetic with hour and minute hands, a day indicator subdial, and retains the brand's signature durability thanks to the Carbon Core Guard. Available in three colourways, the GA-2100 retails for S$169, offering a blend of design and functionality characteristic of G-Shock watches.

site_title: Users worry about smart speaker privacy, but can't stop buying them
summary: Despite growing concerns about smart speaker privacy, consumers continue to buy machines like Amazon's Echo and Google Home. A Capgemini Research Institute report found that users are worried about "passive listening" and eavesdropping, but purchases are not decreasing. The report suggests that people are willing to compromise on privacy for the convenience and benefits of smart speakers. The findings contradict previous reports that indicated a decline in smart speaker sales due to privacy concerns.

site_title: CLMV countries must step up reform of business and financial ecosystems
summary: Thailand plans to collaborate with the CLMV bloc, aiming to boost economic growth and investment in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam. The CLMV Exposure Index on the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) is set to launch a board listing stocks from its neighbors, increasing access to Thailand's capital market. However, the CLMV countries need to raise standards of doing business to attract more investors, with their combined market capitalization being only 0.3% of Thailand's. This collaboration aims to promote economic development and stability in the region amidst global competition.

site_title: Fine Dining For Kids
summary: Fine dining restaurants are relaxing their no-kids policies to introduce young palates to haute cuisine. Several Michelin-starred restaurants, including Cloudstreet, Saint Pierre, and Labyrinth, now welcome children nine years and under with specially designed menus and interactive experiences. Experts believe that fine dining can help children develop good eating habits and broaden their palates, with chefs emphasizing the importance of exposing children to a variety of cuisines from a young age.

site_title: Ascott eyes millennials with its first co-living space lyf Funan
summary: The Ascott has opened lyf Funan Singapore, its first co-living space, offering 412 rooms across 279 apartments in a nine-storey property spanning 121,000 sq ft. The property features five apartment types with room rates starting from S$150, catering to short and long stays. The goal is to provide collaborative spaces and social programs for a live-work-play experience, targeting millennials.

site_title: Safran raises profit forecasts after strong 1st half results
summary: Safran, a French aerospace supplier, raised its full-year profit forecasts after reporting stronger-than-expected first-half profits. The company's recurring operating income rose 36% to 1.883 billion euros, driven by higher margins across three reorganized divisions. Revenues increased 27% to 12.102 billion euros. The positive results sent shares sharply higher, with Safran's shares rising on the news.

site_title: Charles Schwab to close Singapore office by year's end
summary: Charles Schwab will close its Singapore office by year's end, citing a review of its business outside the US. The brokerage will focus its resources on markets in Hong Kong, China, Latin America, the UK, and Europe, where it can serve retail investors at scale. Existing clients will need to transfer their funds to a new broker-dealer or liquidate their investments by December 31. The decision follows a successful system integration and accounts migration in 2017, but is likely due to competitive fees and investors' preference for local brokerages.

site_title: Where to show off your US$5m horse
summary: The Hampton Classic, a prestigious outdoor horse show in Bridgehampton, New York, is a popular event where horse enthusiasts can showcase their prized possessions. For those who can afford it, the show offers a unique opportunity to display their high-end horses, with prices ranging from $500,000 to $6 million. However, the event's popularity among horse enthusiasts, particularly parents with young children, can be a gateway to a costly horse sport addiction.

site_title: Risky currencies flourish on investor optimism
summary: Investors turned optimistic about a potential US-China trade deal, causing the Japanese yen to drop to a three-week low and other risky currencies to rise. The Australian dollar reached a one-month high, while the New Zealand dollar and Chinese yuan also saw gains. The US dollar strengthened against the euro and other major currencies, with the pound and Swedish crown also benefiting from positive market sentiment. However, experts caution that the agreement is not a significant step towards resolving trade tensions.

site_title: China signals further stimulus on the cards as economic headwinds worsen
summary: China's State Council signaled further economic stimulus, including a potential reduction in reserve ratios and measures to lower borrowing costs, amid worsening economic headwinds. The move aims to funnel credit into the slowing economy, following a similar broad cut in January and targeted cuts in May. Economists expect policy measures to provide support to the real economy, but uncertainties remain on the extent of loosening. The government also plans to accelerate the issuance of special bonds for infrastructure spending, with the goal of expanding sectors such as transport and healthcare.

site_title: Koon's auditor does not, and is not required to, express an audit opinion from review of IFI
summary: Koon Holdings' auditor, Ernst & Young LLP, reviewed the company's interim financial information for the six months ended June 30, 2019. The auditor's review was conducted in accordance with the Singapore Standard on Review Engagements 2410, which does not require an expression of an audit opinion. The auditor did not express a conclusion on the IFI due to insufficient information to assess the appropriateness of the going concern assumption, but also noted that it is not required to express an audit opinion. The disclaimer of conclusion was issued as a precautionary measure.

site_title: Recessions have become rarer and more scary
summary: The world is ill-equipped to fight a recession, having experienced fewer downturns in recent decades. The current economic expansion, the longest on record, makes a global recession unlikely, but potentially traumatic and unanticipated. With interest rates at zero or close to it, central banks have limited room to respond to a slowdown. The US Federal Reserve, led by Janet Yellen, argues that longer expansions lead to fewer recessions. The economy's reduced volatility, structural shift towards services, and central banks' success in stabilizing inflation also contribute to the rarity of recessions.

site_title: Kam For Laughs
summary: Stand-up comedian Joanne Kam, known for her risqué jokes, is set to perform in Singapore at the Merry Lion on September 6 and 7. A popular figure in Malaysia, Kam has also appeared on TV and radio, produced theater shows, and written for Esquire magazine. Her solo stand-up show is expected to include jokes about men, relationships, and self-deprecation. Tickets are available for S$20 through Sistic.

site_title: Boss Is Back
summary: Hugo Boss launches its new flagship store in Singapore, featuring a lifestyle experience with food bars, comfortable surroundings, and an LED screen for brand-related content. The store opens on Sep 6-8, showcasing the brand's Fall/Winter 2019 collections, along with a photo exhibition of Singapore's first local BOSS ambassador, Joseph Schooling.

site_title: Incumbent banks must leverage tech - or be disrupted
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced it will accept applications for digital bank licenses until the end of this year. The licenses are open to banks and non-banking companies, with a focus on minimum capital requirements and regulatory compliance. This move aims to introduce virtual banking to Singapore, with companies like Razer and Grab expressing interest. Virtual banks in other countries have already shown success, offering services such as credit cards, loans, and deposits. However, traditional banks must innovate to remain competitive, as virtual banks may disrupt the market with new technologies and business models.

site_title: Firms chase sustainability expertise
summary: Singapore's corporate and investor awareness of sustainability issues is driving demand for related expertise, with regulatory changes playing a key role. The Singapore Exchange's requirement for listed firms to report on sustainability has led to an increase in interest and demand for sustainability services. Larger corporates are expected to shift towards in-house teams, while smaller firms are relying on consultants. The talent pool for sustainability services is growing, with young professionals showing particular concern for the environment and an interest in "purposeful work".

site_title: Nissan probe finds CEO Saikawa, other execs overpaid
summary: Nissan's internal investigation found that CEO Hiroto Saikawa and other executives received improper compensation, including tens of millions of yen through a stock-related scheme. The probe raises doubts about Saikawa's pledge to improve governance after Carlos Ghosn's arrest. Saikawa apologized and vowed to return improperly paid funds, while the company's board will discuss disciplinary action at an upcoming meeting. The scandal may exacerbate tensions with top shareholder Renault, which is discussing reforms to win Nissan's support for a renewed alliance with Fiat Chrysler.

site_title: True Lies
summary: A new play called "Caught" by Singapore Repertory Theatre challenges traditional theatre experiences by allowing audience members to participate in its events, changing the story and outcome based on their choices. Staged in a real art gallery, the play follows a dissident Chinese artist whose version of the truth shifts throughout the performance. Director Ed Sylvanus Iskandar describes the experience as a "live social video game" where audience members can progress through levels, influencing the story's outcome. The play has received positive reviews in the US and will be staged in Singapore from September 10 to October 6.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on September 5, 2019. The puzzle features clues related to various topics, including animals, travel, and everyday life. The solution to the puzzle was published as a PDF document. The puzzle's content is not explicitly stated to be related to any specific news event or topic.

site_title: Nathan Yong, Industrial Designer
summary: Singaporean industrial designer Nathan Yong is showcasing his 30 past works and 10 new pieces in a solo exhibition, "The Scheme of Things, Nathan Yong: A Retrospective Show 1999-2019." Yong, who has worked in the industry for 20 years, shares his career highs, including selling a piece to Ligne Roset and being named Designer of the Year at the President's Design Awards. However, he also discusses the challenges of being a furniture designer in Singapore, citing the lack of production and manufacturing opportunities. Yong's exhibition runs from September 14 to October 6 at the National Design Centre.

site_title: Mid-autumn At Mandarin
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore is celebrating the Mid-Autumn Festival with its limited edition mooncakes, including piglet-shaped and snowskin varieties. The Mid-Autumn collection features new flavors such as Cempedak with Low Sugar Pandan Paste and Charcoal-baked Yuzu and Mixed Nuts with Black Sesame Paste. The collection is available at the Festive Counter at Level 1 Lobby until Sep 13.

images.alt_text: The Mid-Autumn collection is available at Mandarin Orchard Singapore's Festive Counter at Level 1 Lobby until Sep 13.

site_title: Taking concrete steps to advance Southeast Asia's digital economy
summary: Southeast Asia's digital economy is expected to grow to $200 billion by 2025, but its full potential is being hindered by regulatory barriers and constraints. The region's digital economy was worth $31 billion in 2015, and a common set of standards for data handling and digital commerce could significantly increase this value. A new strategy is needed to balance digital innovation and regulation, and consensus must be built from the bottom up, rather than relying on a top-down solution. Regional cooperation and collaboration among countries, governments, and tech companies are crucial to achieving a coherent and coordinated digital economy.

site_title: Walking Gourmet
summary: A travel company, Walk Japan, is launching Onsen Gastronomy tours in Japan, combining hiking and relaxation. The tours, in Gifu and Nagano (Oct) and Oita and Kumamoto (Nov), feature 6-8km hikes daily, visits to local sites, and seasonal produce. Participants stay in local inns and soak in private hot springs. Each tour accommodates 12 guests and spots are filling up fast, with more information available at walkjapan.com.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: STAMFORD Tyres Corp posted a 12.5% net profit increase to S$126,000 for the first quarter ended July 31, 2019. Revenue fell 4.87% to S$56.4 million, mainly due to lower sales in North Asia. Operating expenses decreased 5.1% to S$13.1 million due to lower staff costs, marketing, and foreign exchange costs.

site_title: Staying Power: Veteran design creatives mark their 20-year milestone
summary: Five veteran design creatives, Chris Lee, Lim Koon Park, Robin Tan, Cecil Chee, and Pann Lim, mark their 20-year milestone in the competitive design industry. Lee, a former head of design at BBH and Ogilvy & Mather, shifted his focus to spatial design and branding, leading to notable projects like the Johnnie Walker House in Shanghai and The Warehouse Hotel in Singapore. Park expanded his firm's services from houses to bigger public projects, winning design competitions for schools and a Maldivian resort. Tan and Chee of Wallflower Architecture + Design prefer smaller, intimate buildings and have built a reputation for their work in commercial interiors. Lim, co-founder of Kinetic Singapore, credits teamwork and simple pleasures as key to the firm's 20-year success, garnering nearly 500 awards.

site_title: Samsung to launch foldable smartphone after major delay
summary: Samsung will launch its first foldable smartphone on Friday, months after a delay due to faulty screens. The Galaxy Fold was nearly eight years in development but was held back in April after reviewers reported screen problems. The company has since addressed the issues and is now ready to unveil the device. This marks a significant milestone for Samsung, which had been eager to enter the foldable market.

site_title: Johnson's brother quits parliament, torn between family loyalty and national interest
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's brother, Jo, has resigned as a junior minister and lawmaker, citing a conflict between family loyalty and national interest. The move comes days after Boris Johnson expelled 21 Conservative lawmakers, including Winston Churchill's grandson, for not backing his Brexit strategy. Jo Johnson's resignation is the latest in a series of departures among Conservative lawmakers over Brexit, highlighting the deep divisions within the party.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OCBC Bank maintains its "Buy" rating with a target price of S$14.48. Analysts expect the bank to increase its 20% stake in Bank of Ningbo, a Chinese bank, as permitted by Chinese authorities. OCBC aims to double its profit from China's Greater Bay Area to S$1 billion by 2023, supporting capital deployment for this expansion.

site_title: DBS to issue A$700m of senior unsecured floating-rate notes due 2022
summary: DBS Bank Ltd has priced a three-year senior unsecured floating-rate note issue of A$700 million, with expected investment-grade ratings from Moody's and Fitch. The notes, part of a US$30 billion global multi-currency medium-term note programme, pay a quarterly coupon consisting of the three-month Bank Bill Swap reference rate plus a 63 basis point spread. The notes are expected to be issued on September 13, 2022.

site_title: ESR-Reit secures railway firm as tenant at Tuas industrial property
summary: ESR-Reit secured a new lease for approximately 168,846 square feet at its Tuas industrial property with P-Way Construction and Engineering, accounting for about one-fifth of the property's total lettable area. The lease terms, including duration and rent amount, were not disclosed. This marks a significant addition to the industrial Reit's portfolio, with the deal contributing to the property's overall occupancy rate.

site_title: SPH, SGX and FTSE Russell celebrate 12 years of STI
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) celebrated 12 years of the Straits Times Index (STI) with a symbolic gong-striking ceremony. The STI, developed by SPH, SGX, and FTSE Russell, tracks the performance of top 30 stocks listed on SGX and serves as the benchmark index for the local stock market. Over the years, the index has evolved to reflect changes in the market, emphasizing data and methodology. This milestone marks SGX's 20th anniversary and SPH's 35th anniversary, highlighting the strong partnerships between the three organizations.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust to replace Hutchison Port Holdings Trust on STI
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) will replace Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) on the Straits Times Index (STI) starting September 23. This change will bring the combined weightage of the four Reits in the STI to around 8%. MCT's inclusion maintains a weightage close to 1.5%, according to market strategist Geoff Howie. The move aims to diversify the index's composition and enhance its representation of the Singapore real estate market.

site_title: US factory orders increase for second straight month
summary: US factory orders rose 1.4% in July, the second consecutive month of growth, driven by a 7.0% increase in transportation equipment orders, the largest in nearly a year. However, underlying weakness in the sector, trade tensions, and reduced business confidence are expected to erode gains. Shipments of manufactured goods fell 0.2% and unfilled orders remained unchanged. The strong gains in aircraft orders are likely temporary due to Boeing's 737 MAX plane being grounded.

images.alt_text: New orders for US-made goods rose for a second straight month in July as orders for transportation equipment increased by the most in nearly a year, but the gains were unlikely to be sustained as trade tensions erode business confidence.

site_title: Sevak's CEO appointed as executive chairman
summary: Sevak Limited has appointed Maneesh Tripathi, its CEO, as executive chairman, effective September 6. Tripathi will continue to hold the group CEO position. The decision aims to formulate a new strategy for growth and guide the company's planned execution, according to the company.

site_title: Kao family makes S$0.28 delisting offer for San Teh
summary: The Kao family, owners of Mainboard-listed San Teh Ltd, has made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.28 per share to delist the company. The offer values San Teh Ltd at S$95.8 million, representing an 81.82% premium over the last traded price. The offeror controls 67.24% of shares and aims to accumulate 90% of voting rights to complete the deal. The delisting is seen as a means to gain greater control and management flexibility for the company.

site_title: Prudential buys Assurance IQ for US$2.35b in new tech bet
summary: Prudential Financial Inc is acquiring online insurance startup Assurance IQ Inc for $2.35 billion, as part of a trend of traditional insurers investing in technology and data crunching. Assurance brings 17 million customers to Prudential and is expected to add a new earning stream not sensitive to market fluctuations. The deal is part of a broader trend of large insurers betting on Silicon Valley startups to disrupt the traditional insurance space.
