site_title: Tan Quee Lan site underwhelms with two bids, one-north Gateway site secures nine bids
summary: Three Government Land Sale (GLS) tenders in Singapore closed with varying results. The Tan Quee Lan Street site secured only two bids, with GuocoLand, Hong Leong Group, and Hong Leong Investment Holdings leading with a top bid of S$800.19 million. In contrast, the one-north Gateway site attracted nine bids, with TID Residential leading the pack at S$155.74 million. Experts attribute the differing responses to macroeconomic headwinds and weaker economic outlook, as well as the smaller capital requirements for the Tan Quee Lan site.

site_title: US banking sector reports US$62.6b in profits for Q2 of 2019
summary: The US banking sector reported a 4.1% increase in profits to US$62.6 billion in the second quarter of 2019, driven by higher net interest income. This represents a US$2.5 billion increase from the prior year. The number of "problem banks" also fell to 56, the lowest level since 2007.

site_title: Temasek partners Kuehne+Nagel to launch US$50m global fund
summary: Temasek Holdings has partnered with Kuehne + Nagel to launch a US$50 million global fund focused on investing in startups at the forefront of the logistics and supply chain industry. Based in Singapore, the fund will back six to eight startups in verticals such as AI, digital logistics, and trade finance. This inaugural fund aims to support growth-stage startups and disrupt supply chain and logistics.

site_title: Audi Q3 Sportback review: Your Q to shine
summary: Audi Q3 Sportback review: The Audi Q3 Sportback combines sporty styling with practicality, making it an ideal choice for those who want a sports car without the high maintenance costs. The vehicle features a 2.0-liter engine and offers a comfortable driving experience. With its sleek design and spacious interior, the Audi Q3 Sportback is a suitable option for those seeking a versatile SUV.

site_title: Pretty Eyes
summary: Videre Eyecare, a salon in Singapore, has introduced a unique concept combining eye health and beauty services. The salon uses state-of-the-art equipment for comprehensive eye screenings and augmented reality technology for virtually trying on colored lenses with makeup looks. Customers can also receive beauty consultations and makeup tutorials. Videre Eyecare's CEO, Francis Wong, attributes the growing demand for this concept to beauty seekers looking for a holistic experience. The salon is located at The Centrepoint and offers a one-stop-shop for eye health and beauty services.

images.alt_text: Videre Eyecare - which claims to be the first salon in the world to combine eye health and beauty in one stop.

site_title: News of US-China October talks lifts market
summary: US-China trade talks to resume in October, boosting investor confidence. Hong Kong's withdrawal of the extradition Bill also lifted market sentiment, with Singapore's Straits Times Index rising 0.5% to 3,147.06. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding remained the most active counter, and three banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, ended higher. The market's risk-on tone has improved, with investors seeking positive trade war headlines, but the blue-chip index still had seven counters in the red.

site_title: EMS Energy to be delisted from SGX on Oct 4
summary: EMS Energy Limited will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange on October 4, 2019, due to failing to submit a resumption proposal by the deadline and not securing a deadline extension approval. The company will cease trading and continue as an unlisted public limited company with existing shareholders. It had previously announced it was not in a financial position to make an exit offer, citing financial constraints. Shareholders will receive physical share certificates through arrangements with the share registrar and Central Depository Ltd.

site_title: UBS to revamp investment bank in effort to lift flagging earnings
summary: UBS plans to revamp its investment bank, merging its main equities unit with foreign exchange, rates, and credit trading operations to form a single 'Global Markets' unit. The restructuring, expected to be completed by the end of the year, may result in hundreds of job cuts, particularly in higher ranks. The move aims to boost earnings and curb costs amid tough market conditions, following a performance dip. The shake-up is part of a broader effort to address UBS' sluggish client trading and client activity, which has remained subdued in recent years.

site_title: E-sports firm Team Flash expands to Vietnam, raises US$1.5m in seed funding
summary: Team Flash, a Singapore-based e-sports firm, has secured US$1.5 million in seed funding to expand its operations to Vietnam. The funding, led by Octava, a Singapore-based family office, will be used to secure the company's leadership in the Vietnamese market and establish brand sponsorships and a dedicated merchandising arm. Team Flash's Vietnam team won the championship at the Arena of Valor (AOV) World Cup, and the company plans to focus on the South-east Asian market, including Indonesia and Thailand, in the next 12 months.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on easing trade tensions
summary: US stocks rose for a second session on Thursday, driven by easing trade tensions between Washington and Beijing, which agreed to hold high-level talks next month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.94%, 0.78%, and 1.06%, respectively. The news lifted market sentiment and raised hopes for a de-escalation in trade tensions, contributing to a rally in US stocks.

site_title: GM will use Google to power future infotainment systems
summary: General Motors (GM) will integrate Google technology into its infotainment systems starting in 2021, offering Google Assistant, Google Maps, and other applications. This partnership marks a significant shift for GM, which had previously been hesitant to share dashboard space with tech companies. Google will not have access to data on individual driving habits or vehicle maintenance needs, but will enable voice commands for scheduling maintenance. GM will continue to offer Apple's CarPlay and Android Auto, and will launch Google's voice assistant in all vehicle brands outside China.

site_title: Singapore shares continue to post gains, STI adds 0.5% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% on Thursday, closing at 3,147.06, driven by improved investor confidence following China's announcement of trade talks with the US and Washington. This comes after Hong Kong scrapped its extradition bill. The rally follows a 5-day gain for Singapore stocks, ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: Stamford Tyres Q1 profit up 12.5 per cent
summary: STAMFORD Tyres reported a 12.5% net profit increase to S$126,000 for Q1 2019, driven by a net loss of S$41,000 from joint ventures. Total revenue fell 4.87% to S$56.4 million, mainly due to lower sales in North Asia. Operating expenses decreased 5.1% to S$13.1 million, primarily due to lower staff and marketing costs. Shares closed flat at S$0.24.

site_title: Parliament's next Brexit brawl: When to hold elections
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to call for a snap general election as his Brexit plan stalls. Lawmakers from both parties want to hold elections, but opposition lawmakers are pushing for a say over the timing. Johnson's Conservative Party is divided, and his team is framing the Brexit law as a "surrender" to the EU. The Labour Party is divided over when to hold an election, with some lawmakers preferring a mid-October vote to prevent a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: US private payrolls accelerate; weekly jobless claims rise
summary: US private payrolls increased by 195,000 jobs in August, suggesting the economy remains strong despite trade tensions and slowing global growth. The unemployment rate is expected to hold at 3.7% for the third straight month. Initial jobless claims rose 1,000 to 217,000 for the week ended Aug. 31, and the four-week moving average of initial claims increased 1,500 to 216,250. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates again this month due to the ongoing trade war with China.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Charles Schwab is closing its Singapore office, citing the high cost of doing business in the country. Vietnam was surprised by the US's announcement of a potential tariff reduction, while the Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs. Malaysia's government plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, Citigroup forecasts a 1,150-point target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. In other news, Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter will be cleared as prime minister in an ethics case, and the UK economy contracted for the second month in a row.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end flat
summary: Hong Kong shares ended flat on Thursday, following a near-four percent surge the previous day, amid news that China and the US will resume trade talks next month. The Hang Seng Index decreased 7.70 points to 26,515.53, while mainland Chinese markets rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.96 percent.

site_title: Fortress Minerals' subsidiary served writ of summons over workplace accident
summary: A Fortress Minerals subsidiary, Fortress Mining Sdn Bhd, has been served a writ of summons by the Kuala Terengganu Session Court in Malaysia over a workplace accident at its Bukit Besi Mine, resulting in the death of a plant operator. The court has fixed a return date of Sept 23, 2019. The company is seeking legal advice amid the lawsuit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.14 points lower at 1,599.75 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 1.9 billion lots worth RM 1.6 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 431 to 308.

site_title: SATS acquires remaining 49% in JV company for S$17m
summary: SATS Limited has acquired the remaining 49% stake in joint venture company SATS BRF Food Pte Ltd for S$17 million. The deal is part of a previously announced agreement. The book value and net tangible asset value of the acquired equity interest are S$20.8 million each, based on SBRF's management accounts as of August 31, 2019.

site_title: Loch Ness monster might just be a giant eel, say scientists
summary: Scientists analyzing DNA samples from Loch Ness found high levels of eel DNA, suggesting the "Loch Ness monster" may be a giant eel. The team, led by Professor Neil Gemmell, ruled out large animals like dinosaurs, but can't exclude the possibility of a giant eel. Despite the idea of a giant eel existing for decades, no one has ever caught one in the loch. The use of environmental DNA sampling is a new tool for monitoring marine life, and the findings leave the mystery of Nessie unresolved.

site_title: 8Telecom returns shares in Arete M, is classified as cash company
summary: 8Telecom International has returned shares in Arete M Pte Ltd, a cash company, after cancelling promissory notes related to a 2016 acquisition. The shares were returned in exchange for the cancellation, as the company was unable to pay the notes. Arete M ceased to be a subsidiary of 8Telecom on September 4. This move was agreed upon by the board after an agreement with minority shareholders on August 20.

site_title: New ICAEW chartered accountants to learn data analytics, take modified exams
summary: The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW) is introducing data analytics into its Associate Chartered Accountant (ACA) qualification starting from 2021. The new approach will be reflected in the 2021 learning materials and will task students with reviewing company data, visualizations, and financial results using data analytics software, Inflo. The modified exams will test students' ability to analyze and interpret data, provide commentary, and justify their actions. This change aims to make the ACA qualification more relevant and practical, reflecting the current and future workplace.

site_title: Hong Kong halts derivatives trading after technical problems
summary: Hong Kong's exchange operator halted derivatives trading due to unspecified connectivity problems, affecting the local stock market amid heightened sensitivity over the city's financial status. The halt occurred during a press conference by Chief Executive Carrie Lam, who resisted protesters' demands. The MSCI Hong Kong Index fell 1.6% after the halt, with trading volumes significantly lower than usual. The issues hindered hedging opportunities for investors, causing concerns about their ability to respond to unexpected events.

site_title: German factory orders sink in July, raising risk of recession
summary: German factory orders dropped 2.7% in July, deepening an industrial slump that puts Europe's largest economy at risk of recession. The decline, largely due to reduced demand from outside the euro region, follows a similar pace in June. The economy ministry warns that no significant improvement in momentum is expected in the coming months due to ongoing international trade conflicts and a no-deal Brexit. This raises uncertainty over Germany's export-reliant economy and intensifying global trade tensions.

site_title: Thailand seeks US$251m for palace budget, a 13% hike
summary: Thailand is seeking a 13% hike in its monarchy budget to $251 million in the 2020 budget, with the funds allocated for "security" purposes. The proposal comes under the administration of Prayut Chan-O-Cha, who is pro-royalist. This is the first budget under his leadership, following the coronation of 67-year-old King Maha Vajiralongkorn four months prior. The allocation is subject to parliamentary approval.

images.alt_text: The palace budget proposal, which still needs parliamentary approval, comes four months after 67-year-old King Maha Vajiralongkorn was crowned in an elaborate ceremony.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit one-month highs on trade optimism
summary: European stocks hit one-month highs on Thursday after China announced trade talks with the US, boosting hopes for progress in the ongoing trade dispute. The STOXX 600 index rose 0.63%, with France's CAC 40 index jumping 0.79% to a one-month high. However, data showed German industrial orders fell more than expected, suggesting continued struggles in Europe's largest economy. Despite this, shares in engine maker Safran rose 6% after the company raised its full-year profit forecasts.

site_title: Investors pull US$1.5b from UK equities as Brexit bites
summary: Investors in the UK have pulled $1.5 billion from equities in July, amid Brexit uncertainty, according to the Investment Association. This marks the fifth consecutive month of positive bond sales, with £2.2 billion in net retail sales. Despite a 1.9% rise in the CBOE UK All Companies Index, investors sought safe-haven assets, citing ongoing uncertainty. The outflows were accelerated after Boris Johnson took power in June, with £744 million in outflows in June and £1.2 billion in July.

images.alt_text: Canary Wharf financial district of London. Savers jettisoned £1.2 billion(S$2.04 billion) from UK equity funds in July, when Prime Minister Boris Johnson took power, according to figures published Thursday by the Investment Association, which represents fund managers.

site_title: Singapore SMEs stay put in Hong Kong as city's leader urges end to protests
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Hong Kong remain optimistic about doing business there despite the city's leader urging an end to protests. Despite a 40% slump in business in June and July, companies like Lunch Actually and Love, Bonito are hopeful for a recovery. They believe that as long as they can understand the local market and culture, they can continue to operate in Hong Kong. Some SME leaders, however, think that the prolonged unrest may lead to a shift in businesses away from Hong Kong, citing concerns about stability and viability.

site_title: Johnson boxed in over Brexit as bill is pushed through Lords
summary: Boris Johnson's Brexit strategy was dealt a significant blow as the UK Parliament rejected his plan for a general election and his do-or-die Brexit deadline of October 31. Despite being humiliated for a second day, Johnson plans to appeal directly to voters in a speech, seeking to seize back the initiative. The rejection of his general election plan and the bill to prevent a no-deal Brexit leaves Johnson with a precarious position, with the UK on the cusp of a third election in just over four years.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust to replace Hutchison Port Holdings Trust on Straits Times Index
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) will replace Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) on the Straits Times Index (STI) starting September 23. MCT will maintain a 1.5% weightage in the index, bringing the total weightage of four Reits to around 8%. This change aims to reflect the market's performance and weightages.

site_title: Singapore, China tie-up to ease sea port clearance with the use of e-certificates
summary: Singapore and China have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to issue, use, and accept electronic certificates for port clearance and Port State Control (PSC) inspections. The collaboration aims to increase efficiency and reduce administrative burdens on shipping companies and ships. This move builds upon the existing partnership between the two countries and advances the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative. The agreement is expected to benefit international shipping, which accounts for over 80% of global trade. The MOU was signed by the China Maritime Safety Administration and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Australian shares end at 1-month high as Sino-US trade talks lift mood; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares ended a three-day losing streak at a one-month high, closing 0.9% higher at 6,613.2 points, driven by confirmation of US-China trade talks and soaring crude oil prices. Energy stocks jumped 1.4%, while financial stocks rose 1%. However, CYBG Plc slumped 20.3% after increasing provisions for legacy payment protection insurance costs. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also advanced 0.9%.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says China backs her 'all the way'
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said China supports her government's decision to formally withdraw an extradition bill, which sparked months of unrest. The move comes after Beijing allegedly thwarted earlier proposals to withdraw the bill. Lam announced other measures to address economic and social issues, but protesters say it's too little, too late, with five demands still unmet. Skirmishes broke out in districts after Lam's announcement, and China has warned of using force to restore order, amid a recession and over 1,100 arrests since violence escalated in June.

site_title: China signals further stimulus coming as economic headwinds rise
summary: China's cabinet signaled further stimulus measures to support the slowing economy, including a potential reduction in reserve ratios for banks and faster implementation of measures to reduce real borrowing costs. This comes as economists forecast China's GDP growth to slow to below 6% in 2020 due to increasing risks from the tariff war. The government also plans to accelerate infrastructure spending through special bonds, with a focus on sectors such as transport and healthcare. The move aims to alleviate economic headwinds and provide support to the real economy.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit changes name to Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, to enter new outsourcing management agreement
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has changed its name to Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, effective September 5. The reit is entering a new outsourcing management agreement with Pacific Oak Capital Advisors LLC, which will employ the existing asset management team. The new agreement is expected to be on the same terms as the existing one with KBS Capital Advisors LLC, with no material impact on the reit's management. The reit's portfolio comprises 12 US office buildings and has a combined asset value of US$1.09 billion, with a technology focus in Seattle, Austin, and Denver.

site_title: Surbana teams up with JTC to boost productivity, sustainability in building sector
summary: Surbana Jurong, an urban and infrastructure consultancy, partnered with JTC Corporation to boost productivity and sustainability in the building sector through digitalization and automation. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) combines JTC's project management capabilities with Surbana Jurong's expertise to develop practical solutions. The partnership aims to reduce manual monitoring, explore alternative building materials, and improve sustainability, with potential applications in areas like building information modeling, robotics, and smart cities.

site_title: Malaysia's top supermarket chain bans 'palm-oil-free' products, govt urges others to follow
summary: Malaysia's top supermarket chain, Mydin, has removed 'palm-oil-free' products from its stores to support the country's palm oil industry, amid concerns over deforestation. The move follows similar actions by Indonesia and a European Union ban on palm oil in renewable fuels by 2030. Malaysian Minister of Primary Industries Teresa Kok welcomed the move, urging other retailers to follow suit. The goal is to counter "subtle messages" that palm oil is bad for consumers, emphasizing its importance to the Malaysian economy and Southeast Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Britain and US sink in ranking of best places for expats
summary: Britain and the US have dropped in the ranking of best places for expats, according to a global survey. The UK ranks 57th for political stability and 58th overall, down 25 spots since 2016. The InterNations Expat Insider survey, conducted by 20,000 expats, found that the UK's Brexit turmoil is a major factor. The US ranks 46th for political stability and 47th overall, also experiencing a decline. The survey highlights the impact of global events on expat destinations.

images.alt_text: Political turmoil over Brexit means the UK is now among the world's least desirable destinations for expats. Out of 64 countries ranked by the InterNations Expat Insider survey, Britain ranks 57th for political stability and 58th overall.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares jump on easing Hong Kong, Brexit worries
summary: Tokyo shares rose 2.12% on Thursday, extending Wall Street's gains, as Brexit and Hong Kong worries eased. The Nikkei 225 index surged 436.80 points to 21,085.94, while the Topix index rose 27.65 points to 1,534.46. The rally followed easing concerns over the UK's Brexit plans and the Hong Kong crisis. Investors remain optimistic despite US trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Flash floods hit Thai rice growers months after drought
summary: Flash floods caused by tropical storm Podul damaged over 240,000 hectares of Thai agriculture land, including nearly 220,000 hectares of rice farms. The damage may reduce Thailand's rice production by 100,000 tonnes, impacting the country's economy. The floods also killed 16 people and affected over 100,000 households. The Thai government has implemented an income guarantee for farmers as part of a US$10 billion stimulus package to mitigate losses. The country's rice exporters face additional challenges due to a strong Thai baht, which makes exports more expensive.

site_title: Fewer HDB resale flats sold in August, with slight increase in prices: SRX
summary: Fewer Housing Board (HDB) resale flats were sold in August, with 1,921 flats changing hands, a 9.4% decline from July. This represents a 7.6% lower resale volume compared to the same month last year. Despite the decline, resale prices showed a slight increase of month on month.

site_title: SPH, SGX and FTSE Russell celebrate 12 years of STI
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) celebrated its 20th anniversary and the 12th anniversary of the Straits Times Index (STI) with a symbolic gong-striking ceremony. The STI, developed by SPH, SGX, and FTSE Russell, tracks the performance of top 30 stocks listed on SGX and is considered the benchmark index for the local stock market. The index has evolved over the years to reflect changes in the market, including the addition of the Reits component. The partnership has enabled investors to access the broad market easily, leading to the creation of investment products based on the STI.

site_title: Far East Hospitality to open its first hotel in Japan ahead of 2020 Tokyo Olympics
summary: Far East Hospitality plans to open its first hotel in Japan, Village Hotel Ariake Tokyo, in the second quarter of 2020, ahead of the Tokyo Olympics. The 306-key hotel, under a 50-50 joint venture with Far East Organization, is located near the Ariake waterfront area and major venues such as Toyosu Market and Ariake Arena. This marks the first Village Hotel outside of Singapore.

site_title: Asia's richest man is handing out free 4k televisions
summary: Asia's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, is handing out free 4K TVs to users of his JioFiber broadband service in India, as part of a bid to lure users onto the internet for entertainment. The offer comes with high-definition TV sets and set-top boxes at no charge for annual lifetime subscribers, and includes subscriptions to premium streaming services starting at $13.50 per month. This move aims to compete with rivals like Netflix and Amazon.com, and disrupt the streaming market if Jio produces its own content.

site_title: Trump administration pulls plug on energy-efficient bulb rules
summary: The Trump administration has rolled back a rule requiring all new light bulbs to be energy-efficient by 2020, a move welcomed by industry but criticized by climate change groups. The rollback reverses a 2007 law mandating phased-in energy efficiency targets for incandescent bulbs, which were set to be phased out by 2020. Environmental groups argue the move will lead to higher energy bills and increased pollution, despite receiving over 64,000 comments opposing the rollback.

site_title: New Zealand government announces plan to clean up dirty waters
summary: New Zealand's government has announced plans to clean up its polluted waterways, restricting farming intensification, synthetic nitrogen fertilizer use, and improving standards at tourist spots. The measures aim to protect the country's environmentally pristine image and address concerns about industrial farming and tourism's impact on lakes and rivers. The government vows to achieve a noticeable improvement in five years, but some farmers and groups have expressed concerns that the measures will be economically unsustainable and harm pastoral farming.

site_title: Temasek-backed AI startup SenseTime plans to triple staff in Singapore to 300 within 3 years
summary: SenseTime Group Ltd, backed by SoftBank and Temasek, plans to triple its staff in Singapore to 300 within three years, amid its expansion into areas like semiconductors. The Chinese AI startup, valued at over $7.5 billion, has raised funds to drive forays into new areas and is shoring up its presence in South-east Asia. SenseTime's CEO, Xu Li, emphasized the company's focus on AI ethics and its responsibility to collaborate with regulators, despite US concerns over its close relationship with Beijing.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,147.11, up 0.53% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.53% to 3,147.11 at 1:02pm on Thursday, driven by rallies in Asian markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 183 to 136, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, Rex International Holding, and AusGroup advancing 4.3%, 2.5%, and 4.8% respectively. The market's rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Charles Schwab to close Singapore office
summary: Charles Schwab Corp is closing its Singapore office, less than two years after opening it in 2017. The US-based discount brokerage company cited a decision to no longer open new accounts for prospective clients. The move aims to provide greater access to the US market for investors in Singapore and Asia, who often face high transaction fees.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on perfect storm of positive news
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, driven by positive news on trade, Hong Kong, and Europe. China agreed to resume trade talks with the US in Washington next month, boosting investor confidence. Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam withdrew a controversial extradition bill, while Italy formed a new moderate government. Asian equities, including Tokyo, Shanghai, and Seoul, surged, with the S&P 500 moving near a record high. Sterling extended its gains, and high-yielding currencies rose against the dollar.

site_title: Cathay Pacific shares fall nearly 4% after chairman resigns
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways shares fell nearly 4% after chairman John Slosar resigned, following the exit of CEO Rupert Hogg amid Chinese regulatory scrutiny. Slosar's departure was announced just before the market closed on Wednesday, replacing Patrick Healy, who was appointed as chairman. Analysts believe the situation at Cathay should stabilize if the political situation in Hong Kong stabilizes, and the withdrawal of a controversial extradition bill is a positive development for the airline.

site_title: Malaysia firms up bauxite mining, export operating procedures
summary: Malaysia has finalized new operating procedures for bauxite mining and export activities, capping monthly exports at 600,000 tonnes. The procedures, finalized after discussions with stakeholders, come into effect immediately. The move follows a 2016 ban on mining due to environmental concerns, which was lifted earlier this year due to strong demand for bauxite. The new procedures will be expanded nationwide through broader standard operating procedures, according to Minister Xavier Jayakumar.

site_title: Tech firms, US officials talk US election protection at Facebook
summary: US tech firms, including Facebook, Google, Microsoft, and Twitter, met with US officials at Facebook's Silicon Valley headquarters to discuss protecting the 2020 presidential election from cyber threats. Representatives from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Department of Homeland Security, and the office of the Director of National Intelligence attended the meeting. Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy, Nathaniel Gleicher, stated that the gathering aimed to strengthen collaboration on election security. The meeting builds on previous discussions and seeks to further fortify the security of the 2020 US elections.

site_title: Extradition from Hong Kong to mainland China would help fight money laundering: watchdog
summary: A watchdog report from the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) suggests that Hong Kong's lack of an extradition mechanism to mainland China hinders efforts to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The report calls for Hong Kong to improve its cooperation with China through formal means, despite robust informal cooperation. The proposal for an extradition bill has been withdrawn after mass protests. Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, has implemented anti-money laundering measures since 2016, and the FATF found the city's regime to be "sound" in fighting money laundering and terrorist financing.

images.alt_text: The lack of a mechanism in Hong Kong to extradite suspects to mainland China is an obstacle to tackling money laundering and terrorism financing, a watchdog said on Wednesday as Hong Kong withdrew an extradition bill that sparked mass protests.

site_title: Temasek partners Kuehne + Nagel to launch US$50m fund for logistics startups
summary: Temasek Holdings has partnered with Kuehne + Nagel to launch Reefknot Investments, a US$50 million global fund backing logistics startups at the Series A and B stages. The fund will support six to eight startups in AI, digital logistics, and trade finance, providing business insights from Temasek and logistics expertise from Kuehne + Nagel. The venture aims to create a community of industry experts to support growth, with partners including EDBI, SGInnovate, and Unilever Foundry.

site_title: Big Oil circles Permian riches as shale stocks collapse
summary: Big Oil companies, such as Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell, are taking advantage of a collapse in shale stock valuations in the Permian Basin. With oil prices near $55 a barrel, independent producers are struggling, leading to a rich opportunity for majors to acquire shale assets at discounted prices. Exxon and Chevron have expressed interest in expanding in the Permian, with CEO Darren Woods stating he's willing to wait for a better price, while Chevron's head says the company will be "opportunistic" in making acquisitions.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit 1-month high on trade optimism
summary: South Korea's stocks reached a one-month high as the US and China agreed to hold trade talks next month, boosting optimism. The KOSPI index rose 0.82% to 2,004.75, with foreigners buying US$154.29 million worth of shares. This follows a 1.78% decline in the KOSPI so far this year. Positive developments in Hong Kong and Britain also contributed to the rally, with the KOSPI falling 5.4% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: New Singapore govt e-service to help banks combat fraud risks in trade financing
summary: Singapore has introduced a new e-service, Trade Finance Compliance (TFC), to aid banks in combating fraud risks in trade financing. Created by a joint partnership between Singapore Customs, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and financial institutions, the service aims to address compliance challenges and provide reliable data for price checks on non-commodity goods. The TFC service is now available on Singapore's digital national trade platform, the Networked Trade Platform (NTP).

site_title: Gojek chief says on track to raise US$2b before 2019's end
summary: Gojek, a ride-hailing giant, is on track to raise US$2 billion in its funding round before the end of 2019, driven by its expansion into mobile payments and food delivery. The company has handled about US$1.5 billion of transactions outside of Indonesia, with a focus on South-east Asia. Backed by Google and Tencent Holdings, Gojek aims to outdo rival Grab Holdings Inc in providing a super-app. Amazon.com Inc is reportedly in talks to join the funding round, further fueling Gojek's growth in the region.

site_title: Europe's buoyant property markets help hide executives' failings
summary: European real estate executives failed to add value to their firms over the past three years, with about 40% of executives at European real estate investment trusts (Reits) not taking action to enhance returns. Despite buoyant property markets, management teams were ranked based on their balance sheet management and capital allocation. Companies that borrowed heavily post-financial crisis often ranked poorly, but some have learned from past experiences. A study by Green Street Advisors found that Barcelona-based Inmobiliaria Colonial Socimi earned the highest grade, while Intu Properties, whose shares have plummeted 68% this year, ranked last.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as worries over Hong Kong, UK ease
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending Wall Street rallies, as worries over Brexit and the Hong Kong crisis eased. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.97% to 20,850.46, while the Topix index gained 0.86% to 1,519.80. The positive sentiment followed easing tensions in Hong Kong and improved US-UK relations.

site_title: IPO hopeful WeWork adds woman to board, CEO returns US$5.9m after backlash
summary: WeWork owner The We Company has taken steps to address investor concerns ahead of its IPO by adding a woman, Frances Frei, to its all-male board and CEO Adam Neumann returning a $5.9 million payment for using the trademarked word "We". The moves come after investor criticism of the company's ties to Neumann and its controlling shareholder structure. Corporate governance advocates say the steps may not be enough to quell concerns, with a multi-class share structure giving Neumann operational control. WeWork plans to add another director to its board within a year.

site_title: Australia: Energy stocks pull shares higher, New Zealand also rises
summary: Australia's shares rose 1% to 6,616.2, tracking a global rally, as energy stocks gained 2% due to a surge in crude oil prices. The rally was supported by upbeat economic data from China, easing Hong Kong tensions, and US-China trade talks. However, some sectors, including Whitehaven Coal, fell as shares traded ex-dividend. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also rose 0.7% to 11,089.16, driven by gains in dairy and construction firms.

site_title: China's private bond defaults climb to record 31.8b yuan
summary: China's private bond defaults reached a record 31.8 billion yuan through August, with 78.4 billion yuan in total corporate bond defaults, a 51% increase from the same period last year. Weaker companies are seeking to repay publicly traded debt first, while investors are demanding higher risk premiums on privately issued notes. The private bond market, a key source of funding for smaller non-state-owned companies, is experiencing declining demand and increased defaults, leading investors to favor state-owned enterprises and local government financing vehicles.

site_title: Nissan CEO Saikawa received excess pay: reports
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa admitted to receiving excess pay in the form of stock appreciation rights, exceeding his entitlement by 47 million yen (S$609,000). The overpayment was made through a scheme allowing directors to receive bonuses if the company's share price rises above a certain level. The admission comes as Nissan struggles to recover from the arrest and ouster of former CEO Carlos Ghosn, who is on bail in Tokyo and charged with financial misconduct. Saikawa denied any personal wrongdoing, stating he thought the procedures were correct.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks barely moved at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the open on Thursday, following a surge the previous day, as investors took a breather after the government agreed to a key demand of campaigners. The Hang Seng Index inched down 10.37 points to 26,512.86. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.52% and 0.51%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore-South Korea joint fund invests US$2.3m in Vietnam proptech platform Rever
summary: Singapore's GEC-KIP Technology and Innovation Fund has invested US$2.3 million in Vietnam proptech platform Rever, valuing the company at US$15 million. Rever, founded in 2016, provides tailored and transparent services to help clients find homes for living and investment. With the new funding, Rever plans to open 30 large experience centers in 18 months and expand beyond Ho Chi Minh City. The investment will also help the platform build its technology, recruitment, and operations.

site_title: Singapore says global collaboration needed for AI technology
summary: Singapore's Communications Minister S Iswaran emphasizes the need for global collaboration in developing artificial intelligence (AI) technology, despite the ongoing US-China trade war. Companies are still working together across geographical boundaries to advance AI, with Singapore providing a platform for partnerships. The minister notes that the biggest risk is a fragmented global economy, but Singapore remains optimistic about the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) deal, aiming for a tentative deadline of November.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam says hopes extradition bill's withdrawal will help solve crisis
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam hopes the withdrawal of a contentious extradition bill will help resolve the city's crisis. The bill's formal withdrawal follows mass protests and a 50-day standoff. Despite the move, protesters and some lawmakers say it's too little, too late. The bill's withdrawal comes as Lam faces pressure to address the city's worsening economic and social issues. The city's biggest political crisis in decades continues, with Lam's actions seen as insufficient to quell the unrest.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said on Thursday she hopes the formal withdrawal of a controversial extradition bill and other measures will help solve the city's political crisis.

site_title: Malaysia defends move to extend licence for rare earth firm Lynas
summary: Malaysia's government has defended its decision to extend the license for Lynas Corp, a rare earths processing firm, despite protests from activists and politicians. The move aims to preserve 600 jobs and demonstrate the country's business-friendly credentials. Lynas Corp, the largest rare earths producer outside China, had faced concerns over radioactive waste production. The government cited the need to break China's monopoly on rare earth exports and maintain a positive business environment. The six-month extension is shorter than usual, but the government believes it is necessary to avoid job losses.

site_title: Bangkok tops in 2018 for international visitors: report
summary: Bangkok ranked first in 2018 for international visitors with nearly 23 million visitors, surpassing Paris and London. The Thai capital has held this title for four consecutive years. Other top cities included Dubai, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, New York, and Istanbul.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust joins FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Developed Index
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) will be included in the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Developed Index starting Sept 23, 2019. The move aims to expand FCT's reach to a larger pool of institutional investors and improve trading liquidity. FCT's inclusion is part of a growing trend of Singapore-listed Reits seeking participation in the global benchmark index. Other Reits, such as Manulife US Reit and the merged CapitaLand trusts, are also targeting index inclusion, indicating increased competition for investor attention.

site_title: South Korea's CJ Group heir apparent arrested for suspected narcotics law violation
summary: South Korea's heir apparent to CJ Group, Lee Sun-ho, a 29-year-old son of chairman Lee Jay-hyun, was arrested for suspected narcotics law violation after turning himself in. Lee was stopped at Incheon International Airport on September 1 on suspicion of trying to smuggle marijuana into the country. He apologized for his wrongdoing and expressed regret for causing trouble to CJ executives and employees. Lee, a business planning executive at CJ Cheiljedang Corp, is a graduate of Columbia University and is the grandson of Samsung Group founder Lee Byung-chull.

site_title: Astaka unit receives letters of demand for RM125.3m owed to contractor
summary: Astaka, a Catalist-listed property developer, owes RM125.3 million (S$41.3 million) plus interest to a construction firm, China State Construction Engineering (M) Sdn Bhd, for a 2015 construction agreement. The group's board was unaware of the letters of demand until after releasing its full-year results on August 29, 2019. APSB is negotiating to extend the loan repayment deadline and has requested a voluntary suspension of trading in its shares. A prior-year adjustment is required to account for the late interest payment, which amounts to about RM4 million.

site_title: China, US to hold trade talks in October: China commerce ministry
summary: China and the US agreed to hold trade talks in early October in Washington, following a call between Chinese Vice Premier Liu He and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. The two sides will hold consultations in mid-September before the talks, with both agreeing to take actions to create favorable conditions for the talks. This comes after a period of escalating trade tensions between the two countries.

images.alt_text: The announcement followed a call earlier in the day between China's Vice Premier Liu He and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, the Ministry of Commerce said in a statement on its website. China's central bank governor Yi Gang also attended the call.

site_title: Certis wins contract to manage security for over 60 JTC properties
summary: JTC Corporation has awarded a contract to Certis to manage security for over 60 properties in Singapore's south and west region, spanning 150 square kilometers. The 150-square-kilometer area includes community spaces, industrial buildings, and vacant land. The contract focuses on security outcomes rather than manpower, using digital technology and training to ensure safer and smarter properties. The Security+ project will be implemented in two phases, starting in 2020, and will utilize a centralized security operations center and smart mobile app to improve response times and resource optimization.

site_title: New Zealand's Fonterra to freeze pay, scrap bonuses of 7,000 employees
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, has frozen pay and scrapped bonuses for about 7,000 employees earning over NZ$100,000 per year due to expected annual losses of up to NZ$675 million. The decision affects employees on collective agreements above the NZ$100,000 threshold, while those below the threshold will not be impacted. The move comes after the company reported a loss of NZ$196 million in 2018 and a write-down of assets, including a Brazilian joint venture and Chinese farms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.72 points to 1,598.17 at 9am. Volume reached 39.08 million lots worth RM11.38 million. The market had a slight edge in gainer-to-loser ratio, with 92 gainers out of 38 losers.

site_title: Disciplined approach to land acquisition amid uncertainties
summary: The Singapore housing market remains positive for long-term development opportunities despite recent cooling measures. Land acquisition has slowed, with subdued top bid prices and fewer bidders. Developers have turned to Government Land Sales (GLS) for certainty and pricing discretion. However, collective sales remain an important source of land, particularly for prime and mature locations. The government's intervention in the property cycle ensures a sustainable market, leading to a more manageable risk environment for stakeholders.

site_title: Philippines annual inflation slows to 1.7% in August
summary: Philippine annual inflation eased to 1.7% in August, down from 2.4% in the previous month, primarily due to a decrease in food and utility prices. This outcome was in line with economists' forecasts, which ranged from 1.8% to the central bank's 1.3%-2.1% forecast. The slower inflation rate is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: Hanwha Investment & Securities invests US$4m in private capital platform CapBridge
summary: Hanwha Investment & Securities invested US$4 million in private capital platform CapBridge, backed by the Singapore Exchange. The investment aims to promote the growth of the private markets ecosystem in South Korea and Southeast Asia. CapBridge founder and CEO Johnson Chen welcomed Hanwha as a shareholder and strategic partner, looking to expand private markets opportunities for companies and investors in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares up 0.56% to 3,148.12 at Thursday's open as fears ease over Hong Kong, Brexit
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.56% to 3,148.12 at Thursday's open, driven by easing fears over Hong Kong and a no-deal Brexit. The Straits Times Index gained 17.55 points. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings advanced 2.7% after announcing new order contracts. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gainers outnumbering losers 71 to 37.

site_title: New York mayor hints he may end 2020 presidential bid
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio hinted at potentially ending his 2020 presidential bid if he fails to gain more support, citing a possible drop-out as early as next month. He faces an uphill battle to meet the debate qualification criteria, which includes a 2% poll average and 130,000 donors in 20 US states. With six candidates already out of the running, de Blasio's chances seem uncertain, and he is expected to miss the next debate on September 12.

site_title: Italian PM sets seal on new government, unveils cabinet
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte unveiled his new cabinet, uniting two rival parties in an unlikely coalition that aims to improve ties with the European Union and adopt a softer stance on immigration. The new government, formed after the previous administration collapsed, includes key posts such as economy minister Roberto Gualtieri and foreign minister Luigi Di Maio. Analysts welcomed the move, citing a pro-European government and a more balanced lineup, which could ease pressure on Italy's credit rating and boost financial markets.

site_title: GIC nears deal for majority stake in Oxford Group's Fairmont hotels
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is nearing a deal to buy a majority stake in Oxford Properties Group's Fairmont hotels, consisting of four iconic Canadian hotels, for approximately C$2 billion. The deal could be announced in coming weeks, with Oxford retaining a minority stake and managing the properties. The Fairmont hotels, with over 2,200 rooms and 1.2 million annual guests, have historical roots dating back to Canada's train travel era. A deal is expected, but no agreement has been reached yet.

site_title: ESR-Reit secures railway firm as tenant at 8 Tuas South Lane
summary: ESR-Reit secured a lease for about 168,846 square feet at its 8 Tuas South Lane property to P-Way Construction and Engineering, a Singapore railway firm, for steel fabrication, equipment storage, and employee dormitory services. P-Way will operate at the site from October 1 and is contracted by the Singapore Land Transport Authority for track work services related to the Jurong Region MRT Line and Changi Airport Terminal extension. The lease diversifies tenant concentration risks and improves tenant mix for ESR-Reit.

site_title: Hong Kong government takes out overseas ad to reassure investors
summary: The Hong Kong government has taken out an advertisement in the Australian Financial Review to reassure investors that the city is stable and its economy is strong despite recent protests. The ad emphasizes Hong Kong's commitment to "One Country, Two Systems" and rejects the use of violence, highlighting the city's peaceful protest tradition. The move comes as the city continues to grapple with unrest sparked by proposed extradition legislation to mainland China, with over 1,100 arrests made so far. The ad aims to reassure investors and counter negative media coverage.

site_title: How important is Hong Kong to the rest of China?
summary: Hong Kong's political and economic future is uncertain amid pro-democracy protests, with China warning that forceful intervention is possible. The city's unique system of governance, including freedoms of expression and an independent judiciary, has made it a stable international financial center and gateway for global capital. Losing Hong Kong could destabilize China's economy and hurt its reputation as a global economic power. China relies heavily on Hong Kong's currency, equity, and debt markets to attract foreign funds, with the city handling a significant share of China's exports and imports.

images.alt_text: Concerns over Hong Kong's political and economic future are growing as pro-democracy protests drag on and turn increasingly violent, and China makes clear that forceful intervention is possible.

site_title: Getting out - tariffs push some US manufacturers to exit China
summary: US tariffs on Chinese imports have prompted some manufacturers to exit China, with Illinois-based Xentris Wireless shifting production to the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. The tariffs, which began on Sunday on $112 billion worth of Chinese goods, have forced companies like Xentris to absorb the cost, raise prices, or move production to other countries. The impact of tariffs is expected to continue, with some companies planning to move up to 30% of their production from China to other countries.

site_title: Ascott eyes millennials with its first lyf co-living space at Funan
summary: The Ascott has opened lyf Funan Singapore, its first co-living space targeting millennials, with 412 rooms across 279 apartments. The property offers collaborative spaces and social programs, including TED talks and hackathons, and is managed by "lyf guards" who are community managers and problem solvers. The lyf concept is expected to cater to the growing millennial travel segment, which already forms a quarter of Ascott's customer base. Seven more lyf properties are slated to open in the next three years, including in Singapore and other key markets.

images.alt_text: Capitaland business unit The Ascott has opened lyf Funan Singapore - its first co-living property to date spanning around 121,000 square feet in gross floor area.
Capitaland business unit The Ascott has opened lyf Funan Singapore - its first co-living property to date spanning around 121,000 square feet (sq ft) in gross floor area.
Capitaland business unit The Ascott has opened lyf Funan Singapore - its first co-living property to date spanning around 121,000 square feet (sq ft) in gross floor area.
Capitaland business unit The Ascott has opened lyf Funan Singapore - its first co-living property to date spanning around 121,000 square feet (sq ft) in gross floor area.

site_title: Grab and Gojek squaring off in international food fight
summary: Grab and Gojek, two Asian technology startups, are engaging in an international food delivery fight. Gojek, founded by Nadiem Makarim, has grown to have 400,000 food merchants and 50 million orders per month in Indonesia, Vietnam, and Thailand. Grab, co-founded by Anthony Tan, has tripled sales and doubled its roster of merchants, with SoftBank funding and the acquisition of Uber's local business. The companies see a bright spot in the food delivery market, with attractive margins and expected growth to surpass on-demand transport by revenue in the next five years.

site_title: British MPs reject PM Johnson's motion for general election
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's motion for a general election to break the Brexit deadlock was rejected by MPs, with only 298 votes in favor, falling short of the 434 threshold needed. The opposition Labour Party abstained, allowing the motion to fail. The rejection deals a significant blow to Johnson's strategy, and the UK's Brexit deadlock remains unresolved.

site_title: GM CEO Barra set to hold White House meetings on Thursday
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra is set to meet with US President Donald Trump and White House officials on Thursday to discuss trade, contract talks, and fuel efficiency standards. Trump is expected to attend part of the meetings, despite Hurricane Dorian affecting his schedule. The meetings come amid criticism of GM on Twitter, with Trump calling the company "one of the smallest auto manufacturers" in the US. Details of the discussions were not made available by GM or the White House.

site_title: Vienna the world's most liveable city for the second year running: EIU
summary: Vienna has been ranked the world's most liveable city for the second year running, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit. Singapore, on the other hand, dropped to 40th place. The EIU notes that the world's most liveable cities tend to be regional second cities, rather than global capitals.

site_title: Twitter nixes tweets by text after CEO account hack
summary: Twitter temporarily halted users' ability to send tweets via text messages after CEO Jack Dorsey's account was hijacked through a SIM swap scam, a type of "two-factor authentication" vulnerability. The hack occurred when attackers tricked a mobile carrier into transferring Dorsey's number, potentially exposing sensitive information. Twitter is working to fix the issue and will restore tweeting via SMS in markets where users rely on it once a long-term solution is implemented. The company emphasizes the need for mobile carriers and two-factor authentication to be addressed to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: US offered millions in cash to captain of Iranian tanker
summary: The US offered Indian captain Akhilesh Kumar $3-4 million to steer the Iranian oil tanker Adrian Darya 1 away from Syria and towards a country where it could be seized. The offer was made by US State Department official Brian Hook via emails. Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif mocked the US initiative, calling it "outright blackmail." After Kumar did not respond, the US imposed sanctions on the ship and Kumar, freezing his assets and criminalizing US financial transactions with him.

site_title: Ensuring the future of industrial and logistics real estate
summary: The future of industrial and logistics real estate is evolving with Industry 4.0 practices, which can be integrated into existing infrastructure. Consumer preferences for bespoke goods and sustainable supply chains are driving changes in manufacturing processes. However, older industrial properties may not meet the new demands, requiring adaptive re-use or upgrading. Landlords can benefit from leasing space to multiple tenants, minimizing rental income losses. A feasibility study is recommended to determine the best approach for enhancing or replacing existing facilities. The government's flexibility and openness to adapt industrial land usage will also play a key role in shaping the future of industrial real estate.

site_title: Venture capital fundraising in Asean is on course to match 2018 record
summary: Venture capital fundraising in ASEAN is on track to match the 2018 record, with six funds closing in the first half of 2019, raising a total of US$0.5 billion. This is close to the amount raised in the first half of last year. Despite a challenging macroeconomic environment, buyout deal values are falling, but ASEAN-focused VC fundraising remains strong.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: City Developments Limited secured a S$250 million three-year revolving credit facility from DBS Bank to promote the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. CDL will be eligible for a discount on interest rates when achieving sustainability-related performance targets on innovations that contribute positively to UN goals.

site_title: Trump displays incorrectly altered map of Hurricane Dorian path
summary: US President Donald Trump displayed a map from the National Hurricane Center showing Hurricane Dorian's initial predicted path, but it had been edited to include Alabama, contrary to Trump's earlier tweets. The National Weather Service's office in Birmingham, Alabama, responded to the contrary, stating that the state would not be affected by the hurricane. Trump responded with "I don't know" when asked about the edit, continuing to maintain that Alabama was a possible landfall state.

images.alt_text: Trouble is raining down on US President Donald Trump, who appears to have given Americans incorrect information on Hurricane Dorian's trajectory.

site_title: Brexit ordeal unmasks PM Johnson's ruthless side
summary: Boris Johnson's ruthless side has emerged as Britain's Brexit Prime Minister, displaying a scowl and a wagging finger after a few weeks in office. He's betting on forcing an election to regain his parliamentary majority, despite criticism for his tactics, including sacking 21 Tory MPs and suspending parliament. His image as a jovial leader has given way to accusations of dictatorial behavior, with some comparing him to North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. Johnson's past gaffes, including racist quips, have also resurfaced, further polarizing opinions about his leadership.

site_title: Most Jardine-linked stocks soar on extradition Bill withdrawal
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam formally withdraws the extradition bill, leading to a surge in Jardine-linked stocks. Hongkong Land rose 8.3%, while Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings also advanced. The Straits Times Index finished 1.3% higher. However, analysts believe the market rebound may not last, as protests are unlikely to end until other demands are met, including Mrs. Lam's resignation and more democratic freedoms.

site_title: China shoppers adopt facial recognition payment technology
summary: China is embracing facial-recognition payment technology, allowing shoppers to make purchases by simply looking into point-of-sale machines equipped with cameras. Major companies like Alipay and Tencent are leading the charge, with Alipay spending billions to implement the technology nationwide. Despite concerns over data security and privacy, consumers seem to be accepting facial-recognition payment, citing convenience and ease of use. However, analysts warn of the potential risks of the technology being used for surveillance and monitoring, particularly in China's surveillance-heavy region of Xinjiang.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as odds of Hong Kong crisis ebb
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining about 1% or more, following positive developments in Hong Kong and the Brexit process. Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam withdrew a bill allowing extradition to mainland China, easing concerns of a Beijing crackdown. The US Federal Reserve reported modest growth, despite ongoing trade policy uncertainty. Markets have factored in the US-China trade war but have not yet reflected the improved situation in Hong Kong, according to fund manager Gregori Volokhine.

site_title: US slaps fresh duties on Chinese, Mexican steel goods
summary: The US has imposed new duties on over $1 billion in imported structural steel from China and Mexico, citing dumped products at margins of 0-141.4%. The decision follows a similar June ruling on Chinese alloy aluminum imports. The Commerce Department rejected similar allegations from Canada, but a final determination is due in 2020. The US International Trade Commission can still reverse the duty increases if the preliminary findings are overturned. This decision comes after President Trump lifted punitive duties on Mexican steel in May, as part of the new North American trade pact.

site_title: Billionaire Uniqlo founder wants a woman to succeed him
summary: Billionaire Tadashi Yanai, founder of Uniqlo, wants to be succeeded by a woman, citing their persevering nature, attention to detail, and aesthetic sense. He aims to increase the ratio of female senior executives to over half of the total, a goal Fast Retailing has already achieved in management positions. Yanai has identified Maki Akaida, a 40-year-old Uniqlo executive, as a possible candidate. Japan's lack of gender diversity in top management roles has raised concerns, with only 4.1% of executive titles held by women, compared to 25% in the US.

site_title: By design, it's been 20 years - and counting
summary: Five design veterans have achieved a milestone of 20 years in their careers, with profiles published in Weekend magazine. The individuals, including Chris Lee, Pann Lim, Robin Tan, Cecil Chee, and Nathan Yong, share their experiences in highly competitive industries, discussing challenges, successes, and lessons learned. They also highlight changes in the design industry, such as the shift towards more inclusive dining spaces and the decline of the sneaker trend in streetwear. Their stories offer insights into the design world and the dedication required to thrive in it.

site_title: Oil prices rise over 4% on positive economic data from China
summary: Oil prices surged over 4% on Wednesday, driven by positive economic data from China. Brent futures rose $2.44 to $60.70 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude gained $2.32 to $56.26. This marked the largest daily percentage increase for WTI since July 10. The market boost came after three days of losses due to global economic concerns.

site_title: S$20m more for green building fund
summary: Singapore's government is adding S$20 million to its green building fund, bringing the total to S$72 million, to encourage developers and researchers to develop more eco-friendly building innovations. The fund aims to support projects such as super low-energy technologies and the launch of the SLE Buildings Smart Hub, a digital knowledge centre for green buildings. The government also plans to introduce a more flexible Buildability framework, allowing consultants to propose innovative solutions, and to launch the Open option by the end of the year.

site_title: Pound extends recovery amid Brexit drama
summary: The British pound rebounded by almost 1% on Wednesday, reaching above US$1.22, as Brexit turmoil led to a potential snap election. Analysts believe rising hopes of a no-deal Brexit are lifting sterling, but a general election could cap gains. A proposed snap election, which lawmakers rejected, could have significant economic implications, including a potential recession. Global stocks rose, while Hong Kong's stock market surged 3.9% as the city's leader shelved a contentious extradition bill. Oil prices also surged in late European trading.

site_title: US sees 'modest' growth, businesses show 'near-term' optimism: Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy grew at a modest pace in recent weeks, according to the Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey. Despite the escalating US-China trade war, most businesses remain optimistic about the near-term outlook. Key findings include: auto sales rose, tourism was solid, and bank lending and commercial real estate leasing increased slightly. However, farms were affected by bad weather, low prices, and trade uncertainty. Consumer spending was mixed, and employers struggled to find workers and offered higher pay and benefits. The Fed is expected to cut interest rates again in two weeks to insulate the US economy.

site_title: Evolving occupier trends in office sector
summary: In Singapore's office sector, technology firms and agile space operators have emerged as key drivers of demand, accounting for 34.5% of the market from 2014 to 2018. The growth of startups, fueled by ample liquidity and a thriving entrepreneurial ecosystem, has driven this shift. Leasing activity by technology firms has not only been contributed by international companies but also by homegrown startups. Agile space operators have seen a doubling of locations and a tripling of market size, with landlords embracing flexible office options and corporates adopting the core + flex model.

site_title: Smart cities have yet to become a reality
summary: Despite a global push for smarter, better solutions, smart cities have yet to become a reality due to scalability and bureaucratic issues. Only 15 out of 1,000 smart city projects have comprehensive strategies, and many initiatives are overly focused on technology without considering the specific needs of local communities. Physical spaces, including buildings and real estate, are often overlooked. To overcome these challenges, governments and businesses must adopt a more holistic approach, incorporating technology, data, and community engagement to create sustainable, equitable, and competitive cities.

site_title: Luxury market continues to draw investors
summary: Luxury real estate investments continue to attract foreign ultra-high net worth individuals, drawn to Singapore's stable economy and political climate. Despite global market uncertainty, high-profile luxury deals in New York, such as Ken Griffin's $240 million penthouse purchase, have lifted market sentiments. The oversupply of luxury homes in New York is expected to continue to impact the market, while Singapore's prime projects above $3,000 psf are set to test demand in Q3.

site_title: Dollar extends decline, helping euro to recover
summary: The US dollar declined 0.2% against a basket of major currencies, its lowest level in over two years, after disappointing manufacturing data showed the world's biggest economy contracting for the first time in three years. The euro rose 0.2% to US$1.0992, recovering from a 28-month low, while sterling rallied 0.5% to US$1.2157. The dollar's decline was attributed to increased bets on Federal Reserve interest rate cuts and a weaker yen and Swiss franc.

site_title: Investor appetite for Singapore's hotel market to stay healthy
summary: Singapore's hotel investment market remains upbeat, with a total transacted value of S$1.35 billion in 1H 2019, triple the amount from the same period last year. The market is expected to stay healthy due to increasing tourist arrivals and initiatives to develop new attractions and rejuvenate existing ones. The Singapore Tourism Board recorded moderate year-on-year growth in tourist arrivals, and occupancy performance has been resilient despite an increase in new supply. The market is expected to continue to attract investors, with prices firm and demand high.

site_title: SGTech does its bit to turn Singapore into a Smart City
summary: SGTech, a trade association for the tech industry in Singapore, is working to address the country's skills gap and digital divide through various programs. The organization's Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) has helped 33 employees transition into new careers in the tech industry since its inception in 2018. SGTech is also expanding its skills development programs for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and tech startups, providing support with digitalization efforts and funding. The organization aims to make technology accessible to all, including those who are not tech-savvy, to ensure a more inclusive and digital-ready society.

site_title: Committed to upholding high standards of corporate governance
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is organizing the 10th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2019, themed "Technology - The New Face Of Governance?" from September 23 to October 1. The event is endorsed by key organizations, including The Association of Banks Singapore and The Singapore Exchange. A key feature of the program is the Statement of Support by corporates to uphold good corporate governance standards. The week aims to promote high standards of corporate governance in Singapore's business community.

site_title: Europe: Relief for stocks as political tensions ease
summary: European stocks rose 0.89% on Wednesday, driven by a rally in Italian shares following the formation of a new government. The easing of political tensions in Britain and Hong Kong also boosted investor sentiment. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index reached its highest level in months, as investors took heart from the unity of rival parties in Italy and the potential end to prolonged instability.

site_title: 'Flight shaming' threatens air travel demand beyond Europe: Iata chief
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) chief warns that the "flight shaming" movement, where environmentally conscious travelers choose trains over planes, may spread globally beyond Europe, particularly to North America. Alexandre de Juniac predicts that anti-aviation sentiment will lead to increased taxes on the industry, with governments like France already implementing such measures. Despite the aviation industry's efforts to reduce carbon emissions, activists are becoming increasingly passionate and effective, with climate activists like Greta Thunberg taking bold stances against air travel.

site_title: The rise of experiential and activity-based retail
summary: Singapore's retail industry is adapting to declining sales and changing shopping habits by enhancing shoppers' experiences with experiential and activity-based retail. Despite e-commerce's growth, brick-and-mortar stores remain relevant, accounting for over 90% of retail sales. Larger mall operators are investing in F&B, leisure, and entertainment, with unique attractions like indoor floating markets and rooftop parks. Successful community malls in Bangkok have shown that catering to local needs and providing intimate experiences can thrive. As shoppers seek personalized experiences, experiential retail will continue to evolve and innovate, with uncertain returns on investments for non-retail attractions.

site_title: Factors behind success of new property launches
summary: In post-July 2018's cooling measures, Singapore's property market underwent significant changes. Buyers now carefully consider projects' pricing and risk mitigation before purchasing. The median unit price of new sales launches decreased to S$1,280 per sq ft in Treasure at Tampines, while One Pearl Bank's units sold at a similar price to contemporaries. Freehold projects in growth districts, such as District 15, have performed well due to perceived resilience and potential for quicker rebounds. Developers are adopting strategies to balance sales and potential upturns, avoiding the Winners' Curse and focusing on maintaining cashflow.

site_title: To vote or not to vote? Britain mulls over early election
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government has tabled a motion to call for an early general election after lawmakers voted against his hardline Brexit strategy. The motion, which could be his only option, would be put to a vote if MPs decide to block a "no deal" Brexit scenario. The decision is uncertain, and Johnson may rely on opposition MPs to support his call for an election, which could take place before the European Council meeting on October 17 and 18.

site_title: Nordic Group to buy environmental engineering firm Envipure for S$14-15.5m
summary: Nordic Group is set to acquire environmental engineering firm Envipure for S$14-15.5 million. The acquisition will expand Nordic Group's product and service range, and tap new markets in the semiconductor and environmental engineering sectors. Envipure's maintenance contracts are expected to provide a stable income stream. The deal is conditional upon approval from directors and shareholders, and due diligence by Sunalps, the seller. Nordic Group plans to finance the purchase through internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: China launches probe into viral face-swap app
summary: China's technology industry overseer has launched an inquiry into the viral face-swapping app Zao, following online outcry over user data privacy. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has asked Momo Inc, the app's developer, to "rectify" its data handling practices and prevent online fraud. Zao's developers have agreed to abide by local laws and implement higher data security standards. The move comes after the app faced backlash over its initial user agreement, which granted "permanent" rights to user-generated content.

site_title: HDB resale market sees strong demand
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore saw a 6.8% increase in transaction volume in the first half of 2019, despite a 0.2% decline in the price index. The median resale price of 5-room HDB flats increased 0.4% year-on-year, while 4-room flats in non-mature towns like Bukit Panjang saw a 8.7% year-on-year growth. The steady supply of new HDB flats and competition from cheaper BTO flats contributed to the price decline, but the rise in HDB resale transactions is a healthy sign for the market.

site_title: Gold to rise above US$1,600 as Fed opts for cuts
summary: The Federal Reserve has opted for four 25 basis point interest rate cuts to combat slowing US growth and the fallout from the trade war with China. This move is expected to push gold prices above $1,600 an ounce, according to BNP Paribas SA. The cuts will reduce the upper bound on the Fed's benchmark rate to 1.25%, making real rates move into negative territory, increasing the appeal of holding gold. Gold prices have soared this year due to increased demand for havens, and investors have boosted holdings in bullion-backed exchange-traded funds.

site_title: New chairman says working to prepare Saudi Aramco listing
summary: Saudi Aramco's new chairman, Yasir al-Rumayyan, stated he will work to prepare for the company's listing by 2020-2021, aiming for transparency and efficiency. This move is part of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy away from oil. Aramco, the world's largest oil producer, is preparing an initial public offering (IPO) of up to 5% of its stake.

site_title: Staying invested for the long term
summary: In September 2019, Singapore's property sector bucked the trend of economic uncertainty, with developers continuing to roll out new launches and bid for government land tenders. Despite cooling measures, some projects stood out, and luxury apartments saw a surge in sales driven by foreign and permanent residents. Mass market condominiums also offered attractive capital appreciation due to reduced supply. The sector is expected to continue to thrive, with opportunities for landlords to leverage technology and retail malls to adapt to changing consumer preferences.

site_title: Female-focused Toronto film fest gets under way
summary: The Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) kicked off with a focus on female filmmakers and talent, featuring a special tribute to Meryl Streep, gala line-ups dedicated to women, and inaugural awards for female talent and outstanding careers in film. The festival showcases over 300 films from 84 countries, including 133 world premieres, with nearly half of the gala films directed by women. Notable world premieres include Taika Waititi's "Jojo Rabbit" and "Just Mercy", starring Brie Larson and Jamie Foxx. The festival aims to correct the industry's historic imbalance against women and provide a platform for leading ladies in the movies.

images.alt_text: Honouring leading ladies in the movies. Meryl Streep will be honoured with a special tribute; she will also receive the inaugural actress prize.

A new award honouring outstanding young female talent will go to Mati Diop, a black 37-year-old French director, whose film Atlantics - a haunting ghost story about African migrants - won the Grand Prix at Cannes.

site_title: Ex-NY Fed chief's break with tradition puts policymakers in a bind
summary: Former New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley's op-ed urging the Fed to block President Donald Trump's re-election by blocking interest rate cuts has put policymakers in a bind. Dudley broke with tradition, suggesting the Fed should intervene in politics to prevent Trump's re-election. Fed officials and former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers have rejected Dudley's proposal, citing the need to maintain central bank independence. The move has created tension among Fed officials, with some expressing doubts about further rate cuts and others defending the idea of using monetary policy to influence the election.

site_title: Asian currencies firm on stronger case for rate cuts
