summary: Asian currencies strengthened on Wednesday following weak US manufacturing data, which led to a decline in the dollar's value. The Chinese yuan rose 0.2% against the dollar, supported by a survey showing robust services sector activity in China. Other emerging Asian currencies, including the Indian rupee, Korean won, and Indonesian rupiah, also gained ground. Analysts predict that the dollar's vulnerability may be transient, and Asian currencies may benefit from the trend.

site_title: JPMorgan to phase China govt bonds into some benchmark bond indexes
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to phase Chinese government bonds into some of its benchmark indexes, starting February 28, 2020, with China's weight capped at 10% of the GBI-EM global diversified and narrow diversified indexes. This move could lead to $3 billion of inflows into China's bond market per month, according to Goldman Sachs estimates. China's onshore debt has seen steady access, with recent inflows reaching $4.8 billion in onshore Chinese bonds. The inclusion will accelerate capital inflows into the onshore bond market, with more passive funds buying the debt.

site_title: Singapore, Sichuan ink 17 pacts on back of jump in bilateral trade
summary: Singapore and China's Sichuan province signed 17 partnerships in areas such as medical technology, transport, and lifestyle, following a 42.8% year-on-year growth in bilateral trade in 2018. The agreements were announced at the 20th Singapore-Sichuan Trade & Investment Committee meeting. Minister Ng Chee Meng emphasized the potential for small and medium enterprises to drive growth and urged Sichuan companies to expand in South-east Asia. A medtech partnership between Singapore-based Innovfusion and West China Hospital was also signed, marking the first of its kind in the region.

site_title: Hotel, tourism-linked stocks could get a lift as visitor arrivals pick up
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals increased 4% in July, reaching 11.13 million for the first seven months, a 1.8% increase from last year. This boost is attributed to peak travel season and diversions from Hong Kong. Hotel and tourism-linked stocks may benefit from this trend, with several hotels reportedly trading at close to full occupancy. The industry's stronger third quarter outlook is a positive sign for the sector.

site_title: Yangzijiang inks new orders for 5 vessels
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, a Chinese shipbuilder, has signed new order contracts for five vessels, including three 82,000DWT bulk carriers and two 325,000DWT bulk carriers. The orders are worth US$395 million and follow previous announcements of orders for seven vessels in the third quarter of 2019. CEO Ren Letian attributed the surge in orders to ship owners' plans to cope with IMO2020 emission rules, and said the company is in an "advantageous position" to capitalize on market momentum.

site_title: China's services sector growth hits 3-month high: survey
summary: China's services sector experienced its highest growth in three months in August, with a 52.1 PMI index, driven by new orders and hiring. This is a welcome sign for Beijing, which is struggling to reverse a manufacturing slump. However, export orders pulled back, possibly due to US-China trade tensions. The services sector accounts for over half of China's economy and its growth has been cooling over the past year. The US-China trade conflict remains a drag, but government growth measures are gradually kicking in.

site_title: Nickel fires up on fears of supply deficit
summary: Nickel prices surged to a five-year high, reaching US$18,850 per tonne, amid fears of a supply deficit due to Indonesia's early export ban on nickel ore, set for January 2020, and a decline in nickel pig iron production in China. The ban is expected to drive the market into a deep deficit next year, while a booming electric vehicle market and stainless steel demand provide a rosy picture on the demand side. Analysts forecast the EV battery segment could grow 19% annually by 2030, while stainless steel demand is expected to stay resilient.

site_title: Cathay chairman Slosar resigns weeks after CEO's departure
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Chairman John Slosar resigned on Wednesday, less than three weeks after CEO Rupert Hogg's departure, amid mounting Chinese regulatory scrutiny. Slosar, 63, confirmed his resignation was due to retirement, not a disagreement with the board. He will be replaced by Patrick Healy, a long-time executive at Swire Pacific Ltd, the airline's top shareholder and manager. The move comes after Cathay faced backlash from China over staff involvement in protests.

site_title: Old money, young talent a potent mix to take Singapore's deep-tech scene forward: panellists
summary: Singapore's prominent families are backing young deep-tech entrepreneurs, recognizing the need for "something meaningful" to attract and retain young talent in the industry. The city-state's deep-tech scene is expected to flourish with the support of old money and new-age startups. Panellists at a recent forum emphasized the importance of meaningful projects and opportunities to draw young talent, which will help drive innovation and growth in the sector.

site_title: GLE SUVs piling up at German airport as Mercedes faces supplier issues
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, is storing thousands of GLE SUVs at a German airport due to supplier issues. The cars, valued at around $56,000, were made in the US for European customers and were delayed in delivery. This is the fourth profit warning issued by the company in less than a year, citing a "slower model ramp-up" as a reason. The issue is attributed to production bottlenecks caused by a supplier problem in the US, despite strong demand for the vehicles.

site_title: Househunt September 2019
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Househunt September 2019 issue. US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of decline. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases expected. Goldman Sachs acquired S$262 billion worth of Seoul hotel and retail assets. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay, filling more space after its post-bankruptcy recovery.

site_title: PM Johnson gambles all on election that will transform Britain
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to call a general election in October, which will determine the future of Brexit and the Union. After losing his majority and control of the Brexit process, Johnson has orchestrated the biggest rupture in the Conservative party in decades, expelling 21 MPs who opposed his Brexit plan. The election will be a painful contest for centrists, with voters forced to choose between Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn's radical left agenda. Johnson hopes to win a mandate to deliver Brexit and reshape the Conservative party, but the gamble is considered incredibly risky.

site_title: GuocoLand to launch freehold Meyer Mansion on Sept 13
summary: GuocoLand will launch the sale of its freehold condominium Meyer Mansion on September 13. Located along Amber Road in District 15, the 25-storey residential tower features 200 units, ranging from 484 sq ft to 2,142 sq ft. Analysts expect prices to be above S$2,700 per square foot, driven by the limited supply of freehold developments in the area. The development is expected to be completed in 2024, with a public preview scheduled for September 13.

site_title: Demand for mass market condos expected to continue
summary: Singapore's mass market condominium prices are expected to continue rising despite the slew of property measures introduced in recent years. Prices rose 9.7% in the Outside Central Region from Q2 2016 to Q2 2019, with 13.1% of resale transactions exceeding S$1,300 psf. New project launches have shattered previous price records, with 52 new mass market homes breaching S$1,800 psf and 28 sales soaring past S$2,000 psf. Attractive capital appreciation, with an average gross profit of S$160,000 over the past 10 years, is also sustaining buying interest. A potential supply crunch in two years may further drive up prices.

site_title: Corporate governance: more teeth and substance needed
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation (CES) has faced scrutiny over its corporate governance practices, particularly regarding remuneration disclosure. The company was queried by the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) regarding the disclosure of directors' remuneration in its FY2018 annual report. CES replied that disclosing the upper limit of remuneration for its executive director and group CEO, Chia Lee Meng, would be disadvantageous due to the competitive environment. However, this response raises concerns about transparency and fairness. The 2018 Code of Corporate Governance requires companies to disclose remuneration policies and levels, and CES's approach is inconsistent with this principle. Additionally, the company's remuneration of its top executives, including Chia, is estimated to be high, with one executive potentially earning over $4.9 million. CES's lack of transparency regarding remuneration and its board composition also raises concerns, particularly regarding the independence of its directors.

site_title: ECs have a pivotal role to play in the mass market
summary: Executive condominiums (ECs) remain a promising choice for buyers in Singapore, despite rising prices and diminishing supply. Introduced in 1995, ECs cater to the "sandwiched group" of Singaporeans seeking affordable private housing. Buyers must form a family nucleus with a household income not exceeding S$14,000. The government's larger supply of ECs will help aspiring Singaporeans own affordable private housing, offering a price advantage comparable to buying a luxury item at a reasonable price.

site_title: Economists slash Singapore's 2019 growth forecast to 0.6%
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at 0.6% in 2019, down from a previous forecast of 2.1%, according to a survey of economists. The downgrade is attributed to the escalation of the US-China trade conflict and weaker-than-expected Q2 numbers. The most likely growth range for 2019 is 0.5-0.9%, with a 37.3% chance. The survey also predicts a decline of 9.2% in non-oil domestic exports for the full year. Despite this, the finance and insurance sector is expected to grow 4.3% and private consumption is forecast to grow 3.4%.

images.alt_text: Domestic consumption continues to be buoyed by relatively low unemployment. Respondents expect 2.3% unemployment, up marginally from 2.2% previously.

site_title: Boundaries panel formed in first formal step towards next Singapore GE
summary: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) has been formed in Singapore, marking the first formal step towards the next general election, which must be held by April 2021. The committee, chaired by Cabinet Secretary Tan Kee Yong, will review current electoral boundaries and recommend changes, including reducing the average size of Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and creating more Single-Member Constituencies (SMCs). The committee's recommendations will be made to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong once completed.

site_title: Include ESG evaluation in investment recommendations
summary: Investors are increasingly considering the standard of corporate governance when evaluating company shares, as good governance has a significantly positive impact on share price performance. A growing body of evidence shows that well-governed firms attract more capital, leading to higher stock prices. Introducing governance assessments is crucial, especially with the growing emphasis on "environmental, social and governance" (ESG) issues. The Singapore Exchange's Governance and Transparency Index (GTI) score can be used to screen companies, and broking houses should highlight GTI indicators in their investment calls to encourage retail investors to consider ESG when making stock picks.

site_title: Asia markets rise on HK bill withdrawal
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 39.94 points to close at 3,130.57, driven by news of Hong Kong's withdrawal of its extradition bill. This lifted other Asia-Pacific markets, including China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea. The Hang Seng Index surged 600 points, and Hong Kong stocks were the best performers in Asia. However, analysts note that this may be a temporary reprieve, and investor appetite for risk-friendly assets remains high.

site_title: Traders everywhere tremble over Trump's Twitter tirades - except in China
summary: Chinese traders are less affected by President Donald Trump's Twitter tirades compared to their global counterparts. Despite Trump's tweets having previously impacted China's equity markets, traders now view them as having less influence. China's Shanghai Composite Index has risen 19% for the year, and traders are focusing on mid-to-long-term strategies rather than reacting to short-term market movements. The impact of Trump's tweets has waned, with the Shanghai Composite Index experiencing decreased volatility and limited declines in response to his comments.

site_title: Discrepancies among global regulators over Boeing 737 MAX worry Iata
summary: Global regulators are divided over reapproving Boeing's 737 MAX for commercial flight, raising concerns about a precedent for future aircraft programs. The 737 MAX was grounded worldwide after two deadly crashes in 2019, and Boeing is updating flight-control software. International regulators, including the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, will conduct their own analysis, while the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has traditionally led certification. IATA warns that a lack of unanimity among regulators could set a worrying precedent, with the FAA's credibility dented following the 737 MAX crashes.

site_title: Conspiracy theories are a threat to our democracy
summary: Conspiracy theories pose a significant threat to democracy, as they exploit vulnerable citizens and manipulate public opinion. Despite initial skepticism, research suggests that people prone to conspiracy thinking often lack interpersonal trust, suffer from insecurity, and have high levels of pessimism. These individuals are more susceptible to cognitive errors and can be exploited by powerful figures. Elites, including politicians and media hosts, have been found to propagate conspiracy theories to manipulate the public. This phenomenon is morally reprehensible and poses a danger to democratic societies, which rely on trust and transparency to function.

site_title: US trade deficit shrinks, but shortfall with China widens
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed slightly in July, but the gap with China surged to a six-month high. The trade deficit dropped 2.7% to $54.0 billion, while the goods trade deficit with China increased 9.4% to $32.8 billion. The US imposed 15% tariffs on Chinese imports, and China retaliated with additional duties on some US goods. The trade tensions have triggered a global manufacturing recession, and US financial markets were little moved by the data.

site_title: Google to pay US$170m fine for sharing YouTube kids data
summary: Google agreed to pay a US$170 million fine to settle charges of illegally collecting and sharing data from children on YouTube without parent consent. The Federal Trade Commission and New York state Attorney General reached the settlement, the largest under the 1998 Children's Online Privacy Protection Act. YouTube was accused of failing to comply with COPPA and misleading corporate clients about its platform's use of children. FTC Chairman Joe Simons stated that YouTube's violations were "unacceptable."

site_title: Hacker linked to WikiLeaks says he's been brought to Virginia for testimony
summary: Jeremy Hammond, a hacker linked to WikiLeaks, has been brought to Virginia to testify before a grand jury, according to his representatives. The move suggests prosecutors in the Eastern District of Virginia are expanding the WikiLeaks investigation, as Julian Assange fights extradition from England. Hammond previously admitted to stealing files from an intelligence firm.

site_title: Johnson demands Oct 15 election after defeat over Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson demanded an October 15 snap election after opposition lawmakers blocked a motion to extend Britain's EU exit date, dealing him a humiliating defeat in parliament. The move leaves Brexit uncertain, with possible outcomes including a turbulent no-deal exit or abandoning the endeavour. Johnson described the opposition's action as an attempt to surrender to the European Union, which would be unacceptable to many UK voters. The outcome sets the stage for a potential election, which could have significant implications for the country's future in the EU.

site_title: Jet Airways' creditors to recover only $300m-$400m rupees in liquidation scenario
summary: India's bankrupt Jet Airways' creditors are likely to recover only $300-$400 million in a liquidation scenario, less than 10% of the airline's total outstanding dues. The airline's financial and operational creditors, owed nearly 300 billion Indian rupees, will recover from the sale of assets such as owned planes and real estate. Jet Airways, once India's biggest private carrier, stopped flying in April after running out of cash, and was admitted to bankruptcy court in June.

site_title: St George's Road shops and apartments up for collective sale at S$26.5m
summary: A 4,403 sq ft freehold site at 2, 4, and 6 St George's Road in Singapore is up for collective sale via private treaty at S$26.5 million. The site has a plot ratio of three and gross floor area of 13,210 sq ft. The sale is being marketed by Jie Sheng Housing Agency.

site_title: Widodo orders Cabinet to step up efforts to attract FDI
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo ordered his Cabinet to streamline regulations hindering foreign direct investment, amid a global economic slowdown and US-China trade war. The president expressed frustration over the country's slow bureaucracy, citing a World Bank report showing 23 out of 33 companies relocated from China chose Vietnam or other countries over Indonesia. Indonesia targets 5.3% economic growth this year, but Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati revised down the forecast to 5.08% due to slowing global growth.

site_title: ST Engineering's aerospace arm injects US$19.5m into aircraft leasing business
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm has injected US$19.5 million into its aircraft leasing business, ST Engineering Aerospace Resources, bringing the total share capital contribution to US$49 million. The net asset value of the business is estimated to be US$53.74 million. This investment supports the expansion of the group's aircraft leasing business without affecting its consolidated net tangible asset per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: HK leader Lam withdraws contentious extradition Bill
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam has withdrawn the contentious extradition bill, a move that may ease public anger but won't end the months of protests. The bill's withdrawal follows a meeting with pro-establishment politicians, and Lam also announced an independent study of the government's performance and a review of the police response. This about-face may help calm the streets, but observers say it's unlikely to end the unrest, which has been ongoing for months.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International's second quarter oilseeds & grains profit before tax fell 80% due to weak soybean crushing margins. However, August's Chinese crush margins rose sharply, and palm-oil prices increased, potentially turning around the segment. Despite this, the company remains cautious due to escalating trade-war tariffs and the ASF crisis. In contrast, First Resources is preferred for its rising palm-oil prices and young acreage. BreadTalk's proposed acquisition of Food Junction is expected to boost profitability post-acquisition.

site_title: Porsche unveils its first-ever electric car
summary: Porsche unveiled its first-ever electric car, the Taycan, in three major markets. The top Turbo S version is priced at $185,000, while the base version is expected to be priced below $100,000. The car boasts ultra-fast charging capabilities and will be displayed alongside the mass-market VW ID.3 at the Frankfurt auto show. Porsche aims to capitalize on the growing demand for battery-powered vehicles, positioning itself for a sustainable future and competing with Tesla, the pioneer in e-car technology.

site_title: OUE C-Reit, H-Trust merger takes effect; creates enlarged S$6.9b Reit
summary: The trust scheme of arrangement for the merger of OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (C-Reit) and OUE Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) became effective, creating an enlarged S$6.9 billion Reit. The merger was approved by both trusts' holders on August 14 and sanctioned by the High Court last month.

site_title: UK finance minister Javid says he is "turning the page on austerity"
summary: UK finance minister Sajid Javid has announced a spending increase of over £13 billion, the largest in 15 years, as part of a push for an early election by Prime Minister Boris Johnson to break the Brexit impasse. The spending plan prioritizes education, health, and the police, but Javid has vowed to stick to Britain's existing fiscal rules. Analysts warn that this could weaken budget credibility at a time when the economy is at risk of recession and Brexit's outcome remains unclear.

site_title: Cathay Chairman Slosar resigns weeks after CEO left, deepening reshuffle
summary: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways Chairman John Slosar resigned on Wednesday, less than three weeks after CEO Paul Poon's departure amid Chinese regulatory scrutiny. The airline was forced to suspend staff involved in or supporting anti-government protests, which have plunged the city into a crisis. Slosar, 63, will be replaced by Patrick Healy, a long-time executive at Swire Pacific Ltd, Cathay's top shareholder. This move deepens the airline's reshuffle following the departure of Poon and other executives amid mounting pressure from China.

site_title: GuocoLand to launch Meyer Mansion condo on Sept 13
summary: GuocoLand will launch the sale of Meyer Mansion condos on Sept 13. The 25-storey freehold development, located in District 15, offers 200 units with prices starting at $2,400 per square foot. The site was bought through a collective sale for S$319.8 million. The development boasts frontline sea views, with prices potentially higher than Amber Park, and is expected to be completed in 2024. The limited supply of freehold developments in the area is expected to drive demand, with GuocoLand focusing on commercial projects in the future.

site_title: Harnessing big data in retail real estate
summary: Big data analysis in retail real estate is empowering landlords and retailers to better understand customers and adjust strategies. In Singapore, the use of big data has increased over the past two years, with landlords and retailers leveraging internal data and third-party services to benchmark performance. This data collection and analysis enables landlords and retailers to tailor their strategies to specific customer groups, increasing footfall in malls. Top planning areas driving footfall in Jurong East and Tampines malls have been identified, but no specific conclusions are drawn from this data.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as robust Chinese data eases growth concerns
summary: US stocks rose broadly at the open on Wednesday as China's robust data eased concerns of slowing global growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.70%, the S&P 500 gained 0.63%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.96%. The data, which showed China's manufacturing activity accelerating, boosted sentiment and eased tensions in Hong Kong following the withdrawal of a controversial bill. The positive start to the week helped to extend the US stocks rally despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 183.97 points, or 0.70 per cent, at the open to 26,301.99.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.37 points to 1,599.89. The index saw a significant gain in volume, with 2.49 billion lots worth RM 1.73 billion traded. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index is the only relevant index mentioned in the article, and no other specific information about Malaysia is provided.

site_title: Amazon may need to raise prices to offset latest tariff blow - BofA
summary: Amazon may need to raise prices in the US by 2.1-2.6% to offset the impact of new tariffs on Chinese goods, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch analysts. The 15% tariff on Chinese goods, including footwear and smart watches, intensifies trade tensions between the US and China. Amazon's first-party marketplace prices would need to increase by 2.1%, while third-party marketplace prices would need to rise by 2.6% to offset the tariff blow.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc will need to raise prices in the United States by about 2.1 per cent-2.6 per cent on average to offset the impact of fresh tariffs slapped by the Trump administration on various Chinese goods, Bank of America Merrill Lynch analysts estimated.

site_title: Russia asserts in Asia as geopolitical gambit
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin is focusing on Asia-Pacific as a key geopolitical gambit amid uncertainty with the West. He hosted the Eastern Economic Forum in Vladivostok, aiming to increase Russia's influence in the region. This strategy also includes strengthening ties with countries such as India, China, Japan, and Mongolia, with leaders from these nations attending the forum. Putin's approach has helped him maintain domestic popularity, as seen in his 2018 presidential re-election.

site_title: Synagie inks exclusive deal with Nicholas Tse's Hong Kong food company
summary: Synagie Corporation has inked an exclusive deal with Chef Nic, a Hong Kong-based food company founded by Nicholas Tse, to manage and expand the distribution and sales of its packed food products across South-east Asia. Synagie will provide cross-border solutions, including e-commerce management, customer service, and logistics. The deal aims to replicate Chef Nic's success in Greater China, with a focus on developing new product ideas for local markets. No value was disclosed for the deal.

site_title: Thailand seeks to become Southeast Asia energy trading hub
summary: Thailand is aiming to become a Southeast Asia energy trading hub through a new platform developed in collaboration with the state-owned Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (Egat). The platform, set to be studied by the Stock Exchange of Thailand and Egat, will allow trading of power for up to three to five years ahead and daily energy trading. Thailand, Laos, and Malaysia have committed to making 300 megawatts of power capacity available for trading, as part of a regional power grid project to support Asean member states with rapidly growing energy demands.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.3% higher after news of Hong Kong extradition bill withdrawal
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.3% to close at 3,130.57, following news that Hong Kong's extradition bill would be withdrawn. The Hang Seng Index surged 3.9% in Hong Kong, and other Asia-Pacific markets also gained. The STI's benchmark jumped in the afternoon session, with the banking trio DBS, OCBC, and UOB also higher. Real estate play HongKong Land led the STI's best performers, with a 8.3% gain.

site_title: EU makes 780m euros available in emergency funding for Brexit
summary: The European Union has allocated 780 million euros (approximately $1.19 billion) in emergency funding to address the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit on member states. The majority of the funds, 600 million euros, come from the Emergency Solidarity Fund, while the remaining 180 million euros come from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The funds will help affected businesses, workers, and border checks, primarily impacting countries like Ireland, Germany, and France. The EU will assess applications from affected member states by the end of April 2020.

site_title: Yangzijiang inks new order contracts for 5 vessels
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has signed new order contracts for five vessels, including three 82,000DWT bulk carriers and two 325,000DWT bulk carriers. The contracts, worth US$395 million, bring the total value of new orders for the third quarter to US$395 million. CEO Ren Letian attributed the surge in orders to ship owners' plans to cope with IMO2020 emission rules. The company's stock price has rebounded after turbulence last month, closing at 94 Singapore cents on Wednesday.

site_title: DLF Holdings' subsidiary secures subcontract works worth S$4.29m
summary: DLF Holdings' subsidiary Acmes-Kings Corporation secured a S$4.29 million subcontract for pre-fabricated multi-trade services at a health campus in Woodlands, Singapore. The contract, valued at S$4.29 million, is expected to start in September 2019 and be completed by the first quarter of 2021, contributing to the group's revenue but not affecting its earnings per share.

site_title: Court dismisses claim by ex-employees of Asiaphos' subsidiary
summary: Asiaphos' subsidiary, Sichuan Mianzhu Norwest Phosphate Chemical Co, had a claim of 1.844 million yuan (S$357,347) in severance pay dismissed by the Mianzhu Municipal People's Court. The 20 former employees can still appeal the decision to the Deyang Intermediate Court.

site_title: Rex International to take over company guarantee for group's 90%-owned subsidiary
summary: Rex International has submitted documentation to take over the company guarantee for its 90%-owned subsidiary Lime Petroleum AS, required under Norwegian law for sub-sea natural resource exploration and transportation. The takeover is expected to have no significant impact on Rex International's financial statements for 2019. The move follows standard procedures for the group's operations, which involve exploration and exploitation of sub-sea natural resources on the Norwegian Continental Shelf.

site_title: CDL secures S$250m sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: CDL secures a S$250 million, three-year revolving credit facility from DBS Bank to promote the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. The loan, known as the SDG Innovation Loan, will be used for general working capital and corporate funding, aligning with the green financing concept focused on innovations. This move supports CDL's efforts to promote the UN's Sustainable Development Goals and is part of DBS Bank's commitment to green financing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Private-sector economists lowered Singapore's 2019 growth forecast to 0.6%, aligning with the government's official range of zero to 1%. Meanwhile, Vietnam surprised by Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs, while China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain ground at open
summary: European stock markets opened on a positive note, with the FTSE 100 rising 0.3%, the CAC 40 adding 0.8%, and the DAX 30 increasing 1.0%. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare sectors. Meanwhile, US stocks edged towards fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions, while Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Bangkok tops Paris, London as world's most-visited city
summary: Bangkok has been named the world's most-visited city for the fourth consecutive year, with 22.8 million visitors reported in the annual rankings by MasterCard Inc. Paris and London ranked second and third, respectively. The number of international visitors across 200 cities grew by 76% in the last 10 years. Despite a drop in Chinese arrivals, Indian tourists are expected to reach 2 million in 2019, offsetting the decline. The Thai tourism industry faces headwinds, but growth in the middle class and low-cost airlines are expected to increase travel accessibility.

site_title: COE prices continue to dip across the board
summary: COE prices in Singapore dipped across the board in the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp priced at $31,783, down from $31,917. Commercial vehicles were priced at $25,502, and motorcycles at $4,089. The market expects no large fluctuations in premiums for the rest of the year due to offsetting replacement demand and uncertain economic conditions.

site_title: Hong Kong leader announces withdrawal of controversial extradition bill
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam announced the withdrawal of a contentious extradition bill that triggered months of unrest, marking a significant concession to protesters demanding greater democracy and an independent inquiry into police brutality. The bill, which would have allowed extraditions to mainland China, has sparked widespread protests and arrests. Lam's decision, made in an internal meeting with lawmakers and delegates, comes amid rising tensions between China and the US. The move is seen as a partial victory for protesters, but its impact on the ongoing unrest remains uncertain, with many calling for further concessions.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes marginally higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.12% to close at 20,649.14, driven by late bargain hunting due to a weak yen. Investors remain concerned over a potential global economic slowdown, despite US data showing weakness in the manufacturing sector. The broader Topix index fell 0.26%. Key movers included Nintendo, which jumped 2.59%, and Sony, which gained 0.85%. Nissan and Toyota also experienced losses, with Nissan down 1.73% and Toyota down 0.69%.

site_title: Electoral boundaries committee convened in first formal step towards next S'pore GE
summary: Singapore's Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) has been convened, marking the first formal step towards the next general election. The committee aims to further reduce the average size of Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and create more single-member constituencies (SMCs). This move is expected to lead to more competitive elections and potentially alter the electoral landscape in Singapore.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on global growth worries, but NZ rises
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,553, marking a third consecutive day of decline, due to weak domestic growth data and US manufacturing contraction. The country's economy grew at its slowest pace in a decade last quarter, with tepid wage growth and a downturn in home building weighing on domestic consumption. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.5% to 11,008.13, contrasting with Australia's decline.

site_title: Six developers that may thrive if Hong Kong home prices drop 30%
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has identified six property stocks that could withstand a 30% drop in Hong Kong home prices, retail sales decline, and 40% decrease in prime office rents. The worst-case scenario, driven by US-China trade war and social unrest, threatens Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The selected stocks include developers that are likely to benefit from the potential downturn, such as those with strong balance sheets and diversified portfolios. The move is a response to growing investor concerns and uncertainties in the Hong Kong market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 3.90% higher on extradition bill hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 3.90% on Wednesday, driven by hopes the government would agree to a key demand of campaigners amid months of protests. The Hang Seng Index surged 995.38 points to 26,523.23. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the Hang Seng Index's gains marking the largest in nearly two months. The positive move comes after months of economic and financial turmoil caused by the protests.

site_title: The pound's decline hasn't done much to boost UK tourism
summary: The UK's decline in the World Economic Forum's tourism rankings has not improved its attractiveness to visitors despite the pound's depreciation. The country fell from fifth to sixth place, the only nation to drop in the rankings, due to a decrease in its score for international openness and business environment. The UK now ranks 23rd in the world for international openness.

site_title: Fragrance Group acquires Min Yuan Apartments; plans to build hotel development
summary: Fragrance Group's subsidiary Fragrance Victory acquired Min Yuan Apartments at 62 Waterloo Street for S$141 million. The property, with a 999-year tenure, will be redeveloped into a hotel development with a combined land area of 2,694 square meters and a gross floor area of 11,315 square meters, alongside the adjacent land plot owned by Fragrance Victory.

site_title: Hot Stock: Yangzijiang up 4.42% on heavy volume
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's stock surged 4.42% on heavy volume to 94.5 cents, following a report that Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam plans to formally withdraw the extradition bill, ending the city's months-long protest crisis. The company's shares have been active since August after a TradeWinds article linked Chairman Ren Yuanlin's charitable foundation to Xi Jinping's anti-corruption commission. Liu Jianguo, an industry veteran connected to Yangzijiang, was being probed for disciplinary violations by Beijing's anti-graft body.

site_title: Hong Kong leader to meet protesters' demand to withdraw extradition bill
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam will formally withdraw the extradition bill that sparked months of unrest, meeting one of protesters' key demands. The bill's withdrawal is seen as a potential end to the crisis, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumping 3.3% after the report. The move comes after a leaked audio recording revealed Lam's concerns about the bill's impact and a proposal by Lam to defuse the conflict. China's government has supported Lam's decision, but some officials have denounced it as "fake."

site_title: Trade-war damage piles weight of global economy onto consumers
summary: Global economic growth is increasingly dependent on consumers, with retail sales volumes rising 4.8% in the last quarter. However, signs of weakness in manufacturing, such as falling factory employment, could soon filter through to the rest of the economy, threatening a recession. This could be exacerbated by the ongoing US-China trade war, Brexit uncertainty, and weakening labor markets in advanced economies. Central bankers must gauge the spillover threat from manufacturing to household demand, with the US consumer spending being a key driver of growth.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks jump as investors cheer upbeat China services sector survey
summary: South Korean stocks rose over 1% on Wednesday after a private survey showed an upbeat China service sector in August, easing worries about the Sino-US trade war. The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI index ended up 22.84 points, or 1.16%, at 1,988.53. This follows a 2.57% decline for the KOSPI so far this year and a 6.1% drop in the previous 30 trading sessions.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI ended up 22.84 points, or 1.16 per cent, at 1,988.53.

site_title: Analysts maintain negative outlook for Malaysian aviation sector
summary: Malaysian analysts have maintained a negative outlook for the country's aviation sector due to policy uncertainty, overcapacity, and a challenging yield environment. The recent reduction of passenger service charge (PSC) rates for international flights from October 1 will result in a loss of 200 million ringgit per annum in revenue for the government. Analysts believe this will undermine industry reform measures, including the Regulated Asset Base (RAB) framework, and create regulatory uncertainty for investors.

site_title: St George's Rd shops, apartments up for collective sale at S$26.5m
summary: A collective sale of three shops and residential units along St George's Road in Singapore will be launched on Thursday at S$26.5 million. The 4,403 sq ft freehold land has a plot ratio of 3 and gross floor area of 13,210 sq ft. Owners have consented to the sale, and the buyer can build up to five storeys, with redevelopment possibilities including a 4,000 sq ft restaurant or 12 apartments. The site is strategically located at the city fringe, near the Boon Keng MRT station, and offers freehold title and prominent visibility.

site_title: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam to formally withdraw extradition bill, says SCMP; stocks soar
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam plans to formally withdraw the extradition bill, a key demand of pro-democracy protesters who have been demonstrating against the government for almost three months. The move comes after clashes between protesters and riot police, resulting in over 1,100 arrests. The bill's withdrawal is expected to ease tensions, with Hong Kong stocks soaring 3.9% in response. The move is seen as a major concession to protesters, but it remains to be seen whether it will fully address their demands for greater democratic freedom and autonomy.

site_title: Hot stock: Hongkong Land jumps 8% on news Carrie Lam is formally withdrawing extradition bill
summary: Hongkong Land shares jumped 8% after Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam formally withdrew the extradition bill, a key demand of pro-democracy protesters. The bill's withdrawal is seen as a major concession, easing tensions in the city. The Hong Kong dollar also gained, and the Hang Seng Index rose 3.5%. The move is expected to bring an end to 13 weeks of protests, with Lam calling a meeting with pro-establishment politicians. The decision is seen as a positive for the stock market, with Hongkong Land's shares trading at US$5.88.

site_title: Australia: Shares in the red on global growth fears; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% to 6,515.4, tracking weak global economic growth concerns. The country's economy grew at its slowest pace in a decade last quarter, with cash-strapped consumers on strike. This has heightened the need for monetary and fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Hong Kong shares rally after Lam said to 'withdraw' controversial bill
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 4.6% after reports suggested Chief Executive Carrie Lam would formally withdraw the extradition bill sparking months of protests. The MSCI Hong Kong Index reached its biggest gain since 2011, with property developers Wharf Real Estate Investment Co and New World Development Co rallying 8%. The Hang Seng Index also rose 3.5%. The bill's withdrawal is seen as an inflection point in the crisis, with retail and property stock investors signaling optimism. However, experts warn the rebound may be short-lived and the unrest may not be fully placated by the government's concession.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,108.84, up 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,108.84 as of 1pm, driven by upbeat service sector data from China and positive trading in the private sector. Despite economists lowering their full-year growth forecast for Singapore to 0.6%, the market saw gains from various stocks, including YZJ Shipbuilding, Singtel, and ComfortDelGro. Banking stocks also rose, while Asian stocks traded mixed on low volumes.

site_title: D'Grove Villas condo in District 10 relaunched for collective sale at S$392m
summary: FREEHOLD condominium D'Grove Villas in District 10 has been relaunched for collective sale at S$392 million, with a unit land rate of S$2,908 per square foot per plot ratio. The property, located at 8A Orange Grove Road, has 45 units and sits on a 50,400 square feet site. The tender will close on Sept 30, with Centaline Singapore citing a surge in foreign property purchases and rising property sales in the market. The redevelopment site is zoned for residential use and may be redeveloped into a condominium up to 36 storeys high.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.34 points to 1,593.86. The market saw 62.8 million lots traded worth RM10.46 million, with losers beating gainers 72 to 70.

site_title: Private-sector economists lower Singapore 2019 growth forecast to 0.6%
summary: Private-sector economists have lowered their full-year growth forecast for Singapore to 0.6% from 2.1%, citing the escalation of the US-China trade conflict and weaker-than-expected Q2 numbers. This forecast aligns with the government's revised growth range of 0-1%. The downgrade is attributed to the trade conflict's impact on the global economy, with economists expecting a challenging year ahead.

site_title: Singapore, Sichuan deepen cooperation in sectors including medtech
summary: Singapore and Sichuan province in China deepened their economic cooperation with 17 partnerships in sectors such as medical technology, transport, and logistics. The partnerships include a research collaboration on smart anesthesia systems and were signed at the 20th Singapore-Sichuan Trade and Committee meeting. Trade between the two regions grew 42.8% year-over-year to $1.44 billion, with Singapore remaining Sichuan's largest investor in 2018. The agreements aim to promote innovation and business opportunities between the two economies.

site_title: Chinese shoppers adopt facial payments in cashless drive
summary: China is embracing facial payment technology, allowing shoppers to make purchases without cards or wallets by simply posing in front of point-of-sale machines equipped with cameras. This technology is being rolled out nationwide, marking a significant shift towards a cashless society. Customers link their face to a digital payment system or bank account before making a purchase, making facial payments a convenient alternative to traditional payment methods.

site_title: Credit Suisse brings in ex-UBS, Lombard Odier senior staff to boost impact-investing team
summary: Credit Suisse has hired three senior staff members from rival UBS and Lombard Odier to boost its impact-investing team. James Gifford, formerly head of impact investing at UBS, joins as head of impact advisory, while Guillaume Bonnel, previously head of impact investing at Lombard Odier, takes on the role of head of sustainable and impact products. Helen McDonald, also from UBS, becomes UK head of foundations and impact advisory services. These hires aim to enhance Credit Suisse's impact thought leadership and product offerings.

site_title: Shoppers at 7 FairPrice outlets to pay for plastic bags in month-long trial
summary: NTUC FairPrice will start charging 10-20 cents for plastic bag use at seven outlets in a month-long trial starting Sept 16. Shoppers will pay 10 cents for plastic bags at Cheers outlets and FairPrice Xpress stores, while 20 cents will be charged at FairPrice, FairPrice Finest, and FairPrice Xtra stores. The trial aims to encourage shoppers to bring their own bags, with collected bags to be donated to charity.

site_title: Telegram secretly plans 'Gram' cryptocurrency
summary: Telegram, a Russian-founded messaging service, is secretly planning to launch a cryptocurrency called "Gram" to compete with Facebook. The project, which has been working in secrecy for a year, aims to create an accessible service that is easier to use than existing cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. Telegram's goal is to create a "standard cryptocurrency used for the regular exchange of value in the daily lives of ordinary people". The company has not released any official information about Gram, but media reports suggest it will be launched soon.

site_title: Dissenting voice on Bank of Japan board calls for pre-emptive monetary easing
summary: Bank of Japan board member Goushi Kataoka has called for pre-emptive monetary easing to address risks to Japan's inflation outlook and economic growth. Kataoka warns that the US-China trade war will hurt exports, and the yen's strength could weigh on import costs, making it unlikely for inflation to reach the BOJ's 2% target. His comments run counter to Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's view that Japan's economy is sustaining momentum to achieve the central bank's price goal, and signal a growing sense of alarm within the BOJ over the damage the trade war is inflicting on the economy.

site_title: Australia set to beat 2020 clean energy target
summary: Australia has met its 2020 clean energy target, generating 33,000 gigawatt hours of power from large-scale renewable energy a year ahead of plan. The milestone was achieved despite challenges, including climate policy uncertainty, soaring power prices, and unreliable supply. The Clean Energy Regulator reported 4,851 MW of committed capacity and an additional 1,556 MW likely to be built. The achievement marks the end of a government subsidy scheme and demonstrates the industry's ability to innovate and adapt.

site_title: China seen heading for sub-6 per cent economic growth as tariffs soar
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow to below 6% in 2020 due to the ongoing US tariff war, with forecasts cut by major economists including Oxford Economics, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Bloomberg Economics. China's economic growth is already weakening, with output growth slowing to 6.2% in the second quarter, and demand for credit remaining weak. Policymakers are under pressure to act, with some warning that the current approach to stimulus is insufficient, and the government's ability to claim a "moderately prosperous society" by 2021 is at risk.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.58% higher on Wednesday, following a two-day drop, but investors remain concerned about the China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose to 25,675.16, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.08%. The US stock market also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian economic growth hits 10-year low
summary: Australia's economic growth has hit a 10-year low, expanding just 1.4% in the year to June, according to official data. The economy grew 0.4% between April and June, driven by mining exports and government spending. Despite avoiding recession for almost 28 years, the weak data will fuel concerns about the economic outlook. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates at a record low, with analysts expecting further cuts to boost the economy. Prime Minister Scott Morrison remains optimistic about recent tax cuts stimulating the economy in the current quarter.

site_title: Indonesia plans tax overhaul to make tech firms pay VAT
summary: Indonesia is preparing a bill to make tech firms like Google, Amazon, and Netflix pay value added tax (VAT), regardless of physical presence. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati stated that these companies have a "significant economic presence" and will be considered a "permanent establishment" liable for VAT. The move aims to increase tax revenue from the tech sector.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is preparing a bill that will make tech firms such as Alphabet Inc's Google and Amazon pay value added tax (VAT), Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said.

site_title: Singapore takes 40th place in EIU world's most liveable cities ranking; Vienna in top spot
summary: Singapore ranks 40th in the Economist Intelligence Unit's (EIU) world's most liveable cities ranking, behind Hong Kong at 38th. Vienna holds the top spot for the second year, with Melbourne in second place. Cities with populations between 300,000 and 1 million are deemed liveable due to high-quality education, public healthcare, and transport systems. Financial hubs London and New York lag behind, with Hong Kong's ranking expected to decline due to recent political unrest. Climate change poses a risk to cities' liveability, with pollution affecting cities like New Delhi and Cairo.

site_title: Top 30 stocks by turnover outpace STI in first 8 months of 2019: SGX
summary: Singapore's 30 most actively traded stocks by turnover outpaced the Straits Times Index (STI) by 7.7% in the first 8 months of 2019, with average total returns of 11.5% compared to the STI's 4.8% return. Six non-STI stocks, including Mapletree Logistics Trust and Suntec Reit, contributed significantly to the outperformance with average daily turnover of S$84 million and a 27.8% total return over the period.

site_title: ComfortDelGro rolls out free on-demand buses
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean transport giant, has launched an on-demand bus service called ComfortConnect. The service, available in Tanjong Rhu and Meyer Road since August 15, operates from Mondays to Fridays between 10am and 4pm and serves 16 stops. No fares are collected during a three-month trial. The company aims to gauge the commercial viability of on-demand services, following the Land Transport Authority's decision to shelve plans for a similar scheme. This is ComfortDelGro's second on-demand bus service, with a similar service operating in Australia.

site_title: Billionaire Uniqlo founder wants a woman to succeed him
summary: Tadashi Yanai, 70-year-old founder of Uniqlo, has expressed a preference for a female successor, citing their perceived advantages in perseverance, detail orientation, and aesthetic sense. Maki Akaida, 40, is a possible candidate, having managed Uniqlo's Japan operations and working in sales and human resources. Yanai aims to increase the ratio of female senior executives to more than half of total executives, reflecting Japan's push for gender diversity in top management roles.

images.alt_text: Tadashi Yanai, Fast Retailing Co's 70-year-old billionaire founder, said he would prefer to be succeeded by a woman, which would be better for Asia's largest retailer.

site_title: Clifford Capital prices US$300m 5-year bonds at 1.733%
summary: Clifford Capital, a Temasek-backed specialist provider of structured finance solutions, priced US$300m 5-year senior unsecured notes at 1.733% coupon, with the Singapore government guaranteeing the debt. The notes will mature on Sept 10, 2024, and proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. The deal represents a spread of 35 basis points above five-year US Treasuries, with Standard & Poor's expected to rate the notes "AAA".

site_title: Gold seen cracking US$1,600 as Fed cuts rates 4 more times
summary: Gold prices are expected to surge above $1,600 an ounce as the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates four times to combat slowing US growth and the trade war with China. The Fed's accommodative stance will make gold more appealing as real rates move into negative territory. This follows recent rate cuts in July and is expected to boost holdings in bullion-backed exchange-traded funds. The US-China trade war has damaged global growth, prompting investors to seek safe-haven assets like gold.

site_title: 21 Conservative MPs voted against UK's Johnson: official
summary: Twenty-one Conservative MPs, including former finance minister Philip Hammond and Winston Churchill's grandson Nicholas Soames, voted against the UK government in a Brexit vote, defying Prime Minister Boris Johnson. This rebellion could lead to expulsion from the party.

images.alt_text: Twenty-one Conservative MPs rebelled against British Prime Minister Boris Johnson to vote against the government in Tuesday's Brexit vote and now face possible expulsion from the party.

site_title: 32 shophouses along Lavender St, Serangoon Rd for sale with S$138m guide price
summary: A portfolio of 32 freehold shophouses along Lavender Street and Serangoon Road has been launched for sale by public tender at a guide price of S$138 million. The shophouses have a combined land area of 49,244 sq ft and a gross floor area of 79,502 sq ft, with a potential for a six-storey rear extension. Assuming no development charge is payable, the indicative price is S$1,736 psf. The sale is expected to attract interest from developers, real estate funds, and local companies, driven by higher rental yields compared to CBD shophouses.

site_title: Pentagon frees US$3.6b to build 282km of wall on Mexican border
summary: The US Defence Department has freed up $3.6 billion to build a 282km wall on the Mexican border as ordered by President Donald Trump. This diversion of funds comes from 127 "deferred military projects" both inside and outside the country, confirmed by Defence Secretary Mike Esper. The move follows six weeks of Congressional confirmation.

site_title: E-cigarette pioneer Juul looks to Asian smokers for growth
summary: Juul Labs Inc, the e-cigarette pioneer, is shifting its focus to Asia, where it aims to capitalize on the region's high smoking rates and favorable regulations. The company has begun selling its vaping devices in South Korea, Indonesia, and the Philippines and is exploring more markets in the region. Despite negative publicity and government crackdowns in the US, Juul believes Asia offers a lucrative alternative for tobacco giants. The company's expansion plans come as Philip Morris International Inc and Altria Group Inc, which has a 35% stake in Juul, consider a merger, potentially complicating Juul's growth strategy.

site_title: Martial law is the latest risk worrying investors in Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong investors are concerned about the possibility of martial law being invoked by Chief Executive Carrie Lam amid ongoing unrest. A colonial-era statute, the Emergency Regulations Ordinance, gives Lam broad powers similar to martial law, which could be implemented if necessary. Chinese officials have confirmed that the law could be used if necessary, adding to investor worries. The statute, introduced in 1922, allows Lam to make "any regulations whatsoever" deemed desirable in the public interest, sparking fears of a potential crackdown. Investors are mapping out potential risks and considering the implications of such a move.

images.alt_text: As investors map out potential risks from Hong Kong's summer of unrest, one tool at the government's disposal is attracting increased attention: a colonial-era statute that gives authorities broad powers similar to martial law.

site_title: P2P lending platform Funding Societies makes three C-suite hires
summary: Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer lending platform, has made three key hires to its management team. Matt Lambie joins as CTO, bringing experience in software development and technical operations. Dheeraj Chowdhry, a former CEO at global banking organizations, joins as CEO of Singapore. Jared Goldberg, with almost 15 years of experience in financial services technology, takes on the role of chief data officer. These hires aim to strengthen the platform, which has funded over S$800 million in loans, backed by SoftBank Ventures Asia and Sequoia India.

site_title: Japan's economy minister Motegi front-runner to be next foreign minister: paper
summary: Japan's economy minister Toshimitsu Motegi is likely to replace Taro Kono as foreign minister in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet reshuffle on September 11. Motegi will continue as lead negotiator in trade talks with the US, emphasizing "stability" and "challenge". Finance Minister Taro Aso and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga are expected to keep their key posts, while younger members may be appointed.

site_title: France pushes US$15b credit line plan for Iran, if US allows it
summary: France has proposed a US$15 billion credit line for Iran, contingent on Tehran's full compliance with the 2015 nuclear deal, a move that depends on US approval. The credit line, guaranteed by Iranian oil revenues, aims to encourage Iran's return to the deal and address regional security concerns. However, US opposition to the plan contradicts its policy of "maximum pressure" on Iran. The proposal comes amid tensions between the US and Iran, with Iran threatening to scale back its nuclear commitments if European guarantees are not met.

site_title: Qatar unveils 2022 World Cup logo round the globe
summary: Qatar unveiled the official logo for the 2022 World Cup, a stylized Arabic white unisex shawl with maroon patterning, displayed in a figure-of-eight symbolizing infinity and creating a heart shape above the words "FIFA WORLD CUP Qatar 2022". The logo was projected onto the National Archives building in Doha and displayed in major cities worldwide. The tournament is scheduled to take place in November and December 2022, and preparations are accelerating, including the construction of new stadiums and infrastructure projects.

site_title: DoorDash spreads beyond North America with Australia launch
summary: DoorDash, the largest US food delivery company, launched its services in Melbourne, Australia, marking its first foray outside North America. The company aims to sell deliveries from thousands of restaurants in the city, competing with Uber Eats, Menulog, and Deliveroo. DoorDash plans to expand globally, with Melbourne chosen for its relatively affordable real estate and popularity among global companies. The move comes as the Australian food delivery market shows signs of slowing growth.

images.alt_text: Meal delivery service DoorDash Inc said it will begin taking orders in the Australian city of Melbourne on Wednesday, its first foray outside North America, adding to the competition in the country's home-delivery service market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: China Jinjiang Environment, Cache Logistics Trust, Bonvests, Nordic Group
summary: China Jinjiang Environment announced that majority lenders of its US$200 million loan facility do not require mandatory prepayment of outstanding loans due to a change in control. Cache Logistics Trust secured a major new tenant, leasing over 300,000 square feet, and has secured 1,112,100 sq ft of leases and renewals in 2019. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Japan Aug service sector growth jumps to near 2-yr high: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector experienced its fastest growth in nearly two years in August, with the Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 53.3 from 51.8 in July. This marks the fastest expansion since October 2017, indicating domestic resilience despite mounting overseas pressures. The revised PMI reading was slightly lower than the initial flash PMI reading of 53.4. Economists attribute the growth to a shift in Japan's service sector, with the sector showing increased activity.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.2% to 3,085.86
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.2% to 3,085.86, following a decline in US stocks overnight due to trade woes and manufacturing contraction. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1%, the S&P 500 shed 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 1.1%. Locally, Singtel lost 0.3%, OCBC Bank slipped 0.4%, while DBS and United Overseas Bank posted gains. The decline was part of a broader Asian market downturn, with Japan's Topix and Australia stocks also falling.

site_title: UK announces £2 billion extra Brexit funding
summary: The British government announced an additional £2 billion in Brexit funding, bringing the total to £14.8 billion, to be spent on projects such as border guards and port infrastructure in the year after the UK leaves the EU. The funding was announced after the government suffered a defeat over its Brexit strategy.

site_title: No US interest rate cut 'required' if growth continues: Fed member
summary: US Federal Reserve member Eric Rosengren stated that no interest rate cut is required if the US economy continues on its current path, citing steady growth, strong consumer spending, low inflation, and wage increases. This contradicts market expectations of a rate cut later this month. Rosengren noted that while risks are rising, they have not become reality, and unemployment remains low, GDP growth is steady, and inflation is below target. The Fed will carefully monitor incoming data to determine if policy adjustments are necessary.

site_title: Facial recognition becomes opt-in feature at Facebook
summary: Facebook has rolled out an opt-in facial recognition feature for users worldwide, replacing a previous "tag" suggestion setting. The new feature allows users to turn it on or off by default, with a notification provided to new users or those who previously had the "tag" feature enabled. The company claims it doesn't share facial recognition information with third parties and doesn't sell its technology. This move comes amid growing concerns about facial recognition technology, particularly in surveillance applications.

site_title: Russia open to private companies developing energy-rich Arctic shelf: minister
summary: Russia's natural resources and environment minister, Dmitry Kobylkin, expressed support for allowing private oil and gas companies to work on the Arctic shelf, citing the need for increased investment in hydrocarbon projects. The Arctic's vast oil and gas reserves are expected to become more accessible as climate change melts the ice and technology advances, with the Russian economy heavily reliant on natural resources. This move is seen as a potential boost to the country's energy sector.

site_title: Chile cuts benchmark rate to 9-year low as economy weakens
summary: Chile's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to 2% - a 9-year low - to stimulate an economy weakened by a global trade war and domestic demand. The rate cut is seen as a response to a slowing economy, with analysts forecasting 2.7% growth in 2019, down from 3.4% initially forecast. The decision is expected to be followed by further rate cuts, with traders predicting a key rate of 1.75% by March. The move aims to stimulate inflation and stabilize the economy amid weakening business and consumer confidence.

site_title: OUE C-Reit, H-Trust merger becomes effective; creates enlarged S$6.9b Reit
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (C-Reit) and OUE Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) have successfully merged, creating a diversified S$6.9 billion real estate investment trust (S-Reit). The merger, approved by holders and the High Court, has made the enlarged entity one of the largest in Singapore. The new entity will have a broader investment mandate, increased funding capacity, and a larger capital base, allowing it to undertake larger transactions and asset enhancement initiatives. Units of OUE C-Reit closed flat at S$0.52 following the completion of the merger.

site_title: ecoWise to buy Malaysia land parcel, factory for RM13m
summary: ecoWise, a CATALIST-listed environmental solutions provider, plans to buy a 2.4-hectare industrial land in Malaysia along with the factory building for RM13 million (S$4.3 million). The acquisition is expected to boost production capacity of rubber compound and rethreaded tyres, increasing efficiency through economies of scale. The leasehold property has a remaining tenure of 56 years and will be sold on an as-is-where-is basis. The company will finance the acquisition with internal funds, and shares closed at 2.1 Singapore cents on Tuesday, down 0.5 cent or 19.2 percent.

site_title: Climate change already costing meat and dairy producers a lot
summary: The meat and dairy industry is increasingly feeling the effects of climate change, with 77% of companies making little to no disclosure about emissions from their operations and supply chains. The sector is responsible for 13-18% of global greenhouse gas emissions, and climate change is causing droughts, floods, and storms to impact animal protein industries, resulting in significant losses. A new report by Fairr found that only 1 in 60 companies has a comprehensive global policy aimed at stopping deforestation, and the trend towards plant-based meat may be a preview of the shifts ahead.

site_title: GIC-backed South Korea hotel app looks beyond love motels in Indian expansion
summary: Yanolja Co, backed by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC Pte and Booking Holdings Inc, has acquired eZee Technosys, a leading Indian lodgings management platform. The acquisition brings 21,000 global clients to Yanolja, expanding its reach beyond South Korea's love motels. The company plans to automate technology to other businesses across the region, targeting families and business travelers in Asia. This expansion follows Yanolja's investment in Zen Rooms, a South-east Asian budget hotel chain, and aims to capitalize on the region's growing travel market.

site_title: How to survive the world's longest flights in style
summary: Airlines are pushing the boundaries of long-distance flying with ultra-long range flights exceeding 16,000 km. For business travelers, non-stop marathons of 18+ hours prove superior to airport lay-overs. To survive these flights in style, consider investing in premium seats, booking a window seat for minimal disturbance, and staying hydrated and entertained with in-flight entertainment. Airlines like Airbus and Boeing are also investing in high-tech innovations to enhance passenger comfort. With the rise of ultra-long range flights, business travelers can now enjoy a more convenient and comfortable journey.

site_title: Common data environment for all Lum Chang projects
summary: Singapore's urban population growth poses significant challenges for housing, infrastructure, and utilities demand. To address these issues, the city-state is transforming its built environment industry through digitalization and innovation. The Lum Chang Group, a leading construction arm, has implemented a common data environment (CDE) to streamline processes and improve quality. The government's initiatives, such as integrated digital delivery and Design for Manufacturing and Assembly, also aim to enhance the industry's transformation. With coordinated efforts from multiple organizations and government support, Singapore's built environment industry can create sustainable and smart living spaces.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit announced a non-renounceable preferential offering, raising around S$101.8 million to fund an Australian property acquisition, expected to be distribution per unit dilutive. SIA Engineering's share price has fallen 14% in two months due to market chatter on possible privatization, but Q1 earnings were in line with expectations. Analysts maintain their buy recommendations for both stocks, citing franchise strengths and cost control measures.

site_title: Nordic Group to buy environmental engineering firm Envipure for S$14-15.5m
summary: Nordic Group is set to acquire environmental engineering firm Envipure for S$14-15.5 million. The acquisition, made through subsidiary Nordic Flow Control, aims to expand Nordic Group's product and service offerings and tap new markets in the semiconductor and environmental sectors. Envipure provides turnkey engineering solutions in process and environmental engineering services. The deal is subject to approval by Nordic Group's directors and shareholders, and financing will come from internal funds and bank borrowings. No assurance is given that the acquisition will proceed.

site_title: Boeing not able to respond to regulators on Max at August meeting
summary: Boeing failed to address regulators' questions on modifications to the 737 Max flight control system during an August meeting, pushing back the timeline for the jet's return to service. The planes have been grounded since mid-March following two crashes that killed 346 people. Boeing expects to submit its certification package to the FAA in September, with anticipated approval around a month later, but regulators say they are following a "thorough process" and not a prescribed timeline. This has led to a 2.7% drop in Boeing shares.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters appeal to Merkel before China visit
summary: Hong Kong protest leaders appealed to German Chancellor Angela Merkel to support their push for democracy during her upcoming visit to China. Prominent leader Joshua Wong and others wrote an open letter, drawing parallels between Merkel's experience in communist East Germany and their own struggle against the Chinese government. They urged Merkel to express concern over Hong Kong's situation and convey their demands to the Chinese government. Merkel starts a three-day trip to China, a major trade partner, with a large business delegation.

site_title: Huawei to spend US$300m a year in research funding for universities
summary: Huawei plans to invest over $300 million annually in research funding for universities, despite facing a US trade ban. The move aims to foster academic ties and research collaborations. This investment is part of the company's efforts to stay competitive in the global market.

site_title: Oil sinks as manufacturing data feeds global economy worries
summary: Oil prices fell 2-3% on Tuesday, with US crude futures down 2% and Brent crude down 0.7%, amid concerns about a weakening global economy and the ongoing US-China trade dispute. Manufacturing data showed a contraction in US and euro zone activity, and Venezuela's oil exports fell to their lowest level in 2019. The US-China trade dispute continues to drag on investor sentiment, with US President Donald Trump warning of tougher negotiations if talks drag on.

site_title: China softens tone on Hong Kong, but doesn't yield on demands
summary: China has softened its tone on Hong Kong's protests, stating that peaceful demonstrations are allowed under the law. Officials clarified the distinction between violent protesters and those marching peacefully, backing Chief Executive Carrie Lam. The Chinese government ruled out a fundamental demand for direct democracy and reaffirmed its support for the economy. However, officials warned that an emergency law could be implemented if necessary and pledged to maintain control over the narrative, as China dispatches state-run media to Hong Kong.

site_title: Justin Bieber opens up on drug abuse, weight of fame
summary: Justin Bieber has opened up about his struggles with fame, depression, and addiction, reflecting on how his child stardom led to feelings of resentment and anger. The 25-year-old pop star shared his journey of self-discovery, crediting his marriage to Hailey Baldwin and support from friends and faith for helping him turn his life around. Bieber acknowledged his past mistakes, including reckless behavior and substance abuse, and expressed gratitude for the people who love him for who he is, encouraging others to keep fighting despite adversity.

site_title: Bonds show it pays to be boring
summary: Investors are flocking to bonds as the trade war and economic uncertainty spook the stock market, driving bond prices to their best year since 2002. Despite risks, bonds offer more certain returns and less volatility, attracting nearly $260 billion in cash from investors. The Bloomberg Barclays Aggregate index has gained over 9% this year, while the 10-year Treasury note has risen by 13%. However, if the global economy starts to improve, bond prices could fall, making them a less attractive investment.

site_title: Quarterly reporting: risk-based approach cannot be too narrow
summary: Singapore's market regulator, SGX RegCo, plans to unveil a new risk-based approach to quarterly reporting (QR) by the end of the year. The approach aims to remove QR requirements for a segment of the market, focusing on companies deemed to pose a higher investment risk. The move is part of a broader effort to increase market surveillance and accountability. While a risk-based approach is encouraged, its success depends on proper implementation and avoiding a significant roll-back of QR requirements.

site_title: Boost your business
summary: A business owner struggling to survive in the current market can benefit from growth hacking tips. Three key strategies include building a strong brand, which is crucial for recognition and growth. A well-designed logo can add value to a business and establish its identity. This is evident in the case of Nike's iconic "swoosh" logo. By investing in branding, businesses can level the playing field and boost their growth.

site_title: Facebook might start hiding 'Like' counts for posts
summary: Facebook is testing hiding 'Like' counts from public displays, following Instagram's similar move earlier this year. The change aims to reduce pressure on users to produce content that garners likes. Twitter has also experimented with hiding engagement numbers, finding that it leads to less engagement. The move is part of a broader trend to shift focus from likes to content quality.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Tuesday confirmed it is dabbling with no longer making a public display of how many "likes" are racked up by posts.

site_title: Britain seeks to calm no-deal Brexit fears
summary: Britain's pointman on no-deal Brexit preparations, Michael Gove, assured parliament that a leaked government assessment predicting food and medicine shortages was a worst-case scenario whose risks were overblown. Gove conceded that Britain faced "significant challenges" if it left without an agreement with Brussels on October 31, but emphasized that risks can be mitigated with proper preparations. The government has set up "Operation Yellowhammer" to prepare for disruption in 12 areas, including food and water supplies, healthcare, and transport, but businesses and ordinary Britons must also take action.

site_title: Trump hardens tone on China as trade war rattles economy
summary: US President Donald Trump has hardened his stance on China, warning that Chinese negotiators may be holding out for a better deal in hopes he will be voted out in next year's presidential elections. This comes as the trade war between the two countries continues to rattle the US economy, with the US manufacturing sector contracting for the first time in three years. The US benchmark Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1% and yields on 10-year US Treasury notes briefly touched three-year lows. The US and Chinese negotiations are due to resume this month, but officials are having difficulty scheduling a meeting after Washington rebuffed Beijing's demands.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on tariffs, weak data
summary: US stocks tumbled on Tuesday as new tariffs in the US-China trade war took effect, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.1% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.7%. The tariffs, which assess 15% on consumer goods, were seen as a blow to hopes for a delay in the trade talks. A weak manufacturing sector report also weighed on the market, with US manufacturing activity falling into contraction for the first time in three years. The losses followed hawkish commentary from US President Donald Trump against Beijing, fueling investor concerns about a tough trade deal.

site_title: Europe: Weak data, Brexit woes knock stocks off 1-month high
summary: European shares retreated from a 1-month high on Tuesday, weighed down by weak US factory data and Brexit uncertainty.
