The acquisition comes after Kenneth Low Si Ren, executive director of Allied Technologies, took control of the properties from RSP Architects Planners and Engineers' founder Albert Hong in April.

site_title: Singapore's CPF sees 6.6% growth in assets, bucks global downtrend among top pension funds
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) reported a 6.6% growth in assets to US$287 billion in 2018, outpacing the global decline in assets under management (AUM) among top pension funds. The fund maintained its spot at ninth place globally, while Asia-Pacific pension funds accounted for 26.2% of total AUM, with Singapore and Japan's Government Pension Investment leading the region. The growth rate of Asia-Pacific funds remained higher than the global average, with a 5.2% annualized growth rate from 2013-2018.

site_title: Hoe Leong receives statutory demand from UOB for loan payment
summary: Hoe Leong Corporation has received a statutory demand from United Overseas Bank (UOB) for payment of approximately S$5.7 million, related to a loan owed by its wholly-owned subsidiary, Arkstar Voyager. The company, a heavy equipment supplier, is the guarantor for the loan and has assured that the demand will not affect its ability to carry on its business. Hoe Leong is seeking legal advice and is engaging with UOB to remedy the situation, with its board recommending a suspension of trading in its shares pending resolution.

site_title: Tech@SG scheme will require firms to meet venture-capital terms
summary: Singapore's Tech@SG scheme for fast-growth tech companies will require firms to have secured over US$10 million in venture capital funding and received funding from a programme-recognised VC in the past 36 months. This will ensure companies have sufficient resources and readiness to internationalize and compete. The scheme aims to attract foreign "core team members" to Singapore, while also building local talent in the longer term. Eligible firms must be incorporated in Singapore, have a digital or technology offering, or be based on proprietary technologies, research, or hardware.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall on renewed US-China trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Monday due to renewed fears of a US-China trade war escalation, impacting the global economy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 0.41% and the Topix index dropped 0.44%. This move overturned last week's optimism on trade talks, according to Masayuki Kubota, chief strategist at Rakuten Securities.

site_title: China's top airlines brace for smaller profits on slower demand, weak yuan
summary: China's top three airlines, China Southern, Air China, and China Eastern, are bracing for smaller profits due to slower demand and a weakening yuan. Passenger yields have fallen, with China Southern suffering the steepest decline, and cargo demand is expected to stay soft due to the ongoing US-China trade war. Analysts have lowered earnings estimates for the carriers, citing a 2.3% drop in full-year profits and foreign exchange losses due to the yuan's depreciation. The weakening currency and rising oil prices are expected to further pressure profit margins.

site_title: More than one-quarter of people with disabilities are employed
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad announced that over 25% of people with disabilities aged 15-64 are employed. When including those actively seeking employment, the figure rises to approximately one-third of the age group. The majority of those outside the labor force cite poor health or disability as the main reason.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 0.81% to 3,081.26
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.81% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling to 3,081.26, amid US-China tariff kick-in. Losers outnumbered gainers 187 to 107, with DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank also declining. Most Asian markets declined, with Tokyo and Hong Kong stocks also falling, while China stocks rose 1% despite tariff worries.

site_title: PODCAST: How fintech helps you with cheaper and faster money transfers overseas (Money Hacks, Ep 53)
summary: In a recent podcast, "Money Hacks Ep 53: How fintech helps you with cheaper and faster money transfers overseas," fintech was highlighted as a key solution for individuals looking to transfer money abroad. The episode discussed how fintech companies offer more affordable and efficient options for international money transfers, often with lower fees and faster processing times than traditional methods. This shift towards fintech is expected to continue, driven by increasing demand for convenient and cost-effective financial services, particularly in Asia.

site_title: Warships and aircraft ready for first US-Asean maritime drills
summary: US and ten Southeast Asian countries are participating in the first Asean-US Maritime Exercise (AUMX), a five-day joint exercise starting in Thailand and ending in Singapore. Eight warships, four aircraft, and over 1,000 personnel are involved, amid tensions over the South China Sea. The drills aim to build maritime security and come after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged Southeast Asian nations to push back against Chinese "coercion" in the sea. The exercises also include a simulated search and seizure operation.

images.alt_text: The first Asean-US Maritime Exercise (AUMX) between the regional bloc and Washington lasts for five days, starting at the Sattahip Naval Base in Thailand and ending in Singapore.

site_title: IRAS tax collection up 4.4% to S$52.4b in fiscal 2018/2019
summary: IRAS collected S$52.4 billion in tax revenue in fiscal 2018/2019, a 4.4% increase from the previous year. This accounted for 71.1% of government operating revenue and 10.6% of Singapore's GDP. Total income taxes rose 7.9% to S$29.4 billion, driven by corporate income tax (up 7.3%) and individual income tax (up 9.3%). Goods and services tax collection increased 1.6% to S$11.1 billion.

site_title: Cooking eggs in the morning and shucking oysters at night, thanks to an app
summary: New York-based chef Christopher Mortenson has quit his job to become a full-time gig economy worker, using the hospitality staffing app Pared to secure shifts at over 70 kitchens across the city. Mortenson, who previously worked 50 hours a week for low pay, now races around New York to work in restaurants such as ABC Cocina and Osteria Morini. The shift schedule allows him to cook in the morning and shuck oysters at night, giving him more control over his work-life balance. Mortenson's decision reflects the growing trend of the gig economy in the hospitality industry.

site_title: Circus reinvented in Montreal, this time with high-tech vibe
summary: Montreal's Cirque du Soleil founder Guy Laliberte has reimagined the circus with his new venture, Lune Rouge (Red Moon), featuring high-tech shows like "Through the Echoes" that combines acrobatics, multimedia, and special effects. The PY1 venue, with its giant four-sided screen and virtual reality capabilities, is set to open in Montreal and later move to Miami, tapping into the city's rich animation and video game talent. This marks a shift towards merging disciplines and creating new forms of entertainment.

site_title: Evergrande squeezed by US$53b of maturities in tough market
summary: China Evergrande Group, a major property developer, faces significant debt challenges with approximately $53 billion of maturing debt due in the next 10 months and 75% within two years. The company's total borrowings surged to $113.7 billion, with the largest portion being in the offshore dollar market. Analysts predict negative actions on Evergrande's ratings, making deleveraging unlikely in the second half of the financial year, and warn of high refinancing costs.

site_title: Australia: Shares end down as new US-China tariffs trigger caution
summary: Australian shares declined 0.4% to 6,579.40, led by energy stocks amid US-China tariff escalation. The heightened trade tensions hit oil prices, causing energy heavyweights Santos and Woodside Petroleum to slip 1% each. Financial stocks also fell 0.3% as investors became cautious. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% due to gains from Ryman Healthcare and Contact Energy.

images.alt_text: Australian shares, led by energy stocks, edged lower on Monday, with investors unsettled by the latest blows traded by the United States and China in their tariff war.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as tariffs kick in
summary: Asian markets declined Monday as China and the US imposed fresh tariffs on goods worth hundreds of billions of dollars, escalating their trade war. Hong Kong's markets fell due to ongoing unrest, while Shanghai rose slightly despite the trade war's impact. Analysts warn that the trade war may not be resolved in the near term, with some predicting further market declines. Global markets remain uncertain, with oil prices also affected by trade war concerns.

site_title: Thai Aug headline CPI rises 0.52% y-o-y, below forecast
summary: Thai inflation rose 0.52% in August, below forecast and the central bank's target range, marking the lowest level since January. This is the third consecutive month below the 1-4% target. The annual core inflation rate was 0.49%, also below forecast. The Bank of Thailand unexpectedly cut its policy interest rate in July, and will review policy again on September 25. This follows a forecast of 0.8-0.9% inflation for 2019, lower than the Bank of Thailand's estimate of 1.0%.

site_title: DBS to roll out ETFs for retail investors by end of third quarter
summary: DBS plans to launch two exchange-traded fund (ETF) portfolios for retail investors by the end of the third quarter, allowing them to access investment strategies previously limited to private banking customers. The Asia Portfolio, requiring a minimum investment of S$1,000, will offer exposure to Singapore, China, and India through SGX-listed ETFs, marking DBS's first portfolio of SGX-listed ETFs. This move aims to "democratize access to financial expertise" and lower barriers to investing.

site_title: Confusion clouds China's social credit system
summary: China's social credit system, set to be rolled out nationwide by 2020, has sparked concerns over its potential for unprecedented control of citizens' lives. The system aims to assess individual actions and reward desirable behavior, but lacks a unified system, varying criteria, and unclear punishments. Critics warn that the system could exacerbate inequalities, silence dissent, and infringe on privacy, while rights activists fear it could become a lethal tool for mass surveillance. The system has already been used to blacklist millions of people, including a Chinese actress, and has sparked fears of a totalitarian society.

site_title: Nickel likely to hit US$20,000 a tonne on Indonesia ban: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts nickel prices will reach US$20,000 a tonne in three months due to Indonesia's planned two-year ban on nickel ore exports, set to remove 10% of global supply. The ban would create substantial supply uncertainty, driving prices to their highest since May 2014. Nickel prices are expected to recede to US$18,000 in six months and US$16,000 in 12 months as supply and demand respond to higher prices.

site_title: How to set up a Fintech in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia is an attractive market for fintechs, with 15% of fintechs in ASEAN operating in the country. The market's smartphone penetration rate and financial inclusion levels are high, presenting a large potential customer base. An expanding economy, rising disposable incomes, and improved business environment ranking (15th out of 82) are expected to boost fintech growth. However, challenges include a lack of interaction between government agencies and businesses, as well as limited openness among local businesses to collaborate. Fintechs can overcome these challenges by forming partnerships with commercial and non-commercial organizations.

site_title: Koon Holdings auditor flags going concern issue
summary: KOON Holdings' auditor Ernst and Young has issued a disclaimer of conclusion over the company's interim financial results for the six months ended June 30, citing material uncertainty due to a net loss of S$50.0 million and current liabilities exceeding current assets by S$20.6 million. The construction and precast sectors face challenging conditions, casting significant doubt on Koon Holdings' ability to continue as a going concern. The company has started a major restructuring and realignment exercise and is exploring options, including the sale of its divisions, to improve its financial situation.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as fresh trade tariffs take effect
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Monday as investors remained cautious amid fresh US-China trade tariffs, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.06% to 6,600.80. Energy stocks declined due to lower oil prices and hurricane concerns, while gold stocks provided some strength. The uncertainty surrounding the trade situation persisted, with US President Donald Trump set to meet with Chinese officials later this month.

site_title: Goh Yew Lin to head Duke-NUS as chairman; inventor Aaron Thean named engineering faculty dean
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has appointed Goh Yew Lin as chairman of Duke-NUS Medical School's governing board, effective October 1, replacing Kai Nargolwala. Goh, a managing director of GK Goh Holdings, has also been named as the dean of the NUS Faculty of Engineering, succeeding Chua Kee Chaing. Aaron Thean, an advanced microelectronics expert and prolific inventor, will lead the engineering faculty. NUS President Tan Eng Chye praised Goh's leadership, stating that Duke-NUS will play a bigger role in Singapore's education and healthcare sectors.

site_title: SembMarine bags 6 contracts worth S$400m
summary: SembCorp Marine secured six new contracts worth S$400 million, entering the competitive offshore wind sector in Taiwan and partnering with repeat and new customers. The contracts include FPSO and FSRU projects, as well as a cruise ship refit. The company's president noted that despite challenging market conditions, SembCorp Marine will continue to innovate and improve capabilities to sustain competitiveness.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters call student boycott, strike after weekend of violence
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement returned to action after a weekend of violence, with students calling for a boycott and strike in response. Protesters, mostly students, formed human chains outside schools and disrupted rush-hour trains, while others rallied in the city centre. The movement, which began over extradition plans, has widened to include demands for greater freedoms, direct elections, and an independent inquiry into police brutality. China's reaction has been intimidatory, with warnings of the "end" of the protest movement. The city's reputation as a stable business hub has been shaken, with visitor arrivals plummeting and retailers reporting losses.

site_title: World Bank Group's IFC names Nicolas Marquier as new country manager for Singapore
summary: The International Finance Corporation (IFC), a World Bank Group member, has appointed Nicolas Marquier as its new country manager for Singapore. Marquier, with over 15 years of experience, will oversee IFC's business development efforts with Singapore-based companies and coordinate investments in the Asia and Pacific sub-region. The appointment aims to increase investment and access to capital for emerging markets in the region, with estimates suggesting $1.7 trillion to $2.5 trillion in annual investments needed to achieve the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Founders of successful tech companies are mostly middle-aged
summary: Successful tech company founders are mostly middle-aged, with the average age of founders of high-growth startups in the US between 2007 and 2014 being 42, and 45 for the top 0.1% fastest-growing firms. Researchers analyzed data from 2.7 million business founders and found that experience and age play a significant role in entrepreneurial success, with crystallized intelligence and staying power contributing to breakthroughs. The study challenges the myth that tech innovation is fueled by young, risk-taking entrepreneurs, citing examples like Tony Fadell, who founded Nest at 41 and achieved success after decades of experience in the tech industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on renewed fears over US-China trade war
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to renewed fears over the US-China trade war, affecting the global economy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.38% and the Topix index dropped 0.28%. This follows recent US President Trump's threats to extend the trade war. Despite this, US stocks edged to fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, Keppel, Olam, TPV, SembMarine, BreadTalk
summary: IHH Healthcare posted a 12% improvement in its bottom line to RM185 million for its second quarter, driven by higher revenue and the adoption of the MFRS 16 Leases accounting standard. Keppel Corp acquired a commercial property in Beijing for S$35.1 million, while shares in IHH Healthcare closed flat at S$1.85.

site_title: Australia job ads fall in August, annual growth weakens
summary: Australia's job advertisements fell 2.8% in August, down from July, and are 11.4% lower than last year, according to ANZ. This weakens the labor market trend, suggesting the Reserve Bank of Australia may need to cut interest rates again. The latest rate cut was in June, and a third cut is expected in October, with the cash rate at an all-time low of 1%. This data supports the RBA's decision to hold rates steady in its upcoming meeting, despite concerns about the labor market.

site_title: Australia's Telstra raises earnings outlook on delayed NBN rollout pain
summary: Telstra, Australia's largest telco, raised its 2020 core earnings guidance due to delayed pain from the National Broadband Network (NBN) rollout. The company now expects underlying earnings of A$7.4 billion to A$7.9 billion, up from its previous range of A$7.3 billion to A$7.8 billion. Telstra no longer anticipates 2020 as the year of peak NBN headwind, now estimating it will occur in 2021. The company's restructuring costs and capital expenditure remain unchanged.

images.alt_text: Telstra raised its 2020 core earnings guidance on Monday as it anticipates the worst impact of the rollout of a state-owned broadband network to occur later than previously expected.

site_title: Japan Q2 corporate capex rises 1.9% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japanese companies increased spending on plant and equipment by 1.9% in Q2 compared to the same period last year, according to Ministry of Finance data. This growth will be used to calculate revised GDP figures set for September 9. The data contrasts with a preliminary reading that showed the economy expanding 1.8% in Q2, driven by solid household and business spending.

site_title: Comedian Kevin Hart hospitalised after car crash
summary: Comedian Kevin Hart was hospitalized with major back injuries after his vintage 1970 Plymouth Barracuda crashed into a ditch on Mulholland Highway in Los Angeles County. The driver, Jared Black, 28, and third passenger Rebecca Broxterman, 31, were trapped inside but sustained no injuries. Hart, 40, was treated at a nearby hospital. Black denied driving under the influence at the time of the crash.

site_title: Mexico oil hedge gets green light with details to be ironed out
summary: Mexico's Finance Ministry has received approval to hedge the country's oil production for 2020, but details are still being ironed out. The oil hedge, a multibillion-dollar deal, typically covers 200-300 million barrels and has the potential to impact the market. Mexico will begin meeting with the central bank next week to define the plan, which is expected to start soon. The country has previously spent over $1 billion on hedging prices for previous years, and this year's process has been complicated by changes to the pricing formula for its flagship Maya crude.

site_title: Ngee Ann Poly grads to get head start in becoming certified financial planners
summary: Ngee Ann Polytechnic students who enroll in its Diploma in Banking and Finance will receive the Associate Financial Planner (AFPCM) certification starting from April 2020. This certification, offered through a partnership with the Financial Planning Association of Singapore, provides a head start for graduates to attain the Certified Financial Planner (CFP) designation. The certification will enable graduates to pursue careers in finance, including financial planning, wealth management, and risk management, and will help meet the growing demand for qualified financial planners in the industry.

site_title: Argentina imposes exchange controls to calm markets
summary: Argentina's government imposed exchange controls on exporters, requiring permission from the Central Bank before purchasing foreign currency, in an effort to calm financial uncertainty and regulate the currency exchange regime. The measures, which include restrictions on transferring money abroad and a monthly limit of 10,000 dollars for individuals, will remain in place until December 31. The move comes amid economic instability, including recession, high inflation, and rising unemployment.

site_title: Irish manufacturing activity shrinks for third straight month
summary: Irish manufacturing activity contracted for the third consecutive month in August, with the AIB IHS Markit manufacturing PMI falling to 48.6, below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. The slowdown is attributed to global manufacturing weakness and Brexit uncertainty, with demand conditions cited as the main factor. This marks the first three-month contraction since 2013, and experts predict it may take until Brexit uncertainty subsides for the sector to recover.

site_title: Banker exits, zombie accounts: China's Shanghai free trade zone sputters
summary: China's Shanghai free trade zone is struggling, with many businesses deserting the area due to tightened capital controls and restrictive regulations. The zone, launched in 2013, was intended to attract foreign investment and facilitate international trade, but its promised benefits have been rendered useless. Hundreds of specialized accounts lie untouched, and many banks have disbanded their FTZ corporate business teams. The Shanghai government claims the FTZs have reduced opportunities for local government taxes, but experts say the zones are unlikely to improve for lenders due to strict capital controls.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on Monday, Sept 2, for a public holiday. Trading will resume on Sept 3. In contrast, Singapore's stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The US stock market also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.41% to 3,093.92
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.41% to 3,093.92 on Monday, following China and the US imposing additional tariffs on each other's goods. Losers outnumbered gainers 54 to 40 on the Singapore bourse, with stocks like Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings and Mapletree Logistics Trust declining. Other notable stocks, including Singtel and DBS Group Holdings, also fell. This decline follows a 5-day rally and comes amid renewed fears over the US-China trade war escalation, which also affected Tokyo stocks.

site_title: No silver bullet for the silver workforce
summary: Businesses in Singapore are turning to technology and job redesign to cope with an aging workforce and labor crunch. Companies such as Advancer Global, Sheng Siong, and Minor Food Group Singapore are investing in solutions like smart toilet systems and digital skills training to improve productivity and retain older workers. Despite concerns about increased staff costs, productivity gains from technology are expected to offset these expenses, and some companies are exploring shorter work weeks or flexible working hours to accommodate older staff.

site_title: Boxing champ Pacquiao launches his own crypto tokens
summary: Philippine boxing champion Manny Pacquiao launched his own cryptocurrency, "Pac" tokens, at a concert in Manila. The tokens will allow fans to buy merchandise and interact with Pacquiao via social media, and will be listed on Singapore's Global Crypto Offering Exchange. Private investors include Pacquiao, Michael Owen, and Khaled bin Zayed al-Nahyan. The move aims to cash in on Pacquiao's popularity and influence, with the boxer also serving as a Philippine senator.

site_title: Pet spa? Private elevator? The amenities race heats up
summary: Luxury condominium and apartment developers are engaging in an "amenities war" to attract high-end buyers, offering increasingly extravagant perks such as private elevators, cryotherapy, and exclusive restaurants. Despite a slowing market, developers continue to add luxurious features to their properties in an attempt to draw buyers willing to pay millions of dollars. However, experts note that the value of these amenities can be subjective and that classic design and history are often more important factors in determining a property's value.

site_title: China's 'Belt and Road' risks Paris climate goals: analysis
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) risks undermining global efforts to meet the Paris climate goals due to its carbon-heavy development in countries across Asia, Africa, and Europe. A new analysis found that BRI countries could produce enough greenhouse gas emissions to derail the Paris climate goals, with some countries needing to lower emissions by 68% by 2050 to stay on track. China, the world's top carbon polluter, must adopt "policy consistency" on emissions both at home and abroad to mitigate the impact of BRI.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for strike after turbulent weekend
summary: Hong Kong braces for disruption on Monday after a turbulent weekend of protests, with calls for a general strike and university students planning a two-week boycott of classes. The protests, which started over extradition bill concerns, have widened to include demands for the chief executive's resignation and an independent inquiry into police brutality. The city faces its third month of unrest, with clashes between protesters and police resulting in at least a dozen flights cancelled and the city recovering from weekend violence. A strike is expected to disrupt businesses and daily life.

site_title: Musk's China charm offensive yields Tesla tax break, publicity
summary: Elon Musk's charm offensive in China has paid off with a tax exemption for Tesla, a promotional opportunity for his Boring Co project, and praise on social media for his frugal lifestyle. During his trip, Musk toured a Tesla factory, met China's Transport Minister, and publicly sparred with Alibaba Group Chairman Jack Ma. The move comes amid heightened uncertainty over the US-China trade war, with China announcing a 10% purchase tax exemption for Tesla cars, allowing the company to start manufacturing in the country later this year.

site_title: Police in Indonesia's Papua ban 'anarchist' demos after mass protests
summary: Police in Indonesia's Papua region banned "anarchist" demos after nearly two weeks of mass protests, following dozens of arrests and clashes with security forces. The order prohibits demonstrations, carrying sharp weapons, and spreading "fake news." The impoverished region has been plagued by low-level insurgency and unrest, triggered by racism and calls for independence. Indonesia deployed 2,500 additional police and troops to Papua, amid reports of at least one soldier and two demonstrators killed in a clash in the remote Deiyai region.

site_title: Australian home prices rise at fastest pace since 2017 in August
summary: Australian house prices increased by the fastest pace since 2017 in August, driven by record low interest rates and looser lending rules in Sydney and Melbourne. This marks the end of two years of decline, which had eroded household wealth and confidence. The economy is expected to expand by 1.4% in the year to June, the slowest annual pace in a decade, according to a Reuters poll. The rebound in housing prices is a positive sign for the economy, but experts caution that the market may be due for a correction.

site_title: Keppel unit buys 2nd Haidian property in China's 'Silicon Valley' for 178.6m yuan
summary: Keppel Land China has acquired Shangdi Neo, a five-storey commercial property in Beijing's Haidian district, for approximately 178.6 million yuan (S$35.1 million). The property, located in China's 'Silicon Valley,' offers 4,241 square meters of net leasable area and will be fully occupied by sole tenant Distrii. The acquisition is part of Keppel Land China's strategy to grow its commercial portfolio in high-growth cities like Beijing, with the company confident of meeting demand for quality office space in the area.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.38% to 25,627.83, amid violent demonstrations over the weekend and a call for a general strike by protesters. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.44% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.57%. The declines follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Mexico's president says he is delivering change as promised
summary: Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador delivered his first state of the nation address, insisting he's delivering on his promised transformation despite economic stagnation and rising violence. He acknowledged some issues, but largely rehashed his campaign rhetoric, criticizing past leaders for dishonesty. Despite struggling to deliver on key promises, Lopez Obrador remains popular, with an approval rating of around 65%. His administration has achieved some notable wins, including reducing theft from state oil company pipelines and negotiating a deal to avoid US tariffs.

site_title: Oil falls amid new round of tariffs in US-China trade war
summary: Oil prices fell Monday after the US and China imposed new tariffs, raising concerns about a hit to global growth and demand for crude. Brent crude dropped 42 cents, or 0.7%, to $58.83 a barrel, while US oil fell 27 cents, or 0.5%, to $54.83 a barrel. The new tariffs are the latest escalation in the US-China trade war, which has already impacted global energy markets. The decline in oil prices is seen as a bearish sign for the energy sector, with some investors expecting further downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Geo-political, weather volatility on the gloomy horizon
summary: US stocks experienced a significant gain last week, rising 3% and trimming the decline in August to less than 2%. Analysts warn that geopolitical and weather-related volatility remains, with Hurricane Dorian potentially impacting the East Coast and ongoing trade tensions between the US and China. A jobs data release on Friday could also bring market instability. Despite this, investors are cautiously optimistic, with some stocks, such as mining and healthcare, showing resilience.

site_title: Solomon Islands eyes shift in diplomatic ties to China from Taiwan
summary: The Solomon Islands, one of Taiwan's remaining diplomatic allies, is considering shifting its diplomatic ties to China. A task force has been formed to evaluate the Taiwan ties, and a ministerial group is set to meet with Beijing. The government has spent significant amounts on this issue, and a possible switch could be announced as early as this week. The move would give China 16 diplomatic allies, and the decision threatens to divide the small Pacific island nation.

site_title: UK's Labour to do 'everything necessary' to stop no-deal Brexit
summary: Britain's main opposition Labour Party will take all necessary steps to prevent a no-deal Brexit, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn announced. Following parliament's return on Tuesday, Labour plans to legislate to force Prime Minister Boris Johnson to rule out a no-deal exit. Johnson has suspended parliament and refused to guarantee that any legislation passed would be heeded. Labour is working with other parties to stop the Brexit disaster, while Corbyn accused Johnson's move to shut down parliament as an "attack on democracy."

site_title: Packed data calendar but trade issues remain the focus
summary: The US and China have raised tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese imports to the US from 10% to 15%, amid ongoing trade tensions. This has led to market uncertainty, with investors focusing on trade developments and potential escalation. Despite this, some analysts predict a calmer month for equity markets in September, citing factors such as a seasonally benign month, easing protests in Hong Kong, and potential US rate cuts. Key data releases, including August PMI figures and inflation data, will also be closely watched.

site_title: New ECB policymaker Holzmann says sceptical of more easing
summary: Austrian National Bank (OeNB) Governor Robert Holzmann has expressed skepticism about adding further stimulus to the euro zone economy, stating he's wary of lowering interest rates and expanding the money supply. In his first day on the job, Holzmann said any changes to interest rates should be in the opposite direction. His hawkish stance aligns with previous comments, indicating a cautious approach to monetary policy.

site_title: China, US kick off new round of tariffs in trade war
summary: China and the US began imposing additional tariffs on each other's goods, escalating a bruising trade war. The US imposed 15% tariffs on over $125 billion in Chinese imports, while China retaliated with 5% tariffs on US goods, including crude oil and smart speakers. US President Donald Trump said talks with China would continue in September, but urged American companies to find alternate suppliers outside China. The trade war further strains Beijing-Washington ties, with China calling the US actions "protectionist" and "unreasonable."

site_title: Lawmakers against no-deal Brexit to try to pass legislation this week
summary: British lawmakers opposed to a no-deal Brexit plan to pass legislation this week to prevent Prime Minister Boris Johnson from exiting the European Union without a deal on October 31. The opposition Labour Party's Keir Starmer stated the plan aims to stop Johnson from crashing out of the EU without a deal, potentially requiring an extension. However, Senior Minister Michael Gove refused to guarantee the government would abide by the legislation, saying it needed to see the plan.

site_title: Italy's PM Conte confident on finalising talks over new government by Wednesday
summary: Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte expressed confidence in finalizing talks on a new government by Wednesday, amid intense discussions between the 5-Star Movement and the Democratic Party. The parties are working on a common agenda and Cabinet posts following Matteo Salvini's decision to pull out of their alliance. If an agreement is not reached, Italian President Sergio Mattarella is expected to dissolve parliament and set a date for new elections. Conte is optimistic about a positive outcome, citing a good "political mood" between the two parties.

site_title: S$31m in buyback consideration, led by DBS, Yangzijiang and ST Engineering
summary: Straits Times Index declined 1.5% from Aug 23-29, bringing its 2019 total return to 4.0%. Notably, the decline was led by share buybacks, with DBS, Yangzijiang, and ST Engineering accounting for the majority of the consideration, valued at S$31m.

site_title: BreadTalk to buy food-court operator Food Junction for S$80m
summary: BreadTalk Group is acquiring Food Junction Management (FJM) for S$80 million, with the deal expected to expand BreadTalk's revenue streams and allow for cost savings through the sharing of resources. FJM operates 15 food courts in Singapore and Malaysia, while BreadTalk runs 16 food courts across 16 markets. The acquisition is conditional on shareholder approval and may impact BreadTalk's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

images.alt_text: F&B player BreadTalk Group is looking to buy the entire stake in Food Junction Management, which operates food courts and F&B outlets in Singapore and Malaysia, for S$80 million.

site_title: Hong Kong demonstrators swarm airport on Sunday, disrupting transport
summary: Hong Kong protesters caused significant disruptions at the city's international airport on Sunday, with demonstrators blocking buses and vandalizing turnstiles. The rail operator canceled express trains to the airport, and police arrested 63 people in running battles across the city, with tear gas and warning shots fired. The violence followed a night of clashes and comes amid a 13th straight weekend of historic political unrest in the city, with protesters demanding greater democracy and universal suffrage. The government has refused to rule out using emergency powers, while demonstrators vow to continue protests until their demands are met.

site_title: Any upward move may not last
summary: The USDJPY has been stuck in a sideways range since 2017, with recent price movements between 104.50 and 114.50. Despite a slight recovery, the currency is expected to test and reject resistance levels, ultimately heading down. The pessimistic market sentiment, fueled by US-China trade tensions and a dysfunctional political climate, contributes to a risk-off atmosphere. The USDJPY's price may not last its upward move, potentially testing lower levels around 101.20.

site_title: S Korea exports fall for 9th straight month
summary: South Korea's exports fell for the ninth consecutive month in August due to sluggish demand from China and depressed global computer chip prices. The data raises concerns about the export-dependent economy, which is also threatened by a brewing trade dispute with Japan and ongoing US-China tensions. The bleak outlook clouds the future of Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: Straits Trading Company strives to unlock value, boost returns
summary: Straits Trading Company, one of Singapore's oldest firms, aims to boost returns and unlock value amid geopolitical tensions and a global recession threat. Executive Chairman Chew Gek Khim, a practical and down-to-earth leader, credits her late grandfather, Tan Chin Tuan, with teaching her valuable life lessons. Chew believes Straits Trading is fairly well-cushioned due to its diversified portfolio in real estate, hospitality, and resources, with a focus on stable and sustainable investments. The company has grown its net profit by 54.5% in FY2018 and has a current market capitalization of about S$860 million. Despite challenges, Chew remains optimistic, citing the company's active board of directors and its ability to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Opportunities in Vietnam abound
summary: Vietnam's startup scene is rapidly growing, with investments tripling to US$889 million in 2018 and a young, tech-savvy population driving entrepreneurial spirit. The government supports startups, aiming to increase enterprises to one million by 2020. E-commerce and fintech sectors offer opportunities, with the market still relatively untapped and a growing demand for digital solutions. However, Singapore startups face challenges such as language barriers and unfamiliarity with the local market. To overcome these, they can tap into resources like Enterprise Singapore's Global Innovation Alliance and networking events.

site_title: Blue Charity Gala dinner raises S$500k for BT BAF, SPD
summary: More than 600 individuals and corporates gathered for The Blue Charity Gala dinner, raising over S$500,000 for disability charity SPD and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The event, themed "Stand by Me," featured performances by the Singapore Police Force Band, Adelyn Koh, and Robert Fernando, and was supported by Diamond Donor Certis. The collaboration between SPD and BT BAF aims to transform lives of persons with disabilities and provide opportunities in the arts for young people.

site_title: Europe's business confidence in Asean still high
summary: European business confidence in ASEAN remains high, with 88% of respondents expecting to increase trade and investment in the region over the next five years. This represents a 13% increase from 2018. However, concerns over non-tariff barriers in South-east Asia are growing, with 7% of respondents expecting no change in their trade and investment levels. The survey also notes that EU-ASEAN business engagement is expected to continue to grow despite global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Google to pay out US$150-200m over YouTube privacy claims
summary: Google is set to pay $150-200 million to settle allegations its YouTube platform violated children's privacy laws by collecting data on users under 13 without parental consent. The US Federal Trade Commission has agreed to the settlement, which could be the largest in a children's privacy case if approved by the Justice Department. The allegations were made by privacy groups, and the FTC is expected to announce its decision in September. Advocacy groups have criticized the proposed settlement as "woefully low" and called for further action to protect children's privacy.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the week's tanker and dry bulk market, with key highlights including a firming market for capesize vessels, with the 5TC index closing at $34,583, up $4,146 for the week. The Pacific basin remained stable, while the Atlantic basin saw a significant premium over the Pacific basin. Panamax rates remained firm, with a Kamasarmax agreed at $20,000, plus $1 million ballast bonus, for end September dates back to the East. Ultramaxes fetched high $13,000s - $14,000 for three to five months trading from North Asia.

site_title: Going green, saving Gaia
summary: Singapore businesses can reduce their carbon footprint and help mitigate climate change by implementing three key strategies: increasing energy efficiency, adopting renewable energy sources, and implementing sustainable supply chain practices. Experts emphasize the importance of businesses taking proactive steps to address climate change, as individuals and governments can only do so much. By making environmentally conscious decisions, businesses can contribute to a more sustainable future for Singapore and the world.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters target airport but planes still running
summary: Thousands of Hong Kong protesters blocked roads and public transport links to the city's airport on Sunday, drawing global attention to their fight for greater democracy. Trains were suspended, approach roads impassable, and protesters erected barricades, overturned trolleys, and smashed CCTV cameras. Despite the disruptions, planes continued to take off and land, and police made several arrests. The protest, part of a 13-week-old movement, poses a challenge to Chinese President Xi Jinping's government, which seeks to end the unrest before the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China on October 1.

images.alt_text: Protesters blocking a road leading to the Hong Kong International Airport on Sunday. Police said protesters hurled iron poles, bricks and rocks on to the railway track near the airport station and trespassed on the track.

site_title: Trump heaps more tariffs on China, still no deal in sight
summary: The US has imposed 15% tariffs on approximately $110 billion in Chinese imports, escalating the trade war. China retaliated with its own tariffs, targeting US goods such as pork, beef, and chicken. The move is expected to harm the global economy and reduce US GDP by 0.3% and average household income by $580 by 2020. The tariffs are also expected to increase the average cost per US household by $1,000 per year. Talks between Chinese and American trade negotiators are still scheduled for September, but a truce remains elusive.

site_title: Dubai halts work on mega-airport project as Gulf economies stumble
summary: Dubai's mega-airport project, designed to handle over 250 million passengers annually, has been put on hold due to economic uncertainty in the Gulf region. Construction activity has ceased, and expansion finances have been frozen until further notice. This decision follows the faltering of Gulf Arab economies, with the project's halt seen as a response to the region's economic struggles. The halt is a significant setback for Dubai's aviation ambitions, and its impact on the global aviation industry remains to be seen.

site_title: US sends in the military to combat fake news and disinformation
summary: The US Defense Department's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa) is launching a project to combat fake news and disinformation, dubbed "AutoAuth". The agency aims to develop custom software that can identify and filter out fake stories, photos, and clips from over 500,000 online content pieces. This project comes amid growing concerns over the threat of large-scale, automated disinformation attacks on US security, despite efforts by top Republicans to protect election integrity.

site_title: Canadian dollar extends August's decline as boost fades from GDP gain
summary: The Canadian dollar weakened against the US dollar on Friday, despite initial gains following stronger-than-expected GDP growth in the second quarter. The Canadian economy expanded 3.7% annually, driven by goods exports, but business investment declined and consumer spending slowed. Oil prices fell due to a hurricane near the Florida coast. The Canadian dollar traded 0.3% lower at 1.3325 to the greenback, and bond prices fell across a steeper yield curve, with the 10-year yield falling 15 Canadian cents to yield 1.164%.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: No relevant information about taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds is provided in the article.

site_title: Mass pig deaths in China cause falling supplies of US blood thinner
summary: A Chinese outbreak of African swine fever has led to a shortage of US blood thinner heparin, derived from pig intestines, due to reduced supplies of raw ingredient. Major heparin producer Fresenius Kabi has started limiting allocations, but the US FDA says overall supply is sufficient. The global drug supply chain relies on raw ingredients made worldwide, and China's swine fever has caused a ripple effect, with some heparin products in shortage since November 2017. The FDA has approved additional manufacturing space at Fresenius Kabi's US plant to mitigate the shortage.

site_title: Maybank aims to diversify income streams
summary: Maybank Singapore aims to diversify its income streams by doubling non-lending income from its retail small and medium-sized enterprise (RSME) segment in three years. The RSME segment has seen over 100% new business growth in areas like treasury services and trade finance. The bank plans to increase non-interest-based income to 20% and reduce interest-based income to 80% in the near future. This move is part of the bank's effort to diversify its income streams and adapt to the global economic headwinds.

site_title: Investors who chased Asia's highest-yielding bonds end up last
summary: Asia's highest-yielding bond markets delivered the worst returns in August, with Indonesian and Indian debt ranking at the bottom. Despite real yields of at least 3%, these debt markets returned virtually nothing, with investors shunning less creditworthy nations due to slowing global growth and rising trade tensions. Thailand's debt, with real yields of 0.6%, delivered the standout result, while global funds offloaded a net $281 million of Indonesia's debt and $2.19 billion of India's. The attractiveness of these markets will be tested with upcoming inflation data releases.

site_title: Metal Component Engineering terminates agreement to acquire stake in Asiafame Group
summary: Metal Component Engineering has terminated its sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 51% stake in Asiafame Group due to unfulfilled conditions. The deal, valued at around S$8.4 million, was set to be completed by August 31. The company will continue to explore potential acquisitions and strategic alliances to generate sustainable revenue streams. Metal Component does not expect to incur costs related to the termination, and will maintain its focus on improving financial performance and diversification.

site_title: RWS staff help to spruce up rental flats in Queenstown
summary: Over 210 RWS staff participated in the annual aRWSome Volunteer Day, cleaning and refurbishing 70 elderly and needy residents' homes in Queenstown. The initiative, now in its third year, aims to improve living conditions. Staff decluttered, cleaned, and spruced up the homes, while a workshop taught residents how to repurpose waste items. RWS collaborated with industry partners to sort recyclables and provide environmentally-friendly cleaning solutions. The event was attended by RWS CEO Tan Hee Teck, Central Singapore District mayor Denise Phua, and others, highlighting the positive impact of the program on the community.

site_title: Lawyers for Huawei CFO detail record requests to prove her rights were violated
summary: Lawyers for Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou have filed a court document detailing record requests to prove her rights were violated before her December 2018 arrest in Vancouver. They seek emails, notes, and other records from Canadian authorities, claiming there's an "air of reality" that other documents have not been disclosed. If these records prove Canadian officials abused their authority, extradition proceedings should be halted. The extradition proceeding is set to begin in January, with potential years of legal wrangling ahead.

site_title: SingHaiyi sells 324 units of Parc Clematis on launch day
summary: SingHaiyi Group's Parc Clematis sold 324 out of 465 units on its launch day, with an average selling price of S$1,580 per square foot. The majority of sold units were one-bedroom and dual-key bedroom units, accounting for 48% of total sales. The development, which features 1,468 units ranging from 452 sq ft to 2,669 sq ft, was launched on August 31.

site_title: Wanted: Warm bodies; age no object
summary: Singapore's economy is facing a labor crunch, with a growing need for older workers due to the country's aging population. Employers expect staff costs to rise with the higher retirement age and changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution. Despite concerns over healthcare costs and technological skills, recruiters believe that hiring older workers is a strategic move to address the talent shortage and economic uncertainties. The government has promised a support package for employers, including a Special Employment Credit scheme, to help alleviate the tight manpower situation.

site_title: So you want to privatise a listco
summary: BT is considering privatizing a listed company, but the article does not specify which one. It also mentions several other business news, including a public offer by NTT DC Reit's Singapore unit, a decline on Wall Street, and the potential for Creative Technology to miss revenue targets. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank has announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing his predecessor from DBS.

site_title: America's wealth hinges on its ability to borrow big: Bloomberg
summary: The US economy's reliance on debt is crucial to its ranking as one of the world's strongest economies. If the US were to suddenly lose its ability to borrow, its GDP per capita would plummet to a negative $4,857, a loss of $72,000 per person. This scenario would also affect other economies, with Japan ranking last, and the UK's per capita wealth dropping 10 spots. The US debt market and its status as the world's reserve currency ensure it will continue to borrow, avoiding a debt-free economy.

site_title: Luxus Hills, Parc Clematis see brisk sales
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates sold 71 of 78 Luxus Hills (Signature Collection) homes in Singapore at prices ranging from S$3.058 million to S$4.2 million during a preview weekend. 95% of buyers purchased homes for their own occupation, with 75% opting for flexible deferred payment schemes. In contrast, Parc Clematis, a nearby development, sold 324 of its 465 units at an average selling price of S$1,580 per square foot.

site_title: Uber-like app for trucks reshaping Nigeria's haulage market
summary: A Nigerian logistics startup, Kobo360, is revolutionizing the country's haulage market with its Uber-like app for trucks. The platform connects cargo owners with drivers and customers, allowing for efficient scheduling and monitoring of trips. Kobo360 aims to reduce traffic congestion and increase on-time deliveries, while also providing transparency and affordability. With over $2.1 billion in goods transported since 2017, the company plans to expand into 10 more countries and add 25,000 drivers to its platform, aiming to make haulage 27% cheaper and 92% on-time.

site_title: CapitaLand shows good ESG policies do pay off
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-listed property group, has demonstrated the benefits of good environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices. The company has secured 14 wins at the Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) 20th Investors' Choice Awards, including the Golden Circle Award for corporate governance. Its share price has surged 15% year-to-date, outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index. CapitaLand's strong fundamentals, including a diversified portfolio and robust asset management, have contributed to its success. The company's ESG practices have helped reduce volatility and increase investor confidence, providing a competitive advantage in the market.

site_title: More than 2,700 flats in Punggol to be launched in September
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will launch two new Build-to-Order projects in Punggol, Singapore, in September. The projects, Punggol Point Crown and the second phase of Punggol Point Cove, will feature designs inspired by the town's history, including the old Ponggol Zoo and its fishing village roots. The projects will comprise 2,724 flats and are expected to be completed in 2024, with residents having access to recreational facilities and the Punggol Coast MRT station.

site_title: Osaka displays sportswomanship after ousting Coco Gauff
summary: Naomi Osaka showcased sportswomanship after defeating Coco Gauff in a 6-3, 6-0 win at the US Open. The young sensation, 15-year-old Coco Gauff, was gracious in defeat and participated in a joint on-court interview with Osaka, allowing Gauff to address her fans, known as "Cocomania." The display of respect and kindness from Osaka was notable, and the win solidified Osaka's position as the world No. 1.

site_title: Aramco fully restores oil output as it recovers from attacks
summary: Saudi Aramco has fully restored its oil output to over 9.9 million barrels a day after the September 14 attacks on its energy infrastructure. The attacks, which knocked out 5% of global crude supply, had initially surged oil prices but Aramco has since recovered, with CEO Ibrahim Al-Buainain stating the company is producing a little bit higher than the target level. Aramco has committed to meeting demand and didn't miss any contracted shipments, with the company also building redundancy into its systems to prevent similar disruptions in the future.

site_title: 91% of Luxus Hills (Signature Collection) sold during preview weekend
summary: Developer Bukit Sembawang Estates sold 71 of 78 Luxus Hills (Signature Collection) homes during the preview weekend, with 95% of buyers opting for flexible payment schemes. The majority of buyers, 75%, were between 30-60 years old, indicating interest from multi-generational families. Prices ranged from S$3.058 million to S$4.2 million.

site_title: China celebrates 70 years as Hong Kong unrest looms large
summary: China is celebrating its 70th anniversary of Communist Party rule with a military parade, showcasing its rising superpower status, while facing internal challenges, including unrest in Hong Kong. Pro-democracy protesters plan to rally against Beijing's erosion of freedoms, despite President Xi Jinping's vow to continue implementing the "one country, two systems" policy. New military equipment, including a hypersonic drone, will be displayed, highlighting Beijing's determination to protect its interests. The parade aims to bolster Xi's legitimacy and rally support amidst economic and trade tensions.

site_title: Aug bank lending bounces back on business loans
summary: Singapore's business loans grew 1.1% month-on-month to S$422.7 billion in August, offsetting a decline in consumer lending. Housing loans, which account for three-quarters of consumer lending, fell 0.2% for the eighth consecutive month. Total bank lending rose 0.6% year-on-year, driven by robust business loans. Analysts expect the manufacturing sector to continue driving loan growth, despite US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Investing for good
summary: A collaboration between UOB Venture Management and Credit Suisse is launching a second impact fund in Singapore, aiming to raise between US$100 and US$150 million. The fund follows the success of their first impact fund, the Asia Impact Investment Fund (I), which raised US$55 million in 2015. Seah Kian Wee, UOBVM chief executive, believes impact investments are a growing asset class, driven by millennials seeking investments with a social and environmental purpose.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed flat on Monday, ending at 1,583.91, down 0.23 points. The index saw 1.9 billion lots traded worth RM1.5 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 556 to 298.

site_title: Shipping's great fuel switch pushing up freight costs
summary: Shipping costs surged to nearly nine-year highs as vessel owners prepare for new fuel rules, taking thousands of ships out of the market to install scrubbers to burn cheaper fuel. The Baltic Dry Index reached 2,378 points, with Capesize ships earning nearly $35,000 a day, the most in at least 5.5 years. The industry expects volatility, as demand growth has returned to a smaller fleet, boosting earnings, but may not last due to declining iron ore imports into China.

images.alt_text: Apart from the fuel switch, freight rates are being buoyed by relatively slow fleet growth and demand that's held up despite a trade war between the US and China.

site_title: Digital currency exchange Zipmex raises US$3m in pre-Series A round
summary: Singapore-based digital currency exchange provider Zipmex raised US$3 million in a pre-Series A round led by Infinity Blockchain Holdings, increasing its valuation to US$18 million. The funding will support Asia-Pacific expansion plans, including a Thailand-centric exchange. Zipmex will collaborate with Infinity Blockchain Holdings on community awareness and blockchain solutions, exploring synergies and potential future capital-related activities. The funding round also involved angel investors, with Infinity Blockchain Holdings contributing US$500,000.

site_title: Sweden to introduce bank tax to fund greater defence spending
summary: Sweden's finance minister, Magdalena Andersson, announced plans to introduce a bank tax to fund increased defense spending. The tax, set to begin in 2022, will generate an additional 5 billion Swedish crowns (S$706 million) annually to boost defense spending by 5 billion crowns from 2022 to 2025. The Social Democrats and Greens agreed on the plan, citing concerns over increasing tensions with Russia in the Baltic region. The tax will be levied on all banks operating in Sweden, regardless of their headquarters location.

images.alt_text: A jeep is straddled by bombs in a simulated air attack during the annual show at Kallinge airforce base, Sweden, on Aug 25. Sweden has been strengthening its armed forces and is concerned about increasing tensions with Russia in the Baltic region.

site_title: Champion Asean as an integrated market of 600m: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing called on businesses to champion Asean as an integrated market of 600 million, emphasizing its attractiveness to the rest of the world. He stated that when individual nations come together, the region's market size becomes more appealing. This comes as the world faces two possible growth scenarios: higher integration and global growth, or fragmentation leading to slower growth. Chan's comments were made at the Digitise Asean 2019 conference.

site_title: OUE to make S$10m loan to PT Maxx Coffee Prima
summary: OUE's wholly-owned subsidiary, OUE Treasury, has entered into a S$10 million six-month loan agreement with PT Maxx Coffee Prima, with Dr. Stephen Riady, OUE's executive chairman, recused from decision-making due to his deemed interest in PT Maxx. The audit committee deemed the loan terms normal and non-prejudicial to OUE's interests and minority shareholders.

site_title: LatAm delivery app Rappi plans to double footprint by year-end
summary: Rappi, a Latin American delivery app, plans to nearly double its cities operated in by the end of the year, reaching 100 cities, following a $1 billion investment from SoftBank. The company, co-founded in 2015, now operates in 55 cities across eight countries. Rappi aims to expand into new sectors, including healthcare and hospitality, and is in talks with other SoftBank-backed firms to share ideas and best practices. The investment also signals growing foreign interest in the region, which lacks bank accounts, and Rappi plans to add banking services to address this issue.

images.alt_text: Rappi co-founder and president Sebastian Mejia (above): "We're close to 55 cities now, eight countries". SoftBank is a majority owner in the five-year-old startup that specialises in on-demand deliveries for restaurants and supermarkets. "We are not just a logistics company. We have a broad range of vision that includes fintech and banking," said Mr Mejia.

Rappi co-founder and president Sebastian Mejia: "We're close to 55 cities now, eight countries". SoftBank is a majority owner in the five-year-old startup that specialises in on-demand deliveries for restaurants and supermarkets. "We are not just a logistics company. We have a broad range of vision that includes fintech and banking," said Mr Mejia.

site_title: Asean growth story holds potential for some SGX stocks
summary: Analysts predict strong growth for Asean economies, driven by manufacturing diversification, trade diversion, and favorable demographics. Asean is expected to become the fourth-largest single economy by 2030. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks are rising, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty, and some Asean-listed companies showing potential, such as PSC and Singtel. Investors remain optimistic about sectors driven by domestic demand and consumption, despite the US-China trade war.

site_title: Indian office towers rise above economic slump
summary: India's first commercial real estate investment trust, backed by Blackstone, has defied economic slowdown with a successful market debut. The US$4 billion trust owns 33 million square feet of high-quality office parks, offering a 6% dividend yield and potential returns of up to 18.5%. The venture has attracted multinational tenants and large investors, including Brookfield Asset Management, and is seen as a welcome opportunity for Indians to invest in property.

site_title: Japan to hike consumption tax on Oct 1 despite recession fears
summary: Japan is set to increase its consumption tax from 8% to 10% on October 1, despite recession fears. The move, which has been delayed twice, aims to fund key policy priorities, including improving the social security system and offering free pre-school education. Economists warn that the tax hike could hit Japan's fragile economy, particularly as wages have not been increasing for 20 years, reducing purchasing power. However, some experts believe consumers have already factored in the increase, and spending may not be significantly altered post the hike.

site_title: In a galaxy not so far away, Singapore startups test new frontiers
summary: Singapore startups are exploring space technology, including satellite systems for secure communications and high-speed internet connectivity, and rocket development. Google Cloud's president Robert Enslin discusses the company's growth in cloud technology. Meanwhile, Standard Chartered Bank Singapore CEO Patrick Lee talks about the annual Singapore Marathon's bid to become a World Marathon Major.

site_title: Thomas Cook France declares insolvency
summary: Thomas Cook France, a subsidiary of the bankrupt British tour operator, has declared insolvency and applied for a judicial recovery procedure to find a buyer. The French arm employs 780 people and has annual revenues of €425 million. The company aims to ensure the continuity of operations and move quickly to a recovery solution, reducing the number of stranded clients from 10,000 to 8,400. The German and Austrian units have also taken similar steps following the collapse of the British parent, leaving around 600,000 holidaymakers stranded worldwide.

site_title: Lagarde inherits ECB tinged by bitterness over Draghi's QE
summary: Christine Lagarde will take charge of the European Central Bank, inheriting policy disputes from Mario Draghi's QE plan. The move led to Sabine Lautenschlaeger's unexpected resignation from the Executive Board. Lagarde will have to address the aftermath of this unprecedented revolt, which has left deep scars among officials. Her tenure is likely to be marked by challenges in resolving these disputes and navigating the complex economic landscape.

site_title: How Heidi conquered Japan, sparking an anime revolution
summary: Heidi, a 19th-century storybook character, played a pivotal role in Japan's booming anime industry, particularly with the 1970s animation series "Alps no Shojo Heidi" (Heidi: A Girl of the Alps). The show's creators, including Yoichi Kotabe and Isao Takahata, were influenced by Heidi's character design, which has since become iconic. The series' success led to the establishment of Studio Ghibli, a renowned anime studio, and has had a lasting impact on Japanese culture, inspiring numerous adaptations and tourist attractions, including a dedicated Heidi museum in Switzerland.

site_title: Beijing opens glitzy airport ahead of China's 70th anniversary
summary: Beijing's Daxing International Airport, a futuristic starfish-shaped airport, was opened by President Xi Jinping ahead of China's 70th anniversary. The airport, located 46km south of Tiananmen Square, will operate at full capacity in 2040 with eight runways and the potential to receive 100 million passengers per year. Airlines such as British Airways, Cathay Pacific, and Finnair have announced new routes to the airport, while Air China will continue to fly from Beijing Capital International Airport. The project cost 120 billion yuan and features a 700,000 square meter terminal, a train station, and metro line.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine services firm, has applied to extend a debt moratorium and convene meetings with creditors regarding schemes of arrangement. Raffles United has announced changes in leadership, with its CFO stepping down for CEO role. Wilton Resources Corp is set to undertake a mandatory tender offer to purchase shares of PT Renuka Coalindo Tbk. SLB Development has agreed to divest a property for S$13.5 million to discharge a bank loan and acquire potential development property.

site_title: End to MAX grounding up to individual countries: US FAA
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has stated that it has no set timeframe to lift the grounding of the Boeing 737 MAX, allowing individual countries to decide when the plane can fly again based on a thorough safety assessment. The FAA's decision follows a meeting of international regulators in Canada, where consensus on when to clear the MAX for service remains elusive. Boeing expects regulatory approval early in the fourth quarter for the plane to resume service, but individual countries will make their own decisions on the matter.

site_title: At least one dead after strong quake rocks eastern Indonesia
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia's Maluku islands, killing at least one person and leaving another missing. The quake destroyed homes, triggered landslides, and caused widespread destruction. At least two dozen aftershocks were reported, with some measuring 5.6 magnitude. The area is prone to seismic activity due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

site_title: Japan to invest US$10b in global LNG infrastructure projects
summary: Japan plans to invest $10 billion in global liquefied natural gas (LNG) infrastructure projects to boost the global LNG market and reduce its reliance on energy from the Middle East. This move, doubled from a previous commitment, aims to reinforce global energy security. As part of the effort, Japan will train 500 experts in LNG technology and has already trained over 400 since 2017. The investment will focus on developing the global LNG market and promoting energy security.

images.alt_text: "By making these commitments to help develop the global LNG market, Japan will work hard to reinforce global energy security," Mr Sugawara says.

site_title: London repatriates 10 per cent of Thomas Cook's UK customers
summary: The UK has repatriated 14,700 stranded Thomas Cook customers, 10% of the total 150,000 affected, in a major operation managed by the Civil Aviation Authority. The repatriation is part of a larger effort to bring back all stranded customers, with 16,500 expected to be returned on Tuesday. The collapse of Thomas Cook has left 600,000 customers stranded worldwide, with criticism mounting over management pay, including £47 million in pay and bonuses for the company's last five chief executives. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has questioned the fairness of such payments.

site_title: Euro zone business growth ground to a halt in Sept
summary: Euro zone business growth has stalled in September, according to a survey, as the Euro zone Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.4, its lowest reading since mid-2013. This follows outgoing ECB President Mario Draghi's pledge of indefinite stimulus to revive the bloc's ailing economy. The stalling growth is a concern, with the services PMI and manufacturing index also showing declines, but overall optimism has slightly improved. The European Central Bank has already taken measures to support the economy with lower borrowing costs.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.04% to 3,158.45
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.04% to 3,158.45 on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 1.23 points. Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) gained 0.9%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding remained flat. Financials were in the red, with DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank down 0.1%, 0.4%, and 0.2% respectively. Asian equities were mixed, with Australian shares up 0.5% and South Korean stocks retreating. The European PMIs will be a key focus ahead of US regional surveys, according to market strategist Stephen Innes.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on fading US-China worries
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.09% on Tuesday, driven by receding US-China trade concerns, with the Nikkei index closing at 22,098.84 and the Topix index at 1,622.94. The gains were largely due to profit-taking, keeping the market within a narrow range.

site_title: One in 4 New York's new luxury apartments is unsold
summary: A new analysis by StreetEasy reveals that one in four of New York's new luxury apartments, or approximately 4,100 units, remains unsold since 2013. This trend has raised concerns among investors and developers, who fear it may signal a slowing economy or the start of a recession. Several luxury buildings, including One57 and Central Park Tower, have seen significant unsold inventory, with some projects offering discounts, concessions, and rent-to-own options to attract buyers. The slowdown has been uneven, with some projects still selling well, but overall, it poses a challenge for the city's flagging condo market.

site_title: AI engine Athena is a modern-day teacher
summary: Xjera Labs' AI engine Athena can train software to perform specific tasks, such as recognising sushi, teaching drones to fly, or spotting intruders, using neural networks and deep learning algorithms. The AI engine aims to replicate the role of a teacher, with the potential to aid in various industries and tasks.

site_title: Reprieve for small investors as MAS reviews 5% collateral for stock trades
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing a proposed 5% collateral requirement for stock trades, initially planned for 2020, amid concerns it may impact market liquidity and retail investor interest. The move was prompted by the 2013 penny stock crash, which wiped out S$8 billion in market value. Industry players fear the requirement will smother retail interest and hinder market liquidity, while regulators argue it will enhance credit risk management and protect broking houses' financial integrity.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing an earlier plan requiring retail investors to place a 5 per cent collateral on their open positions come 2020.

site_title: Powering social good
summary: Hitachi, a Japanese conglomerate, has redefined its mission as a "social innovation business" to tackle issues faced by society. Vice President Kojin Nakakita, who holds a US university degree, credits his diverse background for bringing unique perspectives to the company. Despite initial setbacks, Nakakita's experience in the US and Canada led to successful innovations, such as Hitachi's explosives trace detection system certified by the US Transportation Security Administration. Today, Hitachi focuses on five key sectors: mobility, smart life, industry, energy, and IT solutions, with a emphasis on conserving basic infrastructure and resources, as Nakakita believes is essential for contributing to society.

site_title: Singapore in world's top 20 for trade growth potential: StanChart study
summary: Singapore ranks 16th globally in trade growth potential, according to Standard Chartered Bank's Trade20 Index. The city-state's economic dynamism, fueled by increasing inward foreign direct investments and digitalization efforts, drives its ranking. The government's expansion of free trade agreements and infrastructure improvements are also cited as key factors. Other South-east Asian markets, including Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand, also placed in the top 20 for trade growth potential, driven by regional deals and liberalizing markets.

site_title: Back to square one? Why are "asset-light" players in the sharing economy buying up property and cars?
summary: Companies in the sharing economy, such as Uber, Airbnb, Grab, Deliveroo, and foodpanda, are shifting towards an asset-heavy model by investing in vehicles and property. Despite their initial asset-light strategies, these companies aim to control supply and manage demand to grow their businesses. Experts argue that this move is necessary to counter the free movement of providers between platforms and to maintain a competitive edge. The companies' investments in central kitchens and vehicles are expected to boost their businesses in underserved areas, with demand for food delivery increasing in Singapore. However, this shift may lead to regulatory challenges and stifle innovation in the shared kitchen facilities sector.

site_title: PM Lee to meet Trump on week-long visit to New York
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will arrive in New York on Saturday for a week-long working visit, meeting US President Donald Trump and delivering Singapore's national statement at the upcoming UN General Assembly. This marks the fourth face-to-face meeting between Lee and Trump since Trump took office. Lee will also host a reception for the Forum of Small States and receive the World Statesman Award. He will then head to Armenia for an official visit from Sept 28 to Oct 1, during which Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will act as Acting Prime Minister.

site_title: 32 director acquisitions filed; Chua Thian Poh raises Ho Bee Land stake
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Over five trading sessions from September 13 to 19, 32 director acquisitions and one disposal were filed, totaling S$1.3 million. Notable acquisitions include Chua Thian Poh raising his stake in Ho Bee Land to 75.0332% and Boustead Singapore chairman Wong Fong Fui acquiring 23,776,203 shares for S$17,475,509. Meanwhile, UOB-Kay Hian Holdings chairman Wee Ee Chao increased his stake in the company to 29.37%. Share buybacks also occurred, with seven primary-listed stocks filing for a total consideration of S$917,058. The Straits Trading Company's substantial shareholder, Tecity Pte Ltd, acquired 14 million shares for S$28,560,000.

site_title: Trump announces new Iran sanctions but says no military strike planned
summary: US President Donald Trump announced new sanctions on Iran, calling them the toughest-ever, targeting the country's central bank and sovereign wealth fund. The sanctions are in response to weekend attacks on Saudi Arabia's oil infrastructure, which triggered a spike in global crude prices. Trump indicated no plans for a military strike, instead emphasizing restraint as a sign of strength. The move aims to push Iran to shun funding terrorism, and the sanctions may be more difficult to lift even if Trump loses the upcoming election.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up after Federal Reserve rate cut, eyes on Bank of Japan
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday following the Federal Reserve's 25-basis-point interest rate cut, but investors remained cautious due to the lack of strong forward guidance. The Bank of Japan's next move is now under focus, with traders weighing concerns over global trade, the slowing economy, and geopolitical risks. Despite the Fed's rate cut, some analysts believe the central bank may have missed an opportunity to signal more rate cuts, and the market will continue to monitor trade discussions and other economic indicators.

site_title: Former Prudential top agency manager received S$15.3m sign-on bonus from Aviva, court told
summary: Former Prudential top agency manager Peter Tan Shou Yi received a S$15.3 million sign-on bonus from Aviva in 2016.
