His company, PTO Management and Consultancy, received an additional S$24 million from Aviva's subsidiary after he quit Prudential. Prudential is suing Tan and his company for allegedly poaching 221 agents and 23 agency leaders to defect to Aviva, seeking up to S$2.5 billion in compensation. Tan denies any liability, claiming he was not bound by a non-solicitation contractual obligation and did not engage in any alleged acts of solicitation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Tiong Seng, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel DC Reit, Wing Tai, Jumbo
summary: Several Singapore stocks saw developments that may impact trading on Tuesday. Tiong Seng Holdings' CEO and executive director Pek Lian Guan and project director Pay Teow Heng are on bail amid a corruption probe. Mapletree Industrial Trust is raising S$350 million through a private placement, while Keppel DC Reit has raised S$478.2 million through a private placement. Wing Tai Holdings acquired a data centre in Australia for S$48.2 million. Jumbo Group opened its second Tsui Wah outlet in Singapore.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Samsonite's sustainable solutions
summary: Samsonite's President, Subrata Dutta, discussed the company's sustainable innovations, Born to Go, on The Soul of Business podcast. Born to Go aims to reduce waste and increase efficiency in the luggage industry. The initiative includes the use of recycled materials, biodegradable products, and a take-back program for old luggage. Samsonite's commitment to green solutions is part of its broader corporate purpose to minimize its environmental footprint and promote a more sustainable future.

site_title: Why aren't there better cancer drugs? Scientists may have picked the wrong targets
summary: Scientists have discovered that many cancer drugs fail to effectively treat cancer due to targeting proteins that are not essential to cancer cell survival. A study found that 97% of proteins targeted by cancer drugs are " expendable" in cancer cells, yet all cells stopped growing when exposed to the drugs. The mistake may be attributed to the use of outdated and unreliable technology, such as RNAi, which can block multiple proteins instead of the intended target. Researchers recommend searching for mutations in cancer cell genes to avoid false positives and targeting essential proteins to develop more effective cancer treatments.

site_title: US singles out Iran, readies response to Saudi oil attacks
summary: The US is prepared to respond to the "unprecedented" attack on Saudi oil facilities, with President Trump attributing the attack to Iran. The attack, which slashed Saudi oil output in half, occurred on Saturday and involved drones and cruise missiles. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani claimed the attack was an act of self-defense, while the US Secretary of Defense Mike Esper singled out Iran as a regional destabilizing force. Russia and China have called for restraint, amid concerns of escalation and impact on global energy supplies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 0.83% on Monday, following last week's gains, amid violent protests and weak Chinese economic data. The Hang Seng Index fell to 27,124.55. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained unchanged, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.23%. Investors were spooked by fresh protests and concerns over the Chinese economy.

site_title: SingPost's struggling US units fail to find suitable buyers, to seek court protection
summary: SingPost's US e-commerce units, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, failed to attract suitable buyers after a six-month sale process, with eight expressions of interest resulting in two non-binding offers deemed unfeasible. The companies filed for voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of the US bankruptcy code, seeking additional liquidity or restructuring options. The move comes after SingPost reported a consolidated loss of around S$6.9 million from the US subsidiaries for the quarter ended June 30, 2019.

site_title: Industry-wide effort to boost leadership and digital skills for biomedical sciences PMETs
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and Chemical Industries Employees' Union (CIEU) have launched a training community for professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) in the biomedical sciences industry. The Biomedical Sciences Training Community aims to boost digital and leadership skills, with a focus on Industry 4.0 technologies. Since its launch in March, around 200 PMETs have participated in training programs, with plans to train another 1,500 by next year. The initiative also includes bite-sized courses on Industry 4.0, digitalisation, and microbiology laboratory safety, available through the NTUC's mobile learning app U Leap.

site_title: Aug new home sales up; mixed results so far for Sept launches
summary: Aug new home sales increased, with mixed results for Sept launches. The US saw a climb in mortgage rates after five weeks of declines. In Singapore, a Q3 condo launch wave will test demand for projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record, with more increases anticipated. Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won worth of Seoul hotel and retail assets. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, according to an index.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz A 200 Saloon review: Beauty saloon
summary: The Mercedes-Benz A 200 Saloon review finds the car to be an attractive option due to its sleek design and advanced features, but it falls short in terms of driving pleasure. The A 200 model's turbocharged engine provides smooth power, but its voice control system is undignified, and the gearbox delivers occasional lurches. The car handles decently but lacks zip in its pace. The A-Class sedan is priced lower than other Mercedes sedans, but alternatives like the Audi A3 Sedan and Skoda Superb offer better value for those willing to stretch their budget.

images.alt_text: As the least expensive and smallest Mercedes sedan around, the A-Class Saloon is an obvious choice and looks to continue that trend, since it certainly has the requisite appearance.

site_title: HK activist Wong seeks Trump, US congress support
summary: Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong urged US President Donald Trump to include a "human rights clause" in any trade agreement with China, seeking Washington's backing for the city's democracy movement. Wong called for American politicians to pass a bill expressing support for the pro-democracy campaign during a speaking engagement in New York. He also expressed concern over Hong Kong's threat of emergency laws and feared China's potential military intervention. Wong's visit comes as millions have taken to Hong Kong's streets in recent months, calling for free and fair elections and an end to China's rule.

site_title: EVs, batteries could draw bulk of GM's US$7b pledge to invest in the US
summary: General Motors Co has pledged US$7 billion to invest in the US as part of contract talks with the United Auto Workers. The majority of the investment is likely to be allocated for electric vehicles and battery cells at two Michigan plants and an Ohio plant. GM plans to produce at least five new electric vehicles in the US by 2023, including a full-size electric pickup truck. The investment will also support updates to existing plants in Michigan, Tennessee, and Missouri, with a focus on mid-size pickups and cross-overs.

site_title: HK Exchange's US$39b bid for LSE faces significant hurdles
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) has made a $39 billion bid for the London Stock Exchange Group (LSE), aiming to create a global trading powerhouse. However, the proposal faces significant hurdles, including political resistance and regulatory scrutiny, as LSE's board remains committed to acquiring data provider Refinitiv. The deal could be seen as a takeover from China, which could be a security concern for the UK government. LSE's shares rose 6.2% after the announcement, but the offer's success is uncertain due to the complex geopolitical landscape.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Dasin Retail Trust, AEM Holdings, Sakae
summary: CDL's final cash offer for Millennium & Copthorne hotels has been declared unconditional, with 58.28% of shares accepted. Dasin Retail Trust completed the acquisition of Doumen Metro Mall in China for S$274.8 million. AEM Holdings revised its expected revenue range to S$285-305 million for FY2019 after receiving S$280 million in sales orders. Sakae Holdings received S$8.1 million in net proceeds after the High Court approved the partial return of capital to its associate company.

site_title: Eurasian Roots
summary: A heritage gallery in Singapore is set to reopen, offering insight into the Eurasian ethnic group, which makes up about 0.4% of the population. The group has a long history in Singapore, with European and Asian ancestries, and has contributed to the country's history, including authors, lawyers, and politicians. The gallery features over 130 artefacts, including a 1912 three-tier cake stand and a telephone used for the first international direct call. The gallery aims to showcase Eurasians as part of Singaporean society, with the chairperson stating that they are "just as Singaporean as anyone else."

site_title: Odds of US recession in 2020 less than 50%: Shiller
summary: Nobel Prize winner Robert Shiller says the odds of a US recession in 2020 are less than 50%, contradicting market volatility and trade-war concerns. Shiller believes narratives and stories can influence the economy, and that fear-driven narratives can cause market volatility. He also predicts that a Democratic presidential candidate, such as Joe Biden, would be more favorable for the stock market than a candidate like Donald Trump. Shiller warns that left-wing ideas, like raising taxes on the wealthy, would harm the market.

site_title: China's property investment growth at 4-month high in August
summary: China's property investment grew 10.5% in the first eight months of the year, the fastest pace in four months, driven by accelerating sales growth. This comes as other sectors weaken due to the Sino-US trade war and slowing consumer demand. However, a surge in demand raises concerns for policymakers about high household debt and potential bubble risk.

site_title: Aramco ready for foreign float alongside primary domestic listing
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's top oil producer, is set to float on international markets alongside a planned domestic initial public offering (IPO) in 2020-2021. CEO Amin Nasser confirmed the company's readiness for the floatation, stating it will be the primary listing on Saudi Arabia's home market. Aramco has been keen to diversify its economy and meet climate challenges, investing in cleaner technologies and reducing its carbon footprint. The IPO is crucial for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plans to diversify the Saudi economy and raise funds for his initiatives.

site_title: Age-related hearing loss has wider ramifications
summary: Age-related hearing loss affects an estimated 5% of the world's population, with 900 million expected to be affected by 2050. This condition is linked to cognitive impairment, dementia, depression, and social isolation in the elderly. Hearing loss can be caused by aging, genetics, medication, trauma, and noise exposure. Assessing hearing loss involves various tests, including pure tone audiograms and speech audiometry. Treatment options include hearing aids and cochlear implants, which can help slow down the progress of dementia and cognitive decline. A focused approach to elderly individuals with hearing loss is essential for promoting health, social well-being, and reducing cognitive decline and dementia.

site_title: Powering lives with renewable solar energy
summary: Third Wave Power, a Singapore-based company, aims to create social impact through its solar-powered products, which provide portable energy solutions to regions with unreliable or no electricity. Founded by CEO Vishnampet Sethuraman Hariharan, the company has sold its products to over 10 states in rural India, with portable lanterns being its best-selling item. To address affordability, Third Wave Power has partnered with micro-financing institutions and introduced a pay-as-you-go system, allowing customers to buy products in instalments. The company plans to venture into Africa, leveraging product differentiation to meet customer needs.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange's LSE bid hit by further setback as China balks
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange's (HKEX) unsolicited takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange Group (LSE) has been rejected, with the LSE citing geopolitical and business concerns. China has praised the rejection, stating that Hong Kong's unrest makes the stock less attractive. The People's Daily article described the bid as a "persistent worry" and praised the LSE for citing its existing tie-up with the Shanghai Stock Exchange as its preferred way to access China. The bid's rejection signals growing resistance to the acquisition, and the Hong Kong exchange is now focusing on its own deal for data provider Refinitiv.

site_title: AT&T chief's drive to create 'modern media company' under threat
summary: AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson's vision to transform the company into a modern media company is under threat after activist investor Elliott Management criticized his blockbuster acquisitions, including the $85 billion purchase of Time Warner. Elliott's $3.2 billion stake in AT&T has raised concerns about the company's debt and stock performance. The firm has suggested AT&T consider divesting assets and separating the CEO and chairman roles, which would be a significant change for the company. Stephenson's future as CEO may hinge on convincing investors that his strategy is the right idea.

site_title: German marques are losing their allure and that's got Germany worried
summary: Germany's car industry, a key contributor to the country's economy, is facing significant challenges. Despite new electric models, the sector is losing its allure, with concerns over pollution, trade woes, and slowing economies. Production has slumped to its lowest level since 2010, with investors fearing the industry's prospects. The Frankfurt car show, a showcase of German automotive excellence, is now a platform for protest, drawing attention to climate change and the need for a transition to cleaner vehicles. The industry must adapt to the risks, with carmakers spending billions on cleaner vehicles and ride-sharing services, or risk going out of business.

site_title: US Reits in Singapore
summary: US Reits listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have gained significant attention, with three US property trusts making their debut in 2019. ARA US Hospitality Trust and Eagle Hospitality Trust listed in May, focusing on hotels, while Prime US Reit listed in July, focusing on office properties across nine cities. This growth is attributed to Singapore's growing reputation as a listing platform for US property trusts, with SGX market strategist Geoff Howie noting that the exchange has been listing US property trusts since 2016.

site_title: Facebook's Libra seeks Swiss payment system licence
summary: Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency project is seeking a Swiss payment system license, which would require broad oversight due to the planned services' breadth. FINMA, the Swiss financial watchdog, has stated that Libra's services would go beyond those of a pure payment system, requiring capital allocation and risk management. The Libra Association is engaging in constructive dialogue with FINMA, seeking clarification on the status of the association and the Libra coin under Swiss supervisory law. The US Under Secretary of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence has emphasized the need for anti-money laundering and terrorism financing standards to be built into the design.

site_title: Hutchison weighs Indonesia mobile combination with Axiata
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong conglomerate, has made a preliminary approach to Axiata Group Bhd about a potential combination of their Indonesian telecommunications operations. The proposed deal would combine Hutchison's Indonesian wireless business with Axiata's local unit, PT XL Axiata. The exact structure of the deal has not been determined, and negotiations have not started yet. This move comes as Axiata has attracted strategic investors and suitors to partner with it, including Japan's Sumitomo Corp and Tokyo-based Mitsui & Co.

site_title: Europe: Equities mainly climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose in opening deals on Friday, with the FTSE 100 index weakening 0.2% to 7,255.83 points, while the CAC 40 index firmed 0.1% to 5,595.92 and the DAX 30 advanced 0.3% to 12,161.66 points. Mining and healthcare sectors drove the gains, with investors brushing off new US trade threats. The rally comes ahead of US-EU trade talks and amid a strong performance in Asia.

site_title: What is heritage worth to you?
summary: Singapore's heritage sites, such as the National Theatre and Bukit Brown Cemetery, are increasingly being threatened by urban development. While preserving heritage sites is crucial, it also comes with significant costs. An exploratory study found that the Botanical Gardens is the most valued site by society, with an average individual willing to donate S$4.10 per year to preserve it. Using monetary values to measure heritage sites' worth can help inform decision-making, but it's essential to consider the limitations and potential biases. Policymakers should weigh the value of heritage preservation against economic development and other policy objectives.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights the tanker and dry bulk market's surge in rates, with the 5TC reaching a 6-year high of $38,014. However, vessel delays caused by docking issues due to upcoming IMO regulations are affecting tonnage flows. The Pacific Basin market experienced a surge early on, while the Panamax market remained relatively steady. Supramax/Ultramax rates remained healthy, with the Atlantic seeing some sideways movement. The Baltic Handysize Index reached a new high, surpassing the last peak in October 2018, with firm rates in the Continent and US Gulf markets.

site_title: Investing FOMO and its real cost
summary: Investing FOMO, or the fear of missing out, can have a significant real cost to staying in cash. According to the Blackrock Investor Pulse Survey, 47% of Singaporeans hold almost half of their savings in cash, but this approach can lead to inflation erosion and a lower overall portfolio return. Warren Buffett notes that cash is a riskier investment than stocks over the long-term, and investing can help achieve long-term goals despite short-term market volatility. Holding more cash means taking on inflation risk, which can result in permanent loss of purchasing power.

site_title: Naspers prepares to list global empire from ads to Tencent
summary: Naspers is set to list its global empire, Prosus NV, a $100 billion company, on September 11. The separation will allow for more international investors and help narrow the gap in valuation between Prosus and its majority Tencent stake. Naspers, which has grown from a local newspaper publisher, will retain 73% ownership of Prosus. The move aims to attract investors and alleviate concerns about Naspers' ability to invest its Tencent returns successfully. CEO Bob van Dijk believes the food industry, particularly investments in companies like Swiggy, holds significant potential for growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Yangzijiang, ESR-Reit, Fragrance Group
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on Thursday, with ST Engineering's aerospace arm injecting US$19.5 million into aircraft leasing, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding securing new order contracts for seven vessels worth US$395 million, ESR-Reit securing a new lease for 168,846 square feet, and Fragrance Group acquiring the Min Yuan Apartments at 62 Waterloo Street for S$141 million.

site_title: Astaka unit receives letters of demand for RM125.3m owed to contractor
summary: Astaka, a Singapore-based property developer, owes RM125.3 million (S$41.3 million) plus interest to a construction firm, China State Construction Engineering, for a project initiated in 2015. The debt was not accounted for in Astaka's financial year ended June 30, 2018, and the company's board was only informed of the letters of demand after releasing its full year results on August 29, 2019. Astaka is currently negotiating with the creditor to extend the loan repayment deadline and has requested a voluntary suspension of trading in its shares.

site_title: Lagarde open to combining euro zone bonds in a common asset
summary: European Central Bank President-designate Christine Lagarde suggests combining euro zone bonds into a single asset to attract investors and strengthen the euro's global role. This move could increase the offer of high-rated securities, rivaling those of the US, and facilitate monetary policy. Plans for a common bond issuance have failed in the past due to concerns over debt-servicing costs, but Lagarde believes it's a mid- to long-term necessary step to enhance the euro's international role.

site_title: Dubai house prices to fall sharply on oversupply and slowdown in economy: poll
summary: Dubai house prices are expected to decline sharply this year and next due to an oversupply of housing units and a slowdown in the economy, according to a Reuters poll. This marks a continuation of the real estate market's weak outlook, which has been affected by a slowdown for most of the decade, except for a brief period. Experts attribute the decline to the oversupply of housing units and economic slowdown, posing a significant risk to the already fragile market.

site_title: Robert Frank, photography titan, dead at 94
summary: Renowned documentary photographer Robert Frank, known for his raw and influential style, has died at 94. Born in Zurich, Switzerland, Frank rose to fame with his book "The Americans," a 1958 publication showcasing unflinching looks at US society. Frank's career spanned post-WWII, during which he worked as a fashion and reporting photographer, before embarking on a series of road trips that yielded 28,000 images, condensed into the iconic book that rewrote photo-journalism rules. Frank's gritty style laid bare emotions and relationships, including racial tensions, in a style that earned praise from fellow writer Jack Kerouac.

images.alt_text: Swiss photographer Robert Frank gives an interview to Swiss Televison in 2012.According to media reports, Robert Frank died aged 94 on 09 Sept 2019.

site_title: Australian regulator appeals against court dismissal of Westpac lending case
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, has appealed a court decision dismissing its accusations that Westpac Banking Corp approved 262,000 home loans without proper credit checks. The court found Westpac followed the law using an automated system to estimate expenses. ASIC argues the decision creates uncertainty about lender obligations under the responsible lending regime and is inconsistent with legislative intention. The regulator had initially started court proceedings against Westpac in 2017.

images.alt_text: Australia's corporate watchdog on Tuesday said it had lodged an appeal against a court decision dismissing its accusations that the nation's second-biggest lender Westpac Banking Corp had approved mortgages without appropriate credit checks.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase bets on six HK property stocks
summary: JPMorgan Chase has identified six Hong Kong property stocks that can withstand a worst-case scenario, including a 30% drop in home prices and a 40% decline in prime office rents. The six companies are CK Asset Holdings, Henderson Land Development, New World Development, Wharf Holdings, Hang Lung Properties, and Link REIT. Analysts cited the impact of the US-China trade war and social unrest in Hong Kong on the city's status as an international financial center. The companies have been diversifying or adapting to the market, with New World expected to see the most substantial increase in rents.

site_title: US Fed must be 'vigilant' to support growth: Fed member
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank chief John Williams expressed readiness to take action to support the American economy, citing mounting risks and uncertainty. Despite a strong labor market, Williams cited weak exports, manufacturing, and inflation, as well as trade wars, as concerns. His remarks come after a more hawkish address from Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren, who suggested a rate cut is unlikely. Investors expect the Fed to cut interest rates at its September 17-18 meeting, with some predicting a 50-basis-point reduction. Williams vowed to remain vigilant and act to support continued growth.

site_title: StanChart keeping option open on Singapore digital bank licence
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has left the door open to applying for a digital banking licence in Singapore, its second-largest market after Hong Kong. The bank, which has a 5% stake in Line Bank, a Taiwanese web-only bank, plans to tap its experience in Hong Kong and Taiwan if it enters the digital banking market. Applications for digital banking licences are now open, with MAS expecting to award the licences in mid-2020. StanChart's decision comes as Singapore banks invest heavily in their digital capabilities to stay ahead of the curve.

site_title: UOB completes purchase of 75% stake in Indonesia's PG Asset Management
summary: UOB Asset Management has completed the acquisition of a 75% stake in Indonesia's PG Asset Management, expanding its presence in the country's $49.4 billion mutual fund industry. The deal will allow UOBAM to offer investment expertise across various asset classes and provide insights into the local market. With the acquisition, UOBAM has grown its regional network to eight markets in Asia, strengthening its presence in South-east Asia. The move is seen as a strategic expansion into Indonesia, driven by the country's economic development and increasing demand for investment solutions.

site_title: Surbana inks 10 MOUs to boost productivity and sustainability
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean urban and infrastructure consultancy, has signed 10 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with industry partners to boost productivity and sustainability in the built environment sector. The partnerships include JTC Corp, Glodon, Signify, Republic Poly, and others, aiming to develop solutions in digitalisation, automation, and sustainability. The agreements also include collaborations on alternative building materials and technologies to lower carbon footprint.

site_title: Samsung's Galaxy Fold will go on sale on Sept 6 in South Korea: source
summary: Samsung's Galaxy Fold will go on sale in South Korea on September 6, after being delayed from its original US launch in April due to screen defects. The phone will cost approximately 2.4 million won (S$2,750) for South Korean buyers. Samsung made changes to the device, including strengthening hinges, after early reviewers found them problematic. The delay is seen as a setback for the company, which had hoped to capitalize on the slow summer season with the launch.

site_title: Old-School Newsman
summary: Gary Liu, CEO of the South China Morning Post, believes the print product will remain relevant despite the digital expansion of the newspaper. Liu, a Taiwanese-American Harvard graduate, enjoys the smell and atmosphere of the print press and has been known to visit the press at midnight. He maintains that the SCMP's journalists are committed to the truth and that the newspaper will continue to evolve to meet reader needs. Liu also defends the newspaper's ownership model, stating that it has allowed the SCMP to experiment with new revenue streams, such as branded content and digital-only lifestyle publications. He believes that the rise of digital news organizations has led to consolidation and a need for traditional newsrooms to adapt to new formats, including audio and video content. Liu sees a future where print and digital coexist, with the print product evolving to provide deeper, more in-depth content.

site_title: Twitter CEO hack highlights dangers of 'SIM swap' fraud
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's account was compromised when attackers hijacked his phone number through "SIM swap" fraud, a type of attack that tricks mobile carriers into transferring a number, potentially causing loss of sensitive information. This vulnerability in two-factor authentication via text message has been used to take over other high-profile social media accounts and for various fraud schemes. Experts say the problem is not over, with thousands of reported attacks in countries with mobile payments, and security systems by mobile operators are weak, leaving customers open to SIM swap attacks.

site_title: To cut or not? Dueling Fed views boost pressure on Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell faces pressure to cut interest rates as two central bankers, James Bullard and Eric Rosengren, have differing views on the need for a rate cut. Bullard wants a half-percentage-point cut to address a global economic slowdown and escalating US-China trade war, while Rosengren sees no immediate need for action given stable inflation and labor markets. The Fed's next policy-setting meeting is set for September 17-18, with financial markets pricing in a 90% chance of a rate cut.

site_title: TEE Int'l investigating unauthorised transactions of over S$6m linked to CEO
summary: Singapore-based engineering group TEE International is investigating unauthorized transactions totaling S$6.55 million made by its subsidiaries to related parties. The transactions, which occurred from July 2018 to May 2019, were allegedly made under the instruction of CEO Phua Chian Kin. The group has appointed an external investigator and repaid the monies, but the nature of the transactions remains unclear. CEO Phua has been removed and interim measures have been taken, with Deloitte raising concerns over the lack of documentation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares declined Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.39% to 25,527.85, amid concerns over China-US trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter up 0.66%. Investors are worried about the lack of a scheduled meeting between the two sides, despite recent positive signals.

site_title: Business software firm Slack's shares plunge after it predicts a larger loss
summary: Slack's shares plummeted 15% after the business software firm reported a larger loss and a 58% rise in revenue in its first earnings report since going public. The company expects a wider loss in the current quarter, citing increased spending related to its direct listing. CEO Stewart Butterfield acknowledged it would take time for the market to understand Slack's software, which creates a new category. Despite a 37% increase in paying customers, Slack's performance echoes that of other once-sizzling startups, raising questions about their ability to become profitable.

site_title: Manhattan Sensation
summary: The Manhattan Transfer, a jazz vocal group, celebrates its 50th anniversary with a concert at the Esplanade in Singapore. The group, which includes Janis Siegel, Alan Paul, Cheryl Bentyne, and Trist Curless, will perform on September 10. Despite the passing of original member Tim Hauser in 2014, the group continues to entertain audiences with its unique arrangements and hits. This marks the group's first performance in Singapore since 2011, where they also wowed the crowd at the Esplanade's Mosaic series.

site_title: Iran admits to launch blast after Trump shares revealing image
summary: Iran has admitted to a blast at a satellite launch site, attributing it to a technical error during a test launch. The explosion occurred at the Imam Khomeini Space Center in Iran's north. US President Donald Trump's tweet about the incident, which included an image of the site, was criticized by an Iranian government official, who accused Trump of "tweeting and posting satellite pictures with excitement." The incident is the latest in a series of failed launches by Iran's space program, which has experienced a 67% failure rate over the past 11 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on fears global economy is slowing
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, September 4, 2019, due to fears that the global economy may be slowing. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.19% or 40.07 points to 20,585.09, while the Topix index fell 0.32% or 4.77 points to 1,506.02. The decline was attributed to weak US manufacturing data.

site_title: Corporate governance in a digital age
summary: Corporate governance is undergoing a transformation in the digital age, driven by the rise of digital technologies and social media. The traditional focus on shareholder value is incomplete, as digital technologies empower all stakeholders and blur industry boundaries. Companies must adapt to a new world with complex, dynamic ecosystems comprising diverse, interacting elements. To engage with stakeholders, companies need to cultivate and maintain active and healthy ecosystems, using digital and social media platforms to gather feedback and encourage open dialogue. Examples of companies embracing this approach include Philips, Microsoft, and others, highlighting the need for digitally savvy corporate governance experts and policymakers to move beyond traditional approaches.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,090.81, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,090.81, up 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by gains in Sembcorp Marine and Sembcorp Industries. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS and UOB down 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. Asian equities were mixed, with Japan's Topix rising 0.6% and Australia's stocks unchanged. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 0.2%, while futures on the S&P 500 Index declined 0.5%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: HK students rally peacefully after weekend violence
summary: Thousands of Hong Kong university and school students boycotted class and rallied peacefully on Monday, the latest acts of defiance in the anti-government movement that has plunged the city into crisis. The protest followed a weekend marred by violence, with protesters burning barricades and throwing petrol bombs, and police retaliating with water cannon, tear gas, and batons. Students are seeking greater democracy for the former British colony, fearing freedoms are being eroded by Communist Party rulers in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Thousands of students gathered on the hilltop campus of Chinese University under leaden skies, taking turns to make speeches.

site_title: Will Boris Johnson's political coup succeed?
summary: Boris Johnson's attempt to suspend Parliament and push for a no-deal Brexit may backfire, as it could prompt a no-confidence motion and lead to his resignation. If Johnson loses, a caretaker prime minister, such as Jeremy Corbyn or Kenneth Clarke, could be appointed to extend the Brexit deadline and call a general election. The EU may be willing to offer Johnson concessions, including removing the "Irish backstop" provision, to avoid a no-deal Brexit, which could harm both the UK and EU. Alternatively, if MPs fail to elect a new prime minister, Parliament will be suspended, allowing Johnson to implement his Brexit plan without opposition.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators carry an effigy of Mr Johnson at a protest against the move to suspend parliament in the final weeks before Brexit outside Downing Street on Aug 31.

site_title: Chinatown conservation shophouse up for sale with S$8.5m indicative price
summary: A three-storey conservation shophouse in Singapore's Chinatown is up for sale with an indicative price of S$8.5 million, equivalent to S$2,660 per square foot. Located on a 1,115 sq ft land area, the property has a 99-year leasehold tenure and is zoned for commercial use. The sale is open to both locals and foreigners, with no additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty imposed. The property is fully tenanted with leases expiring between 2020 and 2022, offering immediate rental income, and potential for value-add through refurbishment or conversion.

images.alt_text: The three-storey conservation shophouse at 18 Sago Street has an estimated gross floor area of 3,196 sq ft, which works out to S$2,660 psf.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank Kim Eng raises 'underappreciated' SIA Engineering to 'buy'
summary: Maybank Kim Eng upgraded its call on SIA Engineering to 'buy' with an unchanged target price of S$2.85, citing the company's "underappreciated" franchise strengths and scale advantages. The analyst believes shares are trading at attractive valuations despite a recent 14% decline. The firm notes that SIAEC's maintenance and repair business has shown resilience in past downturns and remains a leading player in the aviation maintenance market.

site_title: Keppel unit buys 2nd Haidian property in China's 'Silicon Valley'
summary: Keppel Land China acquired Shangdi Neo, a five-storey commercial property in Beijing's Haidian district, for approximately 178.6 million yuan (S$34.6 million). The property, located in China's Silicon Valley, offers 4,241 square meters of net leasable area and will be fully occupied by sole tenant Distrii. The acquisition is part of Keppel Land China's strategy to grow its commercial portfolio in high-growth cities like Beijing, with the company confident of meeting strong demand for quality office space in the area.

images.alt_text: Shangdi Neo offers about 4,241 square metres of net leasable area, and will be fully occupied by sole tenant Distrii, an operator of smart, modern working spaces in China and Singapore.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.2% to 3,076.83
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,076.83 at Tuesday's open, weighed down by trade fears. The US imposed new tariffs on billions of dollars of Chinese goods, prompting Beijing to lodge a complaint with the World Trade Organization. Banking stocks, including DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank, also declined.
